DOC.HEADLINE: Voucher donations high despite weak economy: animal rescue group

TEXT.P: Despite the sluggish economy, the Kaohsiung-based Animal Rescue Team Taiwan has raised NT$312,400 (US$9,200) in consumption vouchers since launching a voucher donation drive at the end of January, a volunteer said Tuesday.

The donation campaign reached its peak in the first two weeks after the government first distributed the vouchers on Jan. 18. Volunteer Chen Tsai-han said the post office box used by the group to receive donated vouchers has been filled to capacity several times.
Most of the donors are families or groups of friends, while some are students, and group volunteers are often moved by the messages donors enclose with the vouchers, Chen said.

"I'm a poor student but hope to contribute the maximum amount of money I can afford, " and "I have read stories online about your canine rescue effort. It is so good to have you around, " were just two examples cited by Chen.
One donor who attached a photo of his mother with a dog wrote he was making the donation on behalf of his mother because she died not long after receiving her vouchers, Chen recalled.

Since the group set up its Web site in 2004 to report animal rescue stories and promote animal protection concepts, it has received increased financial support from numerous sponsors but also sparked the jealousy of other similar groups, Chen said.

Those groups frequently reported the Animal Rescue Team to the city, county and central government and even accused Joseph Nee, founder and leader of the animal rescue team, of fraud, nearly leading him to quit the volunteer job, Chen said.
After registering with the Ministry of the Interior and being recognized as a legal animal protection group in 2007, however, the team has operated without any disruptions, she added.

The team spends an average of NT$8 million a year on rescuing and rehabilitating abused and injured stray animals and promoting awareness on protecting animals. The vouchers received this year will also be spent on those functions, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vice president touts Taiwan's sourcing market

TEXT.P: Vice President Vincent Siew touted Taiwan as a potential source of goods Tuesday, saying the country provides a wide range of high-quality industrial products at a reasonable price that offer considerable value to overseas buyers.
Siew was speaking at the opening ceremony of Sourcing Taiwan 2009, organized by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA).

Siew described Taiwan's accession to the World Trade Organization's Government Procurement Agreement last December as symbolizing the country's determination to open its market to the world, and he called on overseas buyers to help Taiwan boost its exports by opting for its quality products.

Under the principle of a liberal and open market, Taiwan looks forward to forging a partnership with overseas buyers that not only is mutually beneficial but also lasts forever, the vice president said.

Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming said the Sourcing Taiwan show was part of the government'sNew Zheng Heproject, launched to combat declining exports by tapping into emerging markets, and he encouraged foreign buyers to foster strong and lasting cooperation with Taiwanese suppliers.
To promote export growth at the show, the MOEA and 10 overseas enterprises signed a letter of intent to confirm the companies intentions to import or expand purchases from Taiwan.
According to TAITRA, some 548 companies from over 63 countries registered to attend Sourcing Taiwan 2009, which is being held until April 2.
The trade body estimates that the more than 10,000 discussions between 2,200 Taiwanese suppliers and 735 overseas buyers will generate an estimated NT$120 billion (US$3.5 billion) in business.

Many of the foreign buyers are major players in global trade, including French sporting goods retailer Oxylane, India's largest light engineering company Amalgamations Group, German automobile parts supplier ZF Lemfoerder GMBH, and U.S.-based Tyco Electronics, one of the worlds largest providers of engineered electronic components.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Walk-to-school' campaign seen bearing fruit

TEXT.P: A government-initiated campaign that urges young people to maintain a "dynamic lifestyle" and keep active has seen some measure of success in its efforts to encourage students to walk to and from school, according to Ministry of Education (MOE) statistics.
The MOE launched the campaign in 2005, then expanded it last year to 44 junior high schools and elementary schools around Taiwan.

According to MOE statistics, among the 48,000 students who have joined the "walking to school" campaign, the percentage of junior high school students who walk to school every day has risen since last November from 27.08 percent to 30.76 percent, while the percentage of elementary school students has increased from 33.27 percent to 45.73 percent.

Taipei Municipal Xinglong Elementary School is at the forefront of the effort, with some 86.5 percent of its 1,000 students walking to school regularly, according to the principal Cheng Chou-kuei Monday.
Cheng said that the campaign has also led to weight loss among some teachers and students. Some teachers have dropped the habit of driving to school and now commute by bicycle or bus, she added.

According to a report released by the MOE on the physical fitness of the more than 2 million students in elementary and high schools in the 2007 academic year, only 65.36 percent attained the lower limits of physical fitness standards.
The walk-to-school campaign was introduced in the hope that students will develop the habit of exercising regularly, said Wang Chun-chuan, director of the MOE Department of Physical Education.
Apart from that, the MOE has also directed the schools to come up with various other methods of encouraging students to exercise, Wang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Evergreen head denies shipping unit may withdraw from Kaohsiung
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, March 31 (CNA) 03/31/09 16:26:10 (By Charles Kang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Evergreen Group founder Chang Yung-fa denied Tuesday a Taiwanese report that his group's container shipping unit would pull out of Kaohsiung Port in southern Taiwan to save money at a time when cargo volumes are plummeting.

"How could it be possible that Evergreen withdraws its operations from the fifth container wharf of Kaohsiung Port, given that Kaohsiung is an irreplaceable operating base in southern Taiwan, ? " Chang said in Singapore, where he arrived Monday for a five-day visit.

A Taiwan TV station reported recently that Evergreen might halt operations at Kaohsiung Port and instead launch services at a container wharf at Taipei Port in northern Taipei County jointly run by Evergreen, Wan Hai Lines Ltd. and Yang Ming Marine Transport Corp.
Pulling out of Kaohsiung would help Evergreen save as much as NT$3 billion (NT$88.2 million) a year in rental fees, the report claimed.

Chang is currently in Singapore to inspect Evergreen's operations and promote his "Morals Monthly Digest" -- a magazine he launched in January 2008 and distributed for free in a bid to restore traditional ethnic and moral values.

Chang also announced the opening of Evergreen Marine (Singapore) Pte Ltd. and revealed his plan to have 13 ships presently flying the Panamanian flag to move to Singapore and raise the Singaporean flag. One vessel already began flying Singapore's flag earlier this month.
In the future, Evergreen's Singapore-based fleet would be increased to some 50 vessels, he added.
Evergreen originally pulled out of Singapore in 2002 because of what it saw as excessively high port fees and moved its fleet to nearby Malaysia.
The company decided to head back to the city state last December, however, to take advantage of Singapore's Approved International Shipping Enterprise scheme.
Under the program, international shippers that establish their operations in Singapore get 10-year tax holidays on qualifying shipping income.

DOC.HEADLINE: Northern Taiwan should remain on guard against dengue: CDC

TEXT.P: Residents in northern Taiwan should not let down their guard against dengue fever, although the nation's first case of indigenous dengue fever this year was confirmed in the southern county of Kaohsiung, the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) said Tuesday.

The CDC issued the warning in light of the fact that indigenous dengue fever cases were recorded last year in Taipei city and county, Keelung city and Taoyuan county, which it said indicates that a dengue outbreak could occur not just in the south of the island, but also in the northern regions.

The first case this year was a 55-year-old farmer from Daliao, Kaohsiung County who worked on a pineapple farm in the southernmost county of Pingtung. On March 22, he showed typical symptoms of the disease, including fever, joint soreness and pains, and a skin rash, according to the CDC.
The case was reported March 27 when the man was hospitalized, the CDC said.
Subsequent blood tests ruled out the possibility that his family members were also infected, it added.
As of March 30 this year, Taiwan had recorded a total of 41 dengue fever cases -- one indigenous case and 40 imported cases, according to statistics released by the CDC.

As outbreaks of dengue fever in neighboring countries have increased this year, the number of imported cases has risen significantly to 40, compared with 23 recorded during the same period of last year, the CDC said.
Of the imported cases, 23 were from Indonesia, 13 from Vietnam, two from Thailand, and one each from Myanmar and India, the statistics showed.
The CDC urged people to clean up their communities and empty water in indoor and outdoor containers at least once a week as these could serve as breeding grounds for dengue carrying mosquitoes.
Mosquitoes also breed in drains, discarded tires, plant pots, uncovered buckets, and canopies, the CDC warned.

The center also urged that people seek immediate medical treatment if they develop early symptoms of dengue fever, such as fever, headache, nausea, fatigue, pain behind the eyes, and muscle and joint pains.

People who think that they may have been infected should have a screening test and if they are confirmed as dengue cases, they would be given an NT$2,500 reward for reporting the disease, in accordance with a reward clause in the Communicable Disease Control Act, the CDC added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT, cancer foundation to launch nutrition program for children

TEXT.P: The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Agricultural Trade Office and the non- governmental Formosa Cancer Foundation (FCF) will jointly launch the 2009 "Vegetable and Fruit Rainbow 5-7-9 Campaign" Thursday to promote better nutrition among Taiwan's children, the AIT said Tuesday.

AIT Director Stephen M. Young and Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng will attend a press conference that day to encourage elementary school children in Taiwan to eat more fresh fruits and vegetables in order to stay healthy, the AIT said in a press release.

The campaign "highlights the importance of daily servings of fruit and vegetables for overall health and cancer prevention, with five servings for children, seven for adult women, and nine for adult men," the AIT said.

This year's program will feature nutrition checkbooks for children, which will include homework reminders such as "today, I will eat two different colored vegetables, " and "today before I leave for school, I will remind my family about the '5-7-9' program," according to the AIT.
In addition, the checkbooks contain coupons for discounts on selected fruits and vegetables, which may be redeemed at 200 participating Wellcome stores throughout the island, it added.
Children and their parents will have access to an interactive Web site featuring ongoing surveys regarding the consumption of fruits and vegetables among youth in Taiwan.
Prizes, including two tickets to the United States and a trip to the State of Montana, are up for grabs in a lucky draw sponsored by the AIT and the FCF.
The program, originally known as "5-a-day," was designed by the FCF in 2007 to promote nutrition by increasing consumption of fresh fruits and vegetables.
The AIT's Agricultural Trade Office in Taipei and the Washington Apple Commission have provided funding support for the program ever since it was first launched.
In its first year, the program's in-school nutrition seminars reached over 78,000 students and their families, and by the following year, the number had grown to 120,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices up slightly on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed marginally higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, advancing 4.79 points, or 0.09 percent, to close at 5,210.84.

Recovering from a 3.42 percent fall the day before, the local bourse opened at 5,214.96 and fluctuated between 5,286.45 and 5,194.93. A total of 5.03 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$94.24 billion (US$2.78 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues advancing the most at 3.8 percent. Textile stocks rose 1.9 percent, foodstuff issues gained 1.6 percent, and construction stocks as well as banking and financial shares moved up 1.2 percent.
Cement stocks remained unchanged.
The two other major stock categories lost ground, with plastics and chemicals shares dropping 0.9 percent, and machinery and electronics stocks shedding 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,039 to 891, with 141 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$1.26 billion.
The Taiwan stock market has gained 18 percent since the beginning of March.
Although the market will face some technical resistance, the bullish trend will continue and the benchmark TAIEX index will stay above 5,000 points in the short term, according to analysts.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, falling NT$0.098 to close at NT$33.917.
A total of US$733 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$34.115 and reached a low of 33.904.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hong Kong to host 2nd Taiwan night market festival
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, March 31 (CNA) 03/31/09 17:58:29 (By Mandy Wang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan night market festival is slated to be held for the second time at Hong Kong's East Point City from April 23-26, with snack and dishes from 16 famous Taiwanese eateries to be on display.
The festival will be jointly organized by the Taiwan Visitors Association, Sun Hung Kai Properties and Hong Kong & Macau Taiwanese Association to promote Taiwan's tourism.
Taiwanese pop diva, Jolin Tsai, will act as a spokeswoman for the event and will perform at the festival, along with aboriginal and traditional artist groups.
Wang Chun-pao, director of the Taiwan Visitors Association's Hong Kong office, said the festival is one of the important projects in Taiwan's tourism promotion efforts this year.
The first Taiwan night market festival in Hong Kong was held last year in a bid to lure more Hong Kongers to Taiwan.

Apart from Taiwanese snacks, which are always the No. 1 attraction for Hong Kong visitors, Taiwan fruit, tea, liquor, and fish will also be on display at the night market festival. In addition, the exhibition will include popular tourist travel-theme packages, such as cycling and massage tours.

Late last year, a blockbuster Taiwanese movie -- Cape N0. 7 -- featuring Kenting in Taiwan's southernmost Pingtung County, drew large audiences in Hong Kong, which helped to attract more Hong Kong visitors to Kenting.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei zoo breeds Formosan wild boars to preserve pure strain

TEXT.P: The Taipei Zoo has recently delivered a Formosan wild boar, the first of the animal endemic to Taiwan bred under a preservation program the zoo has been working on in cooperation with National Taiwan University to keep the pure strain of the boar.

Zoo Director Jason Yeh announced Tuesday that the male boar, born on Feb. 21, is named "Tai An" because the breeders hope it will grow in a healthy and safe way, reflecting the meaning of the Chinese name.

It is also hoped that Tai An will be able to help reproduce its kind, Yeh said, adding that it has become increasingly unusual to spot pure-blood Formosan wild boars on Taiwan's mountainous areas where the animals once dominated.
Some hog breeders living in the mountains have let their stock run around without fencing them, raising the chance of mating between the domestic and wild animals, Yeh explained.

Citing research findings, Yeh said there has been a big amount of hybrid wild boars spotted on mountains in recent years whose physical characters, such as fur color and the shape of ears, are seen to be different from those of pure Formosan wild boars.

Although the wild animal is not categorized as endangered species in Taiwan, the zoo still decided to launch efforts to preserve the strain, which lives in groups in the hills and mountain areas around the island, Yeh added.
The Taipei Zoo has a pair of pure-blood Formosan wild boars, and Tai An is their first offspring born under the zoo's preservation program, according to the zoo.

DOC.HEADLINE: Workers on parental leave to receive subsidies for up to 6 months

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed an amendment to the Employment Insurance Act Tuesday to introduce a subsidy for workers on unpaid parental leave to take care of children under three years old.

All workers who have joined the insurance program for at least one year when they take parental leave are eligible for a monthly subsidy equal to 60 percent of their salary for up to six months, the amendment stipulated.

In the event that two working parents rotate to take parental leave to take care of the same child, both parents are eligible for the subsidy, meaning the total subsidy received can reach up to 12 months, according to the amendment.
The Gender Equality in Employment Law of 2002 allows either of the parents to take unpaid parental leave for up to two years until their children reach three years old.

However, not many workers have taken the leave, either because most workers could not afford to lose their salaries or because they are worried their positions would be filled permanently by replacements.

Data from the Council of Labor Affairs show that only 3 percent of the more than 100,000 women covered by the Labor Insurance system who gave birth from 2005 to 2007 took parental leave during these three years.
During the three years, 1,939 insured women took leave in 2005, 2,721 took leave in 2006, and 3,206 took leave in 2007.
Introducing the parental subsidy was one of President Ma Ying-jeou's campaign promises.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's electricity retail prices among world's lowest: Taipower

TEXT.P: Taiwan has managed to maintain its retail electricity prices at low levels despite drastic fluctuations in global fuel prices, according to a report released Tuesday by the state-run Taiwan Power Company (Taipower).

The report showed that the average retail price of electricity supplied to industrial consumers in Taiwan stood at NT$1.8331 per kilowatt-hour (kwh) in 2007, which was the third lowest among 26 countries selected by the company for comparison.

The price was higher only than Norway's NT$1.5052 per kwh and France's NT$1.7560 per kwh, but significantly lower than neighboring South Korea's NT$2.1637 per kwh, Indonesia's NT$2.1678 per kwh, Malaysia NT$2.2201 per kwh, Singapore's NT$3.5121 per kwh, and Japan's NT$6.2404 per kwh, the report stated

In terms of the average residential retail electricity price, the rate in Taiwan was NT$2.5855 per kwh in 2007, also the third lowest, behind Indonesia's NT$1.9901 per kwh and Malaysia's NT$2.3019 per kwh, according to the report
The rate compared closely to South Korea's NT$3.1985 per kwh, Singapore's NT$4.4842 per kwh and Japan's NT$5.7067 per kwh.
Meanwhile, the average revenue per kwh of electricity sold by Taipower -- calculated by dividing total annual revenue by total annual retail sales -- amounted to NT$2.1484 in 2007, the report showed.
The figure was lower than Indonesia's NT$2.1878, Malaysia's NT$2.4351, South Korea's NT$2.8849, Thailand's 2.8972, the Philippines' NT$5.6177 and Japan's NT$5.7711.
The data was obtained from the International Energy Agency, the U.S. Energy Information Administration and Malaysia's largest electricity utility company Tenaga Nasional Berhad, Taipower said.
The average revenue per kwh of electricity sold by Taipower in 2008 was NT$2.3010. Data for other countries was not immediately available for comparison, the company said.
The report said that in 2008, Taipower produced a record 39.26 billion kwh of electricity through nuclear power, with the average cost per kwh amounting to just NT$0.62.

According to Taipower, besides being a cost efficient form of energy, nuclear power is also known to be environmentally friendly because no carbon dioxide is released in the production of electricity.
The use of the 39.26 billion kwh of nuclear-generated electricity in Taiwan was equal to cutting carbon dioxide emissions by 25 million metric tons, the company said.

Meanwhile, the company's efforts to promote an automatic generation control system and governor-free operation also helped enhance power quality, with the average duration of power interruption per household dropping significantly from 165.4 minutes in 1992 to 20.81 minutes in 2008, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign minister leaves for El Salvador to strengthen ties

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou left for El Salvador Tuesday to cement bilateral relations following the March 15 election of a new president in the Central American ally, according to an announcement from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).
"The trip is to congratulate newly elected President Mauricio Funes, as well as to express gratitude to the outgoing government for its long-term support of Taiwan, said MOFA spokesman Henry Chen.
In a meeting scheduled for later in the week with Funes, Ou will reaffirm Taiwan's commitments on various bilateral cooperation projects, he added.
In addition to Funes and other Salvadoran government officials, Ou will also meet with Taiwanese expatriates in El Salvador before returning April 7, Chen said.

Agence France-Presse recently reported that Funes, who led the leftist Farabundo Marti Liberaction Nacional to power in a historic election two weeks ago, has said he is mulling establishing diplomatic links with China after he assumes the presidency June 1.
His comment instilled fear that Taiwan will lose the Central American ally, one of the country's just 23 formal allies.
The Foreign Ministry, however, has repeatedly expressed confidence that relations between Taiwan and El Salvador will remain unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Russian rescue team will be invited to 921 anniversary event

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday that it will invite a Russian rescue team, which participated in the disaster relief work after the Sept. 21, 1999 earthquake in Taiwan, to attend a series of events in Taiwan to mark the 10th anniversary of the disaster.

"The Foreign Ministry has instructed its representative office in Russia to invite the team, which provided enormous support to Taiwan after the Sept. 21 earthquake," said Antonio C.S. Chen, secretary-general of MOFA's Department of West Asian Affairs, at a regular press briefing.

He added that the team will join other international rescue missions in a series of events to be held by the Cabinet-level National Disaster Prevention and Protection Commission Sept. 17-22 to commemorate the 10th anniversary of the earthquake.

When Taiwan's Nantou County was hit by the magnitude 7.3 earthquake in 1999, Russian radio and television stations provided extensive coverage of the disaster, and the Russian government immediately sent a rescue team to help in the international relief effort.

However, the Russian rescue mission was delayed and made headlines when the Russian press reported on Sept. 23 that China had refused to open an air corridor for the plane carrying the 50 members of the rescue team. This meant that the plane had to make two extra stops for refueling and the arrival of the team in Taiwan was delayed by 12 hours.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health authorities working on draft national nutrition act

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) has decided to draft a national nutrition act in an effort to promote healthy diets and the nation's health, a DOH official said Tuesday.

The proposed act comes in the wake of a 2005-2008 national nutrition and health study revealing that 11.7 percent of male adults had diabetes during the period, approximately triple the 3.7 percent between 1993 and 1996, according to the official.
The study also shows that more than 50 percent of all male adults and more than 30 percent of all adult females were overweight.
In addition, more than 25 percent of men and over 20 percent of women suffered from metabolic problems linked to pre-chronic disease, the results show.

If people continue their dietary habits of eating food with high fat, high sugar and high calories but low fiber, the number of chronic patients and young people with chronic diseases is expected to increase, which could create a heavy financial burden on the national health insurance system, the official said.

The draft act is being drawn up taking into consideration the World Health Organization's Global Strategy on Diet, Physical Activity and Health, as well as related laws in the United States, Canada and Japan, according to DOH official Hsieh Tien-hung.

The act aims to regulate the implementation of monitoring activities, nutritional research studies, the establishment of nutrition standards and a database of the nutritional values of various food, as well as the promotion of nutrition education.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislature ratifies two human rights covenants

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan finally ratified two United Nations human rights treaties Tuesday that had been shelved since the Republic of China lost its U.N. membership in 1971.

The treaties are the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights that were introduced by the United Nations in 1966 and came into force in 1976.
The ratification finalized the legal procedure for implementing world-recognized human rights protection in Taiwan.

While endorsing the treaties, the legislature also passed an act on the enforcement of the two covenants, providing that government rules and regulations must conform with the U.N. rules in terms of human rights protection.
Those that fail to conform will have to be amended or abolished within two years of the covenants entering into force in Taiwan, according to the Legislative Yuan.

President Ma Ying-jeou had expressed his wish for the Legislative Yuan to ratify the treaties before the first anniversary of his May 20 inauguration in order that they can be put into force on Dec. 10, International Human Rights Day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung City opens food bank

TEXT.P: A food bank run by the Department of Social Affairs under the Taichung city government was inaugurated Tuesday, with assistance from over 80 charitable organizations based in the central Taiwan city and the first distribution of aid materials set for May.
Department director Chang Kuo-hui presided over the opening of the "Dadun Love Food Bank" located in retail premises offered by a sympathetic citizen to the department free of charge.

The bank has already received a large amount of monetary and material donations from private individuals or groups prior to the start of its first distribution of food or aid materials to people in need at five spots around the city in May, Chang said.
The food bank serves as a warehouse and management center in which items donated by people from all walks of life to the city government to help the impoverished can be stored.
Chang said he was really touched to see so many packs of food and so much money flooding into the bank shortly after it opened earlier that same day.
"The kindness of the Taiwanese people has not been hit by the economic crisis," he said.

Contributions to the food bank included NT$1 million (US$29,400) from the private Wenying Foundation and NT$125,000 worth of food for 500 people from former Taichung Mayor Lin Poh-jung, who is now an adviser to President Ma Ying- jeou.
Among other items were 1,200 packs of rice worth some NT$100,000 donated by a businessman surnamed as Tsai, who paid for the rice with money he would originally have spent on his 50th birthday party.

Apart from its first distribution in May, which will give out rice and other cereal, as well as canned food and noodles, to people in need, city government officials said the bank is projected to conduct two another rounds of distribution in August and November.
The food bank will target jobless people, single parents and people hit hard by disaster in its initial stages, city government officials said.

In mid-February, the city government teamed up with a mobile food bank run by the non-profit Hsingshih Foundation to distribute food packages to low-income families and homeless people at a local activity center.

It was the first time the city and the foundation had teamed up to make use of the mobile food bank service. Some 380 food packages were distributed to members of 100 underprivileged households and 120 cooked meals were handed out to homeless people.
"The city government learned something very valuable from the aid operation in February, despite playing only a support role, " a city government official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH to reduce window for measles vaccinations

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) will suggest to parents that they reduce the 3-month window for getting their children vaccinated in the wake of a recent unusually high number of measles cases, a DOH official said Tuesday.
"Doing this will help parents remember to get their children vaccinated, " according to Chou Jih-haw, deputy director of the DOH's Centers for Disease Control.
Chou noted that there were five imported measles cases reported between late last year and early this year.

Among them, two were children who had traveled to Vietnam with their mothers and two who had visited China, who infected 22 others upon their return, mostly children with whom they shared hospital wards, members of their families or neighbors.
The remaining case was also from Vietnam, but the child did not infect anyone else. Three indigenous measles cases were also reported during the period.

Chou noted that the inoculation rate for measles -- a highly infectious disease -- is as high as 95 percent in Taiwan. In the last decade, except for a series of cluster infections of 2002, the number of imported and indigenous cases has not exceeded 10 on average per year.

He noted that experts usually suggest that children should be vaccinated at between 12 months and 15 months, but the DOH said quite a number of parents forget to get shots for their children until the last minute.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japan lifts ban on Taiwanese poultry imports

TEXT.P: The Japanese government lifted a ban Tuesday on imports of live domestic fowl and poultry products from Taiwan, according to a statement released by the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine following an announcement of the measure by the Japanese authorities.
The move means that Taiwanese poultry products can be exported to Japan as long as they meet that country's quarantine rules, the statement noted.

According to the bureau, Japan suspended imports of domestic poultry, eggs and related products last Dec. 17 after a chicken farm in Kaohsiung County, southern Taiwan, reported an outbreak of low pathogenicity avian influenza.
The authorities took immediate action to control the outbreak, including killing and incinerating the affected chickens and quarantining 76 other chicken farms near the affected one.

After three months of efforts to eradicate the disease, the bureau recently confirmed that the virus was no longer present, the statement said, leading to Japan's re-opening of its doors to local poultry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chiang Kai-shek to be `put in perspective' in memorial hall

TEXT.P: A group of experts huddled Tuesday to thrash out how to reorganize the exhibits at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in Taipei to give a better impression of the widely divergent views people have of the late president and to put his legacy into perspective.

At the request of the Ministry of Education (MOE) , which administers the memorial hall dedicated to the commemoration of Chiang, the experts were asked to come up with ideas of how best to present the various aspects of the former leader.

Chu Nan-hsien, chief of the Social Education Department under the MOE who chaired Tuesday's meeting, said the experts suggested setting up a panel comprising historians from Academia Sinica and Academia Historica, as well as memorial hall officials, to work out a set of proposals.

Elaborating on the MOE's idea of presenting a wider variety of aspects of Chiang, Chu said the existing exhibition, which features the late leader's military and political careers, fail to show his achievements in education and culture, such as his decision to extend the country's compulsory education from six years to nine years.

Asked whether the new exhibition is intended to shed new light on the late president's possible political responsibility for the 228 Incident and the ensuing iron-fisted rule of the island under martial law, Chu said that "this will be discussed. What we are trying to do is to show the leader in his true image."

The 228 Incident refers to a Taiwanese uprising against the Kuomintang (KMT) government in 1947 in which thousands of people were killed in a brutal crackdown by Chiang's troops that was followed by a government-launched witch- hunt to weed out political dissents.
Thousands more, many of them Taiwan's intelligentsia elite, perished or disappeared during that period, known as the White Terror.
These events see Chiang now regarded as a controversial leader, and although many consider him a national savior, some have branded him a dictator responsible for decades of authoritarian rule.

The controversy came to a head in 2007 when then-President Chen Shui-bian renamed the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall, despite an outcry from the KMT -- at that time in the opposition.
President Ma Ying-jeou, who was elected 2008, reinstated the name of the memorial hall but acceded that Chiang bears some responsibility for the 228 Incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Wednesday, moving up 60.99 points at 5,271.83 on a turnover of NT$2.7 billion (US$79.6 million).
The weighted price index gained 4.79 points, or 0.09 percent, to close at 5,210.84 Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was lower against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Wednesday.
The greenback was trading at NT$33.810 at 9:30 a.m. on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.107 from Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chiang Kai-shek to be `put in perspective' in memorial hall

TEXT.P: A group of experts huddled Tuesday to thrash out how to reorganize the exhibits at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in Taipei to give a better impression of the widely divergent views people have of the late president and to put his legacy into perspective.

At the request of the Ministry of Education (MOE) , which administers the memorial hall dedicated to the commemoration of Chiang, the experts were asked to come up with ideas of how best to present the various aspects of the former leader.

Chu Nan-hsien, chief of the Social Education Department under the MOE who chaired Tuesday's meeting, said the experts suggested setting up a panel comprising historians from Academia Sinica and Academia Historica, as well as memorial hall officials, to work out a set of proposals.

Elaborating on the MOE's idea of presenting a wider variety of aspects of Chiang, Chu said the existing exhibition, which features the late leader's military and political careers, fail to show his achievements in education and culture, such as his decision to extend the country's compulsory education from six years to nine years.

Asked whether the new exhibition is intended to shed new light on the late president's possible political responsibility for the 228 Incident and the ensuing iron-fisted rule of the island under martial law, Chu said that "this will be discussed. What we are trying to do is to show the leader in his true image."

The 228 Incident refers to a Taiwanese uprising against the Kuomintang (KMT) government in 1947 in which thousands of people were killed in a brutal crackdown by Chiang's troops that was followed by a government-launched witch- hunt to weed out political dissents.
Thousands more, many of them Taiwan's intelligentsia elite, perished or disappeared during that period, known as the White Terror.
These events see Chiang now regarded as a controversial leader, and although many consider him a national savior, some have branded him a dictator responsible for decades of authoritarian rule.

The controversy came to a head in 2007 when then-President Chen Shui-bian renamed the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall, despite an outcry from the KMT -- at that time in the opposition.
President Ma Ying-jeou, who was elected 2008, reinstated the name of the memorial hall but acceded that Chiang bears some responsibility for the 228 Incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 1, or the sixth day of the third month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. The following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1572: The Dutch War for Independence from Spain begins.
1578: William Harvey, British physician and anatomist who discovered the circulation of blood, is born.
1815: Prince Otto Eduard Leopold von Bismarck, Prussian statesman and first chancellor of the German Empire, is born.
1908: Japan puts into practice a six-year compulsory primary education system.
1924: Adolf Hitler is sentenced by a court to five years in jail for high treason. He was released on Dec. 20.
1924: The Republic of China's Central News Agency is established in Canton by the ruling Kuomintang.
1930: Yen Hsi-shan, Feng Yu-hsiang and Li Tsung-jen revolt against the ROC National Government.
1938: The Emergency National Congress of the Kuomintang in Wuchang elects Chiang Kai-shek as its director-general and decides to organize a People's Political Council and a "Three Principles of the People" Youth Corps.
1940: The Nationalist government issues a circular to all levels of the nation's governments to call Dr. Sun Yat-sen the "National Father of the Republic of China."
1945: U.S. forces invade the Japanese island of Okinawa.
1959: The Dalai Lama arrives in India from Tibet.
1960: The United State launches Tiros I, its first weather satellite.
1965: King Hussein of Jordan appoints Prince Hassan, his younger brother, as his heir.
1968: Ma Ssu-tsung, former president of mainland China's "National Music Academy," and his wife arrive in Taipei from the United States.
1975: Cambodian President Lon Nol flees to Indonesia as Khmer Rouge guerrillas close in on Phnom Penh.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan visits the Taiwan Machinery Show at the grounds of the China External Trade Development Council.
1984: Chang Gung Memorial Hospital completes the first human pancreas transplant in Asia.
1986: The new Value Added Tax (VAT) system is inaugurated in Taiwan.
1989: Namibia gains independence from South Africa.
1992: President George Bush pledges that the United States will help finance the 24-billion dollar international aid fund for the former Soviet Union.
1995: President Lee Teng-hui starts a four-day visit to the United Arab Emirates and Jordan.
1996: Britain proposes slaughtering 15,000 of its cattle every week for the next six years in order to fight mad cow disease.
1996: Japan's Mitsubishi Bank and Tokyo Bank merge to become one of the world's largest banks, Tokyo-Mitsubishi Bank.
1998: Israel accepts a United Nations resolution calling for its withdrawal from south Lebanon.
2000: Acting Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan says that he expects the party will rise again by winning the elections for legislators and county magistrates in two years and by regaining the presidency in 2004.
2001: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou presents a "Key to Taipei" to Tibetan spiritual leader Dalai Lama, saying that "the city always welcomes you and is always opened to you."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man is easy to serve, but difficult to please. If you go beyond your duty to please him, he will not be pleased. But in his employment of men, he always takes into consideration their capacity. A fool, on the other hand, is easy to please, but difficult to serve. If you go beyond your duty to please him, he will be pleased. But in his employment of men, he expects them to be able to do everything."

DOC.HEADLINE: China, Cuba panned for crackdowns on Internet freedom

TEXT.P: The U.S.-based nongovernmental organization Freedom House warned Wednesday that the rights of Internet and mobile phone users are increasingly at risk as governments, both repressive and democratic, expand their ability to monitor and control online activity.

In a press release forwarded to local press through the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy, the group identified wide disparities in Internet freedom among 15 countries it surveyed and raised concern over trends such as theoutsourcing of censorship" to private companies and authoritarian governments' use of undercover agents to manipulate online conversations.
Cuba received the lowest score for Internet freedom while China and Cuba were found to be the countries imposing the most restrictions on the use of the Internet.

More than a billion people look to the Internet and mobile phones to provide a new freedom frontier where they can exercise their right to freedom of expression without repercussion, Freedom House executive director Jennifer Windsor said in the press release.
As access grows, more governments are employing diverse and sophisticated methods to monitor, censor and punish Internet users, she added.

According to Freedom House, the pilot study is aimed at better understanding emerging threats to Internet freedom by evaluating the 15 countries surveyed based on barriers to access, limitations on content and violations of usersrights.

The countries surveyed were distributed across six regions: China, India, and Malaysia in Asia; Cuba and Brazil in Latin America, Egypt, Tunisia, and Iran in the Middle East and North Africa; Kenya and South Africa in sub-Saharan Africa; Russia, Estonia, and Georgia in the former Soviet Union; and the United Kingdom and Turkey in Europe.

Findings from the study, which covers events from 2007-2008, will be formally released later Wednesday local time to a conference of more than a thousand bloggers in Berlin, Germany, Freedom House said, adding that it hopes to expand the study to examine all countries of the world.

Of the 15 countries surveyed, Cuba received the lowest score because of the Castro regime's near total control over Internet access, while Estonia topped the study as the country with the most Internet freedom.

China, Iran and Tunisia were ranked "Not Free, " but the vast majority of the countries studied received aPartly Freeranking, including Egypt, Georgia, India, Kenya, Malaysia, Russia and Turkey. Brazil, South Africa and the United Kingdom were rankedFree.

The study said that while China is home to 300 million Internet users, the most of any country in the world, its rulers employ the world's most sophisticated, multi-layered, and wide-ranging apparatus for repressing Internet freedom.
China was tied with Cuba as the country with the most curbs on users' rights, including prosecutions for online activities, surveillance and extra-legal harassment of bloggers.

Freedom House is heartened by the fact that citizens, even in highly-repressive countries like China, Cuba and Iran, are pushing back with creativity and courage against these growing government controls over the Internet,Windsor said in the press release.
Democratic countries should not only support such voices, but also set an example of best practice with their own digital media polices,she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Guppies released into flooded basement for mosquito control

TEXT.P: Public health authorities released 100,000 guppies into a notoriously flooded basement in a Kaohsiung building Tuesday, their latest attempt to control the mosquito population through biological methods and prevent a dengue fever outbreak.

The basement, measuring over 3,000 square meters, is located in a building that has been left uninhabited for more than 20 years in the southern city's Jhengren borough, near the border with Kaohsiung County.
The first indigenous dengue fever case this year was recently reported in the southern county.
The pool of water accumulated inside the building, which has become a haven for mosquitos, has long been a headache for public health authorities.
A property ownership dispute has delayed the building's demolition, and the large number of waste materials piled inside make draining the water impossible.
Residents living in the neighborhood launched a large-scale campaign three years ago to try to clean up the place, but the problem remains.

According to officials from the city's health department, the most effective way to control and prevent dengue fever outbreaks is to root out the infestation of mosquitos, and achieving the goal through biological methods that take advantage of the natural food chain is safer and more enduring and environmentally friendly than other methods.
Pesticide spraying, which is usually adopted as an emergency measure, can build resistance to the drug among mosquitos if used excessively, the officials said.

To promote biological methods to control mosquito infestation, the health department has identified more than 130 locations in the city with long-term water collection problems where it will release small fish such as mosquitofish and guppies into the stagnant pools of water to consume mosquito larvae, they said.
Dengue is transmitted by the bites of mosquitoes infected with the dengue virus.
Symptoms include fever, abdominal pain, vomiting and bleeding. The disease is potentially deadly, and early diagnosis increases the survival of patients.
Statistics from the Centers for Disease Control show that a total of 41 dengue fever cases have been reported in Taiwan from the start of this year until March 30.
All of these cases were imported except for one involving a pineapple farmer in Daliao township, Kaohsiung County, which was confirmed last week as an indigenous case.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japan's Elpida confirmed as partner of Taiwan Memory Co.

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Yiin Chii-ming confirmed Wednesday that Japanese chipmaker Elpida Memory Inc. will join soon-to-be-established DRAM company Taiwan Memory Co. (TMC) as a major strategic cooperation partner.
"Cooperation between TMC and Elpida will be deep and wide, " Yiin said during a break at a Legislative Yuan hearing.
Yiin added, however, that Elpida's involvement does not preclude the participation of another global DRAM giant, United States-based Micron Co.

He characterized the possibility of Micron joining the venture as highly promising, but said the timing would depend on how soon Micron completes negotiations with its existing partners, including Nanya Technology Corporation.
Taiwan Memory Co. is being set up by the government to revitalize the local dynamic random access memory (DRAM) industry and consolidate selected technology providers and domestic memory chip makers.

Taiwan's five publicly listed DRAM companies posted a combined net loss of NT$94.76 billion (US$2.8 billion) in the first nine months of 2008, and the government believed consolidation offered the best chance to the big five to survive with the economic slump and depressed DRAM demand extending into 2009.

John Hsuan, honorary vice chairman of United Microelectronics Corp. who is overseeing TMC's launch, said progress made in negotiations over the past month on the content and terms of cooperation has been smooth.

Hsuan stressed TMC's determination to have successful negotiations with Elpida and Micron, both of which have been key technology providers for Taiwan's DRAM manufacturers and are now expressing a keen interest in participating in the new venture.
Hsuan said Wednesday that TMC's operating plan is expected to be crafted by mid- April and that the company will be established within the first half of 2009.
The government, in principle, will not invest more than NT$30 billion (US$887.57 million) in the new venture, and the hope is that the private sector will inject an equally large sum, Hsuan said.
TMC will sign formal letters of intent on strategic partnerships with Elpida and Micron after the company is formally established and start-up funds received, Hsuan added.

When Yiin projected the new company's role March 5, he suggested it would develop its own core technologies to boost the local DRAM sector's competitiveness and said it would also set up a research and development center, develop a capacity consolidation platform and centralize sales functions.
He also indicated that TMC would first form a strategic alliance with a foreign partner before further negotiating the consolidation of Taiwan's existing DRAM manufacturers.

Hsuan on Wednesday emphasized the new venture's initial focus on upgrading technologies in conjunction with its foreign partners. He said the company will initially hire 400 employees in the area of manufacturing process development and another 400 in product design.

"There could be two manufacturing teams -- one from Elpida and one from Micron -- operating simultaneously in the company in order to avoid misgivings about possible infringement of their respective intellectual property rights," Hsuan suggested.

Wednesday's confirmation of the TMC-Elpida tie-up was seen as a positive step forward in consolidating the local DRAM chip industry, which has long taken a back seat technologically to South Korea's DRAM sector.

According to Taiwan-based DRAMeXchange Technology Inc., Asia's biggest online market for memory chips, local makers held a 23.2 percent share of the global market in terms of revenue in the fourth quarter of 2008.
South Korea led the industry worldwide as Samsung Electronics Co. controlled 24.5 percent and Hynix Semiconductor Inc. 20.4 percent of the global market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislature will be notified if financial supervision MOU is signed

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan will be notified if a memorandum of understanding (MOU) on cooperation in financial supervision is signed by Taiwan and China, a financial official confirmed Wednesday.

Speaking at a meeting of the legislature's Finance Committee, Financial Supervisory Commission Chairman Sean Chen said such a cross-strait financial supervision agreement would be considered as a treaty under international law, and the legislature would therefore have to be notified of the deal.

Opposition Democratic Progressive Party legislator Huang Wei-cher questioned, however, whether submitting an MOU for the legislature's reference was sufficient, given the sensitive nature of Taiwan's ties with China.

Huang suggested that any MOU on financial cooperation signed with China be submitted for legislative review, which would require the lawmaking body to vote on the measure, rather than simple notification, which would not require any further legislative action.
Chen insisted, however, that under existing international law, the legislature would only have to be notified of such a deal.

The MOU, expected to be signed in May, is likely to cover cooperation in supervising cross-strait banking, securities, futures and insurance services as well as the establishment of a currency settlement mechanism.
Two other agreements are also expected to be signed during a third meeting between the top negotiators of the two countries, according to political sources.
One will cover cooperation in fighting cross-strait criminal activities, while the other will deal with the launch of regularly scheduled flight services between Taiwan and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to recruit overseas volunteer workers

TEXT.P: Jobless young men and women might consider reappraising their career plans in the present difficult economic climate thanks to the government-funded International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) , which will recruit 90 volunteers this year to serve in Taiwan's diplomatic allies.
The ICDF is slated to recruit volunteers for a variety of positions, ranging from nurses to Chinese-language teachers, as well as professionals in fields such as fishing farming.

Other needed specialists include gynecologists, urologists, pharmacists and nurses to serve in Gambia, while Chinese-language and physical education teachers, as well as a band conductor, are needed in the Marshall Islands, ICDF officials said.
In northern Thailand, mathematics, geography and history teachers are in high demand, while plant pathologists and aquaculture specialists are sought for positions in Panama.

Candidates eligible to serve these posts in nations that maintain diplomatic links with Taiwan or that are friendly to Taiwan will be provided with a basic monthly stipend of between US$400 and US$700 for a two-year period, with boarding in the host country and two-way flights included, ICDF officials said.
Over the past 14 years, the ICDF has dispatched 400 volunteer workers to serve in Taiwan's diplomatic partners.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei launches major renewal project

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government launched a "Beautify Taipei" plan Wednesday, a large- scale urban renewal project aimed at revamping the landscape and skyline of Taiwan's capital and stimulating private investment and commercial opportunities.

Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said at a news conference that the project will encourage the public and private sectors to work together to give Taipei City a facelift by creating more public spaces, landmark buildings, artistic installations, and green areas.
Taipei is a vibrant and convenient city. But in terms of its landscape, the city is known for its lack of special characteristics compared to other international cities,Hau said.

I believe the project will change the urban look of Taipei substantially and upgrade the city to one that can keep up with international standards, he said of the initiative, which consists of eight plans and three major integrated proposals.

Hau said the urban renewal project comes at a crucial time for the city, which is looking to raise its international profile when it hosts the 2009 Summer Deaflympics in September and the Taipei Int'l Expo in 2010.

The mayor pledged that the city government will offer its full support for the urban renewal project by streamlining administrative procedures and providing a range of incentives such as allowing higher "floor area ratios" -- the amount of a building's floor area relative to the land area it sits on -- to encourage the private sector to participate.

The mayor estimated that the project, to emphasize city competitiveness, local industries and sustainable development, will generate an estimated NT$600 billion (US$17.7 billion) in business opportunities, more than 10,000 jobs, and 31 hectares of open space and green land.

Ding Yu-chyurn, head of the city government's Department of Urban Development, said at the news conference that the city only plans to invest NT$130 million in the project, but hopes to leverage that amount through incentives attracting private sector investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices on Taipei bourse surge

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices surged Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, advancing 103.61 points, or 1.98 percent, to close at 5,314.45.

Buoyed by Wall Street's rise overnight, the local bourse opened higher at 5,271.83 and stayed above that for the rest of the session, peaking at 5,341.31. A total of 5.23 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$102.08 billion (US$3.02 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 5.9 percent. Paper and pulp issues rose 5.3 percent, cement stocks advanced 4.2 percent, banking and financial shares were up 3.4 percent, textile stocks gained 2.8 percent, plastics and chemicals shares rose 2.5 percent, foodstuff issues advanced 2.2 percent, and machinery and electronics shares were up 1.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,721 to 325, with 82 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$5.91 billion.

Analysts attributed much of the day's gains to the rise in DRAM related shares after Ministry of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming confirmed Wednesday that Japan's Elpida Memory has agreed to become a strategic technical cooperation partner of the soon-to-be-established Taiwan Memory Company.
Shares in Inotera Memories and Nanya Technology Corporation both rose by the maximum 7 percent.

Banking and financial stocks received a boost on growing indications that a memorandum of understanding (MOU) will be signed with China in the first half of this year on cross-strait financial supervision and the creation of a currency settlement mechanism.

DOC.HEADLINE: NPM Jade cabbage reproduction souvenirs made in China: lawmaker

TEXT.P: It turns out that reproductions of the National Palace Museum's famous Jadeite Cabbage with Insects, which are sold as souvenirs, were made in China, a legislator of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) said Wednesday.

Speaking at a meeting at the legislative Transportation Committee, KMT Legislator Chiang Lien-fu said it is ironic and pathetic that after Chinese tourists went on a binge at the National Palace Museum to shop exclusively for reproductions of the popular cabbage piece, they ended up with souvenirs that were made in China.

Chiang said the National Palace Museum's procurement policy was irresponsible, and asked whether it was because the reproductions could not be made in Taiwan or because it costs more to buy from local makers.
Chiang contended that souvenirs on sale at tourism venues in Taiwan should be fine products of high quality.
Also commenting on the issue, KMT Legislator Chu Feng-chih said it is shameful that products sold at Taiwan's flagship museum are made in China.
"Why should the NPM be so mercenary? " Chu asked. She suggested that all souvenirs procured by public offices and agencies for public distribution should be made in Taiwan.

Responding to the lawmakers' criticisms, Oliver Yu, deputy minister of transportation and communications, agreed that the practice does a disservice to the nation's international image and said he will have relevant officials look into the matter.

Janice Lai, director-general of the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, accepted the legislators' criticism, saying that officials of her bureau have also found China-made woodcarvings on sale in shops in Sanyi, Miaoli County -- a major tourism venue for the sale of Taiwan's signature woodcraft.

DOC.HEADLINE: Levels of financial well-being low among women: survey

TEXT.P: The levels of financial well-being are low among women, most of whom spend less than 30 minutes per week managing their personal finances, according to the results of a survey released Wednesday by Citibank Taiwan.
The results show that the financial well-being index among local women averaged only 45.9 on a 100-point scale in 2008.
The lowest level was seen among women in the 18-29 age group, at 43.3, followed by those in the 30-39 age group, at 45.6.
Those aged 40 and older were slightly better, at 47.7.
The survey was conducted online Oct. 15-20, 2008 among 200 women aged 18 and older who held a bank account or credit card. It had a margin of error of 7.1 percentage points.
The annual income of the respondents averaged NT$386,000 (US$11,386) among the 18-29 age group, NT$454,000 among the 30-39 age group and NT$704,000 among those aged 40 and older.
The survey found that on average, the respondents spent 36 minutes per week managing their personal finances, with 62 percent of the respondents spending less than 30 minutes per week.
On average, 30 minutes per week were spent by those in the 18-29 age group and 38 minutes per week by those aged 30 and older.
In the event of unemployment, the savings of the respondents could support them for an average of 10.2 weeks.
The results show that as the global financial crisis continued, many respondents were feeling insecure about their jobs and were pessimistic about the economic outlook.

Approximately 35 percent of respondents put aside up to 10 percent of their monthly income in the form of savings, while 27 percent put aside over 30 percent. Only 9 percent of the respondents said they did not save money.
Asked to define the meaning of financial independence, many mentioned "being able to buy things one desires at any time" and "no need to worry about life after retirement."

However, many of the respondents said gender inequality remains in the workplace, pointing out that female workers are generally paid less than their male counterparts even if they hold the same position.

DOC.HEADLINE: CSBC orders pile up till 2012

TEXT.P: Officials of Taiwan's leading shipbuilder, CSBC Corp., said Wednesday that despite a contract failure with Israeli shipping company ZIM, CSBC's order books are full until 2012.
"More than 50 vessels are awaiting construction, in addition to ship repair demands from the navy that need to be taken care of in time, " said CSBC Vice President Wang Ko-hsuan.

Confirming ZIM's cancellation of an order it had placed with CSBC for six 1,700 TEU (twenty-foot-equivalent) container ships, Wang said the cancellation has had no adverse impact on the company's operations.
Wang disclosed that according to the contract, ZIM will pay about 10 percent of the order -- worth roughly NT$8 billion (US$236.69 million) -- in compensation for the cancellation.
CSBC has enjoyed the most successful turnaround among all of Taiwan's state- owned companies, with a pre-tax income of NT$2.5 billion in 2007, surpassing its budget target by NT$31 million.
CSBC's container ship orders and total container volume rank fourth in the world.
The company also unveiled a plan last December to expand its ship repair services to meet a possible rise in repair demand following the opening of direct shipping links with China Dec. 15, 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, falling NT$0.082 to close at NT$33.835.
A total of US$846 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$33.977 and reached a low of 33.751.

DOC.HEADLINE: TMC aims to meet initial goals within two years: chairman

TEXT.P: The government-planned DRAM company, Taiwan Memory Co. (TMC), will in the initial stages focus on product design and optimizing the manufacturing process, so as to build Taiwan's independent proficiency in developing DRAM production technologies, said John Hsuan, the appointed chairman of the company, Wednesday.

The company will take advantage of Taiwan's dynamic random access memory (DRAM) productivity to develop design expertise, Hsuan said at a press conference in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, adding that the aim is to achieve these goals within two years after the company's establishment.
He noted that the profile of TMC is a company with unique expertise, dedicated to product design and the development of the DRAM manufacturing process.

Its top priority will be to find the best way to take advantage of the country's productivity in the DRAM industry, he said. TMC's operations will not conflict with the interests of local DRAM makers, but will serve as a platform for local businesses to forge cooperative links, he added.

TMC will offer funds and resources in the areas of technology research and development to affiliated companies, and will authorize or contract local DRAM factories to carry out production, packing and testing, Hsuan said.

Hsuan, honorary vice chairman of United Microelectronics Corp., was assigned by the Ministry of Economic Affairs in early March to execute the establishment of the DRAM company planned by the government to revitalize the local DRAM industry.

At the press conference Wednesday, he outlined the principles by which the company will be guided. It will not compete in the area of production, will not engage in price battles, sell sub-standard products, interfere in the market order, or dump its products, he promised.
Commenting on the outlook for the DRAM industry, Hsuan said its recovery will not be as swift as Frank Huang, chairman of the Hsinchu-based Powerchip Semiconductor Corp., forecast.
Huang predicted a few days ago that the sector will clear all its stocks and that demand will outstrip supply in the third quarter of the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan expects 1 millionth visitor of 2009 this week

TEXT.P: Taiwan is expected to receive its 1 millionth visitor for 2009 this week, with the total visitor arrivals for the year likely to reach 4 million, Tourism Bureau officials said Wednesday.
The officials predicted that the 1 millionth visitor will arrive April 3 -- two days earlier compared with last year, when the 1 millionth visitor arrived April 5.
They attributed this year's faster rate of visitor arrivals to the increasing number of Chinese tourists visiting the country.

The situation is especially encouraging, since the global economic downturn has hit the tourism industry hard, boosting Taiwan's confidence of achieving its goal of receiving 4 million visitors for the whole year, the officials said.
Bureau statistics show that visitor arrivals totaled nearly 3.85 million in 2008, up 3.47 percent from the previous year.
Of these arrivals, approximately 1.78 million, or 46.17 percent, were for pleasure, while 881,431, or 22.92 percent, were for business.
The largest number of visitors from a single country -- nearly 1.09 million -- came from Japan, followed by Hong Kong and Macau, totaling 618,667.
Visitors from the United States totaled 387,197, while those from China totaled 329,204.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT invites HK chief executive to visit Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 1 (CNA) 04/01/09 19:27:45 (By Mandy Wong and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A vice chairman of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) invited Hong Kong Chief Executive Donald Yam-kuen Tsang Wednesday to visit Taiwan.

Eric Liluan Chu, who is also magistrate of northern Taiwan's Taoyuan County, along with six other county officials, arrived in the former British colony earlier that day for a brief visit aimed at promoting an aerotropolis development project in the county built around the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport.
An aerotropolis is a new type of urban conurbation comprising aviation-intensive businesses and related enterprises extending up to 25 km outward from major airports.
Chu expressed hope that Hong Kong investors will invest in the aviation city project and that there will be closer cooperation between the Taiwanese airport and the Hong Kong International Airport.
Citing Chu's remarks, Chang Chi-chiang, a county government secretary, said Chu hopes bilateral government exchanges in the fields of trade, culture and education will also be boosted.
Tsang for his part said that Taiwan and Hong Kong can work together to promote airport cooperation in many ways.
The head of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region government noted that he visited Taiwan in 1977 and expressed hope that he will be able to go there again during his current tenure.
He also invited Taoyuan County to co-host a Taiwan-Hong Kong city exchange forum next year.
Chu and his delegation later left Hong Kong for Singapore to continue their efforts to attract foreign investment in the aerotropolis project.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung City to raise chicken with kitchen food scrap

TEXT.P: The Taichung city government in central Taiwan will sell a kind of high-end chicken raised with organic feed made from kitchen scraps on a trial basis from May, a city official said Wednesday.

Lee Li-teh, head of the city's Environmental Protection Department, gave his assurances that this pedigree of chicken will not contain any residue of antibiotics or growth hormones and he encouraged the public to consume them.
The chickens will be marketed and sold on the Internet next month after two years of experiments with a local farm.
Each chicken will be sold for NT$450 9(US$12.9) during the promotional sales period in which a maximum of 50 chickens can be sold per month, he noted.
Lee made the comments at a news conference with the Taichung City Farmers Association Chief Chen Ching-chih to promote the new strain of free range chickens.
The kitchen scrap will be provided by the city's Environmental Protection Department.

According to Lee, this new pedigree of chickens must be reared for over six months so as to have them develop tasty meat. Usually, ordinary chickens would be raised at the farm for only four to five weeks before they are slaughtered and sold in the market.
The Taichung city government launched the chicken-raising project to take better advantage of readily available kitchen scrap.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yunlin winery to be promoted as tourist attraction

TEXT.P: Yunlin County in south-central Taiwan is aiming to boost its tourism by opening its local winery to public tours with effect from Friday, officials of the central Taiwan office under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Wednesday.

Fu Lu Shou Winery in Gukeng township, which established Taiwan's first wine museum in October 2007, will mark its 10th founding anniversary on April 3 by allowing visitors to observe its wine-making process.

The museum, which has fully preserved the country's traditional wine-making process and equipment, is optimistic about attracting more tourists. It also hopes that by integrating traditional culture and modern technology, it will draw more business opportunities.
The winery obtained an MOEA license last November to operate as a tourism facility in Yunlin County, as did two other enterprises -- a soy sauce company and a towel factory.
Visitors to the winery will be able to gain a firsthand understanding of the wine-making process and to sample a wide variety of liquors and wines from all over the world.
According to the MOEA, the trend of promoting factories and workshops as tourist attractions has been gaining popularity steadily since last year, despite the economic downturn.

This type of business drew more than 110,000 visitors across the country the last year and recorded revenue of more than NT$400 million (US$11.5 million) for the year, according to statistics compiled by the MOEA's central Taiwan office.
The office forecast that the number of visitors to Gukeng township will increase by 30 percent when the winery becomes part of the county's tourism expansion efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: President praises 'Taiwan Heroes' series

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou paid tribute Wednesday to the individuals featured in the Central News Agency's "Taiwan Heroes" series of reports, saying they are models of the society who embody the country's core value of integrity and its spirit of entrepreneurship.
It is this spirit that will enable Taiwan to overcome adversity and to regain prosperity, Ma said at a ceremony to celebrate the CNA's 85th founding anniversary, at its Taipei headquarters.
The CNA launched the "Taiwan Heroes" series on March 8, releasing one story a day that featured local civilians who, through willpower and perseverance, have overcome adversity and risen to success.

The president praised the reporting, saying all the stories in the series have touched his heart because the uncelebrated heroes have not only accomplished the impossible, but have also remained humble and diligent.
These laudable qualities can serve as social model for the country, he added.

The anniversary celebrations were also attended by Lai Feng-wei, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office; Minister without Portfolio Ovid Tzeng; and Chen Charng-ven, president of the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China.
Fifteen of the people featured in the "Taiwan Heroes" series were also at the function, which was hosted by CNA Chairman Huang Chao-sung.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to invest heavily in revitalization of baseball

TEXT.P: The Sports Affairs Council (SAC) will inject NT$1.26 billion (US$37.28 million) into various projects over the next four years to revitalize baseball in Taiwan, Executive Yuan spokesman Su Jun-pin said Wednesday.
Su made the announcement after a special meeting chaired by Premier Liu Chao- shiuan and at which SAC Minister Tai Hsia-ling gave a briefing on the Cabinet- level SAC's baseball revitalization plan.

According to Su, the top goals of the SAC's four-year plan include having Taiwan's national baseball team enter the finals of Asian and world baseball championships and capture at least a silver medal and compete in the semi-finals of every World Baseball Classic tournament.
To realize these goals, the SAC will spend NT$1.26 billion over the next four years on various baseball development projects.

Baseball has been known as Taiwan's national ball game because of its popularity among local people. The urgency to resurrect the sport was highlighted by Taiwan's disastrous performance in the just-concluded World Baseball Classic 2009, in which Taiwan was first crushed by South Korea 9-0 and then embarrassingly eliminated from the tournament by China 4-1.

Projects to be carried out under the four-year revival plan will include helping Taiwan's top-tier professional baseball league -- the Chinese Professional Baseball League -- to form a second-tier professional league and subsidizing any organization or corporation that intends to establish adult amateur baseball teams.
The revival plan also calls for the development of a comprehensive mechanism for the formation and training of national baseball teams at various levels.
The SAC has worked out operational guidelines for the formation of more adult teams, with the goal of establishing 10 amateur teams this year, SAC sources said.
According to the sources, the council on Tuesday invited representatives of city and county governments and companies that intend to start amateur teams to discuss the technical details.

The meeting was attended by representatives from Taipei City, Taipei County, Taoyuan County, Taichung City, Kaohsiung City and Taitung County governments as well as from Taiwan Tobacco and Liquor Co., Chunghwa Telecom, Taiwan Power Co., China Steel Corp., and Taiwan Cooperative Bank, the sources said.
In order to organize high-caliber national teams, the SAC will divide international competitions into three tiers, with the Olympic Games, Asian Games and World Baseball Classic at the top.
The Chinese Taipei Baseball Association will also be responsible for organizing an ad hoc committee to deal with the formation and training of national teams for various international tournaments.

Under the four-year plan, the SAC will sponsor a baseball revival conference every year, invite world-famous coaches to help with the training of national teams, and organize a winter baseball league tournament in which Japanese and South Korean professional baseball teams will be invited to compete.
Moreover, the SAC plans to build a baseball village to facilitate personnel training and sports development.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local government elections spur DPP factional infighting

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) decided Wednesday to nominate DPP Legislator Lee Chun-yi to run for Tainan County magistrate in December, but a veteran DPP member vowed that he will also join the race.

Tan Sun Chen, whose last post under the former DPP government was secretary- general of the Presidential Office, claimed that he had become a victim of factional fighting within the DPP. He vowed that he will go the distance in the election in defiance of factional dominance within the party.
Chen, 74, has served in a series of high-level postions in his political career, including as Tainan County magistrate and minister of foreign affairs.

He expressed confidence that he would emerge as the front runner among all the DPP candidates in the Tainan County magistrate election, and suggested that the party leadership should have chosen the nominee by means of an opinion poll that would have gauged who had the strongest support among the DPP members and voters.
Chen disclosed that DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen had met with him a day earlier in an attempt to persuade him to withdraw from the race but that he flatly refused.

Asked by reporters whether that means he will run in the election even if the party resorts to disciplinary measures against him, Chen did not give a direct answer, but said that he will leave that kind of issue to the DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. official visits Taipei to discuss bilateral trade issues

TEXT.P: U.S. Deputy Assistant Trade Representative Eric Altbach is currently on a visit in Taipei to discuss certain bilateral trade issues, a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) official said Wednesday.

Altbach, who arrived in Taipei Monday, is concerned with what the U.S. calls bilateral trade barriers, such as Taiwan's restrictions on U.S. beef imports and its zero-residue requirements for the feed additive ractopamine, the official said.
At present, Taiwan only allows imports of U.S. boneless beef from cattle younger than 30 months.

In addition to explaining Taiwan's stances on those issues to Altbach, the official said, the ministry will also convey to him Taiwan's hope that the long- stalled sub-Cabinet-level talks under the bilateral Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) can resume as soon as possible.
According to the official, Taiwan's plan to negotiate an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China may also be mentioned in the talks with Altbach.
