DOC.HEADLINE: Government to recruit overseas volunteer workers

TEXT.P: Jobless young men and women might consider reappraising their career plans in the present difficult economic climate thanks to the government-funded International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) , which will recruit 90 volunteers this year to serve in Taiwan's diplomatic allies.
The ICDF is slated to recruit volunteers for a variety of positions, ranging from nurses to Chinese-language teachers, as well as professionals in fields such as fishing farming.

Other needed specialists include gynecologists, urologists, pharmacists and nurses to serve in Gambia, while Chinese-language and physical education teachers, as well as a band conductor, are needed in the Marshall Islands, ICDF officials said.
In northern Thailand, mathematics, geography and history teachers are in high demand, while plant pathologists and aquaculture specialists are sought for positions in Panama.

Candidates eligible to serve these posts in nations that maintain diplomatic links with Taiwan or that are friendly to Taiwan will be provided with a basic monthly stipend of between US$400 and US$700 for a two-year period, with boarding in the host country and two-way flights included, ICDF officials said.
Over the past 14 years, the ICDF has dispatched 400 volunteer workers to serve in Taiwan's diplomatic partners.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei launches major renewal project

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government launched a "Beautify Taipei" plan Wednesday, a large- scale urban renewal project aimed at revamping the landscape and skyline of Taiwan's capital and stimulating private investment and commercial opportunities.

Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said at a news conference that the project will encourage the public and private sectors to work together to give Taipei City a facelift by creating more public spaces, landmark buildings, artistic installations, and green areas.
Taipei is a vibrant and convenient city. But in terms of its landscape, the city is known for its lack of special characteristics compared to other international cities,Hau said.

I believe the project will change the urban look of Taipei substantially and upgrade the city to one that can keep up with international standards, he said of the initiative, which consists of eight plans and three major integrated proposals.

Hau said the urban renewal project comes at a crucial time for the city, which is looking to raise its international profile when it hosts the 2009 Summer Deaflympics in September and the Taipei Int'l Expo in 2010.

The mayor pledged that the city government will offer its full support for the urban renewal project by streamlining administrative procedures and providing a range of incentives such as allowing higher "floor area ratios" -- the amount of a building's floor area relative to the land area it sits on -- to encourage the private sector to participate.

The mayor estimated that the project, to emphasize city competitiveness, local industries and sustainable development, will generate an estimated NT$600 billion (US$17.7 billion) in business opportunities, more than 10,000 jobs, and 31 hectares of open space and green land.

Ding Yu-chyurn, head of the city government's Department of Urban Development, said at the news conference that the city only plans to invest NT$130 million in the project, but hopes to leverage that amount through incentives attracting private sector investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices on Taipei bourse surge

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices surged Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, advancing 103.61 points, or 1.98 percent, to close at 5,314.45.

Buoyed by Wall Street's rise overnight, the local bourse opened higher at 5,271.83 and stayed above that for the rest of the session, peaking at 5,341.31. A total of 5.23 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$102.08 billion (US$3.02 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 5.9 percent. Paper and pulp issues rose 5.3 percent, cement stocks advanced 4.2 percent, banking and financial shares were up 3.4 percent, textile stocks gained 2.8 percent, plastics and chemicals shares rose 2.5 percent, foodstuff issues advanced 2.2 percent, and machinery and electronics shares were up 1.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,721 to 325, with 82 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$5.91 billion.

Analysts attributed much of the day's gains to the rise in DRAM related shares after Ministry of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming confirmed Wednesday that Japan's Elpida Memory has agreed to become a strategic technical cooperation partner of the soon-to-be-established Taiwan Memory Company.
Shares in Inotera Memories and Nanya Technology Corporation both rose by the maximum 7 percent.

Banking and financial stocks received a boost on growing indications that a memorandum of understanding (MOU) will be signed with China in the first half of this year on cross-strait financial supervision and the creation of a currency settlement mechanism.

DOC.HEADLINE: NPM Jade cabbage reproduction souvenirs made in China: lawmaker

TEXT.P: It turns out that reproductions of the National Palace Museum's famous Jadeite Cabbage with Insects, which are sold as souvenirs, were made in China, a legislator of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) said Wednesday.

Speaking at a meeting at the legislative Transportation Committee, KMT Legislator Chiang Lien-fu said it is ironic and pathetic that after Chinese tourists went on a binge at the National Palace Museum to shop exclusively for reproductions of the popular cabbage piece, they ended up with souvenirs that were made in China.

Chiang said the National Palace Museum's procurement policy was irresponsible, and asked whether it was because the reproductions could not be made in Taiwan or because it costs more to buy from local makers.
Chiang contended that souvenirs on sale at tourism venues in Taiwan should be fine products of high quality.
Also commenting on the issue, KMT Legislator Chu Feng-chih said it is shameful that products sold at Taiwan's flagship museum are made in China.
"Why should the NPM be so mercenary? " Chu asked. She suggested that all souvenirs procured by public offices and agencies for public distribution should be made in Taiwan.

Responding to the lawmakers' criticisms, Oliver Yu, deputy minister of transportation and communications, agreed that the practice does a disservice to the nation's international image and said he will have relevant officials look into the matter.

Janice Lai, director-general of the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, accepted the legislators' criticism, saying that officials of her bureau have also found China-made woodcarvings on sale in shops in Sanyi, Miaoli County -- a major tourism venue for the sale of Taiwan's signature woodcraft.

DOC.HEADLINE: Levels of financial well-being low among women: survey

TEXT.P: The levels of financial well-being are low among women, most of whom spend less than 30 minutes per week managing their personal finances, according to the results of a survey released Wednesday by Citibank Taiwan.
The results show that the financial well-being index among local women averaged only 45.9 on a 100-point scale in 2008.
The lowest level was seen among women in the 18-29 age group, at 43.3, followed by those in the 30-39 age group, at 45.6.
Those aged 40 and older were slightly better, at 47.7.
The survey was conducted online Oct. 15-20, 2008 among 200 women aged 18 and older who held a bank account or credit card. It had a margin of error of 7.1 percentage points.
The annual income of the respondents averaged NT$386,000 (US$11,386) among the 18-29 age group, NT$454,000 among the 30-39 age group and NT$704,000 among those aged 40 and older.
The survey found that on average, the respondents spent 36 minutes per week managing their personal finances, with 62 percent of the respondents spending less than 30 minutes per week.
On average, 30 minutes per week were spent by those in the 18-29 age group and 38 minutes per week by those aged 30 and older.
In the event of unemployment, the savings of the respondents could support them for an average of 10.2 weeks.
The results show that as the global financial crisis continued, many respondents were feeling insecure about their jobs and were pessimistic about the economic outlook.

Approximately 35 percent of respondents put aside up to 10 percent of their monthly income in the form of savings, while 27 percent put aside over 30 percent. Only 9 percent of the respondents said they did not save money.
Asked to define the meaning of financial independence, many mentioned "being able to buy things one desires at any time" and "no need to worry about life after retirement."

However, many of the respondents said gender inequality remains in the workplace, pointing out that female workers are generally paid less than their male counterparts even if they hold the same position.

DOC.HEADLINE: CSBC orders pile up till 2012

TEXT.P: Officials of Taiwan's leading shipbuilder, CSBC Corp., said Wednesday that despite a contract failure with Israeli shipping company ZIM, CSBC's order books are full until 2012.
"More than 50 vessels are awaiting construction, in addition to ship repair demands from the navy that need to be taken care of in time, " said CSBC Vice President Wang Ko-hsuan.

Confirming ZIM's cancellation of an order it had placed with CSBC for six 1,700 TEU (twenty-foot-equivalent) container ships, Wang said the cancellation has had no adverse impact on the company's operations.
Wang disclosed that according to the contract, ZIM will pay about 10 percent of the order -- worth roughly NT$8 billion (US$236.69 million) -- in compensation for the cancellation.
CSBC has enjoyed the most successful turnaround among all of Taiwan's state- owned companies, with a pre-tax income of NT$2.5 billion in 2007, surpassing its budget target by NT$31 million.
CSBC's container ship orders and total container volume rank fourth in the world.
The company also unveiled a plan last December to expand its ship repair services to meet a possible rise in repair demand following the opening of direct shipping links with China Dec. 15, 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, falling NT$0.082 to close at NT$33.835.
A total of US$846 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$33.977 and reached a low of 33.751.

DOC.HEADLINE: TMC aims to meet initial goals within two years: chairman

TEXT.P: The government-planned DRAM company, Taiwan Memory Co. (TMC), will in the initial stages focus on product design and optimizing the manufacturing process, so as to build Taiwan's independent proficiency in developing DRAM production technologies, said John Hsuan, the appointed chairman of the company, Wednesday.

The company will take advantage of Taiwan's dynamic random access memory (DRAM) productivity to develop design expertise, Hsuan said at a press conference in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, adding that the aim is to achieve these goals within two years after the company's establishment.
He noted that the profile of TMC is a company with unique expertise, dedicated to product design and the development of the DRAM manufacturing process.

Its top priority will be to find the best way to take advantage of the country's productivity in the DRAM industry, he said. TMC's operations will not conflict with the interests of local DRAM makers, but will serve as a platform for local businesses to forge cooperative links, he added.

TMC will offer funds and resources in the areas of technology research and development to affiliated companies, and will authorize or contract local DRAM factories to carry out production, packing and testing, Hsuan said.

Hsuan, honorary vice chairman of United Microelectronics Corp., was assigned by the Ministry of Economic Affairs in early March to execute the establishment of the DRAM company planned by the government to revitalize the local DRAM industry.

At the press conference Wednesday, he outlined the principles by which the company will be guided. It will not compete in the area of production, will not engage in price battles, sell sub-standard products, interfere in the market order, or dump its products, he promised.
Commenting on the outlook for the DRAM industry, Hsuan said its recovery will not be as swift as Frank Huang, chairman of the Hsinchu-based Powerchip Semiconductor Corp., forecast.
Huang predicted a few days ago that the sector will clear all its stocks and that demand will outstrip supply in the third quarter of the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan expects 1 millionth visitor of 2009 this week

TEXT.P: Taiwan is expected to receive its 1 millionth visitor for 2009 this week, with the total visitor arrivals for the year likely to reach 4 million, Tourism Bureau officials said Wednesday.
The officials predicted that the 1 millionth visitor will arrive April 3 -- two days earlier compared with last year, when the 1 millionth visitor arrived April 5.
They attributed this year's faster rate of visitor arrivals to the increasing number of Chinese tourists visiting the country.

The situation is especially encouraging, since the global economic downturn has hit the tourism industry hard, boosting Taiwan's confidence of achieving its goal of receiving 4 million visitors for the whole year, the officials said.
Bureau statistics show that visitor arrivals totaled nearly 3.85 million in 2008, up 3.47 percent from the previous year.
Of these arrivals, approximately 1.78 million, or 46.17 percent, were for pleasure, while 881,431, or 22.92 percent, were for business.
The largest number of visitors from a single country -- nearly 1.09 million -- came from Japan, followed by Hong Kong and Macau, totaling 618,667.
Visitors from the United States totaled 387,197, while those from China totaled 329,204.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT invites HK chief executive to visit Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 1 (CNA) 04/01/09 19:27:45 (By Mandy Wong and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A vice chairman of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) invited Hong Kong Chief Executive Donald Yam-kuen Tsang Wednesday to visit Taiwan.

Eric Liluan Chu, who is also magistrate of northern Taiwan's Taoyuan County, along with six other county officials, arrived in the former British colony earlier that day for a brief visit aimed at promoting an aerotropolis development project in the county built around the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport.
An aerotropolis is a new type of urban conurbation comprising aviation-intensive businesses and related enterprises extending up to 25 km outward from major airports.
Chu expressed hope that Hong Kong investors will invest in the aviation city project and that there will be closer cooperation between the Taiwanese airport and the Hong Kong International Airport.
Citing Chu's remarks, Chang Chi-chiang, a county government secretary, said Chu hopes bilateral government exchanges in the fields of trade, culture and education will also be boosted.
Tsang for his part said that Taiwan and Hong Kong can work together to promote airport cooperation in many ways.
The head of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region government noted that he visited Taiwan in 1977 and expressed hope that he will be able to go there again during his current tenure.
He also invited Taoyuan County to co-host a Taiwan-Hong Kong city exchange forum next year.
Chu and his delegation later left Hong Kong for Singapore to continue their efforts to attract foreign investment in the aerotropolis project.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung City to raise chicken with kitchen food scrap

TEXT.P: The Taichung city government in central Taiwan will sell a kind of high-end chicken raised with organic feed made from kitchen scraps on a trial basis from May, a city official said Wednesday.

Lee Li-teh, head of the city's Environmental Protection Department, gave his assurances that this pedigree of chicken will not contain any residue of antibiotics or growth hormones and he encouraged the public to consume them.
The chickens will be marketed and sold on the Internet next month after two years of experiments with a local farm.
Each chicken will be sold for NT$450 9(US$12.9) during the promotional sales period in which a maximum of 50 chickens can be sold per month, he noted.
Lee made the comments at a news conference with the Taichung City Farmers Association Chief Chen Ching-chih to promote the new strain of free range chickens.
The kitchen scrap will be provided by the city's Environmental Protection Department.

According to Lee, this new pedigree of chickens must be reared for over six months so as to have them develop tasty meat. Usually, ordinary chickens would be raised at the farm for only four to five weeks before they are slaughtered and sold in the market.
The Taichung city government launched the chicken-raising project to take better advantage of readily available kitchen scrap.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yunlin winery to be promoted as tourist attraction

TEXT.P: Yunlin County in south-central Taiwan is aiming to boost its tourism by opening its local winery to public tours with effect from Friday, officials of the central Taiwan office under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Wednesday.

Fu Lu Shou Winery in Gukeng township, which established Taiwan's first wine museum in October 2007, will mark its 10th founding anniversary on April 3 by allowing visitors to observe its wine-making process.

The museum, which has fully preserved the country's traditional wine-making process and equipment, is optimistic about attracting more tourists. It also hopes that by integrating traditional culture and modern technology, it will draw more business opportunities.
The winery obtained an MOEA license last November to operate as a tourism facility in Yunlin County, as did two other enterprises -- a soy sauce company and a towel factory.
Visitors to the winery will be able to gain a firsthand understanding of the wine-making process and to sample a wide variety of liquors and wines from all over the world.
According to the MOEA, the trend of promoting factories and workshops as tourist attractions has been gaining popularity steadily since last year, despite the economic downturn.

This type of business drew more than 110,000 visitors across the country the last year and recorded revenue of more than NT$400 million (US$11.5 million) for the year, according to statistics compiled by the MOEA's central Taiwan office.
The office forecast that the number of visitors to Gukeng township will increase by 30 percent when the winery becomes part of the county's tourism expansion efforts.

In conjunction with the MOEA, the Industrial Development Bureau made public March 27 a list of 10 factories that qualify for MOEA assistance this year to develop as tourism venues. They include factories that make rice noodles, shoes, sausages and saxophones.
A total of 33 factories had applied for government aid to tailor their business to tourism.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to invest heavily in revitalization of baseball

TEXT.P: The Sports Affairs Council (SAC) will inject NT$1.26 billion (US$37.28 million) into various projects over the next four years to revitalize baseball in Taiwan, Executive Yuan spokesman Su Jun-pin said Wednesday.
Su made the announcement after a special meeting chaired by Premier Liu Chao- shiuan and at which SAC Minister Tai Hsia-ling gave a briefing on the Cabinet- level SAC's baseball revitalization plan.

According to Su, the top goals of the SAC's four-year plan include having Taiwan's national baseball team enter the finals of Asian and world baseball championships and capture at least a silver medal and compete in the semi-finals of every World Baseball Classic tournament.
To realize these goals, the SAC will spend NT$1.26 billion over the next four years on various baseball development projects.

Baseball has been known as Taiwan's national ball game because of its popularity among local people. The urgency to resurrect the sport was highlighted by Taiwan's disastrous performance in the just-concluded World Baseball Classic 2009, in which Taiwan was first crushed by South Korea 9-0 and then embarrassingly eliminated from the tournament by China 4-1.

Projects to be carried out under the four-year revival plan will include helping Taiwan's top-tier professional baseball league -- the Chinese Professional Baseball League -- to form a second-tier professional league and subsidizing any organization or corporation that intends to establish adult amateur baseball teams.
The revival plan also calls for the development of a comprehensive mechanism for the formation and training of national baseball teams at various levels.
The SAC has worked out operational guidelines for the formation of more adult teams, with the goal of establishing 10 amateur teams this year, SAC sources said.
According to the sources, the council on Tuesday invited representatives of city and county governments and companies that intend to start amateur teams to discuss the technical details.

The meeting was attended by representatives from Taipei City, Taipei County, Taoyuan County, Taichung City, Kaohsiung City and Taitung County governments as well as from Taiwan Tobacco and Liquor Co., Chunghwa Telecom, Taiwan Power Co., China Steel Corp., and Taiwan Cooperative Bank, the sources said.
In order to organize high-caliber national teams, the SAC will divide international competitions into three tiers, with the Olympic Games, Asian Games and World Baseball Classic at the top.
The Chinese Taipei Baseball Association will also be responsible for organizing an ad hoc committee to deal with the formation and training of national teams for various international tournaments.

Under the four-year plan, the SAC will sponsor a baseball revival conference every year, invite world-famous coaches to help with the training of national teams, and organize a winter baseball league tournament in which Japanese and South Korean professional baseball teams will be invited to compete.
Moreover, the SAC plans to build a baseball village to facilitate personnel training and sports development.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local government elections spur DPP factional infighting

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) decided Wednesday to nominate DPP Legislator Lee Chun-yi to run for Tainan County magistrate in December, but a veteran DPP member vowed that he will also join the race.

Tan Sun Chen, whose last post under the former DPP government was secretary- general of the Presidential Office, claimed that he had become a victim of factional fighting within the DPP. He vowed that he will go the distance in the election in defiance of factional dominance within the party.
Chen, 74, has served in a series of high-level postions in his political career, including as Tainan County magistrate and minister of foreign affairs.

He expressed confidence that he would emerge as the front runner among all the DPP candidates in the Tainan County magistrate election, and suggested that the party leadership should have chosen the nominee by means of an opinion poll that would have gauged who had the strongest support among the DPP members and voters.
Chen disclosed that DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen had met with him a day earlier in an attempt to persuade him to withdraw from the race but that he flatly refused.

Asked by reporters whether that means he will run in the election even if the party resorts to disciplinary measures against him, Chen did not give a direct answer, but said that he will leave that kind of issue to the DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. official visits Taipei to discuss bilateral trade issues

TEXT.P: U.S. Deputy Assistant Trade Representative Eric Altbach is currently on a visit in Taipei to discuss certain bilateral trade issues, a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) official said Wednesday.

Altbach, who arrived in Taipei Monday, is concerned with what the U.S. calls bilateral trade barriers, such as Taiwan's restrictions on U.S. beef imports and its zero-residue requirements for the feed additive ractopamine, the official said.
At present, Taiwan only allows imports of U.S. boneless beef from cattle younger than 30 months.

In addition to explaining Taiwan's stances on those issues to Altbach, the official said, the ministry will also convey to him Taiwan's hope that the long- stalled sub-Cabinet-level talks under the bilateral Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) can resume as soon as possible.
According to the official, Taiwan's plan to negotiate an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China may also be mentioned in the talks with Altbach.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 2, or the seventh day of the third month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
742: Charlemagne, King of the Franks and founder of the first empire in Western Europe after the fall of Rome, is born. His court at Aix-le-Chapelle becomes the center of the Carolingian Renaissance.
1792: The first silver dollar of the new U.S. currency is struck in Philadelphia by the Bank of the United States.
1801: Britain's Admiral Horatio Nelson, aboard the HMS Elephant, sinks the pro- French Danish fleet off its home port of Copenhagen.
1805: Hans Christian Andersen, the Danish writer of fairy tales including "The Emperor's New Clothes" and "The Ugly Duckling," is born.
1840: Emile Zola, the French realist novelist whose books include "Therese Raquin," "Nana," "Germinal," and " La Terre," is born.
1872: Samuel Finley Breese Morse, the American painter and inventor who refined and patented the telegraph and developed the telegraphic code that bears his name, dies at the age of 81.
1902: The first U.S. movie theater is opened in Los Angeles, California.
1912: The provisional Senate of the Republic of China resolves to move the seat of the government to Beijing.
1917: Thomas Woodrow Wilson, the 28th president of the United States and the winner of the 1919 Nobel Peace Prize, summons a special session of Congress to declare war on Germany. At the Paris Peace Conference in 1919, he included the establishment of the League of Nations in the Treaty of Versailles.
1922: Soviet leader Nikolai Lenin appoints Joseph Stalin as general secretary of the Communist Party.
1938: The Spanish Civil War ends with General Franco's fascists as the victors.
1947: The United Nations Security Council votes to appoint the United States as the trustee for Pacific Islands formerly held by the Japanese.
1951: General Dwight Eisenhower assumes command of all allied armies in Europe and the Western Mediterranean area.
1953: Karl L. Rankin becomes American ambassador to the ROC.
1954: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the Extradition Law.
1965: The ROC government declares that "protocols" signed recently by the Beijing regime with Afghanistan are illegal and not binding on China.
1971: Garuda Indonesia Airlines makes its maiden flight to Taipei.
1973: Brig. Gen. Majed Al Haj Hassan and two other members of a Jordanian military goodwill mission arrive in Taipei for a 10-day visit.
1974: Georges Pompidou, president of France, dies at the age of 62.
1974: Madame Gloria de Lopez Arellana, the first lady of Honduras, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1981: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo is re-elected chairman of the Kuomintang by acclamation at the 12th National Congress in Taipei.
1982: Argentine military forces invade the British Falkland Islands.
1983: Chang Da-chien, a noted Chinese painter, dies in Taipei at the age of 85.
1991: Diego Maradona, star of Napoli soccer team, flies home to Argentina hours before being banned from every sporting activity in Italy after failing a dope test.
1996: Lech Walesa, Poland's first post-war democratic president, resumes his old job as an electrician at the Gdansk shipyard.
1997: U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Newt Gingrich meets with ROC President Lee Teng-hui during a four-hour visit to Taipei. Gingrich praises Taiwan's political progress and economic achievements.
1997: The Statute Governing Relations with Hong Kong and Macau is promulgated by President Lee Teng-hui to go partially into effect on July 1, 1997 for Hong Kong, and in 1999 for Macau.
2000: ROC President-elect Chen Shui-bian denies that he sent an American scientist as special envoy to mainalnd China to discuss cross-strait relations with Beijing leaders.
2001: Exiled Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama says in Taipei that he wants to pursue "a genuine autonomy" for Tibet, not independence. He makes the remarks while delivering a speech at the Legislative Yuan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man is dignified, but not proud. A fool is proud, but not dignified."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Kinmen launches free milk program for students

TEXT.P: The offshore Kinmen County launched the country's first-ever free milk program Thursday with the aim of helping parents to raise strong and healthy children.
The county's education bureau chief Lee Chai-hang said the program will be beneficial to some 7,500 students, from kindergarten to the junior high school level.

It is being implemented on an annual budget of NT$6 million (US$172,000) that was recently approved by the Kinmen County Council, he said. The funding is coming primarily from contributions by the county-run Kinmen Kaoliang Liquor Inc., which is a long-term revenue earner for the outlying island, he added.
Residents of Kinmen on average earn 60 percent of the income of people on Taiwan proper, Lee noted.

The 7,500 Kinmen students will initially be given free milk two days per week, but the county hopes to expand the program to provide the children with milk every school day, once milk production at the county's experimental farm increases to a certain level, he explained.

The county government has introduced similar programs in the past. In December 1999, it became the first local government in the country to launch a free lunch program for elementary and high school students, an initiative that became a model for other areas of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sourcing Taiwan 2009 creates huge business opportunities

TEXT.P: The Sourcing Taiwan 2009 trade fair being held from March 30 to April 2 in Taipei is expected to bring new orders worth a total of NT$180 billion to Taiwanese suppliers, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) estimated Thursday.
Over the past two days, more than 2,200 Taiwanese suppliers held a total of 13,805 one-on-one meetings with 548 buyers from 63 countries, TAITRA statistics show.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs -- the organizer of the event -- has instructed foreign trade officials and TAITRA to maintain regular contact with the buyers to firm up their purchase plans, TAITRA officials said.

To cater to the requirements of various businesses, individual seminars were held Wednesday for 10 large-scale buyers, including the U.S.-based office products seller Office Depot, the U.K.-based pharmaceutical company Alliance Boots, the China-based food company Chia Tai Group, and the India-based automotive parts company Amalgamations Group and India Pistons.

Other participants were Mexico's leading department store chain Distribuidora Liverpool, German transmission builder ZF, France's largest automobile manufacturer PSA Peugeot Citroen, Italy's largest automobile manufacturer the Fiat Group, France's leading electrical, mechanical and HVAC engineering system company SPIE, and Canada's automotive parts company Magna International.
Various visits have been arranged for the participating buyers for Thursday, following the conclusion of the trade meetings and seminars Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Computex TAIPEI expecting good turnout despite economic downturn

TEXT.P: Computex TAIPEI 2009, one of the worlds leading information and communication technology (ICT) procurement platforms and the largest computer show in Asia, will remain strong in terms of scale despite the global economic downturn, organizers said Thursday, adding that they expect to generate US$20 billion in business, even as other major ICT fairs are shrinking.

Walter Yeh, executive vice president of the non-profit trade promotion body Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , said at a press conference to reveal the details of this year's exhibition that Computex TAIPEI 2009 expects swarms of important buyers and exhibitors from domestic and overseas companies, with all the booths fully booked and many others on the waiting list.

TAITRA and the co-organizer Taipei Computer Association estimated that the show will attract 35,000 international buyers and 1,700 exhibitors, which will take up 4,600 booths to showcase their products.

Noting that both the International Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in the United States and CeBit in Germany have seen a drop in size and business by five percent and 20 percent, respectively, Yeh predicted that this years Computex TAIPEI will generate an estimated US$20 billion in business opportunities, the same amount as last year and a satisfying one given the global economic downturn.
This figure is reasonable. But in a time like this, we better be more realistic and conservative,Yeh said.

As Computex TAIPEI is the annual ICT extravaganza that IT professionals simply do not miss, Yeh noted that the fair is expecting participation from important companies with annual sales exceeding US$1 billion, such as Ricoh from Japan and Siemens from Germany.
TAITRA has been working hard to invite international buyers, especially from China and the emerging markets to participate in this years show, Yeh added.

The show, scheduled for June 2-4 at the Taipei World Trade Center in Nangang and Taipei World Trade Center in downtown Taipei, will for the first time have a pavilion designated to some 100 Chinese companies, including big brands such as Tsinghua Tongfang, MALATA.
Yeh attributed the participation of Chinese companies to the warm cross-Taiwan Strait relations and the launch of direct flights between Taiwan and China last December.

In addition to exhibiting the best and the latest in ICT products, 5,000 procurement match-making meetings will be arranged to connect buyers with exhibitors, an event which Yeh said is unique in similar ICT fairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's purple crow butterfly conservation a story of progress

TEXT.P: CNA Staff Writer

Bathed in spring sunshine, thousands of purple crow butterflies alight in the woods near Pingding in south-central Taiwan to feed on nectar on a recent Sunday, gathering strength before continuing on their long journey back to their breeding grounds in the north.

Guided by their teachers, young students from the area concentrate on recording the number of the insects passing by. At times, the teachers catch the delicate creatures with nets and quickly tag their wings with an identifying mark before setting them free.

"The `capture and release' strategy is part of our long-term campaign to track the species' migratory routes for educational and conservation purposes, " said Huang Hsi-pei, academic affairs director of Chengkung Elementary School in Pingding village, Yunlin County.

This grassroots educational drive is a welcome change from previous decades, when the "butterfly kingdom" -- as Taiwan is known -- was a killing field for the colorful winged creatures during their seasonal migrations.

The lack of interest in conservation led to the extinction of two precious species -- king crow and tailed cupid -- in the 1960s, but today, butterfly preservation is a high enough priority that even Taiwan's freeway bureau has blocked off freeway sections to prevent the purple crows from being squashed by passing cars.

Conservationists would like to see even more efforts by the government, but they said efforts by the freeway bureau and programs such as those conducted by the elementary school are a good start to along-term solution -- protecting the butterflies' natural habitat and making butterfly conservation a widespread public concern.

The purple crow butterflies provide an example of how vulnerable fragile insects are to human encroachment on their natural habitats and how a little effort by government and society can make a big difference.

"Butterflies are such delicate creatures that once you destroy the plants they rely on, they have little chance of survival, " said Chan Chia-lung, an entomologist-turned-conservationist who won an award in Japan in 2008 for his long-term observation of the species.

After years of extensive tracking by conservation experts and volunteers, it was discovered that purple crow butterflies spend the winter in the island's warmer southern region to escape the winter cold in the north.

In October each year, instinct draws the butterflies to take refuge in low-lying valleys on the two sides of the southern foothills of Taiwan's Central Mountain Range, most notably Maolin in Kaohsiung County and Dawu in Taitung County, where they winter until March.

At the onset of spring, the butterflies begin a 400-km migration back to their northern habitats, following a variety of routes from Maolin and Dawu until they reach the hillside village of Pingding, where they converge in the thousands or even millions before crossing the Chingshuei River.

The butterflies then fly to different destinations in central, northern and northeastern Taiwan, including Baguashan in Changhua County and Jhunan in Miaoli County, where they fulfill their most important mission -- to mate and lay their eggs.

This "butterfly highway" is nearly unique in the world, with the monarch butterfly in Mexico the only other butterfly species to migrate like birds and winter in a particular valley, according to Chan.
The migration in Taiwan offers an incredible spectacle.
"The sight of hundreds of thousands of butterflies with purple wings that appear to change color as they catch the sunlight at different angles is a thrill for many people, " Chan said.
Yet this rare migratory pattern has led to the deaths of thousands of butterflies as motorists run into them on Taiwan's National Freeway No.3, which lies along their migratory path.
However, measures taken by the National Freeway Bureau (NFB) since three years ago have resulted in a significant decline in the road-kill rate.
According to a study by National Taiwan University entomology professor Yang Ping-shih, butterflies killed by passing cars declined from 3 percent of the flock in 2007 to 0.3 percent in 2008.

Encouraged by the progress, the bureau this year expanded the section of the freeway to be closed during the migration peak period to 3 km from the previous 2 km and extended a security net to 660 meters from 460 meters to encourage the butterflies to fly higher, avoiding the traffic.

"The protective measures are very special. They can only be found in Taiwan. We are proud to be spending a little money to offer some protection for the butterflies and the environment, " said NFB Director-General Lee Thay-ming in a recent interview.

Butterfly populations in Taiwan, which has one of the world's highest butterfly densities in the world, were decimated by commercial collecting, particularly in the 1960s, when they were sold by the kilogram to collectors.
The practice of capturing large numbers of butterflies for commercial use is rare today, because it is no longer profitable.
Today, human encroachment in the form of land reclamation remains the greatest threat to the insects.

According to Chan, about 200,000 butterflies disappeared due to the construction of a parking lot in Maolin to accommodate tourists in the 1990s. The project destroyed part of the insects' winter home.

To prevent similar problems, an area has now been marked off as a butterfly sanctuary in the Maolin National Scenic Area. It is part of aconservation program sponsored by the Council of Agriculture that includes the cultivation of plants upon which the insects feed.

"I hope the latest steps to provide the purple crows safer passage during their migration, coupled with a greater public awareness of the problems they face, can help increase butterfly populations," Chan said.
Some conservation experts share his view, arguing that more must be done if Taiwan is to keep its reputation as a "butterfly kingdom."
Hsu Yu-feng, an entomology professor at National Taiwan Normal University, said butterfly numbers provide an important indicator of the state of the environment.
Since a high of 11,500 butterflies per minute were recorded during the migration period in 2005, the number of butterflies recorded have never been as high, experts said.

In recent years, it has ranged only around several hundreds or a few thousands per minute, partly due to destruction of their habitats, obstruction in their migration and climate change, according to the experts.
"A decline in the butterfly population could signal a deterioration of our environment, so we have to pay more attention to the environment and protection of butterfly habitats," Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese icebreaker research ship opens to Taiwan visitors

TEXT.P: MV Xue Long (Snow Dragon), a Chinese icebreaker and polar research vessel that arrived in southern Taiwan Wednesday, was opened Thursday to the Taiwan public for visits.
MV Xue Long, anchored at Kaohsiung Harbor's True Love Wharf, will remain open to the Taiwan public, students and maritime researchers Thursday and Friday until it departs for China Saturday.

Up to 1,000 visitors per day will be permitted to go aboard the ship, said officials from the National Museum of Marine Biology and Aquarium in the southern county of Pingtung, which is one of the organizations hosting the Xue Long's first port call in Taiwan.

MV Xue Long has just concluded its latest expedition to the Antarctic, which began last October. It is China's only polar research ship and is owned by the Polar Research Institute of China, which operates three research stations in the Antarctic and one in the Arctic.

Wei Wenliang, a deputy director with the Polar Research Institute of China, said the ship's call in Kaohsiung is purely academic in nature and sets the stage for several Taiwanese scientists to join its next research expedition to the Antarctic this October.
Four Taiwanese scientists will join the expedition in what will be the first joint cross-Taiwan Strait polar exploration.
Wei said it is hoped that the expedition will serve as a starter for closer cooperation across the Taiwan Strait in the field of polar research in the future.
Wei squashed speculations in a Taiwan media report the day before that the Xue Long may take the opportunity while in port in Taiwan to "collect national intelligence."
He attributed this speculation to inadequate communication and understanding between the people of the two sides, a situation that he said was the result of decades of political impasse.

The Taiwanese team will focus on marine biological research and will be comprised of experts from the National Museum of Marine Biology and Aquarium, National Dong Hwa University in the eastern county of Hualien and Cheng Shiu University in the southern county of Kaohsiung, according to Wang Hsin-fa, a spokesman for the National Museum of Marine Biology and Aquarium.

Although individual Taiwanese scientists, since the 1980s, have participated in polar research projects organized by other countries, Taiwan's achievements in this area remain sporadic and fragmented, Wang said.
The latest cooperation venture with China is expected to be of great help to Taiwan's polar research in light of China's rich experience and resources in this area, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA completes ECFA evaluation: minister

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) , which is responsible for planning the proposed signing of a comprehensive trade pact with China has completed an overall evaluation of the proposal and finalized consultations with various local industries that were held to gain a better understanding of their needs, according to Economics Minister Yiin Chii-ming.
Yiin was quoted as having made the remarks at an executive meeting of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Wednesday.

According to KMT spokesman Lee Chien-jung, Yiin outlined six stages that must be completed before an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China could be put into effect -- separate assessments by each side, a joint assessment, negotiations, the signing of the agreement, legislative approval and implementation.
Yiin also expressed hopes at the meeting that the first stage could be completed in three months' time.

The minister stressed that it would be best for Taiwan to sign the proposed ECFA sooner rather than later, as China is about to enter into a free trade arrangement with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) member countries.

When the ASEAN-China trade integration takes effect in 2010, tariffs on 93 percent of the products traded in the area will be removed, and Taiwan is under pressure to avoid marginalization, Yiin was quoted as saying.
If Taiwan is excluded from the free trade region, over half of the country's exports will be affected by high tariffs, which would lead to an exodus of local industries, according to Yiin.
For example, local petrochemical companies would be subject to tariffs of 6.5 percent on their products, while their competitors in the region would pay only 0.25 percent, he elaborated.

Yiin also said that the government has come up with a "safeguard mechanism" to protect certain local industries, such as leather, towel and footwear manufacturers. In the initial period, Chinese goods from those sectors will not be allowed into Taiwan, and anti-dumpling measures will also be instituted, he added.

Meanwhile, Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said Wednesday that the ECFA proposal is likely to be discussed in the preparatory meetings ahead of the third round of cross-Taiwan Strait talks.

The preparatory consultations for the third meeting between Taiwan's semi- official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and his Chinese counterpart Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), are scheduled to be held in mid- April in Taiwan, according to Lai.
On the agenda of the next Chiang-Chen meeting are joint anti-crime efforts, regular scheduled cross-strait flights, financial cooperation, and Chinese investment in Taiwan, Lai said.

She said that the proposed ECFA will hopefully be raised during the preparatory meeting and that if both sides are willing to negotiate on the issue, it would be put on the agenda of the next round of Chiang-Chen talks.
As internal consensus is needed before such an agreement with China could be signed, it is still too early to negotiate with China on the proposed pact, Lai said.
The MAC chief said that as far as she knows, China is still studying the proposal, but added that the ECFA issue will definitely be raised in the fourth round of Chiang-Chen talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, falling NT$0.255 to close at NT$33.580.
A total of US$1.90 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$33.835 and reached a low of 33.192.

DOC.HEADLINE: Elderly Taiwanese living in China to visit Taiwan after 60 years
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, April 2 (CNA) 04/02/09 17:57:13 (By H. Y. Chou and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A group of 15 Taiwanese over the age of 70 will fly from Beijing to Taiwan Friday, the day before this year's Tomb-Sweeping Day, for a 10-day visit to search for their roots.

Lin Liyun, an adviser with the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , will serve as group leader. The group's visit to Taiwan, the first of its kind in 60 years, has become possible as a result of improved ties between the two sides over the past year.
A tea party was held Thursday in Beijing by the All-China Federation of Taiwan Compatriots to see off the travelers -- the eldest of whom is 86 and the youngest, 73.

All 15 people had moved to China after 1949 when Taiwan and China split into separate rule, and most of them had been denied entry to Taiwan several times as a result of the delicate political situation across the Taiwan Strait. Two of them have never returned to Taiwan since they left their hometowns in their youth.
Lin, who served as Japanese secretary to the late Chinese Premier Zhou Enlai, visited Taiwan once in 1999 after she settled in Beijing in 1952. She still has relatives in Taiwan.

While in Taiwan, the group will tour cultural and scenic attractions, including Sun Moon Lake in central Nantou County, Taroko National Park and the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation in eastern Hualien County.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA to focus on improving lives of African allied nations' citizens

TEXT.P: The future focus of the ministrys work in terms of promoting relations with Taiwans four diplomatic allies in Africa will be on improving the lives of the people in those nations, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Thursday.

Andrew Chang, director-general of MOFAs Department of African Affairs, said at a regular press briefing that in order to raise the living standards of the people, Taiwan will provide further assistance in increasing agricultural production and upgrading the standards of medical care, and education.
These areas are what Taiwan is most skilled in and by focusing on them, I believe we will achieve a more effective result, Chang told the Central News Agency.
Despite that these areas have long been part of Taiwans foreign aid work, Chang said the ministry decided to put emphasis on them because they are most linked to the lives of the people.
Four of Taiwans 23 diplomatic allies are located in Africa, including Burkina Faso, Sao Tome and Principe, Swaziland and The Gambia.

According to Chang, with the assistance of the Taiwan International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) , the foreign ministry hopes that Taiwans agricultural technology missions in Africa will help the countrys African allies increase agricultural production to reduce their foreign exchange expenditures.

As for medical services, instead of assembling medical missions through ICDF to go to those countries, which is usually difficult to manage, Chang said the ministry has decided to commission the task to big hospitals because they have sufficient specialist doctors and more flexibility in personnel arrangement.
At present, Taipei Medical University and Changhua Christian Hospital have been designated to provide medical assistance in Swaziland and Sao Tome and Principe, respectively.

In terms of education, Chang noted that Taiwan has been active in promoting education for girls and women in Gambia, helping the country achieve the highest ratio of females in school compared to other African countries.

Fruitful results have also been seen in the special classes provided by National Taipei University of Technology in petroleum, civil engineering and technology, as well as those of National Pingtung University of Science and Technology, Chang added.
He also announced at the press briefing that Taiwan and Burkina Faso will jointly launch a seven-year cooperation project to help the African country build up its vocational training system.

Under the commission of the Burkina Faso government, Taiwans Central Training Center will tender a bid on April 3 for the center's procurement of vocational training machines and education facilities totaling NT$70 million (US$2.1 million), Chang said, adding that suppliers are encouraged to join the bid and there will be 20 more bids by 2013.

DOC.HEADLINE: Most stock mutual funds earn returns in first quarter

TEXT.P: Some 95 percent of mutual funds specializing in Taiwan's stocks reported positive returns in the first quarter of this year, buoyed by gains in the local stock market, a dealer said Thursday.

Taiwan's TAIEX stock index climbed 13.5 percent in the first quarter, making it one of the top three best performing markets in the world, which the dealer said had fueled double-digit gains for stock mutual funds.

Of the total 172 closed-end mutual funds (excluding exchange traded funds), 164 reported good returns, with 12 delivering a return of more than 20 percent, according to statistics released by the local mutual fund industry.
Over-the-counter (OTC) , technology and mid- and small-cap funds outperformed the overall market, with OTC funds registering a gain of 18.11 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices on Taipei bourse surge

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices surged for the second consecutive session Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, jumping 159.33 points, or 2.99 percent, to close at 5,473.78.

Following gains on Wall Street overnight, the local bourse opened at 5,428.92 and fluctuated between 5,477.97 and 5,401.30. A total of 5.84 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$148.17 billion (US$4.41 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial stocks surging the most at 5.8 percent on news that a memorandum of understanding (MOU) will be signed with China in the first half of this year.

The MOU is expected to facilitate cross-strait financial supervision and the creation of a currency settlement mechanism, which is indispensable for mutual investments by financial institutions on both sides.
Foodstuff stocks and construction issues both advanced 5.3 percent, as data showed a 40 percent increase in transactions involving used residential houses in March.

Paper and pulp issues rose 5.1 percent, cement stocks advanced 4.6 percent, plastics and chemicals shares rose 4.4 percent, textile issues advanced 3.8 percent, and machinery and electronics shares moved up 1.7 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,548 to 525, with 105 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$12.13 billion.
Analysts advised Thursday that investors should stay alert to the possibility of selling pressure as the index approaches 5,500 points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Age-related hearing impairment linked to belly fat: study

TEXT.P: Excess belly fat has for years been linked to health problems such as cardiovascular disease and diabetes, but a recent study has found an association with another risk -- age-related hearing impairment (ARHI).
The results of the study released Thursday by a local otolaryngolosist show that central obesity is more important than body mass index (BMI) as a risk predictor for ARHI.

The study by Hwang Juen-haur from the Buddhist Dalin Tzu Chi General Hospital in the southern county of Chiayi was conducted in cooperation with National Taiwan University Hospital between August 2007 and October 2008. The findings were included in the March 2009 issue of Obesity, the official journal of the U.S.-based Obesity Society.
The study analyzed the audiometric test results, height, weight and waist circumference of 690 patients with hearing loss within the range of -10 to 15 decibels (dB HL).

The subjects included 432 women and 258 men with the same degree of permanent hearing loss in both ears resulting from damage to the inner ear or to the nerve pathways from the inner ear to the brain.

The study found that the negative impact of visceral fat on hearing began to emerge when the patients were around middle age, with the hearing impairment suffered by men three times more severe than that by women, Hwang said.
After adjusting for age, gender, systemic disease and other variables, it was found the waist circumference showed a significant positive association with hearing loss, Hwang said.

When both waist circumference and BMI were taken into account, waist circumference, but not BMI, showed a significant positive association with low- frequency and high-frequency hearing impairment in males younger than 55, and with high-frequency hearing impairment with borderline significance in women older than 55, Hwang said.

Hwang said women's vulnerability to hearing impairment after the age of 55 could be related to a rapid increase in obesity and reduced estrogen levels after the onset of menopause. Estrogen has been shown to play a protective role in the function and plasticity of the auditory system in women, he added.
Meanwhile, the early development of central obesity in men may explain the association of waist circumference with hearing impairment in men younger than 55, he said.

Hwang surmised that obesity may directly cause hearing loss via obesity-related oxidative stress, which is usually caused by an imbalance between the production of reactive oxygen and the body's ability to detoxify the reactive compounds or easily repair the resulting damage.
According to Hwang, in the interest of health, the waist circumference should not be allowed to exceed 90 cm for men and 80 cm for women. Regular exercise is also advisable to avoid obesity, he said.
The advice applies also to tall people, who can have normal BMIs despite big bellies, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mandarin Airlines will resume daily Taipei-Kaohsiung flights

TEXT.P: Mandarin Airlines announced Thursday that it will resume daily flights between Taipei and Kaohsiung from April 30, in response to strong demand from business passengers.

Mandarin currently operates only three two-way flights per week on Friday, Sunday and Monday between the two largest cities in Taiwan -- a reduction which the Taipei-based carrier implemented in September last year to trim its daily service.

Mandarin launched a discounted ticket package on the Taipei-Kaohsiung route in March, offering one way tickets at NT$1,720 (US$49) each, compared to the original price of NT$2,120. The price cut has helped Mandarin increase its passenger load factor in recent weeks.
The number of flights on the Taipei-Kaohsiung route exceeded 100 per month during its peak years, when it was the most profitable domestic route.
Air travel on Taiwan's western corridor has been hard-hit after the island's high speed train system went into service in January 2007.

In the face of operating difficulties from the fierce competition from the bullet train, airline companies have steadily chopped flights between Taipei and Taichung in central Taiwan and between Taipei, Chiayi and Tainan in the south.

DOC.HEADLINE: Magistrate seeks adoptive parents for 16 orphans

TEXT.P: The magistrate of the south-central county of Yunlin said Thursday that she is seeking adoptive parents for 16 children who are awaiting adoption.
Yunlin Magistrate Su Chih-fen called a news conference at County Hall to call for help in efforts to seek adopters for the orphans, who at present are being looked after by the county government.

Su said she is glad that of the 18 children previously under the care of the county government, two have already been adopted -- a 2-year-old boy adopted by an American couple who left Taiwan for the United States last November and a 10 -year-old girl adopted by a couple living in Taipei City who has been living with her adoptive parents since January.

The adoptive parents of the girl, named Hsiao-yi, wrote to the county government's Department of Social Affairs recently to say that their new daughter is adorable, well-behaved and works particularly hard at her studies.
"Hsiao-yi was ranked fifth in academic performance in her class this semester," the parents said in the letter.

Hsiao-yi's story can serve as an example to explode an adoption myth that the older the adopted children are, the more difficult the bonding process can be, for both the adopters and the adopted, Su said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Parents responsible for children's low-vegetable diets: survey

TEXT.P: Parents play an important role in shaping their children's dietary habits and should assume the greatest responsibility for the low vegetable and fruit consumption among children, according to the results of a survey released Thursday by the Formosa Cancer Foundation.
The survey results reveal that 73 percent of the children who responded to the survey like fruit and vegetables.

However, low vegetable and fruit consumption was reported by 63 percent of the respondents, either because they often eat outside the home or because their families seldom prepare fruit and vegetables for them.
In addition, 60 percent of the respondents said their dietary patterns are related to those of their parents.
Asked to name their favorite food eaten outside the home, most children picked instant noodles, followed by fried chicken, followed by braised food.
Meanwhile, 49 percent of the parents who responded to the survey said they often cook grilled or fried food, with 25 percent saying they provide the same food to their children.
Forty-eight percent of the adult respondents said they do not like fruit and vegetables, compared with 38 percent who said they enjoy them.
The survey was conducted online March 4-27 by the foundation in cooperation with the Yuanta Foundation and the Agriculture Trade Office under the American Institute in Taiwan.
A total of 3,174 children aged 9-12 and 1,815 parents participated in the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Tuvalu joint venture good example of cooperation: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that a cooperation venture involving Taiwan and Tuvalu -- one of the country's diplomatic allies in the Pacific -- to build a fishing vessel, serves as a good example of how to create a mutually beneficial situation among governments and the private sector.

Deputy Foreign Minister Andrew Hsia told CNA that the MOFA acted as mediator for Taiwan's Ching Fu Shipbuilding Company and the Tuvalu government when forging the joint venture to construct the ship, which will be registered in Tuvalu but managed by Ching Fu.
He added that 49 percent of the ship's revenue will go to Ching Fu and 51 percent to Tuvalu.
Vice President Vincent Siew and Tuvalu Prime Minister Apisai Ielemia will attend a launch ceremony for the ship April 3 in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, according to Hsia.
Kaohsiung-based Ching Fu is not only the largest but also the first privately owned shipyard in Taiwan to build international standard cargo and multi-purpose vessels.

"Through the mediation of the Foreign Ministry, the venture not only provides jobs in Tuvalu but also gives the fishery rights to a Taiwanese company, creating a win-win-win situation for the governments of both sides and the private sector," Hsia said.
He added that the MOFA would like to do more in terms of brokering similar cooperation agreements between Taiwan and its 23 diplomatic allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to hold video conference with U.S. think tanks

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou will hold a video conference with U.S. think tanks in late April at the Presidential Office to mark the 30th anniversary of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA), Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi said Thursday.

The announcement came after Ma received Arthur C. Brooks, president of the American Enterprise Institute (AEI) for Public Policy Research a few days ago and expressed the hope that the AEI will hold activities to discuss issues related to the act as it is a key element of U.S. policy toward Taiwan.

This will be the first overseas video conference Ma will have held since he took office on May 20, 2008. Scholars from various think tanks are expected to participate in the conference, according to Wang.

Refusing to confirm reports that Ma will officially respond to the six principles and proposals outlined recently by Chinese President Hu Jintao regarding engagements across the Taiwan Strait, Wang said that details of the meeting have yet to be finalized.
Wang noted the significance of holding such a forum as the TRA has been instrumental in maintaining stability in the Taiwan Strait and maintaining regional peace.
The U.S. Congress passed the TRA in 1979 after Washington established diplomatic relations with Beijing and severed formal diplomatic ties with Taipei.

The act requires the U.S. to guarantee defensive arms sales to Taiwan and to maintain U.S. capacity to resist any resort to force or other forms of coercion that would jeopardize the security, or the social or economic system, of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Airfares stable ahead of Tomb-Sweeping Day: Taiwan carrier
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, April 2 (CNA) 04/02/09 21:14:33 (By S.H. Chiao and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: An executive in Shanghai with Taipei-based China Airlines (CAL) said Thursday that the carrier's fares on cross-Taiwan Strait routes have remained stable since March despite rising demand in the runup to Tomb-Sweeping Day, which this year falls on April 4.

Fu Hsiao-wen, CAL's representative in Shanghai, made the comments to reporters in response to questions about soaring air ticket prices on cross-strait routes offered by Shanghai-based aviation companies with the approach of the traditional holiday for Chinese people around the world.
Fu said that CAL -- Taiwan's largest carrier -- has not increased prices on routes between Taiwan and China because of Tomb-Sweeping Day.
"We cannot imagine how Chinese airlines could charge such high prices for cross- strait routes at this time of year, " Fu said.
"CAL prices for round-trip cross-strait routes are about 2,700 renminbi (US$395), " Fu went on. "Even prices for tickets with a three-month validity are only around 3,800 renminbi."

According to Shanghai media reports, prices of several Shanghai-based Chinese aviation companies have increased sharply over the past week to over 5,800 renminbi for a round-trip cross-strait flight in early April -- more than double the price quoted in March.

Some Taiwanese businessmen who recently returned to Shanghai in March said round-trip cross-strait fares on Chinese carriers were about 2,500 renminbi at that time, but they added that they had doubled their prices for the tomb- sweeping festival.

DOC.HEADLINE: Coast guard cutter assigned to patrol Penghu area

TEXT.P: An offshore patrol cutter with a displacement of 628 tons was assigned Thursday to patrol exclusively the waters around the Penghu Islands in a bid to beef up marine resource protection and maritime law enforcement efforts in the area.

Cabinet-level Coast Guard Administration (CGA) Minister Wang Ginn-wang presided over a ceremony held at the port of Makung, the capital city of Penghu, located about 41 km off the southwest coast of Taiwan proper, to inaugurate the operations of patrol boat CG120 and to christen it the Penghu in a ceremony witnessed by Penghu Magistrate Wang Chien-fa.

Addressing the ceremony, the minister noted that due to the lack of deployment of regular patrol boats in the Penghu area, Chinese fishing boats often intrude into Penghu waters, particularly in waters surrounding Penghu's four major uninhabited islets, to poach under the guise of seeking shelter from inclement weather.

The Chinese poaching has depleted fishery resources and triggered fishery disputes in the Penghu area, he said, adding that in the past, the CGA has only assigned patrol boats from the Southern Patrol Office based in Kaohsiung to patrol the Penghu waters. Owing to the distances involved, interdiction efforts have not been successful, causing the Chinese poachers to become increasingly brazen.
"The deployment of the Penghu to patrol the area will be a shot in the arm for local fishermen," he said.
The Penghu was built in 2001 and is 63.55 meters long. With a crew of 40, it can travel at up to 30.96 knots, according to Captain Wu Chin-ho.

DOC.HEADLINE: Activists to call for gender equity in funeral traditions

TEXT.P: A group of social activists and academics are scheduled to meet Friday to call for gender equity in funeral rituals and traditions in which the female members of a Taiwanese family are discriminated against, a women's rights group said Thursday.
Unmarried or divorced daughters are not listed on the family tree in a clan's ancestral hall for ancestor-worship according to Taiwanese tradition, said a spokeswoman for the Awakening Foundation.

In addition, female family members are usually forbidden from performing most of the ritual procedures at a funeral, the spokeswoman went on, adding that no woman has ever been appointed as a clan head in Taiwan to preside over or organize ancestor-worship rituals, she added.
"These discriminatory practices have been followed for thousands of years in Chinese societies, and they need to be turned around, " she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Wildlife reserve area to be set up at Aogu Wetlands

TEXT.P: A 664-hectare area of the sprawling Aogu Wetlands in Dongshi township in southern Taiwan's Chiayi County will be designated as a wildlife conservation sancturary, a Council of Agriculture (COA) official said Thursday.

A COA advisory committee approved the proposal late last year and the Cabinet- level council is expected to soon make a formal announcement of the designation of the country's 18th wildlife reserve area, the official said.
The Aogu Wetlands, the largest of its kind in Taiwan, has long been known as an ecological treasure of lagoons, sandbars, fish farms and beefwood forests.
Birds in their thousands are attracted to the area, including egrets, black drongos, Japanese whiteeyes, grey plovers, black-headed gulls, moorhens, northern shovelers and night egrets.

According to a COA survey, the Aogu Wetlands, covering a total area of more than 1,500 hectares, is home to 10 mammal species, 18 fish species, 22 crustacean species, 17 amphibious species, 346 insect species and 221 bird species -- or nearly half of the 450 bird species recorded in Taiwan.

The survey also shows that about 75 percent of the birds recorded in the Aogu Wetlands are migratory species, many of which are endangered or protected, such as black-faced spoonbills and Oriental white storks.

"We are hopeful that the designation of the wildlife reserve sancturary will contribute to the protection of the natural habitat of many precious wildlife species and thus helps upgrade Taiwan's status in the world ecological conservation community, " the COA official said.
With the establishment of the sancturary, the region will become a major habitat on Taiwan's west coast for East Asian migratory birds, the official added.
Meanwhile, the official said, the surrounding area of the wildlife reserve sancturary at Aogu will be developed into a forested multi-purpose park for education, pleasure and recreation.
The COA's Forestry Bureau has planted 677 hectares of trees, including paper bark trees at the site of the planned multi-purpose park that is scheduled to open at the end of 2011, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-based Franz Co. opens flagship store in Beijing

TEXT.P: Taiwan-based Franz Porcelain Co. opened its first global flagship shop in Beijing Thursday to cash in on China's growing affluence and economic clout, according to a China News Service report.

Addressing the opening ceremony, Franz Porcelain Co. Chairman Chen Li-heng said that despite the current global economic downturn, the company's business turnover in China posted an encouraging 68 percent gain in February and March.

"The sales record gives us strong confidence and it also highlights the importance of branding, " Chen said, adding that the company will continue to cooperate with Taiwan's National Palace Museum and the Beijing Palace Museum in designing and producing exquisite porcelain items.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for April 3, 2009

TEXT.P: 2. Event: President Ma Ying-jeou receiving FISU Vice President Stefan Bergh. Date and Time: 10:30 a.m., Friday, April 3, 2009. Place: Presidential Office. Press Contact: Tel.2311-3731.
