DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 3, or the eighth day of the third month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1859: The Hsiahai Chenghwang Temple, one of the oldest temples in Taiwan, is formally inaugurated in Taipei.
1881: Alcide de Gasperi, the Italian statesman who became prime minister in 1945 and led Italy during its successful post-war reconstruction, is born.
1882: Jesse James, head of the notorious outlaw James Gang and mastermind of countless bank and train robberies, is gunned down by Robert Ford, one of his own gang, at his home in St. Joseph, Missouri.
1897: German composer Johannes Brahms dies in Vienna at the age of 64. His works, which blended classical tradition with the new romantic impulse, include concertos, symphonies, chamber music, and choral compositions.
1898: Henry Luce, the American publisher who founded Time, Life, and Fortune magazines, is born.
1903: Chou Jung, author of "The Revolutionary Army," dies in jail in Shanghai at the age of 21.
1922: Joseph Stalin is appointed general secretary of the Soviet Communist Party.
1930: Helmut Kohl, the German chancellor who stayed in power for a record 16 years until his defeat by Gerhard Schroeder in 1998, is born.
1933: Four Britons in two Westland biplanes make the first flight over the peak of Mount Everest in the Himalayas.
1946: Directed by the Soviet Union, the so-called "Inner Mongolian Autonomy Movement Committee," is established in Chengteh, Jehol Province.
1948: US President Harry Truman signs the Marshall Plan, allocating US$6 billion in aid to 16 European countries to help reconstruction after World War II.
1962: President and Mme. Philbert Tsiranana of the Republic of Madagascar arrive in Taipei for a six-day state visit.
1964: The Dalai Lama establishes a Tibetan office in New York.
1971: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China issues a statement severing diplomatic relations with the Republic of Cameroon.
1973: The International Federation of Asian and Western Pacific Contractors Association opens its 12th convention in Taipei.
1975: S. K Chow, ROC minister of state, leaves for Riyadh to express the condolences of the Chinese government in the death of King Faisal.
1975: The Free China Relief Association marks its 25th anniversary.
1975: The ROC Control Yuan passes a resolution impeaching Hsu Chi-wei, commissioner of the Department of Education under the Taiwan Provincial Government.
1976: An 11-member Japanese Diet mission including former Prime Minister Nobusuke Kishi, arrives in Taipei to mark the first anniversary of the death of President Chiang Kai-shek.
1976: Dr. Montanaro, Paraguayan minister of the Interior, arrives in Taipei for Chiang's memorial services.
1982: Bueno Aires celebrates the invasion of the Falkland Islands while the United Nations says Argentina must pull out.
1991: Martha Graham, American dancer and choreographer, dies at the age of 97. A central figure in modern dance, she founded the Dance Repertory Theatre in New York City in 1930.
1992: Two weeks after a non-communist parliament is elected, Albanian President Ramiz Alia resigns.
1996: A plane carrying US Commerce Secretary Ron Brown crashes in stormy weather on a hillside outside Dubrovnik, Croatia, killing all 33 aboard.
2000: Kuomintang Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng says that the KMT has agreed to let Defense Minister Tang Fei serve as President-elect Chen Shui-bian's premier in his "personal capacity."
2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian and visiting Liberian President Charles Taylor signed a joint communique Tuesday calling on all nations to resolve international differences through dialogue, negotiations and other peaceful means.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man of strong, resolute, simple character approaches closely the true moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Fishermen thank Taipei county government over compensation issue

TEXT.P: The skipper of a Taiwanese sport fishing boat involving in a collision with a Japanese Coast Guard (JCG) vessel near the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands last year expressed gratitude Friday to the Taipei county government for offering assistance in seeking compensation from Japan, which has finally been forthcoming.

"There is such a mix of feelings after being through all the difficulties in seeking compensation from the Japanese government. Because of the Taipei county government and Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei, however, the incident has had a perfect ending," said Ho Hung-yi, skipper of the Lienho, at a thank-you party held by the Rueifang Fishermen's Association.
"They have stood with us all this time, fighting for the dignity and rights we deserve," he added.

The boat, which was carrying three crew and 13 sport fishermen at the time, sank some six nautical miles southwest of the Tiaoyutais June 10, 2008 after being hit by a Japanese coast guard patrol vessel, spurring tension between Taiwan and Japan over the long disputed uninhabited islands, over which both countries, as well as China, claim sovereignty.

After several months of intense negotiations, the JCG finally agreed to pay NT$10.5 million (US$312,500) in compensation, and the money was remitted recently to Ho, the crewmen and the fishermen involved in the incident.
Henry Chen, spokesman of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, told CNA that the ministry is gratified to see the case come to an end thanks to multilateral efforts and goodwill by both sides.
"The incident's happy ending can serve as a good example in promoting substantial bilateral relations between Taiwan and Japan, " Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan invites Singapore's participation in aerotropolis project
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, April 3 (CNA) 04/03/09 14:49:57 (By Charles Kang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taoyuan Magistrate Eric Liluan Chu hosted an introductory conference in Singapore Thursday as part of Taiwan's efforts to encourage international participation in its Taoyuan aerotropolis project.
According to Taiwanese officials, Singapore has shown great interest in the project and is one of the bidders for the contract to produce a blueprint for the project.
Singapore has also expressed its intention to bid for the construction of related facilities, the officials said.

The plan to develop the area surrounding the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport into an aerotropolis is one of the 12 i-Taiwan projects, a centerpiece of the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou.

Chu said during the conference that the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport's pivotal position in East Asia makes it a perfect choice for an aerotropolis, pointing out that it takes only an average of 2.5 hours to fly from Taoyuan to Beijing, Shanghai, Seoul, Tokyo or Manila.

In addition to government investment worth NT$400 billion (US$11.99 billion) , Taiwan is seeking to draw foreign investment worth NT$1 trillion to pay for the project, which is set to be completed in 2020, Chu said.
Taiwan is also working to ease investment restrictions for Chinese businesses so as to facilitate their participation in the project, he went on.
According to Chu, besides Singapore, businesses from the United States, Europe, Australia and Hong Kong have also expressed interest in taking part in the project.
He predicted that after the completion of the aerotropolis project, passenger and cargo traffic volume at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport will at least double.

With the existence of important airports in surrounding areas, including Singapore, Hong Kong and Shanghai, each of which have their respective functions, the Taoyuan airport will complement, rather than replace, these airports, he said.

In planning the Taoyuan aerotropolis, Taiwan will refer to the successful experience of other airports, such as the management system adopted by Singapore's Changi Airport and the residential area surrounding the Hong Kong International Airport in Chek Lap Kok, he continued.

Equally valuable to Taiwan are the creative design of Amsterdam' Schiphol Airport in the Netherlands, which includes a casino and shopping mall, as well as the Incheon International Airport in South Korea, where there is a free trade zone, Chu said.
Singapore is the second leg of Chu's foreign tour to promote the aerotropolis project, which has already taken him to Hong Kong. He is scheduled to return to Taiwan Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Coffee brewers urged to label for caffeine content

TEXT.P: With the ever-increasing popularity of fresh-brewed coffee, now one of the most popular drinks in Taiwan, chain coffee shops and convenience stores that sell fresh-brewed coffee have been urged to provide labeling for their products to denote caffeine content.

The Consumer Production Commission (CPC) under the Executive Yuan has recently renewed a call for convenience stores to follow a voluntary labeling system that nationwide coffee stores have adopted since August 2006 after they agreed with the CPC's proposal of use the colors red, yellow and green to denote different levels of caffeine content.

CPC official Liu Ching-fang explained Friday that the three-color system was formed based on research by the EU Scientific Committee on Food, which suggests that caffeine consumption of under 300 mg per day will not be harmful to the health.
Under the system, the green label marks a caffeine content of under 100 mg, while yellow represents a content of between 100 mg and 200 mg, and red signals more than 200 mg of caffeine, Liu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung mayor calls for president to open World Games

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu, who is president of the World Games 2009 Kaohsiung Organizing Committee (KOC) , called for the administration Friday to negotiate with the International World Games Association (IWGA) to allow President Ma Ying-jeou to preside over the July 16 opening of the games.

Noting that she has already invited Ma to announce the opening of the Kaohsiung World Games, Chen said it is the responsibility of every Taiwanese citizen to defend the nation's dignity, regardless of his or her political persuasion. Chen belongs to the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, while Ma is a ruling Kuomintang member.

Calling on the IWGA to respect the will of the host country, Chen stressed her strong desire to have Ma preside over the opening of the games, the biggest sports event ever to take place in Taiwan and probably her biggest challenge since she took office two years ago.

The Kaohsiung city government will write to the Sports Affairs Council to ask the top agency in charge of sports affairs to consider how Ma should attend the opening ceremony to benefit the nation to the greatest possible extent, Chen said.

Chen made the remarks after the KOC received an e-mailed letter from the IWGA Thursday urging the organizer to follow the IWGA "practice" of not having the head of state announce the opening of the games.

Hsu Ming-chun, director of the Kaohsiung City Department of Information, confirmed that day that the KOC received a letter dated April 1 from IWGA President Ron Froehlich saying that no head of state of any country has announced the opening of the World Games over its last seven incarnations.
The letter points out that all seven previous games were opened by the IWGA president or his proxy, according to Hsu.

The letter also suggests that after announcing the opening of the 2009 Kaohsiung World Games, the IWGA president or his proxy can present Ma as a special guest to give the games his blessing, allowing the president to receive the greatest possible welcome and respect, Hsu went on.
According to the published rules of the World Games, the head of the state of the host country may be invited by the president of the IWGA to declare the games event open as a guest of honor.
The Kaohsiung city government has had a new spectacular 45,000-capacity main stadium with a solar-paneled roof built for the games slated for July 16-26.

Founded in 1981, the IWGA is a non-government international organization constituted under Swiss law. Made up of International Sports Federations, the IWGA administers the World Games, which aspires to equal and exceed the importance of world championships organized by each federation individually.

DOC.HEADLINE: NPM jade cabbage souvenirs 'designed in Taiwan'

TEXT.P: Reproductions of the National Palace Museum's famous Jadeite Cabbage with Insects, sold as souvenirs by the museum, have been put back on museum store shelves after being relabeled to "better reflect the truth," an NPM official said Friday.

NPM Deputy Director Feng Ming-chu said four types of souvenirs featuring the popular cabbage design have now been given a "Designed in Taiwan" label to go along with the original "Made in China" marking on the product's packaging.

The NPM removed the souvenirs from shelves to have them relabeled after lawmakers protested that the "Made in China" label on the most prized souvenirs among Chinese tourists was not only ironic but harmed Taiwan's image.
"The new label better reflects the actual production process of the souvenir items," Feng said.
According to Feng, the museum sells more than 2,000 types of souvenirs or reproductions of its collection, of which 81 are related to the famous jade carving from the Qing Dynasty.
All 81 souvenirs related to the cabbage carving were designed in Taiwan, but four were manufactured in China and have been relabeled, she said.
Feng said the museum appreciated the timely "reminder" from lawmakers and the local media that it should review its procurement policy.

Speaking at a meeting of the legislature's Transportation Committee April 1, ruling Kuomintang Legislator Chiang Lien-fu said it was ironic and pathetic that the reproductions bought in such large volumes by Chinese tourists turned out to be made in China.
Fellow KMT lawmaker Chu Fong-chi characterized it as "shameful" that products sold at Taiwan's flagship museum were made in China.

Janice Lai, director-general of the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, said at the time that the practice is not uncommon, as bureau officials also found China-made woodcarvings on sale in shops in Sanyi, Miaoli County -- Taiwan's center for wooden handicrafts and artistic products.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait chain store association established in Taipei

TEXT.P: A cross-Taiwan Strait association of chain stores was established Thursday in Taipei with the participation of some 300 Taiwanese chain stores and franchise operators based in Taiwan and China.
The association was formally inaugurated by 60 local operators at a ceremony in Taipei City that was also witnessed by the other China-based companies via a video link in Shanghai.

Association convener Wang Kuo-an said that by taking advantage of its good relations with major international investors, the association will build a platform to help franchise and chain store operators in Taiwan and China list on stock exchanges and over-the-counter markets.

The association will also work to promote cooperation between chain store and franchise operators in Taiwan and China, hold franchise trade shows and seminars, push for the formation of strategic alliance and provide other services.

Wang said many chains have attracted the attention of prominent investment fund managers because of their development potential in Taiwan and their ability to tap into China's market, with some already having foreign shareholders.

Chains such as Yicha Yizuo Tea House, Bobodog, Real Brewed Tea Tea House, bathroom fixtures maker Hocheng Corp., karaoke parlor operator Golden Jaguar Group, Dio Coffee, C. Straits Coffee and Tony Wear have sold stakes to foreign equity firms Carlyle and Goldman Sachs, Wang said.

Franchises such as family entertainment operator Tom's World Amusement Corp., 85XC Coffee, Ay-Chung Flour Rice Noodle and SUSHI Group are also expected to draw funds from foreign investors in the future, Wang added.
Others being eyed by foreign investors include houseware retailer Working House, Merry Spa and Giraffe English School.

DOC.HEADLINE: Airfare subsidies for remote islanders to take effect Sunday

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan on Friday approved a new program of airfare subsidies for residents of remote Taiwan-held islands that will reduce their cost of air travel to Taiwan proper by up to 40 percent when they take effect Sunday.

The new measure will benefit residents living on Green Island and Orchid Island off Taiwan's southeastern coast, Nangan Island and Beigan Island in the Matsu island group, and Chimei Island and Wanan Island in Penghu County, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications said.
The individuals who will be helped by the updated subsidy plan will take an estimated 51,500 flights between the islands and Taiwan proper annually.
Under the program, residents of Kinmen and Penghu counties will have 20 percent of the cost of air travel between Taiwan and their home islands subsidized, as was the case previously.

But residents living on Nangan and Beigan will receive subsidies of 30 percent of their airfares and those living in Chimei, Wanan, Green and Orchid islands will have 40 percent of their air travel costs to Taiwan covered by the program.
Subsidies for the program are expected to total NT$292 million (US$8.71 million) this year, NT$23.3 million higher than the 2008 level.
The measure can be retroactively applied to the period between Jan. 25 and April 4 -- one day before it formally takes effect.

CAA Director-General Lee Long-wen said March 19 that residents of smaller islands will receive higher subsidies because the small airplanes used to fly between their islands and Taiwan proper are more easily affected by weather conditions, unlike the larger aircraft used to fly the Kinmen-Taiwan and Penghu- Taiwan routes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-Japan working holiday program to come into effect on June 1

TEXT.P: A program to allow young people from Taiwan and Japan to work while traveling in each other's country will be officially launched on June, 1, after the two countries completed an agreement Friday, according the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), adding that the program will foster closer ties between the two sides.

We hope that this program will further strengthen exchanges between young adults of Taiwan and Japan, as well as bolster substantial bilateral relations,said MOFA spokesman Henry Chen at a news conference.

As Taiwan has designated 2009 as the year to boost relations with Japan, the working holiday agreement is part of efforts to foster closer cooperation and exchanges between the two countries, Chen added.
According to Chen, Japan is the third country to sign a working holiday agreement with Taiwan, which signed similar pacts with Australia and New Zealand in 2004.

Hsu Juei-hu, deputy secretary-general of the MOFAs Association for East Asian Relations, said at the news conference that starting June 1, young Taiwanese and Japanese nationals aged 18-30 can apply to the Taipei-based Interchange Association for a working holiday visa to work on a short-term basis while visiting the others country. The visas are valid for one year.
Individuals can only join the program once in their life, Hsu added.
Japan at present has similar programs with 10 countries and is expected to sign one with Hong Kong this year, Hsu said. He added that the agreement between Taiwan and Japan is the same as the others.

Taiwan and Japan would each offer 2,000 openings in the first year of the program and will increase the number in the coming years depending on the popularity of the program, Hsu said. The slots of a similar program between Japan and South Korea have been increased from 1,000 in 2000 to 7,200 in 2009, and is expected to be raised to 10,000 by 2012, he said.

Hsu expressed confidence in the program, saying that it will gain enormous popularity among young adults, given that the Interchange Association has been receiving 15-20 inquiries a day since the proposal was disclosed.
Applicants would not be required to speak the other countrys language, Hsu said, adding that details involving financial proof and job hunting will be hammered out in upcoming negotiations.

Taiwan and Japan have maintained close relations in the absence of formal diplomatic ties. The Japanese government granted visa-free entry to Taiwanese citizens in 2007, and the two sides that year also began recognizing each others drivers licenses.
Frequent exchanges between people from the two countries can also be seen, with an average 2.5 million citizens traveling between the two countries each year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tourist arrivals from Beijing to Taiwan jump 53 percent in March

TEXT.P: The number of Chinese visitors on group tours coming from Beijing to Taiwan increased by 53 percent in March compared to February, according to a report by the mainland-based semi-official China News Service.

Judging from recent tallies, the report said, it is apparent that the daily tourist departures from China for Taiwan in March had exceeded 1,000 on average, while the number of Chinese tourists using the "mini links" has been on a steady rise.
The mini links refer to direct ferry service between Taiwan's outlying Kinmen and Matsu islands and China's Xiamen, Mawei and Quanzhou ports in Fujian Province.

The report said the number of Chinese tourists to Taiwan is expected to increase markedly because beginning in December last year, Chinese people from 25 cities and provinces, compared to 13 cities and provinces previously, are allowed to sight-see in Taiwan, while the number of travel agencies authorized to organize tours to Taiwan also rose to 146, from 33.
The newly added 113 travel agencies have already started arranging tours to Taiwan from late March, it said.
As travel costs to Taiwan have been brought down after a larger number of tour agencies began operating in the market, it will further boost Chinese tourist numbers to Taiwan, the report added.

According to the report, over the past six month, no Chinese tourists have filed complaints about their trips to Taiwan. It cited a survey made by Taiwanese authorities as reporting that 86 percent of Chinese visitors were satisfied with their tours to Taiwan.
Taiwan and China adopted measures to boost cross-Taiwan Strait tourism and launched regular direct flights in July last year, with the transportation links expanded in December.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices on Taipei bourse surge on heavy turnover

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices rose for the fourth consecutive day Friday amid optimism that the United States economy is stabilizing, sending the market's benchmark index past the 5,500-point mark for the first time since early October.
Led by financial shares, the Taiex advanced 55.85 points, or 1.02 percent, to close at 5,529.63 on turnover of NT$161.96 billion (US$4.85 billion), the highest turnover this year.

The local bourse opened at 5,541.34 and fluctuated between 5,567.15 and 5,482.18, buoyed by a US$1.1 trillion deal to revive the global economy reached at the G20 summit in London and the European Central Bank's decision to cut interest rates.
A total of 8.53 billion shares changed hands.
Six of eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares surging the most at 4.1 percent, buoyed by the appreciation of the Taiwan dollar against the U.S. greenback.

Cement stocks rose 3.8 percent, foodstuff shares moved up 3.4 percent, construction stocks advanced 3.3 percent, textile stocks increased 1.1 percent, paper and pulp issues rose 1.0 percent, and machinery and electronics shares moved up 0.4 percent.
Only paper and pulp issues, which fell 1.0 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares, which shed 0.3 percent, lost ground.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,320 to 699, with 159 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$4.78 billion.
Analysts said gains in financial shares may be sustained until a long- anticipated financial supervision agreement is signed between Taiwan and China before the middle of the year.
They also believed that despite the possibility of selling pressure in the short term, the Taiex could challenge the 6,000 threshold in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, falling NT$0.2 to close at NT$33.380.
A total of US$2.06 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$33.580 and reached a low of 33.202.

DOC.HEADLINE: Law against unexplained wealth enacted

TEXT.P: A "sunshine bill" that makes it a crime for government officials to hold unexplained wealth was passed into law Friday, a measure authorities hope will curb corruption in the public sector and combat money laundering.

The amendment to the Punishment of Corruption Act, passed by the Legislative Yuan with bipartisan support, stipulates that public functionaries suspected of corruption will face jail terms of up to three years if they cannot account for assets in their possession.

Under the revision, prosecutors can require suspected officials to explain the sources of their wealth if the value of the assets held by them or their families rises in any of the three years after prosecutors discover irregularities by more than the income reported in their tax returns for the most recent fiscal year.
The law also stipulates that any sum that cannot be justified by a public official under investigation will be confiscated by the government.
Justice Minister Wang Ching-feng said the law will not be applied retroactively.

The passage last year of an amendment to the Public Functionary Assets Disclosure Law, which added 9,000 senior officials and public functionaries to the list of the country's civil servants required to report their assets, means that more public officials will be subject to the new unexplained wealth clause.
Before the amendment was enacted, only 1,800 senior public functionaries were subject to the reporting requirement, according to the Control Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan eighth largest recipient of Australian working holiday visas

TEXT.P: Taiwan is now the eighth largest recipient of working holiday visas issued by the Australian government, an indication that the holiday option is growing increasingly popular among Taiwanese citizens.

During the 2007-2008 fiscal year that ended June 30, Australia issued a total of 154,148 working holiday visas worldwide, 6,132 of which were issued to Taiwanese applicants, according to statistics from the Australian Visa Services under the Australian Commerce and Industry Office released Friday.

With the number of working holiday visas granted to Taiwan so far this year 2.7 times more than the number issued in the previous year, Australia's representative office in Taiwan predicted that the total number would exceed 10,000 for the 2008-2009 fiscal year.

Taiwan joined Australia's working holiday program in 2004 and is now one of 18 participants in the program that also includes the United Kingdom, Canada, the Netherlands, Ireland, Sweden, Denmark, Norway, Finland, Italy, France, Japan, Malta, South Korea, Hong Kong, Germany, Belgium and Estonia.
Only those aged 18-30 are eligible to apply for the special visa that allows the holders to stay up to 12 months in Australia, during which they can undertake incidental employment.

The best known Taiwanese holder of the Australian working holiday visa may be Clare Wang, the Taiwanese woman who earned a wild card into the final round of the competition for what is being advertised as "the best job in the world" -- caretaker of a group of islands on Australia's Great Barrier Reef. The drive was launched by Australia's Tourism Queensland, the tourism promotion authority of the Queensland state government.

Wang, who obtained the visa last year but did not travel to Australia immediately, is scheduled to depart Saturday for Australia using the visa. She will spend a month there preparing for the job's final selection process slated for May 3-6.

Wang will compete with 15 other finalists from 14 different countries for the six-month A$150,000 (US$107,306) contract to work on Hamilton Island. The winner will be granted a business visitor visa to undertake the job.

Kimberly Chien, marketing manager of the Tourism Queensland's Taiwan office, said the caretaker recruitment drive has successfully raised the interest and curiosity of Taiwanese in the Great Barrier Reef, which is evident from the influx of phone calls requesting information about ways to visit the world's largest coral reef system.

Chien said, however, that she does not expect any immediate increase in the number of Taiwanese visitors to the area, because there is no direct flight from Taiwan to the area and package tours remain the most popular travel options among Taiwanese. ENITEM/ls

DOC.HEADLINE: Foundation unveils list of role models for love of life

TEXT.P: The Chou Ta-Kuan Cultural and Educational Foundation announced Friday 12 winners of this year's Fervent Global Love of Lives Award who will be honored at a ceremony in June in Taipei.
The 12 winners were selected from 1,929 candidates recommended by various sectors around the world for their excellence in their fields, according to the foundation.

Cheng Mei-chu, a painter from Taiwan's outlying island of Penghu who was born with Ichthyosis--a severe genetic skin disorder--was selected as a recipient for her pursuit of the arts with passion and dedication, despite her physical disability.

Another recipient was Daniel Gottlieb, an American practicing psychologist and family therapist, who has been paralyzed from the neck down since a nearly fatal automobile accident in 1979. He was chosen for his devotion to family and his career by overcoming paralysis.
Also on the list was Wang Hung-yi, who founded a one-person band and performed overseas by using recycled musical instruments.

Among the recipients was Mark Inglis, a New Zealand mountaineer who lost both legs after he was trapped in an ice cave for two weeks due to a storm in 1982. Inglis was recognized for his dedication to helping physically disadvantaged individuals. He also won a silver medal at the 2000 Paralympics in the 1,000 meter cycling individual time trial.
Another winner was Wu Chung-yun, a third grader from an elementary school in Taichung who became completely blind as a result of a brain tumor, but has completed 132 paintings.
The awards will be presented at a ceremony on June 4.
The foundation was founded in 1997 by the parents of Chou Ta-kuan in memory of their son who died of cancer. Ta-kuan was a young poet who had great enthusiasm for life.
Aimed at promoting Ta-kuan's love for life, his parents have sponsored various activities and programs via the foundation, including organizing the award.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan can rebound quickly if operations center plan is ready

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy will rebound quickly if the government can develop basic measures that establish Taiwan as a global operations center, the head of the Taipei Computer Association (TCA) said Friday.

J.T. Wang, TCA chairman and chairman and CEO of Acer Inc., said the government does not need to do much to turn the situation around but whatever it does must be focused with a clear theme, which he believed should be to create "complementary measures for Taiwan to become a global operations headquarters."

Speaking at a meeting on China-based Taiwanese businesses investing in Taiwan, Wang also suggested that corporate income taxes for companies setting up their global headquarters here be set at 15 percent rather than the current 25 percent and that revenues or dividends remitted back to Taiwan from overseas branches not be taxed.
He also advocated that the highest marginal tax rate on the income of top executives be lowered to 12 percent from the present 40 percent.

Wang argued that with the improvement in cross-strait relations, if Taiwan can tackle several cross-strait and major economic issues, then its economy will rebound more quickly than any other countries in the world.
"If a new wave of growth arrives, we will definitely be on the crest of the wave, " the Acer CEO asserted. "I have always been relatively optimistic about the new situation."

Wang said that while the global economic slowdown has affected Taiwan, the relaxation of strained ties between Taiwan and China since the inauguration of President Ma Ying-jeou last May has been positive.
The "positive side has outweighed the negative side, " Wang said. "We have a big opportunity to take advantage of the 'positive, ' and there's no need to be pessimistic."

DOC.HEADLINE: Yunlin County-made soy sauce gains halal certification

TEXT.P: Yunlin County Magistrate Su Chih-fen saluted a nearly 70-year-old local soy sauce maker Friday as a pioneer in leading the county into the Muslim market after the producer gained halal certification in March.
Su sent several agricultural officials earlier in the day to the company's headquarters in Douliou City to congratulate the firm on her behalf, according to the county's Bureau of Agriculture.

The bureau said it was the first agricultural product made in Yunlin County to receive halal certification, which confirms that the approved product is permissable under Islamic law and can be ingested by Muslims.

Su described the certification is the first step taken by the south-central county's agricultural products into the global Muslim market, a market composed of up to 1.4 billion Muslims with considerable spending power that no country in the world can ignore.

Yunlin County, one of Taiwan's most important agricultural regions, is looking to diversify its markets for its many agricultural products, which include fruits such as pomelos and papayas and coffee.

DOC.HEADLINE: 23 Taiwan-born Chinese senior citizens arrive in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 3 (CNA) 04/03/09 22:03:30 (By H. Y. Chou and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A group of 23 high-profile Chinese senior citizens flew into Taipei from Beijing Friday, one day before Tomb-Sweeping Day, for a 10-day visit in the land where they were born but have grown apart from over the past 60 years.

The group composed of elite Taiwanese men and women in China, led by Lin Liyun, an adviser to the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , arrived at Taipei Songshan Airport to a warm greeting from friends and relatives.

Lin, a member of the Communist Party's Central Committee for five terms and who once served as Japanese secretary to late Chinese Premier Zhou Enlai, is China's most prominent female politician from Taiwan.
Lin thanked "Taiwanese compatriots" for the hospitality she immediately felt upon arriving in Taiwan and expressed hope for a continued turnabout in cross- Taiwan Strait relations.
Since settling in Beijing in 1952, she had previously visited Taiwan only once, in 1999. She still has relatives in Taiwan.
The group's visit to Taiwan, the first of its kind in 60 years, was possible as a result of improved ties between the two countries over the past year.
Hsu Wun-pin, an adviser to President Ma Ying-jeou, helped arrange the group's visit.

Most of the group's members moved to China after 1949, when the Nationalists retreated to Taiwan after losing China's civil war, and had been denied entry to Taiwan several times as a result of the delicate political situation across the Taiwan Strait.
Two members of the group had never returned to Taiwan since leaving their hometowns in their youth.
The eldest of the group members is 86 years old and the youngest, 73.

During their 10-day visit in Taiwan, they will tour cultural and scenic attractions, including Sun Moon Lake in central Nantou County, and Taroko National Park and the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation in eastern Hualien County.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislature passes amendment to Local Government Act

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed an amendment to the Local Government Act Friday, finalizing the legal basis for cities and counties to apply for an upgrade of their municipal status.

Under the revised law, the Ministry of the Interior is authorized to outline plans to adjust administrative organizations based on the need for better utilization of national land and resources, as well as balanced regional and urban-rural development
Local governments are also eligible to propose that their municipal status be upgraded, but the law stipulates the Executive Yuan has the authority to make the final decision on such plans.
Among the areas expected to be affected by the passage of the revision are Taichung City and Taichung County, which have expressed an interest in integrating into a special muncipality.

By becoming a special municipality, Taichung City and Taichung County, or any other administrative district, will get a bigger share of central government funding and be allowed to increase local government staffing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Locally made human bird flu vaccine to be ready for clinical trial

TEXT.P: A locally developed emergency vaccine against the virulent H5N1 bird flu strain is expected to be ready for clinical trial in the second half of this year, a senior Department of Health (DOH) official said Friday.

The emergency vaccine, developed by the National Health Research Institute, will mainly be used for emergency use in the event of an H5N1 outbreak among humans, said Shih Wen-yi, deputy director of the DOH's Centers for Disease Control.

According to Shih, the DOH is scheduled to authorize clinical trials for the locally developed bird flu vaccines in the second quarter of this year, and the first phase of the trials are expected to get underway in the third quarter.
As the research institute has a limited production capacity, Shih said, the locally developed vaccine will only be enough for emergency use if Taiwan is struck by an H5N1 outbreak in humans.
A few years ago, the DOH launched a BOO (build-operate-own) project under which a private contractor was picked to produce locally developed human bird flu vaccines.
The bid, however, was dropped because the winning contractor was later merged into another entity in a corporate restructuring.
Shih said the DOH is appraising the feasibility of renewing the BOO project to draw the private sector into investing in human H5N1 vaccine production.

DOC.HEADLINE: Malaysian woman becomes 1 millionth visitor to Taiwan this year

TEXT.P: A Malaysian woman turned out to be the 1 millionth visitor to Taiwan for 2009, customs inspectors at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport said Friday.
Yap Ah Mooi, 51, arrived at the airport in northern Taiwan Friday evening via a China Airlines flight along with 34 of her colleagues on a seven-day company vacation, customs sources said.

Yap appeared to be surprised and overjoyed after customs officers informed her that she was the 1 millionth visitor to Taiwan this year and would receive an NT$100,000 (about US$2,995.8) credit card balance to spend in Taiwan.
She was also presented with many other exquisite gifts, including Taipei and Kaohsiung metro VIP cards and Hakka-style fabrics.

According to tourist officials, this year's 1 millionth visitor arrived two days ahead of last year's. They attributed this year's faster rate of visitor arrivals to the increasing number of Chinese tourists visiting the country.
They also predicted that the total visitor arrivals for 2009 is likely to reach 4 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: List of merged cities and counties to be unveiled in early September

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Liao Liou-yi said Friday that the list of cities and counties that will be merged will come out no later than early September.

Liao noted that the Central Election Commission is scheduled to promulgate the year-end, three-in-one elections, including local city and county chief elections, Sept. 4, so that the list should be ready as early as possible and "not be too close to that date."

The heads of the administrative districts in line to be merged under the new revision would have their terms extended for a year, meaning that any merger plans would have to be submitted by the deadline laid out by the MOI to avoid holding local elections on December 5 this year.

Liao's remarks came after the Legislative Yuan passed an amendment of the Local Government Law, which will provide a legal basis for cities or counties to be upgraded to municipalities either individually or by merging with other cities and counties.

The political implications of the bill actually prompted the opposition Democratic Progressive Party to block it during the previous legislative session late last year, but opposition resistance was quelled in recent deliberations over the amendment.

Under the amended law passed Friday, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) can propose upgrading administrative districts based on the reasonable planning of national land or the nation's development needs.

Local city or county governments can also take the initiative to draft upgrading plans and after the city or county councils approve the plans, they will be submitted for the approval of the Executive Yuan via the MOI.

Liao said the passage of the amended law not only provides the legal basis for city or county upgrading, but also marks the "beginning of a major task of adjusting Taiwan's administrative districts and local government reforms."
He suggested those cities and counties that have the intention to merge to submit merger plans to his ministry by May 31.
"The MOI will handle the plans based on the principles of fairness and openness," he added.
The passage of the amended law is a big step toward helping fulfill President Ma Ying-jeou's campaign promise to merge Taichung city and county and upgrade it into special municipal status.

Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said Friday that he will begin related proceedings for the merger with Taichung County, hoping that the city and county councils will pass the plan in early May to submit their application early enough to the MOI.
While Taichung city and county are expected to take advantage of the legal revision, the Cabinet may also be tested by calls for upgrading from Tainan city and county and Kaohsiung city and county.
Koahsiung Mayor Chen Chu said that city was upgraded into a special municipality more than a decade ago, and the merger of the Kaohsiung city and county should be a natural development.
"If the central government handles the application in a fair manner, then there is no reason for the merger to come later than that of Taichung city and county," Chen added.
Kaohsung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing also said that city and county merger plan should be handled in tandem with the Taichung city and county merger.
Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih said that he had called Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair, and hopes that the merger plan will be passed by the city and county councils by the end of May.
On the other hand, Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei said Friday that his county should be upgraded ahead of Taichung city and county.

According to a previous amendment to the Local Government Law, any county with a population exceeding 2 million could enjoy the same rights as a special municipality in terms of personnel, government structure and finances before receiving formal approval by the Executive Yuan.
Based on that previous revision, Taipei County was substantively upgraded into a special municipality in 2007, but has yet to be formally recognized as one by the Executive Yuan.
Chou stressed that Taipei County currently has a population of 3.84 million, outnumbering the 2.6 million of Taichung city and county combined or any other cities or counties.
"If Taipei County is approved later than others by the Executive Yuan, then it will seriously affect the interests of Taipei County residents," he stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 4, or the ninth day of the third month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1581: Sir Francis Drake, who in 1580 became the first Englishman to circumnavigate the globe, is knighted in London by Queen Elizabeth I. The English naval hero later became vice admiral of the fleet that destroyed the Spanish Armada in 1588.
1617: John Napier, the Scottish mathematician who invented logarithms and introduced the use of the decimal point in writing numbers, dies at the age of 67.
1841: William Henry Harrison, the ninth president of the United States, dies of pneumonia at the age of 68 after only one month in office.
1900: Prince Edward, heir to the throne of England, narrowly escapes death when a teenage anarchist fires two shots at the prince who is on a train in a Brussels station.
1905: An earthquake rocks Lahore, then part of British India, killing some 19,000 people.
1932: The Republic of China observes its first Children's Day. Children have the day off from school.
1942: Japanese forces sink three British warships in the Bay of Bengal.
1949: The foreign ministers of Belgium, Britain, Canada, France, Holland, Luxembourg, Norway, Denmark, Iceland, Italy, Portugal and the United States sign the North Atlantic Treaty in Washington to protect Western nations from Soviet aggression.
1950: The Chinese Refugees Relief Association is inaugurated.
1967: Australian Prime Minister Harold E. Holt arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1968: Dr. Martin Luther King, the American civil rights leader who won the 1964 Nobel Peace Prize, is assassinated at a motel in Memphis, Tennessee. His eloquence and commitment to nonviolent tactics formed the foundation of the civil rights movement of the 1950's and 1960's.
1973: The Republic of China and the Khmer Republic conclude a temporary air transport agreement with an exchange of notes in Phnom Penh.
1974: The 21-member women's national basketball team returns after a tour of the United States and Brazil. The team won 24 games and lost six.
1974: The Republic of China suspends diplomatic relations with Botswana.
1974: U.S. Ambassador Walter P. McConaughy and his wife leave Taipei for retirement. He is succeeded by Ambassador Leonard Unger.
1976: Chinese at home and abroad mark the first anniversary of the passing of President Chiang Kai-shek with solemn ceremonies, tributes and prayers.
1979: Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, Pakistan's former president who was deposed by Gen. Zia ul-Haq in 1977, is hanged in Rawalpindi for the alleged murder of a political opponent.
1980: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo presides over a ceremony marking the inauguration of the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.
1983: The United States grants political asylum to Hu Na, a noted tennis player from mainland China.
1989: The Ministry of Education approves the applications of three mainlanders to visit Taiwan.
1990: Communist China's legislature approves the Basic Law, the constitution that will govern Hong Kong after it reverts to Chinese sovereignty in 1997.
1990: Britain publishes a bill to grant citizenship to up to 225,000 Hong Kong residents in the run-up to the colony's handover to mainland China in 1997.
1994: A communist Chinese court sentences Si Yang, a reporter at Hong Kong's Ming Pao newspaper, to 12 years in prison for "stealing and probing national secrets."
1999: At the conclusion of a weeklong visit to Taiwan, prominent mainland Chinese dissident Wang Dan urges Beijing to abandon threatening Taiwan with military aggression.
2000: Paraguayan President Luis Gonzalez Macchi reiterates that his country's stance of supporting the Republic of China in international forums will never change.
2001: Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, meets with opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong in Taipei to exchange views on issues of mutual concern.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman must be sympathetic, obliging and affectionate: sympathetic and obliging to his friends and affectionate to the members of his family."

DOC.HEADLINE: Malaysian woman becomes 1 millionth visitor to Taiwan this year

TEXT.P: A Malaysian woman turned out to be the 1 millionth visitor to Taiwan for 2009, customs inspectors at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport said Friday.
Yap Ah Mooi, 51, arrived at the airport in northern Taiwan Friday evening via a China Airlines flight along with 34 of her colleagues on a seven-day company vacation, customs sources said.

Yap appeared to be surprised and overjoyed after customs officers informed her that she was the 1 millionth visitor to Taiwan this year and would receive an NT$100,000 (about US$2,995.8) credit card balance to spend in Taiwan.
She was also presented with many other exquisite gifts, including Taipei and Kaohsiung metro VIP cards and Hakka-style fabrics.

According to tourist officials, this year's 1 millionth visitor arrived two days ahead of last year's. They attributed this year's faster rate of visitor arrivals to the increasing number of Chinese tourists visiting the country.
They also predicted that the total visitor arrivals for 2009 is likely to reach 4 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Locally made human bird flu vaccine to be ready for clinical trial

TEXT.P: A locally developed emergency vaccine against the virulent H5N1 bird flu strain is expected to be ready for clinical trial in the second half of this year, a senior Department of Health (DOH) official said Friday.

The emergency vaccine, developed by the National Health Research Institute, will mainly be used for emergency use in the event of an H5N1 outbreak among humans, said Shih Wen-yi, deputy director of the DOH's Centers for Disease Control.

According to Shih, the DOH is scheduled to authorize clinical trials for the locally developed bird flu vaccines in the second quarter of this year, and the first phase of the trials are expected to get underway in the third quarter.
As the research institute has a limited production capacity, Shih said, the locally developed vaccine will only be enough for emergency use if Taiwan is struck by an H5N1 outbreak in humans.
A few years ago, the DOH launched a BOO (build-operate-own) project under which a private contractor was picked to produce locally developed human bird flu vaccines.
The bid, however, was dropped because the winning contractor was later merged into another entity in a corporate restructuring.
Shih said the DOH is appraising the feasibility of renewing the BOO project to draw the private sector into investing in human H5N1 vaccine production.

Meanwhile, a research team headed by Academia Sinica President Chi-Huey Wong at the institute's Genomics Research Center has developed DNA-based vaccines against both human influenza and avian flu, academic sources said Friday.
According to the sources, the procedual platform developed by the team can produce such DNA-based vaccines for emergency use within six months.
The team's research findings have been published in the noted American science journal "Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America."

DOC.HEADLINE: Authoritarian parenting keeps children away from parents: survey

TEXT.P: A recent survey has found that authoritarian parenting is what keeps children distant from parents, prompting the local child welfare promotion organization that released the survey Saturday to urge parents to spend more time with their children.

The nonprofit Child Welfare League Foundation (CWLF) suggested at a news conference that parents follow the "Love Your Child 333 Guidelines" by hugging their children for 30 seconds, listening to them for 3 minutes and spending at least 30 minutes with them every day.

First lady Chow Mei-ching said at the news conference that parents should cherish the time they have with their children while they are still young, not only because the children need such companionship but also because they grow up so quickly.

"Parents are the most important teachers, family, friends and companions that children need when they are growing up -- a period of time that flies by so quickly if parents do not cherish it, " Chow said.
CWLF Chairwoman Joyce Feng said that regardless how busy they are, parents should schedule time in their daily lives to spend time with their children.
Parents' company cannot be replaced with pets or toys, though they might serve as substitutes when parents are busy, she added.

The survey found that while 92.2 percent of the children polled said they like going home, the overall score of their "family life" is 74, lower than the 76 score for "school life" and 80 for "physical and mental status."

The main reason for that is because of authoritarian parenting, the survey found, noting that 47.2 percent of children are rarely praised by parents when they are good, 29 percent are frequently asked to be quiet while adults are talking, and 13.8 percent often receive verbal or physical punishment.

As to school life, 61.7 percent of the children said they feel stress over schoolwork and experience a lot of academic pressure, 23.3 percent said they don't like going to school, and 9.6 percent said they are often bullied by classmates.
The survey, however, found that most children are still optimistic and hold a positive attitude in dealing with problems they face in life.

When asked to evaluate their physical and mental well-being, 88.6 percent said they are both physically and mentally healthy, while 86.7 percent said they like their lives the way they are at present.

The survey, which distributed questionnaires to grade 4,5, and 6 elementary school students, was conducted at the end of 2008. The poll, which has a margin of error of plus or minus 2 percentage points at a confidence level of 99 percent, collected 4,487 valid samples.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei bids for right to host 2015 Universiade

TEXT.P: Taipei is bidding for the right to host the World University Games in 2015, with the city government seemingly confident of success.

Emile C. J. Sheng, chairman of the city's Research Development and Evaluation Commission, said Taipei's considerable experience in organizing international sports events and its emphasis on sports development are factors favoring its bid.

Sheng made the remarks in an interview with the Central News Agency Friday after talks with visiting members of the Federation Internationale du Sport Universitaire (FISU) , the organizer of the biennial World University Games, also known formally as the Universiade.
Sheng said the city is well prepared to host the event because 10 of the 16 events held in the Summer Universiade will be part of the 21st Summer Deaflympics 2009, to be held in Taipei Sept. 5-15.
For other Universiade events not included in the Deaflympics, such as baseball and weightlifting, the city is well-equipped to handle those competitions, the official said.

Sheng said he believed the FISU would take the enthusiasm of Taiwan's government for promoting sports activities and the hospitality and friendliness of Taipei's residents into account in deciding the host of the 2015 event.
Those factors, however, were non-factors in Kaohsiung's bid in 2007 to hold the 2011 Summer World University Games.

The southern port city went into the vote expecting a positive outcome, but ended up being the second of five cities eliminated during the voting process because its bid package only committed US$8 million in rights fees and other funding to the FISU.

Shenzhen, China, which proposed a US$22 million package, won the right to host the 2011 event, prompting Taiwan's FISU representative to observe that money played the decisive role in the competition.
Sheng said the FISU is scheduled to announce next month the winner of the competition between Taipei, South Korea's Gwangju and Canada's Edmonton to host the 2015 Universiade.
Gwangju was a losing finalist for the 2013 Games awarded to Kazan, Russia last year.
Meanwhile, visiting FISU Vice President Stefan Bergh said he was impressed by Taipei when he visited the city three years ago.

Given that Chinese Taipei (as Taiwan is formally known in international competition) has been one of the most active FISU members, Bergh said he was delighted to see Taipei mounting a bid to host the Universiade.

Sheng said that if Taiwan wins the bid, it will receive the support of the central government to build another multi-functional stadium in addition to the planned "Taipei Dome " and a national tennis center.
The three construction projects will cost some 1.2 billion euros, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Families' spending on children remains strong amid recession: poll

TEXT.P: The recession may have cut into the incomes of most local households, but more than half of Taiwan's families are still spending as much on their children as before the economic downturn, a survey conducted by online 1111 Job Bank has found.

According to the results of the online survey released Saturday, 77.35 percent of respondents said they have seen their incomes fall during the economic downturn triggered by last September's global financial storm, with their incomes declining by an average 28.79 percent compared to six months ago.
The fall-off has been mainly caused by unemployment, work changes, cuts in pay and unpaid leave.
Among those respondents whose take-home pay had fallen, however, 56.71 percent said they were spending as much on their children, including for their education, as when they enjoyed higher incomes.
These parents explained that they believe their children's future is more important than money and that they would rather cut other family spending than sums spent on their children.

Of the 43.79 percent of respondents who said they had cut spending on their children after their incomes fell, some noted that the savings mainly came from dining out or traveling less or cutting back on entertainment, such as watching movies, and toys, according to the survey.
The online survey was conducted among white-collar workers with children from March 18 to March 31. A total of 437 valid samples were collected.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two men arrested for smuggling 4.7 kg of heroin

TEXT.P: Two individuals have been arrested for allegedly smuggling 4,705 grams of heroin into Taiwan, police in Kaohsiung announced Saturday.
Police said one of the suspects, surnamed Chen, purchased the heroin in Thailand and hid it in the wall of a specially made 20-kilogram iron barrel to skirt its detection by X-ray machines.
Chen also tightly sealed the lid of the barrel with wax and covered it in butter to prevent sniffing dogs from picking up the illicit drug's scent.
He then mailed the barrel to Taiwan by air mail to a Kaohsiung County resident surnamed Fu, declaring the shipment as motorbike parts and components.
Acting on a tip, police raided Fu's residence in Kaohsiung County Friday and seized the heroin before arresting Chen in Kaohsiung City later the same day.

DOC.HEADLINE: American office supplies retailer to seek suppliers in Taiwan

TEXT.P: High-ranking executives of Office Max, one of the largest office supplies vendors in the United States, plan to visit Taiwan next week to look for suppliers of office products and stationery, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Saturday.

According to a TAITRA statement, three executives from the company's headquarters in charge of global procurement will come to Taiwan to organize a sample show and procurement policy presentation at the Taipei World Trade Center April 7.
Executives from the Office Max's branches in Australia and New Zealand will also be in attendance.

Office Max, headquartered in Naperville, Illinois and specializing in sales of office supplies, office technology and office furniture to businesses, had sales of US$9 billion in 2008, the statement said.
The company purchased US$22 million in goods from Taiwan in 2007 and US$16 million last year, TAITRA said, describing Office Max as a big buyer hoping to create business opportunities on the island.
TAITRA is a semi-official organization founded in 1970 to assist local businesses in exploring and expanding overseas markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: Wang opens new Yankee Stadium with exhibition win
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 4 (CNA) 04/04/09 18:27:22 (By Huang Jaw-pyng and Luke Sabatier)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Chien-Ming Wang opened the new US$1.5 billion Yankee Stadium with an exhibition win over the Chicago Cubs Friday night, another milestone in the 29-year-old right-hander's career with the New York Yankees.

Wang did not particularly distinguish himself, allowing four earned runs on six hits in five innings of work, but still got the win in front of a near capacity crowd of 48,402 with the help of home runs by Robinson Cano, Hideki Matsui, and Cody Ransom.
Wang's first pitch -- a trademark sinker -- was a strike, drawing thunderous applause from the crowd as light bulbs flashed around the park to record the historical moment.
"It's a new stadium, and I wanted to throw the first strike, " said Wang. "When I went out to the mound, I didn't have any special feeling and I wasn't nervous. I just wanted to focus."

Friday night's outing was Wang's final appearance of the exhibition season, which he finished with a 4.15 ERA. Wang admitted that he will need to be better when he starts the Yankees second regular season game in Baltimore April 8.
"I had trouble controlling the break on the sinker, " Wang said, admitting he left some of his sinkers too high. "I have to quickly get back my velocity."

Wang trailed early after yielding a run in the first and two runs in the second on a two-out RBI double by Aaron Miles, but pitched a scoreless third inning by relying on more change-ups and sliders, pitches he felt he controlled better Friday night than his normally reliable sinker.

Considered the No. 2 starter in the Yankees rotation behind newly acquired C.C. Sabathia, Wang is hoping for greater success than in 2008, when his season was curtailed in June after injuring his foot rounding third base in an interleague game against the Houston Astros.
Wang had won 19 games each of the previous two seasons, and the Yankees are counting on him to repeat that success in 2009 to make their opening season in their new stadium a memorable one.

The Yankees are playing two exhibition games this weekend against the Cubs to get acclimated to the new ballpark, but Wang said the new stadium was similar to the old one and that he has already figured out what he needs to know.
"I know how to get from the parking lot to the locker room," Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan should take immediate step to preserve biodiversity: expert

TEXT.P: Taiwan should take immediate action to preserve its biodiversity by educating youth, setting aside natural reserves and developing alternative energy sources, a renowned U.S. botanist said Saturday in Taipei.

As an estimated 75,000 species on Taiwan are restricted to the island, their special characteristics will be important in facilitating a healthy, prosperous future for Taiwan, said Peter Raven, president of the Missouri Botanical Garden and one of the world's leading advocates of conservation and biodiversity.

In a speech organized by the nongovernmental Lung Yingtai Cultural Foundation, Raven noted that half or more of all species on earth may be lost by 2100, and that the speed with which species are becoming extinct is accelerating because of ever-worsening global warming.

He suggested that Taiwan make it a national priority to study as closely as possible scenarios that might come with climate change while at the same time setting aside nature reserves and protecting them.
He also urged the government to strengthen public education on the urgency and importance of protecting biodiversity in Taiwan.

One of the most important things we can do is to educate the youth about nature with the opportunity to understand its variety, " Raven said. "Only by doing that at all levels, whether at home or in schools, will we have greater sustainability in the future."

One of biodiversity's most eloquent defenders, the former member of President Bill Clinton's Committee of Advisers on Science and Technology said that only 1.6 million species of the world's 12 million have been identified and named.

By preserving biodiversity and these many unidentified species, human beings will be saving themselves, as nature can provide new foods, medicines, chemical feedstocks and products that humans cannot yet imagine.

Vice President Vincent Siew said at the function that the government attaches great importance to habitat conservation and species preservation by taking initiatives to protect the environment and restore the eco-system.

It also recognizes the value of biodiversity as an economic resource, and he said the study of biodiversity can foster the development of the biotechnology industry, one of six emerging industries that Taiwan has been actively promoting.

DOC.HEADLINE: Law revisions aim to enhance financial transparency: FSC

TEXT.P: The Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) is drafting measures to enhance corporate transparency that will require financial institutions to reveal under certain circumstances salaries and perks given to their senior executives and board directors, an official said Saturday.

"Current laws will be revised to allow the public disclosure of listed financial institutions' compensation given to senior executives and board members under certain conditions," explained the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
"This is part of our efforts to beef up information transparency and streamline market order amid the current global financial turmoil, " the official said.

Salaries and dividends paid to board members and senior executives of financial institutions became a major concern worldwide after cash-strapped American Insurance Group distributed over US$165 million in bonuses to top executives after securing bailout funds from the U.S. government.

Top leaders of the Group of 20 nations promised at their just-concluded conference in London to restrict financial compensation for senior executives of banks, insurance companies, and financial holding groups to maintain fair market order.
The official said the FSC is working on a draft package of amendments to existing law to coincide with this global trend.

"We are hopeful that the new requirements will increase information transparency so that investors will have enough information to decide whether to continue support those companies, " the official explained, adding that the measure will trigger market mechanisms to help improve corporate governance.

According to the official, the local bankers association has approved an amendment to its membership regulations to require all member banks to set up a salary supervisory commission, with their independent board members as conveners.
The new regulation is expected to help tighten internal monitoring and maintain the financial health of local banks, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Welfare institutions shelter more disabled people

TEXT.P: The number of people with mental or physical disabilities sheltered at social welfare institutions is rising steadily, according to the latest statistics released Saturday by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI).
As of the end of last year, 17,457 physically or mentally challenged people stayed at welfare organizations, up 2.7 percent from the year-earlier number, the MOI statistics showed.
By gender, men outnumbered women, with male residents at welfare centers accounting for 60.5 percent of the total.

According to the MOI tallies, Taiwan had 264 welfare service institutions at the end of 2008, able to shelter a total of 21,958 disabled people. The number of facilities was 6.1 percent higher than in 2007, with 185 owned by the private sector, 63 publicly built but privately run, and 16 publicly owned.

MOI officials said the ministry provided these centers with NT$19.88 billion in subsidies in 2008, up 3.4 percent from the 2007 level, with subsidies for daily living expenses accounting for 75.6 percent of the total and only 2.7 percent of the total going for equipment and assistive aids.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police make large haul of ketamine

TEXT.P: Keelung police announced Saturday the rare seizure of a large amount of ketamine and the arrest of four suspects.
The 246 kilograms of ketamine, worth NT$100 million (US$2.99 million), was seized in a warehouse in southern Taiwan, police said.

They said that they received a tip recently that an individual had colluded with drug manufacturing criminals in China and hid the ketamine in organic fertilizer, which was shipped in a 40-foot container into Taiwan.
Police targeted a suspect surnamed Huang, who shuttled often between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and is well versed in container shipping.
He recently shipped the organic fertilizer into Taiwan, and placed the fertilizer in a warehouse in Yongkang, Tainan County, before discussing prices and quantities with drug peddlers.
Huang, along with another suspect, surnamed Kuo, and two other individuals, were arrested when they were about to remove the ketamine from the warehouse.
Ketamine is usually sold at between NT$300,000 and NT$400,000 per kilo.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOI to review municipality applications professionally: spokesman

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) will evaluate applications by local cities and counties to upgrade to special municipalities in a professional manner, government spokesman Su Jun-pin said Saturday.

"The evaluation process will stand up to public scrutiny, " he said, a day after the legislature passed a revision to the Local Government Law that provides a legal foundation for cities and counties to merge or apply individually to have their statuses upgraded to that of a special municipality.

Under the amended law, if the combined population of merging cities and counties exceeds 1.25 million, they can apply to the MOI to become a special municipality, although the Executive Yuan will have the final say.

Su denied that the revision was passed because of political considerations, after local daily the Liberty Times speculated the move could directly impact three-in-one elections, including city and county chief elections, to be held Dec. 5.

The paper suggested the nation will be embroiled over the next few months in discussions on the upgrading issue, election strategy, and even political conspiracies due to the maneuvering of cities and counties as they seek to upgrade their status.
Meanwhile, the MOI said in a press release Saturday that although the population of a city or county must exceed 1.25 million to become a special municipality, population is not the only criteria.

The ministry noted that the populations of Taipei County (3.84 million) , Taoyuan County (1.96 million) , Taichung County (1.56 million), and Changhua County (1.31 million) all exceed 1.25 million, but none of them have been upgraded into a special municipality.

Even more important than population is the government's overall considerations in the planning of national lands and administrative district development to upgrade the nation's international competitiveness.

Taichung city and county could well become the third municipality, after Taipei and Kaohsiung cities, in Taiwan after the passage of the amended law, reports said. The next special municipality elections should take place in late 2010.

According to MOI guidelines, Taichung's city and county councils will have to approve the merger plan and then have the application sent to the MOI by May 31. After the MOI evaluates the application, it will send the plan to the Executive Yuan, which will approve or deny the applications by Aug. 31.
The Central Election Commission will promulgate the year-end elections Sept. 4, and announce whether the planned Taichung city and county elections are to be postponed.

If Taichung city and county -- or any other administrative districts -- are merged and upgraded, then the present city and county chiefs, councilors, and township council members will have their terms extended to Dec. 24, 2010.

Kaohsiung city and county and Tainan city and county are other local governments that have expressed an interest in seeing their status raised to benefit from the greater funding and bigger staffs given to special municipalities.

The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has expressed worries that as the Executive Yuan will have the final say on upgrading applications, the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) might let certain cities or counties upgrade to circumvent local elections and cling to power.

The DPP speculated that if the KMT feels it can't win specific cities and counties, it will simply upgrade the district to skip local elections and hang on to power for an extra year until special municipality elections are held.
They cited as an example Taipei County, where surveys have shown incumbent KMT Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei trailing far behind possible rivals from the DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hualien, Okinawa hope to build 'blue highway'

TEXT.P: Hualien City and Okinawa hope to build a "blue highway" on the Pacific Ocean that connects the two popular tourist destinations, the heads of Hualien and Okinawa said Saturday in eastern Taiwan.

Following a meeting with Hualien City Mayor Tsai Chih-ta, Okinawa Deputy Governor Katsuko Asato said Okinawa is promoting cruises to attract more foreign tourists, and the planned blue highway is the key element of this tourism promotion plan.
Asato said she hopes the planned blue highway will help increase the volume of tourist visits to the Japanese prefecture from the current 5 million to 10 million per year.

Tsai pointed out that because the blue highway passes through the national borders of two countries, its opening will involve different laws adopted by the different governments in various fields, including sailing rights and quarantine guidelines.

How to settle the legal problems will be the key to opening the blue highway, said Tsai, who suggested that only if Okinawa's government was willing to assist in resolving the problems could the marine road be created.

Asato arrived at Hualien Harbor in eastern Taiwan earlier Saturday on the Japanese luxury tour cruise liner, "Asuka II, " to study customs operations in Hualien and exchange views on the blue highway plan. Asato met with Tsai soon after her arrival.

DOC.HEADLINE: 86.4% of Chinese tourists satisfied with Taiwan trips: PRC official

TEXT.P: An overwhelming majority of Chinese tourists were satisfied with their trips to Taiwan, a visiting official of China's quai-official Cross-Strait Tourism Exchange Association said Saturday.
"Up to 86.4 percent of respondents to a survey of mainland visitors to Taiwan were happy with their sightseeing visits, " said Li Yaying, deputy secretary- general of the association.

Li made the remarks at a seminar in Taipei held at the end of a five-day tour of Taiwan along with representatives of the 113 Chinese travel agencies who recently obtained licenses from Beijing authorities to organize tours to Taiwan.

According to Li, her association has so far not received any complaints from Chinese citizens who have visited Taiwan on sightseeing trips since Taiwan and China agreed to expand tourism exchanges in mid-2008.

Li expressed concerns, however, about reports that Taiwan is accepting low-price Chinese tour groups and that some Taiwanese travel agencies have handed over such groups once they arrive in Taiwan to local travel companies that are not authorized to handle Chinese nationals.

Responding to Li's concerns, Hsieh Wei-chun, deputy director of Taiwan's Tourism Bureau, said the bureau will never compromise on travel quality standards and will make every possible effort to ensure that all Taiwan tour packages are reasonably priced.

Wu Chao-yen, the Tourism Bureau's chief secretary, said that if any Taiwan travel agency is found to have transferred a Chinese tour group to an unauthorized local travel agency, it will be barred from hosting any Chinese tour group for one to six months.

Meanwhile, Hsieh said the number of daily Chinese tourist arrivals is expected to reach the 3,000 person-per-day cap in the near future. At the moment, he said, the bureau is not considering raising the ceiling because of quality concerns.
For quality control, he suggested that mainland provinces follow the example of Sichuan and Helongjiang provinces and set a minimum fee standard to ensure quality.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese travel agents call for more cross-strait flights

TEXT.P: Visiting Chinese travel industry representatives said Saturday that the interest is high among Chinese residents in making sightseeing trips to Taiwan, but that the number of direct cross-Taiwan Strait flights is not enough to meet the market demand.
They also suggested that Taiwan publicize a list of hotels suitable for providing lodging for Chinese tour groups at reasonable prices.

The travel industry representatives expressed the views after concluding a five- day market appraising tour of Taiwan. Most of them are senior executives of the 113 Chinese travel service agencies who recently obtained licenses from Beijing authorities to organize tours to Taiwan.
According to them, Chinese tour groups now mainly comprise elderly people aged between 55 and 80.

Many more Chinese citizens are also interested in visiting Taiwan for sightseeing purposes, but travel agencies often have difficulties securing sufficient flight tickets on direct cross-strait routes. As a result, they said, many mainland tour groups have to travel to Taiwan via Hong Kong or Macau.

Carriers on both sides of the Taiwan Strait are currently allowed to operate 108 direct cross-strait charter flights per week. The two sides are expected to discuss the launch of scheduled direct cross-strait flights later this year.

Responding to Chinese travel professionals' call for presenting a hotel list, Wu Chao-yen, chief secretary of Taiwan's Tourism Bureau, said that the first batch of hotels that pass a new star-rating assessment will be unveiled in the second half of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for April 5, 2009

TEXT.P: 2. Event: President Ma Ying-jeou visiting National Youth Contribution Award- winning Zunhuai conservation association. Date and Time: 02:50 p.m., Sunday, April 5, 2009. Place: Zunhuai association office, No.62, Fusin Street, Cishan township, Kaohsiung County. Press Contact: Tel.2311-3731.
