DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan should take immediate step to preserve biodiversity: expert

TEXT.P: Taiwan should take immediate action to preserve its biodiversity by educating youth, setting aside natural reserves and developing alternative energy sources, a renowned U.S. botanist said Saturday in Taipei.

As an estimated 75,000 species on Taiwan are restricted to the island, their special characteristics will be important in facilitating a healthy, prosperous future for Taiwan, said Peter Raven, president of the Missouri Botanical Garden and one of the world's leading advocates of conservation and biodiversity.

In a speech organized by the nongovernmental Lung Yingtai Cultural Foundation, Raven noted that half or more of all species on earth may be lost by 2100, and that the speed with which species are becoming extinct is accelerating because of ever-worsening global warming.

He suggested that Taiwan make it a national priority to study as closely as possible scenarios that might come with climate change while at the same time setting aside nature reserves and protecting them.
He also urged the government to strengthen public education on the urgency and importance of protecting biodiversity in Taiwan.

One of the most important things we can do is to educate the youth about nature with the opportunity to understand its variety, " Raven said. "Only by doing that at all levels, whether at home or in schools, will we have greater sustainability in the future."

One of biodiversity's most eloquent defenders, the former member of President Bill Clinton's Committee of Advisers on Science and Technology said that only 1.6 million species of the world's 12 million have been identified and named.

By preserving biodiversity and these many unidentified species, human beings will be saving themselves, as nature can provide new foods, medicines, chemical feedstocks and products that humans cannot yet imagine.

Vice President Vincent Siew said at the function that the government attaches great importance to habitat conservation and species preservation by taking initiatives to protect the environment and restore the eco-system.

It also recognizes the value of biodiversity as an economic resource, and he said the study of biodiversity can foster the development of the biotechnology industry, one of six emerging industries that Taiwan has been actively promoting.

DOC.HEADLINE: Law revisions aim to enhance financial transparency: FSC

TEXT.P: The Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) is drafting measures to enhance corporate transparency that will require financial institutions to reveal under certain circumstances salaries and perks given to their senior executives and board directors, an official said Saturday.

"Current laws will be revised to allow the public disclosure of listed financial institutions' compensation given to senior executives and board members under certain conditions," explained the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
"This is part of our efforts to beef up information transparency and streamline market order amid the current global financial turmoil, " the official said.

Salaries and dividends paid to board members and senior executives of financial institutions became a major concern worldwide after cash-strapped American Insurance Group distributed over US$165 million in bonuses to top executives after securing bailout funds from the U.S. government.

Top leaders of the Group of 20 nations promised at their just-concluded conference in London to restrict financial compensation for senior executives of banks, insurance companies, and financial holding groups to maintain fair market order.
The official said the FSC is working on a draft package of amendments to existing law to coincide with this global trend.

"We are hopeful that the new requirements will increase information transparency so that investors will have enough information to decide whether to continue support those companies, " the official explained, adding that the measure will trigger market mechanisms to help improve corporate governance.

According to the official, the local bankers association has approved an amendment to its membership regulations to require all member banks to set up a salary supervisory commission, with their independent board members as conveners.
The new regulation is expected to help tighten internal monitoring and maintain the financial health of local banks, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Welfare institutions shelter more disabled people

TEXT.P: The number of people with mental or physical disabilities sheltered at social welfare institutions is rising steadily, according to the latest statistics released Saturday by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI).
As of the end of last year, 17,457 physically or mentally challenged people stayed at welfare organizations, up 2.7 percent from the year-earlier number, the MOI statistics showed.
By gender, men outnumbered women, with male residents at welfare centers accounting for 60.5 percent of the total.

According to the MOI tallies, Taiwan had 264 welfare service institutions at the end of 2008, able to shelter a total of 21,958 disabled people. The number of facilities was 6.1 percent higher than in 2007, with 185 owned by the private sector, 63 publicly built but privately run, and 16 publicly owned.

MOI officials said the ministry provided these centers with NT$19.88 billion in subsidies in 2008, up 3.4 percent from the 2007 level, with subsidies for daily living expenses accounting for 75.6 percent of the total and only 2.7 percent of the total going for equipment and assistive aids.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police make large haul of ketamine

TEXT.P: Keelung police announced Saturday the rare seizure of a large amount of ketamine and the arrest of four suspects.
The 246 kilograms of ketamine, worth NT$100 million (US$2.99 million), was seized in a warehouse in southern Taiwan, police said.

They said that they received a tip recently that an individual had colluded with drug manufacturing criminals in China and hid the ketamine in organic fertilizer, which was shipped in a 40-foot container into Taiwan.
Police targeted a suspect surnamed Huang, who shuttled often between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and is well versed in container shipping.
He recently shipped the organic fertilizer into Taiwan, and placed the fertilizer in a warehouse in Yongkang, Tainan County, before discussing prices and quantities with drug peddlers.
Huang, along with another suspect, surnamed Kuo, and two other individuals, were arrested when they were about to remove the ketamine from the warehouse.
Ketamine is usually sold at between NT$300,000 and NT$400,000 per kilo.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOI to review municipality applications professionally: spokesman

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) will evaluate applications by local cities and counties to upgrade to special municipalities in a professional manner, government spokesman Su Jun-pin said Saturday.

"The evaluation process will stand up to public scrutiny, " he said, a day after the legislature passed a revision to the Local Government Law that provides a legal foundation for cities and counties to merge or apply individually to have their statuses upgraded to that of a special municipality.

Under the amended law, if the combined population of merging cities and counties exceeds 1.25 million, they can apply to the MOI to become a special municipality, although the Executive Yuan will have the final say.

Su denied that the revision was passed because of political considerations, after local daily the Liberty Times speculated the move could directly impact three-in-one elections, including city and county chief elections, to be held Dec. 5.

The paper suggested the nation will be embroiled over the next few months in discussions on the upgrading issue, election strategy, and even political conspiracies due to the maneuvering of cities and counties as they seek to upgrade their status.
Meanwhile, the MOI said in a press release Saturday that although the population of a city or county must exceed 1.25 million to become a special municipality, population is not the only criteria.

The ministry noted that the populations of Taipei County (3.84 million) , Taoyuan County (1.96 million) , Taichung County (1.56 million), and Changhua County (1.31 million) all exceed 1.25 million, but none of them have been upgraded into a special municipality.

Even more important than population is the government's overall considerations in the planning of national lands and administrative district development to upgrade the nation's international competitiveness.

Taichung city and county could well become the third municipality, after Taipei and Kaohsiung cities, in Taiwan after the passage of the amended law, reports said. The next special municipality elections should take place in late 2010.

According to MOI guidelines, Taichung's city and county councils will have to approve the merger plan and then have the application sent to the MOI by May 31. After the MOI evaluates the application, it will send the plan to the Executive Yuan, which will approve or deny the applications by Aug. 31.
The Central Election Commission will promulgate the year-end elections Sept. 4, and announce whether the planned Taichung city and county elections are to be postponed.

If Taichung city and county -- or any other administrative districts -- are merged and upgraded, then the present city and county chiefs, councilors, and township council members will have their terms extended to Dec. 24, 2010.

Kaohsiung city and county and Tainan city and county are other local governments that have expressed an interest in seeing their status raised to benefit from the greater funding and bigger staffs given to special municipalities.

The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has expressed worries that as the Executive Yuan will have the final say on upgrading applications, the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) might let certain cities or counties upgrade to circumvent local elections and cling to power.

The DPP speculated that if the KMT feels it can't win specific cities and counties, it will simply upgrade the district to skip local elections and hang on to power for an extra year until special municipality elections are held.
They cited as an example Taipei County, where surveys have shown incumbent KMT Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei trailing far behind possible rivals from the DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hualien, Okinawa hope to build 'blue highway'

TEXT.P: Hualien City and Okinawa hope to build a "blue highway" on the Pacific Ocean that connects the two popular tourist destinations, the heads of Hualien and Okinawa said Saturday in eastern Taiwan.

Following a meeting with Hualien City Mayor Tsai Chih-ta, Okinawa Deputy Governor Katsuko Asato said Okinawa is promoting cruises to attract more foreign tourists, and the planned blue highway is the key element of this tourism promotion plan.
Asato said she hopes the planned blue highway will help increase the volume of tourist visits to the Japanese prefecture from the current 5 million to 10 million per year.

Tsai pointed out that because the blue highway passes through the national borders of two countries, its opening will involve different laws adopted by the different governments in various fields, including sailing rights and quarantine guidelines.

How to settle the legal problems will be the key to opening the blue highway, said Tsai, who suggested that only if Okinawa's government was willing to assist in resolving the problems could the marine road be created.

Asato arrived at Hualien Harbor in eastern Taiwan earlier Saturday on the Japanese luxury tour cruise liner, "Asuka II, " to study customs operations in Hualien and exchange views on the blue highway plan. Asato met with Tsai soon after her arrival.

DOC.HEADLINE: 86.4% of Chinese tourists satisfied with Taiwan trips: PRC official

TEXT.P: An overwhelming majority of Chinese tourists were satisfied with their trips to Taiwan, a visiting official of China's quai-official Cross-Strait Tourism Exchange Association said Saturday.
"Up to 86.4 percent of respondents to a survey of mainland visitors to Taiwan were happy with their sightseeing visits, " said Li Yaying, deputy secretary- general of the association.

Li made the remarks at a seminar in Taipei held at the end of a five-day tour of Taiwan along with representatives of the 113 Chinese travel agencies who recently obtained licenses from Beijing authorities to organize tours to Taiwan.

According to Li, her association has so far not received any complaints from Chinese citizens who have visited Taiwan on sightseeing trips since Taiwan and China agreed to expand tourism exchanges in mid-2008.

Li expressed concerns, however, about reports that Taiwan is accepting low-price Chinese tour groups and that some Taiwanese travel agencies have handed over such groups once they arrive in Taiwan to local travel companies that are not authorized to handle Chinese nationals.

Responding to Li's concerns, Hsieh Wei-chun, deputy director of Taiwan's Tourism Bureau, said the bureau will never compromise on travel quality standards and will make every possible effort to ensure that all Taiwan tour packages are reasonably priced.

Wu Chao-yen, the Tourism Bureau's chief secretary, said that if any Taiwan travel agency is found to have transferred a Chinese tour group to an unauthorized local travel agency, it will be barred from hosting any Chinese tour group for one to six months.

Meanwhile, Hsieh said the number of daily Chinese tourist arrivals is expected to reach the 3,000 person-per-day cap in the near future. At the moment, he said, the bureau is not considering raising the ceiling because of quality concerns.
For quality control, he suggested that mainland provinces follow the example of Sichuan and Helongjiang provinces and set a minimum fee standard to ensure quality.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese travel agents call for more cross-strait flights

TEXT.P: Visiting Chinese travel industry representatives said Saturday that the interest is high among Chinese residents in making sightseeing trips to Taiwan, but that the number of direct cross-Taiwan Strait flights is not enough to meet the market demand.
They also suggested that Taiwan publicize a list of hotels suitable for providing lodging for Chinese tour groups at reasonable prices.

The travel industry representatives expressed the views after concluding a five- day market appraising tour of Taiwan. Most of them are senior executives of the 113 Chinese travel service agencies who recently obtained licenses from Beijing authorities to organize tours to Taiwan.
According to them, Chinese tour groups now mainly comprise elderly people aged between 55 and 80.

Many more Chinese citizens are also interested in visiting Taiwan for sightseeing purposes, but travel agencies often have difficulties securing sufficient flight tickets on direct cross-strait routes. As a result, they said, many mainland tour groups have to travel to Taiwan via Hong Kong or Macau.

Carriers on both sides of the Taiwan Strait are currently allowed to operate 108 direct cross-strait charter flights per week. The two sides are expected to discuss the launch of scheduled direct cross-strait flights later this year.

Responding to Chinese travel professionals' call for presenting a hotel list, Wu Chao-yen, chief secretary of Taiwan's Tourism Bureau, said that the first batch of hotels that pass a new star-rating assessment will be unveiled in the second half of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 5, or the 10th day of the 3rd month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1725: Giovanni Casanova, Italian adventurer famous for his amorous conquests, is born.
1793: President George Washington approves plans for new public buildings and roads in the American capital city.
1827: Joseph Lister, British surgeon and discoverer of antiseptic agents, is born. He demonstrated in 1865 that carbolic acid was an effective antiseptic.
1895: Oscar Wilde, the author of the highly successful plays "The Importance of Being Earnest" and "Lady Windemere's Fan," sues the Marquess of Queensberry for libel.
1896: The first modern Olympic Games begin in Athens.
1900: Spencer Tracy, American actor who won an Oscar two years in a row for "Captain Courageous" (1937) and "Boys Town" (1938), is born.
1915: Jack Johnson, the first black world heavyweight boxing champion, losses his title to the "Great White Hope" Jess Willard.
1916: Gregory Peck, American actor noted for both his fine film performances and his work for humanitarian causes, is born.
1941: Allied forces recapture Addis Ababa in Ethiopia during World War II.
1949: The Chinese national government begins talks with Chinese Communists.
1950: The Executive Yuan grants Taiwan authority to carry out self-government by popular elections in counties and cities within two months.
1951: Julius and Ethel Rosenberg are sentenced to death in the United States for giving away atomic weapons secrets to the Soviet Union.
1954: More than 14,000 Chinese Communist POW's in Korea who refused to return to the Chinese mainland take their oath to join the ROC armed forces.
1955: British Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill announces his resignation. He is succeeded by Foreign Secretary Sir Anthony Eden.
1960: The film "Ben Hur" wins 10 Oscars.
1964: Douglas MacArthur, American general who served as U.S. chief of staff and commanded the Allied forces in the South Pacific during World War II, dies at the age of 84. He commanded U.N. forces in Korea until a conflict over strategy led to his dismissal by President Harry S. Truman.
1975: President Chiang Kai-shek passes away in Taiwan at the age of 89.
1976: Howard Robard Hughes, American film producer, aviator, and multimillionaire, dies at the age of 71. He founded Hughes Aircraft Corporation, broke the air speed record in 1935, and flew around the world in record time in 1938.
1976: The National Youth Commission reports helping some 31,000 youths find jobs since its establishment 10 years earlier.
1982: The British task force to oust Argentinian forces from the Falkland Islands sets sail.
1988: Arab gunmen seize a Kuwait Airways Boeing 747 flying from Bangkok to Kuwait. The 111 hostages aboard were freed on April 20 when the hijackers surrendered in Algiers.
1989: A political pact between the independent trade union federation Solidarity and the government of Wojciech Jaruzelski ends Communist rule in Poland.
1990: The Republic of China reestablishes diplomatic relations with the Kingdom of Lesotho. Peking (Beijing) severs ties with Lesotho two days later.
1991: President George Bush orders U.S. Air Force transport planes to begin dropping supplies to Kurdish refugees in northern Iraq.
1994: Israel begins to withdraw from the Gaza Strip.
1998: Japan's 3,911 meter-long Akashi Kaikyo Bridge, the world's longest suspension bridge linking the main islands of Honshu and Shikoku, is opened to traffic.
2000: Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Lin I-hsiung pays a visit to James Soong, chairman of the newly founded People First Party, to seek PFP support for the abolition of the upcoming National Assembly election.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian holds amiable talks with the Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, in a landmark encounter at the Presidential Office.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A good honest man, after educating the people for seven years, will be able to lead them to war."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Salvadoran president-elect recognizes cooperation with Taiwan: Ou
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Panama, April 3 (CNA) 04/05/09 16:26:42 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou said Friday that El Salvador president-elect Mauricio Funes positively recognized the results of cooperation between Taiwan and his country during their meeting Thursday.
Ou flew to El Salvador on short notice on March 31 to visit the newly elected president, who hinted during his campaign that he would consider cutting ties with Taiwan and recognize Beijing.
Taiwan's Foreign Ministry insisted, however, that Ou's trip was simply to solidify ties with a long-time diplomatic ally following the election of a new government March 15.

Ou said in a telephone interview that Funes attached considerable importance to the meeting, as seen by the number of important political figures close to Funes, including heavyweights from his Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front (FMLN), who were invited in the meeting.

During the encounter, Funes expressed his gratitude for Taiwan's long-standing assistance to his country and asserted that he would not rule his country based on political ideology but rather in consideration of national interests, according to Ou.
Funes cited the example of Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega, who had broken ties with Taiwan during his first term in office but has maintained relations with Taiwan during his second term.

Ou suggested that because of the long-term friendship between the FMLN and China's Communist Party, Funes might face pressure from inside his party to forge ties with China after taking over as president.
Under these circumstances, Taiwan needs to communicate with Funes and help him appreciate Taiwan's contribution to the well-being of El Salvador's people, Ou said.

The foreign minister noted that during his meeting with Funes, he briefed the president-elect on the latest developments in Taiwan-China relations and reiterated Taiwan's commitments on several cooperation programs and bilateral relations with El Salvador.

Noting that El Salvador is one of Taiwan's staunchest supporters and closest partners and that bilateral ties remain solid, Ou said he hopes the incoming Salvadoran government will facilitate bilateral cooperation with Taiwan soon after it takes office.
As to whether President Ma Ying-jeou will personally attend Funes' inauguration on June 1, Ou said the matter is still under discussion and a final decision has yet to be made.

DOC.HEADLINE: Alishan's cherry blossom season to close in 10 days

TEXT.P: The annual cherry blossom season on Alishan in southern Taiwan will end on April 15, and flower lovers who have not yet visited the national scenic area this year should do so before the opportunity disappears, the Alishan Community Development Association said Sunday.

Liao Ching-tai, general secretary of the association, told reporters that the flowers on most of the 1,900 Yoshino cherry trees faded by the end of March, and that at present double cherry blossoms known as prunus lannesiana, a sub-variety of the Yaebenishidare family, are in full bloom.
The Alishan National Scenic Area is well-known for its large numbers of cherry trees of various varieties, including indigenous ones and varieties from Japan.

In addition to the white and pink cherry blossoms of some 1,900 Yoshino cherry trees -- a Japanese variety -- there are 4,600 trees of other varieties, including Yaebenishidare, Kurile, peony, and Taiwan cherries.

According to Liao, while the cherry blossom season will soon end, many other kinds of flowers have begun to bloom all over the scenic area, including azaleas, magnolias, the genus Pleione orchids, calla lilies, Hall crabapple, and paradise apples.

In Alishan's Plum Garden and Chaoping Park, Hall Crabapple flowers in full bloom have become the main attraction to visitors. Although the flowers look like cherry blossoms, they actually belong to the rose family, Liao said.
According to the Forestry Bureau's Alishan office, more than 200,000 people have visited the Alishan scenic area since the cherry blossom season began on March 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: Humanitarian activist determined to bring values to medical sector

TEXT.P: CNA staff writer
Lien Chia-en is now a member of the medical establishment, a physician in charge of epidemic prevention in Taiwan's Centers for Disease Control.

Lien, who received his professional license last September after passing the national medical doctors exam, is on a new crusade informed by his experiences earlier this decade in the impoverished western African country -- bringing a humanistic touch to health care and to people's daily lives.
And Lien believes that with the world mired in an economic slump, now is the perfect time to overhaul the medical community's utilitarian climate.

"It's high time to inject medical ethics and the values of humanitarian service into the medical sector now that the economic slump is causing wrenching changes to Taiwan's society and the world, " said Lien recently in an interview with the Central News Agency.

Lien, a devout Christian who gained prominence serving as a health care worker in Burkina Faso from 2001-2003, said "ethics and values" have already begun to appear in certain corners of Taiwan's medical sector.

Kaohsiung Medical University, for example, has sent doctors from its affiliated hospital and its students to work in Africa as volunteers and Taipei Medical University has dispatched students to join medical corps in northern Thailand.
"Working in difficult places gives these students opportunities to get a glimpse of international medical aspects and allows them to nurture empathy toward the needy or disadvantaged," he said.

A graduate of National Yang Ming University's medical school who in addition to helping heal patients in Burkina Faso also led a movement to clean up its countryside, drill wells and set up orphanages, Lien has been an "icon" of male college graduates who still have to perform their compulsory military service.

Over the past year, he has been invited by many social groups to give speeches to young men, particularly male medical students, to share his experiences in Africa, which reinforced his humanitarian values.

Lien said his speaking engagements have convinced him that most medical students have the hearts to help people unconditionally, and he tells them that even if they are young and powerless, they can change the world.

"Try to find your own values to realize your dreams as soon as possible and don't give too much consideration to fame and personal interests, " is how Lien describes the message he tries to convey to them.

That message is the one he lived in Burkina Faso and one that was depicted in Under 45 Degree Skies, a television series about Lien's experiences, including how he became an Internet legend at the age of 27 when his activism and idealism converged into an online clothes-for garbage campaign.

In a country where precious cattle and other animals were choking to death after eating the garbage that blanketed the countryside, Lien asked people in Taiwan to donate clothes that would be given to Burkina Faso residents in exchange for garbage they collected.
The campaign was so successful that at one point, Burkina Faso's post office was brought to a temporary halt after being swamped with donations of about 75,000 pieces of clothing.

Lien, who was raised in Taiwan and had never having left home for longer than three months prior to being posted in Burkina Faso, one of Taiwan's 23 diplomatic allies, was so committed to realizing his ideals that he extended his stay for a year when his compulsory service ended in 2002.
He said he learned much more than he expected while serving in Africa. "I've learned that life is priceless and even if one is penniless, one can pursue a priceless life."

In Burkina Faso, Lien said, the temperature is 40 to 50 degrees Celsius, and the land is dry and barren. Food is scarce, education is insufficient, sanitation and health levels are inadequate, and the risk of AIDS and malaria is high.

The people of Burkina Faso, however, are decent and filled with integrity, he said. Despite their poverty, "the people do not rob or steal, " and Lien describes them as simple, gentle, kindhearted and sincere.
Lien believes that Taiwan has plenty to learn from the kind nature of his African friends despite their impoverished state.
He contends that Taiwan's youth have a service spirit, but it is dampened by the society's mainstream values and the emphasis of parents on academic performance and advancement.
With this rigid mentality and distorted value system that Lien is fighting against, many unemployed young people prefer living at home to taking a job because of long work hours or low pay.
But he hopes that his experience working in a hospice will help Taiwan's youth change their value systems and mind-sets.

Lien recalls that he saw many important businessmen and high ranking officials lying on their death beds murmuring not about how much money they had earned or how glorious their careers had been, but asking "why isn't my son here to see me?"
Success, Lien says, means that when one's days are numbered, one can look back at children who have their own happy families and at things one has done to positively influence others.
It is a message he still hopes Taiwan's medical community and the country's youth will embrace.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taoyuan County to apply to become special municipality

TEXT.P: The Taoyuan County government will apply to the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) to have its status upgraded to that of a special municipality by the end of this year, County Magistrate Eric Liluan Chu said Sunday.

Chu stated his county's intentions just two days after the Legislative Yuan passed an amendment to the Local Government Law that allows cities or counties to be upgraded to special municipalities either individually or by merging with other cities and counties.
Chu stressed that passage of the revision was aimed at adjusting Taiwan's administrative districts and reforming local governments, and not based on election considerations.
Opposition politicians have suggested that the amendment might be used as an instrument to manipulate elections in favor of the ruling Kuomintang.

The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) expressed concerns that the MOI might approve plans to merge cities and counties where the KMT could lose to the DPP in year-end city and county chief elections.
The heads of cities and counties that have their statuses upgraded will have their terms extended for one year, thus avoiding elections in December 2009.

For his part, Chu said he will serve out his term due to end Dec. 20, adding that he "loves Taoyuan County residents even more than Taipei County residents, " an indirect denial that he will run for Taipei County magistrate.
Taipei County is seen as one of the places in which the KMT is fighting an uphill battle, with incumbent Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei faring poorly against potential opposition candidates in polls.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agriculture agency to help build Penghu into outlying forest park

TEXT.P: Council of Agriculture (COA) Minister Chen Wu-hsiung has pledged full support to Penghu County to develop the island county into an outlying forest park and an international standard tourism and leisure area, a COA official said Sunday.
Chen made the promise during a visit to the county Friday after learning of its plan to plant 10 million trees to increase its forest coverage rate to 30 percent, according to the official.
So far, a total of 1,933.5 hectares of forest have been planted in the county, representing a forest coverage rate of 15 percent, the official said.
Chen suggested that the county harness the scenic beauty of forests by incorporating aesthetic landscaping concepts in their design to transform the county into a forest park.

Chen also pledged that the COA would help bring leisure and tourism features to the county's fishing ports and help revamp farming and fishing villages there after the Farming Village Revitalization Act clears the legislature's floor, the official said.
The COA chief believed that thanks to its clean environment free of industrial pollution and contamination, Penghu also has considerable potential in pesticide-free and organic farming.

DOC.HEADLINE: High-speed ferry awaiting go-ahead for Taichung-Xiamen route

TEXT.P: A high-speed ferry owned by Excalibur International Marine Corp. may have to postpone its debut run between Taichung Port in central Taiwan and Xiamen in China's Fujian province on April 10, as Chinese authorities have not yet approved the service.

Ocean Lala, a 2,292-ton ferry, is a five-year-old vessel built in Singapore. It can carry 360 passengers and run at a top speed of 35 knots. Its owner has been planning to operate the Taichung-Penghu-Xiamen route since late October after the vessel was officially launched in Taichung Harbor that month.
Under Taiwan's expanded "mini three links" formula, the ferry is allowed to use Penghu -- about 41 kilometers off the southwest coast of Taiwan proper -- as a transit stop to sail to a Chinese port.
Although Excalibur has obtained permission from local authorities to make four charter trips between Taichung and Xiamen, China has yet to give the company the green light.

Wang Chun-yu, director-general of the Taichung Harbor Bureau, said that because there has never been high-speed ferry service between Taiwan and China before, Chinese authorities want Excalibur to make a trial run to Xiamen without any passengers on board and allow their inspectors to board the vessel to verify that it is safe.

Excalibur has already sold more than 100 tickets to mostly travel agency workers for the April 10 voyage. Ocean Lala is scheduled to set out to sea from Taichung Port at 7 a.m. and arrive in Xiamen Port at 11: 35 a.m. The vessel would then carry 350 tourists from China to Taichung for a sightseeing tour.
Some travel agencies are also putting on hold a NT$12,000 seven-day package tour in Xiamen that would take Taiwanese tourists to the coastal Chinese city by the high-speed ferry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City offers subsidies to help phase out two-stroke scooters

TEXT.P: The Taipei City government announced Sunday that it will offer 5,000 owners of two-stroke engine scooters and motorcycles a subsidy of NT$1,500 each to phase out their highly polluting vehicles, with the application process to begin April 6.

Scooter owners are eligible to apply for the subsidy if their bikes were manufactured before January 2001, registered in the city, had their exhaust emissions inspected during the year or in the year before they were recycled or discarded, and are recycled by authorized vehicle dismantling and recycling operators by the end of this year, according to a city government official.
Some 1.07 million scooters and motorcycles are currently registered in the city, including 190,000 with two-stroke engines, the official said.

Two-stroke bikes emit two to five times more pollution than those with four- stroke engines, the official said, and the pollution they create often leads to complaints from local residents, prompting the city government to come up with the subsidy program.
Owners can determine whether their scooter uses a two-stroke or four-stroke engine by how their motor oil is changed.

Scooters with two-stroke engines have an indicator light on the control panel to show when the motor oil level is low, while the oil in bikes with four-stroke engines is changed after traveling certain distances, and the used oil must be drained before new oil is added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan should consider "dual axis" policy in face of G2: scholars

TEXT.P: Confronted with the emergence of a "G2, " composed of the United States and China, Taiwan should change its U.S.-oriented trade policy mentality into a "dual axis" strategy that gives equal weight to America and China.
Taiwan should even consider a "three-pronged" strategy -- attaching equal importance to the U.S., China and Europe -- in order to survive the ongoing global economic crunch, the experts said.

Speaking at an academic seminar on the "G2" and Taiwan's economic prospects, Dar-yeh Hwang, director of National Taiwan University's Center of Banking and Finance, said China may play the role of the world's economic locomotive as the G2 takes shape.

The U.S. once dominated that role, but with its huge trade and budget deficits, Washington will now be heavily indebted to other countries, limiting its maneuverability and ability to spur global economic growth, Hwang said.

For example, he said, Washington has had no other option but to take a conciliatory attitude toward China in recent months because of Beijing's holding of more than US$1 trillion in U.S. dollar-denominated assets, including treasury bills.
In comparison, he said, China has enjoyed a huge trade surplus, a high domestic savings rate and soaring foreign exchange reserves together with a large but relatively stable banking system.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan dollar with little room to appreciate this week: analysts

TEXT.P: The Taiwan dollar has little room for further appreciation this coming week after leading all Asian currencies with a 1.2 percent rise against the United States dollar last week, according to analysts.
After giving up NT$0.236 to the U.S. greenback last Monday, the Taiwan dollar rose the next four days by a combined NT$0.635 to finish the week at NT$33.38 to the greenback.

The 1.2 percent gain against the U.S. dollar for the week was higher than the Malaysian ringgit's 0.85 percent rise, the Singaporean dollar's 0.76 percent rise, the Korean won's 0.54 percent gain, the Thai baht's 0.28 percent rise and the Indonesian rupiah's 0.14 percent gain.
Meanwhile the Chinese yuan and Japanese yen each lost ground to the U.S. dollar last week.

Hsiao also believe that China's efforts to diversify its holdings of nearly US$2 trillion in foreign exchange reserves to currencies other than the U.S. dollar will also likely send the greenback lower in the future.

But whether the Taiwan dollar will rise to 32 against the greenback as some fear depends on the local stock market, which generally moves in tandem with Wall Street, and how the central bank would react to a further surge, Liang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen residents to get NT$10,800 gift vouchers for fiery liquor

TEXT.P: Kinmen residents may be the happiest lot in Taiwan and the outlying islands under its control, as the Kinmen County government has decided to present each resident with NT$10,800 (US$326) worth of gift vouchers this year for purchasing the island chain's most famous product -- sorghum liquor known as kaoliang.

The first batch of gift vouchers were distributed to the county's 85,143 residents at 45 locations in six townships Sunday -- a day after Tomb Sweeping Day -- with each resident receiving NT$3,600 worth of vouchers. The residents have until June 5 to spend the vouchers in exchange for kaoliang liquor products from a local distillery.
The county government said it will do the same two more times to coincide with Dragon Boat Festival on May 28 and Mid-Autumn Festival on Oct. 3.
The county government made the decision to commemorate the 60th anniversary of the Battle of Kuningtou in Kinmen -- an island group off China's Fujian province -- in late October 1949.

During that battle, the Republic of China's garrison troops in Kinmen defeated the 19,000 invading Communist Chinese troops by killing 3,873 of them and capturing 5,175 others. The Kinmen garrison troops sustained 1,267 deaths and 1,982 injured.

Three years later, Kinmen's defense commander Gen. Hu Lian and his troops built a makeshift distillery, with soldiers familiar with wine-making skills serving as technicians, to produce sorghum liquor.
The high-proof liquor produced by the distillery under the brand-name "Kinmen Kaoliang" became so famous that the factory later became a fully county-owned enterprise.
Kaoliang is the Chinese word for sorghum. The fiery liquor is so well-liked by consumers in both Kinmen and Taiwan proper that it has become synonymous with Kinmen.
Last year, Kinmen Kaoliang Liquor Inc. bucked the global economic downturn by earning the highest revenue in its 56-year history.
Sales of the liquor have become a major source of funding for local construction and welfare programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 5, or the 10th day of the 3rd month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1725: Giovanni Casanova, Italian adventurer famous for his amorous conquests, is born.
1793: President George Washington approves plans for new public buildings and roads in the American capital city.
1827: Joseph Lister, British surgeon and discoverer of antiseptic agents, is born. He demonstrated in 1865 that carbolic acid was an effective antiseptic.
1895: Oscar Wilde, the author of the highly successful plays "The Importance of Being Earnest" and "Lady Windemere's Fan," sues the Marquess of Queensberry for libel.
1896: The first modern Olympic Games begin in Athens.
1900: Spencer Tracy, American actor who won an Oscar two years in a row for "Captain Courageous" (1937) and "Boys Town" (1938), is born.
1915: Jack Johnson, the first black world heavyweight boxing champion, losses his title to the "Great White Hope" Jess Willard.
1916: Gregory Peck, American actor noted for both his fine film performances and his work for humanitarian causes, is born.
1941: Allied forces recapture Addis Ababa in Ethiopia during World War II.
1949: The Chinese national government begins talks with Chinese Communists.
1950: The Executive Yuan grants Taiwan authority to carry out self-government by popular elections in counties and cities within two months.
1951: Julius and Ethel Rosenberg are sentenced to death in the United States for giving away atomic weapons secrets to the Soviet Union.
1954: More than 14,000 Chinese Communist POW's in Korea who refused to return to the Chinese mainland take their oath to join the ROC armed forces.
1955: British Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill announces his resignation. He is succeeded by Foreign Secretary Sir Anthony Eden.
1960: The film "Ben Hur" wins 10 Oscars.
1964: Douglas MacArthur, American general who served as U.S. chief of staff and commanded the Allied forces in the South Pacific during World War II, dies at the age of 84. He commanded U.N. forces in Korea until a conflict over strategy led to his dismissal by President Harry S. Truman.
1975: President Chiang Kai-shek passes away in Taiwan at the age of 89.
1976: Howard Robard Hughes, American film producer, aviator, and multimillionaire, dies at the age of 71. He founded Hughes Aircraft Corporation, broke the air speed record in 1935, and flew around the world in record time in 1938.
1976: The National Youth Commission reports helping some 31,000 youths find jobs since its establishment 10 years earlier.
1982: The British task force to oust Argentinian forces from the Falkland Islands sets sail.
1988: Arab gunmen seize a Kuwait Airways Boeing 747 flying from Bangkok to Kuwait. The 111 hostages aboard were freed on April 20 when the hijackers surrendered in Algiers.
1989: A political pact between the independent trade union federation Solidarity and the government of Wojciech Jaruzelski ends Communist rule in Poland.
1990: The Republic of China reestablishes diplomatic relations with the Kingdom of Lesotho. Peking (Beijing) severs ties with Lesotho two days later.
1991: President George Bush orders U.S. Air Force transport planes to begin dropping supplies to Kurdish refugees in northern Iraq.
1994: Israel begins to withdraw from the Gaza Strip.
1998: Japan's 3,911 meter-long Akashi Kaikyo Bridge, the world's longest suspension bridge linking the main islands of Honshu and Shikoku, is opened to traffic.
2000: Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Lin I-hsiung pays a visit to James Soong, chairman of the newly founded People First Party, to seek PFP support for the abolition of the upcoming National Assembly election.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian holds amiable talks with the Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, in a landmark encounter at the Presidential Office.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A good honest man, after educating the people for seven years, will be able to lead them to war."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Salvadoran president-elect recognizes cooperation with Taiwan: Ou
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Panama, April 3 (CNA) 04/05/09 16:26:42 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou said Friday that El Salvador president-elect Mauricio Funes positively recognized the results of cooperation between Taiwan and his country during their meeting Thursday.
Ou flew to El Salvador on short notice on March 31 to visit the newly elected president, who hinted during his campaign that he would consider cutting ties with Taiwan and recognize Beijing.
Taiwan's Foreign Ministry insisted, however, that Ou's trip was simply to solidify ties with a long-time diplomatic ally following the election of a new government March 15.

Ou said in a telephone interview that Funes attached considerable importance to the meeting, as seen by the number of important political figures close to Funes, including heavyweights from his Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front (FMLN), who were invited in the meeting.

During the encounter, Funes expressed his gratitude for Taiwan's long-standing assistance to his country and asserted that he would not rule his country based on political ideology but rather in consideration of national interests, according to Ou.
Funes cited the example of Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega, who had broken ties with Taiwan during his first term in office but has maintained relations with Taiwan during his second term.

Ou suggested that because of the long-term friendship between the FMLN and China's Communist Party, Funes might face pressure from inside his party to forge ties with China after taking over as president.
Under these circumstances, Taiwan needs to communicate with Funes and help him appreciate Taiwan's contribution to the well-being of El Salvador's people, Ou said.

The foreign minister noted that during his meeting with Funes, he briefed the president-elect on the latest developments in Taiwan-China relations and reiterated Taiwan's commitments on several cooperation programs and bilateral relations with El Salvador.

Noting that El Salvador is one of Taiwan's staunchest supporters and closest partners and that bilateral ties remain solid, Ou said he hopes the incoming Salvadoran government will facilitate bilateral cooperation with Taiwan soon after it takes office.
As to whether President Ma Ying-jeou will personally attend Funes' inauguration on June 1, Ou said the matter is still under discussion and a final decision has yet to be made.

DOC.HEADLINE: Alishan's cherry blossom season to close in 10 days

TEXT.P: The annual cherry blossom season on Alishan in southern Taiwan will end on April 15, and flower lovers who have not yet visited the national scenic area this year should do so before the opportunity disappears, the Alishan Community Development Association said Sunday.

Liao Ching-tai, general secretary of the association, told reporters that the flowers on most of the 1,900 Yoshino cherry trees faded by the end of March, and that at present double cherry blossoms known as prunus lannesiana, a sub-variety of the Yaebenishidare family, are in full bloom.
The Alishan National Scenic Area is well-known for its large numbers of cherry trees of various varieties, including indigenous ones and varieties from Japan.

In addition to the white and pink cherry blossoms of some 1,900 Yoshino cherry trees -- a Japanese variety -- there are 4,600 trees of other varieties, including Yaebenishidare, Kurile, peony, and Taiwan cherries.

According to Liao, while the cherry blossom season will soon end, many other kinds of flowers have begun to bloom all over the scenic area, including azaleas, magnolias, the genus Pleione orchids, calla lilies, Hall crabapple, and paradise apples.

In Alishan's Plum Garden and Chaoping Park, Hall Crabapple flowers in full bloom have become the main attraction to visitors. Although the flowers look like cherry blossoms, they actually belong to the rose family, Liao said.
According to the Forestry Bureau's Alishan office, more than 200,000 people have visited the Alishan scenic area since the cherry blossom season began on March 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: Humanitarian activist determined to bring values to medical sector

TEXT.P: CNA staff writer
Lien Chia-en is now a member of the medical establishment, a physician in charge of epidemic prevention in Taiwan's Centers for Disease Control.

Lien, who received his professional license last September after passing the national medical doctors exam, is on a new crusade informed by his experiences earlier this decade in the impoverished western African country -- bringing a humanistic touch to health care and to people's daily lives.
And Lien believes that with the world mired in an economic slump, now is the perfect time to overhaul the medical community's utilitarian climate.

"It's high time to inject medical ethics and the values of humanitarian service into the medical sector now that the economic slump is causing wrenching changes to Taiwan's society and the world, " said Lien recently in an interview with the Central News Agency.

Lien, a devout Christian who gained prominence serving as a health care worker in Burkina Faso from 2001-2003, said "ethics and values" have already begun to appear in certain corners of Taiwan's medical sector.

Kaohsiung Medical University, for example, has sent doctors from its affiliated hospital and its students to work in Africa as volunteers and Taipei Medical University has dispatched students to join medical corps in northern Thailand.
"Working in difficult places gives these students opportunities to get a glimpse of international medical aspects and allows them to nurture empathy toward the needy or disadvantaged," he said.

A graduate of National Yang Ming University's medical school who in addition to helping heal patients in Burkina Faso also led a movement to clean up its countryside, drill wells and set up orphanages, Lien has been an "icon" of male college graduates who still have to perform their compulsory military service.

Over the past year, he has been invited by many social groups to give speeches to young men, particularly male medical students, to share his experiences in Africa, which reinforced his humanitarian values.

Lien said his speaking engagements have convinced him that most medical students have the hearts to help people unconditionally, and he tells them that even if they are young and powerless, they can change the world.

"Try to find your own values to realize your dreams as soon as possible and don't give too much consideration to fame and personal interests, " is how Lien describes the message he tries to convey to them.

That message is the one he lived in Burkina Faso and one that was depicted in Under 45 Degree Skies, a television series about Lien's experiences, including how he became an Internet legend at the age of 27 when his activism and idealism converged into an online clothes-for garbage campaign.

In a country where precious cattle and other animals were choking to death after eating the garbage that blanketed the countryside, Lien asked people in Taiwan to donate clothes that would be given to Burkina Faso residents in exchange for garbage they collected.
The campaign was so successful that at one point, Burkina Faso's post office was brought to a temporary halt after being swamped with donations of about 75,000 pieces of clothing.

Lien, who was raised in Taiwan and had never having left home for longer than three months prior to being posted in Burkina Faso, one of Taiwan's 23 diplomatic allies, was so committed to realizing his ideals that he extended his stay for a year when his compulsory service ended in 2002.
He said he learned much more than he expected while serving in Africa. "I've learned that life is priceless and even if one is penniless, one can pursue a priceless life."

In Burkina Faso, Lien said, the temperature is 40 to 50 degrees Celsius, and the land is dry and barren. Food is scarce, education is insufficient, sanitation and health levels are inadequate, and the risk of AIDS and malaria is high.

The people of Burkina Faso, however, are decent and filled with integrity, he said. Despite their poverty, "the people do not rob or steal, " and Lien describes them as simple, gentle, kindhearted and sincere.
Lien believes that Taiwan has plenty to learn from the kind nature of his African friends despite their impoverished state.
He contends that Taiwan's youth have a service spirit, but it is dampened by the society's mainstream values and the emphasis of parents on academic performance and advancement.
With this rigid mentality and distorted value system that Lien is fighting against, many unemployed young people prefer living at home to taking a job because of long work hours or low pay.
But he hopes that his experience working in a hospice will help Taiwan's youth change their value systems and mind-sets.

Lien recalls that he saw many important businessmen and high ranking officials lying on their death beds murmuring not about how much money they had earned or how glorious their careers had been, but asking "why isn't my son here to see me?"
Success, Lien says, means that when one's days are numbered, one can look back at children who have their own happy families and at things one has done to positively influence others.
It is a message he still hopes Taiwan's medical community and the country's youth will embrace.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taoyuan County to apply to become special municipality

TEXT.P: The Taoyuan County government will apply to the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) to have its status upgraded to that of a special municipality by the end of this year, County Magistrate Eric Liluan Chu said Sunday.

Chu stated his county's intentions just two days after the Legislative Yuan passed an amendment to the Local Government Law that allows cities or counties to be upgraded to special municipalities either individually or by merging with other cities and counties.
Chu stressed that passage of the revision was aimed at adjusting Taiwan's administrative districts and reforming local governments, and not based on election considerations.
Opposition politicians have suggested that the amendment might be used as an instrument to manipulate elections in favor of the ruling Kuomintang.

The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) expressed concerns that the MOI might approve plans to merge cities and counties where the KMT could lose to the DPP in year-end city and county chief elections.
The heads of cities and counties that have their statuses upgraded will have their terms extended for one year, thus avoiding elections in December 2009.

For his part, Chu said he will serve out his term due to end Dec. 20, adding that he "loves Taoyuan County residents even more than Taipei County residents, " an indirect denial that he will run for Taipei County magistrate.
Taipei County is seen as one of the places in which the KMT is fighting an uphill battle, with incumbent Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei faring poorly against potential opposition candidates in polls.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agriculture agency to help build Penghu into outlying forest park

TEXT.P: Council of Agriculture (COA) Minister Chen Wu-hsiung has pledged full support to Penghu County to develop the island county into an outlying forest park and an international standard tourism and leisure area, a COA official said Sunday.
Chen made the promise during a visit to the county Friday after learning of its plan to plant 10 million trees to increase its forest coverage rate to 30 percent, according to the official.
So far, a total of 1,933.5 hectares of forest have been planted in the county, representing a forest coverage rate of 15 percent, the official said.
Chen suggested that the county harness the scenic beauty of forests by incorporating aesthetic landscaping concepts in their design to transform the county into a forest park.

Chen also pledged that the COA would help bring leisure and tourism features to the county's fishing ports and help revamp farming and fishing villages there after the Farming Village Revitalization Act clears the legislature's floor, the official said.
The COA chief believed that thanks to its clean environment free of industrial pollution and contamination, Penghu also has considerable potential in pesticide-free and organic farming.

DOC.HEADLINE: High-speed ferry awaiting go-ahead for Taichung-Xiamen route

TEXT.P: A high-speed ferry owned by Excalibur International Marine Corp. may have to postpone its debut run between Taichung Port in central Taiwan and Xiamen in China's Fujian province on April 10, as Chinese authorities have not yet approved the service.

Ocean Lala, a 2,292-ton ferry, is a five-year-old vessel built in Singapore. It can carry 360 passengers and run at a top speed of 35 knots. Its owner has been planning to operate the Taichung-Penghu-Xiamen route since late October after the vessel was officially launched in Taichung Harbor that month.
Under Taiwan's expanded "mini three links" formula, the ferry is allowed to use Penghu -- about 41 kilometers off the southwest coast of Taiwan proper -- as a transit stop to sail to a Chinese port.
Although Excalibur has obtained permission from local authorities to make four charter trips between Taichung and Xiamen, China has yet to give the company the green light.

Wang Chun-yu, director-general of the Taichung Harbor Bureau, said that because there has never been high-speed ferry service between Taiwan and China before, Chinese authorities want Excalibur to make a trial run to Xiamen without any passengers on board and allow their inspectors to board the vessel to verify that it is safe.

Excalibur has already sold more than 100 tickets to mostly travel agency workers for the April 10 voyage. Ocean Lala is scheduled to set out to sea from Taichung Port at 7 a.m. and arrive in Xiamen Port at 11: 35 a.m. The vessel would then carry 350 tourists from China to Taichung for a sightseeing tour.
Some travel agencies are also putting on hold a NT$12,000 seven-day package tour in Xiamen that would take Taiwanese tourists to the coastal Chinese city by the high-speed ferry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City offers subsidies to help phase out two-stroke scooters

TEXT.P: The Taipei City government announced Sunday that it will offer 5,000 owners of two-stroke engine scooters and motorcycles a subsidy of NT$1,500 each to phase out their highly polluting vehicles, with the application process to begin April 6.

Scooter owners are eligible to apply for the subsidy if their bikes were manufactured before January 2001, registered in the city, had their exhaust emissions inspected during the year or in the year before they were recycled or discarded, and are recycled by authorized vehicle dismantling and recycling operators by the end of this year, according to a city government official.
Some 1.07 million scooters and motorcycles are currently registered in the city, including 190,000 with two-stroke engines, the official said.

Two-stroke bikes emit two to five times more pollution than those with four- stroke engines, the official said, and the pollution they create often leads to complaints from local residents, prompting the city government to come up with the subsidy program.
Owners can determine whether their scooter uses a two-stroke or four-stroke engine by how their motor oil is changed.

Scooters with two-stroke engines have an indicator light on the control panel to show when the motor oil level is low, while the oil in bikes with four-stroke engines is changed after traveling certain distances, and the used oil must be drained before new oil is added.

Kaoliang is the Chinese word for sorghum. The fiery liquor is so well-liked by consumers in both Kinmen and Taiwan proper that it has become synonymous with Kinmen.
Last year, Kinmen Kaoliang Liquor Inc. bucked the global economic downturn by earning the highest revenue in its 56-year history.
Sales of the liquor have become a major source of funding for local construction and welfare programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen residents to get NT$10,800 gift vouchers for fiery liquor

TEXT.P: Kinmen residents may be the happiest lot in Taiwan and the outlying islands under its control, as the Kinmen County government has decided to present each resident with NT$10,800 (US$326) worth of gift vouchers this year for purchasing the island chain's most famous product -- sorghum liquor known as kaoliang.

The first batch of gift vouchers were distributed to the county's 85,143 residents at 45 locations in six townships Sunday -- a day after Tomb Sweeping Day -- with each resident receiving NT$3,600 worth of vouchers. The residents have until June 5 to spend the vouchers in exchange for kaoliang liquor products from a local distillery.
The county government said it will do the same two more times to coincide with Dragon Boat Festival on May 28 and Mid-Autumn Festival on Oct. 3.
The county government made the decision to commemorate the 60th anniversary of the Battle of Kuningtou in Kinmen -- an island group off China's Fujian province -- in late October 1949.

During that battle, the Republic of China's garrison troops in Kinmen defeated the 19,000 invading Communist Chinese troops by killing 3,873 of them and capturing 5,175 others. The Kinmen garrison troops sustained 1,267 deaths and 1,982 injured.

Three years later, Kinmen's defense commander Gen. Hu Lian and his troops built a makeshift distillery, with soldiers familiar with wine-making skills serving as technicians, to produce sorghum liquor.
The high-proof liquor produced by the distillery under the brand-name "Kinmen Kaoliang" became so famous that the factory later became a fully county-owned enterprise.
Kaoliang is the Chinese word for sorghum. The fiery liquor is so well-liked by consumers in both Kinmen and Taiwan proper that it has become synonymous with Kinmen.
Last year, Kinmen Kaoliang Liquor Inc. bucked the global economic downturn by earning the highest revenue in its 56-year history.
Sales of the liquor have become a major source of funding for local construction and welfare programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 6, or the 11th day of the third month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1199: Richard I, king of England known as "The Lion-Hearted," dies at the age of 42 from an infected wound received while besieging Chaluz Castle during the Crusades. He was captured in Austria in 1192 and held as a prisoner by Holy Roman Emperor Henry VI until England ransomed him in 1194.
1789: George Washington is unanimously elected the first president of the United States.
1814: French Emperor Napoleon Bonaparte is forced to abdicate unconditionally.
1868: Japanese Emperor Meiji establishes the Charter Oath, which was to change the form of government. He also promises an assembly.
1890: Anthony Fokker, Dutch-born American aircraft designer and manufacturer who revolutionized aerial warfare by synchronizing a front-mounted machine gun with the rotations of a propeller, is born.
1896: A modern version of the ancient Olympic Games is opened in Athens, initiated by French aristocrat Baron Pierre de Coubertin, whose goal was to stimulate interest in physical fitness and promote understanding between nations.
1913: The provisional Senate of the Republic of China is dissolved.
1917: President Woodrow Wilson signs a resolution entering the United States into World War I on the side of Great Britain and France.
1933: The Ministry of Finance of the Republic of China orders the implementation of a yuan currency system instead of the tael currency system.
1935: Emperor Henry Pu Yi of Manchukuo, a puppet regime installed by the Japanese, visits Japan.
1938: The ROC armed forces score a major victory over Japan in the battle of Taierchuang, killing more than 30,000 Japanese troops.
1941: German bombers raid Belgrade, killing some 2,500 people. Hundreds of buildings were destroyed during the attack, including the National Library with its countless medieval manuscripts.
1945: U.S. naval forces score a major victory against the Japanese at Kyushu.
1953: Scrap bombs explode on a hillside in Nanshihchiao, Taipei County, killing or injuring more than 300 people.
1963: The Executive Yuan proclaims December 25 "Constitution Day" and a national holiday.
1965: The United States launches Early Bird I, the first commercial communications satellite, from Cape Kennedy, Florida.
1968: Pierre Trudeau becomes prime minister of Canada, succeeding Lester B. Pearson.
1975: Yen Chia-kan, vice president of the Republic of China since 1966, takes the oath of office as the nation's second constitutional president.
1976: Millionaire recluse Howard Hughes dies in a plane while being flown to a hospital, leaving a fortune of US$2 billion.
1976: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo renews his call to communist cadres and mainland China military personnel to rise up against the Maoist regime following the April 5 riots at Tienanmen Square in Beijing.
1993: Two mainland Chinese youths, Liu Bao-zai and Huang Shu-kang, hijack a Southern Airlines' Boeing 757 passenger plane to Taiwan.
1994: A missile hits a plane as it attempts to land in Rwanda, killing all people onboard, including President Cyprien Ntaryamira of Burundi and President Jubenal Habyarimana of Rwanda.
1998 Citicorp merges with Travelers Group Inc., becoming the largest corporation in the world in terms of assets. The new firm is worth more than US$70 billion.
1999: Indonesian President B.J. Habibie assures visiting ROC Economics Minister Wang Shih-kang that his administration will take all necessary measures to protect Taiwan investors in Indonesia.
2000: Republic of China President-elect Chen Shui-bien says that the administration under his leadership will honor all accords and commitments that have already been inked with foreign countries.
2001: Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, calls on former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui and expresses his gratitude for Lee's promotion of increased Taiwan-Tibet exchanges during his term in office.
2004: Lithuanian President Rolandas Paksas is impeached by the Parliament, making him the first European popularly elected president to step down due to impeachment.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To allow people to go to battle without first instructing them is to betray them."
