DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan gravely concerned about Pyongyang's rocket launch: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs expressed grave concern Monday over North Korea's firing of a rocket over Japan the day before, saying the move threatens peace and security in Northeast Asia.
Deputy Foreign Minister Javier C.S. Hou called for vigilance by the relevant parties in the world regarding the matter.

Hou made the remarks at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and National Defense Committee, during which opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Tsai Huang-liang asked why the foreign ministry had not publicly condemned Pyongyang's "provocative" move, as other nations had done.

Hou responded that the foreign ministry had issued a newsletter April 2, before the rocket was launched, calling for Pyongyang to exercise self-restraint and seek solutions to differences by means of dialogue.
The foreign ministry planned to issue a formal statement about North Korea's actions later in the day, Hou told Tsai.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Improved economy boosts public confidence: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Monday that the recent improvement in Taiwan's economic situation has helped to boost public confidence, although the hard economic times are likely to continue throughout the first half of this year.
Ma noted that the situation in March appeared better than in February, which was evident from the influx of unanticipated orders and the decrease in the number of furloughed staff in some businesses.

"The hard times are not expected to be over in the first half of this year, but we can see that public confidence has grown, " Ma said while receiving a group of representatives of the Junior Chamber International Taiwan.

The president pointed out that in a bid to stimulate the economy, the government is promoting a series of measures to try to expand public construction and it hopes that a special NT$500 billion (US$15.1 billion) four-year budget plan for this purpose could be finalized this week.

More than NT$150 billion of the special budget would be earmarked for 2009, which would bring to NT$600 billion the total funding for public construction for the year, including items covered by the annual budget, Ma said.
He promised that the government will plan each public construction project very carefully and make sure there is no waste of resources.

Looking ahead, he said, the government is fully confident in Taiwan's future and looks forward to seeing Taiwan playing a more important role in the global economic landscape after the financial crisis is over.

He again called attention to the fact that Taiwan has the world's fourth largest foreign exchange reserves, amounting to US$300 billion, and one of the world's highest personal savings rate, at 30 percent, which he said is an indication of the strong purchasing power and investment potential of the Taiwan people.
Ma also expressed confidence in the country's small- and medium-sized businesses, many of which have seized a significant share of the world markets despite their size.

DOC.HEADLINE: Highland lake shrinks to half its size

TEXT.P: Jiaming Lake, a highland lake nestled deep in the mountains of eastern Taiwan, has shrunk to about half its size since winter due to low rainfall.

The lake was about 120 meters long, 80 meters wide and 35 meters deep early last year, but has since shrunk to the size of a round pool about 75 meters in diameter. Its volume is estimated at about half the normal level.
The Taiwan Forestry Bureau's Taitung branch has advised that mountain climbers carry their own drinking water when scaling peaks leading to the lake.
Bureau officials have further suggested that visitors refrain from drinking the lake water, saying that might be impure as wild animals frequently drink there.
The lake, known as one of the highest in Taiwan, is located at an altitude of 3,310 meters in the highlands bordering the eastern counties of Taitung and Hualien and the southern county of Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sale of travel packages to Shanghai Expo launched in Taiwan

TEXT.P: With 390 days to go in the countdown to the start of the 2010 Shanghai World Expo, ticket sales in Taiwan for the fair were officially launched Monday, with the commissioned travel agency expressing confidence that a large number of Taiwanese tourists will attend the extravaganza.

"Ever sine it was established in 1851, World Expo has attracted global attention, as it is a display of the world's civilization, " said Chou Ching- shyong, chairman of China Travel Services Taiwan, at a news conference in Taipei.
"I believe the 2010 Shanghai World Expo will attract more Taiwanese tourists than any other fair because of the proximity of Shanghai and common Chinese language used on both sides," Chou said.

He forecast that the number of Taiwanese tourists to the Shanghai fair will exceed the 70,000 that attended the 2003 Aichi World Expo in Japan. However, it is hard to predict the exact figure at the moment because of variants such as the availability of cross-Taiwan Strait charter flight seats, he added.
Regarding the Chinese government's estimate of 400,000 Taiwanese tourists to Shanghai during the expo, Chou said that projection is a bit optimistic and bold.

With regard to the travel packages designed for the expo, Chou said the cost of a five-day group package, excluding airfare and including four nights at a five star hotel and a one-day pass to the expo, will start from NT$6,000 (US$181),

Individual travelers will pay a similar amount, except that the airfare will be slightly higher, he said. At present, group fare tickets to Shanghai are NT$13,000 each, while for individuals the price is NT$14,000-NT$20,000, he said, adding that the exact prices for travel to the expo will be confirmed closer to its opening date.

The Shanghai Expo will be held in Shanghai from May 1 to Oct. 31 2010 under the theme "Better City, Better Life." It is expected to draw participants from 232 countries and international organizations, in addition to an an estimated 70 million local and overseas visitors, which would give it the distinction of being the largest World Expo in the fair's 159-year history.

Chen Xianjin, deputy director of the Bureau of Shanghai World Expo Coordination, said at the news conference that the Shanghai Expo will be a gathering of the world's civilizations in communication, understanding, and joy.

"The expo will also serve as a platform of friendship and cooperation between Taiwan and China, " he said. Taiwanese tourists are welcome to visit the Shanghai Expo, along with the Taiwanese companies that will set up in the business pavilion to tap into global business opportunities, he added.

Taipei City will take part in the expo, displaying its success in creating a wireless city and managing recycling. It will participate under the fair's subtheme of "Urban Best Practices Area, " which will provide a platform for cities to share their experiences in urban development and construction.

DOC.HEADLINE: President's former aide released on parole

TEXT.P: An aide of President Ma Ying-jeou during the president's tenure as mayor of Taipei City who was convicted of embezzlement was released on parole Monday after being incarcerated for nine months.

Yu Wen was given a one-year jail sentence early last year on charges of forgery for using other peoples' invoices to help Ma claim reimbursements from the special allowance fund set aside for the mayor's discretionary use.
Yu, who said he deserved to be punished for neglecting his duties, was jailed in June 2008 and granted early parole by the Ministry of Justice recently for good behavior.

Ma was also indicted, on charges of embezzling NT$11 million (US$332,684) from the special allowance fund he received as Taipei mayor from 1998 to 2006, but was acquitted by both the Taipei District Court Aug. 14, 2007 and by the Taiwan High Court Dec. 28, 2007.

Prosecutors filed an appeal with the Supreme Court in January 2008 against the not-guilty verdict handed down by the Taiwan High Court, but the Supreme Court rejected the appeal in April of that year and upheld the previous district and high court rulings for Ma.

Talking to the press upon his departure from jail, Yu said he had not illegally lined his pockets with a single cent during his time in public service. Noting that he merely wrote off the mayor's expenditures using alternative means, Yu said he believes the law will eventually clear his name.
He declined to answer a reporter's question on whether Ma had corresponded with him while he was doing time.

In related news, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Monday that if Yu files an application with the Taipei city government to resume his post as a secretary, it will be considered in full accordance with the law.
According to the law, Yu, whose wrongdoing involved no major crimes such as sedition, treason or serious corruption, can apply to return to the city government after his sentence term expires.

DOC.HEADLINE: Interviews help reduce mixed marriages of convenience: officials

TEXT.P: An interview system to screen transnational marriages has succeeded in reducing the number of marriages of convenience by an average of 25 percent annually over the past three years, government officials said Monday.

Lo Yu-chung, director-general of the Bureau of Consular Affairs under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), and officials from the National Immigration Agency (NIA) under the Ministry of the Interior made the remarks while fielding questions from lawmakers at a legislative committee meeting about related mechanisms.

Since the MOFA implemented the interview scheme in May 2005 to step up the screening process for transnational marriages involving Taiwanese citizens, Lo said, Taiwanese officials posted overseas have turned down an annual average of 25 percent of such applications following face-to-face interviews during the 2006-2008 period.
In 2008, Taiwan's representative office in Vietnam rejected 35 percent of the total marriage applications between Taiwanese and Vietnamese people.

Taiwan's representative offices in Indonesia and Thailand recorded rejection ratios of 36.2 percent and 33.8 percent, respectively, last year, while the representative office in the Philippines reported an 18.3 percent rejection rate, he went on.

Conducting interviews has proven very effective in preventing immigrants from entering Taiwan under the guise of foreign spouses through marriages of convenience with Taiwanese men and women, Lo said.

According to Lo, the U.S. State Department in its annual global human trafficking report has also praised the effectiveness of the interview method in helping crack down on cross-border human trafficking.
As of the end of February this year, the number of foreign husbands and wives of Taiwanese citizens living in Taiwan had hit around 140,000, according to statistics.
As high as 58 percent of the foreign wives in Taiwan are from Vietnam, he noted.

As a large number of Vietnamese women get married to men from Taiwan, France, the United States and South Korea every year, the authorities here, as well as those in the other three countries, all require their outposts or embassies in Vietnam to conduct interviews with would-be Vietnamese spouses seeking to marry citizens from their respective countries, Lo pointed out.

The Vietnamese government also interviews its own nationals, as well as their would-be foreign wives or husbands, before issuing marriage certificates, also in a bid to crack down on marriages of convenience, he pointed out.

Speaking on the same occasion, NIA Director-General Hsieh Li-kung said NIA agents have detained 302 foreigners suspected of having entered marriages of convenience with Taiwanese people since the agency's establishment Jan. 2, 2007.
Hsieh echoed Lo's view that the interview mechanism has been very helpful in cracking down on the practice.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bamboo charcoal can boost fish growth: study

TEXT.P: Feeding fish with food blended with ground bamboo charcoal can be a natural way to boost their growth and greatly enhance the efficiency of aquaculture, according to the results of a study released over the weekend by the Fisheries Research Institute (FRI) under the Council of Agriculture.
The results were achieved through experiments in which fish food containing ground bamboo charcoal was used to feed Taiwan tilapia, a species farmed mainly for its meat.
It was found that the fish fed with ground bamboo charcoal showed significantly better results in terms of weight gain, growth and length-weight factor than those fed with normal food.
The experiments also showed that using ground bamboo charcoal and bamboo vinegar simultaneously produced better results than using ground bamboo charcoal alone.
According the FRI, previous experiments had indicated that wood charcoal and wood vinegar can yield similar outcome.

For example, feeding eels with food that incorporates ground wood charcoal and wood vinegar improves fish growth and the feed conversion rate and boosts the fish's immunity against diseases, the FRI said.

Also, giving ground wood charcoal and wood vinegar to scads decreases fat accumulation in the abdomen of the fish and reduces the relative ratios of body weight to liver weight, thus raising their meat content, the FRI stated.
Meanwhile, using the ingredients to raise carp helps ease the negative impact of nitrogen and phosphorus on the environment, the study found.

The FRI noted that the strong absorptive properties of charcoal have been proven effective in deodorizing and decomposing harmful chemical substances, and that bamboo charcoal works better than wood charcoal in this respect because of its uniform and compact texture.
The application of bamboo charcoal in animal husbandry has also produced impressive results, according to the FRI.

For instance, feeding hogs with ground bamboo charcoal can relieve gas and diarrhea and boost the animals' appetite, the FRI said. When used in chicken farming, it can make the meat more tender, increase egg-laying rates and greatly reduce the stench of the chickens' droppings, it said.
Also, feeding bamboo charcoal to lambs can enhance their growth and increase their protein digestion and nitrogen deposition, the FRI said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Labor unions to hold protest march against unemployment

TEXT.P: Several labor unions are preparing to hold a protest march in Taipei on May 1 -- Labor Day -- to demand that the government create long-term stable work for the jobless.

Representatives of the groups, which include the Taiwan Confederation of Trade Unions (TCTU), the National Federation of Bank Employees Unions (NFBEU) and the Youth Labor Union 95, held a press conference Monday in Taipei to announce the protest.
TCTU Secretary-General Hsieh Chuang-chih said it is the government's obligation to create work and curb the increasing unemployment in the face of the global economic crisis.

NFBEU Secretary-General Han Shih-hsien said for his part that the massive layoffs over the past few months by financial services operators and electronics manufacturing companies reflects the fact that workers' rights and benefits are not protected by the law at all.

Han suggested that the government amend the law to prohibit employers from using contract workers in an "inappropriate manner, " as well to ban the business of short-term labor dispatch operators, as this does not provide workers with long- term and stable jobs.

At the press conference, Youth Labor Union 95 Convener Chen Puo-chien suggested that the government should appropriate NT$80 billion (US$2.4 billion) from its special budgets each year to funnel into plans to further expand its middle- and long-term public services in fields such as nature conservation and long-term health care for senior citizens.
With that money, the government could hire as many as 160,000 people to work in public services, offering salaries of up to NT$500,000 per annum, Chen noted.

According to statistics released by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, the unemployment rate increased to 5.75 percent in February, up by 1.81 percentage points from the level of the same month of the previous year.
In the same month, Hong Kong registered an unemployment rate of 5 percent, with 4.1 percent recorded in Japan, 3.5 percent in South Korea and 2.6 percent in Singapore, the tallies show.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher for the fifth consecutive day Monday, led by financial shares.
The Taiex advanced 26.59 points, or 0.48 percent, to close at 5,556.22. A total of 7.27 billion shares changed hands on turnover of NT$147.61 billion (US$4.44 billion).
The local bourse opened higher at 5,590.70 and once advanced past the 5,600-point mark before reaching the day's low of 5,521.88.

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile as well as banking and financial shares surging the most at 1.7 percent amid optimism that profits in the banking and financial sector for the first quarter will be better than expected.
Construction stocks rose 1.6 percent, foodstuff shares moved up 1.2 percent, plastics and chemicals stocks closed up 0.7 percent, and machinery and electronics shares moved up 0.1 percent.
Only paper and pulp issues, which fell 0.7 percent, and cement shares, which shed 0.2 percent, lost ground.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,193 to 875, with 146 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$7.13 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

A total of US$1.837 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$33.380 and reached a low of 33.094.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan records deflation rate of 0.15% in March

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) in March dropped by 0.15 percent from the same month of last year, the second consecutive month deflation had been recorded, according to a report released Monday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
For the first quarter of this year, the CPI contracted by 0.01 percent year-on- year, indicating continued moderation of inflation, the report states.
Wu Chao-ming, a DGBAS section chief, said the mild deflation in March reflected the combined influences of a drop in fuel prices and a rise in the price of food and electricity.
While transport and communication costs declined 6.49 percent year-on-year in March, food prices went up 2.64 percent, Wu noted.
However, the core CPI, which excludes prices of fruit, vegetables, fish, shellfish and energy, rose by 0.81 percent year-on-year in March, the DGBAS report shows.

Meanwhile, the wholesale price index (WPI) dropped by 9.2 percent year-on-year in March, marking the fifth consecutive month in which a year-on-year decline was recorded, mainly due to a continued plunge in international agricultural and industrial commodities, the report continues.

Import and export prices calculated in U.S. dollars plummeted by 21.05 percent and 14.98 percent year-on-year, respectively, both figures marking the largest decline on record, according to the report.

Calculated in new Taiwan dollars, import and export prices were down 11.41 percent and 4.57 percent, respectively, the report states, adding that the difference in percentages mainly results from fluctuations in the respective currency exchange rates.
For the first quarter of the year, the WPI lost 9.77 percent year-on-year, according to the DGBAS.

DOC.HEADLINE: Monthly turnover at central Taiwan's science park rebounds

TEXT.P: Business turnover at the Central Taiwan Science Park in February reached NT$10.3 billion (US$309 million), up about by 20 percent over the January figure of NT$8.6 billion, the park administration reported Monday.

Thanks to gradually rebounding business sentiment across the world, the park's revenue has grown month-to-month during the first two months of this year after its operations plunged in the fourth quarter of last year due to the global financial crisis, administration officials said.

Although the combined two-month revenue of the park remains lower compared to the level posted in the same period last year, the officials said that the park's revenue is expected to continue increasing each month from its present relatively low level due to an improved business climate.
Outperforming other sectors, the precision machinery industry recorded an outstanding growth rate of 37 percent in the January-February period, the officials noted.
Facilities in the Central Taiwan Science Park are located in Taichung City, Taichung County and nearby Changhua and Yunlin counties, housing more than 150 high-tech companies.
The park was established in 2002 by the Executive Yuan. It is one of three major science parks in Taiwan, with the other two in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, and Tainan, southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cloud Gates Wanderer program bridges cultural gaps

TEXT.P: Eight Taiwanese artists participating in the renowned Cloud Gate Dance Theaters 2008Wandererprogram on Monday shared their experiences and inspirations gained from their travels in seven Asian countries, revealing how the trips changed their lives and brought Taiwan closer to different cultures.
The eight artists were winners of the 2008 Wanderer program, which provides subsidies for artists to travel abroad or take time off to gain artistic inspiration.

Sharing stories about their trips to different countries through dance, music and documentary films, the group, including four up-and-coming artists Pan Jung- sheng, Wang Shih-wei, Tzeng Ching-wen and Yang Huei-tsi, and four professional artists -- Hsue Chang-huei, Laka Wumao, Chang Yung-chieh, and Lu Shih-ming explained how cross-cultural exchanges have increased their sense of self-worth and beliefs.

For many of them, their trips were not over after coming back to Taiwan because they initiated various projects to increase cultural understanding between Taiwan and these countries, as well as to provide assistance to those in need in the impoverished areas they visited.

Documentary filmmaker Hsue Chang-huei, who spent three months in Iran, used her camera to unveil the mysteries of the Middle East country. During her visit to the Iranian Documentary Film Association, she managed to gain the rights to broadcast 14 Iranian documentary films in Taiwan, and is now looking for sponsorship to hold a Taiwan-Iran documentary film festival.
I hope the cultural distance between Taiwan and Iran will be shortened through the exchanges of these films,Hsue said.

Having traveled to Malawi, Cambodia, and Vanuatu in the Pacific prior to joining the program, Yang Huei-tsi is a well-experienced overseas volunteer. In her trip to Chinas Yunnan, Guizhou and Guangxi provinces as part of the Wanderer program to learn wax printing from the minority groups there, she decided to build a new school for a dozen orphans of the Yao tribe.

After 10 months of fund raising in Taiwan, Yang is scheduled to go back to Guangxi later this month to start the construction. She called on the public to make continuous efforts to help her see the project through to completion.
The Wanderer program was initiated in 2004 by Cloud Gate Theater founder Lin Hwai-min and has been sponsored by Stan Shih, founder of the laptop maker, the Acer group, since 2006.
Since then, the program has provided financial assistance to a total of 41 Taiwanese artists.

Lin said at the news conference Monday that he was deeply touched by the courage and passion demonstrated by the eight artists, who pursued their dreams with an open heart while at the same time tried their best to make contributions to society.
Shih, founder of the program's sponsor Stans Foundation, agreed.
These trips have not only enriched the artists, but also society,Shih said.

The Cloud Gate Theater on Monday also announced that the 2010 Wander program is now accepting applications from budding artists, professional artists or people in social service under the age of 45, who have an enthusiasm for literature, music, performance art, or image art.
Artists interested in the program can obtain more information at www.cloudgate.org.tw or contact the dance company at 02-2712-2102.
The deadline for applying is July 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: `Discover Gulliver' exhibition in central Taiwan extended to April 12

TEXT.P: The "Discover Gulliver" exhibition in the central city of Taichung will be extended from April 6 to April 12 to allow more members of the public, especially children, to see the structure of the human body from within a specially built giant human model, the sponsor of the event announced Monday.

The Paper Windmill Foundation, which built the 60-meter-long, seven-meter-high model at a cost of NT$10 million (US$302,970), said the exhibition has attracted more than 45,000 visitors since it opened at Taichung's Wenhsin Forest Park April 3, and the foundation decided to extend the show at the request of Taichung Mayor Jason Hu.

According to Paper Windmill Theater Chief Director Jen Chien-cheng, the giant human figure has a face modeled on that of the Seediq warrior Mona Rudao, who led the aboriginal people of his tribe in an armed rebellion against their Japanese occupiers in central Taiwan's Nantou County in 1930.
Jen said the mobile exhibition is a gift to Taiwan's children for 2009 Children's Day, which fell on April 4.
The structure is actually an inflated tent supported by a steel frame, with bones, muscles, internal organs and teeth made from polyvinyl chloride and polyresin.

The exhibition is named "Discover Gulliver" after Gulliver, a renowned fictional Englishman who travels to Lilliput, an imaginary land of tiny people, in the classic satirical novel by Jonathan Swift first published in 1726.

Visitors enter the body of Gulliver from his foot and travel along a route that passes his shinbone, muscles, large intestine, small intestine, lungs, beating heart, mouth, teeth -- some of which even have cavities -- and nasal chamber before exiting through an ear.
Explanations are provided by accompanying guides and the whole journey takes between 10 and 15 minutes.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA toughens rhetoric on North Koreas rocket launch

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) toughened its rhetoric Monday over North Koreas firing of a rocket over Japan a day earlier, condemning the Communist countrys move as sabotaging the stability of East Asia.

Following Vice Foreign Minister Javier C.S. Hous expression of grave concern over the incident earlier at the Legislative Yuan, the MOFA officially issued a statement later on Monday to condemn Pyongyangs rocket launch.

As a member of East Asia, the Republic of China (ROC) deeply regrets North Koreas action of sabotaging the stability of East Asia and therefore voices condemnation of such behavior,said MOFA spokesman Henry Chen.

Pyongyangs rocket launch not only violated the United Nations Security Council Resolution 1718, but also created tension and impacted the security and stability of the Asia Pacific region, the MOFA said in a press release.
It also called for the relevant parties in the world to act according to U.N. regulations regarding the matter, and to exercise self-restraint and be rational in seeking solutions to differences.
The ROC reiterated that problems on the Korean Peninsula should be resolved by means of negotiations in order to maintain regional peace, stability and prosperity, the statement added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dance featuring Wushe Incident to premiere in Nantou County

TEXT.P: A local dance troupe will premiere a new show titled "The Song of the Seediq -- Dana Sakura" April 8 in central Taiwan's Nantou County, which tells the story of how the indigenous Seediq tribe fought against their Japanese colonialists in 1930 in an uprising known as the Wushe Incident.

The show marks the first modern dance in Taiwan's history to be created based on the historic tragedy that ended in a massacre of the tribesmen by the Japanese, said Hung Chu-ling, arts director of the Taiwan Youth dance company, affiliated with the Department of Dance at the Taichung County-based private Youth Senior High School.

The play focuses on the same subject matter as that being examined in a film currently in production and titled "Seediq Bale, " directed by local filmmaker Wei Te-sheng who burst into the spotlight with his 2008 low-budget film "Cape No. 7, " which has smashed box office records in Taiwan, Huang noted.

Many local artists, including a composer and Teng Hsiang-yang -- who wrote "Dana Sakura" -- created the score for the dance that tells a story barely addressed in local society, she said, adding her hope that through the dance, audiences will gain a better knowledge of the Seediq people, their life and their culture.
After the premiere, the youth troupe will perform the dance drama again in Nantou May 2 and then in Taichung City May 8 and Taipei City May 16, according to the organizer.

The Seediq are a Taiwanese aboriginal tribe living primarily in Nantou County and Hualien County. They were officially recognized as Taiwan's 14th indigenous group April 23, 2008. Previously, the tribe, along with the closely related Truku people, were classified as Atayal, a different tribe altogether.

DOC.HEADLINE: Communist parties take advantage of Constitutional Court ruling

TEXT.P: Two communist parties, established in July and December last year, have formally registered themselves with the Ministry of the Interior and become legally protected civic organizations in Taiwan, the Interior Ministry confirmed Monday.

Ministry officials pointed out that the Taiwan Communist Party was founded after the justices of the Constitutional Court under the Judicial Yuan ruled on June 20 last year that provisions in the Civil Associations Act banning citizens of the Republic of China from advocating communism or separatism were unconstitutional.

In accordance with the court's constitutional interpretation 644, those provisions were nullified with immediate effect because they were inconsistent with the people's right to freedom of assembly, freedom of speech, and freedom of expression.

The founder of the Taiwan Communist Party had tried several times since 1994 to apply to the Interior Ministry to form the communist party but had been rejected every time because preaching communism in Taiwan was illegal until the June 20 ruling.
The party was founded on July 20 and registered with the Interior Ministry within 30 days to become Taiwan's 141st political party.

On Dec. 27 last year, the second communist party -- the Republic of China Communist Party -- was formed in Taipei, and its application to register the party with the Interior Ministry was filed early this year.
The party was formally approved on March 31, becoming Taiwan's 147th political party.
Neither of the communist parties are subordinate to the Communist Party of China although one of them has explicitly called for Taiwan's eventual reunification with China through peaceful means.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dogs playing key role in Taiwan's anti-drug trafficking efforts

TEXT.P: Sniffer dogs have become more important in detecting illegal narcotics at customs checkpoints, detecting some 20 percent of the illegal drugs brought in by travelers at Taiwan's biggest airport in the first quarter, customs authorities reported Monday.

More than 90 kilograms of unlawful drugs smuggled in by passengers were confiscated at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport in the first three months of this year, with about 20 percent of the drugs discovered by dogs serving at the airport, said the Taipei Customs Office under the Ministry of Finance.
In other neighboring Asian countries such as Japan and South Korea, sniffer dogs can detect more than 30 percent of the drugs smuggled into their airports.

The nation's squad of 26 drug sniffer dogs was established in 2002 to help customs agents crack down on an increased smuggling of illegal substances. Currently, six or seven sniffer dogs are serving at the Taoyuan airport near Taipei.
It is a growing trend across the globe to use sniffer dogs at air and sea ports to detect the smuggling of narcotics, the agents said.
Most drug traffickers concealed smuggled drugs in their luggage, while some of them were body packers who attempted to transport illicit drugs by concealing them in their cavities, the agents said.

Besides the work of the dogs, a majority -- 67 percent -- of banned drugs seized were discovered by customs agents with the help of X-ray machines, while the remaining 13 percent were tracked down through tip-offs, according to an analysis provided by the Taipei Custom Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sewage blamed for deterioration of coral reefs off Kenting

TEXT.P: The continued discharge of untreated sewage into waters off Kenting National Park in southern Taiwan is responsible for the deterioration of coral reefs in the area, an academic said Monday.

Lin Hsing-juh, a professor in National Chung Hsing University's Department of Life Sciences, came to the conclusion after monitoring and studying coral reef ecosystems off Taiwan's southernmost tip for over a decade.
His findings were published recently in the prestigious journal Limnology and Oceanography.
According to Lin, for coral reefs to thrive, they must grow in clean shallow water, with a low density of anthropogenic nutrients, a stable density of salt, moderate temperatures and bright sunshine.
Human encroachment in the form of excessive development and the arrival of 4 million tourists a year in the Kenting area has led to an influx of sewage into Kenting's coastal regions, Lin said.
Lin found that Kenting's Nanwan and Wanlitung, which boast the largest concentration of tourists, have suffered the most serious entrophication.
To facilitate his study, Lin established a mesocosm -- a controlled ecosystem approximating natural conditions -- to conduct extensive observations and experiments and verify his findings.
"Outdoor field surveys can only observe the results of coral reef deterioration while providing no clues to the processes and causes of the degeneration," Lin explained.

With the assistance of the National Museum of Marine Biology and Aquarium in southern Taiwan's Pingtung County, Lin managed to build a mesocosm -- the first of its kind built in the world -- that replicated the coral reef ecosystem in Nanwan 20 years ago when there was less human activity.
After 10 years of observation, simulations and experiments, Lin reached his conclusion that untreated sewage is to blame for the deterioration of the Kenting coral reef ecosystem.
To replicate the process of polluting the waters in the area, Lin introduced sewage or anthropogenic (human-made) nutrients into the mesocosm at a rate of 5.5 mmol per square meter.
Mmol, or millimoles, is a unit measuring the amount of a substance.

"It turned out that algae grew rapidly and completely covered corals, resulting in the death of the corals, " Lin said. He also observed that normally passive sea anemones also began to attack the coral following the introduction of the sewage.
Overfishing, particularly of fish species that can stem the growth of algae and sea anemones, has led to a further imbalance in Kenting's ecosystem, Lin said.

Noting that coral reefs are natural habitats for more than 25 percent of marine life and fish output from coral reefs accounts for 12 percent of the global fish catch, Lin said conservation of natural coral reef ecosystem was essential.
Coral reefs are also important because they can help protect the coastline, minimize beach erosion from big waves and tsunamis, and nurture coastal fishery resources, he added.

Lin said that the most urgent task at present is to prevent the excessive flow of sewage or anthropogenic contaminants into coastal waters and step up the conservation of coral reefs and fish species.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan working to rescue fishing ship hijacked by Somali pirates

TEXT.P: The government is doing everything it can to rescue a Taiwanese deep-sea fishing vessel hijacked by Somali pirates in the Indian Ocean early Monday, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said later in the day.

The 700-ton long-line fishing ship "Win Far 161, " with 30 crew members on board, was hijacked near an island in the Seychelles in the Indian Ocean, said Chang Yun-ping, director-general of the MOFA's Department of African Affairs.
According to Chang, only the ship's skipper and first engineer are Taiwanese nationals, while all other crew members originate from China, the Philippines and Indonesia.

Chang said the ministry has sought the assistance of the U.K. Maritime Trade Organization, the maritime liaison office of America's Bahrain-based 5th Fleet, the Seychelles fishery bureau and the Somali harbor bureau in rescuing the hijacked Kaohsiung-based long-liner.
Moreover, Chang said, the ministry is endeavoring to get information about the hijacked ship's latest situation through the country's representative office in South Africa and other channels.

"We have gained knowledge of the Win Far's current location. It is more than 1,000 kilometers away from land, " Chang said. He added, however, that the ministry has yet to receive any information related to the pirates' ransom request.

Asked whether the ministry will seek China's help in rescuing the ship, Chang said that as China's military fleet is currently patrolling the Gulf of Aden and the estuary of the Red Sea, far north of where the Win Far was hijacked, the ministry has no plan to approach China for assistance at the moment.

According to a foreign wire service report, the Taiwanese ship was the second attack by Somali pirates in the Seychelles within a week. A small Yemeni boat was also hijacked near the Seychelles Sunday.

Analysts say the pirates have moved many of their operations out of the Gulf of Aden, which is heavily patrolled by naval warships from a number of countries, including China, the United States, France and India.
Instead, they are targeting ships coming out of the Mozambique Channel, an area of the Indian Ocean farther south between the southeastern Africa coast and Madagascar.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taoyuan County to host Songkran Festival for Thai workers in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Thailand Trade and Economic Office in Taipei and the Taoyuan County government are inviting Thai workers in Taiwan to a gathering in a county stadium on April 12 to celebrate the Songkran Festival and usher in the Thai New Year.

Songkran, the most important festival of Thailand, falls on April 13 every year and lasts three days. It is also known as the "Water Festival" as people believe that throwing water at one another will wash away bad luck.
According to Taoyuan County government officials, there will also be performances by singers and dancers from Thailand.
The officials said that Taiwanese people are also welcome to join the Thai workers in their celebrations.
Songkran is a Thai word meaning "move" or "change place" as it is the day when the sun changes its position in the zodiac.
During the festival, Thai people gather in the streets to sing and dance, knowing they will be splashed with water and get soaked to improve their luck.
@There are about 90,000 Thai laborers working in Taiwan and most of them are concentrated in Taoyuan County.

The Taoyuan County government and the Thailand Trade and Economic Office in Taiwan have jointly held Songkran celebrations every year since 1999 to ease the homesickness of Thai workers who cannot return home for the festival, which is traditionally a time to pay respects to elders and meet old friends.

DOC.HEADLINE: High-profile Chinese delegation arrives for visit

TEXT.P: A high-profile delegation from the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) arrived in Taipei Monday for a week-long visit.

It marks the first time that the quasi-official Chinese intermediary organization has sent a delegation to Taiwan since the two sides of the Taiwan Strait resumed institutionalized dialogue in mid-2008 after a nearly 10-year hiatus.
The 13-member delegation is headed by ARATS Vice President An Min who said he was very pleased to be able to visit Taiwan after having been rejected three times beforehand.
According to An, half of the members of the delegation, including Lin Zheying, a deputy department chief of China's Ministry of Commerce, are visiting Taiwan for the first time.
An said he will take advantage of the trip to learn more about Taiwan's beauty, culture and way of life.

Noting that cross-strait economic exchanges have grown into an enormous scale, An said he looks forward to seeing normalization, stabilization and institutionalization of bilateral trade and economic cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: President's former aide released on parole

TEXT.P: An aide of President Ma Ying-jeou during the president's tenure as mayor of Taipei City who was convicted of embezzlement was released on parole Monday after being incarcerated for nine months.

Yu Wen was given a one-year jail sentence early last year on charges of forgery for using other peoples' invoices to help Ma claim reimbursements from the special allowance fund set aside for the mayor's discretionary use.
Yu, who said he deserved to be punished for neglecting his duties, was jailed in June 2008 and granted early parole by the Ministry of Justice recently for good behavior.

Ma was also indicted, on charges of embezzling NT$11 million (US$332,684) from the special allowance fund he received as Taipei mayor from 1998 to 2006, but was acquitted by both the Taipei District Court Aug. 14, 2007 and by the Taiwan High Court Dec. 28, 2007.

Prosecutors filed an appeal with the Supreme Court in January 2008 against the not-guilty verdict handed down by the Taiwan High Court, but the Supreme Court rejected the appeal in April of that year and upheld the previous district and high court rulings for Ma.

Talking to the press upon his departure from jail, Yu said he had not illegally lined his pockets with a single cent during his time in public service. Noting that he merely wrote off the mayor's expenditures using alternative means, Yu said he believes the law will eventually clear his name.
He declined to answer a reporter's question on whether Ma had corresponded with him while he was doing time.

In related news, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Monday that if Yu files an application with the Taipei city government to resume his post as a secretary, it will be considered in full accordance with the law.
According to the law, Yu, whose wrongdoing involved no major crimes such as sedition, treason or serious corruption, can apply to return to the city government after his sentence term expires.

DOC.HEADLINE: Interviews help reduce mixed marriages of convenience: officials

TEXT.P: An interview system to screen transnational marriages has succeeded in reducing the number of marriages of convenience by an average of 25 percent annually over the past three years, government officials said Monday.

Lo Yu-chung, director-general of the Bureau of Consular Affairs under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), and officials from the National Immigration Agency (NIA) under the Ministry of the Interior made the remarks while fielding questions from lawmakers at a legislative committee meeting about related mechanisms.

Since the MOFA implemented the interview scheme in May 2005 to step up the screening process for transnational marriages involving Taiwanese citizens, Lo said, Taiwanese officials posted overseas have turned down an annual average of 25 percent of such applications following face-to-face interviews during the 2006-2008 period.
In 2008, Taiwan's representative office in Vietnam rejected 35 percent of the total marriage applications between Taiwanese and Vietnamese people.

Taiwan's representative offices in Indonesia and Thailand recorded rejection ratios of 36.2 percent and 33.8 percent, respectively, last year, while the representative office in the Philippines reported an 18.3 percent rejection rate, he went on.

Conducting interviews has proven very effective in preventing immigrants from entering Taiwan under the guise of foreign spouses through marriages of convenience with Taiwanese men and women, Lo said.

According to Lo, the U.S. State Department in its annual global human trafficking report has also praised the effectiveness of the interview method in helping crack down on cross-border human trafficking.
As of the end of February this year, the number of foreign husbands and wives of Taiwanese citizens living in Taiwan had hit around 140,000, according to statistics.
As high as 58 percent of the foreign wives in Taiwan are from Vietnam, he noted.

As a large number of Vietnamese women get married to men from Taiwan, France, the United States and South Korea every year, the authorities here, as well as those in the other three countries, all require their outposts or embassies in Vietnam to conduct interviews with would-be Vietnamese spouses seeking to marry citizens from their respective countries, Lo pointed out.

The Vietnamese government also interviews its own nationals, as well as their would-be foreign wives or husbands, before issuing marriage certificates, also in a bid to crack down on marriages of convenience, he pointed out.

Speaking on the same occasion, NIA Director-General Hsieh Li-kung said NIA agents have detained 302 foreigners suspected of having entered marriages of convenience with Taiwanese people since the agency's establishment Jan. 2, 2007.
Hsieh echoed Lo's view that the interview mechanism has been very helpful in cracking down on the practice.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bamboo charcoal can boost fish growth: study

TEXT.P: Feeding fish with food blended with ground bamboo charcoal can be a natural way to boost their growth and greatly enhance the efficiency of aquaculture, according to the results of a study released over the weekend by the Fisheries Research Institute (FRI) under the Council of Agriculture.
The results were achieved through experiments in which fish food containing ground bamboo charcoal was used to feed Taiwan tilapia, a species farmed mainly for its meat.
It was found that the fish fed with ground bamboo charcoal showed significantly better results in terms of weight gain, growth and length-weight factor than those fed with normal food.
The experiments also showed that using ground bamboo charcoal and bamboo vinegar simultaneously produced better results than using ground bamboo charcoal alone.
According the FRI, previous experiments had indicated that wood charcoal and wood vinegar can yield similar outcome.

For example, feeding eels with food that incorporates ground wood charcoal and wood vinegar improves fish growth and the feed conversion rate and boosts the fish's immunity against diseases, the FRI said.

Also, giving ground wood charcoal and wood vinegar to scads decreases fat accumulation in the abdomen of the fish and reduces the relative ratios of body weight to liver weight, thus raising their meat content, the FRI stated.
Meanwhile, using the ingredients to raise carp helps ease the negative impact of nitrogen and phosphorus on the environment, the study found.

The FRI noted that the strong absorptive properties of charcoal have been proven effective in deodorizing and decomposing harmful chemical substances, and that bamboo charcoal works better than wood charcoal in this respect because of its uniform and compact texture.
The application of bamboo charcoal in animal husbandry has also produced impressive results, according to the FRI.

For instance, feeding hogs with ground bamboo charcoal can relieve gas and diarrhea and boost the animals' appetite, the FRI said. When used in chicken farming, it can make the meat more tender, increase egg-laying rates and greatly reduce the stench of the chickens' droppings, it said.
Also, feeding bamboo charcoal to lambs can enhance their growth and increase their protein digestion and nitrogen deposition, the FRI said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Labor unions to hold protest march against unemployment

TEXT.P: Several labor unions are preparing to hold a protest march in Taipei on May 1 -- Labor Day -- to demand that the government create long-term stable work for the jobless.

Representatives of the groups, which include the Taiwan Confederation of Trade Unions (TCTU), the National Federation of Bank Employees Unions (NFBEU) and the Youth Labor Union 95, held a press conference Monday in Taipei to announce the protest.
TCTU Secretary-General Hsieh Chuang-chih said it is the government's obligation to create work and curb the increasing unemployment in the face of the global economic crisis.

NFBEU Secretary-General Han Shih-hsien said for his part that the massive layoffs over the past few months by financial services operators and electronics manufacturing companies reflects the fact that workers' rights and benefits are not protected by the law at all.

Han suggested that the government amend the law to prohibit employers from using contract workers in an "inappropriate manner, " as well to ban the business of short-term labor dispatch operators, as this does not provide workers with long- term and stable jobs.

At the press conference, Youth Labor Union 95 Convener Chen Puo-chien suggested that the government should appropriate NT$80 billion (US$2.4 billion) from its special budgets each year to funnel into plans to further expand its middle- and long-term public services in fields such as nature conservation and long-term health care for senior citizens.
With that money, the government could hire as many as 160,000 people to work in public services, offering salaries of up to NT$500,000 per annum, Chen noted.

According to statistics released by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, the unemployment rate increased to 5.75 percent in February, up by 1.81 percentage points from the level of the same month of the previous year.
In the same month, Hong Kong registered an unemployment rate of 5 percent, with 4.1 percent recorded in Japan, 3.5 percent in South Korea and 2.6 percent in Singapore, the tallies show.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher for the fifth consecutive day Monday, led by financial shares.
The Taiex advanced 26.59 points, or 0.48 percent, to close at 5,556.22. A total of 7.27 billion shares changed hands on turnover of NT$147.61 billion (US$4.44 billion).
The local bourse opened higher at 5,590.70 and once advanced past the 5,600-point mark before reaching the day's low of 5,521.88.

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile as well as banking and financial shares surging the most at 1.7 percent amid optimism that profits in the banking and financial sector for the first quarter will be better than expected.
Construction stocks rose 1.6 percent, foodstuff shares moved up 1.2 percent, plastics and chemicals stocks closed up 0.7 percent, and machinery and electronics shares moved up 0.1 percent.
Only paper and pulp issues, which fell 0.7 percent, and cement shares, which shed 0.2 percent, lost ground.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,193 to 875, with 146 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$7.13 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, falling NT$0.13 to close at NT$33.250.
A total of US$1.837 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$33.380 and reached a low of 33.094.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan records deflation rate of 0.15% in March

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) in March dropped by 0.15 percent from the same month of last year, the second consecutive month deflation had been recorded, according to a report released Monday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
For the first quarter of this year, the CPI contracted by 0.01 percent year-on- year, indicating continued moderation of inflation, the report states.
Wu Chao-ming, a DGBAS section chief, said the mild deflation in March reflected the combined influences of a drop in fuel prices and a rise in the price of food and electricity.
While transport and communication costs declined 6.49 percent year-on-year in March, food prices went up 2.64 percent, Wu noted.
However, the core CPI, which excludes prices of fruit, vegetables, fish, shellfish and energy, rose by 0.81 percent year-on-year in March, the DGBAS report shows.

Meanwhile, the wholesale price index (WPI) dropped by 9.2 percent year-on-year in March, marking the fifth consecutive month in which a year-on-year decline was recorded, mainly due to a continued plunge in international agricultural and industrial commodities, the report continues.

Import and export prices calculated in U.S. dollars plummeted by 21.05 percent and 14.98 percent year-on-year, respectively, both figures marking the largest decline on record, according to the report.

Calculated in new Taiwan dollars, import and export prices were down 11.41 percent and 4.57 percent, respectively, the report states, adding that the difference in percentages mainly results from fluctuations in the respective currency exchange rates.
For the first quarter of the year, the WPI lost 9.77 percent year-on-year, according to the DGBAS.

DOC.HEADLINE: Monthly turnover at central Taiwan's science park rebounds

TEXT.P: Business turnover at the Central Taiwan Science Park in February reached NT$10.3 billion (US$309 million), up about by 20 percent over the January figure of NT$8.6 billion, the park administration reported Monday.

Thanks to gradually rebounding business sentiment across the world, the park's revenue has grown month-to-month during the first two months of this year after its operations plunged in the fourth quarter of last year due to the global financial crisis, administration officials said.

Although the combined two-month revenue of the park remains lower compared to the level posted in the same period last year, the officials said that the park's revenue is expected to continue increasing each month from its present relatively low level due to an improved business climate.
Outperforming other sectors, the precision machinery industry recorded an outstanding growth rate of 37 percent in the January-February period, the officials noted.
Facilities in the Central Taiwan Science Park are located in Taichung City, Taichung County and nearby Changhua and Yunlin counties, housing more than 150 high-tech companies.
The park was established in 2002 by the Executive Yuan. It is one of three major science parks in Taiwan, with the other two in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, and Tainan, southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cloud Gates Wanderer program bridges cultural gaps

TEXT.P: Eight Taiwanese artists participating in the renowned Cloud Gate Dance Theaters 2008Wandererprogram on Monday shared their experiences and inspirations gained from their travels in seven Asian countries, revealing how the trips changed their lives and brought Taiwan closer to different cultures.
The eight artists were winners of the 2008 Wanderer program, which provides subsidies for artists to travel abroad or take time off to gain artistic inspiration.

Sharing stories about their trips to different countries through dance, music and documentary films, the group, including four up-and-coming artists Pan Jung- sheng, Wang Shih-wei, Tzeng Ching-wen and Yang Huei-tsi, and four professional artists -- Hsue Chang-huei, Laka Wumao, Chang Yung-chieh, and Lu Shih-ming explained how cross-cultural exchanges have increased their sense of self-worth and beliefs.

For many of them, their trips were not over after coming back to Taiwan because they initiated various projects to increase cultural understanding between Taiwan and these countries, as well as to provide assistance to those in need in the impoverished areas they visited.

Documentary filmmaker Hsue Chang-huei, who spent three months in Iran, used her camera to unveil the mysteries of the Middle East country. During her visit to the Iranian Documentary Film Association, she managed to gain the rights to broadcast 14 Iranian documentary films in Taiwan, and is now looking for sponsorship to hold a Taiwan-Iran documentary film festival.
I hope the cultural distance between Taiwan and Iran will be shortened through the exchanges of these films,Hsue said.

Having traveled to Malawi, Cambodia, and Vanuatu in the Pacific prior to joining the program, Yang Huei-tsi is a well-experienced overseas volunteer. In her trip to Chinas Yunnan, Guizhou and Guangxi provinces as part of the Wanderer program to learn wax printing from the minority groups there, she decided to build a new school for a dozen orphans of the Yao tribe.

After 10 months of fund raising in Taiwan, Yang is scheduled to go back to Guangxi later this month to start the construction. She called on the public to make continuous efforts to help her see the project through to completion.
The Wanderer program was initiated in 2004 by Cloud Gate Theater founder Lin Hwai-min and has been sponsored by Stan Shih, founder of the laptop maker, the Acer group, since 2006.
Since then, the program has provided financial assistance to a total of 41 Taiwanese artists.

Lin said at the news conference Monday that he was deeply touched by the courage and passion demonstrated by the eight artists, who pursued their dreams with an open heart while at the same time tried their best to make contributions to society.
Shih, founder of the program's sponsor Stans Foundation, agreed.
These trips have not only enriched the artists, but also society,Shih said.

The Cloud Gate Theater on Monday also announced that the 2010 Wander program is now accepting applications from budding artists, professional artists or people in social service under the age of 45, who have an enthusiasm for literature, music, performance art, or image art.
Artists interested in the program can obtain more information at www.cloudgate.org.tw or contact the dance company at 02-2712-2102.
The deadline for applying is July 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: `Discover Gulliver' exhibition in central Taiwan extended to April 12

TEXT.P: The "Discover Gulliver" exhibition in the central city of Taichung will be extended from April 6 to April 12 to allow more members of the public, especially children, to see the structure of the human body from within a specially built giant human model, the sponsor of the event announced Monday.

The Paper Windmill Foundation, which built the 60-meter-long, seven-meter-high model at a cost of NT$10 million (US$302,970), said the exhibition has attracted more than 45,000 visitors since it opened at Taichung's Wenhsin Forest Park April 3, and the foundation decided to extend the show at the request of Taichung Mayor Jason Hu.

According to Paper Windmill Theater Chief Director Jen Chien-cheng, the giant human figure has a face modeled on that of the Seediq warrior Mona Rudao, who led the aboriginal people of his tribe in an armed rebellion against their Japanese occupiers in central Taiwan's Nantou County in 1930.
Jen said the mobile exhibition is a gift to Taiwan's children for 2009 Children's Day, which fell on April 4.
The structure is actually an inflated tent supported by a steel frame, with bones, muscles, internal organs and teeth made from polyvinyl chloride and polyresin.

The exhibition is named "Discover Gulliver" after Gulliver, a renowned fictional Englishman who travels to Lilliput, an imaginary land of tiny people, in the classic satirical novel by Jonathan Swift first published in 1726.

Visitors enter the body of Gulliver from his foot and travel along a route that passes his shinbone, muscles, large intestine, small intestine, lungs, beating heart, mouth, teeth -- some of which even have cavities -- and nasal chamber before exiting through an ear.
Explanations are provided by accompanying guides and the whole journey takes between 10 and 15 minutes.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA toughens rhetoric on North Koreas rocket launch

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) toughened its rhetoric Monday over North Koreas firing of a rocket over Japan a day earlier, condemning the Communist countrys move as sabotaging the stability of East Asia.

Following Vice Foreign Minister Javier C.S. Hous expression of grave concern over the incident earlier at the Legislative Yuan, the MOFA officially issued a statement later on Monday to condemn Pyongyangs rocket launch.

As a member of East Asia, the Republic of China (ROC) deeply regrets North Koreas action of sabotaging the stability of East Asia and therefore voices condemnation of such behavior,said MOFA spokesman Henry Chen.

Pyongyangs rocket launch not only violated the United Nations Security Council Resolution 1718, but also created tension and impacted the security and stability of the Asia Pacific region, the MOFA said in a press release.
It also called for the relevant parties in the world to act according to U.N. regulations regarding the matter, and to exercise self-restraint and be rational in seeking solutions to differences.
The ROC reiterated that problems on the Korean Peninsula should be resolved by means of negotiations in order to maintain regional peace, stability and prosperity, the statement added.

The play focuses on the same subject matter as that being examined in a film currently in production and titled "Seediq Bale, " directed by local filmmaker Wei Te-sheng who burst into the spotlight with his 2008 low-budget film "Cape No. 7, " which has smashed box office records in Taiwan, Huang noted.

Many local artists, including a composer and Teng Hsiang-yang -- who wrote "Dana Sakura" -- created the score for the dance that tells a story barely addressed in local society, she said, adding her hope that through the dance, audiences will gain a better knowledge of the Seediq people, their life and their culture.
After the premiere, the youth troupe will perform the dance drama again in Nantou May 2 and then in Taichung City May 8 and Taipei City May 16, according to the organizer.

The Seediq are a Taiwanese aboriginal tribe living primarily in Nantou County and Hualien County. They were officially recognized as Taiwan's 14th indigenous group April 23, 2008. Previously, the tribe, along with the closely related Truku people, were classified as Atayal, a different tribe altogether.

DOC.HEADLINE: Communist parties take advantage of Constitutional Court ruling

TEXT.P: Two communist parties, established in July and December last year, have formally registered themselves with the Ministry of the Interior and become legally protected civic organizations in Taiwan, the Interior Ministry confirmed Monday.

Ministry officials pointed out that the Taiwan Communist Party was founded after the justices of the Constitutional Court under the Judicial Yuan ruled on June 20 last year that provisions in the Civil Associations Act banning citizens of the Republic of China from advocating communism or separatism were unconstitutional.

In accordance with the court's constitutional interpretation 644, those provisions were nullified with immediate effect because they were inconsistent with the people's right to freedom of assembly, freedom of speech, and freedom of expression.

The founder of the Taiwan Communist Party had tried several times since 1994 to apply to the Interior Ministry to form the communist party but had been rejected every time because preaching communism in Taiwan was illegal until the June 20 ruling.
The party was founded on July 20 and registered with the Interior Ministry within 30 days to become Taiwan's 141st political party.

On Dec. 27 last year, the second communist party -- the Republic of China Communist Party -- was formed in Taipei, and its application to register the party with the Interior Ministry was filed early this year.
The party was formally approved on March 31, becoming Taiwan's 147th political party.
Neither of the communist parties are subordinate to the Communist Party of China although one of them has explicitly called for Taiwan's eventual reunification with China through peaceful means.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dogs playing key role in Taiwan's anti-drug trafficking efforts

TEXT.P: Sniffer dogs have become more important in detecting illegal narcotics at customs checkpoints, detecting some 20 percent of the illegal drugs brought in by travelers at Taiwan's biggest airport in the first quarter, customs authorities reported Monday.

More than 90 kilograms of unlawful drugs smuggled in by passengers were confiscated at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport in the first three months of this year, with about 20 percent of the drugs discovered by dogs serving at the airport, said the Taipei Customs Office under the Ministry of Finance.
In other neighboring Asian countries such as Japan and South Korea, sniffer dogs can detect more than 30 percent of the drugs smuggled into their airports.

The nation's squad of 26 drug sniffer dogs was established in 2002 to help customs agents crack down on an increased smuggling of illegal substances. Currently, six or seven sniffer dogs are serving at the Taoyuan airport near Taipei.
It is a growing trend across the globe to use sniffer dogs at air and sea ports to detect the smuggling of narcotics, the agents said.
Most drug traffickers concealed smuggled drugs in their luggage, while some of them were body packers who attempted to transport illicit drugs by concealing them in their cavities, the agents said.

Besides the work of the dogs, a majority -- 67 percent -- of banned drugs seized were discovered by customs agents with the help of X-ray machines, while the remaining 13 percent were tracked down through tip-offs, according to an analysis provided by the Taipei Custom Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sewage blamed for deterioration of coral reefs off Kenting

TEXT.P: The continued discharge of untreated sewage into waters off Kenting National Park in southern Taiwan is responsible for the deterioration of coral reefs in the area, an academic said Monday.

Lin Hsing-juh, a professor in National Chung Hsing University's Department of Life Sciences, came to the conclusion after monitoring and studying coral reef ecosystems off Taiwan's southernmost tip for over a decade.
His findings were published recently in the prestigious journal Limnology and Oceanography.
According to Lin, for coral reefs to thrive, they must grow in clean shallow water, with a low density of anthropogenic nutrients, a stable density of salt, moderate temperatures and bright sunshine.
Human encroachment in the form of excessive development and the arrival of 4 million tourists a year in the Kenting area has led to an influx of sewage into Kenting's coastal regions, Lin said.
Lin found that Kenting's Nanwan and Wanlitung, which boast the largest concentration of tourists, have suffered the most serious entrophication.
To facilitate his study, Lin established a mesocosm -- a controlled ecosystem approximating natural conditions -- to conduct extensive observations and experiments and verify his findings.
"Outdoor field surveys can only observe the results of coral reef deterioration while providing no clues to the processes and causes of the degeneration," Lin explained.

With the assistance of the National Museum of Marine Biology and Aquarium in southern Taiwan's Pingtung County, Lin managed to build a mesocosm -- the first of its kind built in the world -- that replicated the coral reef ecosystem in Nanwan 20 years ago when there was less human activity.
After 10 years of observation, simulations and experiments, Lin reached his conclusion that untreated sewage is to blame for the deterioration of the Kenting coral reef ecosystem.
To replicate the process of polluting the waters in the area, Lin introduced sewage or anthropogenic (human-made) nutrients into the mesocosm at a rate of 5.5 mmol per square meter.
Mmol, or millimoles, is a unit measuring the amount of a substance.

"It turned out that algae grew rapidly and completely covered corals, resulting in the death of the corals, " Lin said. He also observed that normally passive sea anemones also began to attack the coral following the introduction of the sewage.
Overfishing, particularly of fish species that can stem the growth of algae and sea anemones, has led to a further imbalance in Kenting's ecosystem, Lin said.

Noting that coral reefs are natural habitats for more than 25 percent of marine life and fish output from coral reefs accounts for 12 percent of the global fish catch, Lin said conservation of natural coral reef ecosystem was essential.
Coral reefs are also important because they can help protect the coastline, minimize beach erosion from big waves and tsunamis, and nurture coastal fishery resources, he added.

Lin said that the most urgent task at present is to prevent the excessive flow of sewage or anthropogenic contaminants into coastal waters and step up the conservation of coral reefs and fish species.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan working to rescue fishing ship hijacked by Somali pirates

TEXT.P: The government is doing everything it can to rescue a Taiwanese deep-sea fishing vessel hijacked by Somali pirates in the Indian Ocean early Monday, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said later in the day.

The 700-ton long-line fishing ship "Win Far 161, " with 30 crew members on board, was hijacked near an island in the Seychelles in the Indian Ocean, said Chang Yun-ping, director-general of the MOFA's Department of African Affairs.
According to Chang, only the ship's skipper and first engineer are Taiwanese nationals, while all other crew members originate from China, the Philippines and Indonesia.

Chang said the ministry has sought the assistance of the U.K. Maritime Trade Organization, the maritime liaison office of America's Bahrain-based 5th Fleet, the Seychelles fishery bureau and the Somali harbor bureau in rescuing the hijacked Kaohsiung-based long-liner.
Moreover, Chang said, the ministry is endeavoring to get information about the hijacked ship's latest situation through the country's representative office in South Africa and other channels.

"We have gained knowledge of the Win Far's current location. It is more than 1,000 kilometers away from land, " Chang said. He added, however, that the ministry has yet to receive any information related to the pirates' ransom request.

Asked whether the ministry will seek China's help in rescuing the ship, Chang said that as China's military fleet is currently patrolling the Gulf of Aden and the estuary of the Red Sea, far north of where the Win Far was hijacked, the ministry has no plan to approach China for assistance at the moment.

According to a foreign wire service report, the Taiwanese ship was the second attack by Somali pirates in the Seychelles within a week. A small Yemeni boat was also hijacked near the Seychelles Sunday.

Analysts say the pirates have moved many of their operations out of the Gulf of Aden, which is heavily patrolled by naval warships from a number of countries, including China, the United States, France and India.
Instead, they are targeting ships coming out of the Mozambique Channel, an area of the Indian Ocean farther south between the southeastern Africa coast and Madagascar.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taoyuan County to host Songkran Festival for Thai workers in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Thailand Trade and Economic Office in Taipei and the Taoyuan County government are inviting Thai workers in Taiwan to a gathering in a county stadium on April 12 to celebrate the Songkran Festival and usher in the Thai New Year.

Songkran, the most important festival of Thailand, falls on April 13 every year and lasts three days. It is also known as the "Water Festival" as people believe that throwing water at one another will wash away bad luck.
According to Taoyuan County government officials, there will also be performances by singers and dancers from Thailand.
The officials said that Taiwanese people are also welcome to join the Thai workers in their celebrations.
Songkran is a Thai word meaning "move" or "change place" as it is the day when the sun changes its position in the zodiac.
During the festival, Thai people gather in the streets to sing and dance, knowing they will be splashed with water and get soaked to improve their luck.
@There are about 90,000 Thai laborers working in Taiwan and most of them are concentrated in Taoyuan County.

The Taoyuan County government and the Thailand Trade and Economic Office in Taiwan have jointly held Songkran celebrations every year since 1999 to ease the homesickness of Thai workers who cannot return home for the festival, which is traditionally a time to pay respects to elders and meet old friends.

DOC.HEADLINE: High-profile Chinese delegation arrives for visit

TEXT.P: A high-profile delegation from the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) arrived in Taipei Monday for a week-long visit.

It marks the first time that the quasi-official Chinese intermediary organization has sent a delegation to Taiwan since the two sides of the Taiwan Strait resumed institutionalized dialogue in mid-2008 after a nearly 10-year hiatus.
The 13-member delegation is headed by ARATS Vice President An Min who said he was very pleased to be able to visit Taiwan after having been rejected three times beforehand.
According to An, half of the members of the delegation, including Lin Zheying, a deputy department chief of China's Ministry of Commerce, are visiting Taiwan for the first time.
An said he will take advantage of the trip to learn more about Taiwan's beauty, culture and way of life.

Noting that cross-strait economic exchanges have grown into an enormous scale, An said he looks forward to seeing normalization, stabilization and institutionalization of bilateral trade and economic cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open lower

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened lower Tuesday, moving down 58.34 points at 5,497.88 on a turnover of NT$2.87 billion (US$86.32 million).
The weighted price index gained 26.59 points, or 0.48 percent, to close at 5,556.22 Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 7, or the 12th day of the third month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1348: Charles IV, king of Bohemia, founds Prague University, the first university in central Europe.
1827: John Waller, a chemist in northern England, sells the first matches, which he invented.
1928: Chiang Kai-shek resumes the Northward Expedition at the order of the National Government.
1932: A National Emergency Conference in Loyang decides on continued resistance against Japanese aggression.
1934: Mahatma Gandhi suspends his campaign of civil disobedience against British rule in India.
1945: The Yamato, Japan's largest battleship, is sunk by U.S. aircraft carrier warplanes.
1947: Henry Ford, American car manufacturer, dies at the age of 84. He developed a gasoline-powered automobile in 1893, founded the Ford Motor Company in 1903, and mass-produced the Model T from 1908 to 1927.
1948: The World Health Organization (WHO) is founded in Geneva.
1953: Dag Hammarskjold, Swedish diplomat and political leader who won the 1961 Nobel Peace Prize posthumously, succeeds Trygve Lie as secretary-general of the United Nations.
1954: Jackie Chan, Hong Kong movie star who is noted for his action films, is born.
1963: The Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia is set up with Marshal Tito as president for life.
1969: Traffic courts are set up in Taipei City and other locations around Taiwan to begin handling traffic violation cases.
1976: Simon Kuznets, 1971 Nobel Prize winner for economics, arrives in Taipei for a three-week-visit.
1976: The Communist Party of China's Political Bureau decides at a meeting to appoint Hua Guofeng as premier and to depose Deng Xiaoping as deputy premier after riots in Beijing.
1976: Hishan M. Nazer, Saudi Arabian minister of planning, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1978: U.S. President Jimmy Carter backpedals on building the Neutron bomb.
1979: The International Olympic Committee decides the ROC can retain its membership while admitting Communist China as a new member.
1981: Voters in the Philippines approve a new constitution, giving President Ferdinand Marcos sweeping powers.
1987: U.S. President Ronald Reagan announces that American diplomats will not occupy the new embassy in Moscow until he is sure that it is secure against Soviet eavesdropping.
1989: Cheng Nan-jong, the person in charge of the "Era of Freedom" magazine, immolates himself after refusing arrest for involvement in an insurrection case.
1989: The Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee announces that ROC athletic teams and organizations will participate in international sports events held on the mainland under the name "Chinese Taipei."
1990: Communist China launches a U.S.-made telecommunications satellite into orbit.
1998: Indonesia and the International Monetary Fund agree on a package of measures to get a US$43 billion bailout package on track.
1999: Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Minister Chiao Jen-ho urges the government to step up its international publicity drive to buttress global awareness of the Republic of China.
2000: Almost two-dozen founding members of the hard-line Independence Party announce their decision to drop out of the party because they say that the party has completed its mission.
2001: Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, receives a set of CNA file photos, including one showing he in the arms of his mother along with his father and his elder brother.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When there is justice and order in the government of the country, to think only of pay is dishonorable. When there is no justice and order in the government of the country, to think only of pay is also dishonorable."
