DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Immigration officials required to report domestic violence

TEXT.P: Immigration officials will now be required to report domestic violence cases after the Legislative Yuan on Tuesday amended the Domestic Violence Prevention Act, a step lawmakers hope will improve the protection of foreign spouses.
The amended law requires immigration officials to inform concerned authorities within 24 hours after discovering such cases, just as social workers are currently required to do.

Ruling Kuomintang Legislator Shyu Jong-shyong, the initiator of the amendment, noted that the step is necessary to protect foreign spouses because immigration officials are the civil servants who maintain the most contact with them.

As of the end of August 2008, there were approximately 400,000 foreign and Chinese spouses in Taiwan, Shyu noted, adding that many of them are not aware of ways to file complaints about domestic violence because of language barriers.

According to statistics from the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) , 6,539 cases of domestic violence were reported in January 2009, an increase of 8.9 percent from the same month of last year when 6,006 cases were reported.

Nearly 60 percent of the cases involved violence between spouses, former spouses or cohabitants. More than 17 percent concerned abuse of children or teenagers, and another 3 percent involved assaults on the elderly.
In 2008, 79,874 domestic violence cases were reported, up 10 percent from 2007 when 72,606 cases were reported, the statistics show.

Concerned that the current economic recession might lead to a spike in the incidence of this type of abuse, the legislature adopted a rider along with the passage of the amendment Tuesday that will require the MOI to increase its budget for domestic violence prevention for 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese expatriates, tourists safe in Italy's earthquake: MOFA

TEXT.P: No Taiwanese expatriates or tourists were among those killed in a deadly earthquake that hit central Italy Monday, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) confirmed Tuesday while also pledging disaster relief assistance if the Italian government requests it.

Anne Hung, director-general of the MOFA's Department of European Affairs, said at a regular press briefing that according to the Foreign Ministry's representative office in Rome, no Taiwanese expatriates were among the casualties in Monday's earthquake in central Italy's Abruzzo.
She added that three Taiwanese tourist groups that include 58 people traveling in Italy are also safe and will continue their trips in the country.

On behalf of Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou and Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, the foreign ministry has expressed its condolences to the Italian government and the willingness to offer necessary help if it requests it," Hung said.

MOFA spokesman Henry Chen denied speculation that there was any delay in disclosing the condition of Taiwanese in Italy after the earthquake occurred, saying that after receiving a call from its representative office in Rome at 9:40 a.m. Taipei time, the ministry took immediate action to try to confirm the safety of Taiwanese nationals in Italy.
Protecting our expatriates is the responsibility to which the ministry devotes absolutely every effort,Chen said.
According to media reports, at least 150 were killed in the 6.3-magnitude quake -- Italy's deadliest earthquake in three decades -- which also left 1,500 injured and 70,000 homeless.

DOC.HEADLINE: No news on safety of crew of hijacked fishing vessel

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday that it is closely monitoring the movement of a Taiwanese deep sea fishing vessel hijacked by Somali pirates in the Indian Ocean early Monday but still does not have any news regarding the safety of its crew members.

The ministry cannot confirm at the moment casualties, if any, among crew members because we have lost contact with the vessel since yesterday, said MOFA spokesman Henry Chen at a regular press briefing.
But based on past experience, their safety should not be a problem if the pirates are simply looking to collect a ransom, he added.
According to Chen, the foreign ministry has gained knowledge of the location of the hijacked vessel and is following its course. But he said the hijackers have yet to demand a ransom.

The 700-ton long-line fishing shipWin Far 161was hijacked near an island in the Seychelles in the Indian Ocean on Monday, according to the MOFA, and it is currently some 1,500 kilometers away from land.
Among its 30 crew members, the ship's skipper and first engineer are Taiwanese nationals, while five other are Chinese, 17 are Filipinos and six are Indonesian.

In addition to trying to get the latest information about the ship through its representative office in South Africa, the foreign ministry has sought the assistance of the U.K. Maritime Trade Organization, the maritime liaison office of America's Bahrain-based 5th Fleet, the Seychelles fishery bureau and the Somali harbor bureau in rescuing the hijacked Kaohsiung-based long-liner.

Asked whether the ship has sent out a distress signal, Chen said the incident was reported back to the ship's owner in Taiwan by three other fishing vessels of the same company working in the area. They all returned to the Seychelles immediately after the incident occurred.
As to whether the Chinese government has offered to assist, Chen said so far no such offer has been made but the ministry is actively seeking help from all types of channels.

Foreign wire services reported that pirates are now avoiding the Gulf of Aden because it is heavily patrolled by warships from countries such as the United States, Japan and China and choosing to attack merchant vessels far off Somalia's coast.

DOC.HEADLINE: 45,000 of last year's graduates still looking for jobs: job bank

TEXT.P: Approximately 45,000 2008 university graduates who have had their resumes posted with online employment broker 104 Job Bank are still looking for work, according to statistics released Tuesday by the company.
The group represents some 21 percent of the 210,000 graduates who posted their resumes on the job bank site, the company said.
Meanwhile, a survey conducted March 9-12 among 1,135 of the graduates found that 14.8 percent of them had been searching for jobs for over eight months.
Asked about the reasons behind their failure to land jobs, 48.5 percent of the job seekers mentioned their lack of work experience and 38.6 percent said there are too many people looking for jobs.
Also, 31.1 percent of job seekers complained about the few employment opportunities available, and 29.8 percent attributed their failure to their lack of professional skills.
According to the job bank, the job seekers' failure to adjust their job-search strategies to the needs of the labor market could also be a factor in their inability to land jobs.

While 33 percent of the job seekers were targeting general administrative positions and 21.5 percent desired to become customer service agents, these positions are not highly demanded by businesses, the job bank said.

The latest data from the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics show that Taiwan's unemployment rate continued to rise to 5.75 percent in February as a result of the economic downturn, with 634,000 people out of work.
The unemployment duration of first-time job seekers averaged 34.1 weeks, significantly higher than the average of 24.9 weeks for experienced job seekers.

DOC.HEADLINE: All-male Taiwanese dance troupe wins acclaim in New York
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 6 (CNA) 04/07/09 14:40:34 (By Lillian Lin and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first all-male dance troupe -- the Horse Dance Theater -- was praised by The New York Times for its unique style and innovation after performing in New York recently.
Invited by the Ballet Tech Foundation for the second time, the troupe performed the premiere of "Bones" at the Joyce Theater in New York as part of the Mandance Project's 2009 Spring Season.

Following the premiere, a dance review published April 5 in the New York Times praised the rapport among the dancers and their impressive body language and vivid movement, as well as the style presented on stage.
The Horse Dance Theater's productions are collectively choreographed and performed by the troupe's five dancers Su Wei-gia, Chen Wu-kang, Chou Shu-yi, Yang Yu-min, and Cheng Tsung-lung.

Yang, a student at Taipei National University of the Arts' Graduate Institute of Dance Choreography, said that the troupe is a rare ensemble made up of a group of longtime friends who know each other well.
As a co-founder who has been involved in the group's collective choreography since the theater was founded in 2005, Yang said that one of the troupe's strengths is partnership among its members.

Meanwhile, Cheng, who performed with the group in New York for the first time and whose choreography has been recognized in recent years, said their motivation in creating and dancing in Bones was to do something that made them happy rather than preparing a production to be performed.
Cheng is also a contracted choreographer of Cloud Gate 2, an offshoot of the world renowned Cloud Gate Dance Theater composed of Cloud Gate's younger dancers.
He has been invited as an artist-in-residence to work at the Watermill Center in New York and created a new production for the Transition Dance Company of the Laban Center in London in 2008.
The up-and-coming choreographer is currently in Taipei preparing to stage his new work The Wall during Cloud Gate 2's spring season programs slated to open April 10.
After appearing in New York, the five dancers will not perform together in the next few months.

Chou will join an artists-in-residence project in North Carolina in May. In the past two years, he has performed in works staged by Hsu Fang-yi's LA/FA Dance Theater and joined in a performance of Asian dancers in Hong Kong.
According to Chou, a soundscrape created by French sound artist Yannick Dauby for Bones has won recognition from New York choreographer Eliot Feld, who is also the project organizer.
Chou said Dauby has been a partner of the Horse Dance Theater since he made the acquaintance of Dauby during a 2007 artists-in-residence project in Taipei.
After their New York performance, the troupe's five members will be busy preparing for the opening ceremony of the 2009 Taipei Deaflympics slated for September, Yang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's top earners cautious about finances: survey

TEXT.P: High income earners in Taiwan tend to be cautious about their personal finances, with one of their main principles being to avoid indebtedness, according to the results of an international survey released Tuesday by Visa International Taiwan.
The results showed that 42 percent of the Taiwanese respondents listed debt disposal as their top objective with regard to their personal finances.
Also, only 14 percent of the wealthy Taiwanese in the survey said they would borrow money for investment purposes.
In the same category, 42 percent of the respondents in China and 25 percent in Hong Kong said they would take loans for this purpose.

The survey, conducted between Sept. 29 and Oct. 21, 2008, targeted the top 20 percent to 40 percent most wealthy households in Taiwan, China, Hong Kong, Singapore, Australia, Japan, South Korea and India. A total of 4,106 people were interviewed, including 1,545 from Taiwan, Hong Kong and China.

The survey found that for 86 percent of the Taiwanese respondents, increasing personal wealth is their top career objective, compared with 67 percent who wish to gain professional respect and 55 percent who are seeking opportunities for promotion.
While 74 percent of the Taiwanese respondents listed savings and preparation for retirement as their top priority, 59 percent said their main aim is to provide the best education for their children.

Sixty-percent of Taiwanese high income earners have not used the personal investment, priority or private banking services provided by banks, compared with 37 percent among those from China and 32 percent among those from Hong Kong, the poll found.
Sixty percent of the wealthy respondents in China hold personal investment or priority services accounts, while 14 percent hold private banking accounts, according to the survey.
In Taiwan, however, only 36 percent hold personal investment or priority services accounts, and 8 percent hold private banking accounts, the poll showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Missing gun found at airport to be returned to Brazilian man

TEXT.P: A pistol belonging to a Brazilian government security guard is being returned to its owner by local airport authorities after it was mistakenly transported to Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport near Taipei, airport police said Tuesday.
The Brazilian security guard reported his pistol was missing after returning home from an international conference in Indonesia, where he was accompanying a Brazilian official.
He asked the airlines he took to help track the weapon down, and it was eventually discovered that the suitcase containing the gun had been inadvertently flown to Taiwan, rather than back to Brazil.
Workers at the Taoyuan airport found the suitcase under a mountain of luggage, which had not left the airport, airport police said.

According to airport police, the gun is being sent back to its owner in Brazil after an investigation ruled out the possibility that it may have been linked to any crime or intended to be used for any criminal act.
The pistol, divided into several parts, was kept in a box along with three cartridges, and there was a clear imprint showing "police" on its barrel, airport police said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher for the sixth consecutive day Tuesday, after opening weaker following overnight losses on Wall Street.
The Taiex advanced 20.63 points, or 0.37 percent, to close at 5,576.85. A total of 5.95 billion shares changed hands on turnover of NT$117.40 billion (US$ 3.50 billion).
The local bourse opened lower at 5,497.88 and fluctuated between 5,576.85 and 5,484.89.

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp stocks surging the most at 4.8 percent. Construction shares advanced 2.6 percent, plastics and chemicals dropped 1.3 percent, foodstuff issues rose 1.2 percent, and machinery and electronics stocks gained 0.5 percent.

The three other major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks falling the most at 2.8 percent. Cement issues dropped 1.6 percent, while banking and financial sector slipped 0.5 percent, snapping more than one week of gains amid pessimism over the Legislative Yuan's plan to pass a law amendment to lower the ceiling interest rate for revolving credit recorded by holders of credit and cash cards to 12.5 percent per annum from the existing 20 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,100 to 925, with 135 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net seller of shares worth NT$7.16 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: Halting a five-session losing streak, the U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, increasing NT$0.319 to close at NT$33.569.
A total of US$937 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.500 and fluctuated between NT$33.240 and NT$33.700.
Analysts attributed the greenback's rebound to the intervention of Taiwan's central bank.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan wins big at Geneva invention exhibition
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 7 (CNA) 04/07/09 18:03:47 (By Han Nai-kuo and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: In its best performance ever, Taiwan won 21 gold, nine silver and four bronze medals at the 37th International Exhibition of Inventions of Geneva, an education official here said Tuesday.
Thirty-four of the 35 entries Taiwan submitted won prizes at the exhibition.

National Yunlin University of Science and Technology in south-central Taiwan bagged two golds and two silvers for its four inventions, posting a 100 percent award-winning rate, according to a university official.
At the exhibition which was held April 1-5, more than 1,000 entries were submitted by 710 participants from 45 countries around the world.

Taiwan's award-winning inventions include multiple fun brain games using six wood building blocks, know as "Luban Lock;" a drawing compass and digital protractor; high speed-reducing ratio planetary gear transmission; an umbrella with ultraviolet sensor.

DOC.HEADLINE: Decline in exports further narrows in March

TEXT.P: Taiwan's export volume in March amounted to US$15.59 billion, the highest value recorded over the past four months, due mainly to rush orders and inventory refill from clients, according to a report released Tuesday by the Ministry of Finance (MOF).

However, the amount was US$8.65 billion, or 35.7 percent, less than the same month of last year. The decline, nonetheless, was narrower compared with the plunge of 41.9 percent in December and 37.2 percent for the January-February period, MOF officials said.
Further observation is needed in the next two to three months to judge whether the economic downturn has hit bottom, the officials said.
In March, the largest decrease in terms of value was seen in semiconductor exports, which lost US$1.98 billion, or 33.6 percent, year-on-year, the report showed.
Coming in second were TFT-LCD products and their parts and components, which were down US$1.27 billion, or 58.1 percent.
Base metals and their products dropped US$1.05 billion, or 39.6 percent, and chemicals fell US$830 million, or 46.1 percent.

Meanwhile, import volume in March was valued at US$12.17 billion, down US$11.94 billion, or 49.5 percent, year-on-year -- the largest decline on record -- owing to sluggish domestic demand, MOF officials said.
A trade surplus amounting to US$3.41 billion was recorded in March, up 25.4 times year-on-year and hitting the highest level for a single month since December 2007.

For the first quarter of this year, the export volume amounted to US$40.55 billion, a decrease of 36.6 percent year-on-year, and the import volume was down 47.2 percent to stand at US$32.06 billion, both marking the largest contraction for a single quarter.
The trade surplus of US$8.49 billion for the first quarter, however, marked an increase of 155.3 percent compared with the same time last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan professor gains membership in American Ceramic Society

TEXT.P: A professor at National Cheng Kung University has been selected as a fellow of the American Ceramic Society, which gives him the distinction of being the third Taiwanese in a century to become a member of the organization, an official of the Tainan City-based university announced Tuesday.

Huang Jow-lay, who teaches at the university's Department of Materials Science and Engineering, graduated from National Ching Hua University and earned a doctorate degree in materials science and engineering at the University of Utah. He specializes in ceramic materials, complex materials, electric materials and surface and coatings technology, according to the official.

Founded in 1989, the American Ceramic Society is one of the world's most important membership organizations for international materials science professionals. The organization serves the informational, educational, and professional needs of its 6,000 members from 60 countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Home of Taiwanese ship seized by Somali pirates a major tuna producer

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung, the southern Taiwanese city where the Taiwanese fishing vessel seized by Somali pirates originated, is the world's second largest tuna producer.

Fishing vessels based in the city can catch nearly 200,000 tons of tuna fish each year, with the annual production value of the local tuna fishing industry hitting around NT$20 billion (US$599 million) , according to officials at the Kaohsiung City Marine Bureau.
"Kaohsiung City's tuna fish catch is the world's largest or second-largest," bureau officials said.
According to the bureau, local deep-sea fishing boats, like the one seized Monday, catch mostly tuna, squid and saury pike.

The "Win Far 161, " a 700-ton fishing ship which was hijacked by Somali pirates early Monday in the Indian Ocean, is a long-line tuna fishing boat from Kaohsiung City, bureau officials said, confirming what Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs reported Monday.

The Kaohsiung City Tuna Association said 360 fishing ships registered with the southern Taiwanese city operate in various oceans in the world, including the Indian Ocean, the Pacific and the Atlantic.
Most of them are large long-line ships weighing over 100 tons, and their catch are mainly exported to Japan, Europe and the United States, association officials said.
As of Tuesday evening, there was still no word about the whereabouts of the vessel and its 30-member crew, which include two Taiwanese citizens. No ransom demand has surfaced.
The boat is one of several ships from various countries seized by Somali pirates in recent days.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Loving home', not wealth, key to children's happiness: survey

TEXT.P: A survey conducted this year has found that more children said they feel happy than those in a similar poll last year, and that having a loving home and living well are the two leading factors that make kids feel happy.

The annual survey on children's happiness was conducted by the "Better Life" monthly magazine on students between the third grade and sixth grade from 42 elementary schools in Taiwan from late 2008 to early 2009.
The Taipei-based magazine held a press conference Tuesday to publicize the results, after collecting 2,002 valid questionnaires.
The results show that 83.4 percent of the surveyed students said they feel happy, up 4.6 percent from the previous year.

The level of happiness found in the latest survey marks the second highest level recorded since the poll was first launched in 2001, when 84.2 percent kids said they were happy, according to Tsai Wen-che, a pediatrician at the psychiatry department of Taiwan University Hospital's Children Mental Health Center.
More than half of the happy children, or 51.8 percent, said they feel happy because they have a sweet home with parents and they spend happy hours with their parents.

Tsai said the family does not have to be wealthy for kids to feel happy, as survey results showed that most children attributed being happy to their parents spending time with them, while only 16.2 percent of the respondents said they feel happy because they live well.

The survey also found that the leading factors that make school boys and girls unhappy were "academic performance problems" and "quarrels with family members, " followed by "no money at home" and "being dressed down."
Given that the number of children feeling happy has gone up compared to previous years, Tsai said it seems that the economic downturn has not yet had a big impact on children.

However, Tsai said the growth in the percentage of happy kids could have resulted from the fact that parents now have more time to spend with their children since many of them have been forced to take unpaid leave.

Despite this, Tsai said, there has been a surge in the number of children who appeared worried about the family's financial state and more children who are not happy attributed their unhappiness to financial problems.

Notably, the percentage of students expressing they are not happy because of "no money at home" increased from the 5.2 percent in 2008 to 13.6 percent this year, according to the survey, while that of the kids attributing their unhappiness to "divorce of parents" rose from 4.5 percent to 12 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Boy dies of enterovirus in southern Taiwan

TEXT.P: A two-year-old boy in southern Taiwan's Yunlin County has died after being infected with enterovirus, the first victim of the disease this year, Centers for Disease Control (CDC) Deputy Director Shih Wen-yi said Tuesday.

Citing an April 5 notice to the CDC from National Cheng Kung University Hospital in Tainan City where the boy was treated, Shih said the patient fell sick March 31, with symptoms of fever, vomiting and hand-foot-and-mouth syndrome.

He received initial treatment at a hospital in Singang rural township in Chiayi County before being referred to a clinic in Chiayi City April 2 after he continued to suffer cramps and persistent fever, and was finally admitted to the National Cheng Kung University Hospital in Tainan City April 4, by which time he was suffering drowsiness, increased heart rate and cold extremities.
Suspecting that he was suffering from enterovirus infection, the hospital alerted the CDC and admitted him to the intensive care unit, where the boy died April 5.
CDC experts later determined that the boy was a victim of enterovirus type 71(EV71).
Shih noted that 11 severe enterovirus infections have been recorded in Taiwan this year, most of them in southern parts of the country.
A Yunlin County health official said the victim's five-year old brother, who attended a kindergarten in Chiayi, had developed hand-foot-and-mouth syndrome March 28 but recovered after treatment.
The local health authorities disinfected the kindergarten and checked the children's temperatures every day. However, none of the other children had developed symptoms.

Enteroviruses are the most common cause of aseptic meningitis and can be deadly, especially in young children. EV71 -- the deadliest type of enterovirus -- is one of the major causative agents of hand-foot-and-mouth syndrome and is sometimes associated with severe central nervous system diseases.

In 1998, Taiwan experienced a serious outbreak of EV71, with 405 severe infections recorded, 78 of which were fatal. Another EV71 outbreak in 2005 resulted in 145 severe infections, 15 of which were fatal.

DOC.HEADLINE: Softex Taipei participants to open more booths to promote trade

TEXT.P: Despite the dark cloud of global recession that has engulfed Taiwan for several months, manufacturers and traders in 3C products still regard the upcoming Softex Taipei show as a good opportunity to promote sales and have applied to set up more booths at the venue than ever before.

The 2009 Softex Taipei will take place at the Taipei World Trade Center April 9-13. It will be the only 3C (computer, communications and consumer electronics) products show targeting consumers in the first half of the year in Taipei, according to the Taipei Computer Association (TCA), which organizes the annual event.
Softex, known locally as the "spring computer show, " has been touted as the best place to showcase the newest technology inventions, as it attracts over 300,000 visitors each year, the TCA said.

This year, 120 businesses have applied to have a presence at the show, the same amount of participants as last year, although the number of exhibition booths will increase from 660 to 700, according to the TCA.

Lenovo Taiwan General Manager Benjamin Ou said Tuesday that while many technology businesses have been receiving rush orders over the past few weeks -- seen as a sign that the recession might have bottomed out -- they still hope Softex will trigger further demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City extends trial period of bicycle rental service

TEXT.P: The Taipei City government has decided to extend the deposit-free trial period for its public bicycle rental program until the end of April and will open five more rental stations, as the service has been growing in popularity since it was launched last month, the Taipei City Department of Transportation announced Tuesday.

In the trial phase of the city's YouBike program, from March 11 to April 10, users were allowed to register for a one-day or five-day membership card that would be valid for a month, without having to pay the NT$3,000 (US$89) deposit. They were also not required to pay the rental fees of NT$40 per day or NT$1,500 per year.

As of April 5, some 9,500 people had used the service, according to an official of the citys Department of Transportation. Due to the popularity of the service, the city government decided to extend the concessionary period to the end of April and to install another five self-service meters with effect from April 11 for rental of the bikes, the official said.

This will bring to 10 the number of YouBike Bicycle Parking Meters in downtown Taipei. The five already in service are located at the Xinyi Square, City Hall Square, Taipei City Hall, MRT Taipei City Hall Station and Taipei World Trade Center (TWTC) Hall 3. The five new ones will be at MRT Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall Station, Taipei Municipal Xingya Junior High School, Taipei Disaster Prevention and Response Center, New York New York Shopping Mall and exit C of TWTC Hall 1.

The public bicycle rental service go into full operation on May 1. Users will then be required to apply for short-term or long-term membership cards, which will give them the first 30 minutes of each rental session free of cost, the official said. After the first half an hour, the fee will be NT$10 for every 15 minutes.
During the extended trial period, customers can use IC credit cards or the city's EasyCard to register free of cost at the 10 YouBike stations.
"In order to safeguard the personal information of credit card users and ensure the safety of the transactions, only IC credit cards will be permitted for use at the kiosks," the official said.
However, from April 11, magnetic strip credit cards will be accepted at the YouBike Service Center located at exit 3 of MRT Taipei City Hall Station, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Jiangsu-based businessmen want direct Wuxi-Taiwan flights
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, April 7 (CNA) 04/07/09 22:23:02 (By H.H. Chiao and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese businessmen operating in China's Jiangsu Province called Tuesday for the opening of non-stop flights between Taiwan and the province's Wuxi airport to help them save on travel time.

Sun Chia-chun, chairman of the Taiwan Businessmen's Association in Wuxi, said the heads of Taiwanese businessmen's organizations in 13 cities in central and southern Jiangsu Province, including Wuxi, Suzhou, Kunshan, Yangzhou, Wujiang and Nantong, have signed a petition expressing their desire for better air links.

Sun said they will raise the proposal in the upcoming third round of talks between the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation and the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits scheduled to take place in China.

According to Sun, about 1,800 Taiwanese enterprises and some 300,000 Taiwanese students, businessmen and their families are presently based in central and southern regions of Jiangsu Province, but there are no direct flights linking Wuxi and Taiwan.

Instead of landing at the Wuxi airport, he went on, they usually have to fly to and from Taiwan through Shanghai's Pudong Airport in neighboring Zhejiang Province or via Nanjing's Lukou International Airport.
"The Wuxi airport already serves non-stop flights to Macau and Hong Kong," he noted.
If non-stop flights can be put in place between Taiwan and Wuxi, it will be a great boon to Taiwanese businessmen operating in central and southern regions of Jiangsu, Sun said.

Chi Chih, chairman of the Taiwan Businessmen's Association in Wujiang, said that neither Pudong Airport nor the Nanjing airport serve them adequately, as traveling to and from each of them entails a round-trip drive of some five hours.

Wang I-lung, a vice chairman of the Taiwan Businessmen's Association in Suzhou, echoed the viewpoint, adding that many Taiwanese businessmen based in the Suzhou area have complained about the waste of time involved traveling between Suzhou and Shanghai.

A flight between Taiwan and Shanghai takes only about 80 minutes, but it takes at least two hours to make a one-way trip from Pudong Airport to Suzhou, he noted, adding that the drive from Suzhou to Wuxi takes only 30 minutes.

Wang Wen-chao, also a vice chairman of the Suzhou Taiwan businessmen's association, said having to use Pudong Airport or Lukou International Airport to travel between Suzhou and Taiwan is a serious headache as road traffic between Suzhou and either of the two airports is usually terrible.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher for the sixth consecutive day Tuesday, after opening weaker following overnight losses on Wall Street.
The Taiex advanced 20.63 points, or 0.37 percent, to close at 5,576.85. A total of 5.95 billion shares changed hands on turnover of NT$117.40 billion (US$ 3.50 billion).
The local bourse opened lower at 5,497.88 and fluctuated between 5,576.85 and 5,484.89.

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp stocks surging the most at 4.8 percent. Construction shares advanced 2.6 percent, plastics and chemicals dropped 1.3 percent, foodstuff issues rose 1.2 percent, and machinery and electronics stocks gained 0.5 percent.

The three other major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks falling the most at 2.8 percent. Cement issues dropped 1.6 percent, while banking and financial sector slipped 0.5 percent, snapping more than one week of gains amid pessimism over the Legislative Yuan's plan to pass a law amendment to lower the ceiling interest rate for revolving credit recorded by holders of credit and cash cards to 12.5 percent per annum from the existing 20 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,100 to 925, with 135 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net seller of shares worth NT$7.16 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: Halting a five-session losing streak, the U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, increasing NT$0.319 to close at NT$33.569.
A total of US$937 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.500 and fluctuated between NT$33.240 and NT$33.700.
Analysts attributed the greenback's rebound to the intervention of Taiwan's central bank.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan wins big at Geneva invention exhibition
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 7 (CNA) 04/07/09 18:03:47 (By Han Nai-kuo and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: In its best performance ever, Taiwan won 21 gold, nine silver and four bronze medals at the 37th International Exhibition of Inventions of Geneva, an education official here said Tuesday.
Thirty-four of the 35 entries Taiwan submitted won prizes at the exhibition.

National Yunlin University of Science and Technology in south-central Taiwan bagged two golds and two silvers for its four inventions, posting a 100 percent award-winning rate, according to a university official.
At the exhibition which was held April 1-5, more than 1,000 entries were submitted by 710 participants from 45 countries around the world.

Taiwan's award-winning inventions include multiple fun brain games using six wood building blocks, know as "Luban Lock;" a drawing compass and digital protractor; high speed-reducing ratio planetary gear transmission; an umbrella with ultraviolet sensor.

DOC.HEADLINE: Decline in exports further narrows in March

TEXT.P: Taiwan's export volume in March amounted to US$15.59 billion, the highest value recorded over the past four months, due mainly to rush orders and inventory refill from clients, according to a report released Tuesday by the Ministry of Finance (MOF).

However, the amount was US$8.65 billion, or 35.7 percent, less than the same month of last year. The decline, nonetheless, was narrower compared with the plunge of 41.9 percent in December and 37.2 percent for the January-February period, MOF officials said.
Further observation is needed in the next two to three months to judge whether the economic downturn has hit bottom, the officials said.
In March, the largest decrease in terms of value was seen in semiconductor exports, which lost US$1.98 billion, or 33.6 percent, year-on-year, the report showed.
Coming in second were TFT-LCD products and their parts and components, which were down US$1.27 billion, or 58.1 percent.
Base metals and their products dropped US$1.05 billion, or 39.6 percent, and chemicals fell US$830 million, or 46.1 percent.

Meanwhile, import volume in March was valued at US$12.17 billion, down US$11.94 billion, or 49.5 percent, year-on-year -- the largest decline on record -- owing to sluggish domestic demand, MOF officials said.
A trade surplus amounting to US$3.41 billion was recorded in March, up 25.4 times year-on-year and hitting the highest level for a single month since December 2007.

For the first quarter of this year, the export volume amounted to US$40.55 billion, a decrease of 36.6 percent year-on-year, and the import volume was down 47.2 percent to stand at US$32.06 billion, both marking the largest contraction for a single quarter.
The trade surplus of US$8.49 billion for the first quarter, however, marked an increase of 155.3 percent compared with the same time last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan professor gains membership in American Ceramic Society

TEXT.P: A professor at National Cheng Kung University has been selected as a fellow of the American Ceramic Society, which gives him the distinction of being the third Taiwanese in a century to become a member of the organization, an official of the Tainan City-based university announced Tuesday.

Huang Jow-lay, who teaches at the university's Department of Materials Science and Engineering, graduated from National Ching Hua University and earned a doctorate degree in materials science and engineering at the University of Utah. He specializes in ceramic materials, complex materials, electric materials and surface and coatings technology, according to the official.

Founded in 1989, the American Ceramic Society is one of the world's most important membership organizations for international materials science professionals. The organization serves the informational, educational, and professional needs of its 6,000 members from 60 countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Home of Taiwanese ship seized by Somali pirates a major tuna producer

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung, the southern Taiwanese city where the Taiwanese fishing vessel seized by Somali pirates originated, is the world's second largest tuna producer.

Fishing vessels based in the city can catch nearly 200,000 tons of tuna fish each year, with the annual production value of the local tuna fishing industry hitting around NT$20 billion (US$599 million) , according to officials at the Kaohsiung City Marine Bureau.
"Kaohsiung City's tuna fish catch is the world's largest or second-largest," bureau officials said.
According to the bureau, local deep-sea fishing boats, like the one seized Monday, catch mostly tuna, squid and saury pike.

The "Win Far 161, " a 700-ton fishing ship which was hijacked by Somali pirates early Monday in the Indian Ocean, is a long-line tuna fishing boat from Kaohsiung City, bureau officials said, confirming what Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs reported Monday.

The Kaohsiung City Tuna Association said 360 fishing ships registered with the southern Taiwanese city operate in various oceans in the world, including the Indian Ocean, the Pacific and the Atlantic.
Most of them are large long-line ships weighing over 100 tons, and their catch are mainly exported to Japan, Europe and the United States, association officials said.
As of Tuesday evening, there was still no word about the whereabouts of the vessel and its 30-member crew, which include two Taiwanese citizens. No ransom demand has surfaced.
The boat is one of several ships from various countries seized by Somali pirates in recent days.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Loving home', not wealth, key to children's happiness: survey

TEXT.P: A survey conducted this year has found that more children said they feel happy than those in a similar poll last year, and that having a loving home and living well are the two leading factors that make kids feel happy.

The annual survey on children's happiness was conducted by the "Better Life" monthly magazine on students between the third grade and sixth grade from 42 elementary schools in Taiwan from late 2008 to early 2009.
The Taipei-based magazine held a press conference Tuesday to publicize the results, after collecting 2,002 valid questionnaires.
The results show that 83.4 percent of the surveyed students said they feel happy, up 4.6 percent from the previous year.

The level of happiness found in the latest survey marks the second highest level recorded since the poll was first launched in 2001, when 84.2 percent kids said they were happy, according to Tsai Wen-che, a pediatrician at the psychiatry department of Taiwan University Hospital's Children Mental Health Center.
More than half of the happy children, or 51.8 percent, said they feel happy because they have a sweet home with parents and they spend happy hours with their parents.

Tsai said the family does not have to be wealthy for kids to feel happy, as survey results showed that most children attributed being happy to their parents spending time with them, while only 16.2 percent of the respondents said they feel happy because they live well.

The survey also found that the leading factors that make school boys and girls unhappy were "academic performance problems" and "quarrels with family members, " followed by "no money at home" and "being dressed down."
Given that the number of children feeling happy has gone up compared to previous years, Tsai said it seems that the economic downturn has not yet had a big impact on children.

However, Tsai said the growth in the percentage of happy kids could have resulted from the fact that parents now have more time to spend with their children since many of them have been forced to take unpaid leave.

Despite this, Tsai said, there has been a surge in the number of children who appeared worried about the family's financial state and more children who are not happy attributed their unhappiness to financial problems.

Notably, the percentage of students expressing they are not happy because of "no money at home" increased from the 5.2 percent in 2008 to 13.6 percent this year, according to the survey, while that of the kids attributing their unhappiness to "divorce of parents" rose from 4.5 percent to 12 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Boy dies of enterovirus in southern Taiwan

TEXT.P: A two-year-old boy in southern Taiwan's Yunlin County has died after being infected with enterovirus, the first victim of the disease this year, Centers for Disease Control (CDC) Deputy Director Shih Wen-yi said Tuesday.

Citing an April 5 notice to the CDC from National Cheng Kung University Hospital in Tainan City where the boy was treated, Shih said the patient fell sick March 31, with symptoms of fever, vomiting and hand-foot-and-mouth syndrome.

He received initial treatment at a hospital in Singang rural township in Chiayi County before being referred to a clinic in Chiayi City April 2 after he continued to suffer cramps and persistent fever, and was finally admitted to the National Cheng Kung University Hospital in Tainan City April 4, by which time he was suffering drowsiness, increased heart rate and cold extremities.
Suspecting that he was suffering from enterovirus infection, the hospital alerted the CDC and admitted him to the intensive care unit, where the boy died April 5.
CDC experts later determined that the boy was a victim of enterovirus type 71(EV71).
Shih noted that 11 severe enterovirus infections have been recorded in Taiwan this year, most of them in southern parts of the country.
A Yunlin County health official said the victim's five-year old brother, who attended a kindergarten in Chiayi, had developed hand-foot-and-mouth syndrome March 28 but recovered after treatment.
The local health authorities disinfected the kindergarten and checked the children's temperatures every day. However, none of the other children had developed symptoms.

Enteroviruses are the most common cause of aseptic meningitis and can be deadly, especially in young children. EV71 -- the deadliest type of enterovirus -- is one of the major causative agents of hand-foot-and-mouth syndrome and is sometimes associated with severe central nervous system diseases.

In 1998, Taiwan experienced a serious outbreak of EV71, with 405 severe infections recorded, 78 of which were fatal. Another EV71 outbreak in 2005 resulted in 145 severe infections, 15 of which were fatal.

DOC.HEADLINE: Softex Taipei participants to open more booths to promote trade

TEXT.P: Despite the dark cloud of global recession that has engulfed Taiwan for several months, manufacturers and traders in 3C products still regard the upcoming Softex Taipei show as a good opportunity to promote sales and have applied to set up more booths at the venue than ever before.

The 2009 Softex Taipei will take place at the Taipei World Trade Center April 9-13. It will be the only 3C (computer, communications and consumer electronics) products show targeting consumers in the first half of the year in Taipei, according to the Taipei Computer Association (TCA), which organizes the annual event.
Softex, known locally as the "spring computer show, " has been touted as the best place to showcase the newest technology inventions, as it attracts over 300,000 visitors each year, the TCA said.

This year, 120 businesses have applied to have a presence at the show, the same amount of participants as last year, although the number of exhibition booths will increase from 660 to 700, according to the TCA.

Lenovo Taiwan General Manager Benjamin Ou said Tuesday that while many technology businesses have been receiving rush orders over the past few weeks -- seen as a sign that the recession might have bottomed out -- they still hope Softex will trigger further demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City extends trial period of bicycle rental service

TEXT.P: The Taipei City government has decided to extend the deposit-free trial period for its public bicycle rental program until the end of April and will open five more rental stations, as the service has been growing in popularity since it was launched last month, the Taipei City Department of Transportation announced Tuesday.

In the trial phase of the city's YouBike program, from March 11 to April 10, users were allowed to register for a one-day or five-day membership card that would be valid for a month, without having to pay the NT$3,000 (US$89) deposit. They were also not required to pay the rental fees of NT$40 per day or NT$1,500 per year.

As of April 5, some 9,500 people had used the service, according to an official of the citys Department of Transportation. Due to the popularity of the service, the city government decided to extend the concessionary period to the end of April and to install another five self-service meters with effect from April 11 for rental of the bikes, the official said.

This will bring to 10 the number of YouBike Bicycle Parking Meters in downtown Taipei. The five already in service are located at the Xinyi Square, City Hall Square, Taipei City Hall, MRT Taipei City Hall Station and Taipei World Trade Center (TWTC) Hall 3. The five new ones will be at MRT Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall Station, Taipei Municipal Xingya Junior High School, Taipei Disaster Prevention and Response Center, New York New York Shopping Mall and exit C of TWTC Hall 1.

The public bicycle rental service go into full operation on May 1. Users will then be required to apply for short-term or long-term membership cards, which will give them the first 30 minutes of each rental session free of cost, the official said. After the first half an hour, the fee will be NT$10 for every 15 minutes.
During the extended trial period, customers can use IC credit cards or the city's EasyCard to register free of cost at the 10 YouBike stations.
"In order to safeguard the personal information of credit card users and ensure the safety of the transactions, only IC credit cards will be permitted for use at the kiosks," the official said.
However, from April 11, magnetic strip credit cards will be accepted at the YouBike Service Center located at exit 3 of MRT Taipei City Hall Station, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Jiangsu-based businessmen want direct Wuxi-Taiwan flights
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, April 7 (CNA) 04/07/09 22:23:02 (By H.H. Chiao and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese businessmen operating in China's Jiangsu Province called Tuesday for the opening of non-stop flights between Taiwan and the province's Wuxi airport to help them save on travel time.

Sun Chia-chun, chairman of the Taiwan Businessmen's Association in Wuxi, said the heads of Taiwanese businessmen's organizations in 13 cities in central and southern Jiangsu Province, including Wuxi, Suzhou, Kunshan, Yangzhou, Wujiang and Nantong, have signed a petition expressing their desire for better air links.

Sun said they will raise the proposal in the upcoming third round of talks between the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation and the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits scheduled to take place in China.

According to Sun, about 1,800 Taiwanese enterprises and some 300,000 Taiwanese students, businessmen and their families are presently based in central and southern regions of Jiangsu Province, but there are no direct flights linking Wuxi and Taiwan.

Instead of landing at the Wuxi airport, he went on, they usually have to fly to and from Taiwan through Shanghai's Pudong Airport in neighboring Zhejiang Province or via Nanjing's Lukou International Airport.
"The Wuxi airport already serves non-stop flights to Macau and Hong Kong," he noted.
If non-stop flights can be put in place between Taiwan and Wuxi, it will be a great boon to Taiwanese businessmen operating in central and southern regions of Jiangsu, Sun said.

Chi Chih, chairman of the Taiwan Businessmen's Association in Wujiang, said that neither Pudong Airport nor the Nanjing airport serve them adequately, as traveling to and from each of them entails a round-trip drive of some five hours.

Wang I-lung, a vice chairman of the Taiwan Businessmen's Association in Suzhou, echoed the viewpoint, adding that many Taiwanese businessmen based in the Suzhou area have complained about the waste of time involved traveling between Suzhou and Shanghai.

A flight between Taiwan and Shanghai takes only about 80 minutes, but it takes at least two hours to make a one-way trip from Pudong Airport to Suzhou, he noted, adding that the drive from Suzhou to Wuxi takes only 30 minutes.

Wang Wen-chao, also a vice chairman of the Suzhou Taiwan businessmen's association, said having to use Pudong Airport or Lukou International Airport to travel between Suzhou and Taiwan is a serious headache as road traffic between Suzhou and either of the two airports is usually terrible.
