DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 8, or the 13th day of the third month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
217 AD: Caracalla, or Marcus Aurelius Antonius, the Roman emperor who was obsessed with and sought to imitate Alexander the Great, is assassinated after a bloody reign.
1513: Juan Ponce de Leon, the Spanish explorer who completed the conquest of Puerto Rico, discovers Florida and claims it for the Spanish throne.
1861: Elisha Graves Otis, the American inventor of the passenger elevator which was first installed in 1857, dies at the age of 50.
1902: China's Ching court and Russia reach agreement on the evacuation of Manchuria. After the Boxer Uprising in 1900, Russia took the opportunity to occupy Manchuria. When the troops of the other foreign powers withdrew from Chinese territory, Russia refused to leave Manchuria.
1907: France and Britain sign a convention confirming the independence of Siam (now Thailand).
1914: The Republic of China's first Congress is organized in Beijing.
1913: Brazil officially recognizes the Republic of China, which was founded on Jan. 1, 1912, becoming the first country in the world to do so.
1925: The Australian government and the British Colonial Office offer low- interest loans to encourage 500,000 Britons to emigrate to Australia.
1946: The League of Nations holds its final session in Geneva. It was later replaced by the United Nations.
1958: U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower proposes mutual inspection as a means of enforcing the nuclear test ban.
1965: The ROC severs diplomatic relations with the Republic of Dahomey.
1966: Leonid Brezhnev is elected general secretary of the Soviet Communist Party. He later became president of the USSR in 1977.
1973: Dr. Mohammed Abder Rahman Basbeer, minister of communications of Jordan, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1973: Pablo Picasso, the Spanish artist who was one of the most prolific and influential artists of the 20th century, dies in his chateau at Mougins at the age of 92. He excelled in painting, sculpture, etching, stage design, and ceramics.
1979: Lee Pao-chen, a noted Chinese musician, dies in Taipei at the age of 73.
1981: Omar Nelson Bradley, the American general who played a major part in the Allied victory in World War II, dies at the age of 88. He commanded the U.S. forces in the Normandy invasion and later led the 12th Army Group as France was liberated.
1986: Clint Eastwood, the screen tough guy famed for his portrayal of "Dirty Harry," is elected mayor of Carmel, a Californian resort town.
1989: More than 60 Soviet submariners die after a nuclear-powered Mike-class submarine refuses assistance from nearby Western merchant ships after catching fire off the coast of Norway.
1990: ROC Economics Minister Chen Li-an and Singaporean Minister of Trade and Industries Lee Hsien Loong preside over the first ministerial-level conference on economic cooperation between the two countries.
1991: The second extraordinary session of the First National Assembly is convened in Taipei to discuss constitutional reforms.
1992: Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat is found alive 12 hours after his plane crashes in the Sahara desert.
1994: Japanese Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa resigns over a loan scandal.
1995: At a meeting of the National Unification Council, ROC President Lee Teng-hui offers a six-point proposal for Taiwan-mainland China relations.
1999: NATO continues airstrikes against Yugoslavia while the eastern European country says its 14-month war against ethnic Albanian separatists is over.
2000: Hong Kong Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa tells U.S. President Bill Clinton that granting mainland China permanent normal trade relations status would give Hong Kong's recovering economy a further boost.
2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian says while attending the inauguration of Taiwan's Anti-Cancer Federation that a heart full of pleasure is the best medicine against cancer.
Confucius lesson of the day: "A gentleman who only thinks of the comforts of life cannot be a true gentleman."

DOC.HEADLINE: Visually impaired offered touch tours of National Palace Museum

TEXT.P: The visually-impaired are being invited to take special touch tours of the National Palace Museum the next four Sundays, which will give them the chance to touch replicas of well-known artifacts such as the Jadeite Cabbage and Meat- Shaped Stone, the organizer said Wednesday.
The tours, which will compensate for the visually impaired's inability to see the museum's exhibits, are aimed at promoting art education for the group, according to the Blinds Welfare Association.
They will take place the mornings of April 12, April 19, April 26 and May 3, and each tour will accommodate up to 12 people, the association said.

Each of the visitors will be assisted by a volunteer worker during the tour and have access to an audio guide offered by the museum and be allowed to touch replicas of selected artifacts and a model of the museum building, the association said.
Those interested in taking part can register with the association by calling (02)2599-1234.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
U.S. government looks into hijacking of Taiwanese fishing vessel

TEXT.P: The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Taipei Office expressed its concern Wednesday over the hijacking of a Taiwanese deep sea vessel in the Indian Ocean early Monday and said the U.S. government is taking a closer look at the matter.

We are concerned about the recent capture of the Taiwan fishing vessel in the Indian Ocean. The Department of Defense is looking into the incident, said AIT press officer Lawrence Walker in response to a Central News Agency inquiry.
The U.S. Navy has a responsibility to render assistance if feasible to any vessel anywhere in the world that is in distress and requests assistance,he added.
The AIT is the de facto U.S. embassy in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

The AIT issued a statement in January saying it had discussed with Taiwan the problem of piracy in the Gulf of Aden, at a time when attacks by Somali pirates on commercial vessels were growing increasingly serious.
When asked about it, Walker declined to comment on the discussion between the two countries, saying only that it is an ongoing subject.

The 700-ton long-line fishing shipWin Far 161was hijacked near an island in the Seychelles in the Indian Ocean on Monday. Among its 30 crew members, the ship's skipper and first engineer are Taiwanese nationals, while five other are Chinese, 17 are Filipinos and six are Indonesian.

Henry Chen, spokesman of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), told the CNA that while it is closely monitoring the movement of the vessel, it has not received news regarding the conditions on board, and the hijackers have yet to demand a ransom.
The MOFA is actively pursuing every every channel as it attempts to resolve the problem, Chen said.
He also said the Foreign Ministry appreciates the concern shown by the U.S. government over the hijacking.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan completes entry into IHR framework

TEXT.P: Taiwan recently received the password to get into the International Health Regulations (IHR) information portal, formally completing the country's accession into the global health management framework, a local health official said Tuesday.

The head of the National Public Health Command, Chuang Jen-hsiang, was authorized to use the password to get into the IHR Event Information Site at the end of March, said Centers for Disease Control (CDC) Deputy Director-General Shih Wen-yi.

Immediately after Chuang received the password and posted information on a communicable disease in Taiwan imported from China, World Health Organization (WHO) officials responded right away asking for further clarification, according to Shih.

Through its accession to the IHR, a framework under the WHO devised to control the spread of infectious diseases around the globe, Taiwan will be able for the first time to directly contact the world health body and get first-hand information about avian flu prevention and control, food security, and the spread and control of other epidemic diseases.

Because of China's opposition, Taiwan had previously been excluded from the IHR, even though a "universal application" phrase was introduced in the regulations in 2005 with the firm support of the United States and Taiwan's diplomatic allies, and the encouragement of the EU and Japan.
In the past, Taiwan was only able to obtain information on outbreaks of communicable diseases or emergencies in the region, including in China and Hong Kong, on a secondhand basis.
The WHO notified the Department of Health in a letter in January that Taiwan would be included in the IHR framework.
The WHO letter confirmed that the CDC is the communication liaison between Taiwan and the WHO and that the CDC and WHO can communicate directly.

It also said the WHO will dispatch specialists to Taiwan or invite Taiwan representatives to meetings called by the WHO in the event of any public health emergencies in Taiwan of international concern.
Taiwan is also allowed to recommend candidates to be included in the IHR group of specialists, the letter said.

The CDC has since recommended a list of candidates, including Ho Mei-shang, a research fellow in Academia Sinica's Institute of Biomedical Sciences, but it has yet to receive confirmation of the list by the WHO, Shih said.
The IHR was adopted in May 2005 by the WHA and took effect in June 2007. It requires all member states to report and address any public health emergencies of international concern.
Officials in charge of health and foreign affairs have all welcomed Taiwan's inclusion in the IHR framework, which some attributed to improved ties with China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Child abuse growing as economic pressure increases: organization

TEXT.P: A local children welfare promotion organization expressed concern Wednesday over the growing number of cases of child abuse as economic pressures rise, and it urged parents not to take their frustrations out on their children.

The nonprofit Taiwan Fund for Children and Families (TFCF) said that as of March, 46 cases of domestic violence involving 73 children, including eight who died, have been reported this year in the local media, and it urged parents who were on edge to seek professional help or take some time away from their children.
The TFCF said that as the economy has worsened, it has observed a growing rate of domestic violence against children, triggered primarily by a lack of parenting skills, unemployment, and poverty.

Of the 1,206 child abuse cases that the organization dealt with in 2007, parents were the abusers in 85.5 percent of the cases, while 64.3 percent of the cases occurred because parents did not know how to appropriately discipline their children.

Wang Ming-ren, executive director of the TFCF, said at Tuesday's news conference that parents can learn to ease up while dealing with job and parenting pressures simply by taking five steps -- taking 10 deep breaths, closing their eyes for 10 minutes, hugging their children for 10 seconds, laughing with their children 10 times or calling the TFCF at 0800-078585 for assistance.

Parents should face up to the issue of emotion management, as it is the key to a better parent-child relationship, said Chang Hsin-yo, a consultant and assistant professor at Taipei Medical University's Center for General Education.

Chang suggested that parents get into the habit of consistent positive reinforcement, such as giving positive messages to encourage children, recognizing and acknowledging their wishes, or restricting their behavior in a calm manner, according to Chang.

Sharing his own parenting experience at the news conference, news broadcaster Sam Tsen said that while taking atime-outfrom children is a good way to avoid losing one's temper, it is better to foster a closer relation with children through intimate actions such as hugs and kisses.

The parent-child relationship is like a bank book -- you have to keep depositing happy moments you share with your children so that there is something for you to withdraw when things get tough, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese hospitals advanced in organ transplants: health bureau

TEXT.P: Several hospitals in Taiwan have perfected advanced techniques in organ transplants, with the Taipei-based National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH) regarded as excellent in the field of kidney transplants, a Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) official said Wednesday.
The official made the remarks upon the release that same day of statistics on organ transplants conducted by Taiwanese medical institutes between 1997 and 2007.
Tzeng Wen-fu, responsible for medical service reviewing affairs at the BNHI, said the bureau reimbursed 3,875 cases involving organ transplants during the 10-year period.

The statistics show that the average five-year survival rate for heart transplants was 69 percent during the period, while the figure for kidney transplants reached 93 percent, with 80 percent recorded for liver transplants and 24 percent for lung transplants.

Tzeng said that no matter whether the organs come from living or deceased donors, there are no differences in the survival rates, as the surgical techniques and quality of health care are what matter.
The Taipei-based Cheng Hsin Hospital was found to have performed the best in heart transplants, with a 79 percent three-year survival rate, according to the BNHI statistics.

The figures also show that NTUH recorded the highest five-year survival rate of 96 percent for kidney transplants among the country's medical institutes, while the Kaohsiung Chang Gung Memorial Hospital registered the highest survival rate of 91 percent for liver transplants.
NTUH has also ranked in the top five in terms of survival rates for heart, liver and kidney transplants, according to the statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: President reaffirms resolve to fight corruption

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou reaffirmed Wednesday his administration's tough stand on corruption, in the wake of the publication of a report ranking Taiwan's corruption level as even more serious than that of China.
Ma demanded that the authorities get to the bottom of any alleged corruption cases regardless of the rank or political affiliation of the suspects.
He also instructed the authorities to produce a review report on major corruption cases and work out a plan to improve the situation within three months.

"We cannot allow corruption to disgrace Taiwan's democratic achievements, which are the pride of the ethnic Chinese community, " Ma said in a news conference in which he addressed the issue in person to show the importance he attaches to the matter.

According to the Asian Risk Prospect -- 2009 report released recently by the Hong Kong-based Political and Economic Risk Consultancy, Taiwan ranks eighth in terms of corruption levels among the 17 Asian countries rated, placing ahead of China on the list that is topped by Indonesia, Thailand and Cambodia.

Ma said that although all the corruption cases that have come to light so far took place during the former Democratic Progressive Party administration, the new government has an ineluctable responsibility to crack down on corruption.
He instructed the authorities to speed up their investigations and trials of the cases based on the principle of impartiality.
"Clean politics is not a slogan, but an action," Ma said.

According to the president, an amendment the previous week of Punishment of Corruption Act making it a crime for government officials to hold unexplained wealth marked an important milestone in Taiwan's pursuit of clean politics.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exports regaining momentum: CEPD chief

TEXT.P: Exports are steadily regaining momentum as the country's outbound shipments to China and the United States are showing signs of initial recovery, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman Chen Tain-jy said Wednesday.
Chen made the remarks while answering questions from ruling Kuomintang Legislator Wu Ching-chih during a legislative meeting.

He based his optimism on the grounds that Taiwan's outbound shipments to the two major overseas markets have gradually increased during the first three months of this year thanks to more orders placed with local companies.
But he added that it is still too early to term the situation a turnaround before the country's single-month export value rebounds to more than US$20 billion (US$598 million).
"It will be a genuine economic recovery if Taiwan's monthly export value returns to above that level," he explained.

Export volume, local consumption and private-sector investment are three major indicators of an economic rebound, according to the CEPD chief, who said local consumption seems to have stopped decreasing in March.

According to a report released a day earlier by the Ministry of Finance (MOF), export volume in March totaled US$15.59 billion, the highest level posted over the past four months, mainly due to rush orders and inventory refills.

However, the March figure was down US$8.65 billion -- a drop of 35.7 percent -- compared with the same month of a year ago. The decline, nonetheless, was narrower than the plunge of 41.9 percent in December and 37.2 percent for the January-February period, MOF officials said.

Meanwhile, a trade surplus of US$8.49 billion for the first quarter of this year represented an increase of 155.3 percent compared with the same period of last year, although the officials added that further observation will be needed in the next two to three months to judge whether the economic downturn has come to an end.

DOC.HEADLINE: Professional license acquisition rate at Chaoyang U. tops 108%

TEXT.P: Students of Chaoyang University of Technology in the central county of Taichung have posted a professional license acquisition rate of 108 percent, one of the highest among all academic institutions in Taiwan.

As of March 31 this year, the 14,635 students of Chaoyang University had passed exams or tests to obtain 15,813 professional licenses from national agencies, said Chung Jen-chin, president of the university.
"Each student has at least one professional license now, " Chung said proudly.

Chung attributed the students' performance mainly to the university's active response to an incentive project launched by the Ministry of Education (MOE) nearly three years ago to encourage outstanding teaching.
He said that over the past two years, Chaoyang University has received NT$177 million (US$5.24 million) from the MOE in incentive grants for outstanding teaching performances.
Meanwhile, students admitted in 2008 and after will be required to pass the Level One National English Test Proficiency for All before they could graduate, he said.

"This is one of Chaoyang's policies in its goal to produce graduates who will be highly sought after by private companies and enterprises in need of professionals with foreign language proficiency," Chung noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, increasing NT$0.331 to close at NT$33.90.
A total of US$1.154 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.95 and fluctuated between NT$33.79 and NT$34.00.

DOC.HEADLINE: Weaker financial shares send prices on Taipei bourse tumbling

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices fell sharply Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 133.29 points, or 2.39 percent, to close at 5,443.56.

The local bourse opened lower at 5,534.58 but rose to a high of 5,608.96 early in the session before falling as low as 5,435.04, under pressure from plunging financial shares after legislators reached a consensus to cap interest rates on credit card debt at 12.5 percent,
A total of 7.47 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$150.27 billion (US$4.44 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares falling the most at 5.5 percent. Construction issues dropped 5.3 percent, paper and pulp issues decreased 3.5 percent, textile stocks fell 3.4 percent, cement stocks were down 3.1 percent, foodstuff issues lost 2.4 percent, and machinery and electronics shares dropped 2.2 percent.
Plastics and chemicals shares increased, gaining 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,414 to 681, with 118 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$10.23 billion.
Analysts said the fall in financial shares hurt investor confidence and dragged down prices in other sectors.

Investors feared earnings at financial institutions will suffer after ruling and opposition legislators reached a consensus on an amendment that would lower the ceiling on credit and debit card balances to 12.5 percent, from the existing 20 percent.

Chinatrust Financial Holding Co. and Mega Financial Holding Co. shares both fell by the maximum 7 percent. Chinatrust shares lost NT$1.05 to close at NT$14.15, while Mega Holdings shares dropped NT$1.0 to close at NT$13.95.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP in deadlock over rival candidates for Tainan magistrate job

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) remained at an impasse Wednesday over which of two competing candidates should run for Tainan magistrate in year-end elections, a DPP lawmaker acknowledged.

DPP Legislator Lee Chun-yi, who was nominated by the party a week earlier to run for the position in December, told reporters that he had a friendly half-hour meeting on the issue a day earlier with another self-proclaimed DPP candidate, Tan Sun Chen, but to no avail.
"So far we have not found a way for Chen to withdraw his candidacy, but we are still making more efforts," he said.

Lee expressed worry that he is now in a situation that will not allow him to back out of the race, because if he does so, it will not only ruin his political career but also destroy the credibility of the DPP.
He said the only hope for a solution to the issue now lies in whether DPP heavyweights can persuade Chen to withdraw his candidacy.
Chen, a 74-year-old party veteran, announced last week that he will run for the Tainan magistrate post.

He has served in a series of high-level positions during his political career, including Tainan magistrate, minister of foreign affairs and secretary-general of the Presidential Office under the former DPP administration.
He claimed he has become a victim of factional fighting within the party and vowed that he will go the distance in the election in defiance of factional dominance within the party.

Chen expressed confidence that he will emerge as the front-runner in the election and suggested that the party leadership should have chosen the nominee by means of an opinion poll that would have gauged who had the strongest support among the DPP members and voters.

DOC.HEADLINE: Louvre Museum `touching' exhibition opens in Taipei

TEXT.P: Eighteen replicas of sculptures from the world renowned Louvre Museum's "touching exhibition" were unveiled at Taipei's National Museum of History Wednesday, with visitors encouraged to feel the works with their hands.

Huang Yung-chuan, director of the National Museum of History, said at a news conference to unveil the sculptures that Taipei is very fortunate to be the first stop on the exhibition's first overseas tour.

He added that it is a result of more than two years of planning and cooperation among the National Museum of History, the Louvre, the French Institute in Taipei, the Taiwan Foundation for the Blind and the Ravenel Art Group.

Introduced in 1995, the exhibition aims at bringing the experience of art to visually challenged people, as rather than being warned to keep their hands off the works, visitors are asked to indulge themselves by feeling and touching the reproductions of famous sculptures.

Alice Rambert, project manager of the Louvre's Education Department, said at the news conference that the exhibition will strengthen not only the cooperation between the two museums, but also cultural exchanges between Taiwan and France.
"This exhibition will serve as a bridge between the visually impaired and sighted people and will give them a whole new feeling of art appreciation," Rambert said.

Daisy Xu, vice president of Ravenel Art Group, said that by sponsoring the event, she hopes a message will be sent that more people and enterprises should support such art exhibitions and show more care for underprivileged groups.

The 18 sculptures, including reproductions of the Venus de Milo, the Borghese Gladiator and the Rebel Slave, are resin or plaster reproductions of the marble originals, according to the organizers, who added that because the Louvre used 3D laser readings of each piece, the replicas are exact copies.

From April 10 to May 24, the exhibition, titled "Sculptures in Movement, " will be held at the National Museum of History, moving to Kaohsiung Museum of Fine Arts from June 20 to August 23 before traveling on to Beijing, Hangzhou and Wuhan in China.
Blindfolds will be available at the exhibition to enhance the sense of touch for the non-vision-impaired.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hyperactive children may get access to special education

TEXT.P: Children suffering from attention-deficit/ hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) will be given access to special education if an amendment to the Special Education Act clears the Legislative Yuan.

The bill, which completed a preliminary review by the legislature's Education and Culture Committee Wednesday, would expand the eligibility for special education to include children with behavioral disorders, also covering hyperactive children.
The legislation must still pass two more votes by the full lawmaking body before the amendment can be implemented.

In light of the fact that some children with learning disabilities do not necessarily have any easily identifiable physical or mental disabilities, the bill stipulates that any child who has been "professionally evaluated and assessed as having special learning needs" would qualify for special education.
In addition, to promote early intervention programs for disabled children, the bill states that special education should begin as soon as the child reaches the age of 3.
ADHD is one of the most common childhood disorders and can continue through adolescence and adulthood. Local studies show that ADHD affects 7.5 percent to 9.9 percent of children in Taiwan.
Symptoms of ADHD include difficulty staying focused and paying attention, difficulty controlling behavior and hyperactivity.
Without treatment, ADHD can cause problems at home, school, work, and with relationships.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese high quality rice selling well due to creative promotions

TEXT.P: A Council of Agriculture agency said Wednesday it plans to continue to promote the sales of Taiwanese rice of excellent strains and tasty flavors, after a creative promotional campaign last year resulted in success.
Last year, the council's Agriculture and Food Agency promoted the rice, produced by farmers from 10 townships around the country, by packing them as wedding gifts for guests.

More than 30,000 packages of the rice marketed as wedding gifts, and priced from NT$400 to NT$600 each have been sold over the past year, said Jao Mei-chu, a section chief with the agency's Central Region Branch.
To step up their marketing efforts, the branch has recently put forth rice gift packages to celebrate the birth of new born babies and rice packages as all- purpose gifts, said Jao.

All the wedding, birth, all-purpose rice gift packages are prepared by rice farmers whose produce carries the Certification of National Standards (CNS) mark and are marketed by local farmers' associations, Jao added.

DOC.HEADLINE: First locally born coati put on display at Taipei Zoo

TEXT.P: The first Taiwan-born coati, a mammal belonging to the raccoon family, has been put on public display at the city zoo in suburban Taipei, a zoo official said Wednesday.
A pair of coatis, also known as hog-nosed coons, which are endemic to tropical zones of South America, were introduced to the public at the Taipei Zoo for the first time last July.
The pair gave birth to six cubs in January, but five of them died the following day, probably because of their mother's inability to rear them, said Jason Yeh, director of the Taipei Zoo.
"Zoo keepers then began to feed the surviving coati, " Yeh said, adding that it marked the first time coatis have successfully reproduced in Taiwan.
According to Yeh, the animal now weighs 1.48 kg and is in good health.
He reminded zoo visitors to refrain from banging on the glass wall of the display gallery and from using camera flashes so as not to scare or annoy the little animal.
As its parents will soon enter their breeding period again, the coati may soon get siblings, Yeh added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan food department to be opened in Shanghai supermarket
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/09 19:41:01 (By H. H. Chiao and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A special department for the display and sale of Taiwan food will be opened April 10 at City Shop, an upscale supermarket in Shanghai, organizers said Wednesday.

Victor Chu, representative of the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) in Shanghai, said the special department was set up through the joint efforts of the TAITRA-affiliated Taipei World Trade Center and City Shop executives.

TAITRA Chairman Wang Chih-kang and Huang Chih-peng, director-general of the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) , will preside over the opening ceremony in Shanghai Friday, Chu said.

According to Chu, the increase in two-way exchanges brought about by the wider opening of cross-Taiwan Strait tourism last year has helped to stir Chinese consumers' interest in Taiwan-made foodstuff.

In a bid to help Chinese consumers learn more about a wide range of Taiwan- produced foodstuff, the TAITRA decided, in conjunction with City Shop, to set up a special department for Taiwan food products in Shanghai, he said.
City Shop owns 12 stores in the city and one in Beijing. The Shanghai-based food importer also operates farms, tourism resort parks, coffee factories, bakeries and foreign trade companies.
City Shop began importing Taiwan food products in 2000, and some 600 items of Taiwan-made goods are being sold at its stores.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of furloughed workers halved in export processing zones

TEXT.P: The number of workers on unpaid leave in the country's export processing zones has decreased by half over the past month thanks to an influx of rush orders, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Wednesday.

Statistics from the Export Processing Zone Administration (EPZA) under the MOEA show that only 11,000 workers in the zones were still on furlough as of Wednesday, down from 22,000 people March 10 and 26,000 people Feb. 10.
There are more than 200 businesses operating in the seven processing zones around Taiwan, with a combined workforce amounting to approximately 56,000 people, according to EPZA tallies.
Affected by the global economic downturn, 4,186 workers in the zones were laid off between September and December 2008, and 1,912 during the first three months of this year, the statistics indicate.

However, rush orders have been coming in since the end of the Chinese New Year holiday in early February and according to EPZA deputy chief Tai Jui-ching, many of them that were originally only good for one month have now been extended to short-term orders for two to three months, which has rapidly restored capacity utilization in the processing zones.

Tai said many electronics manufacturers in the processing zones have abolished unpaid leave for their workers for the last two weeks, adding that further observation will be required in the coming two months to see if the rush order effect continues.

Meanwhile, in what will be the first large-scale worker recruitment drive since the outbreak of the global financial crisis, Chi Lin Technology Co. is planning to recruit 700 production operators for its plant in the Nanzih Export Processing Zone in Kaohsiung City.

DOC.HEADLINE: State-run institute to help Taiwanese craftsmen promote works

TEXT.P: Taiwan is home to a wide variety of crafts, from stone and wood carving to glass work, but talented local craftsmen have difficulties marketing their products, which led the National Taiwan Craft Research Institute (NTCRI) to announce Wednesday that it will step up efforts to help promote locally-created handicraft works.

Institute Director Lin Cheng-yi told a press conference that despite the talents in many different fields, most local artists are unable to build their own brand names and increase sales of their creative works.

To help the craftsmen, the institute began a few years ago to assist individual artists in selling to the domestic and international markets, by promoting local arts and crafts creations through various marketing channels, including online shops, department stores and hotels, as well as 117 NTCRI-certified crafts workshops around Taiwan.
It has also contracted retail stores and resort hotels to display native craft work, Lin said at the press conference held to present the NTCRI's efforts to promote local handicraft works.

Four noted hotels have been selected to serve as model sites to showcase and market local handicraft works, which include the Shangrila Boutique Hotel in Ilan County, northeastern Taiwan; the Young Lake Hotel in Miaoli County, northern Taiwan; the Freshfields hotel in Taichung County, central Taiwan; and the Hotel Holiday Garden in Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan.

In addition, Lin said the NTCRI has also opened an exhibition hall for Taiwanese handicraft products in the Park Lane by CMP department store in Taichung City to display and sell works from the NTCRI-certified crafts workshops.
Overseas and domestic tourists can get a sense of the wide array of Taiwanese handicrafts by visiting the concept hall and the hotel's gift shops.
Lin further said the NTCRI will continue to invite more hotels to help market local arts and crafts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei to install high performance roadside cameras

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government will spend NT$1.6 billion (US$47.5 million) within the next year to install 13,000 new high-performance close-circuit television cameras on streets all over the city to fight crime and monitor traffic conditions, Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Wednesday.

After hearing a briefing at the Taipei City Police Department on a plan for the new video surveillance system, Hau told reporters that the 13,000 latest model CCTV video cameras, including 1,500 megapixel ones, will be mounted at strategic locations on the city's public roads to make Taipei a safer metropolis.
Asked whether the new equipment would mean a further erosion of residents' privacy, Hau said that no one will be given access to the recorded tapes without a justifiable reason.
He added that all the video footage will be recordings of activities on public roads and will not infringe on people's privacy in their homes.

According to police executives, the new cameras, linked to a computer terminal, will be able to home in on suspected targets and will have the ability to detect cars thefts by reading the number plates of vehicles and sounding alarms.

Huang Lu-ching, director of the city government's Department of Civic Affairs, said the existing 12,000 old-model roadside cameras in Taipei will be phased out when the new ones are put in place next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung offering one-dollar night market food to lure visitors

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government in southern Taiwan is promoting a "One-Dollar Go" campaign to encourage residents and their foreign friends to visit a local night market, a city official said Wednesday.

For the price of one dollar, visitors will have an opportunity on April 11 to sample the traditional dishes on offer at the Chung Hsiao night market located between the Ching Nien Road and the Ling Ya Road, said Ho Yi-lun, head of the city's research, development and evaluation affairs.

However, the preferential treatment will be offered only to foreigners, or the locals visiting the night market with at least one foreigner, said Ho. Only food stands certified as English service providers will be participating in the promotion effort, he added.

The campaign is part of the "2009 English Service Festival," organized by the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission to encourage private business operators to offer more English-language services.
It focuses mainly on businesses in the sectors of lodging and dining, tourism and leisure entertainment, retail, medical services, and transportation.

Ho said the Kaohsiung city government has invested some NT$10 million over the past three years to help local street food stands produce English menus and provide English content on their Web sites, The money is also being used to fund English conversation courses for business operators, he said.
Currently, more than 300 store and street stand owners in the city are taking the courses, Ho added.
Some 20 street stand operators at the Ching Hsiao night market have already completed the training and have been certified as English service providers, Ho said.
Members of the public can obtain coupons for the one-dollar promotion offers by signing up on the Web site http: //es.ffunlab.com, Ho said.

DOC.HEADLINE: First Taiwanese in Masters in two decades set to play Augusta with a smile

TEXT.P: Taiwanese golfer Lin Wen-tang will be extremely focused when he faces top players from around the world at the 52nd U.S. Masters beginning Thursday, but he vowed to keep a smile on his face as he plays in golf's first major of the year.

Even if the 35-year-old doesn't challenge Tiger Woods or some of the other favorites for the title, or fails to make the cut, he will still be the first Taiwanese golfer to play in the prestigious event at the revered Augusta National Golf Club since T.C. Chen in 1989.
Lin, the son of a golf coach, began to play golf at the age of 5. He had captured amateur golf titles in Taiwan and Hong Kong before turning pro in 1996.

He has won four Asian PGA Tour victories, all coming since 2006, but his breakout year came in 2008, when he finished second on the Tour's Order of Merit with US$844,734 in prize money after capturing the Asian Tour International, Thailand and the 2008 UBS Hong Kong Open.

Lin also had two seconds and finished in the top-10 nine other times in 20 tournaments. Lin's world ranking rose significantly after he became the first Asian golfer to win the UBS Hong Kong Open in 10 years, and improved to No. 49 in the world after tying for sixth place in the 2008 Asian Masters.
His ranking inside the top 50 secured him a spot at the Masters, which he admitted in an interview with the Asian Tour was athrill but also a real test of his ability as a golfer.

(I've) always wanted to be a part of it. But I'm also aware of the pressure, he said.To excel at the highest level in professional golf, your mental strength has to be very strong. I'll do my best and as long as I do it, I believe my results will come.

Lin has spent the last few weeks in the United States preparing for the big tournament, but he already has a strategy for coping with pressure, as he revealed after winning the UBS Hong Kong Open last year.

"Psychological strength is the key to stand out in a high-profile golf game. I have always reminded myself to smile, to take it easy, to be composed and concentrate and never to be distracted by anything else no matter whether I play well or less than ideal, " he told reporters at a post-tournament news conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: Q1 tax revenue posts largest annual decrease

TEXT.P: Taiwan's tax revenue for the first quarter of this year was NT$245.3 billion (US$7.34 billion), down by NT$58.6 billion year-on-year, or 19.3 percent -- the biggest drop in the country's history, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) reported Wednesday.

The Q1 tax revenue amounted to only 13.7 percent of the annual target set by the government, which was also a new low since 2001, according to statistics released by the MOF's Department of Statistics.

However, for the month of March, tax offices nationwide collected NT$7.5 billion in stock transaction taxes, which represented a new single-month high since August last year, the statistics showed. MOF officials attributed this growth to a rising stock market, which to date has recorded the world's second-biggest rebound of more than 20 percent since late last year, after the Chinese bourse.

Stock transaction taxes for Q1 totaled NT$14.7 billion, an increase of NT$1.5 billion compared to the figure posted in last Q4. However, this was a NT$12.4 billion drop, or 45.9 percent reduction, year-on-year.
In the first quarter of this year, a total of NT$8.9 billion in land value increment taxes was collected, marking a drop of NT$5.6 billion, or 38.6 percent, compared to the same period in 2008.
This was a result of a sluggish real-estate and property market, which has been hit hard by the global financial crisis since last September, MOF officials said.
In March, the national coffers received NT$3.7 billion in land value increment taxes, down by NT$1.5 billion from the year-earlier level, the MOF statistics showed.

Meanwhile, Q1 business taxes totaled NT$65.9 billion, dropping by NT$13.5 billion from the same period last year and representing a negative growth of 17 percent year-on-year due to a large decline in imports.
March business taxes amounted to NT$38 billion, a decrease of NT$6.4 billion, or a reduction of 14.4 percent, compared to the previous March's level, according to the tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung mayor attends 2009 Global City Forum

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu gave a speech at the 2009 Global City Forum in Abu Dhabi, capital of the United Arab Emirates, Wednesday to share the experience of the central Taiwan city's growth, said Taichung City government officials.

Hu and a delegation from Taichung took part in the forum April 7-8, along with mayors and planners from major international cities, including Paris, San Francisco, Mumbai, Beijing, Jeddah, Riyadh, Seoul and Lyon.
In a speech in the mayors' panel, Hu narrated Taichung's development and how he has been trying to transforming Taichung into a major cultural, economic and international city.

He also explained Taichung's future development plans, including proposals to build a metropolis opera house, a new civic center, the Shuinan Tarde Zone, and a special leisure area in five years, and to transform Taichung into one of the most important international cities in the Asia-Pacific region.
The forum, sponsored by the Abu Dhabi Council for Economic Development and the Abu Dhabi Urban Planning Council, took place at the Emirates Palace hotel in Abu Dhabi.
Six other mayors also shared their experience in urban management and planning, with the discussion focusing on how to develop a blueprint for successful urban living in the future.
In addition to the mayors' panel, there was also a closed-door leaders' summit -- a collaborative platform for new ideas and thinking on mobility patterns in modern cities.

There were also other sessions on various topics, including globalization of the world's sustainable cities, culture and immigration as drivers of a successful city, developing sustainable downtown areas, smart cities and public transport.

DOC.HEADLINE: Senior cross-strait negotiator departs for China visit

TEXT.P: Taiwan's No.2 negotiator with China left for Shanghai Wednesday on a visit reportedly aimed at arranging for a third round of high-level cross-strait talks on matters of mutual concern.

Kao, vice chairman and secretary-general of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , kept a low profile and refrained from answering any questions from the press about the purpose of his Shanghai visit. He was accompanied by SEF Deputy Secretary-General Kao Wen-cheng.
Four other SEF staff members also traveled to China Wednesday on a different flight, sources said.

Lai Shin-yuan, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council that oversees SEF operations, said a day earlier that in view of the continued improvement in cross-strait relations, the third round of high-level cross- strait talks will be held in May ahead of schedule.

Nevertheless, Lai said the exact dates and venue for the third meeting between SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and his Chinese counterpart, Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), have yet to be decided.

Political sources said it is believed that Kao will hold preparatory talks with ARATS officials during his current visit to set the stage for the upcoming Chiang-Chen meeting. The agenda for the meeting will include cooperation in financial fields and crime-fighting and launch of regular scheduled flights.
Chiang and Chen met twice last year to sign six critical agreements on the launch of direct charter flights and shipping and postal links as well as the expansion of tourism exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for April 9, 2009

TEXT.P: The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP in deadlock over rival candidates for Tainan magistrate job

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) remained at an impasse Wednesday over which of two competing candidates should run for Tainan magistrate in year-end elections, a DPP lawmaker acknowledged.

DPP Legislator Lee Chun-yi, who was nominated by the party a week earlier to run for the position in December, told reporters that he had a friendly half-hour meeting on the issue a day earlier with another self-proclaimed DPP candidate, Tan Sun Chen, but to no avail.
"So far we have not found a way for Chen to withdraw his candidacy, but we are still making more efforts," he said.

Lee expressed worry that he is now in a situation that will not allow him to back out of the race, because if he does so, it will not only ruin his political career but also destroy the credibility of the DPP.
He said the only hope for a solution to the issue now lies in whether DPP heavyweights can persuade Chen to withdraw his candidacy.

Daisy Xu, vice president of Ravenel Art Group, said that by sponsoring the event, she hopes a message will be sent that more people and enterprises should support such art exhibitions and show more care for underprivileged groups.

The 18 sculptures, including reproductions of the Venus de Milo, the Borghese Gladiator and the Rebel Slave, are resin or plaster reproductions of the marble originals, according to the organizers, who added that because the Louvre used 3D laser readings of each piece, the replicas are exact copies.

From April 10 to May 24, the exhibition, titled "Sculptures in Movement, " will be held at the National Museum of History, moving to Kaohsiung Museum of Fine Arts from June 20 to August 23 before traveling on to Beijing, Hangzhou and Wuhan in China.
Blindfolds will be available at the exhibition to enhance the sense of touch for the non-vision-impaired.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hyperactive children may get access to special education

TEXT.P: Children suffering from attention-deficit/ hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) will be given access to special education if an amendment to the Special Education Act clears the Legislative Yuan.

The bill, which completed a preliminary review by the legislature's Education and Culture Committee Wednesday, would expand the eligibility for special education to include children with behavioral disorders, also covering hyperactive children.
The legislation must still pass two more votes by the full lawmaking body before the amendment can be implemented.

In light of the fact that some children with learning disabilities do not necessarily have any easily identifiable physical or mental disabilities, the bill stipulates that any child who has been "professionally evaluated and assessed as having special learning needs" would qualify for special education.
In addition, to promote early intervention programs for disabled children, the bill states that special education should begin as soon as the child reaches the age of 3.
ADHD is one of the most common childhood disorders and can continue through adolescence and adulthood. Local studies show that ADHD affects 7.5 percent to 9.9 percent of children in Taiwan.
Symptoms of ADHD include difficulty staying focused and paying attention, difficulty controlling behavior and hyperactivity.
Without treatment, ADHD can cause problems at home, school, work, and with relationships.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese high quality rice selling well due to creative promotions

TEXT.P: A Council of Agriculture agency said Wednesday it plans to continue to promote the sales of Taiwanese rice of excellent strains and tasty flavors, after a creative promotional campaign last year resulted in success.
Last year, the council's Agriculture and Food Agency promoted the rice, produced by farmers from 10 townships around the country, by packing them as wedding gifts for guests.

More than 30,000 packages of the rice marketed as wedding gifts, and priced from NT$400 to NT$600 each have been sold over the past year, said Jao Mei-chu, a section chief with the agency's Central Region Branch.
To step up their marketing efforts, the branch has recently put forth rice gift packages to celebrate the birth of new born babies and rice packages as all- purpose gifts, said Jao.

All the wedding, birth, all-purpose rice gift packages are prepared by rice farmers whose produce carries the Certification of National Standards (CNS) mark and are marketed by local farmers' associations, Jao added.

DOC.HEADLINE: First locally born coati put on display at Taipei Zoo

TEXT.P: The first Taiwan-born coati, a mammal belonging to the raccoon family, has been put on public display at the city zoo in suburban Taipei, a zoo official said Wednesday.
A pair of coatis, also known as hog-nosed coons, which are endemic to tropical zones of South America, were introduced to the public at the Taipei Zoo for the first time last July.
The pair gave birth to six cubs in January, but five of them died the following day, probably because of their mother's inability to rear them, said Jason Yeh, director of the Taipei Zoo.
"Zoo keepers then began to feed the surviving coati, " Yeh said, adding that it marked the first time coatis have successfully reproduced in Taiwan.
According to Yeh, the animal now weighs 1.48 kg and is in good health.
He reminded zoo visitors to refrain from banging on the glass wall of the display gallery and from using camera flashes so as not to scare or annoy the little animal.
As its parents will soon enter their breeding period again, the coati may soon get siblings, Yeh added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan food department to be opened in Shanghai supermarket
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/09 19:41:01 (By H. H. Chiao and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A special department for the display and sale of Taiwan food will be opened April 10 at City Shop, an upscale supermarket in Shanghai, organizers said Wednesday.

Victor Chu, representative of the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) in Shanghai, said the special department was set up through the joint efforts of the TAITRA-affiliated Taipei World Trade Center and City Shop executives.

TAITRA Chairman Wang Chih-kang and Huang Chih-peng, director-general of the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) , will preside over the opening ceremony in Shanghai Friday, Chu said.

According to Chu, the increase in two-way exchanges brought about by the wider opening of cross-Taiwan Strait tourism last year has helped to stir Chinese consumers' interest in Taiwan-made foodstuff.

In a bid to help Chinese consumers learn more about a wide range of Taiwan- produced foodstuff, the TAITRA decided, in conjunction with City Shop, to set up a special department for Taiwan food products in Shanghai, he said.
City Shop owns 12 stores in the city and one in Beijing. The Shanghai-based food importer also operates farms, tourism resort parks, coffee factories, bakeries and foreign trade companies.
City Shop began importing Taiwan food products in 2000, and some 600 items of Taiwan-made goods are being sold at its stores.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of furloughed workers halved in export processing zones

TEXT.P: The number of workers on unpaid leave in the country's export processing zones has decreased by half over the past month thanks to an influx of rush orders, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Wednesday.

Statistics from the Export Processing Zone Administration (EPZA) under the MOEA show that only 11,000 workers in the zones were still on furlough as of Wednesday, down from 22,000 people March 10 and 26,000 people Feb. 10.
There are more than 200 businesses operating in the seven processing zones around Taiwan, with a combined workforce amounting to approximately 56,000 people, according to EPZA tallies.
Affected by the global economic downturn, 4,186 workers in the zones were laid off between September and December 2008, and 1,912 during the first three months of this year, the statistics indicate.

However, rush orders have been coming in since the end of the Chinese New Year holiday in early February and according to EPZA deputy chief Tai Jui-ching, many of them that were originally only good for one month have now been extended to short-term orders for two to three months, which has rapidly restored capacity utilization in the processing zones.

Tai said many electronics manufacturers in the processing zones have abolished unpaid leave for their workers for the last two weeks, adding that further observation will be required in the coming two months to see if the rush order effect continues.

Meanwhile, in what will be the first large-scale worker recruitment drive since the outbreak of the global financial crisis, Chi Lin Technology Co. is planning to recruit 700 production operators for its plant in the Nanzih Export Processing Zone in Kaohsiung City.

DOC.HEADLINE: State-run institute to help Taiwanese craftsmen promote works

TEXT.P: Taiwan is home to a wide variety of crafts, from stone and wood carving to glass work, but talented local craftsmen have difficulties marketing their products, which led the National Taiwan Craft Research Institute (NTCRI) to announce Wednesday that it will step up efforts to help promote locally-created handicraft works.

Institute Director Lin Cheng-yi told a press conference that despite the talents in many different fields, most local artists are unable to build their own brand names and increase sales of their creative works.

To help the craftsmen, the institute began a few years ago to assist individual artists in selling to the domestic and international markets, by promoting local arts and crafts creations through various marketing channels, including online shops, department stores and hotels, as well as 117 NTCRI-certified crafts workshops around Taiwan.
It has also contracted retail stores and resort hotels to display native craft work, Lin said at the press conference held to present the NTCRI's efforts to promote local handicraft works.

Four noted hotels have been selected to serve as model sites to showcase and market local handicraft works, which include the Shangrila Boutique Hotel in Ilan County, northeastern Taiwan; the Young Lake Hotel in Miaoli County, northern Taiwan; the Freshfields hotel in Taichung County, central Taiwan; and the Hotel Holiday Garden in Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan.

In addition, Lin said the NTCRI has also opened an exhibition hall for Taiwanese handicraft products in the Park Lane by CMP department store in Taichung City to display and sell works from the NTCRI-certified crafts workshops.
Overseas and domestic tourists can get a sense of the wide array of Taiwanese handicrafts by visiting the concept hall and the hotel's gift shops.
Lin further said the NTCRI will continue to invite more hotels to help market local arts and crafts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei to install high performance roadside cameras

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government will spend NT$1.6 billion (US$47.5 million) within the next year to install 13,000 new high-performance close-circuit television cameras on streets all over the city to fight crime and monitor traffic conditions, Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Wednesday.

After hearing a briefing at the Taipei City Police Department on a plan for the new video surveillance system, Hau told reporters that the 13,000 latest model CCTV video cameras, including 1,500 megapixel ones, will be mounted at strategic locations on the city's public roads to make Taipei a safer metropolis.
Asked whether the new equipment would mean a further erosion of residents' privacy, Hau said that no one will be given access to the recorded tapes without a justifiable reason.
He added that all the video footage will be recordings of activities on public roads and will not infringe on people's privacy in their homes.

According to police executives, the new cameras, linked to a computer terminal, will be able to home in on suspected targets and will have the ability to detect cars thefts by reading the number plates of vehicles and sounding alarms.

Huang Lu-ching, director of the city government's Department of Civic Affairs, said the existing 12,000 old-model roadside cameras in Taipei will be phased out when the new ones are put in place next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung offering one-dollar night market food to lure visitors

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government in southern Taiwan is promoting a "One-Dollar Go" campaign to encourage residents and their foreign friends to visit a local night market, a city official said Wednesday.

For the price of one dollar, visitors will have an opportunity on April 11 to sample the traditional dishes on offer at the Chung Hsiao night market located between the Ching Nien Road and the Ling Ya Road, said Ho Yi-lun, head of the city's research, development and evaluation affairs.

However, the preferential treatment will be offered only to foreigners, or the locals visiting the night market with at least one foreigner, said Ho. Only food stands certified as English service providers will be participating in the promotion effort, he added.

The campaign is part of the "2009 English Service Festival," organized by the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission to encourage private business operators to offer more English-language services.
It focuses mainly on businesses in the sectors of lodging and dining, tourism and leisure entertainment, retail, medical services, and transportation.

Ho said the Kaohsiung city government has invested some NT$10 million over the past three years to help local street food stands produce English menus and provide English content on their Web sites, The money is also being used to fund English conversation courses for business operators, he said.
Currently, more than 300 store and street stand owners in the city are taking the courses, Ho added.
Some 20 street stand operators at the Ching Hsiao night market have already completed the training and have been certified as English service providers, Ho said.
Members of the public can obtain coupons for the one-dollar promotion offers by signing up on the Web site http: //es.ffunlab.com, Ho said.

DOC.HEADLINE: First Taiwanese in Masters in two decades set to play Augusta with a smile

TEXT.P: Taiwanese golfer Lin Wen-tang will be extremely focused when he faces top players from around the world at the 52nd U.S. Masters beginning Thursday, but he vowed to keep a smile on his face as he plays in golf's first major of the year.

Even if the 35-year-old doesn't challenge Tiger Woods or some of the other favorites for the title, or fails to make the cut, he will still be the first Taiwanese golfer to play in the prestigious event at the revered Augusta National Golf Club since T.C. Chen in 1989.
Lin, the son of a golf coach, began to play golf at the age of 5. He had captured amateur golf titles in Taiwan and Hong Kong before turning pro in 1996.

He has won four Asian PGA Tour victories, all coming since 2006, but his breakout year came in 2008, when he finished second on the Tour's Order of Merit with US$844,734 in prize money after capturing the Asian Tour International, Thailand and the 2008 UBS Hong Kong Open.

Lin also had two seconds and finished in the top-10 nine other times in 20 tournaments. Lin's world ranking rose significantly after he became the first Asian golfer to win the UBS Hong Kong Open in 10 years, and improved to No. 49 in the world after tying for sixth place in the 2008 Asian Masters.
His ranking inside the top 50 secured him a spot at the Masters, which he admitted in an interview with the Asian Tour was athrill but also a real test of his ability as a golfer.

(I've) always wanted to be a part of it. But I'm also aware of the pressure, he said.To excel at the highest level in professional golf, your mental strength has to be very strong. I'll do my best and as long as I do it, I believe my results will come.

Lin has spent the last few weeks in the United States preparing for the big tournament, but he already has a strategy for coping with pressure, as he revealed after winning the UBS Hong Kong Open last year.

"Psychological strength is the key to stand out in a high-profile golf game. I have always reminded myself to smile, to take it easy, to be composed and concentrate and never to be distracted by anything else no matter whether I play well or less than ideal, " he told reporters at a post-tournament news conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: Q1 tax revenue posts largest annual decrease

TEXT.P: Taiwan's tax revenue for the first quarter of this year was NT$245.3 billion (US$7.34 billion), down by NT$58.6 billion year-on-year, or 19.3 percent -- the biggest drop in the country's history, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) reported Wednesday.

The Q1 tax revenue amounted to only 13.7 percent of the annual target set by the government, which was also a new low since 2001, according to statistics released by the MOF's Department of Statistics.

However, for the month of March, tax offices nationwide collected NT$7.5 billion in stock transaction taxes, which represented a new single-month high since August last year, the statistics showed. MOF officials attributed this growth to a rising stock market, which to date has recorded the world's second-biggest rebound of more than 20 percent since late last year, after the Chinese bourse.

Stock transaction taxes for Q1 totaled NT$14.7 billion, an increase of NT$1.5 billion compared to the figure posted in last Q4. However, this was a NT$12.4 billion drop, or 45.9 percent reduction, year-on-year.
In the first quarter of this year, a total of NT$8.9 billion in land value increment taxes was collected, marking a drop of NT$5.6 billion, or 38.6 percent, compared to the same period in 2008.
This was a result of a sluggish real-estate and property market, which has been hit hard by the global financial crisis since last September, MOF officials said.
In March, the national coffers received NT$3.7 billion in land value increment taxes, down by NT$1.5 billion from the year-earlier level, the MOF statistics showed.

Meanwhile, Q1 business taxes totaled NT$65.9 billion, dropping by NT$13.5 billion from the same period last year and representing a negative growth of 17 percent year-on-year due to a large decline in imports.
March business taxes amounted to NT$38 billion, a decrease of NT$6.4 billion, or a reduction of 14.4 percent, compared to the previous March's level, according to the tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung mayor attends 2009 Global City Forum

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu gave a speech at the 2009 Global City Forum in Abu Dhabi, capital of the United Arab Emirates, Wednesday to share the experience of the central Taiwan city's growth, said Taichung City government officials.

Hu and a delegation from Taichung took part in the forum April 7-8, along with mayors and planners from major international cities, including Paris, San Francisco, Mumbai, Beijing, Jeddah, Riyadh, Seoul and Lyon.
In a speech in the mayors' panel, Hu narrated Taichung's development and how he has been trying to transforming Taichung into a major cultural, economic and international city.

He also explained Taichung's future development plans, including proposals to build a metropolis opera house, a new civic center, the Shuinan Tarde Zone, and a special leisure area in five years, and to transform Taichung into one of the most important international cities in the Asia-Pacific region.
The forum, sponsored by the Abu Dhabi Council for Economic Development and the Abu Dhabi Urban Planning Council, took place at the Emirates Palace hotel in Abu Dhabi.
Six other mayors also shared their experience in urban management and planning, with the discussion focusing on how to develop a blueprint for successful urban living in the future.
In addition to the mayors' panel, there was also a closed-door leaders' summit -- a collaborative platform for new ideas and thinking on mobility patterns in modern cities.

There were also other sessions on various topics, including globalization of the world's sustainable cities, culture and immigration as drivers of a successful city, developing sustainable downtown areas, smart cities and public transport.

DOC.HEADLINE: Senior cross-strait negotiator departs for China visit

TEXT.P: Taiwan's No.2 negotiator with China left for Shanghai Wednesday on a visit reportedly aimed at arranging for a third round of high-level cross-strait talks on matters of mutual concern.

Kao, vice chairman and secretary-general of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , kept a low profile and refrained from answering any questions from the press about the purpose of his Shanghai visit. He was accompanied by SEF Deputy Secretary-General Kao Wen-cheng.
Four other SEF staff members also traveled to China Wednesday on a different flight, sources said.

Lai Shin-yuan, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council that oversees SEF operations, said a day earlier that in view of the continued improvement in cross-strait relations, the third round of high-level cross- strait talks will be held in May ahead of schedule.

Nevertheless, Lai said the exact dates and venue for the third meeting between SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and his Chinese counterpart, Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), have yet to be decided.

Political sources said it is believed that Kao will hold preparatory talks with ARATS officials during his current visit to set the stage for the upcoming Chiang-Chen meeting. The agenda for the meeting will include cooperation in financial fields and crime-fighting and launch of regular scheduled flights.
Chiang and Chen met twice last year to sign six critical agreements on the launch of direct charter flights and shipping and postal links as well as the expansion of tourism exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for April 9, 2009

TEXT.P: The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 9, or the 14th day of the third month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1241: Batu Khan, grandson of Genghis Khan, leads his Mongol horsemen to victory over the Teutonic Knights at Liegniz, Silesia.
1626: Sir Francis Bacon, English philosopher, essayist, courtier, jurist, and statesman, dies at the age of 65. His writings include "The Advancement of Learning," and the "Novum Organum," in which he proposed a theory of scientific knowledge based on observation and experiment that came to be known as the inductive method.
1667: The world's first art exhibition opens in Paris, and lasts for 15 days.
1682: La Salle, the title of Robert Cavelier, the French explorer of North America who claimed Louisiana for France in 1682, reaches the Gulf of Mexico after traveling down the Mississippi River.
1865: Confederation Gen. Robert E. Lee surrenders to Union Gen. Ulysses S. Grant at the Appomattox Courthouse in Virginia, ending the U.S. Civil War.
1926: Tuan Chi-jui resigns as provisional chief executive of the Republic of China.
1928: Islam is no longer recognized as the state religion of Turkey.
1940: German troops invade Norway and Denmark.
1942: American and Filipino forces on Bataan surrender to the Japanese after a four-month siege.
1957: Egypt announces the opening of the Suez Canal after the withdrawal of invading troops from Great Britain and France from Port Said.
1961: The Republic of Vietnam holds its first presidential elections with Ngo Dinh Diem elected as president.
1963: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill is proclaimed an honorary U.S. citizen at the White House.
1965: The ROC and the United States conclude in Taipei an accord to establish a Sino-American fund for economic and social development in Taiwan.
1969: The Concorde, the supersonic passenger jet, makes its maiden flight from Bristol to Fairford in England.
1973: Hedley Donavan, editor-in-chief of Time magazine, arrives in Taipei for a two-day visit.
1973: Lt. Gen. Thomas K. McGebee, commander of the U.S. Aerospace Defense Command, arrives in Taipei from Bangkok for a three-day visit.
1974: Nguyen Van Kieu, newly elevated Vietnamese ambassador-extraordinary and plenipotentiary, presents a copy of his credentials to ROC Foreign Minister Shen Chang-huan.
1976: The fifth congress of the Federation of Asian Photographic Arts opens with 200 representatives from South Korea, the Philippines, India, Indonesia, Sabah and the ROC attending.
1976: Bernard B. Matawali, permanent secretary of the Ministry of Agriculture of Malawi, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1988: Mainland China's National Peoples Congress names Li Peng as premier.
1990: The Democratic Forum of Hungary sweeps to power in elections, after 40 years of communism.
1991: Georgia declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1998: More than 100 Muslim pilgrims are crushed to death in a stampede at the Haj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia.
2000: Paraguay's first flower exhibition center is inaugurated in the Central Province city of Caacupe, with Paraguayan President Luis Gonzalez Macchi and Republic of China Ambassador to Asuncion Liu Ting-tsu cutting the ribbon.
2001: Former Republic of China Vice President Shieh Tung-min passes away at the age of 95 at his home in a suburb of Taipei from cardial infarction.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When there is justice and order in the government of the country a man may be bold and lofty in the expression of his opinions as well as in his actions. When, however, there is no justice and order in the government of the country, a man may be bold and lofty in his actions, but should be reserved in the expression of his opinion."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Thursday, moving up 89.43 points at 5,532.99 on a turnover of NT$4.77 billion (US$140.71 million).
The weighted price index lost 133.29 points, or 2.39 percent, to close at 5,443.56 Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Owner of hijacked Taiwan boat wants to avoid publicity: MOFA

TEXT.P: The owner of a Taiwanese deep sea fishing vessel hijacked by Somali pirates in the Indian Ocean early Monday wishes to maintain a low-profile so that he could be better positioned to negotiate with the hijackers when they make a ransom demand, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday.

"The Foreign Ministry is in close contact with the owner of the hijacked vessel and he has expressed the hope that he could keep a low profile, which will be to his advantage in any negotiations on the matter," said MOFA spokesman Henry Chen at a regular press briefing.
"The Foreign Ministry respects the owner's wishes and is calling on the media to play this down as much as possible," Chen added.

The 700-ton long-line fishing ship "Win Far 161" with 30 crew members on board was hijacked near an island in the Seychelles in the Indian Ocean on Monday. The ship's skipper and first engineer are Taiwan nationals, five of crew members are Chinese, 17 are Filipinos and six are Indonesian.

The MOFA has been trying to obtain updates about the situation from its representative office in South Africa, and has sought the assistance of the U.K. Maritime Trade Organization, the maritime liaison office of the U.S' Bahrain- based 5th fleet, the Seychelles fishery bureau and the Somali harbor bureau to rescue the Kaohsiung-based vessel.

While the MOFA is closely monitoring the movement of the ship, which is heading northwest, it still does not have any news regarding the safety of the crew members, Chen said at a press briefing Thursday. However, based on past experience, the crew should not be in danger if the pirates are looking only to collect a ransom, he added.
When it obtains further news of the vessel, the ministry will decide what to do next, he said.

With the attacks by Somali pirates on commercial vessels escalating, the American Institute in Taiwan Taipei Office expressed concern Wednesday over the incident, saying that the U.S. Department of Defense is taking a closer look at the matter.

When asked about the U.S. response, Harry Tseng, director-general of the MOFA's Department of North American Affairs, said at the press briefing that the U.S. government is aware of Taiwan's request for assistance to resolve the problem.
"The U.S. government is still looking into the matter to see if it can provide any assistance," Tseng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Huge clan symbolizes Hakka people's preservation of family values

TEXT.P: CNA staff writer
For most Taiwanese families, Tomb-Sweeping Day involves gathering a few relatives and heading out to a cemetery to pay homage to deceased ancestors at their graves.

For offspring of the Hakka Chang Liu Ho clan in northern Taiwan's Hsinchu County, however, the festival takes on the trappings of a major international conference -- and provides a glimpse into the tightknit family bonds linking most Hakka people.

Every year in late March, some 1,500 members of the Chang Liu Ho return to their ancestral home from all parts of the island and around the world to take part in the annual ritual that has been a fixture since the late 18th century.

Tourist buses are arranged, hotel rooms reserved and restaurant tables booked long beforehand to facilitate the annual reunion, said Chang Fu-pu, head of the Chang Liu Ho clan in Hsinchu's Hakka-dominated Hukou Township and the town's incumbent secretary-general.
The large-scale reunion reflects the essence of the Hakka culture -- they stick together no matter how distantly related -- which has helped them survive and thrive throughout history.

The "Hakka, " literally meaning "guest families" in Cantonese, comprise a unique ethnic group of Han Chinese, who fled famine and wars in central China in past centuries and eventually settled in southern and eastern China, predominantly in the provinces of Guangdong, Jiangxi and Fujian.
Hakka people comprise the second largest ethnic group in Taiwan behind the Hoklo, early immigrants from southern China's Fujian province.
Unlike the Hoklos, ancestors of Taiwan's Hakkas immigrated mostly from China's Guangdong province.

A 2008 survey conducted by the Cabinet-level Council for Hakka Affairs found that Taiwan's Hakka population -- using a broad definition of the term -- accounts for 25.6 percent of the country's total population.
They are concentrated in the northern counties of Hsinchu, Miaoli and Taoyuan and in Pingtung County in southern Taiwan.

Worldwide, there are an estimated 80 million Hakkas spread out around Southeast Asia, East Africa, Europe and North and South America, although the number of Hakka speakers is considerably lower. Former Thailand Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra is just one of the notable Hakkas dispersed around the globe.
When Chang Yi-piao headed across the Taiwan Strait in a ferry from Guangdong province in 1740, he became just one of the millions of Hakkas who have since left China in search of a better life.
His ferry landed in Hsinchu, where he settled down, raised a small family and eventually died, Chang Fu-pu says.

Chang Yi-piao arrived at a time when most of Taiwan was covered with wild vegetation or forests, but he survived hardships in his new land and married an aboriginal woman at the age of 42. It was not until 13 years later that she successfully bore him a son -- named Chang Ying-shih -- after the deaths of two infants.
Although he survived, the young Ying-shih was physically frail as he grew up, and his parents were worried that he would not live long and carry on the family name.

Panicking and feeling helpless in a strange country, Chang Yi-piao sought help from the spirits of Wu Ju-chih and Wu Ju-liang, brothers who crossed the Taiwan Strait with him on the same boat before vanishing soon after, to look after the child.
Magically, Ying-shih overcame the health problems of his youth and lived to the age of 88, longevity that was almost unheard of at the time.

Ying-shih had six sons and from that generation, a Chang family tree began to thrive. It expanded into a big Hakka clan in the Hsinchu area that only later became known as the Chang Liu Ho clan, meaning six branches of Changs living harmoniously under one clan banner.

Strictly observing Chang Yi-piao's will, the Chang Liu Ho clan requires that all male offspring must remain as part of the family. In practice, that means no Chang son can split from the clan after getting married or maintain his own ancestor-worshipping altar.

The clan operates an ancestral hall, where a diagram of the big Chang family tree is maintained and constantly updated as the clan continues to mushroom. It is now a gigantic diagram of over 2,000 sons and 6,000 people -- if all the sons' spouses and children are included -- covering 20 generations.

While Chang family members have shown great loyalty to their forefathers' clan and the Hakka are among the most patriarchal groups among all Han Chinese, they have also shown a surprisingly progressive edge.
