Defying a traditional Chinese taboo on worshipping people not related to the family, the clan resolved during an earlier generation that the Wu brothers be ushered into the Chang ancestral hall and be commemorated by the Chang offspring annually because of their role as saviors of Chang Ying-shih.

Also, showing unprecedented respect for gender equity, Chang Fu-pu proposed at a clan convention in 2007 that women belonging to the clan who were unmarried or divorced be allowed to be enshrined in the clan's ancestral hall after their deaths.
This sign of respect to female members of the clan was later emulated by many other clans in Taiwan.

Lo Lie-shih, an assistant professor in National Chiao Tung University's College of Hakka Studies, traces the close bonds of Hakka clans seen in the Chang Liu Ho family to the fears of early Hakka settlers of becoming lost souls, without anyone to depend on in a hostile and strange country.
Those fears prompted them to orchestrate a series of rituals to help prevent them from falling into an eternal panic over being alone and forgotten after their deaths.

"Those rituals, stressed over and over again, create an important solidifying force, " says Lo. Wedding and funeral customs and even election-time maneuvering also reinforce the clan's bonds, he notes.
Unlike non-Hakka weddings, where friends comprise the majority of the guests at the reception, most of those invited to a Hakka wedding are relatives of the bride and groom, Lo observes.

For funerals, Lo adds, Hakka people traditionally offer their help and financial support to the family whose relative died to facilitate the holding of the funeral service and get them through the mourning period -- making it a family affair involving the entire community rather than simply the nuclear family.
Even during elections, the influence of clan power can eclipse political party loyalties, often swaying election results, Lo says.

These many traditions reinforcing clan bonds allow Hakka offspring to feel a stronger sense of stability over their futures, and in a modern society where interpersonal relations can be distant and cold, the Hakka clan's wisdom and values are worth respecting and even emulating, Lo contended.

Chang Fu-pu, for one, is proud to have upheld the culture's values and successfully stewarded the big Hakka family, one of the largest in Taiwan's genealogical history, through the challenging modern age.
Though he is uncertain the tight family relationship will survive the test of time, he feels he has fulfilled his duty.
"At least I've lived up to my ancestors' expectations and preserved the clan's legacy," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet approves government restructuring plan

TEXT.P: The Cabinet approved Thursday a government restructuring plan that would downsize the number of ministries and Cabinet agencies from 37 to 29.

Chiang Yi-hua, chairman of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, said after a weekly Cabinet meeting that under the restructuring plan, there will be 13 ministries, nine councils and commissions, two directorate-generals, and three independent agencies and two other organizations.
The new structure will be adopted in 2011, pending amendment of the Executive Yuan's organic law by the legislature, Chiang said.

The 13 ministries would cover interior affairs, foreign affairs, national defense, finance, education, justice, economic affairs, transportation and construction, health and social welfare, culture, labor affairs, agriculture, and environmental resources, Chiang said.

The nine councils and commissions would deal with overseas compatriot affairs, veterans affairs, science, national development, China affairs, indigenous affairs, Hakka affairs, financial supervision and maritime affairs, he added.
The two directorate-generals would be in charge of personnel management and budget, accounting and statistics, Chiang said.
The three independent agencies would be the Central Election Commission, the Fair Trade Commission and the National Communications Commission, he stated.
The remaining two organizations would be the Central Bank and the National Palace Museum, he said.

Chiang said the government had originally intended to merge the existing Overseas Compatriot Affairs Commission with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to form a new "Ministry of Foreign and Overseas Compatriot Affairs, " but later decided to drop the plan after some Taiwanese expatriates expressed opposition to it.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's role in global economic arena depends on China: economists

TEXT.P: The issue of whether or not Taiwan will be able to play a role in the international economic arena remains in the hands of China, despite the fact that the island has foreign reserves that far exceed those of many major economies in the world, two noted U.S. economists said Thursday.

"I've always thought that Beijing is taking a very tough line on Taiwan's participation in international organizations, and I don't see we have much leverage to change that, " said Nicholas R. Lardy, a senior fellow at the U.S. non-governmental Peterson Institute for International Economics.

He made the remarks in response to a question at a video conference held by the Office of Trade Negotiations of Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) on the topic "the Global, Regional and Local Significance of the Outcome of the G20 Summit in London."

"I don't see that external actors -- the United States or anybody else -- have any leverage to change that," Lardy said. "Until the Chinese on the mainland have a change of view, it seems unlikely to happen."
Michael Mussa, a senior fellow at the Peterson Institute and a former economic counselor and director of the Department of Research at the International Monetary Fund (IMF), expressed a similar view.

While Taiwan's GDP might be bigger than the bottom two or three economies that participated in the G20 summit, the possibility for it to play a role in the summit or in similar international economic meetings is very slim due to China's obstruction, Mussa said.

He noted that from Taiwan's perspective, its accession to the World Trade Organization and the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum under the designation Chinese Taipei was arguably its most important achievement in this area. However, Mussa said he doubted Taiwan would be able to go further than that, and certainly not to the G20 summit.
"That is not one that the Beijing government will go along with it at all," he said.

The noted economist added that while he would not rule out the possibility that at some point Taiwan would be able to join the World Bank, the IMF, or some other institution of that kind if the relations between Taipei and Beijing continue to improve, fundamentally it all depends on the attitude of the Beijing government.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP chairwoman to visit U.S., Canada for fundraising

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen will visit the United States and Canada in early May to raise funds for the party's candidates in the year-end city mayor and county magistrate elections, a party spokesman said Thursday.

During her 10-day trip, Tsai will first attend the Executive Committee meeting of Liberal International slated to take place May 1-3 in Vancouver, Canada to promote party diplomacy and enhance Taiwan's international visibility, according to DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang.
Tsai will then head to the United States to hold talks with Taiwan expatriates there, but details of her itinerary have not yet been finalized, Cheng added.
According to DPP sources, Tsai will call on several famous U.S. think tanks, such as the Foreign Policy Research Institute, the Brookings Institution and the Heritage Foundation.

In addition, Tsai will visit officials of the new U.S. government, which took office in January when President Barack Obama was sworn in, to make them more aware of the DPP's political agenda and proposed activities and of Taiwan's political situation, the sources said.
The DPP chairwoman also plans to visit Southeast Asian countries to meet overseas party members and Taiwanese expatriates there, the sources disclosed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Justice ministry unveils anti-corruption plan

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) has finalized a feasibility study for an anti- corruption agency and has drafted a national integrity action plan that will be submitted to the Executive Yuan for approval before being implemented, MOJ Minister Wang Ching-feng said Thursday.

Wang unveiled the plan at a legislative session in reaction to President Ma Ying-jeou's call Wednesday for government and judiciary reviews of major corruption cases and for the introduction of concrete proposals within three months to address the corruption situation in the country.
The president made the call in light of a report by a Hong Kong consultancy that stated corruption was worse in Taiwan than in mainland China.
Saying that she has always known of Ma's resolve to fight corruption, Wang added that the ministry is well prepared to set up the agency as proposed.

But she turned down a suggestion by Kuomintang Legislator Chiu Yi that a special Cabinet-level anti-corruption committee should be established to vertically and horizontally integrate the operations of all Cabinet agencies, saying there is no need to do so.
In an effort to clean up corruption in Taiwan, the MOJ has launched various reform measures over the past year to promote integrity among public officials, according to a ministry official.

The measures include encouraging the central government as well as cities and counties to set up anti-corruption commissions and publish anti-corruption reports, the official said. They also include formulating a code of ethics and revising anti-corruption regulations for public employees, enacting an anti- corruption law against unexplained wealth, and helping companies launch measures to promote business ethics, the official added.

To keep abreast of anti-corruption trends around the world, the ministry has come up with a draft national integrity action plan that combines the existing well-formed government ethics program, the program for getting rid of organized crime and corruption, and the anti-corruption program, the official said.

The action plan aims to combat and prevent corruption, strengthen public servant ethics, promote honesty in business, step up anti-corruption education, make the government more open, make the government procurement process more transparent, ensure fair political participation, and enhance international cooperation, according to the official.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of workers on unpaid leave down to one third: science park

TEXT.P: Only about one third of the workers employed by companies at a major science park in central Taiwan are still being asked to take unpaid leave days, the management said Thursday.

Yang Wen-ker, director-general of the Central Taiwan Science Park Administration, said only 6,000 employees working for companies at the park remain on unpaid leave, and he predicted that the number will further decline after June in view of the rash of orders that the park has been receiving.
The number of furloughed workers at the park peaked at around 14,000 in December last year after the global financial crisis broke in September, Yang noted.

Meanwhile, business turnover at the park in February totaled NT$10.3 billion (US$308 million) , up by about 20 percent over the January figure of NT$8.6 billion, the park administration reported early this week.
The Central Taiwan Science Park, with facilities in Taichung City, Taichung County and the nearby Changhua and Yunlin counties, houses more than 150 high- tech companies.
The park was established in 2002 by the Executive Yuan. It is one of three major science parks in Taiwan, with the other two being in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, and in Tainan, southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan prosecutors to monitor baseball games for rigging

TEXT.P: Prosecutors from the southern city of Tainan will begin to monitor professional baseball games from Friday in a bid to prevent a reoccurrence of game rigging.

Starting Friday, a group of 17 prosecutors from the Tainan District Prosecutors Office, who are also lovers of the baseball game, will take turns to lead local police to monitor the games and collect evidence if they think there are signs of rigging, said Lin Chih-feng, a chief prosecutor.
It would be the first time ever that prosecutors would be openly monitoring professional baseball games in a bid to stem crime.
However, only games at the baseball stadiums in Tainan will be monitored, Lin said.
Professional baseball game rigging and related underground gambling have been rampant over the past two decades since Taiwan's Chinese Professional Baseball League (CPBL) was launched in 1990.

Over the years, some coaches and players have been detained and indicted for game rigging. In some cases, the coach instructed the pitcher and the other players on the team how to play in order to produce game results in line with the team owner's plan. This allowed underground gambling rings to net huge winnings from their bets.
The accused were usually indicted on charges of fraud, breach of trust and organized crime, the prosecutors said.
In the past, some prosecutors and police units sporadically monitored professional baseball games, but did so using undercover methods, Lin said.
Taiwan was the sixth nation in the world to establish a professional baseball league, following the United States, Japan, South Korea, Australia and Mexico, in that order.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China to discuss new air routes: SEF chief

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China will discuss plans to increase the current number of charter flights and open new routes to accommodate the increased tourism exchanges between the two sides, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin- kung said Thursday.

Officials of the SEF and its Chinese counterpart, Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , will address the two issues in their upcoming third round of talks scheduled for later this month or early May in China. The SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies that handle exchanges between the two sides.
Chiang made the remarks at a ceremony that he co-chaired with Shandong Tourism Bureau Director Yu Chong to mark the start of "2009 Taiwan-Shandong Tourism Exchange Year."
Under the exchange plan, 23,000 people from Shandong Province in northern China will visit Taiwan in the coming year, while 10,000 Taiwanese tourists will travel to Shandong, Yu said.

In May, a group of more than 400 Shandong tourists will visit Taiwan via the mini links -- direct ferry services between Xiamen Port in China's Fujian Province and the Taiwan-held Kinmen Island, he said. The group of Shandong tourists will travel to Xiamen by train, he added.

In an effort to further promote tourism exchanges between Taiwan and Shandong Province, representatives from the Taipei-based Travel Quality Assurance Association, along with 10 city and county tourism associations and six tour agencies, signed a cooperation accord with Shandong tourism representatives from 10 cities and six travel agencies in Shandong.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, falling NT$0.123 to close at NT$33.777.
A total of US$1.278 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.900 and fluctuated between NT$33.725 and NT$33.920.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices close at 6-month high on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices rose 4.11 percent to a six-month high Thursday, following gains on Wall Street and regional markets.
The weighted index, the market's key barometer, advanced 224.24 points to close at 5,667.80, on the government's bid to promote tourism and expand warming ties with China.
Recouping a 2.39 percent fall in the previous session, the local bourse opened at 5,532.99 and fluctuated between 5,667.80 and 5,526.13.
A total of 7.00 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$144.84 billion (US$4.29 billion).
The Taiwan stock market has gained more than 20 percent since late last year, making it by far one of the strongest major Asian markets.

All the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial stocks moving up the most at 5.6 percent. Textile issues advanced 5.3 percent, foodstuff shares gained 4.7 percent, cement stocks rose 4.6 precent, construction stocks surged 4.4 percent, machinery and electronics shares rose 4.0 percent, plastics and chemicals shares climbed 3.7 percent, and paper and pulp issues closed up 2.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,889 to 320, with 52 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$11.04 billion.

An analyst predicted that the market could test the 6,300-point level in the near future on optimism that Taiwan's economy may rebound after the second quarter and that a long-anticipated financial supervision agreement will be signed between Taiwan and China before the middle of the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cyclists biking on Yushan to promote it as one of seven wonders

TEXT.P: In the latest twist to an ongoing campaign to get Taiwan's Jade Mountain or Yushan listed as one of the world's seven natural wonders, 24 cyclists from around the country are biking on the tallest mountain on the island.

According to the Yushan National Park Headquarters, the cyclists launched the tour Wednesday, and are expected to complete the 185-kilometer route by Friday, after going up one of Taiwan's most challenging mountain trails.
The park headquarters organized the cycling activity in an effort to boost the international image of the tallest peak in northeast Asia, which reaches 3,952 meters.

Park rangers said that the cyclists, including Cheng Huai, the Taiwanese athlete who will participate in the cycling events in the 21st Deaflympics Taipei 2009 slated for Sept. 5-16, set off from the national park's Nan-an tourist center in Hualien County, eastern Taiwan.

They will ride on the challenging South Cross-Island Highway -- one of the major roads that bridges the southern and eastern parts of Taiwan -- and the new Cross-Island Highway, before arriving at the national park headquarters in Shueili Township of Nantou County, central Taiwan.

Park Headquarters Deputy Director Wu Hsiang-chien said Wednesday that the riders entered the South Cross-Island Highway from Chihshang and Haiduan townships in Taitung County, southeastern Taiwan, earlier in the day. They will then climb to the highway's highest point of Yakou, at 2,722 meters, before descending to the national park's Meishan tourist center.
It is not possible to bike all the way up to Yushan's 3,952-meter peak due to the lack of bike trails.
On Thursday and Friday, the group will ride on the Alishan highway in Chiayi County and the new Cross-Island Highway to complete the cycling activity in Nantou, Wu said.
The cycling challenge is also part of the celebrations for the national park's 24th founding anniversary.

Park officials said they hope the cyclists' enthusiasm, energy and spirit of embracing challenges will be demonstrated to the public, and they hope the activity will help unite Taiwanese people around the goal of bringing Yushan onto the world's stage.
Each of the cyclists are wearing a vest printed with the slogan "Vote for Yushan."
Organizers urged all Taiwanese people to give their support for Yushan, and for Taiwan, by voting online in the global competition.

According to the organizer, the riders come from different social sectors, with some working as either the chairman or general manager of businesses, restaurant chef, or editor-in-chief of a publication. Others work as a professor, photographer, or engineer.
Yushan is currently in first place in the "mountains, volcanoes" category in the contest for the world's new seven natural wonders organized by the Swiss-based New7Wonders Foundation.
The foundation initiated the campaign after organizing the selection of the seven manmade wonders of the world.

In the ongoing second round of the worldwide online voting, 261 natural sites in 222 countries, including Loch Ness in Scotland, the Grand Canyon in Arizona, Mount Fuji in Japan, the Yangtze River in China and Jeju Island in South Korea, are competing in seven categories for the title of the "New Seven Wonders of the Natural World."

Yushan is the only natural attraction from Taiwan to make the list of contenders in any category, and is up against Mount Everest, Mount Fuji, Mount Olympus and K2 Mountain in the mountains and volcanoes category.

The top 11 sites chosen in each of the seven categories by July 7 will then be reviewed by a panel of experts headed by Federico Mayor Zaragoza, former director-general of the United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization (UNESCO), who will select three nominees in each category.

The 21 nominees will be put to the final round of the worldwide online vote in 2010 and 2011 to select the top seven wonders in the landscape, island, mountain, cave, forest, lake and seascape categories.
Yushan, located along the boundaries of Chiayi, Nantou and Kaohsiung counties, is known for its diverse wildlife and ecology.
To boost Yushan's chances of being selected, the national park headquarters urged the public to cast their vote for the mountain by visiting the Web site http://www.new7wonders.com. endtiem/cs

DOC.HEADLINE: Investable assets shrink for 73% of working investors: survey

TEXT.P: The majority of Taiwan office workers with financial investments have suffered losses as a result of the global financial crisis, according to the results of a survey released Thursday by the online employment broker 1111 Job Bank.
The survey, conducted among 1,413 office workers between March 27 and April 7, found that 36.16 percent of the respondents have invested in financial products over the past six months.
Some 73.1 percent of these investors complained about shrinkage of their investable assets, saying that their wealth has contracted by 42.46 percent on average.
Only 7.03 percent of the investors have made profits, while 14.48 percent have broken even on their investments, and 5.48 percent are unaware of their investment outcomes, according to the poll.

The poor investment performance, however, has not dampened the workers' interest in financial investment, as nearly 77 percent of respondents indicated their intention to continue investment in the next six months.
Some 20.24 percent said they would take an aggressive approach, as opposed to 30.29 percent who planned to be more conservative.

In addition, the survey revealed that 55.27 percent of workers have developed an interest in acquiring investment know-how, in light of the financial crisis. Those with full-time jobs and those who have not been affected by the furlough policy are showing greater interest than others, the results indicated.
The survey also found that workers are taking a more proactive attitude toward continuing studies, amid the economic downturn.
Nearly 66 percent of the respondents are engaged in continuing studies, up 19.13 percent from October 2008 when a similar survey was conducted.

Regarding the objectives that the respondents are trying to achieve, the poll showed that 62.83 percent wish to enhance their professional skills, 58.32 percent hope to improve their employment opportunities, and 49.08 percent want to develop a second area of expertise.
More than 43 percent of the respondents are focusing on studies on information literacy and computer know-how, and approximately 37 percent are concentrating on technical skills and personal talent.

However, nearly 60 percent of the workers engaged in continuing studies have reduced their spending in this regard because of the weak economy, with their spending for this purpose averaging NT$5,159 per month.

Self-study -- the option that costs the least money -- has become the most popular choice, favored by 46.61 percent of the workers, according to the survey. The second-most popular choice is enrolling in programs provided by private educational institutions or cram schools -- an option that is favored by 35.11 percent of workers.
Attending speeches or lectures was the next most popular choice, with 31.21 percent of workers opting for this route.
Registering in university continuing studies programs, which was the top choice in October, has now dropped to fifth place due to high costs, with 23.2 percent of the workers choosing this option.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung to cut foreign workers as unemployment rises to 6%

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government pledged Thursday to cut back on the number of foreign laborers working in the city and save those jobs for locals, as the city's unemployment rate is estimated to have climbed past the national 5.75 percent average to break the 6 percent mark.
City Director of Labor Affairs Chung Kung-chao made the statement after a city councilor, Lin Kuo-cheng, expressed concern over rising unemployment in the southern Taiwan port city.

Quoting statistics from the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs and the city's Bureau of Labor Affairs, Lin said that the average national effective employment rate among people seeking jobs was 38 percent in 2008, while in Kaohsiung the figure was only 27 percent.
In February, the effective employment rate among job seekers in Kaohsiung fell to 10 percent, also much lower than the national average of 22 percent for that month, he said.

The figures show that there are fewer work opportunities in Kaohsiung than in the northern part of the island, Lin said, urging the city bureau to take measures to protect the employment rights of local citizens.

At the City Council, Chung pointed out that the city's jobless population was 33,000 at the end of last year, and that as of February this year the number had risen by 9,000. This means that the unemployment rate may have exceeded 6 percent, he added.
There are currently some 706,000 working people in the port city, Chung said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan takes part in Shanghai world travel fair
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/09 19:22:23 (By Chiao Hsing-hua and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan tourism delegation is taking part in the World Travel Fair 2009 in Shanghai, which is being held April 9-11 at the Shanghai New International Expo Center.

The Taiwan delegation, led by hotelier Stanley Yen, honorary chairman of the Taiwan Visitors Association, is composed of several government officials, chiefs of local governments and executives of 37 Taiwanese travel agencies and hotels.
Shanghai Deputy Mayor Zhao Wen paid a visit to the Taiwan pavilion soon after the opening of the Shanghai World Travel Fair, at which she officiated.
During talks with Zhao, Yen said that a majority of mainland Chinese people still have an outdated impression that Taiwan's only attractions are Sun Moon Lake and Alishan.
In fact, he said, Taiwan has other rich tourism resources, such as quality hotspring resorts, gourmet food, cycling tours and related facilities, its aboriginal cultures and an exquisite tea culture.

Noting that Chinese sightseers are just beginning to visit Taiwan in large numbers, Yen said Taiwan's target of attracting one million Chinese tourists per year could be exceeded. The number could reach 3 million or even 5 million a year if Taiwan's tourism industry operators continue to improve the quality of their products, said Yen, who is known as the godfather of Taiwan's hotel service industry and is president of the Landis Hotels and Resorts group.

Also speaking on the same occasion, Hualien County Magistrate Hsieh Shen-shan suggested that mainland Chinese tourists should stay for at least one night in Hualien if they visit the Pacific coast of Taiwan.
"Only by making overnight visits can the tourists savor the quality and attractions of Hualien," Hsieh said.

It is the first time that the Taiwan Visitors Association is leading a Taiwan delegation to the Shanghai World Travel Fair, which has been a major indicator of the development of China's outbound travel industry.
In the past, Taiwan travel industry operators have participated in the Shanghai fair on their own.

Kuo Su Tsan-yang, deputy director-general of the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, is also attending the fair in his capacity as an adviser to the Taiwan Visitors Association.

DOC.HEADLINE: Executive Yuan unveils tourism-boosting plan

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan approved an ambitious tourism expansion project Thursday in its regular weekly meeting, with the aim of turning Taiwan into a tourism hub in East Asia that could generate NT$550 billion (US$16.5 billion) in tourism revenue in four years on a planned budget of NT$30 billion.
Premier Liu Chao-shiuan instructed government agencies to cooperate fully in the program, which the government estimates will help create 400,000 jobs by 2012.
Speaking after the meeting, Tourism Bureau Director-General Janice Lai said the program will capitalize on upgrading travel quality in Taiwan to lure more foreign tourists from around the world.

Through a NT$30 billion fund dedicated to promoting local tourism, Lai said, the government hopes to rack up NT$550 billion in tourism revenue by 2012, with some NT$300 billion contributed by foreign tourists and the remaining NT$250 billion generated from domestic travelers.
In addition to U.S. and European tourists, Lai said, visitors from countries such as China and India, as well as countries in the Middle East and Southeast Asia, will be targeted in the program.
The government hopes to achieve 4.1 million foreign tourist arrivals for 2009, 4.5 million in 2010, 5 million in 2011 and 5.5 million in 2012, she elaborated.

As part of the government's marketing program, the Tourism Bureau will divide the country into four major regions featuring different themes in an effort to cater to the different tastes of the tourists from around the world, according to Lai.
To promote northern Taiwan, the bureau will feature lifestyle aspects such as the arts, pop music and fashion, she said.
Tea and flower gardens will be main focus of the bureau when it introduces central Taiwan regions, while historic monuments will be the major attraction in its efforts to promote southern Taiwan.

The slow pace of life in eastern Taiwan will be capitalized on with an emphasis on cycle tours and the cultures of indigenous tribes in the area, Lai continued, adding that the offshore counties of Penghu and Kinmen will be promoted as international resort islands and as the location of Cold War military relics, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: No safety concerns from radioactive leakage at university: AEC

TEXT.P: There are no safety concerns resulting from the leakage of radioactive material at a northern Taiwan university described by the Atomic Energy Council (AEC) as minimal, an AEC official said Thursday.
"The amount of the released radiation is far below the allowable level, " the official said, although he conceded that the level is higher than it has been in the past.

"The AEC has demanded that National Tsing Hua University makes a complete report on the situation within two weeks and also that it makes improvements so that the same thing does not happen again, " the official said.

He noted that during a regular check of the Hsinchu City university in February for radioactivity levels in the fourth quarter of 2008, the council noticed that the iodine-131 levels in the grass and trees sampled around the production facility for the radioactive isotope were slightly higher than previously recorded figures.
The council therefore alerted the university and told it to conduct checks and find out the reasons for the changes.

The council sent officials to the university in late March to learn more about the situation and found that in order to increase its iodine-131 production, the facility had modified its production process so that minimal levels of iodine-131 were not absorbed by the activated carbon used in the manufacturing process but were instead released into the atmosphere.
Iodine-131, also called radio iodine, is an iodine radioisotope that has various medical and pharmaceutical uses.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC head to attend opposition state of nation conference

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said Thursday that she will attend a forthcoming conference organized by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) on the state of the nation.

Lai, Taiwan's top China policy planner, said that "the administration will not be absent" from the meeting slated for April 11, which is described by the organizers as an "overall check-up of the Ma Ying-jeou administration's China- tilted policy, " with Taiwan's plans to sign an economic cooperation framework agreement with China tabled as the centerpiece of the gathering.

Meanwhile, Lai is scheduled to meet with executives of companies in Taiwan's 10 largest traditional manufacturing industries Friday to gain a better understanding of their development issues and possible coping measures.
The delegates will represent the towel, footwear, ceramics, underwear, hosiery, luggage, general garments, swimwear, tea and bedlinen industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Third round of cross-strait talks to take place in Nanjing

TEXT.P: The third round of talks between top negotiators from both sides of the Taiwan Strait will be held in the Chinese city of Nanjing "barring accidents, " the spokesman for the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Thursday.
MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun said the two sides have both expressed hope that the talks will take place in a city other than the Chinese capital of Beijing.

He made the remarks at a press conference on the most recent visit to Shanghai by Kao Koong-lian, vice chairman and secretary-general of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , to arrange for the third meeting since last June between SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and his Chinese counterpart, Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).
Kao, accompanied by his deputy Kao Wen-cheng, went to Shanghai Wednesday and returned the following day.

Liu said Kao was tasked with discussing procedural problems with ARATS officials and to gain more understanding of the progress of talks between the two intermediary bodies in terms of technical issues.
Judging by the progress to date, the two bodies still need to communicate with each other on certain technical problems, including the exact date of the high- profile Chiang-Chen meeting

MAC Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said earlier in the week that in view of the continued improvement in cross-strait ties, the third round of high-level cross- strait talks will be held in May, ahead of schedule.

Asked about the issue of a proposed cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement -- a topic of great concern -- Liu said it is expected to be discussed during the upcoming Chiang-Chen meeting.
Chiang and Chen met twice last year and signed six critical agreements on the launch of direct charter flights, shipping and postal links, and the expansion of tourism exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: TFT-LCD panel uptake expected to rise in Q2

TEXT.P: The global uptake of thin film transistor liquid crystal display (TFT-LCD) panels is expected to regain near full capacity in the second half of this year owing to increasing demand, a display market research and consulting firm forecast Thursday.

With uptake having dropped to around 70 percent since the start of the global economic downturn in the final quarter of 2008, it is likely that it will rise to 80 percent in the second quarter of 2009 and further to 90 percent in the second half of the year, said David Hsieh, vice president of the Greater China Market at DisplaySearch, during the 2009 Taiwan FPD International Conference in Taipei.

DisplaySearch statistics show that global shipments of large-area TFT-LCD panels totaled 29.5 million units in February, up 23 percent from the previous month, with revenue rising 14 percent month-on-month to reach US$2.96 billion.
Both figures represent the first positive monthly growth since September 2008, due mainly to increasing rush orders and inventory refills from clients, according to DisplaySearch.
The growth could be an indication that the TFT-LCD industry is at, or near, the bottom of a cycle, the company said.
Taiwan, which shipped 44 percent of the world's large-area panels in 2008, plans to increase shipments by 12 percent in 2009, DisplaySearch data shows.

Hsieh predicted that China will become an important market for Taiwan's TFT-LCD panel sector this year, thanks to that country's latest economic stimulus measures to encourage home appliance purchases by rural consumers.

The phase-out of traditional cathode ray tube (CRT) television sets -- which presently number 150 million units worldwide -- also bodes well for a promising market for the TFT-LCD sector in the coming years, Hsieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Numerous health insurance fraud cases cracked in southern Taiwan

TEXT.P: Dozens of medical institutions and professionals in southern Taiwan were found of defrauding more than NT$70 million (US$2.09 million) from the National Health Insurance program in over 100,000 cases in an investigation conducted during the first three months of this year, a spokesman for the Tainan Public Prosecutors Office said Thursday.

Although almost all the cases occurred in Tainan and Kaohsiung cities, the spokesman said, they represent only "the tip of the iceberg" in the widespread problem of fraud against the insurance system by medical institutions in the country.

Those accused of being involved in the insurance fraud cases include the Department of Health (DOH) -governed Tainan Hospital Hsinhua Branch, 10 private clinics, five pharmaceutical stores and about 70 nursing homes, as well as two clinic owners, 19 medical doctors, seven pharmacists, and four medical service brokers, according to the spokesman.
The Tainan District Court granted a prosecutors' request to detain 12 suspects. Fourteen others have been released on bail, the spokesman added.

During raids of the medical institutions, investigators removed a batch of patient records and questioned 22 people, including nine physicians at the DOH Tainan Hospital, the first time a public hospital was suspected to have been involved in fraud, according to the spokesman.

The nine medical professionals, including three active executives and six former physicians at the hospital, were suspected of colluding with scores of local nursing homes to defraud the national health care program of NT$30 million between 2006 and 2008 by issuing a large number of chronic illness prescription refill slips, according to spokesman.

The nine doctors have been released on NT$800,000-NT$1 million bail after admitting to committing fraud, the spokesman said. They had claimed they were under pressure to reach their business targets set by the hospital to avoid being fired, the spokesman added.

However, the hospital issued a statement Thursday denying that it had pressed doctors to meet revenue objectives, adding that some of the accused were contracted doctors and were unlikely to be under work performance pressure.
Using fake prescriptions is a common fraud practice against the national health insurance system, the spokesman added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Micron will not cooperate with TMC, wants government support

TEXT.P: U.S.-based Micron Technology Inc., a leading DRAM technology provider, will not cooperate with Taiwan Memory Co. (TMC) , but looks forward to more support from Taiwan's government, corporate executives said Thursday.

Micron authorized the company's representative, Fred Fishburn, and Charles Kao, president of Inotera Memories Inc. -- a cooperative partner of both Micron and Nanya Technology Corp. -- to make the announcement.

Kao told a news conference that after a comprehensive assessment, Micron has decided not to cooperate with TMC, a company Taiwan's government is planning to set up in collaboration with local and foreign business groups to revamp the country's struggling dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chip industry.
According to Kao, Micron has decided instead to further reinforce its long-term cooperation with Nanya Technology and Inotera Memories in research and development of advanced DRAM technology.
Micron has long been a key technology provider for Nanya and Inotera, both of which are affiliates of the giant Formosa Plastics Group.
Kao said Micron hopes the government will give the Micron-Nanya-Inotera alliance the same level of support as it would have given to a Micron-TMC venture.
Responding to Micron's announcement, TMC's appointed Convener John Hsuan said he respects the company's decision.

Economics Minister Yiin Chii-ming also said the ministry respects Micron's decision and that if the Micron-Nanya-Inotera alliance needs the government's assistance, it can present a concrete plan to the Ministry of Economic Affairs for evaluation.
Meanwhile, Nanya Technology Chairman Wu Chia-chau said the Micron -Nanya-Inotera alliance fully complies with TMC's goal of helping local DRAM manufacturers acquire core technologies.

"So we are hopeful that the government will make the best use of our resources to consolidate the domestic DRAM industry and that in the process, will offer the same treatment to our alliance as it gives to TMC," Wu added.
According to Wu, Nanya Technology began to invest in the development of DRAM production technologies eight years ago in cooperation with IBM.
"Over the past eight years, we have injected NT$40 billion in R&D funds and built up a certain level of technological proficiency, " Wu noted.
Moverover, he went on, Nanya Technology has signed a 10-year technological cooperation pact with Micron on an equal footing and will use Inotera as a joint research platform.

Reaffirming the company's commitment to the continued development of sophisticated DRAM technologies, Wu said both Nanya Technology and Inotera will increase their capital in the near future to improve their financial status.
He stressed that the alliance is not seeking a government bailout. "What we need is the government's assistance in the development of DRAM core technologies," he added.

According to Fishburn, Micron decided against an alliance with TMC mainly because it feared that such a partnership could erode its technological superiority by exposing its secrets to Elpida, a Japanese company which has agreed to cooperate with TMC.
Taiwan's six DRAM makers have suffered from a supply glut as the global economic slump has sapped demand for electronics and machinery run with semiconductors.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs proposed the establishment of TMC in the hope that it will focus on technological development to help local chipmakers compete with their South Korean counterparts, aided by technology from American and Japanese makers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan will continue to bar Chinese garlic imports: food agency

TEXT.P: Denying allegations that some 30 percent of the garlic sold in Taiwan originates from China, the Agriculture and Food Agency (AFA) said Thursday that there have been no legal imports of garlic from there.
In fact, said AFA Secretary-General Hsu Han-ching, most of the foreign garlic sold here is imported from Argentina.
Hsu added that even if Taiwan signs an economic cooperation framework agreement with China in the near future, the country will still not open its doors to Chinese garlic.
"Our policy of restricting imports of Chinese garlic and protecting the rights of local farmers will remain unchanged, " Hsu said.
He told garlic farmers not to be fooled by lies by traders alleging that some 30 percent of Taiwan's garlic is imported from China, which he described as being aimed at driving down prices.

He noted that nationwide, the amount of land given over to garlic totaled 5,477 hectares this year, 429 hectares less than last year, with total annual production expected to top 48,800 tons -- a 10 percent decrease year-on-year.

Despite the decrease, local garlic can almost meet annual demand -- which averages about 50,000 tons per year -- he went on, adding that the agency allows the import of a small amount of garlic, mainly from Argentina, to ensure that supply fully meets demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for April 10, 2009

TEXT.P: The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Justice ministry unveils anti-corruption plan

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) has finalized a feasibility study for an anti- corruption agency and has drafted a national integrity action plan that will be submitted to the Executive Yuan for approval before being implemented, MOJ Minister Wang Ching-feng said Thursday.

Wang unveiled the plan at a legislative session in reaction to President Ma Ying-jeou's call Wednesday for government and judiciary reviews of major corruption cases and for the introduction of concrete proposals within three months to address the corruption situation in the country.
The president made the call in light of a report by a Hong Kong consultancy that stated corruption was worse in Taiwan than in mainland China.
Saying that she has always known of Ma's resolve to fight corruption, Wang added that the ministry is well prepared to set up the agency as proposed.

But she turned down a suggestion by Kuomintang Legislator Chiu Yi that a special Cabinet-level anti-corruption committee should be established to vertically and horizontally integrate the operations of all Cabinet agencies, saying there is no need to do so.
In an effort to clean up corruption in Taiwan, the MOJ has launched various reform measures over the past year to promote integrity among public officials, according to a ministry official.

The measures include encouraging the central government as well as cities and counties to set up anti-corruption commissions and publish anti-corruption reports, the official said. They also include formulating a code of ethics and revising anti-corruption regulations for public employees, enacting an anti- corruption law against unexplained wealth, and helping companies launch measures to promote business ethics, the official added.

To keep abreast of anti-corruption trends around the world, the ministry has come up with a draft national integrity action plan that combines the existing well-formed government ethics program, the program for getting rid of organized crime and corruption, and the anti-corruption program, the official said.

The action plan aims to combat and prevent corruption, strengthen public servant ethics, promote honesty in business, step up anti-corruption education, make the government more open, make the government procurement process more transparent, ensure fair political participation, and enhance international cooperation, according to the official.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of workers on unpaid leave down to one third: science park

TEXT.P: Only about one third of the workers employed by companies at a major science park in central Taiwan are still being asked to take unpaid leave days, the management said Thursday.

Yang Wen-ker, director-general of the Central Taiwan Science Park Administration, said only 6,000 employees working for companies at the park remain on unpaid leave, and he predicted that the number will further decline after June in view of the rash of orders that the park has been receiving.
The number of furloughed workers at the park peaked at around 14,000 in December last year after the global financial crisis broke in September, Yang noted.

Meanwhile, business turnover at the park in February totaled NT$10.3 billion (US$308 million) , up by about 20 percent over the January figure of NT$8.6 billion, the park administration reported early this week.
The Central Taiwan Science Park, with facilities in Taichung City, Taichung County and the nearby Changhua and Yunlin counties, houses more than 150 high- tech companies.
The park was established in 2002 by the Executive Yuan. It is one of three major science parks in Taiwan, with the other two being in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, and in Tainan, southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan prosecutors to monitor baseball games for rigging

TEXT.P: Prosecutors from the southern city of Tainan will begin to monitor professional baseball games from Friday in a bid to prevent a reoccurrence of game rigging.

Starting Friday, a group of 17 prosecutors from the Tainan District Prosecutors Office, who are also lovers of the baseball game, will take turns to lead local police to monitor the games and collect evidence if they think there are signs of rigging, said Lin Chih-feng, a chief prosecutor.
It would be the first time ever that prosecutors would be openly monitoring professional baseball games in a bid to stem crime.
However, only games at the baseball stadiums in Tainan will be monitored, Lin said.
Professional baseball game rigging and related underground gambling have been rampant over the past two decades since Taiwan's Chinese Professional Baseball League (CPBL) was launched in 1990.

Over the years, some coaches and players have been detained and indicted for game rigging. In some cases, the coach instructed the pitcher and the other players on the team how to play in order to produce game results in line with the team owner's plan. This allowed underground gambling rings to net huge winnings from their bets.
The accused were usually indicted on charges of fraud, breach of trust and organized crime, the prosecutors said.
In the past, some prosecutors and police units sporadically monitored professional baseball games, but did so using undercover methods, Lin said.
Taiwan was the sixth nation in the world to establish a professional baseball league, following the United States, Japan, South Korea, Australia and Mexico, in that order.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China to discuss new air routes: SEF chief

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China will discuss plans to increase the current number of charter flights and open new routes to accommodate the increased tourism exchanges between the two sides, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin- kung said Thursday.

Officials of the SEF and its Chinese counterpart, Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , will address the two issues in their upcoming third round of talks scheduled for later this month or early May in China. The SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies that handle exchanges between the two sides.
Chiang made the remarks at a ceremony that he co-chaired with Shandong Tourism Bureau Director Yu Chong to mark the start of "2009 Taiwan-Shandong Tourism Exchange Year."
Under the exchange plan, 23,000 people from Shandong Province in northern China will visit Taiwan in the coming year, while 10,000 Taiwanese tourists will travel to Shandong, Yu said.

In May, a group of more than 400 Shandong tourists will visit Taiwan via the mini links -- direct ferry services between Xiamen Port in China's Fujian Province and the Taiwan-held Kinmen Island, he said. The group of Shandong tourists will travel to Xiamen by train, he added.

In an effort to further promote tourism exchanges between Taiwan and Shandong Province, representatives from the Taipei-based Travel Quality Assurance Association, along with 10 city and county tourism associations and six tour agencies, signed a cooperation accord with Shandong tourism representatives from 10 cities and six travel agencies in Shandong.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, falling NT$0.123 to close at NT$33.777.
A total of US$1.278 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.900 and fluctuated between NT$33.725 and NT$33.920.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices close at 6-month high on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices rose 4.11 percent to a six-month high Thursday, following gains on Wall Street and regional markets.
The weighted index, the market's key barometer, advanced 224.24 points to close at 5,667.80, on the government's bid to promote tourism and expand warming ties with China.
Recouping a 2.39 percent fall in the previous session, the local bourse opened at 5,532.99 and fluctuated between 5,667.80 and 5,526.13.
A total of 7.00 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$144.84 billion (US$4.29 billion).
The Taiwan stock market has gained more than 20 percent since late last year, making it by far one of the strongest major Asian markets.

All the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial stocks moving up the most at 5.6 percent. Textile issues advanced 5.3 percent, foodstuff shares gained 4.7 percent, cement stocks rose 4.6 precent, construction stocks surged 4.4 percent, machinery and electronics shares rose 4.0 percent, plastics and chemicals shares climbed 3.7 percent, and paper and pulp issues closed up 2.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,889 to 320, with 52 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$11.04 billion.

An analyst predicted that the market could test the 6,300-point level in the near future on optimism that Taiwan's economy may rebound after the second quarter and that a long-anticipated financial supervision agreement will be signed between Taiwan and China before the middle of the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cyclists biking on Yushan to promote it as one of seven wonders

TEXT.P: In the latest twist to an ongoing campaign to get Taiwan's Jade Mountain or Yushan listed as one of the world's seven natural wonders, 24 cyclists from around the country are biking on the tallest mountain on the island.

According to the Yushan National Park Headquarters, the cyclists launched the tour Wednesday, and are expected to complete the 185-kilometer route by Friday, after going up one of Taiwan's most challenging mountain trails.
The park headquarters organized the cycling activity in an effort to boost the international image of the tallest peak in northeast Asia, which reaches 3,952 meters.

Park rangers said that the cyclists, including Cheng Huai, the Taiwanese athlete who will participate in the cycling events in the 21st Deaflympics Taipei 2009 slated for Sept. 5-16, set off from the national park's Nan-an tourist center in Hualien County, eastern Taiwan.

They will ride on the challenging South Cross-Island Highway -- one of the major roads that bridges the southern and eastern parts of Taiwan -- and the new Cross-Island Highway, before arriving at the national park headquarters in Shueili Township of Nantou County, central Taiwan.

Park Headquarters Deputy Director Wu Hsiang-chien said Wednesday that the riders entered the South Cross-Island Highway from Chihshang and Haiduan townships in Taitung County, southeastern Taiwan, earlier in the day. They will then climb to the highway's highest point of Yakou, at 2,722 meters, before descending to the national park's Meishan tourist center.
It is not possible to bike all the way up to Yushan's 3,952-meter peak due to the lack of bike trails.
On Thursday and Friday, the group will ride on the Alishan highway in Chiayi County and the new Cross-Island Highway to complete the cycling activity in Nantou, Wu said.
The cycling challenge is also part of the celebrations for the national park's 24th founding anniversary.

Park officials said they hope the cyclists' enthusiasm, energy and spirit of embracing challenges will be demonstrated to the public, and they hope the activity will help unite Taiwanese people around the goal of bringing Yushan onto the world's stage.
Each of the cyclists are wearing a vest printed with the slogan "Vote for Yushan."
Organizers urged all Taiwanese people to give their support for Yushan, and for Taiwan, by voting online in the global competition.

According to the organizer, the riders come from different social sectors, with some working as either the chairman or general manager of businesses, restaurant chef, or editor-in-chief of a publication. Others work as a professor, photographer, or engineer.
Yushan is currently in first place in the "mountains, volcanoes" category in the contest for the world's new seven natural wonders organized by the Swiss-based New7Wonders Foundation.
The foundation initiated the campaign after organizing the selection of the seven manmade wonders of the world.

In the ongoing second round of the worldwide online voting, 261 natural sites in 222 countries, including Loch Ness in Scotland, the Grand Canyon in Arizona, Mount Fuji in Japan, the Yangtze River in China and Jeju Island in South Korea, are competing in seven categories for the title of the "New Seven Wonders of the Natural World."

Yushan is the only natural attraction from Taiwan to make the list of contenders in any category, and is up against Mount Everest, Mount Fuji, Mount Olympus and K2 Mountain in the mountains and volcanoes category.

The top 11 sites chosen in each of the seven categories by July 7 will then be reviewed by a panel of experts headed by Federico Mayor Zaragoza, former director-general of the United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization (UNESCO), who will select three nominees in each category.

The 21 nominees will be put to the final round of the worldwide online vote in 2010 and 2011 to select the top seven wonders in the landscape, island, mountain, cave, forest, lake and seascape categories.
Yushan, located along the boundaries of Chiayi, Nantou and Kaohsiung counties, is known for its diverse wildlife and ecology.
To boost Yushan's chances of being selected, the national park headquarters urged the public to cast their vote for the mountain by visiting the Web site http://www.new7wonders.com. endtiem/cs

DOC.HEADLINE: Investable assets shrink for 73% of working investors: survey

TEXT.P: The majority of Taiwan office workers with financial investments have suffered losses as a result of the global financial crisis, according to the results of a survey released Thursday by the online employment broker 1111 Job Bank.
The survey, conducted among 1,413 office workers between March 27 and April 7, found that 36.16 percent of the respondents have invested in financial products over the past six months.
Some 73.1 percent of these investors complained about shrinkage of their investable assets, saying that their wealth has contracted by 42.46 percent on average.
Only 7.03 percent of the investors have made profits, while 14.48 percent have broken even on their investments, and 5.48 percent are unaware of their investment outcomes, according to the poll.

The poor investment performance, however, has not dampened the workers' interest in financial investment, as nearly 77 percent of respondents indicated their intention to continue investment in the next six months.
Some 20.24 percent said they would take an aggressive approach, as opposed to 30.29 percent who planned to be more conservative.

In addition, the survey revealed that 55.27 percent of workers have developed an interest in acquiring investment know-how, in light of the financial crisis. Those with full-time jobs and those who have not been affected by the furlough policy are showing greater interest than others, the results indicated.
The survey also found that workers are taking a more proactive attitude toward continuing studies, amid the economic downturn.
Nearly 66 percent of the respondents are engaged in continuing studies, up 19.13 percent from October 2008 when a similar survey was conducted.

Regarding the objectives that the respondents are trying to achieve, the poll showed that 62.83 percent wish to enhance their professional skills, 58.32 percent hope to improve their employment opportunities, and 49.08 percent want to develop a second area of expertise.
More than 43 percent of the respondents are focusing on studies on information literacy and computer know-how, and approximately 37 percent are concentrating on technical skills and personal talent.

However, nearly 60 percent of the workers engaged in continuing studies have reduced their spending in this regard because of the weak economy, with their spending for this purpose averaging NT$5,159 per month.

Self-study -- the option that costs the least money -- has become the most popular choice, favored by 46.61 percent of the workers, according to the survey. The second-most popular choice is enrolling in programs provided by private educational institutions or cram schools -- an option that is favored by 35.11 percent of workers.
Attending speeches or lectures was the next most popular choice, with 31.21 percent of workers opting for this route.
Registering in university continuing studies programs, which was the top choice in October, has now dropped to fifth place due to high costs, with 23.2 percent of the workers choosing this option.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung to cut foreign workers as unemployment rises to 6%

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government pledged Thursday to cut back on the number of foreign laborers working in the city and save those jobs for locals, as the city's unemployment rate is estimated to have climbed past the national 5.75 percent average to break the 6 percent mark.
City Director of Labor Affairs Chung Kung-chao made the statement after a city councilor, Lin Kuo-cheng, expressed concern over rising unemployment in the southern Taiwan port city.

Quoting statistics from the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs and the city's Bureau of Labor Affairs, Lin said that the average national effective employment rate among people seeking jobs was 38 percent in 2008, while in Kaohsiung the figure was only 27 percent.
In February, the effective employment rate among job seekers in Kaohsiung fell to 10 percent, also much lower than the national average of 22 percent for that month, he said.

The figures show that there are fewer work opportunities in Kaohsiung than in the northern part of the island, Lin said, urging the city bureau to take measures to protect the employment rights of local citizens.

At the City Council, Chung pointed out that the city's jobless population was 33,000 at the end of last year, and that as of February this year the number had risen by 9,000. This means that the unemployment rate may have exceeded 6 percent, he added.
There are currently some 706,000 working people in the port city, Chung said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan takes part in Shanghai world travel fair
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/09 19:22:23 (By Chiao Hsing-hua and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan tourism delegation is taking part in the World Travel Fair 2009 in Shanghai, which is being held April 9-11 at the Shanghai New International Expo Center.

The Taiwan delegation, led by hotelier Stanley Yen, honorary chairman of the Taiwan Visitors Association, is composed of several government officials, chiefs of local governments and executives of 37 Taiwanese travel agencies and hotels.
Shanghai Deputy Mayor Zhao Wen paid a visit to the Taiwan pavilion soon after the opening of the Shanghai World Travel Fair, at which she officiated.
During talks with Zhao, Yen said that a majority of mainland Chinese people still have an outdated impression that Taiwan's only attractions are Sun Moon Lake and Alishan.
In fact, he said, Taiwan has other rich tourism resources, such as quality hotspring resorts, gourmet food, cycling tours and related facilities, its aboriginal cultures and an exquisite tea culture.

Noting that Chinese sightseers are just beginning to visit Taiwan in large numbers, Yen said Taiwan's target of attracting one million Chinese tourists per year could be exceeded. The number could reach 3 million or even 5 million a year if Taiwan's tourism industry operators continue to improve the quality of their products, said Yen, who is known as the godfather of Taiwan's hotel service industry and is president of the Landis Hotels and Resorts group.

Also speaking on the same occasion, Hualien County Magistrate Hsieh Shen-shan suggested that mainland Chinese tourists should stay for at least one night in Hualien if they visit the Pacific coast of Taiwan.
"Only by making overnight visits can the tourists savor the quality and attractions of Hualien," Hsieh said.

It is the first time that the Taiwan Visitors Association is leading a Taiwan delegation to the Shanghai World Travel Fair, which has been a major indicator of the development of China's outbound travel industry.
In the past, Taiwan travel industry operators have participated in the Shanghai fair on their own.

Kuo Su Tsan-yang, deputy director-general of the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, is also attending the fair in his capacity as an adviser to the Taiwan Visitors Association.

DOC.HEADLINE: Executive Yuan unveils tourism-boosting plan

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan approved an ambitious tourism expansion project Thursday in its regular weekly meeting, with the aim of turning Taiwan into a tourism hub in East Asia that could generate NT$550 billion (US$16.5 billion) in tourism revenue in four years on a planned budget of NT$30 billion.
Premier Liu Chao-shiuan instructed government agencies to cooperate fully in the program, which the government estimates will help create 400,000 jobs by 2012.
Speaking after the meeting, Tourism Bureau Director-General Janice Lai said the program will capitalize on upgrading travel quality in Taiwan to lure more foreign tourists from around the world.

Through a NT$30 billion fund dedicated to promoting local tourism, Lai said, the government hopes to rack up NT$550 billion in tourism revenue by 2012, with some NT$300 billion contributed by foreign tourists and the remaining NT$250 billion generated from domestic travelers.
In addition to U.S. and European tourists, Lai said, visitors from countries such as China and India, as well as countries in the Middle East and Southeast Asia, will be targeted in the program.
The government hopes to achieve 4.1 million foreign tourist arrivals for 2009, 4.5 million in 2010, 5 million in 2011 and 5.5 million in 2012, she elaborated.

As part of the government's marketing program, the Tourism Bureau will divide the country into four major regions featuring different themes in an effort to cater to the different tastes of the tourists from around the world, according to Lai.
To promote northern Taiwan, the bureau will feature lifestyle aspects such as the arts, pop music and fashion, she said.
Tea and flower gardens will be main focus of the bureau when it introduces central Taiwan regions, while historic monuments will be the major attraction in its efforts to promote southern Taiwan.

The slow pace of life in eastern Taiwan will be capitalized on with an emphasis on cycle tours and the cultures of indigenous tribes in the area, Lai continued, adding that the offshore counties of Penghu and Kinmen will be promoted as international resort islands and as the location of Cold War military relics, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: No safety concerns from radioactive leakage at university: AEC

TEXT.P: There are no safety concerns resulting from the leakage of radioactive material at a northern Taiwan university described by the Atomic Energy Council (AEC) as minimal, an AEC official said Thursday.
"The amount of the released radiation is far below the allowable level, " the official said, although he conceded that the level is higher than it has been in the past.

"The AEC has demanded that National Tsing Hua University makes a complete report on the situation within two weeks and also that it makes improvements so that the same thing does not happen again, " the official said.

He noted that during a regular check of the Hsinchu City university in February for radioactivity levels in the fourth quarter of 2008, the council noticed that the iodine-131 levels in the grass and trees sampled around the production facility for the radioactive isotope were slightly higher than previously recorded figures.
The council therefore alerted the university and told it to conduct checks and find out the reasons for the changes.

The council sent officials to the university in late March to learn more about the situation and found that in order to increase its iodine-131 production, the facility had modified its production process so that minimal levels of iodine-131 were not absorbed by the activated carbon used in the manufacturing process but were instead released into the atmosphere.
Iodine-131, also called radio iodine, is an iodine radioisotope that has various medical and pharmaceutical uses.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC head to attend opposition state of nation conference

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said Thursday that she will attend a forthcoming conference organized by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) on the state of the nation.

Lai, Taiwan's top China policy planner, said that "the administration will not be absent" from the meeting slated for April 11, which is described by the organizers as an "overall check-up of the Ma Ying-jeou administration's China- tilted policy, " with Taiwan's plans to sign an economic cooperation framework agreement with China tabled as the centerpiece of the gathering.

Meanwhile, Lai is scheduled to meet with executives of companies in Taiwan's 10 largest traditional manufacturing industries Friday to gain a better understanding of their development issues and possible coping measures.
The delegates will represent the towel, footwear, ceramics, underwear, hosiery, luggage, general garments, swimwear, tea and bedlinen industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Third round of cross-strait talks to take place in Nanjing

TEXT.P: The third round of talks between top negotiators from both sides of the Taiwan Strait will be held in the Chinese city of Nanjing "barring accidents, " the spokesman for the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Thursday.
MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun said the two sides have both expressed hope that the talks will take place in a city other than the Chinese capital of Beijing.

He made the remarks at a press conference on the most recent visit to Shanghai by Kao Koong-lian, vice chairman and secretary-general of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , to arrange for the third meeting since last June between SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and his Chinese counterpart, Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).
Kao, accompanied by his deputy Kao Wen-cheng, went to Shanghai Wednesday and returned the following day.

Liu said Kao was tasked with discussing procedural problems with ARATS officials and to gain more understanding of the progress of talks between the two intermediary bodies in terms of technical issues.
Judging by the progress to date, the two bodies still need to communicate with each other on certain technical problems, including the exact date of the high- profile Chiang-Chen meeting

MAC Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said earlier in the week that in view of the continued improvement in cross-strait ties, the third round of high-level cross- strait talks will be held in May, ahead of schedule.

Asked about the issue of a proposed cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement -- a topic of great concern -- Liu said it is expected to be discussed during the upcoming Chiang-Chen meeting.
Chiang and Chen met twice last year and signed six critical agreements on the launch of direct charter flights, shipping and postal links, and the expansion of tourism exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: TFT-LCD panel uptake expected to rise in Q2

TEXT.P: The global uptake of thin film transistor liquid crystal display (TFT-LCD) panels is expected to regain near full capacity in the second half of this year owing to increasing demand, a display market research and consulting firm forecast Thursday.

With uptake having dropped to around 70 percent since the start of the global economic downturn in the final quarter of 2008, it is likely that it will rise to 80 percent in the second quarter of 2009 and further to 90 percent in the second half of the year, said David Hsieh, vice president of the Greater China Market at DisplaySearch, during the 2009 Taiwan FPD International Conference in Taipei.

DisplaySearch statistics show that global shipments of large-area TFT-LCD panels totaled 29.5 million units in February, up 23 percent from the previous month, with revenue rising 14 percent month-on-month to reach US$2.96 billion.
Both figures represent the first positive monthly growth since September 2008, due mainly to increasing rush orders and inventory refills from clients, according to DisplaySearch.
The growth could be an indication that the TFT-LCD industry is at, or near, the bottom of a cycle, the company said.
Taiwan, which shipped 44 percent of the world's large-area panels in 2008, plans to increase shipments by 12 percent in 2009, DisplaySearch data shows.

Hsieh predicted that China will become an important market for Taiwan's TFT-LCD panel sector this year, thanks to that country's latest economic stimulus measures to encourage home appliance purchases by rural consumers.

The phase-out of traditional cathode ray tube (CRT) television sets -- which presently number 150 million units worldwide -- also bodes well for a promising market for the TFT-LCD sector in the coming years, Hsieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Numerous health insurance fraud cases cracked in southern Taiwan

TEXT.P: Dozens of medical institutions and professionals in southern Taiwan were found of defrauding more than NT$70 million (US$2.09 million) from the National Health Insurance program in over 100,000 cases in an investigation conducted during the first three months of this year, a spokesman for the Tainan Public Prosecutors Office said Thursday.

Although almost all the cases occurred in Tainan and Kaohsiung cities, the spokesman said, they represent only "the tip of the iceberg" in the widespread problem of fraud against the insurance system by medical institutions in the country.

Those accused of being involved in the insurance fraud cases include the Department of Health (DOH) -governed Tainan Hospital Hsinhua Branch, 10 private clinics, five pharmaceutical stores and about 70 nursing homes, as well as two clinic owners, 19 medical doctors, seven pharmacists, and four medical service brokers, according to the spokesman.
The Tainan District Court granted a prosecutors' request to detain 12 suspects. Fourteen others have been released on bail, the spokesman added.

During raids of the medical institutions, investigators removed a batch of patient records and questioned 22 people, including nine physicians at the DOH Tainan Hospital, the first time a public hospital was suspected to have been involved in fraud, according to the spokesman.

The nine medical professionals, including three active executives and six former physicians at the hospital, were suspected of colluding with scores of local nursing homes to defraud the national health care program of NT$30 million between 2006 and 2008 by issuing a large number of chronic illness prescription refill slips, according to spokesman.

The nine doctors have been released on NT$800,000-NT$1 million bail after admitting to committing fraud, the spokesman said. They had claimed they were under pressure to reach their business targets set by the hospital to avoid being fired, the spokesman added.

However, the hospital issued a statement Thursday denying that it had pressed doctors to meet revenue objectives, adding that some of the accused were contracted doctors and were unlikely to be under work performance pressure.
Using fake prescriptions is a common fraud practice against the national health insurance system, the spokesman added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Micron will not cooperate with TMC, wants government support

TEXT.P: U.S.-based Micron Technology Inc., a leading DRAM technology provider, will not cooperate with Taiwan Memory Co. (TMC) , but looks forward to more support from Taiwan's government, corporate executives said Thursday.

Micron authorized the company's representative, Fred Fishburn, and Charles Kao, president of Inotera Memories Inc. -- a cooperative partner of both Micron and Nanya Technology Corp. -- to make the announcement.

Kao told a news conference that after a comprehensive assessment, Micron has decided not to cooperate with TMC, a company Taiwan's government is planning to set up in collaboration with local and foreign business groups to revamp the country's struggling dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chip industry.
According to Kao, Micron has decided instead to further reinforce its long-term cooperation with Nanya Technology and Inotera Memories in research and development of advanced DRAM technology.
Micron has long been a key technology provider for Nanya and Inotera, both of which are affiliates of the giant Formosa Plastics Group.
Kao said Micron hopes the government will give the Micron-Nanya-Inotera alliance the same level of support as it would have given to a Micron-TMC venture.
Responding to Micron's announcement, TMC's appointed Convener John Hsuan said he respects the company's decision.

Economics Minister Yiin Chii-ming also said the ministry respects Micron's decision and that if the Micron-Nanya-Inotera alliance needs the government's assistance, it can present a concrete plan to the Ministry of Economic Affairs for evaluation.
Meanwhile, Nanya Technology Chairman Wu Chia-chau said the Micron -Nanya-Inotera alliance fully complies with TMC's goal of helping local DRAM manufacturers acquire core technologies.

"So we are hopeful that the government will make the best use of our resources to consolidate the domestic DRAM industry and that in the process, will offer the same treatment to our alliance as it gives to TMC," Wu added.
According to Wu, Nanya Technology began to invest in the development of DRAM production technologies eight years ago in cooperation with IBM.
"Over the past eight years, we have injected NT$40 billion in R&D funds and built up a certain level of technological proficiency, " Wu noted.
Moverover, he went on, Nanya Technology has signed a 10-year technological cooperation pact with Micron on an equal footing and will use Inotera as a joint research platform.

Reaffirming the company's commitment to the continued development of sophisticated DRAM technologies, Wu said both Nanya Technology and Inotera will increase their capital in the near future to improve their financial status.
He stressed that the alliance is not seeking a government bailout. "What we need is the government's assistance in the development of DRAM core technologies," he added.
