According to Fishburn, Micron decided against an alliance with TMC mainly because it feared that such a partnership could erode its technological superiority by exposing its secrets to Elpida, a Japanese company which has agreed to cooperate with TMC.
Taiwan's six DRAM makers have suffered from a supply glut as the global economic slump has sapped demand for electronics and machinery run with semiconductors.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs proposed the establishment of TMC in the hope that it will focus on technological development to help local chipmakers compete with their South Korean counterparts, aided by technology from American and Japanese makers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan will continue to bar Chinese garlic imports: food agency

TEXT.P: Denying allegations that some 30 percent of the garlic sold in Taiwan originates from China, the Agriculture and Food Agency (AFA) said Thursday that there have been no legal imports of garlic from there.
In fact, said AFA Secretary-General Hsu Han-ching, most of the foreign garlic sold here is imported from Argentina.
Hsu added that even if Taiwan signs an economic cooperation framework agreement with China in the near future, the country will still not open its doors to Chinese garlic.
"Our policy of restricting imports of Chinese garlic and protecting the rights of local farmers will remain unchanged, " Hsu said.
He told garlic farmers not to be fooled by lies by traders alleging that some 30 percent of Taiwan's garlic is imported from China, which he described as being aimed at driving down prices.

He noted that nationwide, the amount of land given over to garlic totaled 5,477 hectares this year, 429 hectares less than last year, with total annual production expected to top 48,800 tons -- a 10 percent decrease year-on-year.

Despite the decrease, local garlic can almost meet annual demand -- which averages about 50,000 tons per year -- he went on, adding that the agency allows the import of a small amount of garlic, mainly from Argentina, to ensure that supply fully meets demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for April 10, 2009

TEXT.P: The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open sharply higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened sharply higher Friday, moving up 117.10 points at 5,784.90 on a turnover of NT$6.96 billion (US$206.06 million).
The weighted price index gained 224.24 points, or 4.11 percent, to close at 5,667.80 Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Friday, trading NT$0.035 higher at NT$33.812 at 10:30 a.m. on the Taipei Foreign Exchange.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 10, or the 15th day of the third month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1512: James V of Scotland, who became king at the age of 17 months, is born. He allied Scotland with France against the English.
1810: Pirate chieftainess "Dragon Lady" Cheng Yi-sao surrenders herself and the 1,800 junks under her command to China's Ching court.
1814: British and Spanish forces defeat Napoleon's army at the Battle of Toulouse, leading to his abdication and exile to the island of Elba the next day.
1829: William Booth, the British religious leader who founded the Salvation Army with his wife Catherine Mumford Booth and who served as its first general, is born.
1847: Hungarian-born American journalist Joseph Pulitzer is born. The newspaper publisher owned newspapers in St. Louis and New York City and established and endowed the Pulitzer Prizes for achievements in journalism and literature.
1858: Chinese Governor-General Ye Ming-chen of Canton and a prisoner of Britain, dies in Calcutta during an Anglo-French expedition against Beijing in 1858.
1898: France obtains concessions from China's Ching court.
1921: Dr. Sun Yat-sen is elected president of the Republic of China.
1932: German general and politician Paul von Hindenburg is re-elected president of the Weimar Republic with 19 million votes to Adolf Hitler's 13 million. He appoints Hitler chancellor in 1933.
1938: More than 99 percent of Austrian voters in a referendum cast their ballots in favor of a merger with Germany.
1944: Brigadier General Charles de Gaulle, who is number one on the hit list of the collaborationist Vichy government of Marshal Petain, becomes commander-in- chief of all the Free French forces.
1946: Japan holds general elections with women voting for the first time.
1953: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the resignation of Taiwan Governor Wu Kuo- chen and names Yu Hung-chun as his replacement.
1958: Dr. Hu Shih assumes office as president of the ROC's Academia Sinica.
1960: The U.S. Senate passes the Civil Rights Bill.
1963: The USS Thresher, an American atomic submarine, sinks in the northern Atlantic, killing all 290 aboard.
1971: Ethnic Chinese hold a mass rally in Washington, D.C., to show their support for the protection of a disputed territory known to the Chinese as the Tiaoyutai Islands.
1972: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the establishment of diplomatic relations with the Kingdom of Tonga.
1972: The United States and the Soviet Union sign a treaty banning biological warfare.
1976: Miguel Urrutia Montoya, director of the national planning department of the Republic of Colombia, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1979: U.S. President Jimmy Carter signs legislation permitting continued commercial and cultural relations between the American government and the ROC following the break in their diplomatic ties.
1980: Mainland China and the Soviet Union end a friendship pact they signed in 1950.
1983: U.S. President Ronald Reagan's Middle East peace plan collapses when King Hussein of Jordan fails to reach an accord with the Palestine Liberation Organization on the terms of the deal.
1986: The United States conducts a nuclear test in the Nevada desert.
1991: Georgia becomes the latest of the Soviet republics wishing to break away from central control.
1996: Mainland Chinese Premier Li Peng's visit to France is marred by a diplomatic wrangle with his French counterpart Alain Juppe over human rights in Beijing.
2000: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui confers the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on David Dean, former Taipei director of the American Institute in Taiwan.
2001: The 13th annual convention of the Overseas Chinese Council in Asia opens in Osaka, Japan, with more than 400 delegates from the Asia-Pacific region participating.
2002: Vice President Annette Lu wins a civil suit against the Taipei-based Journalist weekly, for damage to her image arising from a false report carried by the magazine.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who possesses moral worth will always have something to say worth listening to, but a man who has something to say is not necessarily a man of moral worth."

DOC.HEADLINE: State-run airport company to be set up in 2010

TEXT.P: A state-run company is expected to be set up in 2010 that will own and operate the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, a step that the government hopes will enhance the airport's efficiency and competitiveness, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said Friday.

CAA Director-General Lee Long-wen explained that the establishment of the company is aimed at introducing corporate management to the airport's operation, noting that similar formats have been adopted in countries such as the Netherlands, Japan and South Korea.
An important component of the proposed Taoyuan aerotropolis project, the company will manage a compound covering 1,800 hectares once the project is completed, Lee said.
To pave the way for the establishment of the company, the Cabinet approved Thursday a draft law governing the organization of the company.
The bill will be forwarded to the Legislative Yuan for review and enactment.
The plan to develop the area surrounding the airport into an aviation city is one of the "i-Taiwan 12 Projects, " a centerpiece of the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou.

The project -- set to be completed in 2020 -- would involve the expansion of the existing airport terminals and the establishment of an aerospace industrial park and special zones for cargo, passenger and logistics services.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Peace agreement with China next step: former envoy to U.S.

TEXT.P: Signing a peace agreement with China will be the next step for Taiwan and China to advance the warming relations and consolidate them for the long term, although it will take a long time to achieve such a pact, a former representative to the United States said Friday.

"We talked about economic and trade agreements, and financial cooperation will be next. The next thing after that will be a peace agreement, but it will take a long time," said Stephen S.F. Chen, who is now a national policy advisor to President Ma Ying-jeou.
"The so-called confidence-building measures (CBMs) will be beyond a peace agreement," he added.

Chen made the remarks in response to a reporter's comment that there seems to be some concern in Washington about possible military exchanges between Taiwan and China, as the issue of CBMs has been raised more and more often recently.

The senior diplomat said that a peace agreement between both sides of the Taiwan Strait will come before the establishment of CBMs because only Taiwan unilaterally terminated its civil war with China.
"They still think the civil war is not over. That is why the peace agreement is necessary. But a peace agreement does not necessarily include CBMs," he said.

Chen contended that a hotline between military commanders on the Taiwan- controlled island of Kinmen and nearby Xiamen City in China should be established in the first stage of building up cross-strait CBMs because small incidents could trigger war.
"Small steps in reducing tension, such as a hotline between the frontline commanders, may be a necessity in order to avoid any misunderstanding or any mishaps," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to redevelop scenic spots to promote tourism

TEXT.P: The government will choose in May five scenic spots around the country that have the potential to attract international tourists, and each will be given NT$300 million (US$8.88 million) for redevelopment over two years, Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo said Thursday.

As part of a tourism-boosting plan unveiled that day, the government plans to develop at least 10 of the most attractive scenic spots around Taiwan with international appeal, the first five of which will be unveiled during the initial stage, according to Mao.
He said each county can apply for the subsidies by mid-April by proposing tourist destinations that have development value and have the potential to attract investment.

The tourism-stimulation plan aims to generate over the next four years NT$550 billion (US$16.3 billion) in tourism revenue, create 400,000 jobs in the tourism industry, attract private investment worth NT$200 billion and bring in 10 world famous hotel chains.

So far, three of the 10 hotel chains have decided to set up operations, or have already begun operating in Taiwan, including Le Meridien hotel group, which is scheduled to open its first hotel in Taiwan in early 2011 in Taipei's Hsinyi district. The first Marriott hotel in Taiwan, which is located in Taipei's Neihu district, and the Novotel Taoyuan International Airport Taipei, which will open later this year, according to a Tourism Bureau official.
Japan's famous Kagaya hot spring hotel has also shown great interest in venturing into Taipei's Beitou district, the official went on.

The government plans to earmark NT$30 billion for the plan in four years until 2012, with NT$3 billion coming from the Tourism Development Fund each year and the rest coming from the treasury, according to Mao.
He added that an estimated NT$18.7 billion will be used for a tourism flagship program and for upgrading specific tourist spots around the country.

Meanwhile, to strengthen the country's tourism competitiveness, the government will spend NT$2 billion on tourism industry transformation and talent cultivation, and another NT$9.3 billion on increasing added value in the industry, the minister added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ties with China will not affect Taiwan Relations Act: ex-envoy

TEXT.P: The United States' Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) , which reached its 30th anniversary Friday, will remain unchanged for a long time despite the warming cross-Taiwan Strait relations, a former representative to the United States said that day.

Stephen S.F. Chen, who now serves as a national policy advisor to President Ma Ying-jeou and as convener of the non-government National Policy Foundation (NPF) , made the remarks after hosting a NPF news conference to announce its holding of an international conference April 12 on a retrospective of the TRA and its prospects.
"This particular legislation, the TRA, is the only domestic law of the U.S. that covers its relations with Taiwan, so I think it's going to last for a long time," Chen said.
Enacted by the U.S. Congress April 10, 1979, the TRA has been the sole legal document on the part of the United States governing bilateral relations.

The act requires the U.S. to guarantee defensive arms sales to Taiwan and to maintain the capacity of the U.S. to resist any resort to force or other forms of coercion that would jeopardize the security, or the social or economic system, of the people of Taiwan. It does not require the U.S. to intervene militarily if the People's Republic of China attacks or invades Taiwan.
Asked whether he thinks the U.S. will make any adjustments to the TRA due to concern about the warming relations between Taiwan and China, the senior diplomat said he sees no such tendency.
Chen noted that some people have the misguided notion that since Taiwan is now warming up to China, relations between Taiwan and the U.S. are cooling off.

He said despite the fact that Taiwan is improving relations with China, it still thinks ties with the U.S. are the most important facet of its foreign relations and that Washington remains the country's most important friend.
"This development (between Taiwan and China) does not in any way endanger relations between the Republic of China and the U.S. They can co-exist without any problem," Chen said.

As part of the celebration of the 30th anniversary of the passage of the TRA, the NPF and the non-government Cross-Strait Interflow Prospect Foundation will host the April 12 conference in which more than 300 government officials, dignitaries and political experts from home and abroad will look back at the act and inspire new thoughts on how to enhance U.S.-Taiwan relations.

In addition to President Ma Ying-jeou and Deputy Foreign Minister Andrew Hsia, other participants will include Winston Lord, former assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, Douglas Paal, former director of the American Institute in Taiwan Taipei Office, and Alan Romberg, former principal deputy director of the U.S. State Department's Policy Planning Staff. ENDITEM/J Taiwan's ties with China not to affect Taiwan Relations Act: ex-envoy

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of smoking violation complaints tops 400

TEXT.P: More than 400 complaints about violations of the smoking ban have been filed with the anti-smoking John Tung Foundation over the past three months since the ban was put into force, foundation officials said Friday.

Of the total of 436 complaints received as of April 7, 72 percent involved private workplaces, Internet cafes, office buildings, billiard parlors, toilets, restaurants, universities and colleges, shrimp fishing clubs, hospitals, government agencies, karaoke parlors and even hookah bars, said Yau Sea-wain, president of the foundation.

Lin Ching-li, director of the foundation's tobacco hazards prevention division, said that cases of employees complaining about their employers or supervisors smoking in their offices were the most common at the beginning of the ban, but he added that there has been an increasing number of complaints about smoking in Internet cafes recently.
Lin said the situation could be an indication that Internet cafe operators are relaxing their attention to the ban.

Among the complaints received by the foundation is a case in which a direct selling company has posted a cigarette advertisement on its Web site, displaying the brand, picture and price of the product and including a description that encourages smoking among women.

According to Lin, that case is being investigated by the health authorities in the southern city of Tainan and the company will face a fine of up to NT$25 million (US$741,839) if the offense is established as having occurred.
Another pending case is one in which a tobacco importer has been giving away bonus cards to consumers of seven of its cigarette products.
Yau said the promotional activity is obviously targeting young people and added that if each of the products is considered an individual offense, the importer can be fined a minimum of NT$35 million.
The ban, which took effect Jan. 11, is considered a major step by Taiwan toward its goal of becoming a smoke-free country.

Under the terms of the ban, smoking is not allowed on public transport or in the indoor areas of most public premises, including roofed transport stations, KTV parlors, Internet cafes, comic-book stores and offices manned by three or more people.
Smoking in prohibited areas can result in fines of up to NT$10,000 for the offender and NT$50,000 for the owner of the establishment in which the offense takes place.
The new law requires that prominent "no smoking" signs be posted at the entrances of such establishments and allows for fines of up to NT$30,000 for owners who fail to comply.

Vendors are not allowed to sell cigarettes to people under 18 years of age, to display cigarettes on shelves that are accessible to consumers, or to sell cigarettes from automatic vending machines, all of which are offenses that can result in fines of up to NT$50,000.

Cigarette advertisements and cigarette promotional activities are also banned, with fines for violators set at a maximum of NT$500,000 for vendors, NT$25 million for cigarette companies and NT$1 million for the advertising media involved.

DOC.HEADLINE: American auto parts retailer to open Asian sourcing base in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Advance Auto Parts, the second largest retailer of automobile parts and accessories in the United States, has decided to establish its Asian sourcing center in Taiwan, expecting that improved links between Taiwan and China will enhance its operational efficiency.
Keven Dempsey, Advance Auto Parts vice president for global sourcing, announced Thursday the company's plan to open its first overseas sourcing center, with the opening slated for May 3.

The planned center will be responsible for sourcing products for the company's more than 3,000 retail outlets in the U.S. and for developing new items, and Advance Auto Parts plans to hire 50 employees in Taiwan within the coming three years to meet those needs, Dempsey said.
The center's operations will cover most of Asia, including China, South Korea and India.

Dempsey said a number of factors made Taiwan attractive, including potential savings in leasing commercial space. The company found that renting office space in Taipei is about 60 percent cheaper than in Hong Kong and 33 percent cheaper than in Shanghai.
He also said Taiwan's executive talent was more stable than similar professionals in China, which will help the company save on personnel costs.

With the recent opening of more convenient trade and transportation links between Taiwan and China, Dempsey said he believes there will be more foreign businesses deciding to set up their regional operations in Taiwan in the future.

Advance Auto Parts, founded in 1932 and headquartered in Roanoke, Virginia, was ranked 476th in the Fortune Global 500 in 2008. It is the 23rd largest specialized retailer in the U.S., with annual sales reaching US$5.1 billion last year.
Advance Auto Parts runs 3,368 stores in the U.S. and plans to open 105 more this year, according to the company.

Dempsey said his company's prospects are bright despite the economic slump, because demand for replacement parts and accessories has been pushed higher by motorists sticking to their old cars rather than replacing them with new ones.

With Advance Auto Parts holding only a 13 percent of the American market in retail store services and a 5 percent share of repair workshops, the company still has considerable space to expand in the automotive aftermarket sector, Dempsey said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan popular among Hong Kong Easter travelers
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 10 (CNA) 04/10/09 16:38:41 (By Stanley Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Despite the global economic downturn, Taiwan is still one of the most popular overseas destinations among Hong Kong vacationers, a local newspaper cited business sources as saying Friday.

The trend has been especially apparent as the four-day Easter weekend begins, with 50 additional flights bound for Taiwan among the 900 flights taking off from and landing at Hong Kong International Airport on Friday, the first day of the Easter holiday.
A travel agent was quoted by Ta Kung Pao as saying that the number of outbound tour groups during the holiday had increased by 20 percent compared to last year.
"Cheaper tour fees were the main reason behind the growth in overseas travel during the holiday period," the travel agent said.

Given a boost by the film "Cape No. 7, " which was filmed in the popular beach resort of Kenting in the southern part of the island, Taiwan has become one of the most popular overseas destinations among Hong Kong travelers, along with Thailand, Japan and Beijing.
Aside from Kenting, Taichung in central Taiwan and Tainan in the south are other popular destinations in Taiwan among Hong Kong vacationers, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taitung County farmers hurt by low demand for oranges

TEXT.P: Farmers in eastern Taitung County are concerned about plummeting demand for their orange varieties and fear it will put their businesses at risk, the local farmers' association said Friday.
Association officials said orders for the farmers' tangerines and Valencia oranges have fallen by some 70 percent, dealing a severe blow to their livelihoods.

"Sluggish business conditions have pushed many buyers, even those who are long- term customers, to cancel their orders, " an association official said, attributing the problem to low consumer demand due to the floundering economy.
While Valencia oranges are normally in short supply, Taitung County farmers had a bumper crop of 370,000 kilograms this spring because of the mild weather in recent months.

Yet farmers have had no cause to celebrate, as half the fruit remains unharvested on their farms, and prices for the fruit has fallen to NT$100 (US$3) for 3.5 kgs., said Donghe farmers' association officials.
"Even at that price, it is hard to sell all of them," an official lamented.
To help relieve pressure on farmers, the Taitung County Government announced it will organize promotional sales of the fruit in city centers on the last two weekends of this month.
It will also ask local schools to buy the fruit to serve as part of students' school lunches.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's magazine industry heading to London to tout its strength

TEXT.P: Representatives of Taiwan's "small but beautiful" magazine industry are heading to London in early May for an international forum at which they plan to present the industry's strength as a leading force in the Chinese-language world.
They also hope to learn what they can from their international partners on how to survive the ongoing global economic slump.

Yu Kuo-ting, chairman of the Magazine Business Association of Taipei, will lead a delegation to the International Federation of the Periodical Press (FIPP) conference. In a pre-departure interview with the Central News Agency, he said Taiwan's magazine industry is quite advanced in terms of innovation, agenda setting, graphic design and printing capability.
"This is a result of more than 40 years of democratic development in Taiwan, during which its cultural workers have enjoyed freedom of expression and a free market," Yu said.

Though Taiwan's magazine industry enjoys an edge over counterparts from China in the Chinese-language cultural sphere, he said the advantage has been eroded as a growing number of Western magazines seek to establish direct contact with Chinese publications.

To date, however, Western magazines have failed to gain a strong foothold in China, mainly because of cultural barriers that even the Taiwanese find difficult to surmount, Yu said, leaving opportunities for Taiwan's magazine industry to play a key role in Chinese-language communities as China gradually opens up its cultural market.

Taiwan already has a number of successful business models, Yu said, citing The Studio Classroom series of English teaching publications in Taipei, a popular brand that has attracted tens of thousands of Taiwanese keen to learn English through print, audio and video media tools.

Yu also cited CommonWealth Magazine to demonstrate that Taiwan's magazine industry is caring, innovative and forward looking, constantly bringing new ideas and new hopes to its readers and their society.
Even the tabloid-like Next magazine, with its diversified content, can be regarded as a proof that Taiwan has indeed matured into a democratic and multicultural society, he added.

Similar to Taiwan's music industry, whose recordings are highly popular in Chinese cultural circles, the island's magazine industry is a "large gem" and a leading industry that Yu said he believes will shine throughout the world simply by being a vital "life-giving" and "meaning-creating" entity.

Yu, president of the Business Weekly Media Group, said his group's Business Weekly now has a circulation of 160,000 copies in a country of 23 million people, while its United States "counterpart" of a similar title prints 900,000 copies for a population 13 times larger than Taiwan's.
"We may not have the experience of operating in a huge market like China, Japan, Europe and the U.S., but Taiwan's magazine business is 'small but beautiful,'" he said.
Learning to gain a niche in large markets is one of the goals the delegation will try to achieve during and after the May 4-6 FIPP conference in the British capital.
In addition to exchanging ideas with other participants, Yu's group will also visit the BBC, the Haymarket Media Group and the Cambridge University Press.

"We will be focusing our efforts on finding successful business models from British and other nations' media corporations, " he said. "We will look into how they are coping with the fast-changing market, their new ways of doing things and how they are creating value -- in essence how they are trying to satisfy new demands from customers in the digital age."

Yu stressed that Taiwan's magazine publishers are demonstrating unprecedented unity in a concerted effort to find new business opportunities, hoping that like their information technology (IT) counterparts they can play a leading role in the Chinese-language cultural market.
"We are confident that the upcoming London trip will be rewarding not only for the magazine industry itself but also for the customers they aim to serve at home and abroad," he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCKU unveils prototype of convenient breast cancer detector

TEXT.P: Researchers at National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) have successfully developed the world's first pocket-sized breast cancer detector for household use, the university in southern Taiwan's Tainan City announced Friday.
Experiments on human beings may start later this year to pave the way for mass production next year, said Tzeng Yonhua, vice president for research and development at NCKU.
The device, whose size is similar to an iPhone, was invented using near-infrared technology and is intended for the early detection and warning of breast cancer, Tzeng said.
The invention is based on previous achievements by U.S. biophysicist Britton Chance, who is now a distinguished professor in NCKU's Institute of Innovations and Advanced Studies, Tzeng said.
NCKU has focused its research on streamlining the size of the device since taking over the research project two years ago.

Releasing near infrared lights of five to seven different wavelengths to detect potential cancer cells, the device performs non-invasive screening on users, who are not even required to take off their clothes or underwear, Tzeng said.
"The device is especially helpful to women who are too embarrassed to receive screening in hospitals," he said.

Equipped with a liquid crystal display panel and a personal storage disc, the device enables users to store the outcome of the screening and show it to their doctors for further diagnosis if abnormalities are detected, Tzeng said.
He said the technology can also be used to measure brain oxygen levels and blood glucose levels as well as detect pancreatic cancer.

Taiwanese manufacturers have expressed an interest in helping NCKU convert the device's prototype into viable samples, which will be sent to hospitals and medical schools in other countries for testing, Tzeng said.
He said the device is expected to be sold at price of around NT$10,000 (US$280) per unit, making it affordable for most households.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices on Taipei bourse rise to new high for the year

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices rose 2.01 percent on Friday to close at a new high for the year, boosted by hopes that a special budget for a government stimulus package would be passed.
The weighted index, the market's key barometer, advanced 114.16 points to close at 5,781.96, following gains on Wall Street and regional markets.
Taiwan's stock market rose 252.33 points, or 4.56 percent, for the week.
Finishing higher for the second consecutive session, the local bourse opened at 5,784.90 and fluctuated between 5,788.21 and 5,696.56.
A total of 7.95 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$160.14 billion (US$4.74 billion) , the second highest turnover in a session this year.

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction moving up the most at 5.0 percent. Cement shares surged 4.3 percent, banking and financial issues rose 2.7 percent, plastics and chemicals shares gained 1.8 percent, textile issues advanced 1.7 percent, machinery and electronics shares rose 1.1 percent, paper and pulp issues closed up 1.0 percent, and foodstuff shares gained 0.4 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,436 to 727, with 127 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$12.1 billion.
One analyst predicted that the market would sustain its upward moment because of sufficient liquidity even as profit-taking and other pressures try to pull the market lower in the coming days.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, increasing NT$0.018 to close at NT$33.795.
A total of US$645 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.925 and fluctuated between NT$33.709 and NT$33.940.

DOC.HEADLINE: Activists urge halt to sea floor study to protect marine ecosystem

TEXT.P: Animal rights activists on Friday urged the National Science Council (NSC) to revoke a license for an international collaborative project to investigate main seismic structure features of the earth's crust under Taiwan island to avoid causing adverse effects on numerous forms of marine life.
The activists made the appeal during a protest rally in front of the NSC, which sponsored the Taiwan Integrated Geodynamics Research (TAIGER) project.

The earthquake study initiated by the Columbia University-affiliated Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory (L-DEO) is a sea floor investigation project in the exclusive economic zones of Taiwan, China, Japan and the Philippines, according to the conservationists.
They noted that air guns, which will be used under the sea in the study, could produce a noise equivalent to 265 decibels (dB) , and could be a threat to the survival of sharks and dolphins.

The U.S. government launched an environmental impact assessment last December, completed the assessment and established measures aimed at minimizing adverse effects on the marine ecosystem in March, according to the activists.
In comparison, the NSC granted a research permit for the project without getting an understanding of the results of the impact assessment, the conservationists pointed out.

They said the U.S. National Marine Fisheries Service has taken measures to protect white dolphins and grey sharks in the Atlantic Ocean as well as other marine species by stipulating that all investigation boats should keep at least 20 kilometers away from Taiwan's western coast and at least 150 kilometers away from the coast of China and that a sonic boom will only be allowed at a depth of at least 50 meters below the surface of the sea.
That means most sea floor investigation projects would not meet the requirements and should not be allowed to be conducted in the Taiwan Strait economic zone, the activists said.

Pointing out that the NSC convened a review meeting on the project last December, but refused to make public the meeting minutes, the animal protection activists said they should be given a chance to provide relevant information and marine experts should be allowed to express their opinion to the NSC.

In response, an NSC official Cheng Chien-hong said that boats used in the experiment are equipped with safety facilities to protect marine animals and five marine biologists abroad would call a halt to firing an air gun any time they find it would go beyond the noise limit.

Cheng argued the NSC's decision to issue the license was made considering that while dolphins usually swim in waters at least three kilometers away from the coast of Taiwan and that the experiment is conducted at 20 kilometers away from the coast.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung travel fair opens with special offers

TEXT.P: The 2009 Taichung International Travel Fair opened at the Taichung World Trade Center Friday with a wide variety of discount travel packages on offer.

Speaking at the show's opening ceremony, Taichung Deputy Mayor Hsiao Chia-chi said the fair provides a very good opportunity for visitors to find bargains as exhibitors have promised to offer several special package deals to counter the economic downturn.
This year's fair is the largest ever in its 15-year history, with 300 exhibitors and an additional 50 booths outside the venue.

Local and foreign tourism bureaus, airline companies, travel agencies, hotels, holiday resorts, theme parks, cruise liners, and city and county governments have all set up booths and will be providing information and special offers for visitors interested in traveling in Taiwan or abroad.

A large crowd attended the first day of the show in search of deals, and found they had plenty to choose from. Among them: a three-day trip to Hong Kong for NT$5,988 (US$179.28), a three-day trip to Macau for NT$5,566, a five-day trip to Langkawi Island in Malaysia for NT$11,900, a five-day excursion to Beijing for NT$19,000, and a six-day excursion to Australia's Gold Coast for NT$19,800.
Domestic tourism and hotel operators are also offering numerous prize drawings and coupon and discount promotions during the fair, with one of the prizes an NT$800,000 van.
The fair will run until April 13.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health surcharge on cigarettes to double starting June 1

TEXT.P: The health surcharge on tobacco will be increased from NT$10 to NT$20 per pack of cigarettes starting June 1 to discourage smoking and raise funds for the country's health insurance program, Taiwan's top health official said Friday.
Yeh Ching-chuan, minister of the Department of Health, said that the price of a pack of cigarettes is expected to increase by between NT$10 and NT$15 following the increase in the health surcharge.
Currently, a pack of cigarettes sells for NT$55 on average.

Yeh estimated that the surcharge, which currently contributes NT$20 billion a year to government programs, would generate between NT$32 billion and NT$36 billion after the increase, but he said he would not mind if his projection turned out to be too high.
"If more people quit smoking, the government's revenues from the health surcharge will decrease, but this is something the government would love to see," he said.
Yeh indicated that NT$1.4 billion, or about 4 percent of the health surcharge, will be used to help low- and middle-income families pay part of their health insurance premiums.
The DOH will also allocate NT$10 billion to the financially strapped National Health Insurance program.
To avoid confusion and profiteering, cigarette manufacturers will either print or affix a sticker reading "NT$20 health surcharge" on each pack to help differentiate between old and new cigarettes.
Yeh said that starting June 1, tobacco distributors cannot raise the price of cigarettes that do not have the "NT$20 health surcharge" marking, though they can continue to sell them.
Government agencies will monitor the market to prevent distributors from hoarding cigarettes ahead of the June 1 launch date and selling them for a higher profit margin, he added.
"The situation of consumers buying old cigarettes at the price of the new cigarettes will not happen," Yeh pledged.

The John Tung Foundation, an anti-smoking group, recently criticized the DOH for only spending NT$160 million from the surcharge funds to help the public kick the habit of smoking, while shelling out NT$600 million to subsidize tobacco manufacturers to print or affix the new marking.

Yeh replied, however, that the DOH has already received confirmation from four major tobacco manufacturers, including Taiwan Tobacco and Liquor Corp., that they will do the markings themselves at no extra cost to the government.

For small tobacco manufacturers who will affix a sticker to their cigarettes, a subsidy of NT$10 million will be paid by the DOH's Bureau of Health Promotion rather than be taken out of the health surcharges, Yeh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exclusive Taiwan food shop opened in Shanghai
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, April 10 (CNA) 04/10/09 20:52:01 (By M. L. Kuo and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: An exclusive shop for the display and sale of Taiwan's fine food was opened Friday at an outlet of City Shop, an upscale supermarket in Shanghai.

The opening ceremony of the speciality department at the store in the city's Time Square was the first in China ever authorized by Taiwan's semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA).
A large number of customers were drawn to the event and treated to a wide variety of delicious dishes prepared with products imported from Taiwan.

More than 600 items of Taiwan-made foodstuff recommended by TAITRA are being sold at the 120-square meter department, including fruits, ingredients, snacks, beverages, tea, rice, noodles, cookies and daily use items of famous Taiwanese brands.
Chen Chi-tang, a TAITRA official in charge of promoting Taiwanese agricultural products, said a batch of Taiwan-grown mangos are slated to be marketed in the shop in late May.

In the future, TAITRA will introduce more original Taiwanese products, including creative cultural or tourism-related items or handicrafts, into the shop, where Chinese customers can indulge in a refined Taiwanese ambiance, Chen said.

An executive with the City Supermarket Inc., a leading retailer of imported food in Shanghai, said around half of the Taiwanese speciality products being sold at the City Shop are shipped from Taiwan, with the other half purchased from Taiwanese businessmen in Shanghai or Fujian Province.
The opening of the exclusive Taiwanese food shop formed part of the New Zheng He Project launched by the Ministry of Economic Affairs to help expand Taiwan's foreign trade.

Victor Chu, TAITRA's representative in Shanghai, said Thursday the special Taiwanese food store was set up through the joint efforts of the TAITRA- affiliated Taipei World Trade Center and City Shop executives.

According to Chu, the increase in two-way exchanges between Taiwan and mainland China brought about by the wider opening of cross-Taiwan Strait tourism last year has helped to stir Chinese consumers' interest in Taiwan-made foodstuff.
City Shop owns 12 stores in Shanghai and one in Beijing. The Shanghai-based food importer also operates farms, tourism resort parks, coffee factories, bakeries and foreign trade companies.
City Shop began importing Taiwanese food products in 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese tourists' economic contribution to Sun Moon Lake surges

TEXT.P: Chinese tourists injected an estimated NT$90 million (US$2.64 million) into the Nantou County economy in March as the numbers of Chinese visitors to the Sun Moon Lake scenic area surged to a new monthly high.

More than 60,000 visitors from China, including 4,266 employees and salespeople tied to the Chinese branch of U.S. direct sales company Amway, visited Sun Moon Lake in March, an average of 1,982 visits per day, according to statistics released Friday by the Sun Moon Lake National Scenic Area Administration.

The visitor numbers to the popular tourist attraction far surpassed the 19,590 Chinese who visited the area in January and the 17,666 who visited the area in February, the scenic area administration said.
Based on average spending of NT$1,500 a day per Chinese visitor on lodging, dining and shopping, the administration estimated that they injected NT$90 million into the local economy in March.
According to the scenic area administration's study, there are 21 hotels and hostels in Puli and the Sun Moon Lake scenic area that are often used by Chinese tourists.
The average cost to stay at the hotels and hostels, excluding exclusive and luxury hotels, was about NT$1,900 for one night.
The administration also identified 25 restaurants that are often visited by Chinese tourists, and they offered meals averaging around NT$300 per person if the more upscale restaurants are excluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: Keelung Harbor Bureau upbeat over tourism boosting plan

TEXT.P: A tourism boosting plan put forward by the Executive Yuan is expected to help inject new life into Keelung Port in northern Taiwan, Keelung Harbor Bureau Director-General Hsiao Ding-shun said Friday.
Hsiao based his optimism on the prospect that the plan would bring in higher numbers of tourists on cruise ships to Keelung Port -- Taiwan's largest sea port in the north.
According to Hsiao, two foreign cruise lines have projected they will make a total of eight calls at the port this year, bringing a total of 18,000 tourists to northern Taiwan.

Rough estimates indicate that these foreign visitors could contribute NT$120 million (US$3.6 million) in tourism revenue to businesses in the port area, he said, also voicing the hope that a government mega-tourism expansion plan will help bolster businesses in the area.

While figures for 2008 are not yet available, 272,000 passengers arrived in Keelung Port on cruise liners in 2007, or 63.8 percent of the year's total, Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) statistics showed.

A total of 426,000 tourists arrived on cruise liners at all of Taiwan's international ports for the year, an increase of about 111,000 visitors, or a 35.3 percent increase, over the 2006 level, according to the same figures.

On Thursday, the Executive Yuan approved an ambitious tourism expansion project in its regular weekly meeting with the aim of turning Taiwan into a tourism hub in East Asia that could generate NT$550 billion (US$16.5 billion) in tourism revenue in 2012 on a planned budget of NT$30 billion.

Of the total targeted spending, the government anticipates some NT$300 billion of the total will be contributed by foreign tourists from around the world, with the balance generated by domestic travelers.
It also estimates that the plan will help create 400,000 jobs by 2012.
The government hopes to attract 4.1 million foreign traveler arrivals in 2009, 4.5 million in 2010, 5 million in 2011 and 5.5 million in 2012, said Tourism Bureau Director General Janice Lai.

DOC.HEADLINE: Special budget for economic stimulus plan clears legislature

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed a special budget Friday that cleared the way to finance an expanded NT$149.1 billion public works plan, another of several measures the government has adopted to revive Taiwan's sputtering economy.
The final amount authorized in the special budget was NT$1.5 billion less than the NT$150.6 billion that had been approved after the bill's initial screening in a legislature committee.
The special budget will be financed by raising debt and will not be subject to the debt ceiling as set by the Public Debt Act.

The legislature also passed a resolution to authorize the central government to commission townships to execute the special budget to prevent differences in party affiliation between the local and central governments affecting the budget's implementation.

Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party criticized the legislature, in which the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) controls nearly three-quarters of the seats, for circumventing the cities and counties in the use of the special budget.
"This is a blatantly pork-barrel move," Yang contended.
He noted that between 80 percent and 90 percent of the heads of townships around the island are KMT members.
The legislature also suggested that the Executive Yuan prohibit the use of foreign laborers and give priority to indigenous peoples in the public works projects.
The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Friday that after the execution of the special budget, the nation's gross domestic product (GDP) is expected to rise by 0.68 percent.
It will also create between 190,000 and 220,000 jobs, the CEPD estimated.

Covered under the bill are projects to provide comfortable and convenient urban transportation services, fast production and marketing networks, a safe environment and facilities to upgrade the public's quality of life.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government-sponsored job fair series to offer 84,000 openings

TEXT.P: A series of four job fairs to be organized by the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) will kick off Saturday, offering a total of 84,000 job openings, an official said Friday.

"The first two job fairs will take place Saturday in central Taiwan's Taichung City and Hualien City in the eastern part of the country, " CLA Vice Minister Kuo Fang-yu said, adding that the remaining two fairs will be held the following weekend in Taoyuan County in northern Taiwan and in the southern city of Tainan.
The job fairs are part of the CLA's efforts to help increase employment after the country's unemployment rate surged to a record 5.75 percent in February amid the global economic downturn.
In addition to offering 84,000 job openings, Kuo said, the four events will also provide 71,000 openings for individuals to receive training or do research.
"The four job fairs will feature three 'plenties' -- plenty of job opportunities, plenty of display booths and plenty of services, " Kuo said confidently.

Of the 84,000 job openings, 25,000 are in the public sector, including 20,000 openings for volunteer military servicemen, 15,000 are in the private sector, and the remaining 44,000 are research and management jobs at local universities and colleges.
To cater to the needs of job seekers, Kuo said five theme areas will be set up at the fair venues to avoid overcrowding at certaining counters.

The job fair in central Taiwan will feature at least 159 service booths and the events in eastern, northern and southern Taiwan will accommodate 98, 155 and 182 stands, respectively, Kuo said, adding that the fairs are expected to lure an estimated 100,000 job seekers.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Cloud Gate 2' begins 2009 Spring Riot tour

TEXT.P: Cloud Gate 2, the offshoot of the world-renowned Cloud Gate Dance Theatre of Taiwan, kicked off its 2009 Spring Riot tour Friday evening, with a production choreographed by the troupe's founder Lin Hwai-min.
The production Spring Breeze is set to a popular Taiwanese love song. Lin said at a dress rehearsal news conference Friday afternoon that the piece is about youth, confusion and yearning.
The 2009 Spring Riot also features productions created by young choreographers, including Cheng Tsung-lung's new work "The Wall" and Huang Yi's "Flow."
Following its eight performances at Taipei's Novel Hall, Cloud Gate 2 will continue its spring tour in Hsinchu, Taichung and Kaohsiung, for a total of 14 performances.
The Cloud Gate 2, founded in 1999 to nurture a new generation of choreographers, turns 10 this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for April 11, 2009

TEXT.P: The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.
