DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 11, or the 16th day of the April of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1713: France cedes Newfoundland and Gibraltar to Britain.
1775: James Parkinson, the British physician who defined Parkinson's disease, a progressive disease of the nervous system also called paralysis agitans or shaking palsy, is born.
1814: Louis XVIII accedes to the throne as Napoleon Bonaparte abdicates and is banished to the island of Elba under the Treaty of Fontainebleau.
1893: Dean Acheson, the U.S. politician and secretary of state who helped to formulate the Truman Doctrine and the Marshall Plan and who promoted the setting up of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), is born.
1899: Spain transfers control of the Philippines to the United States.
1919: The International Labor Organization is founded in Geneva in affiliation with the League of Nations to improve living standards and working conditions.
1926: American horticulturist Luther Burbank dies at the age of 77. He developed countless new varieties of fruits, vegetables and flowers, including the Burbank potato and the Shasta daisy.
1935: Dust storms wreak havoc in the so-called "Dust Bowl" states of Kansas, Colorado, Wyoming, Oklahoma, Texas and New Mexico in the United States.
1945: U.S. forces capture the German towns of Essen and Weimar and liberate the Buchenwald concentration camp near the end of World War II.
1950: The Bank of Taiwan issues its first lottery.
1950: China lodges a complaint with the United Nations against Soviet aid to the Chinese communists, the Soviet invasion of China and Soviet violation of the U.N. Charter.
1951: U.S. President Harry Truman relieves Gen. Douglas MacArthur, the World War II hero who accepted the Japanese surrender in Tokyo Bay in 1945, of all his command, including that of U.N. forces in Korea.
1957: Singapore is granted self-government by the United Kingdom.
1969: Taiwan's Executive Yuan approves the "Guidelines for the Population Policy of the Republic of China."
1970: The government of Prime Minister Lon Nol announces abolishment of the monarchy and proclaims Cambodia a republic.
1974: U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz, leading a party of 19, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the Sino-Honduran Fishery Technical Cooperation Agreement.
1976: An ROC education mission headed by Education Minister Y.S. Tsiang leaves for the Middle East on a visit.
1976: Col. Carlos Humberto Romero, secretary of defense and pacific security of El Salvador, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1978: The Taiwan Province Black Foot Disease Control Center is inaugurated in Peimen Village, Tainan County.
1979: A combined force of Ugandan exiles and Tanzanian troops captures the Ugandan capital of Kampala, ending the eight-year rule of Idi Amin.
1981: Chen Ta, a noted singer of Taiwanese folk songs, dies at the age of 76.
1994: U.S. President Bill Clinton orders trade sanctions against Taiwan in accordance with the Pelly Act.
1995: Chen Yun, one of Communist China's leading veteran hardliners and one of its leading economic planners, dies in Beijing at the age of 90.
1997: Turin Cathedral is engulfed by flames, but firefighters manage to save the famous Turin Shroud.
2000: Foreign ministers of the 113-member Non-Aligned Movement endorse the Philippine-led regional code of conduct in the South China Sea to promote peace and stability in the region.
2001: The Executive Yuan signs an agreement with the Netherlands Trade and Investment Office (NTIO) in Taipei to enact regulations to prevent double taxation on Dutch people working in Taiwan as well as those from Taiwan in the Netherlands.
2002: The European Parliament passes a pro-Taiwan resolution urging mainland China to dismantle missile deployment against Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A moral character always has courage; but a man of courage is not necessarily a moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: Keelung Harbor Bureau upbeat over tourism boosting plan

TEXT.P: A tourism boosting plan put forward by the Executive Yuan is expected to help inject new life into Keelung Port in northern Taiwan, Keelung Harbor Bureau Director-General Hsiao Ding-shun said Friday.
Hsiao based his optimism on the prospect that the plan would bring in higher numbers of tourists on cruise ships to Keelung Port -- Taiwan's largest sea port in the north.
According to Hsiao, two foreign cruise lines have projected they will make a total of eight calls at the port this year, bringing a total of 18,000 tourists to northern Taiwan.

Rough estimates indicate that these foreign visitors could contribute NT$120 million (US$3.6 million) in tourism revenue to businesses in the port area, he said, also voicing the hope that a government mega-tourism expansion plan will help bolster businesses in the area.

While figures for 2008 are not yet available, 272,000 passengers arrived in Keelung Port on cruise liners in 2007, or 63.8 percent of the year's total, Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) statistics showed.

A total of 426,000 tourists arrived on cruise liners at all of Taiwan's international ports for the year, an increase of about 111,000 visitors, or a 35.3 percent increase, over the 2006 level, according to the same figures.

On Thursday, the Executive Yuan approved an ambitious tourism expansion project in its regular weekly meeting with the aim of turning Taiwan into a tourism hub in East Asia that could generate NT$550 billion (US$16.5 billion) in tourism revenue in 2012 on a planned budget of NT$30 billion.

Of the total targeted spending, the government anticipates some NT$300 billion of the total will be contributed by foreign tourists from around the world, with the balance generated by domestic travelers.
It also estimates that the plan will help create 400,000 jobs by 2012.
The government hopes to attract 4.1 million foreign traveler arrivals in 2009, 4.5 million in 2010, 5 million in 2011 and 5.5 million in 2012, said Tourism Bureau Director General Janice Lai.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government-sponsored job fair series to offer 84,000 openings

TEXT.P: A series of four job fairs to be organized by the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) will kick off Saturday, offering a total of 84,000 job openings, an official said Friday.

"The first two job fairs will take place Saturday in central Taiwan's Taichung City and Hualien City in the eastern part of the country, " CLA Vice Minister Kuo Fang-yu said, adding that the remaining two fairs will be held the following weekend in Taoyuan County in northern Taiwan and in the southern city of Tainan.
The job fairs are part of the CLA's efforts to help increase employment after the country's unemployment rate surged to a record 5.75 percent in February amid the global economic downturn.
In addition to offering 84,000 job openings, Kuo said, the four events will also provide 71,000 openings for individuals to receive training or do research.
"The four job fairs will feature three 'plenties' -- plenty of job opportunities, plenty of display booths and plenty of services, " Kuo said confidently.

Of the 84,000 job openings, 25,000 are in the public sector, including 20,000 openings for volunteer military servicemen, 15,000 are in the private sector, and the remaining 44,000 are research and management jobs at local universities and colleges.
To cater to the needs of job seekers, Kuo said five theme areas will be set up at the fair venues to avoid overcrowding at certaining counters.

The job fair in central Taiwan will feature at least 159 service booths and the events in eastern, northern and southern Taiwan will accommodate 98, 155 and 182 stands, respectively, Kuo said, adding that the fairs are expected to lure an estimated 100,000 job seekers.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Cloud Gate 2' begins 2009 Spring Riot tour

TEXT.P: Cloud Gate 2, the offshoot of the world-renowned Cloud Gate Dance Theatre of Taiwan, kicked off its 2009 Spring Riot tour Friday evening, with a production choreographed by the troupe's founder Lin Hwai-min.
The production Spring Breeze is set to a popular Taiwanese love song. Lin said at a dress rehearsal news conference Friday afternoon that the piece is about youth, confusion and yearning.
The 2009 Spring Riot also features productions created by young choreographers, including Cheng Tsung-lung's new work "The Wall" and Huang Yi's "Flow."
Following its eight performances at Taipei's Novel Hall, Cloud Gate 2 will continue its spring tour in Hsinchu, Taichung and Kaohsiung, for a total of 14 performances.
The Cloud Gate 2, founded in 1999 to nurture a new generation of choreographers, turns 10 this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Special budget for economic stimulus plan clears legislature

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed a special budget Friday that cleared the way to finance an expanded NT$149.1 billion public works plan, another of several measures the government has adopted to revive Taiwan's sputtering economy.
The final amount authorized in the special budget was NT$1.5 billion less than the NT$150.6 billion that had been approved after the bill's initial screening in a legislature committee.
The special budget will be financed by raising debt and will not be subject to the debt ceiling as set by the Public Debt Act.

The legislature also passed a resolution to authorize the central government to commission townships to execute the special budget to prevent differences in party affiliation between the local and central governments affecting the budget's implementation.

Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party criticized the legislature, in which the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) controls nearly three-quarters of the seats, for circumventing the cities and counties in the use of the special budget.
"This is a blatantly pork-barrel move," Yang contended.
He noted that between 80 percent and 90 percent of the heads of townships around the island are KMT members.
The legislature also suggested that the Executive Yuan prohibit the use of foreign laborers and give priority to indigenous peoples in the public works projects.
The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Friday that after the execution of the special budget, the nation's gross domestic product (GDP) is expected to rise by 0.68 percent.
It will also create between 190,000 and 220,000 jobs, the CEPD estimated.

Covered under the bill are projects to provide comfortable and convenient urban transportation services, fast production and marketing networks, a safe environment and facilities to upgrade the public's quality of life.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese-Americans urge Washington to stick to commitment to Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 10 (CNA) 04/11/09 15:30:02 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese-American representatives urged the U.S. government Friday to reaffirm its committment to and support for Taiwan to mark the 30th anniversary of the enactment of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA).

In a joint statement released at a news conference held in Washington, D.C., the leaders of 11 Taiwanese-American groups expressed their appreciation to the United States for enacting the TRA on April 10, 1979, providing a legal basis for Washington's commitment to help Taiwan defend itself against possible attacks by China.
Equally important is a provision in the TRA that pledges to preserve and enhance the human rights of all of Taiwan's people, the leaders said.

They called on U.S. President Barack Obama and Congress to abandon the shackle of the "one-China" policy, work to normalize the relations between the United States and Taiwan, and help Taiwan participate in the international community on an equal footing with other countries.
The statement came two weeks after the U.S. House of Representatives adopted a resolution in recognition of the 30th anniversary of the TRA's enactment.
The resolution reaffirmed the TRA as "the cornerstone of U.S. relations with Taiwan" and expressed support for "the strong and deepening relationship between the United States and Taiwan."

Ben Liu, president of the North America Taiwanese Professors' Association, stressed that the United States and East Asian countries share a common interest in Taiwan's security and stability, and he urged the Obama administration to follow the example of Congress and reaffirm Washington's commitment to honor the terms of the TRA.

He suggested that the Obama administration and Congress work together to find a way to strengthen U.S.-Taiwan relations, deter China's military threats against Taiwan, and help increase Taiwan's international presence.
Susan Chang, president of the World Federation of Taiwanese Associations, asserted that Taiwan is a country, regardless of how few diplomatic allies it has.

With Taiwan having transformed from a dictatorship to become a beacon of democracy over the past 30 years, Taiwan's 23 million people deserve fairer treatment in the international community, Chang said.

According to Bob Yang, president of the Formosan Association for Public Affairs, the leaders of the Taiwanese-American groups will jointly write a letter to Obama to directly relay their opinions to him.

Also taking part in Friday's news conference were the Taiwanese Association of America, the World United Formosans for Independence, the Dr. Kang-Lu Wang Memorial Foundation, the North American Taiwanese Women's Association, the Taiwanese Hakka Association for Public Affairs in North America, and the World Taiwanese Congress.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA set to open offices in Sapporo, Istanbul before summer

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) hopes to formally open its planned representative offices in Sapporo, Japan, and Istanbul, Turkey before the summer holiday, the foreign minister said Saturday.

Francisco H. L. Ou said the ministry is now working on budgeting and staffing plans for the new offices. He estimated it would take two or three more months to complete the necessary arrangements, but noted that the governments of Japan and Turkey have both given the green light for Taiwan to open the liasion offices.

Staffing levels at the two offices will be determined based on the number of Taiwanese tourists who travel to the two cities. He disclosed that the Sapporo office will be manned by four to five people while the Istanbul office will have two to three people.
Ou said the idea to open new offices in Sapporo and Istanbul was based on Taiwan's frequent people-to-people exchanges with Japan and Turkey.
Plans to open the new representative branches have won the approval of the Executive Yuan, according to the MOFA.

Since earlier this year, the MOFA has been reviewing the functions and performance of its foreign representative offices to find ways to more efficiently use the country's limited diplomatic resources.

Taiwan currently has 122 embassies and representative offices around the world, which have to be staffed by a relatively large number of diplomats compared to the number posted abroad by South Korea and Singapore, according to the ministry.
Taiwan maintains diplomatic relations with 23 countries, most of which are located in the South Pacific and in Central and South America and the Caribbean.

The minister also commented on Taiwan's ties with El Salvador, which recently elected a president from a party with close ties to China's Communist Party, leading to speculation that the Central American country could cut long-standing ties with Taiwan.

Ou, who recently concluded a visit to San Salvador, said the Foreign Ministry holds a positive view of Taiwan-El Salvador relations, noting that President- elect Mauricio Funes said he would welcome President Ma Ying-jeou to attend his inauguration slated for June 1.

Ou said that in his meeting with Funes, the president-elect recognized the achievements of Taiwan-El Salvador cooperation and indicated he would begin talks with Taiwan on possible mutual cooperation plans after his government assumes office.

DOC.HEADLINE: List of top 10 bicycle theft-prone areas in Taipei released

TEXT.P: The areas surrounding university campuses appear to be the places most vulnerable to bicycle theft in Taipei, taking the top three spots in a list issued by city police of locations where bicycles are most likely to be stolen.

According to a report provided by the Taipei City Police Department to the Taipei City Council, the largest number of bicycle thefts reported in the city during the first three months of 2009 took place in areas surrounding the National Taiwan University campus, following by those surrounding the National Taiwan Normal University campus and the National Taipei University of Technology campus.

Rounding out the top 10 were areas surrounding the Hsinyi smoke-free park, the Taipei Public Library, Daan Forest Park, the Jiantan metro station, the area in front of No. 90 Songjiang Road, the Taipei City Hall metro station, and the Zhishan metro station.
The report shows that of the 99 bicycle thefts reported between the January- March period in the city, 54, or 54.55 percent, have been solved.
A total of 604 cases were reported in 2008, with 265 cases, or 43.87 percent, having been solved.
In 2007, there were 383 reported bicycle theft cases, 123 cases, or 32.11 percent, of which have been solved.
The National Police Agency (NPA) attributed the increase in bicycle theft to the popularity of cycling as a leisure activity in recent years.

Another factor is the lack of a system in the country to provide each bicycle with an identification code, the NPA said, adding that the agency has recently begun to promote such a system in an effort to reduce bicycle theft rates.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung sends invitation to president via roller blade express

TEXT.P: A group of 32 roller skaters set off from Kaohsiung Saturday on a one-day relay to Taipei to deliver an invitation to President Ma Ying-jeou to attend the 2009 World Games in the southern port city.

Mayor Chen Chu presided over a festive ceremony at the Glory Pier to launch the "express delivery" after entrusting the Taiwan Roller-Sport Association to organize the rolling relay to deliver the World Games invitation to the Presidential Office.
With over 4,000 athletes from nearly 100 countries around the world set to participate in the July competition, the city government hopes Ma will attend the opening ceremony, Chen said.

The roller skaters, divided into four small groups, are taking turns to complete the 367-kilometer run and are scheduled to arrive in Taipei Sunday to join the World Games Carnival promotional event at the Presidential Office.
The Taipei event will run from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. and hold a prize drawing as part of the festivities, with a flat-screen television, a bicycle, and computer products among the prizes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Remembering Chiang not nostalgia for dictatorship: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou clarified Saturday that the series of commemorative events organized recently by his administration to pay tribute to the late President Chiang Ching-kuo should not be mistaken as a show of nostalgia for the martial law era or the country's authoritarian past.
Ma raised the issue while addressing the opening of an exhibition held at the National Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei to mark the 100th anniversary of Chiang's birth.
Critics have questioned the necessity and basis for the country, which is now a vibrant democracy, to remember a political figure many regarded as an authoritarian figure.

By remembering Chiang, Ma stressed, the government is not trying to restore martial law or dictatorial government, but to show its respect for the foresight and wisdom displayed by Chiang in promoting various reforms that contributed to Taiwan's modernization in the 1970s and 1980s.

According to Ma, in any period in history, there are always "great figures" who truly change their times and leave valuable legacies from which modern people can gain experience and accumulate wisdom.

Ma said that based on his observation of Chiang during the seven years he served as an aide to the late president, the easygoing style of Chiang's leadership set a very influential example for many Taiwanese politicians who followed him.

Ma noted that he was also deeply impressed by Chiang's success in establishing a clean government by promoting a code of conduct for civil servants and his efforts to boost Taiwan's economic development.

Lastly, the series of political reforms initiated by Chiang -- including lifting martial law, removing a ban on the organization of political parties, reforming the legislature, liberalizing newspapers and opening up travel to China by Taiwan citizens to visit their relatives -- were all important elements forming the foundation of Taiwan's freedom and democracy nowadays, he said.
In memory of Chiang Ching-kuo, an outdoor concert is slated for Sunday at 7 p.m. to 9 p.m. at the National Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in Taipei.
On Monday, Ma is scheduled to host a ceremony in the Presidential Office to mark the anniversary of Chiang Ching-kuo's birth and visit his mausoleum in Touliao, Taoyuan County.

DOC.HEADLINE: Crew aboard hijacked Taiwanese ship safe: official

TEXT.P: All crew members aboard a Taiwanese fishing vessel hijacked by Somali pirates off the Seychelles in the Indian Ocean early this week are alive and safe, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Henry Chen said Saturday.

Concerns for the safety of the 30 crew members aboard the Win Far 161 long-line fishing boat were raised after foreign wire services reported that Somali pirates have threatened to kill American hostages on another hijacked vessel if U.S. warships attack them off the Horn of Africa.
"According to information secured by the ministry, all the Win Fa crew members are safe, " Chen told the Central News Agency in an interview.
Chen elaborated that the ministry has closely tracked the 700-ton deep-sea fishing vessel's course since it fell under the control of Somali pirates Monday.
He said the ship was currently located north-northwest of the Seychelles and is heading in a northwesterly direction toward the Somali coastline.
The Win Far crew includes two Taiwanese -- skipper and the first engineer -- as well as five Chinese, six Indonesians and 17 Filipinos.

Chen said the ministry has been in close contact with the shipowner, who has been quoted as wishing to maintain a low-profile so that he could be better positioned to negotiate with hijackers when they make a ransom demand.
"The ministry fully respects the shipowner's wish, " Chen reaffirmed Saturday.

Meanwhile, a spokesman for the Taiwan Tuna Association said Saturday that the association and the shipowner have been making every possible effort to rescue the Win Far crew, including seeking assistance from U.S. and British naval authorities and relevant international fishery organizations.
The spokesman suggested that the hijackers' main goal is money and are therefore not likely to take any rash actions as long as they have not received a ransom.

DOC.HEADLINE: Latest London public art work by Taiwanese designer a big success
DOC.DATELINE: London, April 11 (CNA) 04/11/09 20:29:24 (By Jennifer Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Lion, a sculptural rendition of a Chinese dragon designed by a Taiwanese artist and her Japanese friend, has become a new attraction in London's Chinatown since its public unveiling earlier this week.
The work, designed by Hsiao-Chi Tsai and Kimiya Yoshikawa, was hung on the wall of a building on the bustling Wardour Street.

During its public unveiling Wednesday, Westminister Mayor Louise Hyam was unreserved about her admiration for the sculpture, which she said has given Chinatown a new landscape and will make it the most noted Chinatown in the world.
The 600-kilogram sculpture is 360 cm long by 145 cm wide with a splendid array of colors ranging from red, white, and yellow to orange and green.

Tsai said in an interview with the Central News Agency that the design for the sculpture won a 20,000-pound Chinatown public art design competition in late 2007, paving the way for their finished piece to be publicly displayed in the neighborhood.
Tsai, 28, said that lion statues are usually placed at the entrance of Asian temples or palaces, which she believes symbolizes avoiding the bad, embracing the auspicious, and serving as guardians.
"The work is trying to convey the sense of hospitality but also of carefully guarding the premises," she said.
To put a contemporary twist on the lion, the sculpture is comprised of thousands of individually laser-cut pieces of colorful Perspex, she said.
The diverse pieces represent the variety of East Asians living in the U.K., which gives out crystallic transparency under the sun, she added.
Tsai said that while the design competition was hard, the production process has been equally arduous.
Since November, Tsai and Yoshikawa have worked an average of 12 hours a day on the project, with their only thought being that they "wanted to be the best."
Tsai said that "the production of the lion is like running a marathon, which is tough, and we're glad to see it completed."
David Tse, creative director of Chinatown Arts Space, expressed the hope that the work will enhance the dynamism and creativity of London's Chinatown.
Tsai graduated from Chelsea College of Art & Design and received her masters degree from Royal College of Art in 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: Penghu protests against plan to build nuclear waste storage site

TEXT.P: More than 200 people -- mostly Penghu residents -- staged a protest in Fengshan in Kaohsiung County Saturday, voicing their strong opposition to the government's plan to establish a nuclear waste storage site on a Penghu islet.

The protesters, headed by Penghu County Magistrate Wang Chien-fa, chanted anti- nuclear slogans at the rally held at a local temple and vowed to use whatever power they had to stop the plan from being carried out.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) announced in mid-March that it has listed Daren Township in Taitung County and Dongjiyu of Penghu County as the two suggested sites to store low-level radioactive waste.
The two counties are required to decide whether or not to accept the proposal by holding a referendum, according to the MOEA.

At the protest rally, Wang admitted that slogans cannot save Dongjiyu, one of 90 islets in the Penghu archipelago in the Taiwan Strait, because the law says that as long as Penghu County residents approve the project through the referendum, Dongjiyu must serve as a depository for nuclear waste.
It will not be up to Dongjiyu residents alone to decide whether or not to accept the plan that Wang contended will damage the island's untainted natural resources and environment.

Dongjiyu covers more than 140 hectares of land, 100 hectares of which have been listed by the Penghu County government as a "nature conservation zone" in an attempt to block the state-run Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) from opening a nuclear storage facility on the islet.
Taipower, however, can still appropriate the other 40 hectares of land, Wang said, and he urged county residents to unite in opposition to the referendum.
"Since the government wants to develop tourism in Penghu, it should not act to set up a nuclear waste storage site there, " he argued, vowing to fight to the death against the facility.
In addition to Wang, Yeh Chung-ju, chief of Wanan Township, and Legislator Wong Chung-Chun of the ruling Kuomintang also joined the protest.

Dongjiyu, located in the southern part of the Taiwan Strait, was once home to nearly 3,000 people, but now the population has fallen to under 30 people, most of whom make their living through fishing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mainland policy coordinator rules out referendum on trade pact

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan on Saturday said it was not necessary to hold a referendum on an economic framework agreement that Taiwan's government plans to sign with China.
The country's top China policy coordinator made the remarks at a seminar on the pros cand cons of a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China.

During the opposition-organized seminar, some critics contended that the plan proposed by President Ma Ying-jeou's administration to sign an ECFA with China could plunge Taiwan into a crisis in which its national sovereignty would be eroded.

In response, Lai argued that the proposed ECFA is just part of the government's efforts to promote normalization of cross-strait relations and is unrelated to such sensitive issues as national sovereignty or cross-strait unification.

"As the proposed cross-strait trade pact is simply a general economic cooperation accord and does not have anything to do with the sovereignty issue, there is no need to put it up for a referendum if such a pact is actually signed," Lai said.

Expressing her understanding of some people's concern over the proposed accord's possible adverse impact, Lai said the ECFA will mainly deal with fair trade issues and will not touch on any sovereignty issues.

"The government should address unfair treatment that our country may face in the future, " Lai said, referring to disadvantages that local manufacturers in some sectors may face after China forms a free trade area with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations next year.

Noting that promoting the signing of an ECFA with China is an established policy, Lai said the Ministry of Economic Affairs is still reviewing the risks and advantages of such a pact and has yet to flesh out its content.
"It's too early to criticize the yet-to-be-signed accord as a pact that would lead to a 'one China market' or lead to cross-striat unfiication under a 'one country, two systems' formula," Lai argued.

Stressing that signing an agreement requires the consent of both sides, Lai said the government will stand firm on its stance and will in no case compromise national sovereignty during the negotiation process.

However, Lai's argument failed to convince Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen who contended that the proposed pact is not only related to national sovereignty but also involves Taiwan's major national interests.

"Lai has not presented convincing evidence or insights to back her argument," Tsai said, adding that Lai should give a more detailed explanation to support her argument that the proposed ECFA will by no means erode Taiwan's sovereign status or major national interests.
The seminar was part of a state-of-the-nation conference jointly organized by the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union to review the Ma administration's China policy and other major policy issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH announces first Japanese encephalitis this year

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) announced Saturday the first case of Japanese encephalitis this year and urged the public to be aware of the mosquito-borne disease.

Shih Wen-yi, deputy director of the DOH's Centers for Disease Control, said the case was reported about a month earlier than is normally the case, as over the past decade the first case of the disease has typically been reported in May.

The victim, a 53-year-old man developed the symptoms of fever and vomiting April 4. He showed signs of a stiff neck and other suspicious symptoms Wednesday and was confirmed as having Japanese encephalitis Friday.

An initial probe showed that the man resides in Pingtung County and works in nearby Kaohsiung County during the day. He was not vaccinated for Japanese encephalitis before and has not traveled overseas recently.
"The family members of the man have not been ill and the cause of his infection is still being investigated," Shih said.
He said that the disease usually strikes between May and October, reaching its peak between June and July.
Shih also said that the DOH provides shots to children over 15 months old between March and May every year, and he urged parents to ensure that their children are vaccinated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Proposal for dialogue between ruling party, opposition rejected

TEXT.P: If the ruling and opposition parties could have a dialogue, it will benefit Taiwan's democratic development, a Presidential Office spokesman said Saturday, regretting that an offer to have a discussion had been turned down by the opposition head.

Wang Yu-chi made the remarks after Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen declined an invitation by President Ma Ying-jeou for a dialogue to help narrow differences and forge a national consensus.

Wang said that Ma's invitation was based on a conviction that "if both sides could start from love for Taiwan and put the public's welfare on a pedestal, then there would be no differences that could not be resolved and no parties that would not cooperate."
Wang cited as an example the passage of a NT$149.1 billion special budget for the expanded public works under an economic stimulus plan a day earlier.
Meanwhile, Tsai suggested several conditions for starting the dialogue, saying that "if the requests are not met, there is no basis to start such a dialogue."

Tsai, speaking on the sidelines of a two-day seminar on Ma administration's China policy sponsored by the DPP and Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , suggested the scrapping of the platform established between China's Communist Party and Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang.
Tsai also asked Ma to retract his words that "it is inevitable and the sooner the better for the two sides to sign the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA)."

Tsai threatened that if the ruler "turns a deaf ear to rational suggestions, then the party will consider whether to act, " adding that the DPP will stage a massive protest on Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office May 17 to demand that Ma apologize to the people.

TSU Chairman Huang Kun-huei also said that the public has misgivings about the signing of the framework agreement, and the Ma administration should not see such feelings as "opposing for the sake of opposing."

The Ma administration should cast away its predisposed position that the ECFA is an established policy, and clearly answer the questions of the people, leaving the final say on the matter to the public, Huang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet-sponsored job fairs help more than 6,000 get jobs

TEXT.P: More than 6,000 people successfully landed jobs Saturday through mediation of two Executive Yuan-organized job fairs, the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said in a statement.
According to initial statistics compiled by the Cabinet-level council, the job fair held in central Taiwan's Taichung City attracted 15,068 job seekers.
About 30 percent of the 10,729 job seekers who actually applied for various openings at the fair, or 3,150 hopefuls, managed to land jobs, the CLA statement said.
Among the successful applicants, 70 percent aged between 20 and 40, while the remaining 30 percent were middle- and senior-aged hopefuls, the statement added.

Meanwhile, 3,225 hopefuls applied for internship at local enterprises or research jobs at local universities and colleges, with 1,741 or more than 50 percent succeeding in realizing their goals. All these vacancies were mediated by the Ministry of Education.
The CLA statement further said a similar job fair held in eastern Taiwan's Hualien on the same day drew 5,326 visitors, with 2,921 of them applying for various job openings available.
Among the hopefuls, 1,095 or nearly 40 percent of the total succeeded in finding jobs. More than 40 percent of the successful applicants were younger than 40 and about 50 percent aged over 45.
In the eastern job fair, 326 hopefuls applied for internships and research positions offered by the Ministry of Education, with an about 65 percent success rate.

Two more Cabinet-sponsored job fairs will be held next weekend -- one in Taoyuan County and the other in Tainan City -- as part of the government's efforts to increase employment after the country's unemployment rate surged to a record 5.75 percent in February amid the global economic slump.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for April 12, 2009

TEXT.P: The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.

DOC.HEADLINE: Latest London public art work by Taiwanese designer a big success
DOC.DATELINE: London, April 11 (CNA) 04/11/09 20:29:24 (By Jennifer Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Lion, a sculptural rendition of a Chinese dragon designed by a Taiwanese artist and her Japanese friend, has become a new attraction in London's Chinatown since its public unveiling earlier this week.
The work, designed by Hsiao-Chi Tsai and Kimiya Yoshikawa, was hung on the wall of a building on the bustling Wardour Street.

During its public unveiling Wednesday, Westminister Mayor Louise Hyam was unreserved about her admiration for the sculpture, which she said has given Chinatown a new landscape and will make it the most noted Chinatown in the world.
The 600-kilogram sculpture is 360 cm long by 145 cm wide with a splendid array of colors ranging from red, white, and yellow to orange and green.

Tsai said in an interview with the Central News Agency that the design for the sculpture won a 20,000-pound Chinatown public art design competition in late 2007, paving the way for their finished piece to be publicly displayed in the neighborhood.
Tsai, 28, said that lion statues are usually placed at the entrance of Asian temples or palaces, which she believes symbolizes avoiding the bad, embracing the auspicious, and serving as guardians.
"The work is trying to convey the sense of hospitality but also of carefully guarding the premises," she said.
To put a contemporary twist on the lion, the sculpture is comprised of thousands of individually laser-cut pieces of colorful Perspex, she said.
The diverse pieces represent the variety of East Asians living in the U.K., which gives out crystallic transparency under the sun, she added.
Tsai said that while the design competition was hard, the production process has been equally arduous.
Since November, Tsai and Yoshikawa have worked an average of 12 hours a day on the project, with their only thought being that they "wanted to be the best."
Tsai said that "the production of the lion is like running a marathon, which is tough, and we're glad to see it completed."
David Tse, creative director of Chinatown Arts Space, expressed the hope that the work will enhance the dynamism and creativity of London's Chinatown.
Tsai graduated from Chelsea College of Art & Design and received her masters degree from Royal College of Art in 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: Penghu protests against plan to build nuclear waste storage site

TEXT.P: More than 200 people -- mostly Penghu residents -- staged a protest in Fengshan in Kaohsiung County Saturday, voicing their strong opposition to the government's plan to establish a nuclear waste storage site on a Penghu islet.

The protesters, headed by Penghu County Magistrate Wang Chien-fa, chanted anti- nuclear slogans at the rally held at a local temple and vowed to use whatever power they had to stop the plan from being carried out.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) announced in mid-March that it has listed Daren Township in Taitung County and Dongjiyu of Penghu County as the two suggested sites to store low-level radioactive waste.
The two counties are required to decide whether or not to accept the proposal by holding a referendum, according to the MOEA.

At the protest rally, Wang admitted that slogans cannot save Dongjiyu, one of 90 islets in the Penghu archipelago in the Taiwan Strait, because the law says that as long as Penghu County residents approve the project through the referendum, Dongjiyu must serve as a depository for nuclear waste.
It will not be up to Dongjiyu residents alone to decide whether or not to accept the plan that Wang contended will damage the island's untainted natural resources and environment.

Dongjiyu covers more than 140 hectares of land, 100 hectares of which have been listed by the Penghu County government as a "nature conservation zone" in an attempt to block the state-run Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) from opening a nuclear storage facility on the islet.
Taipower, however, can still appropriate the other 40 hectares of land, Wang said, and he urged county residents to unite in opposition to the referendum.
"Since the government wants to develop tourism in Penghu, it should not act to set up a nuclear waste storage site there, " he argued, vowing to fight to the death against the facility.
In addition to Wang, Yeh Chung-ju, chief of Wanan Township, and Legislator Wong Chung-Chun of the ruling Kuomintang also joined the protest.

Dongjiyu, located in the southern part of the Taiwan Strait, was once home to nearly 3,000 people, but now the population has fallen to under 30 people, most of whom make their living through fishing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mainland policy coordinator rules out referendum on trade pact

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan on Saturday said it was not necessary to hold a referendum on an economic framework agreement that Taiwan's government plans to sign with China.
The country's top China policy coordinator made the remarks at a seminar on the pros cand cons of a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China.

During the opposition-organized seminar, some critics contended that the plan proposed by President Ma Ying-jeou's administration to sign an ECFA with China could plunge Taiwan into a crisis in which its national sovereignty would be eroded.

In response, Lai argued that the proposed ECFA is just part of the government's efforts to promote normalization of cross-strait relations and is unrelated to such sensitive issues as national sovereignty or cross-strait unification.

"As the proposed cross-strait trade pact is simply a general economic cooperation accord and does not have anything to do with the sovereignty issue, there is no need to put it up for a referendum if such a pact is actually signed," Lai said.

Expressing her understanding of some people's concern over the proposed accord's possible adverse impact, Lai said the ECFA will mainly deal with fair trade issues and will not touch on any sovereignty issues.

"The government should address unfair treatment that our country may face in the future, " Lai said, referring to disadvantages that local manufacturers in some sectors may face after China forms a free trade area with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations next year.

Noting that promoting the signing of an ECFA with China is an established policy, Lai said the Ministry of Economic Affairs is still reviewing the risks and advantages of such a pact and has yet to flesh out its content.
"It's too early to criticize the yet-to-be-signed accord as a pact that would lead to a 'one China market' or lead to cross-striat unfiication under a 'one country, two systems' formula," Lai argued.

Stressing that signing an agreement requires the consent of both sides, Lai said the government will stand firm on its stance and will in no case compromise national sovereignty during the negotiation process.

However, Lai's argument failed to convince Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen who contended that the proposed pact is not only related to national sovereignty but also involves Taiwan's major national interests.

"Lai has not presented convincing evidence or insights to back her argument," Tsai said, adding that Lai should give a more detailed explanation to support her argument that the proposed ECFA will by no means erode Taiwan's sovereign status or major national interests.
The seminar was part of a state-of-the-nation conference jointly organized by the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union to review the Ma administration's China policy and other major policy issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH announces first Japanese encephalitis this year

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) announced Saturday the first case of Japanese encephalitis this year and urged the public to be aware of the mosquito-borne disease.

Shih Wen-yi, deputy director of the DOH's Centers for Disease Control, said the case was reported about a month earlier than is normally the case, as over the past decade the first case of the disease has typically been reported in May.

The victim, a 53-year-old man developed the symptoms of fever and vomiting April 4. He showed signs of a stiff neck and other suspicious symptoms Wednesday and was confirmed as having Japanese encephalitis Friday.

An initial probe showed that the man resides in Pingtung County and works in nearby Kaohsiung County during the day. He was not vaccinated for Japanese encephalitis before and has not traveled overseas recently.
"The family members of the man have not been ill and the cause of his infection is still being investigated," Shih said.
He said that the disease usually strikes between May and October, reaching its peak between June and July.
Shih also said that the DOH provides shots to children over 15 months old between March and May every year, and he urged parents to ensure that their children are vaccinated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Proposal for dialogue between ruling party, opposition rejected

TEXT.P: If the ruling and opposition parties could have a dialogue, it will benefit Taiwan's democratic development, a Presidential Office spokesman said Saturday, regretting that an offer to have a discussion had been turned down by the opposition head.

Wang Yu-chi made the remarks after Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen declined an invitation by President Ma Ying-jeou for a dialogue to help narrow differences and forge a national consensus.

Wang said that Ma's invitation was based on a conviction that "if both sides could start from love for Taiwan and put the public's welfare on a pedestal, then there would be no differences that could not be resolved and no parties that would not cooperate."
Wang cited as an example the passage of a NT$149.1 billion special budget for the expanded public works under an economic stimulus plan a day earlier.
Meanwhile, Tsai suggested several conditions for starting the dialogue, saying that "if the requests are not met, there is no basis to start such a dialogue."

Tsai, speaking on the sidelines of a two-day seminar on Ma administration's China policy sponsored by the DPP and Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , suggested the scrapping of the platform established between China's Communist Party and Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang.
Tsai also asked Ma to retract his words that "it is inevitable and the sooner the better for the two sides to sign the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA)."

Tsai threatened that if the ruler "turns a deaf ear to rational suggestions, then the party will consider whether to act, " adding that the DPP will stage a massive protest on Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office May 17 to demand that Ma apologize to the people.

TSU Chairman Huang Kun-huei also said that the public has misgivings about the signing of the framework agreement, and the Ma administration should not see such feelings as "opposing for the sake of opposing."

The Ma administration should cast away its predisposed position that the ECFA is an established policy, and clearly answer the questions of the people, leaving the final say on the matter to the public, Huang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet-sponsored job fairs help more than 6,000 get jobs

TEXT.P: More than 6,000 people successfully landed jobs Saturday through mediation of two Executive Yuan-organized job fairs, the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said in a statement.
According to initial statistics compiled by the Cabinet-level council, the job fair held in central Taiwan's Taichung City attracted 15,068 job seekers.
About 30 percent of the 10,729 job seekers who actually applied for various openings at the fair, or 3,150 hopefuls, managed to land jobs, the CLA statement said.
Among the successful applicants, 70 percent aged between 20 and 40, while the remaining 30 percent were middle- and senior-aged hopefuls, the statement added.

Meanwhile, 3,225 hopefuls applied for internship at local enterprises or research jobs at local universities and colleges, with 1,741 or more than 50 percent succeeding in realizing their goals. All these vacancies were mediated by the Ministry of Education.
The CLA statement further said a similar job fair held in eastern Taiwan's Hualien on the same day drew 5,326 visitors, with 2,921 of them applying for various job openings available.
Among the hopefuls, 1,095 or nearly 40 percent of the total succeeded in finding jobs. More than 40 percent of the successful applicants were younger than 40 and about 50 percent aged over 45.
In the eastern job fair, 326 hopefuls applied for internships and research positions offered by the Ministry of Education, with an about 65 percent success rate.

Two more Cabinet-sponsored job fairs will be held next weekend -- one in Taoyuan County and the other in Tainan City -- as part of the government's efforts to increase employment after the country's unemployment rate surged to a record 5.75 percent in February amid the global economic slump.

TEXT.P: The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
