DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 12, or the 17th day of the third month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1606: The Union Jack becomes the United Kingdom's official flag.
1860: Vajirananavarorasa, prince and patriarch of Buddhism in Siam, is born. He institutionalized Thai Buddhism.
1861: The U.S. Civil War breaks out as Confederate forces under Gen. Pierre Beauregarde take Fort Sumter in Charlestown harbor, South Carolina.
1927: The Kuomintang starts a "purification" movement by expelling communist members.
1945: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt dies in office at the age of 63. Vice President Harry S. Truman is sworn in as his successor.
1949: The 37.5 Per Cent Farm Rental Reduction Program goes into effect in Taiwan.
1953: The Legislative Yuan passes a bill submitted by President Chiang Kai-shek, extending the term of office for legislators by an additional year, to May 7, 1954.
1958: The first national meeting for commending "Good Men and Good Deeds" is held at Chung Shan Hall in Taipei.
1961: The Russians put the first man into space when cosmonaut Yauri Gargarin is launched in the Vostok I space vehicle for a single orbit of the earth.
1963: Indonesian forces launch an armed attack against Malaysia as part of a new policy of confrontation.
1966: Cheng Wan-fu, former chairman of the "Taiwan Democratic Party" and a leader of the "Taiwan Independence Movement" in Tokyo, returns to Taipei after 20 years of self-imposed exile in Japan.
1973: Deng Xiaoping, who was purged during the Cultural Revolution, resumes his position as the vice premier of Communist China.
1973: Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1974: Economic Affairs Vice Minister K.S. Chang, leading a group of government officials and businessmen, depart for San Francisco to attend a Sino-U.S. conference on economic relations.
1974: Tsinghwa University completes the installation of its second nuclear reactor for research purposes. This is the fourth research reactor installed in Taiwan.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan calls on the people to carry out the Last Testament of the late President Chiang Kai-shek.
1975: Taipei building contractors pledge NT$1 million to start a fund-raising campaign for the proposed Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.
1979: Taiwan's first geothermal power plant formally begins operations.
1981: Joe Louis, American prize fighter, dies at the age of 67. He held the heavyweight title for nearly 12 years (1937-1949), successfully defending it a record 25 times.
1981: Columbia, the world's first reusable space shuttle, is launched at Cape Canaveral.
1983: China Airlines inaugurates its regular flight service to Amsterdam as the first step toward establishing worldwide commercial air services.
1989: Honduran President Jose Azcona Hoyo and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1994: The Mainland Affairs Council decides to suspend all cultural and educational exchanges with the mainland until Beijing provides reasonable and satisfactory explanations for the Qiandao Lake tragedy of March 31 in which 24 Taiwan tourists were killed.
1996: The Petronas Towers in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, are declared the world's tallest buildings.
2000: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew meets with Guenter Rexrodt, a former German economics minister, to exchange views on bilateral relations between the two countries.
2001: an IBM-Linux Development Center is inaugurated in Taiwan. The center will provide local individual and group users with system testing, technical exchanges, experience sharing and training on using the Linux operating system.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are wise men who are not moral characters; but a fool is never a moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: Ultra-marathon champion embraces life after having leg amputated

TEXT.P: As recently as eight months ago, Chiu Chu-jung was Taiwan's most formidable female ultra-marathon runner. Competing around the world, in places as distant as Japan, New Zealand and Greece, Chiu challenged, and defeated, some of the best long-distance runners in the world.
She was looking to continue to her success in a 1,150-kilometer race through France in August 2008 when a blister began developing on her right foot.

The experienced runner ignored the minor irritant just as she had done many times in the past and persevered on. But bacteria that invaded her body through the broken blisters turned into a lethal blood poisoning disease that had doctors at a hospital in southern France fearing she might not survive.

Fortunately, a double amputation that took away her right leg above the knee and part of her left foot saved her life but has left Chiu to face the biggest athletic challenge of her life: simply running again.

The 52-year-old woman who almost ran effortlessly across deserts and up mountains is now fighting just to get back on her feet, pursuing the goal with the same determination that carried her through countless ultra-marathons, without any self-pity.

"So long as I am alive, everything will be OK," Chiu said at her home in Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan, where she has been receiving treatment and undergoing rehabilitation at Kaohsiung Medical University Chung-Ho Memorial Hospital since returning from France on Sept. 27, 2008.

Chiu has already started taking steps with the help of a walking assistance device as she begins her long trek back to the jogging trail, a place ironically she had no interest in for much of her young adult life.
Chiu, an office worker at Kaohsiung-based China Steel Corp. (CSC) , described herself as a woman who loved to dress well and who hated to be exposed to the sun to protect her skin.
It wasn't until the age of 37 that her athletic husband Lu Hua-chieh coaxed her into giving running a try, even though she had not been keen on exercising since her childhood.
Once she began to jog with her husband, however, Chiu realized she had a gift for long-distance running and was ready to pursue the activity for the rest of her life.
In her international competition debut at the 1996 Taipei International Marathon, she finished third in the women's competition.
In the following years, she experimented with different distances in races in Taiwan, from 10 kilometers to the marathon-length 42.195 km.

She then tried longer races spanning 50 km., 80 km. and 100 km. as well as endurance tests of 12 hours, 24 hours, 36 hours, seven days/seven nights, and 18 days and now is the Taiwanese female record-holder in most of those events.

In March 2008, she further broke the Asian record for the seven days/seven nights event previously held by Japanese runner Hiroko Okiyama, in an international ultra-marathon in Greece. Running 785 km. in seven days and seven nights, eclipsing Okiyama's record of 752 km., she finished second in the race among 52 runners.
It was five months later, however, that Chiu met her match, not on the race course but from an invisible bacteria.

Chiu, described as being able to run farther, longer and better than any other woman in Taiwan, joined the "Transe Gaule" race in France Aug. 13, which required her to run from Roscoff, a small fishing village on the northwestern French coast, to the sunny tourist resort of Gruissan-Plage on the Mediterranean coast in 18 days.

Though she suffered from blisters from the beginning of the race, it wasn't until the 16th day that she began to feel weak. Still, she insisted on completing the event and ended up 17th among all 44 runners and second in the women's division, covering the 1,150-km. distance in 125 hours, 7 minutes and 24 seconds.

Only after the race did she discover how serious her condition was. Three different kinds of pathogenic bacteria had invaded her body through the broken blisters, causing a serious infection that eventually turned into a deadly form of septicemia, or blood poisoning.

Fearing that Chiu would not survive, doctors at a Montpellier hospital amputated her right leg and bottom half of her left foot and also scraped most of the flesh from the remaining leg in an effort to stop the infection from spreading.

Her strong will that had carried her through so many long-distance challenges helped keep her alive, and even today, Chiu does not blame anyone or fate for her loss, even admitting that ignoring the blister at the time was perfectly natural behavior because blisters are such a common occurrence among ultra-marathon runners.

She only recalls the physical pain she felt lying on a hospital bed because she had no skin and was not allowed to move, but returning to Taiwan had great therapeutic value, because, as she said, "so long as I was coming home, there would be hope."
Before Christmas last year, Chiu checked out of the Kaohsiung hospital and returned home, ending her "most unforgettable journey" to begin a new one.
The "Ultra-Marathon Mom" as she's known can now stand and walk a few steps with the help of a prosthetic leg made for her.
Her next step, Chiu said, is to "start learning from the beginning" in the hope of returning to her old running haunts.
"I am now in an ultra-marathon race of my own, " acknowledged Chiu, with the destination the ability to run again.
She figures the discipline she learned in long-distance running will serve her well in her latest journey.
"The only secret of success in running is to persist until the very end, " said Chiu, who now has set a longer-term of participating in the Paralympic Games one day in the future.
"Life is long. One should not give up or be pessimistic (because of some tribulations)."

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet estimates 80% rise in tourism revenues by 2012

TEXT.P: The Cabinet has mapped out a four-year plan to raise the quality of Taiwan's tourism environment that it expects will boost revenues from international tourists by 80 percent in four years, the Tourism Bureau disclosed in a report released Sunday.

In the analysis of Taiwan's tourist industry, the bureau said that in 2007, international tourists spent US$5.1 billion in Taiwan, accounting for 1.34 percent of Taiwan's gross domestic product -- better than the United States, Canada, Germany, Japan, South Korea and China.
The planned campaign aims to increase annual tourism revenues to US$9 billion by 2012, accounting for more than 2 percent of Taiwan's GDP, according to the report.
The plan is expected to increase the number of international tourist arrivals by an average of up to 4 percent each year -- from 4.1 million in 2009 to 5.5 million in 2012.

Visitors from Japan will continue to constitute the biggest segment of international tourist arrivals in 2009 and 2010, estimated to reach 1.09 million and 1.1 million respectively in those two years.

The number of visitors from China, however, is expected to grow rapidly, rising from 320,000 in 2009 to 700,000 in 2010, and again to 1.2 million in 2011 to be on par with tourist arrivals from Japan in that year.
But in 2012, the number of tourists from China is expected to rise to 1.5 million, surpassing the number of visitors from Japan for the first time.

Other estimated international tourist arrivals in 2012 are 1.18 million from Hong Kong, Singapore and Malaysia; 720,000 from Europe, North America and Australia; and 290,000 from South Korea, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRA a positive force in U.S.-Taiwan-China relations: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou on Sunday said the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) has not only symbolized the strong friendship and trust between the United States and Taiwan over the past three decades, but will continue to serve as a strong foundation for relations among the U.S., Taiwan and China in the future.

The TRA has served to anchor peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait for the past three decades, " Ma said in English at the opening ceremony of an international conference on the TRA and its prospects on its 30th anniversary.
"Its very existence changed the evolutionary course of cross-strait development by stabilizing the trilateral relationship among Taiwan, the U.S. and mainland China,he said.

Describing the TRA as thesecond best choicein an imperfect world, the president said the TRA has served to accommodate Taiwan's needs by keeping all aspects of U.S.-Taiwan relations intact despite Washington's switching of diplomatic recognition from the Republic of China to the People's Republic of China in 1979.
The TRA also created a resilient triangular framework for relations among U.S., Taiwan and China, he added.
This resilience, or dynamic status quo, is of crucial importance for peace and stability for East Asia,Ma said.
Enacted by the U.S. Congress April 10, 1979, the TRA has been the sole legal document on the United States side governing bilateral relations.

The act requires the U.S. to guarantee defensive arms sales to Taiwan and to maintain the capacity of the U.S. to resist any resort to force or other forms of coercion that would jeopardize the security, or the social or economic system, of the people of Taiwan.
It does not require the U.S. to intervene militarily if the People' Republic of China attacks or invades Taiwan.

Speaking of current cross-Taiwan Strait relations, President Ma said that his administration's continuous efforts to improve relations with Beijing since last May not only put an end to bilateral diplomatic belligerency in favor of substantive economic cooperation, but also demonstrated to the world that Taiwan wants to be a responsible peacemaker instead of troublemaker in the region.

With the resilience of the TRA and the ever-warming relations with China, especially on the economic front, Ma said this new equilibrium will create a win-win-win situation for the U.S., Taiwan, and China to solve complex issues through cooperation.
Describing U.S.-Taiwan-China relations as a train, Ma said he hoped that they will continue to remain on the right track and move smoothly forward.

As part of the celebration of the 30th anniversary of the passage of the TRA, the April 12 international conference was held by the nongovernmental National Policy Foundation and the Cross-Strait Interflow Prospect Foundation.
More than 300 government officials, dignitaries and political experts from home and abroad are attending the conference to look back at the act and discuss new ways to enhance U.S.-Taiwan relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to allow more Chinese tourist arrivals for Labor Day holiday

TEXT.P: The National Immigration Agency will increase the daily quota of Chinese tourists allowed to visit Taiwan beginning April 16 in response to an anticipated increase in Chinese visitor arrivals for the May 1 Labor Day holiday, local tourism operators said Sunday.

Most tour buses and three- and four-star hotels in Taiwan are fully booked until the end of May as an increase in Chinese tourist arrivals is expected ahead of the holiday, according to Hsu Kao-ching, secretary-general of the Tourism Business Association in Taiwan.

Under an agreement reached by Taiwan and China last June, the number of Chinese allowed to visit Taiwan is capped at 3,000 per day, but arrivals in late April and May are expected to exceed that number.
Hsu said the agency will draw from the 170,000 quota slots that went unused during the first three months of 2009 to provide additional spots beyond the daily cap to meet demand.
The National Immigration Agency anticipates approving about 500 Chinese visitor applications more than the cap allows per day, or a total of 5,500, during the last two weeks of April.

The balance of 164,500 unused slots from the first quarter will be allocated during other peak travel periods as necessary if applications from Chinese visitors to travel in Taiwan exceeds the visitor ceiling.

Hsu said that as more Chinese apply to come to Taiwan, the Immigration Agency's manpower has grown tight, and that while it would accept all applications filed during work hours, the maximum number of applications it can approve in one day is limited to 4,311.
A number of Chinese tourist groups are slated to arrive in the next six weeks that will likely push their numbers above the established cap.

A group of 20,000 people from a senior citizens' association in China is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan in May in separate batches, making it the largest ever Chinese tourist group to visit Taiwan, Hsu said.
He indicated that the group will apply to visit on a special-case basis so as not to count against the daily visitor quota.
A 900-member group from China's Fujian province will visit Taiwan April 15 after arriving in the Taiwan island county of Kinmen via a ferry between the island and Xiamen in Fujian.

After flying to Taiwan and touring the island, they will take the Taihua Ferry traveling from Kaohsiung Harbor to Magong in the island county of Penghu April 20 before heading home the next day, Hsu added.

Also, several groups each composed of some 100 travelers from Guangxi and Zhejiang provinces and Hainan Island, and tourism industry representatives from various provinces in China, are expected to attend the 2009 Taipei International Tourism Exposition scheduled to open May 22 at the Taipei World Trade Center, said Ding Lai, deputy secretary-general of the Taipei Association of Travel Agents.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRC should give Taiwan more international space: former U.S. official

TEXT.P: A former top-ranking U.S. official said Sunday in Taipei that given the warming relations between Taiwan and China, Beijing should take further steps to give Taiwan more space in the international community, calling progress on this issue "critical."

Winston Lord, former assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, also asserted that Washington, while continuing to adhere to its commitments to China and Taiwan, should not play a role in mediating problems between the sides.

In a keynote speech at an international conference on the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) 30 years after it was enacted, Lord contended that current cross-Taiwan Strait relations are the most steady and promising -- if not prosperous -- in sixty years, but "there is never room for complacency."
The most immediate issue regarding future moves by Taipei and Beijing, he said, is international space for Taiwan.

While the Chinese have loosened up somewhat and seem to be entertaining flexibility on Taiwan's participation in the World Health Organization, Lord said Beijing should move fromhalting, limited steps to a more forthcoming posture, there and elsewhere, consistent with Taiwan's dignity and stature.

This can be reconciled with Beijing's principles if it has the will to do so, Lord said.Progress on this issue is critical -- both on the merits of the case and to show the Taiwan people that President Ma Ying-jeou's initiatives are bearing fruit.
China's position on security issues is also cause for concern, according to the former diplomat.

Lord said it might be hoped that increasing economic ties, bilateral dialogue and general momentum will lead to progress in this area, but the picture so far is not encouraging, as a recent Pentagon report indicated that China continues to build up its missile force and its general military capabilities.
In addition, fleeting references to confidence-building measures have not yielded concrete steps either, said Lord, who now serves as the chairman emeritus of the International Rescue Committee.

On the issue of Taiwan's sovereignty, Lord said the two sides of the Taiwan Strait need to seek ways to continue obfuscating the problem, adding that China has shown some patience on the sovereignty issue -- perhaps in the belief that time is on its side.

Noting that there is a clear popular consensus in Taiwan that drawing closer to the People's Republic of China (PRC) can only be envisioned if the mainland's political system becomes more open, pluralistic and free, the former top-ranking U.S. official seemed cautiously optimistic in this area.
I am hopeful that China will move toward greater transparency and liberty -- not as a concession to the West but as the proven route to a brighter future,Lord said.

As to the U.S. role in relations among Washington, Beijing and Taipei, Lord said the U.S. should continue to foster a positive environment for progress through deft diplomacy incorporating both encouragement and admonition, as well as adhere to its commitments to the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The U.S. should not, however, mediate in any fashion, even in the highly unlikely event that the two sides sought to cast America in that role, Lord said, because the future relationship between Taiwan and the PRC should be resolved between themdirectly, peacefully and with the support of the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRA still serves U.S. interests in Taiwan: former AIT director

TEXT.P: Three decades after the enactment of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) , the U.S. domestic law still serves the interests of the United States in Taiwan, despite the many political, economic, and strategic changes that have occurred, a former U.S. diplomat said Sunday.

From political, economic and strategic perspectives, the United States retains strong but changing interests in its unofficial relations with Taiwan, said Douglas Paal, former director of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Taipei Office, at an international conference to mark the 30th anniversary of the TRA in Taipei.

The instrument of the TRA, accompanied by confidence in the wisdom of the people of Taiwan expressed through ballot box democracy, is a source of reassurance for both America and Taiwan going forward,he added.
Enacted by the U.S. Congress April 10, 1979, the TRA has been the sole U.S. legal document governing bilateral relations with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

The act requires the U.S. to guarantee defensive arms sales to Taiwan and to maintain the capacity of the U.S. to resist any resort to force or other forms of coercion that would jeopardize the security, or the social or economic system, of the people of Taiwan.
It does not require the U.S. to intervene militarily if the People's Republic of China attacks or invades Taiwan.

According to Paal, U.S. calculations have changed enormously since 1979, because politically, the U.S. sense of Taiwan as a plucky, stalwart outpost of freedom against tyranny has eroded, while economically, China's trade with Taiwan and the U.S. has grown significantly from 1979 levels.

He said America still has important strategic interests in Taiwan because how China's policy toward Taiwan evolves can be a strategic signal as to how China wants to interact with America and the world.

Also, how China's leaders manage the views in China that "reunification" with the island would be an important component of Beijing's new maritime assertiveness and promote better relations with Taipei can be indicators of China's strategic ambitions, he added.
Beijing's handling of Taipei's desire for participation in international organizations like the World Health Assembly will also give the U.S. indications of Chinese intentions, according to Paal.
So far, there is much to be reassured about in China's recent dealings with Taiwan, yet there are still sources of concern. The picture remains mixed,Paal said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Experts launch renewed efforts to conserve rare fish species

TEXT.P: The government has enlisted the help of four academics to launch another effort to conserve the Formosan landlocked salmon -- a critically endangered indigenous species -- later this month, officials of the Ministry of the Interior disclosed Sunday.

The officials at the Construction and Planning Agency said that an initial survey by the four experts showed that the Luoyewei River in the Sheipa National Park in central Taiwan is an ideal environment where artificially bred young fry of the species can be released.

The Formosan landlocked salmon -- a holdover from the last Ice Age -- has been designated as a national treasure. The salmon became landlocked during the last glacial epoch in frigid mountain streams, and thus its discovery in Taiwan -- a subtropical island -- is considered a biological miracle.
A survey conducted last October showed that after five successive typhoons stuck central Taiwan in 2008, the number of the fish in Taiwan's mountain streams dropped from some 5,300 to 3,600.
The four academics in charge of the new conservation efforts are ecologist Lin Sin-Chu, ichthyologist Tseng Ching-hsien, aquaculture expert Huang Yi-syun, and river expert Ye Chao-sian.

They have found that the 11.4-kilometer river along the 2,700-meter-high Luoyewei Mountain has many deep ponds with agreeable temperatures and suitable oxygen levels that provide ideal new habitats for the rare fish.

The officials said that the new conservation efforts became necessary because the 1,280 artificially bred young fish released in a number of rivers in the national park between 2006 and 2008 had a survival rate of less than 1 percent, mainly because of the typhoons last year.
Most of the existing fish are found in the Cijiawan river, a protected sanctuary for the Formosan landlocked salmon in the Sheipa National Park.

Formosan landlocked salmon grow to about 30 centimeters in length and inhabit cold, slow-flowing streams with gently sloping beds at elevations above 1,500 meters, such as the Cijiawan river upstream from the Dajia River.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
No change of TRA needed for warming Taiwan-China ties: U.S. scholars

TEXT.P: There is no need to amend the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) or replace it with a new one to adjust to new realities in Taiwan or to changing relations with China because it has and will continue to serve United States interests, U.S. scholars said Sunday.

They were in Taipei attending a conference on the significance of the TRA 30 years after it was enacted, and Bonnie Glaser, a senior associate at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, asserted that the TRA continued to be in Washington's interests.

In her speech on the future direction of the TRA and its implications for cross- Taiwan Strait relations, Glaser said the TRA does not need to be amended because it addresses U.S. policy interests, not outcomes, and its efficacy has not been affected substantially by shifting U.S.-China-Taiwan dynamics.
The TRA endures because it serves the U.S.interest, she said.

Alan Romberg, a distinguished fellow and director of the East Asia Program of the Henry L. Stimson Center, echoed Glaser's view, saying that the TRA has been interpreted and applied as a very useful statement of U.S. policy and a point of reference.

The fact that the U.S. has maintained that policy through all these years regardless of many changes in the situation is a testament to its correctness from the perspective of American interests,he said.
Enacted by the U.S. Congress April 10, 1979, the TRA has been the sole U.S. legal document governing Washington's bilateral relations with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

The act requires the U.S. to guarantee defensive arms sales to Taiwan and to maintain the capacity of the U.S. to resist any resort to force or other forms of coercion that would jeopardize the security, or the social or economic system, of the people of Taiwan.
It does not require the U.S. to intervene militarily if the People's Republic of China attacks or invades Taiwan.

Drew Thompson, director of China Studies and a senior fellow of the U.S. think tank Nixon Center, contended that the TRA is unlikely to change in the future as it continues to serve its intended purpose to help maintain peace, security and stability in the Western Pacific.

The ambiguity encapsulated in the TRA benefits Taiwan. Changing it, in my opinion, would not improve Taiwan's condition, nor would it necessarily further the unique U.S.-Taiwan relationship, Thompson said.
Changing it could potentially embolden China and increase anxiety in Taiwan,he added.

The scholars also seemed to agree that closer cooperation between Taiwan and China serves U.S. interests because the consistent objective of U.S. policy is to preserve cross-strait peace and stability.

That goal has been advanced by the initiatives that President Ma Ying-jeou has taken toward China over the past year, and the U.S. should continue to support his approach, which has the support of a majority of the Taiwanese people, the scholars argued.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese woman advances to doubles final of clay court event

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Chuang Chia-jung, who has been unable to sustain her top 10 doubles ranking playing with a variety of partners after splitting with compatriot Chan Yung-jan, seems to have found a good fit with India's Sania Mirza.

One week after the duo reached the semifinals of women's doubles at the prestigious Sony Ericsson Open, Chuang and Mirza reached the finals of the MPS Group Championships in Florida by defeating Liga Dekmeijere of Latvia and Angela Haynes of the U.S. 6-4, 6-3 in Saturday's semis.

In the final of the clay court event, Chuang and Mirza will face top seeds Czech Kveta Peschke and American Lisa Raymond, the same duo that knocked them out at the Sony Ericsson Open in two tight sets.

Chuang was ranked as high as No. 5 in the world in doubles during her nearly 20-month collaboration with Chan, which ended at last year's U.S. Open after a failed bid for an Olympic medal at the Beijing Summer Olympics in 2008.

Her ranking has fallen since the split, but Chuang is now back up to No. 17 in the world and could move up another two slots if she and Mirza capture the MPS Group Championships title Sunday in the U.S. By Luke Sabatier

DOC.HEADLINE: Young men show highest increase in abnormal blood lipid levels

TEXT.P: Young and middle-aged men are the two groups that have exhibited the highest rate of increase in abnormal blood lipid levels in recent years, two cardiologists said at a health promotion event in Taipei Saturday.

Nearly 80 percent of the more than 200 people who had their blood fat tested at the event Saturday were found to have abnormally high blood lipid levels, which can contribute to cardiovascular disease and diabetes.

Chiang Fu-tien, president of the Taiwan Society of Cardiology, and Hwang Juey- jen, deputy chief executive of Taiwan Heart Foundation, said at the event that blood fat levels have been on the rise among men in recent years.

Based on the results of blood lipid tests done in 2002 and 2007, the percent of men aged 30-40 who have high blood fat levels rose to 10.4 percent in 2007 from 8.3 percent in 2002, while the rate for men aged 50-60 increased by 3.1 percentage points to 16.5 percent in 2007.
An increase in high blood lipid levels was not observed, however, in females of any age group, they said.
Higher levels of low density lipoprotein-cholesterol (LDL-C) , known as "bad" cholesterol, were found among both males and females between 2002 to 2007.

Men in the 30-40 age bracket saw the largest increase -- 4 percentage points -- among all age groups while the 0.7 percentage point increase seen in women aged 40-50 was the biggest among female age groups, the two found.

People who want to know whether they have high blood lipid levels should be checked for total cholesterol, LDC-C and high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C) and triglyceride levels after fasting for eight hours, Hwang said.
Individuals with a total cholesterol level above 200 mg/dl and a higher LDC-C level tend to have abnormally high levels of lipids, or fatty molecules, in the blood.

People with cardiovascular disease or diabetes should try to keep their LDC-C level below 100 mg/dl, while those with one or without any risk factor for developing cardiovascular disease should keep their LDC-C level below 160 mg/dl, and those with two or more risk factors should keep their LDC-C level below 130 mg/dl, Hwang added.
The blood test Saturday was held to mark Taiwan Blood Lipid Day, observed on the 100th day of every year.

The event aims to remind adults to have a blood lipid test done during their physical checkups and to promote the concept of exercising regularly, refraining from alcohol, and eating a balanced diet that is low in fat and high in fiber, Hwang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tzu Chi raises efficiency in bone marrow donor registry management

TEXT.P: The Buddhist Tzu Chi Foundation announced Sunday that newly added facilities will allow it to further increase efficiency in managing its bone marrow donor registry.

The foundation indicated that the improvement of its electronized network was made possible because of 60 computers donated by two of Taiwan's largest computer companies -- Asustek Computer Inc. and Acer Inc.

Tzu Chi Hospital staff often go to different places in northern, central and southern Taiwan to encourage members of the public to take a blood test and join the registry as potential bone marrow donors.

Previously they had to write down all initial information about potential donors and their blood test results before going back to their offices to enter the data in the registry. But now, with the new equipment that can be carried around with them, Tzu Chi medical workers can transmit the information electronically to the database directly on the spot.

At a ceremony held to inaugurate the new system, Shih Ming-huang, director of the Tzu Chi Bone Marrow and Stem Cell Center, said the improved electronized database will allow staff members to eliminate errors caused by unclear handwriting, shorten the time needed to find matching donors, and increase the success rate of bone marrow transplants.

Tzu Chi established the bone marrow donor registry in 1993 to help patients with blood diseases. The data bank has since become the largest marrow donor registry in Asia and the fifth largest in the world.
In 2002, the bone marrow registry was incorporated as a division of the Tzu Chi Stem Cells Center, which was founded to improve research and treatment of blood disease patients.
Tzu center's registry consists of information about 350,000 potential bone marrow donors and 11,000 units of umbilical cord blood.

The data bank has provided bone marrow and stem cells in 1,428 donation cases. The Hualien branch of Tzu Chi Hospital alone has conducted over 1,000 bone marrow extractions from donors to help patients in hospitals around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Man questioned by police for throwing out bank notes on freeway

TEXT.P: A man who threw a large number of NT$1,000 bills out of a taxi on the freeway was questioned by police in Changhua City Sunday.
Police found more than NT$920,000 and some partly burned notes in two bags the man was carrying after he was delivered to the Cihtong Police Station in Changhua City.
The man, identified only by his family name of Chen, grabbed a taxi at the Taichung railway station and asked the driver to take him to Changhua City.

As they were driving southbound on the freeway, the passenger began throwing NT$1,000 bills out the car window on to the road, which prompted the cab driver to take him to the police station. The police found him had lodged in a hotel in Changhua City last night and had triggered the fire alarm for burning bills in his room.

Last Wednesday, a man who hired a taxi to go from Chiayi to Sijhih in Taipei County, also threw money out of the window on the freeway, causing chaos when motorists stopped their cars to pick up the discarded money. The man who said that the money came from the sale of a piece of his land admitted to police that he had thrown bills out of cabs on freeway many times in different places.
Since throwing waste on highway is an offence which could be fined for NT$3000 (US$88)to NT$6000 (US$176), the man was referred to the freeway police for further questioning.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan passenger liner to serve Kaohsiung-Magong-Xiamen route

TEXT.P: China's Ministry of Transport has approved the application by Taiwan Navigation Co. to offer charter ferry services from the southern port of Kaohsiung to China's Xiamen, a coastal city in Fujian province, starting April 20, Wen Wei Po, a Hong Kong-based Chinese language newspaper reported Sunday.

The Taihua Ferry managed by the company will be allowed to carry passengers between the two destinations via Magong, the capital of the island county of Penghu, as Taiwan and China have yet to reach a formal agreement on opening direct passenger shipping links, according to the report.

The Taihua Ferry will sail four round trips between Kaohsiung and Xiamen by May 31. The ferry company estimates it will take four hours to sail from Kaohsiung to Magong and another six hours to get from Magong to Xiamen, based on an estimated speed of 20 knots per hour, the report said.

Operators of marine passenger liners have sought to explore the possibility of offering passenger service between Taiwan and China, as the 108 direct charter flights per week between the two countries cannot meet the demand created by an increase in Chinese visitor arrivals.
The 7,000 tickets available for the four round-trips were snapped up by a travel agency in Xiamen because of the cheap cost relative to airfares.
Because of the cheaper fare, the travel agent can offer a seven-day tour to Taiwan for only NT$19,600, according to Taiwan Navigation Co. general manager Ma Chi-chiang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 12, or the 17th day of the third month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1606: The Union Jack becomes the United Kingdom's official flag.
1860: Vajirananavarorasa, prince and patriarch of Buddhism in Siam, is born. He institutionalized Thai Buddhism.
1861: The U.S. Civil War breaks out as Confederate forces under Gen. Pierre Beauregarde take Fort Sumter in Charlestown harbor, South Carolina.
1927: The Kuomintang starts a "purification" movement by expelling communist members.
1945: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt dies in office at the age of 63. Vice President Harry S. Truman is sworn in as his successor.
1949: The 37.5 Per Cent Farm Rental Reduction Program goes into effect in Taiwan.
1953: The Legislative Yuan passes a bill submitted by President Chiang Kai-shek, extending the term of office for legislators by an additional year, to May 7, 1954.
1958: The first national meeting for commending "Good Men and Good Deeds" is held at Chung Shan Hall in Taipei.
1961: The Russians put the first man into space when cosmonaut Yauri Gargarin is launched in the Vostok I space vehicle for a single orbit of the earth.
1963: Indonesian forces launch an armed attack against Malaysia as part of a new policy of confrontation.
1966: Cheng Wan-fu, former chairman of the "Taiwan Democratic Party" and a leader of the "Taiwan Independence Movement" in Tokyo, returns to Taipei after 20 years of self-imposed exile in Japan.
1973: Deng Xiaoping, who was purged during the Cultural Revolution, resumes his position as the vice premier of Communist China.
1973: Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1974: Economic Affairs Vice Minister K.S. Chang, leading a group of government officials and businessmen, depart for San Francisco to attend a Sino-U.S. conference on economic relations.
1974: Tsinghwa University completes the installation of its second nuclear reactor for research purposes. This is the fourth research reactor installed in Taiwan.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan calls on the people to carry out the Last Testament of the late President Chiang Kai-shek.
1975: Taipei building contractors pledge NT$1 million to start a fund-raising campaign for the proposed Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.
1979: Taiwan's first geothermal power plant formally begins operations.
1981: Joe Louis, American prize fighter, dies at the age of 67. He held the heavyweight title for nearly 12 years (1937-1949), successfully defending it a record 25 times.
1981: Columbia, the world's first reusable space shuttle, is launched at Cape Canaveral.
1983: China Airlines inaugurates its regular flight service to Amsterdam as the first step toward establishing worldwide commercial air services.
1989: Honduran President Jose Azcona Hoyo and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1994: The Mainland Affairs Council decides to suspend all cultural and educational exchanges with the mainland until Beijing provides reasonable and satisfactory explanations for the Qiandao Lake tragedy of March 31 in which 24 Taiwan tourists were killed.
1996: The Petronas Towers in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, are declared the world's tallest buildings.
2000: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew meets with Guenter Rexrodt, a former German economics minister, to exchange views on bilateral relations between the two countries.
2001: an IBM-Linux Development Center is inaugurated in Taiwan. The center will provide local individual and group users with system testing, technical exchanges, experience sharing and training on using the Linux operating system.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are wise men who are not moral characters; but a fool is never a moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: Ultra-marathon champion embraces life after having leg amputated

TEXT.P: As recently as eight months ago, Chiu Chu-jung was Taiwan's most formidable female ultra-marathon runner. Competing around the world, in places as distant as Japan, New Zealand and Greece, Chiu challenged, and defeated, some of the best long-distance runners in the world.
She was looking to continue to her success in a 1,150-kilometer race through France in August 2008 when a blister began developing on her right foot.

The experienced runner ignored the minor irritant just as she had done many times in the past and persevered on. But bacteria that invaded her body through the broken blisters turned into a lethal blood poisoning disease that had doctors at a hospital in southern France fearing she might not survive.

Fortunately, a double amputation that took away her right leg above the knee and part of her left foot saved her life but has left Chiu to face the biggest athletic challenge of her life: simply running again.

The 52-year-old woman who almost ran effortlessly across deserts and up mountains is now fighting just to get back on her feet, pursuing the goal with the same determination that carried her through countless ultra-marathons, without any self-pity.

"So long as I am alive, everything will be OK," Chiu said at her home in Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan, where she has been receiving treatment and undergoing rehabilitation at Kaohsiung Medical University Chung-Ho Memorial Hospital since returning from France on Sept. 27, 2008.

Chiu has already started taking steps with the help of a walking assistance device as she begins her long trek back to the jogging trail, a place ironically she had no interest in for much of her young adult life.
Chiu, an office worker at Kaohsiung-based China Steel Corp. (CSC) , described herself as a woman who loved to dress well and who hated to be exposed to the sun to protect her skin.
It wasn't until the age of 37 that her athletic husband Lu Hua-chieh coaxed her into giving running a try, even though she had not been keen on exercising since her childhood.
Once she began to jog with her husband, however, Chiu realized she had a gift for long-distance running and was ready to pursue the activity for the rest of her life.
In her international competition debut at the 1996 Taipei International Marathon, she finished third in the women's competition.
In the following years, she experimented with different distances in races in Taiwan, from 10 kilometers to the marathon-length 42.195 km.

She then tried longer races spanning 50 km., 80 km. and 100 km. as well as endurance tests of 12 hours, 24 hours, 36 hours, seven days/seven nights, and 18 days and now is the Taiwanese female record-holder in most of those events.

In March 2008, she further broke the Asian record for the seven days/seven nights event previously held by Japanese runner Hiroko Okiyama, in an international ultra-marathon in Greece. Running 785 km. in seven days and seven nights, eclipsing Okiyama's record of 752 km., she finished second in the race among 52 runners.
It was five months later, however, that Chiu met her match, not on the race course but from an invisible bacteria.

Chiu, described as being able to run farther, longer and better than any other woman in Taiwan, joined the "Transe Gaule" race in France Aug. 13, which required her to run from Roscoff, a small fishing village on the northwestern French coast, to the sunny tourist resort of Gruissan-Plage on the Mediterranean coast in 18 days.

Though she suffered from blisters from the beginning of the race, it wasn't until the 16th day that she began to feel weak. Still, she insisted on completing the event and ended up 17th among all 44 runners and second in the women's division, covering the 1,150-km. distance in 125 hours, 7 minutes and 24 seconds.

Only after the race did she discover how serious her condition was. Three different kinds of pathogenic bacteria had invaded her body through the broken blisters, causing a serious infection that eventually turned into a deadly form of septicemia, or blood poisoning.

Fearing that Chiu would not survive, doctors at a Montpellier hospital amputated her right leg and bottom half of her left foot and also scraped most of the flesh from the remaining leg in an effort to stop the infection from spreading.

Her strong will that had carried her through so many long-distance challenges helped keep her alive, and even today, Chiu does not blame anyone or fate for her loss, even admitting that ignoring the blister at the time was perfectly natural behavior because blisters are such a common occurrence among ultra-marathon runners.

She only recalls the physical pain she felt lying on a hospital bed because she had no skin and was not allowed to move, but returning to Taiwan had great therapeutic value, because, as she said, "so long as I was coming home, there would be hope."
Before Christmas last year, Chiu checked out of the Kaohsiung hospital and returned home, ending her "most unforgettable journey" to begin a new one.
The "Ultra-Marathon Mom" as she's known can now stand and walk a few steps with the help of a prosthetic leg made for her.
Her next step, Chiu said, is to "start learning from the beginning" in the hope of returning to her old running haunts.
"I am now in an ultra-marathon race of my own, " acknowledged Chiu, with the destination the ability to run again.
She figures the discipline she learned in long-distance running will serve her well in her latest journey.
"The only secret of success in running is to persist until the very end, " said Chiu, who now has set a longer-term of participating in the Paralympic Games one day in the future.
"Life is long. One should not give up or be pessimistic (because of some tribulations)."

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet estimates 80% rise in tourism revenues by 2012

TEXT.P: The Cabinet has mapped out a four-year plan to raise the quality of Taiwan's tourism environment that it expects will boost revenues from international tourists by 80 percent in four years, the Tourism Bureau disclosed in a report released Sunday.

In the analysis of Taiwan's tourist industry, the bureau said that in 2007, international tourists spent US$5.1 billion in Taiwan, accounting for 1.34 percent of Taiwan's gross domestic product -- better than the United States, Canada, Germany, Japan, South Korea and China.
The planned campaign aims to increase annual tourism revenues to US$9 billion by 2012, accounting for more than 2 percent of Taiwan's GDP, according to the report.
The plan is expected to increase the number of international tourist arrivals by an average of up to 4 percent each year -- from 4.1 million in 2009 to 5.5 million in 2012.

Visitors from Japan will continue to constitute the biggest segment of international tourist arrivals in 2009 and 2010, estimated to reach 1.09 million and 1.1 million respectively in those two years.

The number of visitors from China, however, is expected to grow rapidly, rising from 320,000 in 2009 to 700,000 in 2010, and again to 1.2 million in 2011 to be on par with tourist arrivals from Japan in that year.
But in 2012, the number of tourists from China is expected to rise to 1.5 million, surpassing the number of visitors from Japan for the first time.

Other estimated international tourist arrivals in 2012 are 1.18 million from Hong Kong, Singapore and Malaysia; 720,000 from Europe, North America and Australia; and 290,000 from South Korea, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRA a positive force in U.S.-Taiwan-China relations: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou on Sunday said the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) has not only symbolized the strong friendship and trust between the United States and Taiwan over the past three decades, but will continue to serve as a strong foundation for relations among the U.S., Taiwan and China in the future.

The TRA has served to anchor peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait for the past three decades, " Ma said in English at the opening ceremony of an international conference on the TRA and its prospects on its 30th anniversary.
"Its very existence changed the evolutionary course of cross-strait development by stabilizing the trilateral relationship among Taiwan, the U.S. and mainland China,he said.

Describing the TRA as thesecond best choicein an imperfect world, the president said the TRA has served to accommodate Taiwan's needs by keeping all aspects of U.S.-Taiwan relations intact despite Washington's switching of diplomatic recognition from the Republic of China to the People's Republic of China in 1979.
The TRA also created a resilient triangular framework for relations among U.S., Taiwan and China, he added.
This resilience, or dynamic status quo, is of crucial importance for peace and stability for East Asia,Ma said.
Enacted by the U.S. Congress April 10, 1979, the TRA has been the sole legal document on the United States side governing bilateral relations.

The act requires the U.S. to guarantee defensive arms sales to Taiwan and to maintain the capacity of the U.S. to resist any resort to force or other forms of coercion that would jeopardize the security, or the social or economic system, of the people of Taiwan.
It does not require the U.S. to intervene militarily if the People' Republic of China attacks or invades Taiwan.

Speaking of current cross-Taiwan Strait relations, President Ma said that his administration's continuous efforts to improve relations with Beijing since last May not only put an end to bilateral diplomatic belligerency in favor of substantive economic cooperation, but also demonstrated to the world that Taiwan wants to be a responsible peacemaker instead of troublemaker in the region.

With the resilience of the TRA and the ever-warming relations with China, especially on the economic front, Ma said this new equilibrium will create a win-win-win situation for the U.S., Taiwan, and China to solve complex issues through cooperation.
Describing U.S.-Taiwan-China relations as a train, Ma said he hoped that they will continue to remain on the right track and move smoothly forward.

As part of the celebration of the 30th anniversary of the passage of the TRA, the April 12 international conference was held by the nongovernmental National Policy Foundation and the Cross-Strait Interflow Prospect Foundation.
More than 300 government officials, dignitaries and political experts from home and abroad are attending the conference to look back at the act and discuss new ways to enhance U.S.-Taiwan relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to allow more Chinese tourist arrivals for Labor Day holiday

TEXT.P: The National Immigration Agency will increase the daily quota of Chinese tourists allowed to visit Taiwan beginning April 16 in response to an anticipated increase in Chinese visitor arrivals for the May 1 Labor Day holiday, local tourism operators said Sunday.

Most tour buses and three- and four-star hotels in Taiwan are fully booked until the end of May as an increase in Chinese tourist arrivals is expected ahead of the holiday, according to Hsu Kao-ching, secretary-general of the Tourism Business Association in Taiwan.

Under an agreement reached by Taiwan and China last June, the number of Chinese allowed to visit Taiwan is capped at 3,000 per day, but arrivals in late April and May are expected to exceed that number.
Hsu said the agency will draw from the 170,000 quota slots that went unused during the first three months of 2009 to provide additional spots beyond the daily cap to meet demand.
The National Immigration Agency anticipates approving about 500 Chinese visitor applications more than the cap allows per day, or a total of 5,500, during the last two weeks of April.

The balance of 164,500 unused slots from the first quarter will be allocated during other peak travel periods as necessary if applications from Chinese visitors to travel in Taiwan exceeds the visitor ceiling.

Hsu said that as more Chinese apply to come to Taiwan, the Immigration Agency's manpower has grown tight, and that while it would accept all applications filed during work hours, the maximum number of applications it can approve in one day is limited to 4,311.
A number of Chinese tourist groups are slated to arrive in the next six weeks that will likely push their numbers above the established cap.

A group of 20,000 people from a senior citizens' association in China is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan in May in separate batches, making it the largest ever Chinese tourist group to visit Taiwan, Hsu said.
He indicated that the group will apply to visit on a special-case basis so as not to count against the daily visitor quota.
A 900-member group from China's Fujian province will visit Taiwan April 15 after arriving in the Taiwan island county of Kinmen via a ferry between the island and Xiamen in Fujian.

After flying to Taiwan and touring the island, they will take the Taihua Ferry traveling from Kaohsiung Harbor to Magong in the island county of Penghu April 20 before heading home the next day, Hsu added.

Also, several groups each composed of some 100 travelers from Guangxi and Zhejiang provinces and Hainan Island, and tourism industry representatives from various provinces in China, are expected to attend the 2009 Taipei International Tourism Exposition scheduled to open May 22 at the Taipei World Trade Center, said Ding Lai, deputy secretary-general of the Taipei Association of Travel Agents.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRC should give Taiwan more international space: former U.S. official

TEXT.P: A former top-ranking U.S. official said Sunday in Taipei that given the warming relations between Taiwan and China, Beijing should take further steps to give Taiwan more space in the international community, calling progress on this issue "critical."

Winston Lord, former assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, also asserted that Washington, while continuing to adhere to its commitments to China and Taiwan, should not play a role in mediating problems between the sides.

In a keynote speech at an international conference on the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) 30 years after it was enacted, Lord contended that current cross-Taiwan Strait relations are the most steady and promising -- if not prosperous -- in sixty years, but "there is never room for complacency."
The most immediate issue regarding future moves by Taipei and Beijing, he said, is international space for Taiwan.

While the Chinese have loosened up somewhat and seem to be entertaining flexibility on Taiwan's participation in the World Health Organization, Lord said Beijing should move fromhalting, limited steps to a more forthcoming posture, there and elsewhere, consistent with Taiwan's dignity and stature.

This can be reconciled with Beijing's principles if it has the will to do so, Lord said.Progress on this issue is critical -- both on the merits of the case and to show the Taiwan people that President Ma Ying-jeou's initiatives are bearing fruit.
China's position on security issues is also cause for concern, according to the former diplomat.

Lord said it might be hoped that increasing economic ties, bilateral dialogue and general momentum will lead to progress in this area, but the picture so far is not encouraging, as a recent Pentagon report indicated that China continues to build up its missile force and its general military capabilities.
In addition, fleeting references to confidence-building measures have not yielded concrete steps either, said Lord, who now serves as the chairman emeritus of the International Rescue Committee.

On the issue of Taiwan's sovereignty, Lord said the two sides of the Taiwan Strait need to seek ways to continue obfuscating the problem, adding that China has shown some patience on the sovereignty issue -- perhaps in the belief that time is on its side.

Noting that there is a clear popular consensus in Taiwan that drawing closer to the People's Republic of China (PRC) can only be envisioned if the mainland's political system becomes more open, pluralistic and free, the former top-ranking U.S. official seemed cautiously optimistic in this area.
I am hopeful that China will move toward greater transparency and liberty -- not as a concession to the West but as the proven route to a brighter future,Lord said.

As to the U.S. role in relations among Washington, Beijing and Taipei, Lord said the U.S. should continue to foster a positive environment for progress through deft diplomacy incorporating both encouragement and admonition, as well as adhere to its commitments to the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The U.S. should not, however, mediate in any fashion, even in the highly unlikely event that the two sides sought to cast America in that role, Lord said, because the future relationship between Taiwan and the PRC should be resolved between themdirectly, peacefully and with the support of the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRA still serves U.S. interests in Taiwan: former AIT director

TEXT.P: Three decades after the enactment of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) , the U.S. domestic law still serves the interests of the United States in Taiwan, despite the many political, economic, and strategic changes that have occurred, a former U.S. diplomat said Sunday.

From political, economic and strategic perspectives, the United States retains strong but changing interests in its unofficial relations with Taiwan, said Douglas Paal, former director of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Taipei Office, at an international conference to mark the 30th anniversary of the TRA in Taipei.

The instrument of the TRA, accompanied by confidence in the wisdom of the people of Taiwan expressed through ballot box democracy, is a source of reassurance for both America and Taiwan going forward,he added.
Enacted by the U.S. Congress April 10, 1979, the TRA has been the sole U.S. legal document governing bilateral relations with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

The act requires the U.S. to guarantee defensive arms sales to Taiwan and to maintain the capacity of the U.S. to resist any resort to force or other forms of coercion that would jeopardize the security, or the social or economic system, of the people of Taiwan.
It does not require the U.S. to intervene militarily if the People's Republic of China attacks or invades Taiwan.

According to Paal, U.S. calculations have changed enormously since 1979, because politically, the U.S. sense of Taiwan as a plucky, stalwart outpost of freedom against tyranny has eroded, while economically, China's trade with Taiwan and the U.S. has grown significantly from 1979 levels.

He said America still has important strategic interests in Taiwan because how China's policy toward Taiwan evolves can be a strategic signal as to how China wants to interact with America and the world.

Also, how China's leaders manage the views in China that "reunification" with the island would be an important component of Beijing's new maritime assertiveness and promote better relations with Taipei can be indicators of China's strategic ambitions, he added.
Beijing's handling of Taipei's desire for participation in international organizations like the World Health Assembly will also give the U.S. indications of Chinese intentions, according to Paal.
So far, there is much to be reassured about in China's recent dealings with Taiwan, yet there are still sources of concern. The picture remains mixed,Paal said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Experts launch renewed efforts to conserve rare fish species

TEXT.P: The government has enlisted the help of four academics to launch another effort to conserve the Formosan landlocked salmon -- a critically endangered indigenous species -- later this month, officials of the Ministry of the Interior disclosed Sunday.

The officials at the Construction and Planning Agency said that an initial survey by the four experts showed that the Luoyewei River in the Sheipa National Park in central Taiwan is an ideal environment where artificially bred young fry of the species can be released.

The Formosan landlocked salmon -- a holdover from the last Ice Age -- has been designated as a national treasure. The salmon became landlocked during the last glacial epoch in frigid mountain streams, and thus its discovery in Taiwan -- a subtropical island -- is considered a biological miracle.
A survey conducted last October showed that after five successive typhoons stuck central Taiwan in 2008, the number of the fish in Taiwan's mountain streams dropped from some 5,300 to 3,600.
The four academics in charge of the new conservation efforts are ecologist Lin Sin-Chu, ichthyologist Tseng Ching-hsien, aquaculture expert Huang Yi-syun, and river expert Ye Chao-sian.

They have found that the 11.4-kilometer river along the 2,700-meter-high Luoyewei Mountain has many deep ponds with agreeable temperatures and suitable oxygen levels that provide ideal new habitats for the rare fish.

The officials said that the new conservation efforts became necessary because the 1,280 artificially bred young fish released in a number of rivers in the national park between 2006 and 2008 had a survival rate of less than 1 percent, mainly because of the typhoons last year.
Most of the existing fish are found in the Cijiawan river, a protected sanctuary for the Formosan landlocked salmon in the Sheipa National Park.

Formosan landlocked salmon grow to about 30 centimeters in length and inhabit cold, slow-flowing streams with gently sloping beds at elevations above 1,500 meters, such as the Cijiawan river upstream from the Dajia River.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
No change of TRA needed for warming Taiwan-China ties: U.S. scholars

TEXT.P: There is no need to amend the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) or replace it with a new one to adjust to new realities in Taiwan or to changing relations with China because it has and will continue to serve United States interests, U.S. scholars said Sunday.

They were in Taipei attending a conference on the significance of the TRA 30 years after it was enacted, and Bonnie Glaser, a senior associate at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, asserted that the TRA continued to be in Washington's interests.

In her speech on the future direction of the TRA and its implications for cross- Taiwan Strait relations, Glaser said the TRA does not need to be amended because it addresses U.S. policy interests, not outcomes, and its efficacy has not been affected substantially by shifting U.S.-China-Taiwan dynamics.
The TRA endures because it serves the U.S.interest, she said.

Alan Romberg, a distinguished fellow and director of the East Asia Program of the Henry L. Stimson Center, echoed Glaser's view, saying that the TRA has been interpreted and applied as a very useful statement of U.S. policy and a point of reference.

The fact that the U.S. has maintained that policy through all these years regardless of many changes in the situation is a testament to its correctness from the perspective of American interests,he said.
Enacted by the U.S. Congress April 10, 1979, the TRA has been the sole U.S. legal document governing Washington's bilateral relations with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

The act requires the U.S. to guarantee defensive arms sales to Taiwan and to maintain the capacity of the U.S. to resist any resort to force or other forms of coercion that would jeopardize the security, or the social or economic system, of the people of Taiwan.
It does not require the U.S. to intervene militarily if the People's Republic of China attacks or invades Taiwan.

Drew Thompson, director of China Studies and a senior fellow of the U.S. think tank Nixon Center, contended that the TRA is unlikely to change in the future as it continues to serve its intended purpose to help maintain peace, security and stability in the Western Pacific.

The ambiguity encapsulated in the TRA benefits Taiwan. Changing it, in my opinion, would not improve Taiwan's condition, nor would it necessarily further the unique U.S.-Taiwan relationship, Thompson said.
Changing it could potentially embolden China and increase anxiety in Taiwan,he added.

The scholars also seemed to agree that closer cooperation between Taiwan and China serves U.S. interests because the consistent objective of U.S. policy is to preserve cross-strait peace and stability.

That goal has been advanced by the initiatives that President Ma Ying-jeou has taken toward China over the past year, and the U.S. should continue to support his approach, which has the support of a majority of the Taiwanese people, the scholars argued.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese woman advances to doubles final of clay court event

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Chuang Chia-jung, who has been unable to sustain her top 10 doubles ranking playing with a variety of partners after splitting with compatriot Chan Yung-jan, seems to have found a good fit with India's Sania Mirza.

One week after the duo reached the semifinals of women's doubles at the prestigious Sony Ericsson Open, Chuang and Mirza reached the finals of the MPS Group Championships in Florida by defeating Liga Dekmeijere of Latvia and Angela Haynes of the U.S. 6-4, 6-3 in Saturday's semis.

In the final of the clay court event, Chuang and Mirza will face top seeds Czech Kveta Peschke and American Lisa Raymond, the same duo that knocked them out at the Sony Ericsson Open in two tight sets.

Chuang was ranked as high as No. 5 in the world in doubles during her nearly 20-month collaboration with Chan, which ended at last year's U.S. Open after a failed bid for an Olympic medal at the Beijing Summer Olympics in 2008.

Her ranking has fallen since the split, but Chuang is now back up to No. 17 in the world and could move up another two slots if she and Mirza capture the MPS Group Championships title Sunday in the U.S. By Luke Sabatier

DOC.HEADLINE: Young men show highest increase in abnormal blood lipid levels

TEXT.P: Young and middle-aged men are the two groups that have exhibited the highest rate of increase in abnormal blood lipid levels in recent years, two cardiologists said at a health promotion event in Taipei Saturday.

Nearly 80 percent of the more than 200 people who had their blood fat tested at the event Saturday were found to have abnormally high blood lipid levels, which can contribute to cardiovascular disease and diabetes.

Chiang Fu-tien, president of the Taiwan Society of Cardiology, and Hwang Juey- jen, deputy chief executive of Taiwan Heart Foundation, said at the event that blood fat levels have been on the rise among men in recent years.

Based on the results of blood lipid tests done in 2002 and 2007, the percent of men aged 30-40 who have high blood fat levels rose to 10.4 percent in 2007 from 8.3 percent in 2002, while the rate for men aged 50-60 increased by 3.1 percentage points to 16.5 percent in 2007.
An increase in high blood lipid levels was not observed, however, in females of any age group, they said.
Higher levels of low density lipoprotein-cholesterol (LDL-C) , known as "bad" cholesterol, were found among both males and females between 2002 to 2007.

Men in the 30-40 age bracket saw the largest increase -- 4 percentage points -- among all age groups while the 0.7 percentage point increase seen in women aged 40-50 was the biggest among female age groups, the two found.

People who want to know whether they have high blood lipid levels should be checked for total cholesterol, LDC-C and high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C) and triglyceride levels after fasting for eight hours, Hwang said.
Individuals with a total cholesterol level above 200 mg/dl and a higher LDC-C level tend to have abnormally high levels of lipids, or fatty molecules, in the blood.

People with cardiovascular disease or diabetes should try to keep their LDC-C level below 100 mg/dl, while those with one or without any risk factor for developing cardiovascular disease should keep their LDC-C level below 160 mg/dl, and those with two or more risk factors should keep their LDC-C level below 130 mg/dl, Hwang added.
The blood test Saturday was held to mark Taiwan Blood Lipid Day, observed on the 100th day of every year.

The event aims to remind adults to have a blood lipid test done during their physical checkups and to promote the concept of exercising regularly, refraining from alcohol, and eating a balanced diet that is low in fat and high in fiber, Hwang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tzu Chi raises efficiency in bone marrow donor registry management

TEXT.P: The Buddhist Tzu Chi Foundation announced Sunday that newly added facilities will allow it to further increase efficiency in managing its bone marrow donor registry.

The foundation indicated that the improvement of its electronized network was made possible because of 60 computers donated by two of Taiwan's largest computer companies -- Asustek Computer Inc. and Acer Inc.

Tzu Chi Hospital staff often go to different places in northern, central and southern Taiwan to encourage members of the public to take a blood test and join the registry as potential bone marrow donors.

Previously they had to write down all initial information about potential donors and their blood test results before going back to their offices to enter the data in the registry. But now, with the new equipment that can be carried around with them, Tzu Chi medical workers can transmit the information electronically to the database directly on the spot.

At a ceremony held to inaugurate the new system, Shih Ming-huang, director of the Tzu Chi Bone Marrow and Stem Cell Center, said the improved electronized database will allow staff members to eliminate errors caused by unclear handwriting, shorten the time needed to find matching donors, and increase the success rate of bone marrow transplants.

Tzu Chi established the bone marrow donor registry in 1993 to help patients with blood diseases. The data bank has since become the largest marrow donor registry in Asia and the fifth largest in the world.
In 2002, the bone marrow registry was incorporated as a division of the Tzu Chi Stem Cells Center, which was founded to improve research and treatment of blood disease patients.
Tzu center's registry consists of information about 350,000 potential bone marrow donors and 11,000 units of umbilical cord blood.

The data bank has provided bone marrow and stem cells in 1,428 donation cases. The Hualien branch of Tzu Chi Hospital alone has conducted over 1,000 bone marrow extractions from donors to help patients in hospitals around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Man questioned by police for throwing out bank notes on freeway

TEXT.P: A man who threw a large number of NT$1,000 bills out of a taxi on the freeway was questioned by police in Changhua City Sunday.
Police found more than NT$920,000 and some partly burned notes in two bags the man was carrying after he was delivered to the Cihtong Police Station in Changhua City.
The man, identified only by his family name of Chen, grabbed a taxi at the Taichung railway station and asked the driver to take him to Changhua City.

As they were driving southbound on the freeway, the passenger began throwing NT$1,000 bills out the car window on to the road, which prompted the cab driver to take him to the police station. The police found him had lodged in a hotel in Changhua City last night and had triggered the fire alarm for burning bills in his room.

Last Wednesday, a man who hired a taxi to go from Chiayi to Sijhih in Taipei County, also threw money out of the window on the freeway, causing chaos when motorists stopped their cars to pick up the discarded money. The man who said that the money came from the sale of a piece of his land admitted to police that he had thrown bills out of cabs on freeway many times in different places.
Since throwing waste on highway is an offence which could be fined for NT$3000 (US$88)to NT$6000 (US$176), the man was referred to the freeway police for further questioning.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan passenger liner to serve Kaohsiung-Magong-Xiamen route

TEXT.P: China's Ministry of Transport has approved the application by Taiwan Navigation Co. to offer charter ferry services from the southern port of Kaohsiung to China's Xiamen, a coastal city in Fujian province, starting April 20, Wen Wei Po, a Hong Kong-based Chinese language newspaper reported Sunday.

The Taihua Ferry managed by the company will be allowed to carry passengers between the two destinations via Magong, the capital of the island county of Penghu, as Taiwan and China have yet to reach a formal agreement on opening direct passenger shipping links, according to the report.

The Taihua Ferry will sail four round trips between Kaohsiung and Xiamen by May 31. The ferry company estimates it will take four hours to sail from Kaohsiung to Magong and another six hours to get from Magong to Xiamen, based on an estimated speed of 20 knots per hour, the report said.

Operators of marine passenger liners have sought to explore the possibility of offering passenger service between Taiwan and China, as the 108 direct charter flights per week between the two countries cannot meet the demand created by an increase in Chinese visitor arrivals.
The 7,000 tickets available for the four round-trips were snapped up by a travel agency in Xiamen because of the cheap cost relative to airfares.
Because of the cheaper fare, the travel agent can offer a seven-day tour to Taiwan for only NT$19,600, according to Taiwan Navigation Co. general manager Ma Chi-chiang.
