DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan stocks reach 7-month high, post 7th weekly gain

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices moved above the 5,800 point mark to a seven-month high Monday, following seven straight weekly gains.

The weighted index, the market's key barometer, advanced 75.68 points, or 1.3 percent, to close at 5,857.64, boosted by the Legislative Yuan's passage of the Cabinet's NT$500 billion economic stimulus package Friday.
Taiwan's stock market rose 252.33 points, or 4.56 percent, last week.
Finishing higher for the third consecutive session, the local bourse opened at 5,814.17 and fluctuated between 5,861.11 and 5,784.10.
A total of 7.21 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$148.58 billion (US$4.41 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction stocks moving up the most at 4.4 percent. Foodstuff shares gained 3.4 percent, textile shares surged 2.3 percent, cement issues advanced 1.6 percent, machinery and electronics shares rose 1.3 percent, plastics and chemicals shares gained 0.9 percent, paper and pulp issues closed up 0.6 percent, and banking and financial issues rose 0.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,397 to 713, with 139 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$7.30 billion.
One analyst predicted that the market would sustain its upward movement because of an increase in export orders in March coupled with sufficient liquidity.

DOC.HEADLINE: New tunnel shortens travel time between two Nantou County villages

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou inaugurated a newly completed tunnel in central Taiwan's Nantou County Monday that shortens the travel time between two mountain villages from two hours to just six minutes.

Ma cut a ribbon at the ceremony to mark the official opening of the 361-meter tunnel, which is on Nantou County Highway No. 83 linking the villages of Wanfeng and Fachih -- both located in Jenai township -- and connected with Nantou County Highway No. 71.

The aboriginal residents of both villages belong to the Bunun tribe, although the two villages are separated by a mountain. For nearly 30 years, residents of each village had to spend two hours making a detour through Puli township if they wanted to visit the other settlement.

Nantou Magistrate Lee Chao-ching sought help with the issue from the central government and received NT$183 million for the project, which covers 2.16 km of roadway, including a 90-meter bridge and the 361-meter tunnel.
County government officials pointed out that the opening of the Wanfeng Tunnel has also made sightseeing trips between Nantou County's scenic areas more convenient.

Visitors can travel from Puli to the Lushan tourist resort and to Chingjing Farm through Wushe on the outward trip, returning through the Aowanda Forest Recreational Park and taking Nantou County Highway No. 83 to Wanfeng village. From there, they can go through the new tunnel to Fachih village and then take Nantou County Highway No. 71 back to Puli, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fish procreation in Kenting area effective: researcher

TEXT.P: Fish procreation at the Houpihu area in the Kenting National Park in southern Taiwan's Pingtung County has shown signs of initial progress as the number of fish species has increased from 50 to 178 over the past four years, a specialist said Monday.

"Immersing in the sea near Houpihu, one now can see thousands of fish swimming around, including damsel fish, five flute porgies, butterfly fish and groupers, " said M. S. Jeng, a researcher at the Biodiversity Research Center under Taiwan's top research institute Academia Sinica.

He attributed the development to a 0.5-hectare "fish- feeding zone" at the Houpihu coastal area in Hengchun township, along with the establishment of a marine resources conservation district in 2005 by the center in collaboration with the Kenting National Park Administration and local diving businesses.
Since then, an agreement was reached among the parties concerned allowing divers to give bread pieces to fish in the feeding zone while banning divers from catching fish at the zone, Jeng said.
Doing so has helped lure large flocks of a wide variety of fish to the zone and boost revenue for tourism-related businesses, according to Jeng.
For 2006 alone, local diving businesses at Houpihu earned an additional NT$1 million (US$30,000), he said.
However, Jeng stressed that feeding is not a correct way to attract and preserve fish because it may easily lead fish to lose its natural ability to seek nutrients by itself.
"It is unnecessary to feed fish to preserve it if local marine resources are rich enough," he noted.

But Jeng said human efforts to protect the environment and help conserve fish are also important. More diversified fish species and undersea resources will also woo more tourists and increase tourism revenues, he explained.

Meanwhile, a "coral reef preservation week" co-sponsored by the Kenting National Park and the ROC (Republic of China) Society for Reef Studies kicked off Monday with an aim of building public awareness of the importance of environmental protection.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung Mayor arrives in Hong Kong for five-day visit
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/09 18:26:02 (By Mandy Wong and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Traveling at the head of a 90-member group of city officials and business executives, Taichung Mayor Jason Hu arrived in Hong Kong Monday for a five-day visit -- the latest sign of recent efforts by Taiwan and Hong Kong to build long-stalled relations since Taiwan-China ties have improved.

Apart from calling on Hong Kong Chief Executive Donald Tsang, Secretary of the Constitutional and Mainland Affairs Bureau Stephan Lam and other Hong Kong officials, Hu will also attend a forum co-sponsored Wednesday by Taichung City and Hong Kong to boost two-way exchanges.
Delegates from the two sides will discuss in the forum issues related to stepping up cooperation between Taichung and Hong Kong in trade, commerce, tourism, culture and city management.

On Thursday, Hu will take part in a "2009 Taichung tea party" organized by the Hong Kong office of the Taipei-based Taiwan Visitors Association, and in other activities arranged by Hong Kong tourism promotion authorities before flying back to Taiwan Friday.
The Hong Kong government decided in early January to establish a forum to boost exchanges with Taiwan's cities on a regular basis, with Taichung City selected as its first partner.
A second meeting of the "Taichung-Hong Kong city exchange forum" will be held in Taichung City, central Taiwan in the coming months.
The Hong Kong government hopes to further advance interactions with cities in Taiwan through the platform set up in the forum, a spokesman said.

Hu last visited Hong Kong in early January, along with three other local government chiefs from central Taiwan -- Taichung Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng, Changhua Magistrate Cho Po-yuan and Nantou Magistrate Lee Chao-ching.

Hu said during the last visit to Hong Kong that he noticed a great change in the Hong Kong government's attitude toward Taiwan, as Hong Kong officials he met during public occasions all showed keen interest in improving relations with Taiwan.
"I used to be able to meet Hong Kong officials in a private capacity only," he noted.

Hu's ongoing trip to Hong Kong follows that of Hong Kong's Home Affairs Secretary Tsang Tak-sing, who visited Taipei March 31-April 2 for an international Buddhist forum. He was the first senior Hong Kong official to visit Taiwan since Hong Kong's 1997 handover to China.

Analysts have told reporters recently that Hong Kong's hands had been tied in terms of building relations with Taiwan during the eight-years of tense relations between Beijing and Taipei under former Taiwanese president Chen Shui- bian's rule.

Relations between Taiwan and China have significantly improved since Taiwan's resident Ma Ying-jeou came into office in May last year. Hong Kong, a British colony until 1997, is a special administrative region of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Quarantine, IPR on agricultural products to be included in ECFA

TEXT.P: In any cross-Taiwan Strait trade pact talks that take place in the future, topics concerning agricultural affairs will focus on quarantine and relevant testing of livestock and plants, as well as intellectual property rights (IPR) protection for Taiwanese agricultural products, the vice minister of the Cabinet-level Council of Agricultural Affairs (COA) said Monday.

Huang Yu-tsai made the remarks at a meeting held by the Legislative Yuan Economics Committee with the authorities who are working on the proposed signing of a cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).

In a briefing to the committee on the COA's preparations for talks with China on the proposed pact, Huang pointed out that as China is listed as an affected area for many insect pests that affect fruit, as well as avian influenza and foot- and-mouth disease, Taiwan must ensure that such pests and diseases are not imported via cross-strait trading channels.

The two sides of the strait must establish a mutual reporting system for plant and animal disease outbreaks, and other operational mechanisms involving quarantine examination and investigation, as well as procedures for negotiations concerning the export and import of agricultural products, he said.
Huang stressed that the council will do all it can to protect Taiwan's agricultural benefits during the ECFA talks.

President Ma Ying-jeou's administration has been working to promote the signing of an ECFA with China, reasoning that when China enters a free trade arrangement with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) member countries -- the so-called ASEAN Plus One scheduled to be established in 2010 -- tariffs on 93 percent of the products traded among the pact signatories will be removed.

To avoid Taiwan being marginalized by this development -- as it would not be involved in any ASEAN tariff reductions -- the government has been heavily promoting the ECFA, in spite of strong protests by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, which is against any signing of such an agreement with China.

Speaking at the same meeting, Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming said that only once the two sides of the Taiwan Strait achieve common consensus on the proposed ECFA will it be time for them to decide the actual content of such a pact.
Such a content finalization "would be soon, maybe in one or two months" after they begin studying the proposal together, according to Yiin.
He made the remarks in response to questions by Legislator Ting Shou-Chung of the ruling Kuomintang.
The two sides began a three-month period of individual studies last month on the proposed ECFA, a precursor to the stage of joint research, Yiin said.

During the individual study stage, Yiin noted, the government is trying to exchange views on details of the proposal with its Chinese counterpart on every possible occasion, including international conferences and academic workshops.

He further said that the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has entrusted the Taipei-based Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research to review the latest research and assessments involving the proposed cross-strait cooperation agreement.
The government "will not just take the positive aspects into consideration but will also consider the possible negative effects" of such an economic cooperation pact, he added.

When the two sides reach the stage of forging an agreement, they will conduct the signing on the negotiation platform of their respective intermediary bodies -- Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation and the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits -- under the World Trade Organization framework, Yiin stated.
He also revealed that ECFA activities will start with trading in commodities.

According to the MOEA, six stages must be completed before an ECFA with China can be put into effect, including separate assessments by each side, a joint assessment, negotiations, the signing of the agreement, legislative approval and finally, implementation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Satisfaction over quality of life rises: survey

TEXT.P: The public satisfaction level with quality of life has risen by 12.2 percentage points compared with figures compiled in a survey carried out a year ago, according to the latest survey results released Monday.
The Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission targeted 19 areas to be tackled by the survey, conducted nearly one year after the May 20 inauguration of President Ma Ying-jeou.
Overall, 69.9 percent of the respondents said they were satisfied with their quality of life, up 12.2 percent from last year's survey.
In comparison, 26.5 percent said they were dissatisfied, down by around 5 percentage points from the previous year.

The top four areas to receive the greatest degrees of satisfaction were listed as clean environment around the home (80.1 percent), convenient transport around the home (79.9 percent) , the ability of water drainage systems around the home to cope with flood conditions (78.1 percent), and family life (77.9 percent).

The survey also found that the respondents were dissatisfied with the life-long learning environment (25.2 percent), the amount and quality of social activities available (31.2 percent), current working conditions (45.7 percent), and the education environment for students (45.4 percent).
The survey was conducted around the country March 24-25 and collected 1,080 effective samples with an error margin of plus or minus 3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese captures first doubles title with non-Taiwanese partner

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Chuang Chia-jung and India's Sania Mirza exacted a small measure of revenge Sunday when they defeated top seeds Czech Kveta Peschke and American Lisa Raymond to capture the MPS Group Championships women's doubles in Ponte Vedra Beach, Florida.
Chuang and Mirza were ousted by Peschke and Raymond from the seminfinals of the Sony Ericsson Open in two tight sets in early April, but returned the favor Sunday in a tense 6-3, 4-6, 10-7 victory.
It was Chuang's 11th career doubles title on the WTA tour, but her first with a non-Taiwanese partner.

Chuang is best known for her partnership with compatriot Chan Yung-jen on the "Golden Doubles Team" that reached the finals of the Australian Open and U.S. Open women's doubles in 2007 and won seven WTA Tour events from 2007 to 2008.
But after having their dreams of an Olympic medal extinguished in the second round of the Beijing Summer Games and losing in the first run of the 2008 U.S. Open, the two split.

Chuang then successfully teamed with compatriot Hsieh Su-wei at the end of 2008 to win one tour event in Seoul and a lower tier ITF event in Taipei, but in 2009 she has stuck with foreign partners, first Sun Tiantian of China at the Australian Open, then Akgul Amanmuradova of Uzbekistan and now Mirza, who seems to be the best fit.

Playing for only the third time together, the unseeded duo knocked out the tournament's first and fourth seeds and showed the ability to raise their games in the clutch, winning two super tiebreakers in their four matches during the week.

Against Peschke and Raymond, Chuang and Mirza quickly jumped to a 5-1 lead in the first-to-10 super tiebreaker and were able to hold on after their opponents pulled to within 7-6 to capture the title, which earned them a total of US$11,000 and 280 ranking points each.
The victory propelled Chuang up to No. 14 in the women's doubles rankings, after having fallen to No. 19 earlier this year. Her career-high ranking is No. 5, achieved in mid-August 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two automobile parts shows to open Tuesday

TEXT.P: The four-day 2009 Taipei International Auto Parts and Accessories Show and the Taipei International Automobile Electronics Show will open Tuesday at the Taipei World Trade Center's Nangang Exhibition Hall.

Some 1,000 manufacturers will display their latest products at 2,600 booths. They include leading Taiwanese automakers Depo Auto Parts Industrial Co., Eagle Eyes Traffic Industrial Co. Sonar Auto Parts Co. Ltd., Tong Hong Automobile Parts Co., Gordon Auto Body Parts Co., and Just Auto Accessories Co., Ltd.

Many Taiwanese manufacturers will use the exhibitions to present the results of their efforts to design more energy-efficient items and launch new products featuring lower fuel consumption, reduced CO2 emissions, and high engine performance.

Also taking part in the exhibitions are several foreign auto parts makers from the United States, Australia, Italy, China, Japan, India, Singapore, Hong Kong, South Korea, Thailand and the Philippines.
During the show period, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) -- the organizer of the exhibitions -- will hold a series of forums on new technologies and market issues.
Eleven winners of the Innovation Awards will be honored during the opening ceremony of the two exhibitions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Man who tossed dollar bills on freeways said he was possessed

TEXT.P: A man who illegally cast more than NT$2 million (US$60,000) worth of cash notes on freeways in Taiwan told police Monday he did it to get rid of evil spirits that had been haunting him.
The man, identified only by his family name Chen, told police that he had discarded at least NT$2 million because he was "possessed by ghosts."
Many motorists who saw him throwing out money stopped their cars on the freeways to try to pick up the cash.
He said he obtained the money after selling an apartment in the Neihu district of Taipei City for NT$10 million (US$300,000).
Chen was arrested Sunday and handed to Changhua District Prosecutors Office Monday on charges of hindering public security and destroying national notes.

Chen was found to have another NT$2.44 million in cash notes with him after police tracked him down Sunday at a Changhua City restaurant. Police later found that he had burned cash notes worth about NT$500,000 at a hotel, where he had checked into a day earlier.

Chen acknowledged to police that he was the man caught in the act by a local cable TV station which showed in its film on April 7 a man throwing out scores of NT$1,000 cash notes from within a taxi traveling on Freeway No. 1 from Chiayi County to Sijhih in Taipei County.

Chen told police that he did so because he was in a bad mood. He admitted having flung money onto freeways several times before in various parts of Taiwan, including Taipei, Kaohsiung, Taichung, Chiayi, and Hsinchu.

He was arrested after a taxi driver carrying him on his last money-purging episode in Taichung City called the police. The taxi driver had seen news reports about a man throwing out money on a freeway and suspected Chen was the man.
As Chen rambled nonsensically during police questioning, police said they suspected he suffers from mental illness.
Ironically, he has a 78-year-old mother who is not doing well financially and still needs to work odd jobs to make ends meet.
Police rejected the finders keepers belief and said anyone they find who has picked up the cash will be ordered to return it. So far no one has come forward with any of the money.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cloud Gate Dance Theatre formally gets permanent home

TEXT.P: Homeless for more than a year, Taiwan's internationally renowned Cloud Gate Dance Theatre has secured a new base of operations after an agreement was reached that will allow the troupe to use a vacated office complex in Danshui, Taipei County.
The contract was signed by Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei, Cloud Gate Dance Foundation Chairwoman Shen Hsueh-yung and Cloud Gate Dance Theatre founder Lin Hwai-min.
The troupe has been homeless since a pre-dawn fire destroyed its rehearsal studio, warehouse and production archives on Feb. 11, 2008.
Shortly after the fire, Chou offered to provide the unused former Radio Taiwan International (RTI) complex in Danshui Township to Cloud Gate to rebuild its rehearsal studio.
The plan quickly ran into roadblocks, however, because there was no legal basis allowing the county government to permit a private group to use a vacant public property.
As a result, both the county government and the dance troupe have undergone a cumbersome process rife with paperwork to complete the transfer.

In line with the provisions of an act that encourages the private sector to invest in public infrastructure construction, the county government mounted an open tender last year for the Cloud Gate Dance Foundation, which operates Cloud Gate Dance Theatre and its offshoot Cloud Gate 2, to bid to manage the unused complex.
The strict legal screening procedures were finally completed last week, paving the way for the signing of the contract Monday.

Addressing the ceremony, Chou urged the central government to enact a law as soon as possible to facilitate the transfer of unused public properties to performing arts groups or other artistic organizations for their use.

"Only by so doing can we boost the development of creative cultural industries, " Chou said, adding that the year-long commercial-style bidding process the Cloud Gate experienced was actually an insult to the world acclaimed troupe.
Speaking on the same occasion, Lin said the stringent legal procedure was "painful" yet memorable because it has provided enormous opportunities for the troupe to learn.
According to Lin, the complex will be renamed the Danshui Arts Education Center.

"It will be a great challenge for Cloud Gate to manage the new center, " said Lin, who hoped that the troupe will be able to thrive at the new center and get a 10-year extension after its current 40-year contract expires.

The two-story, square concrete building on a hillside above Hobe Fort and overlooking the Danshui River and the town of Bali across the river, will need fair amount of work before the company can move in, including the construction of a dance floor.

But there are large open rooms on both floors that could easily be turned into dance and rehearsal studios and several small rooms than could be converted into offices for the costume, design and production crews.

DOC.HEADLINE: More than 34.43 million cases of computer virus attacks in Q1:report

TEXT.P: There were 34.43 million computer virus attacks reported in the first quarter in Taiwan, according to a report released Monday by the local chapter of a global network for computer surveillance and attack prevention.
The first quarter number reached 47 percent of total number of cases last year and represented a 297 percent rise compared to the same period a year earlier.

The number was also 9.79 percent higher than in the fourth quarter of 2008, according to the report conducted by the Global Anti-virus Research and Support Center of TrendLabs -- a branch of Trend Micro's global network committed to computer virus threat surveillance.

The Asian region has been fallen particularly vulnerable to self-executing malicious software due to the popularity of the use of USB flash drives, said Samson Tai, a TrendLabs senior technical adviser.
Of the 10 most common computer viruses that occurred in the first quarter, the top two were USB-related, he added.
Tai advised computer users to switch off the self-executing directive by pressing theShiftkey when connecting USB flash drives to computers to avoid activating virus-affected files.
Users can also disable auto-play functions by right clicking the USB drives and selectingTake no actionin the "Actions" panel under thePropertiesdialogue box, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislature proposes to disallow political status language in ECFA

TEXT.P: The legislature's Economics Committee passed several proposals related to a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, including one that would bar language on the political status of Taiwan and China from the deal.

Terms such as "one-China principle" and "1992 Consensus, " as well as "giving up anti-dumping and anti-compensatory subsidization" which is part of the China- Hong Kong Closer Economic Partnership Arrangement (CEPA), would not be allowed to be included in the ECFA, according to the proposal.

The "1992 Consensus" refers to an understanding the ruling Kuomintang claims was reached in Hong Kong in 1992 between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait that there is only one China, but with both sides free to make their own interpretations of what "one China" actually means.
On Monday the Economics Committee invited agencies working on the proposed framework agreement to discuss their preparations for the drafting of the pact.

The meeting triggered heated debate among lawmakers on the briefing given by ranking officials from the Council of Economic Planning and Development, the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Council of Agriculture, and the Mainland Affairs Council.
After the question-and-answer session, the committee voted on a total of 14 proposals related to the ECFA, with several given the green light.

One of the proposals passed would require the government, before any deal is signed, to hold talks with representatives of the domestic industrial sectors that are likely to be hurt by the framework agreement

The government would have to evaluate the ECFA's possible impact on vulnerable industrial sectors -- including towels, shoes, bedding, and ceramic and porcelain ware -- and work out measures to compensate the businesses that would suffer from the signing of the agreemnet.

Ruling Kuomintang lawmakers also proposed to request the Executive Yuan to include Taiwan's petroleum, textile, and precision machinery exports among the items for which Chinese tariff reductions will be discussed under the Early Harvest section of the framework agreement.

Other proposals include asking the government to continue efforts to sign agreements with other countries to help Taiwan join the global trading network and attract international companies to use Taiwan as their East Asian investment platform.

The government should also take efforts to promote the signing of free trade agreements (FTAs) with Taiwan's major trade partners, such as the United States, Japan and Singapore, and should also insist on the principle of not having the country's sovereignty belittled, the legislators proposed.
Also passed were measures to not allow Chinese workers into Taiwan and not expand the number of agricultural items that can be imported from China.

The Economics Committee, however, did not approve proposals by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party that would require the government to organize a referendum on the ECFA, to ask for Beijing's public promise not to block Taiwan's signing of FTAs with other economies, and to not engage in controversial comprehensive cross-strait framework talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former president to visit Japan May 31

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui will visit Japan next month on a trip that will be devoted entirely to sightseeing, his staff said Monday.

The staff said the former president will not call on any Japanese political figures and that his trip is mainly aimed at completing the visit of the Oku No Hosomich (The Narrow Road to the Deep North), the title of famed haiku poet Matsuo Basho's most famous work, a poem-filled travelogue through Japan's remote northeastern region of Tohoku.

They noted that during Lee's visit of Japan in May 2007, he only completed half of the 2,400-kilogram trail, and he expressed the hope at the time of revisiting Japan to complete the entire journey, his staff added.

According to the initial itinerary, Lee is scheduled to depart from Taipei for Fukuoka, on the northern shore of the island of Kyushu, May 31, and later transfer to Niigata in northern Japan via domestic flight. He will then travel southward to complete the trail and return home via Nagoya June 7.
Lee, 86, will be accompanied by his wife during the visit.
Basho (1644-1694) is generally regarded as Japan's greatest haiku poet, largely responsible for creating the art form with its 5-7-5 syllable syntax.

One of the most famous travelogues ever, the Narrow Road continues to inspire Japanese art and draws visitors to Tohoku (northeast), and each of the places Basho visited continues to revere his poems and observations.
In Basho's day, the land of Oku, literally "Within," was a place where farmers eked out a meager living and bandits and hermits roamed in the mountains.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC hopes to include ECFA issue in fourth round of talks with PRC

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) expressed hope Monday that an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China will be formally included on the agenda of the fourth round of talks between their top negotiators.
MAC Vice Chairman Chao Chien-min made the statement in a briefing to the Legislative Yuan's Economics Committee on the MAC's preparations for talks with China on the proposed pact.

He said the council will first seek Beijing's agreement to allow the ECFA to be one of the topics in the upcoming third round of talks between Taiwan's Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, and his Chinese counterpart Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits.
Chao also rejected claims that a framework agreement would harm Taiwan's sovereignty.
Chao said Taiwan and China signed six agreements in 2008, and none touched on the controversial topic of sovereignty or used sensitive political language.
He said he believes that when the two sides act to forge other agreements, such as the ECFA, they will still continue to sign the deals in the same spirit and with the same self-restraint, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: German wind power company suspends plans to invest in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Germany's InfraVest Wind Power Co. said Monday it will not make any further investment in Taiwan's wind power development projects unless the government comes up with concrete action in support of its policy to develop renewable energy.

Karl-Eugen Feifel, chairman of InfraVest, told a press conference that the company will put on hold its plans for a further investment of more than 500 million euros in the next five years because it is not sure of the government's determination to tap renewable energy sources.
InfraVest is based in Taipei and has offices in Taichung, Changhua, and Miaoli. It also has offices in China, Turkey, Brazil, and Germany.
The company has already invested 300 million euros (US$398.46 million) in Taiwan since its inception in 1999 and has built 88 giant wind turbines on Taiwan's west coast between Miaoli and Changhua.

He said that if it becomes certain by the end of this year that Infra Vest will scrap all its investment plans in Taiwan, the company will still leave some of its engineers behind to keep the wind turbines running.

Feifel called for a change in the measures that allow state-owned Taiwan Power Co. to purchase wind power from the private sector at an "unreasonable" price of NT$2 per kilowatt-hour -- lower than the production cost of NT$2.6 per kilowatt- hour.
He also urged the Ministry of Economic Affairs to simplify the procedure for screening applications to build new wind farms.
Feifel expressed disappointment at the lack of progress the Legislative Yuan has made in passing the Renewable Energy Development Bill.
He said he had discussed the issue with senior energy officials numerous times in the past 16 legislative sessions and that each time he was told that the bill would be passed "in this session."

Noting that the current legislative session is the third one under the new Kuomintang government, Wang Yun-yi, deputy manager of InfraVest, said, "If the law fails to get passed this time, it probably will never be passed in the future."
Wang Yun-ming, deputy director-general of the Bureau of Energy under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, affirmed that the government will continue to support the development of wind power.
He said that a new formula will be proposed to set a more reasonable price for buying wind power from the private sector.
Taiwan has set a goal to draw 10 percent of its electricity capacity from renewable energy sources by 2010, and that wind power will make up 80 percent of the 10 percent of the renewable energy.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA promotes more sustainable consumption to mark Earth Day

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) launched a "green living, sustainable consumption" publicity campaign Monday to celebrate this year's April 22 Earth Day and June 5 World Environment Day.

"Starting Monday and lasting until June 30, the Cabinet-level agency will collaborate with several retail chains and environmental protection bureaus in cities and counties around the country to promote green purchasing and sustainable consumption, " said EPA Minister Stephen Shen at a news conference.

Noting that green purchasing means conservation of energy and reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, Shen said the EPA intends to make the period an "environmental protection season" to enhance public awareness of the importance of maintaining the health of the planet.

During the period from April 13-June 5, Shen said, consumers are encouraged to purchase Earth-friendly products, particularly those which are efficient in energy, water, and electricity consumption and low in carbon dioxide emmissions.

To expand green purchasing from the government into the private sector, Shen said, the EPA helped encourage 1,088 private enterprises and civic groups to make NT$2.2 billion worth of green purchases in 2008, tripling the amount recorded in 2007.
On Monday, the EPA publicly honored the 18 companies and civic groups that purchased more than NT$20 million worth of Earth-friendly products last year.
Two hypermarts -- Far Eastern Geant and Carrefour -- will sponsor special trade fairs in the coming weeks to lend support to the EPA's "green living, sustainable consumption" campaign.

From April 15 through April 28, Far Eastern Geant will market a selection of Earth-friendly goods, and consumers who purchase more than NT$200 worth of those products can take part in a lucky draw that offers many big prizes.

Carrefour will launch a "one day volunteer" program on May 30 to clean up neighborhoods or living environments. From May 1-30, consumers who purchase Earth-friendly goods at its stroes can join a draw to win air conditioners.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China to cooperate in auto electronics development

TEXT.P: The two sides of the Taiwan Strait will sign a letter of intent Tuesday on cooperation in the development of automobile electronic products, industry sources said Monday.

The agreement will be signed by Taiwan's Institute for Information Indstry, the Industrial Technology Research Institute and the Automotive Research and Testing Center as well as China's major auto industry companies, the sources said.

The decision to cooperate in automobile electronics development came after auto industry representatives from both sides held a meeting Monday at the Taipei International Convention Center, the sources said.
After extensive discussions, the sources said, both sides agreed that there are ample room for cooperation in auto parts and accessories, particularly auto electronics, development.
China's auto industry is booming and thriving while Taiwan has a well-developed auto parts and accessories industry, the sources said.

A large delegation of China's auto industry is currently in Taipei as the four- day 2009 Taipei International Auto Parts and Accessories Show and the Taipei International Automobile Electronics Show will open Tuesday at the Taipei World Trade Center's Nangang Exhibition Hall.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
World Vision urges support for its indigenous children's choir

TEXT.P: The local chapter of an international charity called on the public Monday to give moral and financial support to the aboriginal children who make up its Taiwan Children's Choir, as the group prepares to stage its first concert April 18 in Taipei.

Albert Yu, communications manager of World Vision Taiwan, told the CNA in an exclusive interview that the concert, which will feature 219 indigenous children from the charity's cultural teams around Taiwan, will bring to audiences in Taipei the beautiful voices and vibrant aboriginal spirit of the children.
Pop Diva A-mei, who is of Puyuma indigenous origin, will make a guest appearance at the concert to sing the hymn "Little Dream" with the children, he said.
"World Vision works with these children and would also like to give them an opportunity to display their talent and indigenous culture," Yu said.

According to Yu, World Vision Taiwan has established 15 cultural teams in different indigenous communities around Taiwan since 1979, and recently founded the Taiwan Children's Choir to promote indigenous music.

Noting that many of the children in the choir have gone through difficult times because of natural disasters, or are unable to attend school because of their families' financial situation, Yu said the choir serves as a"support mechanism" that fosters interaction among the children and helps them to bounce from adversity.
"Many of the children have been able to find relief, find an outlet for their problems by singing and performing their indigenous songs," he said.

Lead by the noted Paiwan conductor Tivulangan Talivatan, the choir will bring the richness of the singers' heritage to audiences in Taipei through 10 songs performed in aboriginal languages and Mandarin Chinese.

Yu called on the public to join the event, saying that every paying member of the audience will not only be treated to a fantastic performance, but will also be providing moral and financial support to the children on stage.
World Vision Taiwan will release a DVD and CD package of the live performance and of recorded tracks in May to raise funds for the continuation of the program.
Tickets for the concert are available on the Web site http: //www.worldvision.org.tw/edm/20090403-childrenchoir/.

DOC.HEADLINE: 50,000 children affected by parents' joblessness: survey

TEXT.P: At least 50,000 elementary school children have been affected by their parents' job losses, with 20 percent of them able to afford only two meals per day, according to the results of a survey released Monday by a child welfare group.
The survey results were released as Taiwan's February jobless rate surged to a new high of 5.75 percent, or 624,000 unemployed, due to the sputtering economy amid the global recession.
The Child Welfare League Foundation said that of the children surveyed whose parents do not have regular jobs, 72 percent said "they are worried about the economic situation of their families."

Over 30 percent said their parents could not pay their school fees on time and that they were unable to take part in school activities such as outside field trips or commencement tours due to a lack of funds.
In addition, 35 percent of the children said they would not be taken to visit a doctor if they were sick.

The foundation conducted the survey late last year, sending out 5,479 questionnaires to fourth, fifth and sixth graders in 22 cities and counties in which the group provides services, with 4,487 effective questionnaires collected -- 81.9 percent of the total. The margin of error was plus or minus two percentage points.
The results show that the underprivileged families targeted by the group reported a jobless rate as high as 20 percent, averaging one in every five families, or four times the national average.

Foundation Executive Director Wang Yu-min said underprivileged families have in the past been able to find short-term work such as distributing pamphlets, dishwashing or cleaning, but with the economy yet to bottom out, even such menial jobs are now difficult to come by.

Compared with the same period of last year, he went on, underprivileged families needing assistance from the group to find jobs increased 70 percent, while families in need of subsides increased by 17 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, falling NT$0.098 to close at NT$33.697.
A total of US$753 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.795 and fluctuated between NT$33.651 and NT$33.859.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan stocks reach 7-month high, post 7th weekly gain

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices moved above the 5,800 point mark to a seven-month high Monday, following seven straight weekly gains.

The weighted index, the market's key barometer, advanced 75.68 points, or 1.3 percent, to close at 5,857.64, boosted by the Legislative Yuan's passage of the Cabinet's NT$500 billion economic stimulus package Friday.
Taiwan's stock market rose 252.33 points, or 4.56 percent, last week.
Finishing higher for the third consecutive session, the local bourse opened at 5,814.17 and fluctuated between 5,861.11 and 5,784.10.
A total of 7.21 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$148.58 billion (US$4.41 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction stocks moving up the most at 4.4 percent. Foodstuff shares gained 3.4 percent, textile shares surged 2.3 percent, cement issues advanced 1.6 percent, machinery and electronics shares rose 1.3 percent, plastics and chemicals shares gained 0.9 percent, paper and pulp issues closed up 0.6 percent, and banking and financial issues rose 0.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,397 to 713, with 139 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$7.30 billion.
One analyst predicted that the market would sustain its upward movement because of an increase in export orders in March coupled with sufficient liquidity.

DOC.HEADLINE: New tunnel shortens travel time between two Nantou County villages

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou inaugurated a newly completed tunnel in central Taiwan's Nantou County Monday that shortens the travel time between two mountain villages from two hours to just six minutes.

Ma cut a ribbon at the ceremony to mark the official opening of the 361-meter tunnel, which is on Nantou County Highway No. 83 linking the villages of Wanfeng and Fachih -- both located in Jenai township -- and connected with Nantou County Highway No. 71.

The aboriginal residents of both villages belong to the Bunun tribe, although the two villages are separated by a mountain. For nearly 30 years, residents of each village had to spend two hours making a detour through Puli township if they wanted to visit the other settlement.

Nantou Magistrate Lee Chao-ching sought help with the issue from the central government and received NT$183 million for the project, which covers 2.16 km of roadway, including a 90-meter bridge and the 361-meter tunnel.
County government officials pointed out that the opening of the Wanfeng Tunnel has also made sightseeing trips between Nantou County's scenic areas more convenient.

Visitors can travel from Puli to the Lushan tourist resort and to Chingjing Farm through Wushe on the outward trip, returning through the Aowanda Forest Recreational Park and taking Nantou County Highway No. 83 to Wanfeng village. From there, they can go through the new tunnel to Fachih village and then take Nantou County Highway No. 71 back to Puli, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fish procreation in Kenting area effective: researcher

TEXT.P: Fish procreation at the Houpihu area in the Kenting National Park in southern Taiwan's Pingtung County has shown signs of initial progress as the number of fish species has increased from 50 to 178 over the past four years, a specialist said Monday.

"Immersing in the sea near Houpihu, one now can see thousands of fish swimming around, including damsel fish, five flute porgies, butterfly fish and groupers, " said M. S. Jeng, a researcher at the Biodiversity Research Center under Taiwan's top research institute Academia Sinica.

He attributed the development to a 0.5-hectare "fish- feeding zone" at the Houpihu coastal area in Hengchun township, along with the establishment of a marine resources conservation district in 2005 by the center in collaboration with the Kenting National Park Administration and local diving businesses.
Since then, an agreement was reached among the parties concerned allowing divers to give bread pieces to fish in the feeding zone while banning divers from catching fish at the zone, Jeng said.
Doing so has helped lure large flocks of a wide variety of fish to the zone and boost revenue for tourism-related businesses, according to Jeng.
For 2006 alone, local diving businesses at Houpihu earned an additional NT$1 million (US$30,000), he said.
However, Jeng stressed that feeding is not a correct way to attract and preserve fish because it may easily lead fish to lose its natural ability to seek nutrients by itself.
"It is unnecessary to feed fish to preserve it if local marine resources are rich enough," he noted.

But Jeng said human efforts to protect the environment and help conserve fish are also important. More diversified fish species and undersea resources will also woo more tourists and increase tourism revenues, he explained.

Meanwhile, a "coral reef preservation week" co-sponsored by the Kenting National Park and the ROC (Republic of China) Society for Reef Studies kicked off Monday with an aim of building public awareness of the importance of environmental protection.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung Mayor arrives in Hong Kong for five-day visit
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/09 18:26:02 (By Mandy Wong and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Traveling at the head of a 90-member group of city officials and business executives, Taichung Mayor Jason Hu arrived in Hong Kong Monday for a five-day visit -- the latest sign of recent efforts by Taiwan and Hong Kong to build long-stalled relations since Taiwan-China ties have improved.

Apart from calling on Hong Kong Chief Executive Donald Tsang, Secretary of the Constitutional and Mainland Affairs Bureau Stephan Lam and other Hong Kong officials, Hu will also attend a forum co-sponsored Wednesday by Taichung City and Hong Kong to boost two-way exchanges.
Delegates from the two sides will discuss in the forum issues related to stepping up cooperation between Taichung and Hong Kong in trade, commerce, tourism, culture and city management.

On Thursday, Hu will take part in a "2009 Taichung tea party" organized by the Hong Kong office of the Taipei-based Taiwan Visitors Association, and in other activities arranged by Hong Kong tourism promotion authorities before flying back to Taiwan Friday.
The Hong Kong government decided in early January to establish a forum to boost exchanges with Taiwan's cities on a regular basis, with Taichung City selected as its first partner.
A second meeting of the "Taichung-Hong Kong city exchange forum" will be held in Taichung City, central Taiwan in the coming months.
The Hong Kong government hopes to further advance interactions with cities in Taiwan through the platform set up in the forum, a spokesman said.

Hu last visited Hong Kong in early January, along with three other local government chiefs from central Taiwan -- Taichung Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng, Changhua Magistrate Cho Po-yuan and Nantou Magistrate Lee Chao-ching.

Hu said during the last visit to Hong Kong that he noticed a great change in the Hong Kong government's attitude toward Taiwan, as Hong Kong officials he met during public occasions all showed keen interest in improving relations with Taiwan.
"I used to be able to meet Hong Kong officials in a private capacity only," he noted.

Hu's ongoing trip to Hong Kong follows that of Hong Kong's Home Affairs Secretary Tsang Tak-sing, who visited Taipei March 31-April 2 for an international Buddhist forum. He was the first senior Hong Kong official to visit Taiwan since Hong Kong's 1997 handover to China.

Analysts have told reporters recently that Hong Kong's hands had been tied in terms of building relations with Taiwan during the eight-years of tense relations between Beijing and Taipei under former Taiwanese president Chen Shui- bian's rule.

Relations between Taiwan and China have significantly improved since Taiwan's resident Ma Ying-jeou came into office in May last year. Hong Kong, a British colony until 1997, is a special administrative region of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Quarantine, IPR on agricultural products to be included in ECFA

TEXT.P: In any cross-Taiwan Strait trade pact talks that take place in the future, topics concerning agricultural affairs will focus on quarantine and relevant testing of livestock and plants, as well as intellectual property rights (IPR) protection for Taiwanese agricultural products, the vice minister of the Cabinet-level Council of Agricultural Affairs (COA) said Monday.

Huang Yu-tsai made the remarks at a meeting held by the Legislative Yuan Economics Committee with the authorities who are working on the proposed signing of a cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).

In a briefing to the committee on the COA's preparations for talks with China on the proposed pact, Huang pointed out that as China is listed as an affected area for many insect pests that affect fruit, as well as avian influenza and foot- and-mouth disease, Taiwan must ensure that such pests and diseases are not imported via cross-strait trading channels.

The two sides of the strait must establish a mutual reporting system for plant and animal disease outbreaks, and other operational mechanisms involving quarantine examination and investigation, as well as procedures for negotiations concerning the export and import of agricultural products, he said.
Huang stressed that the council will do all it can to protect Taiwan's agricultural benefits during the ECFA talks.

President Ma Ying-jeou's administration has been working to promote the signing of an ECFA with China, reasoning that when China enters a free trade arrangement with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) member countries -- the so-called ASEAN Plus One scheduled to be established in 2010 -- tariffs on 93 percent of the products traded among the pact signatories will be removed.

To avoid Taiwan being marginalized by this development -- as it would not be involved in any ASEAN tariff reductions -- the government has been heavily promoting the ECFA, in spite of strong protests by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, which is against any signing of such an agreement with China.

Speaking at the same meeting, Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming said that only once the two sides of the Taiwan Strait achieve common consensus on the proposed ECFA will it be time for them to decide the actual content of such a pact.
Such a content finalization "would be soon, maybe in one or two months" after they begin studying the proposal together, according to Yiin.
He made the remarks in response to questions by Legislator Ting Shou-Chung of the ruling Kuomintang.
The two sides began a three-month period of individual studies last month on the proposed ECFA, a precursor to the stage of joint research, Yiin said.

During the individual study stage, Yiin noted, the government is trying to exchange views on details of the proposal with its Chinese counterpart on every possible occasion, including international conferences and academic workshops.

He further said that the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has entrusted the Taipei-based Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research to review the latest research and assessments involving the proposed cross-strait cooperation agreement.
The government "will not just take the positive aspects into consideration but will also consider the possible negative effects" of such an economic cooperation pact, he added.

When the two sides reach the stage of forging an agreement, they will conduct the signing on the negotiation platform of their respective intermediary bodies -- Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation and the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits -- under the World Trade Organization framework, Yiin stated.
He also revealed that ECFA activities will start with trading in commodities.

According to the MOEA, six stages must be completed before an ECFA with China can be put into effect, including separate assessments by each side, a joint assessment, negotiations, the signing of the agreement, legislative approval and finally, implementation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Satisfaction over quality of life rises: survey

TEXT.P: The public satisfaction level with quality of life has risen by 12.2 percentage points compared with figures compiled in a survey carried out a year ago, according to the latest survey results released Monday.
The Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission targeted 19 areas to be tackled by the survey, conducted nearly one year after the May 20 inauguration of President Ma Ying-jeou.
Overall, 69.9 percent of the respondents said they were satisfied with their quality of life, up 12.2 percent from last year's survey.
In comparison, 26.5 percent said they were dissatisfied, down by around 5 percentage points from the previous year.

The top four areas to receive the greatest degrees of satisfaction were listed as clean environment around the home (80.1 percent), convenient transport around the home (79.9 percent) , the ability of water drainage systems around the home to cope with flood conditions (78.1 percent), and family life (77.9 percent).

The survey also found that the respondents were dissatisfied with the life-long learning environment (25.2 percent), the amount and quality of social activities available (31.2 percent), current working conditions (45.7 percent), and the education environment for students (45.4 percent).
The survey was conducted around the country March 24-25 and collected 1,080 effective samples with an error margin of plus or minus 3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese captures first doubles title with non-Taiwanese partner

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Chuang Chia-jung and India's Sania Mirza exacted a small measure of revenge Sunday when they defeated top seeds Czech Kveta Peschke and American Lisa Raymond to capture the MPS Group Championships women's doubles in Ponte Vedra Beach, Florida.
Chuang and Mirza were ousted by Peschke and Raymond from the seminfinals of the Sony Ericsson Open in two tight sets in early April, but returned the favor Sunday in a tense 6-3, 4-6, 10-7 victory.
It was Chuang's 11th career doubles title on the WTA tour, but her first with a non-Taiwanese partner.

Chuang is best known for her partnership with compatriot Chan Yung-jen on the "Golden Doubles Team" that reached the finals of the Australian Open and U.S. Open women's doubles in 2007 and won seven WTA Tour events from 2007 to 2008.
But after having their dreams of an Olympic medal extinguished in the second round of the Beijing Summer Games and losing in the first run of the 2008 U.S. Open, the two split.

Chuang then successfully teamed with compatriot Hsieh Su-wei at the end of 2008 to win one tour event in Seoul and a lower tier ITF event in Taipei, but in 2009 she has stuck with foreign partners, first Sun Tiantian of China at the Australian Open, then Akgul Amanmuradova of Uzbekistan and now Mirza, who seems to be the best fit.

Playing for only the third time together, the unseeded duo knocked out the tournament's first and fourth seeds and showed the ability to raise their games in the clutch, winning two super tiebreakers in their four matches during the week.

Against Peschke and Raymond, Chuang and Mirza quickly jumped to a 5-1 lead in the first-to-10 super tiebreaker and were able to hold on after their opponents pulled to within 7-6 to capture the title, which earned them a total of US$11,000 and 280 ranking points each.
The victory propelled Chuang up to No. 14 in the women's doubles rankings, after having fallen to No. 19 earlier this year. Her career-high ranking is No. 5, achieved in mid-August 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two automobile parts shows to open Tuesday

TEXT.P: The four-day 2009 Taipei International Auto Parts and Accessories Show and the Taipei International Automobile Electronics Show will open Tuesday at the Taipei World Trade Center's Nangang Exhibition Hall.

Some 1,000 manufacturers will display their latest products at 2,600 booths. They include leading Taiwanese automakers Depo Auto Parts Industrial Co., Eagle Eyes Traffic Industrial Co. Sonar Auto Parts Co. Ltd., Tong Hong Automobile Parts Co., Gordon Auto Body Parts Co., and Just Auto Accessories Co., Ltd.

Many Taiwanese manufacturers will use the exhibitions to present the results of their efforts to design more energy-efficient items and launch new products featuring lower fuel consumption, reduced CO2 emissions, and high engine performance.

Also taking part in the exhibitions are several foreign auto parts makers from the United States, Australia, Italy, China, Japan, India, Singapore, Hong Kong, South Korea, Thailand and the Philippines.
During the show period, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) -- the organizer of the exhibitions -- will hold a series of forums on new technologies and market issues.
Eleven winners of the Innovation Awards will be honored during the opening ceremony of the two exhibitions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Man who tossed dollar bills on freeways said he was possessed

TEXT.P: A man who illegally cast more than NT$2 million (US$60,000) worth of cash notes on freeways in Taiwan told police Monday he did it to get rid of evil spirits that had been haunting him.
The man, identified only by his family name Chen, told police that he had discarded at least NT$2 million because he was "possessed by ghosts."
Many motorists who saw him throwing out money stopped their cars on the freeways to try to pick up the cash.
He said he obtained the money after selling an apartment in the Neihu district of Taipei City for NT$10 million (US$300,000).
Chen was arrested Sunday and handed to Changhua District Prosecutors Office Monday on charges of hindering public security and destroying national notes.

Chen was found to have another NT$2.44 million in cash notes with him after police tracked him down Sunday at a Changhua City restaurant. Police later found that he had burned cash notes worth about NT$500,000 at a hotel, where he had checked into a day earlier.

Chen acknowledged to police that he was the man caught in the act by a local cable TV station which showed in its film on April 7 a man throwing out scores of NT$1,000 cash notes from within a taxi traveling on Freeway No. 1 from Chiayi County to Sijhih in Taipei County.

Chen told police that he did so because he was in a bad mood. He admitted having flung money onto freeways several times before in various parts of Taiwan, including Taipei, Kaohsiung, Taichung, Chiayi, and Hsinchu.

He was arrested after a taxi driver carrying him on his last money-purging episode in Taichung City called the police. The taxi driver had seen news reports about a man throwing out money on a freeway and suspected Chen was the man.
As Chen rambled nonsensically during police questioning, police said they suspected he suffers from mental illness.
Ironically, he has a 78-year-old mother who is not doing well financially and still needs to work odd jobs to make ends meet.
Police rejected the finders keepers belief and said anyone they find who has picked up the cash will be ordered to return it. So far no one has come forward with any of the money.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cloud Gate Dance Theatre formally gets permanent home

TEXT.P: Homeless for more than a year, Taiwan's internationally renowned Cloud Gate Dance Theatre has secured a new base of operations after an agreement was reached that will allow the troupe to use a vacated office complex in Danshui, Taipei County.
The contract was signed by Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei, Cloud Gate Dance Foundation Chairwoman Shen Hsueh-yung and Cloud Gate Dance Theatre founder Lin Hwai-min.
The troupe has been homeless since a pre-dawn fire destroyed its rehearsal studio, warehouse and production archives on Feb. 11, 2008.
Shortly after the fire, Chou offered to provide the unused former Radio Taiwan International (RTI) complex in Danshui Township to Cloud Gate to rebuild its rehearsal studio.
The plan quickly ran into roadblocks, however, because there was no legal basis allowing the county government to permit a private group to use a vacant public property.
As a result, both the county government and the dance troupe have undergone a cumbersome process rife with paperwork to complete the transfer.

In line with the provisions of an act that encourages the private sector to invest in public infrastructure construction, the county government mounted an open tender last year for the Cloud Gate Dance Foundation, which operates Cloud Gate Dance Theatre and its offshoot Cloud Gate 2, to bid to manage the unused complex.
The strict legal screening procedures were finally completed last week, paving the way for the signing of the contract Monday.

Addressing the ceremony, Chou urged the central government to enact a law as soon as possible to facilitate the transfer of unused public properties to performing arts groups or other artistic organizations for their use.

"Only by so doing can we boost the development of creative cultural industries, " Chou said, adding that the year-long commercial-style bidding process the Cloud Gate experienced was actually an insult to the world acclaimed troupe.
Speaking on the same occasion, Lin said the stringent legal procedure was "painful" yet memorable because it has provided enormous opportunities for the troupe to learn.
According to Lin, the complex will be renamed the Danshui Arts Education Center.

"It will be a great challenge for Cloud Gate to manage the new center, " said Lin, who hoped that the troupe will be able to thrive at the new center and get a 10-year extension after its current 40-year contract expires.

The two-story, square concrete building on a hillside above Hobe Fort and overlooking the Danshui River and the town of Bali across the river, will need fair amount of work before the company can move in, including the construction of a dance floor.

But there are large open rooms on both floors that could easily be turned into dance and rehearsal studios and several small rooms than could be converted into offices for the costume, design and production crews.

DOC.HEADLINE: More than 34.43 million cases of computer virus attacks in Q1:report

TEXT.P: There were 34.43 million computer virus attacks reported in the first quarter in Taiwan, according to a report released Monday by the local chapter of a global network for computer surveillance and attack prevention.
The first quarter number reached 47 percent of total number of cases last year and represented a 297 percent rise compared to the same period a year earlier.

The number was also 9.79 percent higher than in the fourth quarter of 2008, according to the report conducted by the Global Anti-virus Research and Support Center of TrendLabs -- a branch of Trend Micro's global network committed to computer virus threat surveillance.

The Asian region has been fallen particularly vulnerable to self-executing malicious software due to the popularity of the use of USB flash drives, said Samson Tai, a TrendLabs senior technical adviser.
Of the 10 most common computer viruses that occurred in the first quarter, the top two were USB-related, he added.
Tai advised computer users to switch off the self-executing directive by pressing theShiftkey when connecting USB flash drives to computers to avoid activating virus-affected files.
Users can also disable auto-play functions by right clicking the USB drives and selectingTake no actionin the "Actions" panel under thePropertiesdialogue box, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislature proposes to disallow political status language in ECFA

TEXT.P: The legislature's Economics Committee passed several proposals related to a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, including one that would bar language on the political status of Taiwan and China from the deal.

Terms such as "one-China principle" and "1992 Consensus, " as well as "giving up anti-dumping and anti-compensatory subsidization" which is part of the China- Hong Kong Closer Economic Partnership Arrangement (CEPA), would not be allowed to be included in the ECFA, according to the proposal.

The "1992 Consensus" refers to an understanding the ruling Kuomintang claims was reached in Hong Kong in 1992 between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait that there is only one China, but with both sides free to make their own interpretations of what "one China" actually means.
On Monday the Economics Committee invited agencies working on the proposed framework agreement to discuss their preparations for the drafting of the pact.

The meeting triggered heated debate among lawmakers on the briefing given by ranking officials from the Council of Economic Planning and Development, the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Council of Agriculture, and the Mainland Affairs Council.
After the question-and-answer session, the committee voted on a total of 14 proposals related to the ECFA, with several given the green light.

One of the proposals passed would require the government, before any deal is signed, to hold talks with representatives of the domestic industrial sectors that are likely to be hurt by the framework agreement

The government would have to evaluate the ECFA's possible impact on vulnerable industrial sectors -- including towels, shoes, bedding, and ceramic and porcelain ware -- and work out measures to compensate the businesses that would suffer from the signing of the agreemnet.

Ruling Kuomintang lawmakers also proposed to request the Executive Yuan to include Taiwan's petroleum, textile, and precision machinery exports among the items for which Chinese tariff reductions will be discussed under the Early Harvest section of the framework agreement.

Other proposals include asking the government to continue efforts to sign agreements with other countries to help Taiwan join the global trading network and attract international companies to use Taiwan as their East Asian investment platform.

The government should also take efforts to promote the signing of free trade agreements (FTAs) with Taiwan's major trade partners, such as the United States, Japan and Singapore, and should also insist on the principle of not having the country's sovereignty belittled, the legislators proposed.
Also passed were measures to not allow Chinese workers into Taiwan and not expand the number of agricultural items that can be imported from China.

The Economics Committee, however, did not approve proposals by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party that would require the government to organize a referendum on the ECFA, to ask for Beijing's public promise not to block Taiwan's signing of FTAs with other economies, and to not engage in controversial comprehensive cross-strait framework talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former president to visit Japan May 31

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui will visit Japan next month on a trip that will be devoted entirely to sightseeing, his staff said Monday.

The staff said the former president will not call on any Japanese political figures and that his trip is mainly aimed at completing the visit of the Oku No Hosomich (The Narrow Road to the Deep North), the title of famed haiku poet Matsuo Basho's most famous work, a poem-filled travelogue through Japan's remote northeastern region of Tohoku.

They noted that during Lee's visit of Japan in May 2007, he only completed half of the 2,400-kilogram trail, and he expressed the hope at the time of revisiting Japan to complete the entire journey, his staff added.

According to the initial itinerary, Lee is scheduled to depart from Taipei for Fukuoka, on the northern shore of the island of Kyushu, May 31, and later transfer to Niigata in northern Japan via domestic flight. He will then travel southward to complete the trail and return home via Nagoya June 7.
Lee, 86, will be accompanied by his wife during the visit.
Basho (1644-1694) is generally regarded as Japan's greatest haiku poet, largely responsible for creating the art form with its 5-7-5 syllable syntax.

One of the most famous travelogues ever, the Narrow Road continues to inspire Japanese art and draws visitors to Tohoku (northeast), and each of the places Basho visited continues to revere his poems and observations.
In Basho's day, the land of Oku, literally "Within," was a place where farmers eked out a meager living and bandits and hermits roamed in the mountains.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC hopes to include ECFA issue in fourth round of talks with PRC

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) expressed hope Monday that an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China will be formally included on the agenda of the fourth round of talks between their top negotiators.
MAC Vice Chairman Chao Chien-min made the statement in a briefing to the Legislative Yuan's Economics Committee on the MAC's preparations for talks with China on the proposed pact.

He said the council will first seek Beijing's agreement to allow the ECFA to be one of the topics in the upcoming third round of talks between Taiwan's Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, and his Chinese counterpart Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits.
Chao also rejected claims that a framework agreement would harm Taiwan's sovereignty.
Chao said Taiwan and China signed six agreements in 2008, and none touched on the controversial topic of sovereignty or used sensitive political language.
He said he believes that when the two sides act to forge other agreements, such as the ECFA, they will still continue to sign the deals in the same spirit and with the same self-restraint, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: German wind power company suspends plans to invest in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Germany's InfraVest Wind Power Co. said Monday it will not make any further investment in Taiwan's wind power development projects unless the government comes up with concrete action in support of its policy to develop renewable energy.

Karl-Eugen Feifel, chairman of InfraVest, told a press conference that the company will put on hold its plans for a further investment of more than 500 million euros in the next five years because it is not sure of the government's determination to tap renewable energy sources.
InfraVest is based in Taipei and has offices in Taichung, Changhua, and Miaoli. It also has offices in China, Turkey, Brazil, and Germany.
The company has already invested 300 million euros (US$398.46 million) in Taiwan since its inception in 1999 and has built 88 giant wind turbines on Taiwan's west coast between Miaoli and Changhua.

He said that if it becomes certain by the end of this year that Infra Vest will scrap all its investment plans in Taiwan, the company will still leave some of its engineers behind to keep the wind turbines running.

Feifel called for a change in the measures that allow state-owned Taiwan Power Co. to purchase wind power from the private sector at an "unreasonable" price of NT$2 per kilowatt-hour -- lower than the production cost of NT$2.6 per kilowatt- hour.
He also urged the Ministry of Economic Affairs to simplify the procedure for screening applications to build new wind farms.
Feifel expressed disappointment at the lack of progress the Legislative Yuan has made in passing the Renewable Energy Development Bill.
He said he had discussed the issue with senior energy officials numerous times in the past 16 legislative sessions and that each time he was told that the bill would be passed "in this session."

Noting that the current legislative session is the third one under the new Kuomintang government, Wang Yun-yi, deputy manager of InfraVest, said, "If the law fails to get passed this time, it probably will never be passed in the future."
Wang Yun-ming, deputy director-general of the Bureau of Energy under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, affirmed that the government will continue to support the development of wind power.
He said that a new formula will be proposed to set a more reasonable price for buying wind power from the private sector.
Taiwan has set a goal to draw 10 percent of its electricity capacity from renewable energy sources by 2010, and that wind power will make up 80 percent of the 10 percent of the renewable energy.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA promotes more sustainable consumption to mark Earth Day

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) launched a "green living, sustainable consumption" publicity campaign Monday to celebrate this year's April 22 Earth Day and June 5 World Environment Day.

"Starting Monday and lasting until June 30, the Cabinet-level agency will collaborate with several retail chains and environmental protection bureaus in cities and counties around the country to promote green purchasing and sustainable consumption, " said EPA Minister Stephen Shen at a news conference.

Noting that green purchasing means conservation of energy and reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, Shen said the EPA intends to make the period an "environmental protection season" to enhance public awareness of the importance of maintaining the health of the planet.

During the period from April 13-June 5, Shen said, consumers are encouraged to purchase Earth-friendly products, particularly those which are efficient in energy, water, and electricity consumption and low in carbon dioxide emmissions.

To expand green purchasing from the government into the private sector, Shen said, the EPA helped encourage 1,088 private enterprises and civic groups to make NT$2.2 billion worth of green purchases in 2008, tripling the amount recorded in 2007.
On Monday, the EPA publicly honored the 18 companies and civic groups that purchased more than NT$20 million worth of Earth-friendly products last year.
Two hypermarts -- Far Eastern Geant and Carrefour -- will sponsor special trade fairs in the coming weeks to lend support to the EPA's "green living, sustainable consumption" campaign.

From April 15 through April 28, Far Eastern Geant will market a selection of Earth-friendly goods, and consumers who purchase more than NT$200 worth of those products can take part in a lucky draw that offers many big prizes.

Carrefour will launch a "one day volunteer" program on May 30 to clean up neighborhoods or living environments. From May 1-30, consumers who purchase Earth-friendly goods at its stroes can join a draw to win air conditioners.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China to cooperate in auto electronics development

TEXT.P: The two sides of the Taiwan Strait will sign a letter of intent Tuesday on cooperation in the development of automobile electronic products, industry sources said Monday.

The agreement will be signed by Taiwan's Institute for Information Indstry, the Industrial Technology Research Institute and the Automotive Research and Testing Center as well as China's major auto industry companies, the sources said.

The decision to cooperate in automobile electronics development came after auto industry representatives from both sides held a meeting Monday at the Taipei International Convention Center, the sources said.
After extensive discussions, the sources said, both sides agreed that there are ample room for cooperation in auto parts and accessories, particularly auto electronics, development.
China's auto industry is booming and thriving while Taiwan has a well-developed auto parts and accessories industry, the sources said.

A large delegation of China's auto industry is currently in Taipei as the four- day 2009 Taipei International Auto Parts and Accessories Show and the Taipei International Automobile Electronics Show will open Tuesday at the Taipei World Trade Center's Nangang Exhibition Hall.
