On Monday, the EPA publicly honored the 18 companies and civic groups that purchased more than NT$20 million worth of Earth-friendly products last year.
Two hypermarts -- Far Eastern Geant and Carrefour -- will sponsor special trade fairs in the coming weeks to lend support to the EPA's "green living, sustainable consumption" campaign.

From April 15 through April 28, Far Eastern Geant will market a selection of Earth-friendly goods, and consumers who purchase more than NT$200 worth of those products can take part in a lucky draw that offers many big prizes.

Carrefour will launch a "one day volunteer" program on May 30 to clean up neighborhoods or living environments. From May 1-30, consumers who purchase Earth-friendly goods at its stroes can join a draw to win air conditioners.

DOC.HEADLINE: German wind power company suspends plans to invest in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Germany's InfraVest Wind Power Co. said Monday it will not make any further investment in Taiwan's wind power development projects unless the government comes up with concrete action in support of its policy to develop renewable energy.

Karl-Eugen Feifel, chairman of InfraVest, told a press conference that the company will put on hold its plans for a further investment of more than 500 million euros in the next five years because it is not sure of the government's determination to tap renewable energy sources.
InfraVest is based in Taipei and has offices in Taichung, Changhua, and Miaoli. It also has offices in China, Turkey, Brazil, and Germany.
The company has already invested 300 million euros (US$398.46 million) in Taiwan since its inception in 1999 and has built 88 giant wind turbines on Taiwan's west coast between Miaoli and Changhua.

He said that if it becomes certain by the end of this year that Infra Vest will scrap all its investment plans in Taiwan, the company will still leave some of its engineers behind to keep the wind turbines running.

Feifel called for a change in the measures that allow state-owned Taiwan Power Co. to purchase wind power from the private sector at an "unreasonable" price of NT$2 per kilowatt-hour -- lower than the production cost of NT$2.6 per kilowatt- hour.
He also urged the Ministry of Economic Affairs to simplify the procedure for screening applications to build new wind farms.
Feifel expressed disappointment at the lack of progress the Legislative Yuan has made in passing the Renewable Energy Development Bill.
He said he had discussed the issue with senior energy officials numerous times in the past 16 legislative sessions and that each time he was told that the bill would be passed "in this session."

Noting that the current legislative session is the third one under the new Kuomintang government, Wang Yun-yi, deputy manager of InfraVest, said, "If the law fails to get passed this time, it probably will never be passed in the future."
Wang Yun-ming, deputy director-general of the Bureau of Energy under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, affirmed that the government will continue to support the development of wind power.
He said that a new formula will be proposed to set a more reasonable price for buying wind power from the private sector.
Taiwan has set a goal to draw 10 percent of its electricity capacity from renewable energy sources by 2010, and that wind power will make up 80 percent of the 10 percent of the renewable energy.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC hopes to include ECFA issue in fourth round of talks with PRC

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) expressed hope Monday that an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China will be formally included on the agenda of the fourth round of talks between their top negotiators.
MAC Vice Chairman Chao Chien-min made the statement in a briefing to the Legislative Yuan's Economics Committee on the MAC's preparations for talks with China on the proposed pact.

He said the council will first seek Beijing's agreement to allow the ECFA to be one of the topics in the upcoming third round of talks between Taiwan's Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, and his Chinese counterpart Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits.
Chao also rejected claims that a framework agreement would harm Taiwan's sovereignty.
Chao said Taiwan and China signed six agreements in 2008, and none touched on the controversial topic of sovereignty or used sensitive political language.
He said he believes that when the two sides act to forge other agreements, such as the ECFA, they will still continue to sign the deals in the same spirit and with the same self-restraint, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
MOFA mum on WHA negotiations

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) refused to confirm on Tuesday whether the government has engaged in negotiations with China on participating in the upcoming World Health Assembly (WHA) in May.
Such talks, however, would be the best way to help Taiwan achieve its goal of attending the WHA as an observer, the MOFA said.

Regarding whether the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have started substantive negotiations, it is inappropriate for me to make any comment at the moment, said Paul Chang, general-director of MOFA's Department of International Organizations, at a regular press briefing.
Should there be any communications, the government will uphold the principles of dignity and autonomy and will not accept any arrangement that demeans or belittles us,he added.

Chang was responding to a report in a local daily Monday that Beijing has agreed to let Taiwan participate in May's WHA meeting as an observer by invitation of the WHO Secretariat, although some details have yet to be sorted out.

The annual WHA -- the decision-making arm of the World Health Organization (WHO) -- is scheduled to be held May 18-27 in Geneva. Taiwan is preparing to bid for participation in the WHA for the 13th consecutive time since 1997, with previous attempts blocked due to China's obstruction.

Rebutting critics that cross-strait negotiations on the issue have taken place behind closed doors and lack transparency, Chang said there is no such thing as "closed-door meetings" and that the government has a clear goal, which is to participate in the WHA as an observer.

We believe that at the moment, not commenting on relative developments of the issue can facilitate us in achieving our goal, " he said. The foreign ministry will make any substantive results public and will accept public scrutiny, Chang pledged.

Asked what kind of arrangements would be considered by the government as belittling Taiwan, Chang only said that the MOFA is working hard to fight for participation guidelines that are in Taiwan's best interests, including on Taiwan's designation at the WHA, the level of government officials allowed to attend, and the rights that Taiwan will enjoy.
Chang denied the local daily report's contention that Taiwan's observer status would be re-examined on a "year-by-year" basis.

He said according to WHO practice, there is no such a thing as permanent observer, and, therefore, each year the Secretariat will send letters to notify observers, like the Vatican, about the time and place of its annual meeting and request the observers to provide the list of their delegation.

According to the WHA Rules of Procedures, the WHO director-general may invite states having made application for membership, territories on whose behalf application for associate membership has been made, and states which have signed but not accepted the Constitution to send observers to sessions of the Health Assembly.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA advises travelers to Thailand to exercise caution

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has advised travelers bound for Thailand Tuesday to exercise caution, but said it will maintain its current yellow-level travel alert issued a day earlier after monitoring other countriesdecisions.

The foreign ministry issued the yellow-level travel alert in consideration of the safety of Taiwanese nationals, bilateral relations between Taiwan and Thailand, and other countermeasures taken by other countries, said MOFA deputy spokesman James Chang at a regular press briefing.

As the United Kingdom and Canada have issued a "high alert" for travel to Bangkok and certain areas, he said the ministry will carefully evaluate whether to raise its travel alert level for Thailand because such a decision should be based on the situation throughout the country.
A yellow alert is the third most serious alert for foreign travel, behind red and orange alerts. An orange warning would mean that travelers are advised to postpone or cancel their trips.
Chang advised travelers to Thailand to exercise caution and avoid going to Bangkok and its surrounding five districts, including Nonthaburi, Samut Prakan, Pathum Thani, Nakhon Pathom and Ayutthaya.
The ministry's representative office in Thailand has also set up a special task force for emergencies and is maintaining close contact with Taiwanese businessmen and expatriates, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: General aviation companies push for cross-Taiwan Strait opening

TEXT.P: Six local general aviation companies appealed to the government Tuesday to allow them to operate private charters across the Taiwan Strait targeted at high-end businesses and corporate leaders.
They made the appeal after a meeting with three Chinese operators in the general aviation sector in Taipei.

The low-profile meeting was also attended by Taiwan's Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) Director-General Lee Long-wen and Wang Changshun, deputy director of the Civil Aviation Administration of China.

Prior to last year, these small aviation companies were banned from carrying passengers and cargo, with their services limited to aerial photography, atmospheric observation and measurement, construction services, and medical transport.
Taiwan then amended the Civil Aviation Law last year to allow general aviation operators to offer "special business flight services" for corporate clients.

Under an agreement signed by Taiwan and China in November 2008, however, the two countries only agreed to liberalize cross-Taiwan Strait direct charter passenger and cargo flights, and allow businessmen to fly to and from China in their private corporate jets.
Companies offering exclusive commercial services in small aircraft to business clients were excluded from the agreement, even though demand for such service has grown markedly in the past year.
According to CAA surveys, many enterprises have expressed an interest in leasing private aircraft to handle business traffic between Taiwan and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two bluefin tuna fish up for auction at Pingtung tuna festival

TEXT.P: Two bluefin tuna -- instead of one -- will be put up for auction at this year's Pingtung Bluefin Tuna Cultural Festival, breaking the festival's tradition since it was launched in 2001, the Donggang Fishermen's Association in Pingtung County said Tuesday.

The association decided to let the two northern bluefin tuna fish, recently caught by the Donggang-based Shin Shen Ching No. 126 and Chen Lung Hsing No. 2 fishing boats, respectively, be auctioned Thursday to mark the approach of the annual festival.
It will be the first time in nine years that two northern bluefin tuna will be auctioned at the two-month festival, which is slated to officially begin on May 2, association officials said.

In compliance with the rules set by the Pingtung County Government, to qualify for the auction, the tuna must be of the northern bluefin tuna species and weigh over 180 kilograms. It also has to be alive while being caught by a fishing boat registered with the Pingtung or Kaohsiung County, association officials said.

Apart from the requirements, the fish has to be the first tuna transported back to the Donggang Harbor after the boat has reported its catch to the local fishery radio station. The fish meeting all the above conditions will be eligible for the auction as the festival's "first tuna."

Although the Shin Shen Ching No. 126 was the first ship reporting its catch of a giant northern bluefin tuna to the Donggang fishery radio station on April 11, the Chen Lung Hsing No. 2 was the first boat that arrived back at the harbor with a giant tuna that met the qualifications, after having made a report of its catch to the radio station.
The two tunas were shipped back to harbor in a difference of 13 minutes, association officials said, noting that the arrival times of the first two boats have never been so close.

Chen Ching-lung, skipper of the Chen Lung Hsin No. 2 fishing vessel, said he put his boat in full gear at a speed of eight nautical miles per hour while shipping the tuna back from the high seas to Donggang after learning that he could be the quickest to return to the harbor.
Chen Chin-i, skipper of the Shin Shen Ching No. 126, lamented that his boat failed to be the first boat back, but added that was because it is aging.

The two vessels had intersected in waters off the coast of Pingtung County's Eluanbi on the way back to Donggang, and the two skippers discovered that they were elementary school classmates after landing at the harbor.
The first bluefin tuna caught last year for the Pingtung Bluefin Tuna Cultural Festival was auctioned for NT$1.73 million (US$57,055) at the festival.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, falling NT$0.077 to close at NT$33.620.
A total of US$867 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.697 and fluctuated between NT$33.569 and NT$33.715.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices rise on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices extended their winning streak into the fifth day to a seven-month high Tuesday.
The weighted index, the market's key barometer, advanced 35.04 points, or 0.59 percent, to close at 5,892.68.
Taiwan's stock market rose 252.33 points, or 4.56 percent, last week.
The local bourse opened lower at 5,814.42 and fluctuated between 5,898.76 and 5,765.81. A total of 6.47 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$148.97 billion (US$4.43 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp stocks moving up the most at 2.5 percent. Machinery and electronics shares rose 1.2 percent, textile issues added 1.1 percent, and banking and financial stocks rose 0.4 percent.

The four other major stock categories lost ground, with construction shares dropping the most at 1.6 percent. Cement shares lost 0.8 percent, foodstuff issues dropped 0.7 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares shed 0.6 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,222 to 908, with 134 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$3.25 billion.
One analyst predicted that the market would sustain its upward movement to test the 6,000-point level in the coming days, although there was still a risk the market could fall back.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA raises travel alert to orange for certain areas of Thailand

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) raised its travel alert level for certain areas of Thailand to orange Tuesday, advising travelers to postpone any visits to these destinations.
"The orange travel alert for certain areas of Thailand indicates that these locations are more dangerous than others and require extra caution," said MOFA deputy spokesman James Chang.
"However, a yellow travel alert remains in effect for the whole of Thailand," he added.

A yellow alert is a reminder for travelers to exercise caution, an orange travel alert advises travelers to postpone their trips, while a red alerts warns travelers not to enter the area in question under any circumstances.

The foreign ministry on Tuesday issued an orange alert for Bangkok and its surrounding five districts, including Nonthaburi, Samut Prakan, Pathum Thani, Nakhon Pathom and Ayutthaya, according to Chang.

The warning also covers the northern and northeast parts of Thailand, including Chiangmai, Chiangrai, Phrae, Phitsanu Lok, Lam Pang, Lam Phun, and Nakhon Ratcha Sima, Nong Khai, Udon Thani and Ubon Ratcha Thani, he added.

Chang said a yellow travel alert has been in effect for Thailand since last November, the MOFA began issuing travel warnings for certain areas of the country on April 10 when the anti-government protests escalated.

He denied that there was any delay in responding to the situation, adding that the MOFA will decide what to do next after it receives an evaluation report Wednesday from its representative office in Thailand.

Director of the MOFA's Department of East Asia and Pacific Affairs Victor Yu said in response to a reporter's question that even though the demonstrators decided to go along with one of their leaders' call Tuesday for a suspension of the protests, the MOFA will keep a close eye on the situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China looking to cooperate in global telematics industry

TEXT.P: Taiwan is looking to become a major worldwide supplier of automotive telematics devices through cooperation with China, said Deputy Minister of Economic Affairs Huang Chung-chiou Monday.
Huang made the remarks at the opening of a forum in Taipei on cross-Taiwan Strait cooperation and exchanges in the telematics industry.

Huang said although the world automobile industry has been seriously hit by the current economic recession, China's automobile production is forecast to reach 6.5 million to 7.5 million units this year to meet its huge domestic demand.

China is emerging as a major automobile consumption and production market, alongside the United States and Europe, driven by its efforts in recent years to achieve rapid growth in this sector, Huang noted at the forum, which was organized by the Institute for Information Industry and the Industrial Technology Research Institute.

In 2007, the total production volume of Global Positioning Systems (GPS) in Taiwan was 37.73 million, with a production value of NT$177.05 billion, according to statistics quoted by Huang. Personal Navigation Devices (PNDs) accounted for more than 70 percent of the total, with a delivery volume of more than 29 million, he said. The production volume of PNDs is forecast to reach 80 million in 2012, he added.

Roughly 175 million GPS-enabled handsets were manufactured in Taiwan in 2007, and the figure is expected to reach 560 million in 2012, which indicates that Taiwan has become an important supplier of telematics products, he said.

In order to focus more on the development of telematics in the automobile industry, the cost of electronic systems in vehicles would be adjusted from 19 percent to 40 percent of the total cost of automobile production in the future, Huang said.

As telematics companies in both Taiwan and China are specialists in their respective fields, it would be mutually beneficial to the two sides to pool their resources in order to become major suppliers of telematics devices, he suggested.

Dong Yang, Executive Vice President of the China Association of Automobile Manufacturers, said he is also keen to facilitate cooperation between the automobile industries in Taiwan and China, and thus help through the current global economic crisis and create economic benefits for both sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen fishermen catch big yellow croaker

TEXT.P: Four fishermen from Taiwan's outlying Kinmen Island on Tuesday made a highly unusual catch -- a big yellow croaker weighing 2.5 kilograms -- while they were fishing in the South China Sea.
Chen Sung-shu, the 66-year-old skipper of the Sheng Lee fishing boat where the fishermen worked, said it was the biggest yellow croaker that he has ever caught in nearly 20 years.
The fish of 60 centimeters long was purchased by another Kinmen fisherman for NT$12,000 (US$356). That fisherman plans to re-sell it to China at a higher price that could amount to NT$50,000.

"It is already very difficult to catch big yellow croaker weighing over 1.5 kilograms nowadays, although the waters off Kinmen Island were once a fishing ground rich in that specie of the fish, " Chen said.
"I once caught as much as 4,500 kilograms of yellow croaker in just one haul in 1971," he recounted.

According to officials at the Kinmen County Fisheries Research Institute, yellow croaker -- a fish of high-value unique to waters off the county -- has become an endangered specie as a result of poaching and overfishing by Chinese fishing boats which illegally operate in the area.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economics Ministry to expand auto parts export market

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is promoting a guidance plan aimed at helping exporters of auto parts and accessories to create more business opportunities abroad, a ministry official said Tuesday.

The MOEA has crafted the plan as the industry is one of the most competitive of Taiwan's small- and medium-sized enterprises in terms of exports, according to Economic Affairs Deputy Minister Lin Sheng-chung.

Lin said that although global automobile demand has fallen sharply since the second half of last year due to the impact of the global economic downturn, putting major auto parts manufacturers in Europe, the United States and Japan at risk of collapse, Taiwan's counterparts have been relatively less affected by the crisis thanks to their high quality after-sales services and products.

The plan is part of the NT$8.53 billion (US$25.48 million) "New Zheng He Plan" initiated by the MOEA last December to assist suppliers and manufacturers producing goods for export, with the aim of attracting NT$540 billion in export orders per year.

Lin made the remarks at the opening of the 2009 Taipei International Auto Parts and Accessories Show and the Taipei International Automobile Electronics Show running concurrently at the Taipei World Trade Center's Nangang Exhibition Hall.
Up to 1,100 manufacturers are taking part in the two shows, displaying their latest products in 2,700 booths.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fort stands witness to late Taiwan president's inspiration to troops

TEXT.P: As various events held recently to mark the 100th anniversary of the birth of Taiwan's late President Chiang Ching-kuo are invoking the public's memories of him, Chiang's close comradeship with the military posted on the Taiwan-held island group of Kinmen during war times may be among the most remembered.

One of the most important testimonies to Chiang's devotion to troops at a time when the island faced the threat of an invasion from China after the two sides split in 1949 was the General's Fort, a war-time historic site that has been transformed into a tourist destination.

Located in Houtou on the east side of Little Kinmen, the smaller of the two major islands comprising Kinmen, the fort was intended as an outpost monitoring the Jinlieh Channel which separates the two islands. It became well-known when Chiang went there amid China's artillery shelling of the island group in 1958.

The conflict, known internationally as the Battle of the Taiwan Strait or locally as "823 Battle," began Aug. 23 that year with China launching heavy bombardment on Kinmen, with more than 30,000 shells fired in the first 85 minutes alone.
The Chinese military did not suspend the bombardment until Oct. 6, when the intensive action had continued for 44 days.

On Oct. 20, however, China resumed the shelling. This second action ran through Oct. 25 when Beijing announced it would shift to the strategy of attacking Kinmen on odd-numbered days and resting on even-numbered days.

When the battle was over on Jan. 7, 1959, the Chinese troops had fired approximately 480,000 shells, but still failed to pound Kinmen into submission, thanks to not only support provided by the U.S. military, but also the resilience of the Kinmen troops. In the battle, the army on Kinmen countered by firing back 128,000 shells.

Chiang, who started off as a militaryman and was then deputy secretary-general of the National Defense Council, visited Little Kinmen on Oct. 21, the day after the Chinese military resumed bombing Kinmen.

In the fort in Houtou, Chiang met with Hau Pei-tsun, then commander of the 9th Division of the army forces in Kinmen, to discuss defense strategy. The fort was named the General's Fort in 1980 to pay tribute to Chiang.
The meeting is also mentioned in the "823 Battle Journal" authored by Hau, who later served as the chief of the general staff, the minister of national defense and premier.
"He (Chiang) did not come during the cease fire period but risked the shelling to come to Kinmen, which demonstrated his nobility," Hau writes.

Revisiting the General's Fort on Aug. 24, 2007, Hau recalled that fired shells were everywhere in Little Kinmen at the times of the 823 Battle and that Chiang was "the great man who made his way to the most dangerous site of the bombardment."

Hu Lian, who served as Kinmen's defense commander during the battle, writes in his book "Remembering the Old Times in Kinmen" that "Despite the fierceness of the war, he (Chiang) always took a small boat weathering choppy seas to reach every site where the situation was the most violent to boost the morale of the military and local residents, entertaining them with his witty and cheerful speeches on each occasion."
According to Hu, each of Chiang's visits to the battleground encouraged the military so strongly that it was like "bringing an extra 100,000 soldiers" to Kinmen.

Throughout his life, Chiang visited Kinmen on 123 occasions, with the combined duration of stay totaling 352 days and his footsteps were found in all 12 islands and islets of Kinmen. The visits included three that took place during the 823 Battle, making him a best friend who shared the fate of soldiers and local residents in Kinmen.
After Chiang's passing on Jan. 13, 1988, a museum was established in the Jhongshanlin Recreational Area in Kinmen in commemoration of him.
The museum, just like the General's Fort, bears witness to Chiang's sharing of suffering and hardship with the soldiers and residents in Kinmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: `Taipei Performing Arts Center' to be new landmark

TEXT.P: The establishment of a new facility -- the Taipei Performing Arts Center -- will inject new life into the city's Shihlin district, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Tuesday.
Hau made the remarks at a press conference at City Hall in which German architect Ole Scheeren was invited to present his idea for the design of the project.

The blueprint, titled "Rubik Cube, " by Scheeren and his partner Rem Koolhaas of the Netherlands-headquartered Office for Metropolitan Architecture (OMA), won the top prize in an international competition held by the city government to seek proposals for the center.
OMA made its contract bid in collaboration with the Taipei-based Artech Architect house headed by Taiwanese architect Kris Yao.
At the press conference, Hau said a landmark building can change a city's destiny, citing the example of how the Sydney Opera House affected the development of that Australian city.

The mayor also said he hopes the new center will resolve the long-standing predicament that Taipei has only one international site for the performing arts -- the National Theater and the National Concert Hall.
The new facility will also be able to share Taipei's rich cultural and arts resources, which have for long been concentrated in the city's southern region, according to Hau.

The city government plans to spend NT$4.5 billion (US$133.9 million) to build the arts center and Lee Yong-ping, director of the city's Department of Cultural Affairs, said the center, which will occupy two hectares of land, will be situated close to the Shihlin night market, a popular tourist attraction.
According to Scheeren's design, the main part of the center will comprise three theaters -- one with a seating capacity of 1,500 people and the others each with a capacity of 800.
Scheeren also explained how his plan will allow the three theaters to be turned into one giant stage through the concept of rotation he adopted from the Rubik Cube puzzle.
The construction is slated to begin in 2010, with completion projected for 2014, according to the city government.

Scheeren won fame through leading the design and construction of the China Central Television Station (CCTV) and the Television Cultural Center (TVCC), both in Beijing. He is responsible for OMA's work throughout Asia, including the 1,000-unit Scotts Tower in Singapore and a media center in Shanghai.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foundation demands cuts in cross-strait airfares

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Consumers' Foundation demanded Tuesday that carriers operating cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights cut their ticket prices by 42 percent.

Foundation Chairman Hsieh Tien-jen made the call at a news conference in which he urged the aviation companies not to use market mechanisms as an excuse to reject the call, because they are allowed to conduct their cross-strait business with the permission of the government.

Since the daily non-stop charter flights between Taiwan and China were established last December, airline companies have seen their fuel costs and travel times drop by about 50 percent, but some carriers have nevertheless increased their cross-strait charter prices by some 3 percent despite the drop in costs, Hsieh said.

Hsieh said the passenger load factor on cross-strait charter flights averaged more than 90 percent as of late last month, particularly on the routes from Taiwan to Beijing, Shanghai, Nanjing, Guangzhou and Shenzhen. During the first week of this month, in fact, charters serving these routes were all running 100 percent, he noted.

According to Hsieh, Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chih-kuo admitted last November that prices for cross-strait charter flights could be adjusted downward due to falling oil prices, while Lin Teh-he, deputy director- general of the Civil Aeronautics Administration, also said prices could be slashed by as much as 20 percent.
However, nothing concrete has been done to bring the airlines into line, he pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to control chemical substances

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) will impose controls on two chemical substances -- phthalate esters and bisphenol A -- to protect people from the hazard to health that they pose, according to an EPA statement released Monday.

The statement said phthalate esters are used to give flexibility and stability to plastic products but can harm the reproductive system. They are also suspected of causing growth retardation, it said.
The EPA is planning to ban the use of di-(2-ethylhexy) phthalate, di-n-octyl phthalate, di-n-butyl phthalate and butylbenzyl phthalate in the production of toys for children aged under 14.

Bisphenol A, the statement continued, is often used in making epoxy resins and polycarbonate products and is a commonly used chemical raw material, although it has been proven to interrupt the endocrine adjustment system.
The Taipei-based Consumers' Foundation recently discovered bisphenol A in plastic feeding bottles for infants, triggering public health concerns.
The discovery prompted the EPA to list the chemical substance as toxic to a degree that is harmful to the health and the environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former VP among those fined for failure to report assets honestly

TEXT.P: Sixty-eight former or incumbent public officials, including former Vice President Lien Chan, have been fined for failing to properly report their assets, according to a report released Tuesday by the Control Yuan.

According to the report, which covers officials fined between August 2008 and February 2009, Lien, who served as vice president between 1996 and 2000, was fined NT$100,000 (US$2,967) for "deliberately" failing to report a property he owned between 1993 and 1999 to the Control Yuan.
Lien paid the fine Oct. 6, 2008, according to the report.
Other big names among those fined were former Presidential Office Secretary- General Chen Che-nan, who was fined NT$60,000 for failing to list a security among his assets.
Chen paid the fine Jan. 14, 2009.

Cheng Wen-tsan, director of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's Cultural and Information Department, paid a fine of NT$60,000 Dec. 1, 2008 for failing to register an investment while serving as head of the Government Information Office between 2006 and 2007.

Lin Chung-cheng who served as a member of the Finance Supervisory Commission between 2005 and 2006, paid a fine of NT$130,000 Feb. 2, 2009 for failing to report foreign currencies, deposits and five kinds of security he owned.
Hu Cheng-pu, former chief of the Veterans Affairs Commission, paid a fine of NT$70,000 Jan. 5, 2009, for failing to report two deposits in 2007.
Forty-two officials, or 61.8 percent of the total named in the report, were fined for omitting their debts when registering their assets, according to the report.
The law requires senior officials, as well as elected public officials, to report their assets, with those who fail to do so subject to fines of between NT$20,000 and NT$100,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: Preparatory negotiations for cross-strait talks to be held in Taipei

TEXT.P: Preparatory cross-Taiwan Strait negotiations for a third round of talks between the chief negotiators for Taiwan and China will be held in Taipei April 18, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) head said Tuesday.

MAC Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said that Zheng Lizhong, vice president of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , will arrive in Taipei April 17 at the head of a Chinese delegation.
The preparatory meeting will work out details for the planned talks between Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and his ARATS counterpart, Chen Yunlin.
The meeting will also put the final touches to three pacts and a joint statement slated to be inked by Chiang and Chen during their meeting.

The three pacts include one on financial cooperation, one on changing the existing direct cross-strait charter flights into regular flights, and another on joint efforts to combat crime, while the joint statement will relate to opening Taiwan to investment from China.
The preparatory meeting will also broach the possibility of discussing a trade pact in a future fourth round of Chen-Chiang talks, said Lai.
Since Cheng is slated to return to Beijing April 19, another round of preparatory talks can be held at a later date if necessary, he added.
The date of the third round of SEF-ARATS talks has not yet been decided, but is expected to be at some point in late May in the Chinese city of Nanjing.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for April 15, 2009

TEXT.P: 2. Event: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan receives leaders of six industrial and commerce groups Date and Time: 3 p.m., Wednesday, April 15, 2009. Place: Executive Yuan, No. 1, ZongXiao East Road, Section 1, Taipei City. Host and/or main speakers: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan. Organizers: The Executive Yuan. Press Contact: (02) 3356-6500.
Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
MOFA mum on WHA negotiations

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) refused to confirm on Tuesday whether the government has engaged in negotiations with China on participating in the upcoming World Health Assembly (WHA) in May.
Such talks, however, would be the best way to help Taiwan achieve its goal of attending the WHA as an observer, the MOFA said.

Regarding whether the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have started substantive negotiations, it is inappropriate for me to make any comment at the moment, said Paul Chang, general-director of MOFA's Department of International Organizations, at a regular press briefing.
Should there be any communications, the government will uphold the principles of dignity and autonomy and will not accept any arrangement that demeans or belittles us,he added.

Chang was responding to a report in a local daily Monday that Beijing has agreed to let Taiwan participate in May's WHA meeting as an observer by invitation of the WHO Secretariat, although some details have yet to be sorted out.

The annual WHA -- the decision-making arm of the World Health Organization (WHO) -- is scheduled to be held May 18-27 in Geneva. Taiwan is preparing to bid for participation in the WHA for the 13th consecutive time since 1997, with previous attempts blocked due to China's obstruction.

Rebutting critics that cross-strait negotiations on the issue have taken place behind closed doors and lack transparency, Chang said there is no such thing as "closed-door meetings" and that the government has a clear goal, which is to participate in the WHA as an observer.

We believe that at the moment, not commenting on relative developments of the issue can facilitate us in achieving our goal, " he said. The foreign ministry will make any substantive results public and will accept public scrutiny, Chang pledged.

Asked what kind of arrangements would be considered by the government as belittling Taiwan, Chang only said that the MOFA is working hard to fight for participation guidelines that are in Taiwan's best interests, including on Taiwan's designation at the WHA, the level of government officials allowed to attend, and the rights that Taiwan will enjoy.
Chang denied the local daily report's contention that Taiwan's observer status would be re-examined on a "year-by-year" basis.

He said according to WHO practice, there is no such a thing as permanent observer, and, therefore, each year the Secretariat will send letters to notify observers, like the Vatican, about the time and place of its annual meeting and request the observers to provide the list of their delegation.

According to the WHA Rules of Procedures, the WHO director-general may invite states having made application for membership, territories on whose behalf application for associate membership has been made, and states which have signed but not accepted the Constitution to send observers to sessions of the Health Assembly.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA advises travelers to Thailand to exercise caution

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has advised travelers bound for Thailand Tuesday to exercise caution, but said it will maintain its current yellow-level travel alert issued a day earlier after monitoring other countriesdecisions.

The foreign ministry issued the yellow-level travel alert in consideration of the safety of Taiwanese nationals, bilateral relations between Taiwan and Thailand, and other countermeasures taken by other countries, said MOFA deputy spokesman James Chang at a regular press briefing.

As the United Kingdom and Canada have issued a "high alert" for travel to Bangkok and certain areas, he said the ministry will carefully evaluate whether to raise its travel alert level for Thailand because such a decision should be based on the situation throughout the country.
A yellow alert is the third most serious alert for foreign travel, behind red and orange alerts. An orange warning would mean that travelers are advised to postpone or cancel their trips.
Chang advised travelers to Thailand to exercise caution and avoid going to Bangkok and its surrounding five districts, including Nonthaburi, Samut Prakan, Pathum Thani, Nakhon Pathom and Ayutthaya.
The ministry's representative office in Thailand has also set up a special task force for emergencies and is maintaining close contact with Taiwanese businessmen and expatriates, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: General aviation companies push for cross-Taiwan Strait opening

TEXT.P: Six local general aviation companies appealed to the government Tuesday to allow them to operate private charters across the Taiwan Strait targeted at high-end businesses and corporate leaders.
They made the appeal after a meeting with three Chinese operators in the general aviation sector in Taipei.

The low-profile meeting was also attended by Taiwan's Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) Director-General Lee Long-wen and Wang Changshun, deputy director of the Civil Aviation Administration of China.

Prior to last year, these small aviation companies were banned from carrying passengers and cargo, with their services limited to aerial photography, atmospheric observation and measurement, construction services, and medical transport.
Taiwan then amended the Civil Aviation Law last year to allow general aviation operators to offer "special business flight services" for corporate clients.

Under an agreement signed by Taiwan and China in November 2008, however, the two countries only agreed to liberalize cross-Taiwan Strait direct charter passenger and cargo flights, and allow businessmen to fly to and from China in their private corporate jets.
Companies offering exclusive commercial services in small aircraft to business clients were excluded from the agreement, even though demand for such service has grown markedly in the past year.
According to CAA surveys, many enterprises have expressed an interest in leasing private aircraft to handle business traffic between Taiwan and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two bluefin tuna fish up for auction at Pingtung tuna festival

TEXT.P: Two bluefin tuna -- instead of one -- will be put up for auction at this year's Pingtung Bluefin Tuna Cultural Festival, breaking the festival's tradition since it was launched in 2001, the Donggang Fishermen's Association in Pingtung County said Tuesday.

The association decided to let the two northern bluefin tuna fish, recently caught by the Donggang-based Shin Shen Ching No. 126 and Chen Lung Hsing No. 2 fishing boats, respectively, be auctioned Thursday to mark the approach of the annual festival.
It will be the first time in nine years that two northern bluefin tuna will be auctioned at the two-month festival, which is slated to officially begin on May 2, association officials said.

In compliance with the rules set by the Pingtung County Government, to qualify for the auction, the tuna must be of the northern bluefin tuna species and weigh over 180 kilograms. It also has to be alive while being caught by a fishing boat registered with the Pingtung or Kaohsiung County, association officials said.

Apart from the requirements, the fish has to be the first tuna transported back to the Donggang Harbor after the boat has reported its catch to the local fishery radio station. The fish meeting all the above conditions will be eligible for the auction as the festival's "first tuna."

Although the Shin Shen Ching No. 126 was the first ship reporting its catch of a giant northern bluefin tuna to the Donggang fishery radio station on April 11, the Chen Lung Hsing No. 2 was the first boat that arrived back at the harbor with a giant tuna that met the qualifications, after having made a report of its catch to the radio station.
The two tunas were shipped back to harbor in a difference of 13 minutes, association officials said, noting that the arrival times of the first two boats have never been so close.

Chen Ching-lung, skipper of the Chen Lung Hsin No. 2 fishing vessel, said he put his boat in full gear at a speed of eight nautical miles per hour while shipping the tuna back from the high seas to Donggang after learning that he could be the quickest to return to the harbor.
Chen Chin-i, skipper of the Shin Shen Ching No. 126, lamented that his boat failed to be the first boat back, but added that was because it is aging.

The two vessels had intersected in waters off the coast of Pingtung County's Eluanbi on the way back to Donggang, and the two skippers discovered that they were elementary school classmates after landing at the harbor.
The first bluefin tuna caught last year for the Pingtung Bluefin Tuna Cultural Festival was auctioned for NT$1.73 million (US$57,055) at the festival.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, falling NT$0.077 to close at NT$33.620.
A total of US$867 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.697 and fluctuated between NT$33.569 and NT$33.715.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices rise on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices extended their winning streak into the fifth day to a seven-month high Tuesday.
The weighted index, the market's key barometer, advanced 35.04 points, or 0.59 percent, to close at 5,892.68.
Taiwan's stock market rose 252.33 points, or 4.56 percent, last week.
The local bourse opened lower at 5,814.42 and fluctuated between 5,898.76 and 5,765.81. A total of 6.47 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$148.97 billion (US$4.43 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp stocks moving up the most at 2.5 percent. Machinery and electronics shares rose 1.2 percent, textile issues added 1.1 percent, and banking and financial stocks rose 0.4 percent.

The four other major stock categories lost ground, with construction shares dropping the most at 1.6 percent. Cement shares lost 0.8 percent, foodstuff issues dropped 0.7 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares shed 0.6 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,222 to 908, with 134 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$3.25 billion.
One analyst predicted that the market would sustain its upward movement to test the 6,000-point level in the coming days, although there was still a risk the market could fall back.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA raises travel alert to orange for certain areas of Thailand

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) raised its travel alert level for certain areas of Thailand to orange Tuesday, advising travelers to postpone any visits to these destinations.
"The orange travel alert for certain areas of Thailand indicates that these locations are more dangerous than others and require extra caution," said MOFA deputy spokesman James Chang.
"However, a yellow travel alert remains in effect for the whole of Thailand," he added.

A yellow alert is a reminder for travelers to exercise caution, an orange travel alert advises travelers to postpone their trips, while a red alerts warns travelers not to enter the area in question under any circumstances.

The foreign ministry on Tuesday issued an orange alert for Bangkok and its surrounding five districts, including Nonthaburi, Samut Prakan, Pathum Thani, Nakhon Pathom and Ayutthaya, according to Chang.

The warning also covers the northern and northeast parts of Thailand, including Chiangmai, Chiangrai, Phrae, Phitsanu Lok, Lam Pang, Lam Phun, and Nakhon Ratcha Sima, Nong Khai, Udon Thani and Ubon Ratcha Thani, he added.

Chang said a yellow travel alert has been in effect for Thailand since last November, the MOFA began issuing travel warnings for certain areas of the country on April 10 when the anti-government protests escalated.

He denied that there was any delay in responding to the situation, adding that the MOFA will decide what to do next after it receives an evaluation report Wednesday from its representative office in Thailand.

Director of the MOFA's Department of East Asia and Pacific Affairs Victor Yu said in response to a reporter's question that even though the demonstrators decided to go along with one of their leaders' call Tuesday for a suspension of the protests, the MOFA will keep a close eye on the situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China looking to cooperate in global telematics industry

TEXT.P: Taiwan is looking to become a major worldwide supplier of automotive telematics devices through cooperation with China, said Deputy Minister of Economic Affairs Huang Chung-chiou Monday.
Huang made the remarks at the opening of a forum in Taipei on cross-Taiwan Strait cooperation and exchanges in the telematics industry.

Huang said although the world automobile industry has been seriously hit by the current economic recession, China's automobile production is forecast to reach 6.5 million to 7.5 million units this year to meet its huge domestic demand.

China is emerging as a major automobile consumption and production market, alongside the United States and Europe, driven by its efforts in recent years to achieve rapid growth in this sector, Huang noted at the forum, which was organized by the Institute for Information Industry and the Industrial Technology Research Institute.

In 2007, the total production volume of Global Positioning Systems (GPS) in Taiwan was 37.73 million, with a production value of NT$177.05 billion, according to statistics quoted by Huang. Personal Navigation Devices (PNDs) accounted for more than 70 percent of the total, with a delivery volume of more than 29 million, he said. The production volume of PNDs is forecast to reach 80 million in 2012, he added.

Roughly 175 million GPS-enabled handsets were manufactured in Taiwan in 2007, and the figure is expected to reach 560 million in 2012, which indicates that Taiwan has become an important supplier of telematics products, he said.

In order to focus more on the development of telematics in the automobile industry, the cost of electronic systems in vehicles would be adjusted from 19 percent to 40 percent of the total cost of automobile production in the future, Huang said.

As telematics companies in both Taiwan and China are specialists in their respective fields, it would be mutually beneficial to the two sides to pool their resources in order to become major suppliers of telematics devices, he suggested.

Dong Yang, Executive Vice President of the China Association of Automobile Manufacturers, said he is also keen to facilitate cooperation between the automobile industries in Taiwan and China, and thus help through the current global economic crisis and create economic benefits for both sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen fishermen catch big yellow croaker

TEXT.P: Four fishermen from Taiwan's outlying Kinmen Island on Tuesday made a highly unusual catch -- a big yellow croaker weighing 2.5 kilograms -- while they were fishing in the South China Sea.
Chen Sung-shu, the 66-year-old skipper of the Sheng Lee fishing boat where the fishermen worked, said it was the biggest yellow croaker that he has ever caught in nearly 20 years.
The fish of 60 centimeters long was purchased by another Kinmen fisherman for NT$12,000 (US$356). That fisherman plans to re-sell it to China at a higher price that could amount to NT$50,000.

"It is already very difficult to catch big yellow croaker weighing over 1.5 kilograms nowadays, although the waters off Kinmen Island were once a fishing ground rich in that specie of the fish, " Chen said.
"I once caught as much as 4,500 kilograms of yellow croaker in just one haul in 1971," he recounted.

According to officials at the Kinmen County Fisheries Research Institute, yellow croaker -- a fish of high-value unique to waters off the county -- has become an endangered specie as a result of poaching and overfishing by Chinese fishing boats which illegally operate in the area.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economics Ministry to expand auto parts export market

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is promoting a guidance plan aimed at helping exporters of auto parts and accessories to create more business opportunities abroad, a ministry official said Tuesday.

The MOEA has crafted the plan as the industry is one of the most competitive of Taiwan's small- and medium-sized enterprises in terms of exports, according to Economic Affairs Deputy Minister Lin Sheng-chung.

Lin said that although global automobile demand has fallen sharply since the second half of last year due to the impact of the global economic downturn, putting major auto parts manufacturers in Europe, the United States and Japan at risk of collapse, Taiwan's counterparts have been relatively less affected by the crisis thanks to their high quality after-sales services and products.

The plan is part of the NT$8.53 billion (US$25.48 million) "New Zheng He Plan" initiated by the MOEA last December to assist suppliers and manufacturers producing goods for export, with the aim of attracting NT$540 billion in export orders per year.

Lin made the remarks at the opening of the 2009 Taipei International Auto Parts and Accessories Show and the Taipei International Automobile Electronics Show running concurrently at the Taipei World Trade Center's Nangang Exhibition Hall.
Up to 1,100 manufacturers are taking part in the two shows, displaying their latest products in 2,700 booths.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fort stands witness to late Taiwan president's inspiration to troops

TEXT.P: As various events held recently to mark the 100th anniversary of the birth of Taiwan's late President Chiang Ching-kuo are invoking the public's memories of him, Chiang's close comradeship with the military posted on the Taiwan-held island group of Kinmen during war times may be among the most remembered.

One of the most important testimonies to Chiang's devotion to troops at a time when the island faced the threat of an invasion from China after the two sides split in 1949 was the General's Fort, a war-time historic site that has been transformed into a tourist destination.

Located in Houtou on the east side of Little Kinmen, the smaller of the two major islands comprising Kinmen, the fort was intended as an outpost monitoring the Jinlieh Channel which separates the two islands. It became well-known when Chiang went there amid China's artillery shelling of the island group in 1958.

The conflict, known internationally as the Battle of the Taiwan Strait or locally as "823 Battle," began Aug. 23 that year with China launching heavy bombardment on Kinmen, with more than 30,000 shells fired in the first 85 minutes alone.
The Chinese military did not suspend the bombardment until Oct. 6, when the intensive action had continued for 44 days.

On Oct. 20, however, China resumed the shelling. This second action ran through Oct. 25 when Beijing announced it would shift to the strategy of attacking Kinmen on odd-numbered days and resting on even-numbered days.

When the battle was over on Jan. 7, 1959, the Chinese troops had fired approximately 480,000 shells, but still failed to pound Kinmen into submission, thanks to not only support provided by the U.S. military, but also the resilience of the Kinmen troops. In the battle, the army on Kinmen countered by firing back 128,000 shells.

Chiang, who started off as a militaryman and was then deputy secretary-general of the National Defense Council, visited Little Kinmen on Oct. 21, the day after the Chinese military resumed bombing Kinmen.

In the fort in Houtou, Chiang met with Hau Pei-tsun, then commander of the 9th Division of the army forces in Kinmen, to discuss defense strategy. The fort was named the General's Fort in 1980 to pay tribute to Chiang.
The meeting is also mentioned in the "823 Battle Journal" authored by Hau, who later served as the chief of the general staff, the minister of national defense and premier.
"He (Chiang) did not come during the cease fire period but risked the shelling to come to Kinmen, which demonstrated his nobility," Hau writes.

Revisiting the General's Fort on Aug. 24, 2007, Hau recalled that fired shells were everywhere in Little Kinmen at the times of the 823 Battle and that Chiang was "the great man who made his way to the most dangerous site of the bombardment."

Hu Lian, who served as Kinmen's defense commander during the battle, writes in his book "Remembering the Old Times in Kinmen" that "Despite the fierceness of the war, he (Chiang) always took a small boat weathering choppy seas to reach every site where the situation was the most violent to boost the morale of the military and local residents, entertaining them with his witty and cheerful speeches on each occasion."
According to Hu, each of Chiang's visits to the battleground encouraged the military so strongly that it was like "bringing an extra 100,000 soldiers" to Kinmen.

Throughout his life, Chiang visited Kinmen on 123 occasions, with the combined duration of stay totaling 352 days and his footsteps were found in all 12 islands and islets of Kinmen. The visits included three that took place during the 823 Battle, making him a best friend who shared the fate of soldiers and local residents in Kinmen.
After Chiang's passing on Jan. 13, 1988, a museum was established in the Jhongshanlin Recreational Area in Kinmen in commemoration of him.
The museum, just like the General's Fort, bears witness to Chiang's sharing of suffering and hardship with the soldiers and residents in Kinmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: `Taipei Performing Arts Center' to be new landmark

TEXT.P: The establishment of a new facility -- the Taipei Performing Arts Center -- will inject new life into the city's Shihlin district, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Tuesday.
Hau made the remarks at a press conference at City Hall in which German architect Ole Scheeren was invited to present his idea for the design of the project.

The blueprint, titled "Rubik Cube, " by Scheeren and his partner Rem Koolhaas of the Netherlands-headquartered Office for Metropolitan Architecture (OMA), won the top prize in an international competition held by the city government to seek proposals for the center.
OMA made its contract bid in collaboration with the Taipei-based Artech Architect house headed by Taiwanese architect Kris Yao.
At the press conference, Hau said a landmark building can change a city's destiny, citing the example of how the Sydney Opera House affected the development of that Australian city.

The mayor also said he hopes the new center will resolve the long-standing predicament that Taipei has only one international site for the performing arts -- the National Theater and the National Concert Hall.
The new facility will also be able to share Taipei's rich cultural and arts resources, which have for long been concentrated in the city's southern region, according to Hau.

The city government plans to spend NT$4.5 billion (US$133.9 million) to build the arts center and Lee Yong-ping, director of the city's Department of Cultural Affairs, said the center, which will occupy two hectares of land, will be situated close to the Shihlin night market, a popular tourist attraction.
According to Scheeren's design, the main part of the center will comprise three theaters -- one with a seating capacity of 1,500 people and the others each with a capacity of 800.
Scheeren also explained how his plan will allow the three theaters to be turned into one giant stage through the concept of rotation he adopted from the Rubik Cube puzzle.
The construction is slated to begin in 2010, with completion projected for 2014, according to the city government.

Scheeren won fame through leading the design and construction of the China Central Television Station (CCTV) and the Television Cultural Center (TVCC), both in Beijing. He is responsible for OMA's work throughout Asia, including the 1,000-unit Scotts Tower in Singapore and a media center in Shanghai.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foundation demands cuts in cross-strait airfares

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Consumers' Foundation demanded Tuesday that carriers operating cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights cut their ticket prices by 42 percent.

Foundation Chairman Hsieh Tien-jen made the call at a news conference in which he urged the aviation companies not to use market mechanisms as an excuse to reject the call, because they are allowed to conduct their cross-strait business with the permission of the government.

Since the daily non-stop charter flights between Taiwan and China were established last December, airline companies have seen their fuel costs and travel times drop by about 50 percent, but some carriers have nevertheless increased their cross-strait charter prices by some 3 percent despite the drop in costs, Hsieh said.

Hsieh said the passenger load factor on cross-strait charter flights averaged more than 90 percent as of late last month, particularly on the routes from Taiwan to Beijing, Shanghai, Nanjing, Guangzhou and Shenzhen. During the first week of this month, in fact, charters serving these routes were all running 100 percent, he noted.

According to Hsieh, Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chih-kuo admitted last November that prices for cross-strait charter flights could be adjusted downward due to falling oil prices, while Lin Teh-he, deputy director- general of the Civil Aeronautics Administration, also said prices could be slashed by as much as 20 percent.
However, nothing concrete has been done to bring the airlines into line, he pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to control chemical substances

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) will impose controls on two chemical substances -- phthalate esters and bisphenol A -- to protect people from the hazard to health that they pose, according to an EPA statement released Monday.

The statement said phthalate esters are used to give flexibility and stability to plastic products but can harm the reproductive system. They are also suspected of causing growth retardation, it said.
The EPA is planning to ban the use of di-(2-ethylhexy) phthalate, di-n-octyl phthalate, di-n-butyl phthalate and butylbenzyl phthalate in the production of toys for children aged under 14.

Bisphenol A, the statement continued, is often used in making epoxy resins and polycarbonate products and is a commonly used chemical raw material, although it has been proven to interrupt the endocrine adjustment system.
The Taipei-based Consumers' Foundation recently discovered bisphenol A in plastic feeding bottles for infants, triggering public health concerns.
The discovery prompted the EPA to list the chemical substance as toxic to a degree that is harmful to the health and the environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former VP among those fined for failure to report assets honestly

TEXT.P: Sixty-eight former or incumbent public officials, including former Vice President Lien Chan, have been fined for failing to properly report their assets, according to a report released Tuesday by the Control Yuan.

According to the report, which covers officials fined between August 2008 and February 2009, Lien, who served as vice president between 1996 and 2000, was fined NT$100,000 (US$2,967) for "deliberately" failing to report a property he owned between 1993 and 1999 to the Control Yuan.
Lien paid the fine Oct. 6, 2008, according to the report.
Other big names among those fined were former Presidential Office Secretary- General Chen Che-nan, who was fined NT$60,000 for failing to list a security among his assets.
Chen paid the fine Jan. 14, 2009.

Cheng Wen-tsan, director of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's Cultural and Information Department, paid a fine of NT$60,000 Dec. 1, 2008 for failing to register an investment while serving as head of the Government Information Office between 2006 and 2007.

Lin Chung-cheng who served as a member of the Finance Supervisory Commission between 2005 and 2006, paid a fine of NT$130,000 Feb. 2, 2009 for failing to report foreign currencies, deposits and five kinds of security he owned.
Hu Cheng-pu, former chief of the Veterans Affairs Commission, paid a fine of NT$70,000 Jan. 5, 2009, for failing to report two deposits in 2007.
Forty-two officials, or 61.8 percent of the total named in the report, were fined for omitting their debts when registering their assets, according to the report.
The law requires senior officials, as well as elected public officials, to report their assets, with those who fail to do so subject to fines of between NT$20,000 and NT$100,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: Preparatory negotiations for cross-strait talks to be held in Taipei

TEXT.P: Preparatory cross-Taiwan Strait negotiations for a third round of talks between the chief negotiators for Taiwan and China will be held in Taipei April 18, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) head said Tuesday.

MAC Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said that Zheng Lizhong, vice president of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , will arrive in Taipei April 17 at the head of a Chinese delegation.
The preparatory meeting will work out details for the planned talks between Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and his ARATS counterpart, Chen Yunlin.
The meeting will also put the final touches to three pacts and a joint statement slated to be inked by Chiang and Chen during their meeting.

The three pacts include one on financial cooperation, one on changing the existing direct cross-strait charter flights into regular flights, and another on joint efforts to combat crime, while the joint statement will relate to opening Taiwan to investment from China.
The preparatory meeting will also broach the possibility of discussing a trade pact in a future fourth round of Chen-Chiang talks, said Lai.
Since Cheng is slated to return to Beijing April 19, another round of preparatory talks can be held at a later date if necessary, he added.
The date of the third round of SEF-ARATS talks has not yet been decided, but is expected to be at some point in late May in the Chinese city of Nanjing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open lower

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened lower Wednesday, moving down 12.82 points at 5,879.86 on a turnover of NT$3.69 billion (US$109.76 million).
The weighted price index gained 35.04 points, or 0.59 percent, to close at 5,892.68 Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Wednesday, trading NT$0.054 higher at NT$33.674 at 10 a.m. on the Taipei Foreign Exchange.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 15, or the 20th day of the third month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1865: Andrew Johnson is sworn in as the 17th president of the United States following the assassination of Abraham Lincoln.
1912: The British luxury liner the Titanic sinks after hitting an iceberg during its maiden voyage to New York. More than 1,500 people are feared drowned in the icy waters of the North Atlantic.
1923: Insulin is made available for general use by diabetics when Canadian physiologist Sir Frederick Grant Banting shares a 1923 Nobel Prize for the discovery of insulin.
1927: Chiang Kai-shek, commander-in-chief of the National Revolutionary Forces, organizes the Republic of China government in Nanjing.
1942: Japanese artillery blasts U.S. positions on Corregidor in the Philippines.
1945: Art treasures looted by the Nazis, including paintings by Rubens, Goya, Raphael, and Leonardo da Vinci, are found in an Austrian mine shaft.
1949: The Chinese communists demand ROC government acceptance of their eight- point proposal by April 20, following talks which began in Beijing on April 5.
1952: U.S. President Harry S. Truman signs a peace treaty between the United States and Japan.
1958: The first meeting of independent African nations is held in Accra, Ghana.
1959: U.S. Secretary of State John Dulles resigns due to illness. The American diplomat and politician pursued a policy of opposition to the USSR largely through military and economic aid to American allies.
1966: A team of American virologists develops a vaccine for German measles, known medically as rubella.
1971: President Joseph Desire Mobutu of Congo and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1971: London and Beijing agree to the reopening of a telephone link between London and Shanghai which had been closed for 22 years.
1975: Praising the late ROC President Chiang Kai-shek as "an old friend and a great leader," Vice President Nelson A. Rockefeller of the United States arrives in Taipei to attend the National Memorial Services for the generalissimo.
1975: ROC Premier Chiang Ching-kuo reveals President Chiang's last written instruction to him. The late leader told his eldest son to assume full responsibility for the fate of the nation without regard to his personal fate.
1976: India and Communist China resume diplomatic relations.
1976: Dr. Alfredo Lamaison, a member of the State Council of Uruguay, and Arg Gustave Nicolich, president of National University, arrive in Taipei for a nine- day visit.
1980: Jean-Paul Sartre, the French writer and philosopher who declined the 1957 Nobel Prize for literature, dies in Paris at the age of 74. A leading existentialist, he wrote literary works such as the autobiographical novel "Nausea" and the play "No Exit," as well as philosophical volumes that include "Being and Nothingness."
1988: President Kim Il Sung receives 43,000 gifts as he celebrates his 76th birthday in style. The North Korean dictator died in 1994.
1989: Hu Yaobang, former general secretary of China's Communist Party, dies of a heart attack in Beijing at the age of 73. A democracy movement is launched by Beijing University students following his death.
1989: Ninety-five soccer fans are crushed to death and 200 injured at Sheffield's Hillsborough Stadium in Britain's worst-ever sports disaster.
1994: The Uruguay Round of talks on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) concludes with ministers from more than 100 of the world's trading nations signing the GATT pact, the biggest market-opening treaty in history, and also with the announcement of the setting up of the World Trade Organization (WTO).
1996: The United States and Japan announce the closure of six more U.S. military facilities on Okinawa.
1997: The first locally-developed Ching Kuo tactical combat aircraft wing, a second generation ROC Air Force warplane, is founded at the Chingchuankang air force base in Taichung.
1998: Pol Pot, former Khmer Rouge leader, dies of a heart attack.
2000: Republic of China Defense Minister Tang Fei, who has been designated as the next premier by President-elect Chen Shui-bian, checks into Veterans General Hospital to undergo a thymoma operation.
2001: At least four persons are killed and more than 40 injure in an accident involving two buses near Encore Garden in Taichung, central Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man looks upwards in his aspirations; a fool looks downwards."
