DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Number of unemployment benefit applicants falling

TEXT.P: The number of applicants for unemployment benefits continues to decrease in April as the economy shows signs of improvement, the Bureau of Labor Insurance said Wednesday.

During the first 14 days of April, an average of 866 people per working day applied for the benefits for the first time since becoming unemployed, down significantly from the average of 1,275 in the same period the previous month, said Tsai Chi-an, president of the bureau.
Meanwhile, the total number of applications has also been falling after reaching a peak of 6,000 per working day on average in February, Tsai said.
The number dropped to 5,000 per working day in March and further to 4,200 per working day so far in April, he said.

According to the Employment Insurance Law, workers who lose their jobs through no fault of their own and who fail to find new ones within 14 days of registering with a government-run employment service organization can receive 60 percent of their insured wages for up to six months.
They are required to report to a CLA employment service center every month to have their unemployed status verified in order to continue receiving the benefits.
From May, the maximum duration for unemployment benefits will be extended to nine months for older workers and those with physical or mental disabilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former VP among those fined for failure to report assets honestly

TEXT.P: Sixty-eight former or incumbent public officials, including former Vice President Lien Chan, have been fined for failing to properly report their assets, according to a report released Tuesday by the Control Yuan.

According to the report, which covers officials fined between August 2008 and February 2009, Lien, who served as vice president between 1996 and 2000, was fined NT$100,000 (US$2,967) for "deliberately" failing to report a property he owned between 1993 and 1999 to the Control Yuan.
Lien paid the fine Oct. 6, 2008, according to the report.
Other big names among those fined were former Presidential Office Secretary- General Chen Che-nan, who was fined NT$60,000 for failing to list a security among his assets.
Chen paid the fine Jan. 14, 2009.

Cheng Wen-tsan, director of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's Cultural and Information Department, paid a fine of NT$60,000 Dec. 1, 2008 for failing to register an investment while serving as head of the Government Information Office between 2006 and 2007.

Lin Chung-cheng who served as a member of the Finance Supervisory Commission between 2005 and 2006, paid a fine of NT$130,000 Feb. 2, 2009 for failing to report foreign currencies, deposits and five kinds of security he owned.
Hu Cheng-pu, former chief of the Veterans Affairs Commission, paid a fine of NT$70,000 Jan. 5, 2009, for failing to report two deposits in 2007.
Forty-two officials, or 61.8 percent of the total named in the report, were fined for omitting their debts when registering their assets, according to the report.
The law requires senior officials, as well as elected public officials, to report their assets, with those who fail to do so subject to fines of between NT$20,000 and NT$100,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to control chemical substances

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) will impose controls on two chemical substances -- phthalate esters and bisphenol A -- to protect people from the hazard to health that they pose, according to an EPA statement released Monday.

The statement said phthalate esters are used to give flexibility and stability to plastic products but can harm the reproductive system. They are also suspected of causing growth retardation, it said.
The EPA is planning to ban the use of di-(2-ethylhexy) phthalate, di-n-octyl phthalate, di-n-butyl phthalate and butylbenzyl phthalate in the production of toys for children aged under 14.

Bisphenol A, the statement continued, is often used in making epoxy resins and polycarbonate products and is a commonly used chemical raw material, although it has been proven to interrupt the endocrine adjustment system.
The Taipei-based Consumers' Foundation recently discovered bisphenol A in plastic feeding bottles for infants, triggering public health concerns.
The discovery prompted the EPA to list the chemical substance as toxic to a degree that is harmful to the health and the environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Preparatory negotiations for cross-strait talks to be held in Taipei

TEXT.P: Preparatory cross-Taiwan Strait negotiations for a third round of talks between the chief negotiators for Taiwan and China will be held in Taipei April 18, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) head said Tuesday.

MAC Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said that Zheng Lizhong, vice president of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , will arrive in Taipei April 17 at the head of a Chinese delegation.
The preparatory meeting will work out details for the planned talks between Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and his ARATS counterpart, Chen Yunlin.
The meeting will also put the final touches to three pacts and a joint statement slated to be inked by Chiang and Chen during their meeting.

The three pacts include one on financial cooperation, one on changing the existing direct cross-strait charter flights into regular flights, and another on joint efforts to combat crime, while the joint statement will relate to opening Taiwan to investment from China.
The preparatory meeting will also broach the possibility of discussing a trade pact in a future fourth round of Chen-Chiang talks, said Lai.
Since Cheng is slated to return to Beijing April 19, another round of preparatory talks can be held at a later date if necessary, he added.
The date of the third round of SEF-ARATS talks has not yet been decided, but is expected to be at some point in late May in the Chinese city of Nanjing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan student to perform with YouTube Symphony at Carnegie Hall
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 14 (CNA) 04/15/09 15:08:36 (By Lillian Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Kami Lee, a music student from Taiwan who is now pursuing a master's degree at the Boston Conservatory, will make his debut in New York as part of the YouTube Symphony at Carnegie Hall Wednesday evening.

Lee will be the principal second violinist in the 96-member orchestra that will perform the Internet Symphony No. 1 Eroica composed by Tan Dun -- one of the most influential classical composers to emerge out of China -- among other works under the direction of conductor Michael Tilson Thomas.
The YouTube Symphony's concert in New York will mark the debut of its global tour.
The 26-year-old Lee was the sole Taiwanese selected by YouTube over the Internet among more than 3,000 applicants from around the world to play in its symphony orchestra.
"I felt especially honored to be able to perform on the same stage with Thomas, although it is not my first time playing in a symphony orchestra," Lee told the Central News Agency.
To prepare for the upcoming performance, the 96 members assembled in New York for two and a half days ahead of the concert to practice the pieces they will perform, he said.
"It should be a lot of fun because we're going to play both modern and classical music, ranging from Mozart to disco and techno music," he said.

Among the 96 members, there are veteran middle-aged musicians as well as teenaged talent. "Our cooperation is a multi-faceted interpretation of music and I treasure very much this opportunity to work with them," he said.

Lee has been studying in Boston for two years after graduating from National Taiwan Normal University's Department of Music. He will be the only Taiwanese member of the orchestra, which also includes seven members from Hong Kong and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sun Moon Lake to offer first chapel wedding in May

TEXT.P: A historic chapel located on a hill next to the scenic Sun Moon Lake in central Taiwan will be opened for the first time for a wedding ceremony, the Sun Moon Lake National Scenic Area Administration said Wednesday.
The Chapel of Christ overlooking the lake was built in 1971 for personal worship by then President Chiang Kai-shek, who visited Sun Moon Lake frequently with his wife Soong Mayling for relaxation.
After opening the Romanesque building for public visits earlier this year, the administration will hold a joint wedding at the chapel for 10 selected couples next month.

The ceremony to be performed by a Christian pastor will be part of a special two-day, one night package on May 26-27, which will also include a one-night stay in a lake-view suite at Fleur de Chine Hotel and a candlelit dinner and lake cruise.
The package will cost NT$5,200 (US$155) per couple, the administration said.
The activity is open to engaged couples as well as married couples who want to experience a solemn chapel wedding as their second honeymoon, the administration said.

Each couple interested in taking part in the activity should send in their entry form by 5 p.m. on April 20, on which they are required to write a true story describing one of their experiences at Sun Moon Lake.
Ten couples will be selected based on the level of interest of their stories, the administration said, adding that more than 20 couples have registered so far.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices slightly lower on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices edged lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 17.49 points, or 0.29 percent, to close at 5,875.19.
The local bourse opened lower at 5,879.86 but rose to a high of 5,904.28 early in the session before falling as low as 5,798.62,
A total of 6.48 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$148.65 billion (US$4.4 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks and plastics and chemicals shares both falling the most at 0.8 percent. Textile stocks and machinery and electronics shares both dropped 0.5 percent, banking and financial shares were down 0.4 percent, and paper and pulp issues decreased 0.2 percent.
Two other major stocks gained ground, with construction issues moving up 2.4 percent and foodstuff issues rising 0.5 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,080 to 1,032, with 144 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$2.03 billion.
One analyst said with profit-taking on the rise, there is little room for the market to rise further, meaning the Taiex was likely to hover between 5,700 and 6,000 in the coming days.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK to ease entry arrangements for Taiwanese visitors

TEXT.P: The Hong Kong government has decided to ease entry arrangements for visitors from Taiwan with effect from April 27, Hong Kong's immigration department said Wednesday.

Under the new arrangement, travelers holding a valid "Mainland Travel Permit for Taiwan Residents" can enter Hong Kong and stay for up to seven days, a development that analysts said signifies an improvement in Taiwan-Hong Kong relations.
Currently, Taiwanese wishing to enter Hong Kong on this type of document also need to possess a valid entry/exit endorsement for China.
Taiwanese residents can also enter Hong Kong by directly applying for permits from the Hong Kong government with which they can stay in the region for up to 30 days.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'One-handed knife king' finds solace, success in the kitchen

TEXT.P: Kuo Hsing-chung owns two popular Thai food restaurants in Taipei that serve dishes meticulously prepared by him and a team of cooks. At first glance, the restaurants are just two more good choices for Thai food in Taiwan's capital city, led by an accomplished chef.

It's only when clients enter Kuo's restaurant on Taipei's Guangfu South Road and run into the owner that they notice he is missing his left hand -- a condition that has existed since birth -- and they invariably wonder how he manages to stir-fry his dishes.

Kuo is just one of many individuals in Taiwan who has had to overcome a physical disability, but his acquired profession is one that does not lend itself easily to working with only one hand, as he has discovered during his 16-year career.

Some of the simplest kitchen tasks, such as cutting vegetables or stir-frying dishes in a wok, nearly drove Kuo away from the profession more than once, but he persevered through the challenges and now the chef known in the trade as the "one-handed knife king" treats his missing hand as nothing more than an inconvenience.
"I have only one hand, but I can do what a normal person cannot do with two hands, " the 32-year-old chef says proudly and confidently.
Originally from the Thai-Burmese border town of Mae Salong, Kuo faltered and cried numerous times in his pursuit of success after coming to Taiwan with his family at the age of 12.
"Fortunately, I didn't give up on myself in the early years of my apprenticeship. I have accomplished what others may have thought I could never achieve," he reflects.
In retrospect, Kuo says he isolated himself from other people when he first came to Taipei.

"Back then, I felt at loss about the future. From a primitive Thai-Burmese border town to a city like Taipei, I was afraid of strangers' gazes or glares. Walking in public, I instinctively hid my deformed left hand and did not like to expose it in front of others. They would talk about behind my back," he recalls.
A turning point came when he turned 16. His uncle had opened a Thai restaurant and recruited him as an apprentice.

"I was assigned to work in the kitchen. At first, I thought it was good as I didn't need to face customers. But my deformity, coupled with my inability to interact with others, discouraged cooks from teaching me anything," he remembers vividly.

"They even told my uncle that I was unlikely to become a cook or chef. I was enraged by their contempt but reacted with resignation. Since they didn't want to teach me, I didn't want to learn, " Kuo adds.
After working in the kitchen for half a year, Kuo still could not hold a knife properly, and he was ready to give up.

But thanks to the repeated encouragement of his father and uncle, and the shock of seeing others get promoted ahead of him, Kuo finally saw the light. "I couldn't throw in the towel so easily. I was determined to learn by myself if nobody would teach me. "

He began to observe how cooks cut different foods. During breaks, he would practice cutting discarded carrots and cabbages, using his left elbow to keep foods in place as he was cutting them. It was not an easy maneuver for him, and he cut himself often.

After several months of "groping in the dark, " he gradually acquired top cutting skills, slicing cabbage, for instance, in consistent sizes. Fellow cooks began calling him the "one-handed knife king."
Then came the equally difficult challenge of stir-frying or sauteing foods.
"Woks tend to be heavy. Every step -- stirring, seasoning or flavoring, and heating -- should be perfectly timed for a stir-fried dish to be delicious," Kuo relates.
He remembers that he threw away the first sauteed dish he prepared after four months of practice because other workers at his uncle's restaurant yelled that the dish had a "burnt smell."
His lack of progress left him downcast and in despair. Worse still, because he could only use one hand to stir-fry foods, he suffered severe back ligament injuries.
"The debilitating pain frequently made me cry in the middle of the night. At one point, I thought of giving up, " Kuo remembers.
"But realizing that I didn't have too many other choices kept me from yielding. Even though I had to endure more hardships and adversity, I couldn't afford to give up," Kuo recounts.
After three years of diligent and arduous study, Kuo finally emerged as a skilled chef of Thai cuisine who can cut and saute a wide variety of fine Thai dishes.
In all, it took him eight years to climb to the post of chief chef at his uncle's restaurant at the age of 24.
To perfect his culinary art and skill, Kuo has traveled to Thailand many times to study with noted Thai chefs, he said he was lucky to have such an opportunity.

"They repeatedly encouraged me to take part in culinary contests and they often reminded me that I should never lose self-confidence because I can do with one hand what others have to do with two hands," Kuo recalls.
"Their words sounded like a wake-up call, kindling my self-confidence and letting me understand that I'm not frail, " he says.
With firm determination and plenty of confidence, Kuo decided to set up his own restaurant at the age of 28.
"Over the years, my disability has become my strength. Having recognized this, I'm confident I can cope with many of my life's challenges ahead."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, increasing NT$0.170 to close at NT$33.790.
A total of US$1.02 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.700 and fluctuated between NT$33.580 and NT$33.790.

DOC.HEADLINE: Teenagers found vulnerable to rape by online acquaintances

TEXT.P: More than 60 percent of sexual assault cases that result from online encounters involve victims between the ages of 12 and 17 in Taipei City, which highlights the vulnerability of teenagers to this type of violence, the city's Department of Social Welfare said Wednesday.

Statistics from the Taipei City Center for Protection of Domestic Violence and Sexual Assault show that in 2007, there were 82 reported cases of rape that took place during real meetings between persons that had first made contact online, accounting for 11.1 percent of all rape cases reported in the city during the year.
The number of such cases increased slightly to 86 in 2008, accounting for 10.8 percent of all sexual assault cases.
There were 17 such cases during the first three months of 2009, accounting for 10.9 percent of all rape cases reported during that period.
In these cases, the largest group of victims -- more than 60 percent -- were in the 12-17 age group, the statistics show.

Chiang Hsing-hui, director of the center, said that social workers have found that many teenage rape victims had been experiencing great pressure and had suffered setbacks and expected to gain acceptance from friends on the Internet.
The desire to meet someone of the opposite sex also exposes teenagers to dangerous situations, Chiang said.

She advised parents to spend more time with their children and pay closer attention to their Internet use to help prevent them from making any potentially dangerous in-person contact with people they encounter casually online.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China agree to cooperate in telematics industry development

TEXT.P: China and Taiwan have recently agreed to establish the first cross-Taiwan Strait platform for cooperation and mutual exchanges in the telematics industry.

Ke Jyh-sheng, president of Taiwan's quasi-official Institute for Information Industry (III), signed a letter of intent Monday with Lu Ning, president of China's Changchun Optoelectronics Information Industry Association, and Cheng Fu-hsiung, vice chairman of the Taipei-based Taiwan Electrical Electronic Manufacturers' Association as a precursor to the cross-strait cooperation.

The cooperation agreement, once established, will allow Taiwan to assist Changchun City, in northeastern China's Jilin Province, in developing a wireless broadband network while opening the doors for cross-strait cooperation in the automobile electronics and telematics application sectors.

The signing of the letter of intent marked an achievement of a cross-strait conference on telematics cooperation and exchanges that was held April 13-14 at the Taipei World Trade Center Nangang Exhibition Hall.

In addition, Taiwan's E-Lead Electronic Corp. signed an agreement with the College of Automotive Engineering of Jilin University Monday at the closing of the Taipei conference, beginning the first concrete cooperation effort of the two sides in the telematics industry.
E-Lead Vice Chairman Chen Hsi-yiao said that under the new cooperative ties, his company will work with Jilin University in the development and manufacture of automotive electronic products.
In the preliminary stage, Chen went on, the two sides will focus on efforts to come up with an improved tire pressure monitoring system.

At the signing ceremony, III Vice President Wang Wei expressed anticipation that the pact will attract more Taiwanese automotive electronics producers to seek R&D collaboration with Jilin University, as well as with the First Automobile Works (FAW) Group Corp., one of China's three largest auto manufacturers.

The just-ended cross-strait conference on telematics cooperation and exchanges was the third in a series of activities prepared by the Ministry of Economic Affairs as part of a "bridging" program it initiated to boost cross-strait industrial and business cooperation and exchanges.
The program has already succeeded in pushing through cross-strait exchanges in the fields of traditional herbal medicine and solar energy.

The telematics event drew more than 80 Chinese professionals in the field from Beijing, Shanghai, Changchun, Fujien and Xiamen, including Dong Yang, executive vice president of the China Association of Automobile Manufacturers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to spend NT$60 million to improve gas water heater safety

TEXT.P: The government will spend up to NT$60 million (US$1.78 million) to help households around Taiwan to improve the safety of their gas water heaters and reduce the risk of carbon monoxide poisoning, Minister of the Interior Liao Liao-yi said Wednesday.

Liao told a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Social Welfare and Environmental Hygiene Committee that a recent survey shows that about 34,000 households in Taiwan are prone to carbon monoxide poisoning because their gas water heaters have been installed at locations where ventilation is poor.
The survey, conducted by the National Fire Agency under the Ministry of the Interior in March, collected information from the families of 960,000 junior middle school students.
The results showed that of the 34,000 households with a high risk of carbon monoxide poisoning, 20,000 said they would improve the situations themselves.

Liao said his ministry will grant a subsidy of NT$3,000 to each of the remaining 14,000 households to reduce gas poisoning risk by relocating their gas water heaters to safer locations or by improving the ventilation in their homes.
He acknowledged that he is not sure where the money will come from, but said he will try to coordinate with the Ministry of Economic Affairs to come up with funds for the plan.

According to the National Fire Agency, most carbon monoxide poisoning accidents caused by bathroom gas water heaters occur during the period from December to March when people normally do not open windows in the cold season.
Statistics compiled by the agency showed that the number of carbon monoxide poisoning accidents in Taiwan have steadily risen in recent years after falling in 2006.

There were 176 such cases nationwide in 2005, resulting in 31 deaths and 358 people injured; 38 cases in 2006, causing 20 deaths and 86 people injured; 41 cases in 2007, leading to 15 deaths and 90 people injured; and 68 cases in 2008, killing 13 people and injuring 155 others.
The statistics also showed that in January of this year alone, there were 16 carbon monoxide poisoning cases, causing 10 people to lose their lives and 40 others to suffer injuries.

DOC.HEADLINE: 18 pigs culled in Changhua County FMD scare: official

TEXT.P: Eighteen pigs on a farm in the central county of Changhua were culled late Monday after they were found to have developed symptoms of the highly contagious foot-and-mouth disease (FMD), a county official confirmed Wednesday.

Kuo Chou-tseh, head of the county's Bureau of Animal Health Inspection and Quarantine, said the 18 pigs were killed on the farm immediately after a veterinarian at the Changhua meat market discovered April 13 that 10 out of 50 pigs sent to the meat market by the farm appeared to have FMD symptoms.
A total of 947 pigs were being raised on the farm, Kuo added.

According to Kuo, seven other pig farms within a 1-km radius of the farm were disinfected later Monday in an effort to prevent the spread of the virus, and vaccinations were also given to about 5,000 pigs being raised in the neighborhood.

According to officials of the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA), there are about 12,000 hog farms in Taiwan, with 90 percent of their stock having received no FMD inoculation.

Monday's report was the fourth of its kind since February, following the first case reported in Yunlin County Feb. 4, a second reported in Changhua County Feb. 9 and a third in Chiayi County March 27, COA officials reported.

They urged the public not to panic over the development, describing the appearance of sporadic cases as normal in the process of gradual reduction of inoculation percentage on way to eradicating the disease.

Under guidelines set by the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE), Taiwan is entitled to apply for status as an FMD-free country with the body before its 2010 annual meeting slated for May of that year if no more cases are reported and no vaccinations are given to livestock for one year before applying for FMD- free status, according to the COA.
Once a country reports an FMD outbreak, it can take up to 40 years before it can eventually be listed as FMD-free, as has been the case in some European countries, COA officials noted.

The percentage of pigs in Taiwan to have received FMD vaccination has dropped from 50 percent last November to less than 10 percent on average at each farm, moving toward a zero injection rate so as to meet OIE requirements, COA officials went on.
After the first FMD case was reported in Taiwan March 20, 1997, Taiwan has been trying to stamp out the disease as quickly as possible, they added.
Since then, all pig farms and slaughterhouses around the country have continuously conducted disinfection work to keep the virus at bay.

Taiwan used to raise as many as 12 million pigs per year in the peak years, with 7 million exported to Japan annually, according to the COA officials. Taiwan now raises only about 6.4 million pigs a year, mainly for local consumption, the officials noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Defense minister denies son-in-law involved in arms sales

TEXT.P: Minister of National Defense Chen Chao-min denied on Wednesday a news report that implied that his son-in-law, Mo Hsu-teng, is involved in arms sales.

In a statement issued by the spokesman for the Ministry of National Defense (MND), Chen said the insinuations in the report carried in the latest issue of the weekly Next Magazine are "contrary to the facts."
Chen said the report has regrettably caused serious damage to his and his family members' reputations and that he reserves the right to take legal action against the magazine for defamation.

Chen's son-in-law also issued a written statement saying that he has absolutely not been involved in any arms sales related to the MND, nor has he used his relationship to the defense minister to seek any favors from the ministry.
Mo demanded that Next Magazine carry his statement in full, or he would consider seeking legal redress.

DOC.HEADLINE: Formosan black bear cub donated to Taipei Zoo

TEXT.P: A Formosan black bear cub was donated to the Taipei Zoo in a ceremony held Wednesday in southern Taiwan's Pingtung County.

Lee Teng-cheng, owner of the bear cub and a resident of the county's Changchi township, said donating the four-and-a-half-month old male cub felt like "giving away his daughter," so much so that he even prepared some of the cub's favorite fruit as a "dowry."

Jason Yeh, director of the Taipei Zoo, presided over the donation ceremony, with Hwang Mei-hsiu, an assistant professor at National Pingtung University of Science & Technology who has long dedicated herself to research on the bears, serving as "matchmaker."
As a gesture of appreciation for Lee's generosity, Yeh also announced that elementary school children from Changchi township will now be given free admission to the zoo.

Lee bought a pair of bears and various other wild animals more than 20 years ago in local shops because he did not have the heart to see them being killed for restaurant guests. He was later forced to get rid of most of them, especially after the enactment of the Wildlife Conservation Act in 1989, which prohibits private individuals from keeping or breeding protected species.
However, he could not bring himself to part with the bears, one of which gave birth to her seventh cub late last year.

Lee, who fought with the government to be allowed to keep the two previous surviving cubs, reached an agreement with Taipei Zoo two years ago that he would give away the latest cub because the zoo's own Formosan black bear could no longer breed.

Lee noted Wednesday that since the Formosan black bear is an endangered species, and "not my personal asset, " he was willing to give it away, although he has said previously that if the bears kept by government agencies or the academic sector are barren, competent people in the private sector should be allowed to breed the animals.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese tourist arrivals break 3,000 daily ceiling

TEXT.P: The number of arriving Chinese visitors broke the 3,000 mark for the first time Wednesday to reach 3,043, according to statistics released that day by the Tourism Bureau.

The tourists, among a total of 105 tour groups from major Chinese cities and provinces, arrived in Taiwan throughout the day, either via direct charter flights across the Taiwan Strait or through Hong Kong or Macau, Tourism Bureau officials said.

According to an agreement signed by the two sides of the Taiwan Strait last June, Taiwan allows entry of a maximum of 3,000 Chinese tourists per day, although due to the global economic downturn, the daily figure had never before hit the daily limit.
Tourism officials said the unrealized quotas from previous months can be used to accommodate the influx of Chinese tourists.
With cross-strait relations improving steadily, more Chinese tourists are expected to visit Taiwan in the future, the officials went on.

As Thailand has been plagued by anti-government protests in recent weeks, the officials said, many tourists have dropped their Thailand travel plans and have instead included Taiwan on their vacation itineraries.

Meanwhile, many Hong Kong citizens also took advantage of their Easter holidays to visit Taiwan, leading to a full load factor on nearly all Hong Kong-Taiwan flights and prompting carriers operating the route to offer additional flights in recent days to meet the surge in demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma hopes to see renewable energy legislation passed this year

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou urged the Executive Yuan Wednesday to integrate the seven different versions of a draft bill on renewable energy development and push for its passage in the current session of the legislature.
Ma made the call at the opening of the third national conference on energy policy, which is being held over two days at the Taipei International Convention Center.
Ma also stated that it is Taiwan's duty as part of the international community to save energy and cut carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions in an effort to help achieve sustainable global development.

He noted that the government has set a goal of reducing energy intensity -- calculated as units of energy consumption per unit of gross domestic product -- by 20 percent in 2015 from the 2005 level, and further by 50 percent in 2025.

The government will also push to cut carbon emissions in the period 2016-2020 to the 2008 level, is aiming for a reduction in 2025 to the 2000 level, and has set a goal of halving the volume in 2050 from the 2025 level, the president said.

He said that while these are ambitious goals, no action will be taken in Taiwan if the government does not set such targets. He also pointed out that an environmental protection component has been included in every project in his government's four-year NT$500 billion national economic stimulus package.

Also at the opening of the energy conference, Premier Liu Chao-shuan said the government is faced with the challenge of devising a comprehensive strategy for the research and development of green energy technologies and to put Taiwan in play in the expanding global market for green energy products.
Liu urged the participants at the conference to set aside their preconceived ideas and positions and assist the government in drafting a blueprint for the development of sustainable energy.
All governments around the world are facing the major task of finding a balance among developing energy, growing the economy and protecting the environment, he said.

Representatives of the industrial, governmental and academic sectors taking part in the energy conference were expected to discuss issues related to sustainable development and energy safety; energy management and efficiency improvement; energy prices and market opening; and energy technology and industrial development.

The conference was overshadowed by a German wind power company's threat to pull its investments out of Taiwan in an attempt to push the government to come up with concrete action in support of its policy to develop renewable energy.
The conference also drew demonstrations by anti-nuclear activists who gathered outside the venue to protest against the ongoing construction of the fourth nuclear power plant.

The national energy conference, launched in 1998, was slated to be held every three years, but since then there had been only one other meeting -- in 2005 -- as it has been plagued by nuclear energy disputes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Okinawa officials visit Hualien

TEXT.P: Three city and township chiefs from Japan's Okinawa Prefecture arrived Wednesday in eastern Taiwan's Hualien City for a two-day visit to promote bilateral exchanges.

The three Japanese officials from Ishigaki City, Yonaguni township and Taketomi township signed a pledge with Hualien City Mayor Tsai Chi-ta to jointly push for making one-day trips between the two sides possible, Hualien City officials said.

Due to the geographic proximity between the Hualien area and the Japanese localities, the two sides are planning to work out tour packages that could bring tourists and business people to the two countries and back within one day, the officials said.

Such an arrangement should be very appealing to both Taiwanese and Japanese people as well as travelers from other countries, they added, forecasting that more than 1 million foreign tourists would be attracted to eastern Taiwan's regions each year on the planned "one-day two-countries" tour packages.

Ishigaki City on Ishigaki Island is the southernmost Japanese city and the two townships all belong to Okinawa's Yaeyama Islands, which are only about 120 kilometers away from Taiwan's Hualien County.

These Japanese islands far from Tokyo have long maintained close economic and cultural links with Taiwan, and the two sides are expected to gradually form a regional trade bloc as a result of ever increasing two-way exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma invited to address U.S. seminar via teleconference
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 14 (CNA) 04/15/09 22:57:32 (By Jorge Liu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou has been invited to give a keynote speech by video conference from Taiwan at a seminar to be held in Washington, D.C. April 22 on the role of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) in Taipei-Beijing-Washington ties 30 years after its enactment.
Ma will be introduced by Richard Armitage, a former U.S. deputy secretary of state, according to the host, the Washington-based Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), Tuesday.

Noted China affairs experts such as Bonnie Glaser, Douglas Paal, Alan Romberg, Randy Schriver and Kerry Dumbaugh will take part in discussion panels at the seminar, which is titled "U.S. -Taiwan Relations in a New Era: Looking Forward 30 Years After the Taiwan Relations Act."
Since Washington switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1979, the TRA has served as a policy framework to define and guide Taiwan-U.S. relations.
Almost all major U.S. think tanks have sponsored seminars to mark the 30th anniversary of the U.S. law, particularly at a time of warming relations between Taiwan and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kenting corals spawning: diver

TEXT.P: Corals in the waters off the Kenting National Park in southern Taiwan are spawning, according to a diver and coral reef ecology observer who said he saw clumps of pink coral eggs drifting off Taiwan's southwestern coast.
Tsai Yung-chun, who made the discovery Monday, said he anticipated that the spawning will peak on April 18.

On his most recent dive, Tsai said, he also observed an increase in the population of cleaner shrimps in the protected marine area, which is a sign that the efforts to restore the marine ecology in Kenting are bearing fruit.

DOC.HEADLINE: Moderate recovery noted in container volume at Kaohsiung port

TEXT.P: The container handling volume at the port of Kaohsiung made some recovery in March, signifying that the global economy was slowly warming up, the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau indicated Wednesday.
Officials at the bureau quoted statistics as showing that Kaohsiung port handled 718,800 20-foot equivalent units (TEUs) in March, up from 551,000 TEUs in February and 619,100 TEUs in January.
They noted that the March figure, however, was still lower than the monthly average of 800,000 TEUs in recent years.
In the January-March period, Kaohsiung handled a total of 1.89 million TEUs, lower than the 2.46 million TEUs recorded in the same period of last year.

Kaohsiung's container-handling volume saw an year-on-year decline for the fifth consecutive month in February, mainly because of the severe global economic downturn and partly because of the Lunar New Year holiday.
The officials attributed the moderate increase in March to growing exports -- an apparent indicator that the world economy was recovering slowly.

In the past years, Kaohsiung port handled nearly 10 million TEUs per year, or an average of 800,000 TEUs per month, but the volume began to decline precipitously in the fourth quarter of 2008, with a year-on-year decrease of more than 10 percent recorded in October, more than 24 percent in November and December, and 28 percent in January.
The volume dropped to a seven-year low of 551,000 TEUs in February, before inching up again in March.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's health insurance system highlighted at world meeting
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 14 (CNA) 04/15/09 23:29:21 (By Jorge Liu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A senior official from Taiwan gave a presentation at the annual conference of the World Health Care Congress (WHCC) Tuesday on the country's well-developed health insurance system.

Chen Hsiao-ping, vice president of the Bureau of National Health Insurance under the Cabinet-level Department of Health, explained in detail the historical background of the national health insurance system, its special features, factors contributing to its success and the challenges it faces.
His address drew much attention as it came at a time when President Barack Obama's administration is actively promoting reform of the United States' health care system.
Chen used diagrams, graphs and solid figures to give an extensive and vivid analysis and to make comparisons between the health insurance systems in Taiwan and the U.S.

His presentation impressed many foreign public health officials and medical professionals at the WHCC conference, which is also being attended by health care industry representatives from across the United States and around the world with a view to exchanging opinions and experiences in medical service development.

A number of participants asked Chen questions during the Q&A session following his speech and expressed admiration over the wide coverage, efficiency and relatively low premiums that are the hallmarks of Taiwan's national health insurance system. Many of them also said it is worthy of emulation by the United States.

Muhammad Yunus, the 2006 Nobel Peace Prize winner who founded Grameen Bank to help poor people in Bangladesh build their own businesses, also spoke at the session, recounting his experience in developing social enterprises in Bangladesh that offer health insurance services for impoverished people.
The sixth WHCC conference opened Tuesday and will run until Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: More people in Taiwan seeking protection from domestic violence

TEXT.P: The 113 special phone line for the protection of women and children handled more than 284,600 phone calls last year, a considerably higher number than in 2007, the Ministry of the Interior said Wednesday.

Citing official statistics, officials at the ministry said that the special phone service to protect women and children from domestic violence and sexual assault received 284,641 phone calls in 2008, including 15,953 reporting domestic violence cases, a 56.2 percent increase over 2007.
There were also 187,950 phone calls last year from people seeking counseling on domestic violence and sexual assaults, representing an increase of 11.4 percent from 2007, the officials said.
The special phone line, set up by the ministry in January 2001, is managed by the Domestic Violence and Sexual Assault Prevention Committee under the Ministry of the Interior.

The phone line, manned around the clock by specially trained staff, provides service to callers seeking protection from domestic violence and sexual assaults and refers the cases to law enforcement agencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait trade pact could aid FTA talks with U.S.: rep

TEXT.P: If Taiwan signs an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, this would definitely contribute to future negotiations with the United States on a bilateral free trade agreement (FTA) , Taiwan's representative to Washington, D.C. said Wednesday.
Jason C. Yuan, who is currently on a home consultation tour in Taipei, made the remarks at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and National Defense Committee.

Fielding questions from legislators after reporting on the latest developments in Taiwan-U.S. relations and U.S. policy toward Taiwan under U.S. President Barack Obama, Yuan said the direction of the new U.S. administration's trade policy remains to be seen.
Amid the current global economic downturn, Yuan said, calls for protectionism are rife in the United States and its Congress is not keen on FTA talks with other countries at the moment.
Against this backdrop, American politicians friendly toward Taiwan have suggested that Taiwan foster a peaceful and harmonious atmosphere.
For instance, he said, if Taiwan can sign an ECFA with China, it would be very helpful in future FTA talks with the U.S.

As the Obama administration has publicly voiced support for the resumption of visits to Taiwan by U.S. Cabinet-level officials, the Taiwan representative office has stepped up efforts to invite senior U.S. officials to visit Taiwan in the future, Yuan said.

Yuan further said his office has also listed "signing of an extradition accord with the U.S. and pushing the Obama administration to grant visa-free treatment for prospective Taiwan tourists" as priority tasks on its work agenda.

On Taiwan's bid for joining the World Health Assembly (WHA) as an observer, Yuan said the U. S. adminsitration presented a report to Congress last week, in which it holds a positive stance on Taiwan's bid and clearly states that it would not like to see China interfer with the issue.
WHA is the decision-making arm of the U.N.-affiliated World Health Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'One-handed knife king' finds solace, success in the kitchen

TEXT.P: Kuo Hsing-chung owns two popular Thai food restaurants in Taipei that serve dishes meticulously prepared by him and a team of cooks. At first glance, the restaurants are just two more good choices for Thai food in Taiwan's capital city, led by an accomplished chef.

It's only when clients enter Kuo's restaurant on Taipei's Guangfu South Road and run into the owner that they notice he is missing his left hand -- a condition that has existed since birth -- and they invariably wonder how he manages to stir-fry his dishes.

Kuo is just one of many individuals in Taiwan who has had to overcome a physical disability, but his acquired profession is one that does not lend itself easily to working with only one hand, as he has discovered during his 16-year career.

Some of the simplest kitchen tasks, such as cutting vegetables or stir-frying dishes in a wok, nearly drove Kuo away from the profession more than once, but he persevered through the challenges and now the chef known in the trade as the "one-handed knife king" treats his missing hand as nothing more than an inconvenience.
"I have only one hand, but I can do what a normal person cannot do with two hands, " the 32-year-old chef says proudly and confidently.
Originally from the Thai-Burmese border town of Mae Salong, Kuo faltered and cried numerous times in his pursuit of success after coming to Taiwan with his family at the age of 12.
"Fortunately, I didn't give up on myself in the early years of my apprenticeship. I have accomplished what others may have thought I could never achieve," he reflects.
In retrospect, Kuo says he isolated himself from other people when he first came to Taipei.

"Back then, I felt at loss about the future. From a primitive Thai-Burmese border town to a city like Taipei, I was afraid of strangers' gazes or glares. Walking in public, I instinctively hid my deformed left hand and did not like to expose it in front of others. They would talk about behind my back," he recalls.
A turning point came when he turned 16. His uncle had opened a Thai restaurant and recruited him as an apprentice.

"I was assigned to work in the kitchen. At first, I thought it was good as I didn't need to face customers. But my deformity, coupled with my inability to interact with others, discouraged cooks from teaching me anything," he remembers vividly.

"They even told my uncle that I was unlikely to become a cook or chef. I was enraged by their contempt but reacted with resignation. Since they didn't want to teach me, I didn't want to learn, " Kuo adds.
After working in the kitchen for half a year, Kuo still could not hold a knife properly, and he was ready to give up.

But thanks to the repeated encouragement of his father and uncle, and the shock of seeing others get promoted ahead of him, Kuo finally saw the light. "I couldn't throw in the towel so easily. I was determined to learn by myself if nobody would teach me. "

He began to observe how cooks cut different foods. During breaks, he would practice cutting discarded carrots and cabbages, using his left elbow to keep foods in place as he was cutting them. It was not an easy maneuver for him, and he cut himself often.

After several months of "groping in the dark, " he gradually acquired top cutting skills, slicing cabbage, for instance, in consistent sizes. Fellow cooks began calling him the "one-handed knife king."
Then came the equally difficult challenge of stir-frying or sauteing foods.
"Woks tend to be heavy. Every step -- stirring, seasoning or flavoring, and heating -- should be perfectly timed for a stir-fried dish to be delicious," Kuo relates.
He remembers that he threw away the first sauteed dish he prepared after four months of practice because other workers at his uncle's restaurant yelled that the dish had a "burnt smell."
His lack of progress left him downcast and in despair. Worse still, because he could only use one hand to stir-fry foods, he suffered severe back ligament injuries.
"The debilitating pain frequently made me cry in the middle of the night. At one point, I thought of giving up, " Kuo remembers.
"But realizing that I didn't have too many other choices kept me from yielding. Even though I had to endure more hardships and adversity, I couldn't afford to give up," Kuo recounts.
After three years of diligent and arduous study, Kuo finally emerged as a skilled chef of Thai cuisine who can cut and saute a wide variety of fine Thai dishes.
In all, it took him eight years to climb to the post of chief chef at his uncle's restaurant at the age of 24.
To perfect his culinary art and skill, Kuo has traveled to Thailand many times to study with noted Thai chefs, he said he was lucky to have such an opportunity.

"They repeatedly encouraged me to take part in culinary contests and they often reminded me that I should never lose self-confidence because I can do with one hand what others have to do with two hands," Kuo recalls.
"Their words sounded like a wake-up call, kindling my self-confidence and letting me understand that I'm not frail, " he says.
With firm determination and plenty of confidence, Kuo decided to set up his own restaurant at the age of 28.
"Over the years, my disability has become my strength. Having recognized this, I'm confident I can cope with many of my life's challenges ahead."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, increasing NT$0.170 to close at NT$33.790.
A total of US$1.02 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.700 and fluctuated between NT$33.580 and NT$33.790.

DOC.HEADLINE: Teenagers found vulnerable to rape by online acquaintances

TEXT.P: More than 60 percent of sexual assault cases that result from online encounters involve victims between the ages of 12 and 17 in Taipei City, which highlights the vulnerability of teenagers to this type of violence, the city's Department of Social Welfare said Wednesday.

Statistics from the Taipei City Center for Protection of Domestic Violence and Sexual Assault show that in 2007, there were 82 reported cases of rape that took place during real meetings between persons that had first made contact online, accounting for 11.1 percent of all rape cases reported in the city during the year.
The number of such cases increased slightly to 86 in 2008, accounting for 10.8 percent of all sexual assault cases.
There were 17 such cases during the first three months of 2009, accounting for 10.9 percent of all rape cases reported during that period.
In these cases, the largest group of victims -- more than 60 percent -- were in the 12-17 age group, the statistics show.

Chiang Hsing-hui, director of the center, said that social workers have found that many teenage rape victims had been experiencing great pressure and had suffered setbacks and expected to gain acceptance from friends on the Internet.
The desire to meet someone of the opposite sex also exposes teenagers to dangerous situations, Chiang said.

She advised parents to spend more time with their children and pay closer attention to their Internet use to help prevent them from making any potentially dangerous in-person contact with people they encounter casually online.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China agree to cooperate in telematics industry development

TEXT.P: China and Taiwan have recently agreed to establish the first cross-Taiwan Strait platform for cooperation and mutual exchanges in the telematics industry.

Ke Jyh-sheng, president of Taiwan's quasi-official Institute for Information Industry (III), signed a letter of intent Monday with Lu Ning, president of China's Changchun Optoelectronics Information Industry Association, and Cheng Fu-hsiung, vice chairman of the Taipei-based Taiwan Electrical Electronic Manufacturers' Association as a precursor to the cross-strait cooperation.

The cooperation agreement, once established, will allow Taiwan to assist Changchun City, in northeastern China's Jilin Province, in developing a wireless broadband network while opening the doors for cross-strait cooperation in the automobile electronics and telematics application sectors.

The signing of the letter of intent marked an achievement of a cross-strait conference on telematics cooperation and exchanges that was held April 13-14 at the Taipei World Trade Center Nangang Exhibition Hall.

In addition, Taiwan's E-Lead Electronic Corp. signed an agreement with the College of Automotive Engineering of Jilin University Monday at the closing of the Taipei conference, beginning the first concrete cooperation effort of the two sides in the telematics industry.
E-Lead Vice Chairman Chen Hsi-yiao said that under the new cooperative ties, his company will work with Jilin University in the development and manufacture of automotive electronic products.
In the preliminary stage, Chen went on, the two sides will focus on efforts to come up with an improved tire pressure monitoring system.

At the signing ceremony, III Vice President Wang Wei expressed anticipation that the pact will attract more Taiwanese automotive electronics producers to seek R&D collaboration with Jilin University, as well as with the First Automobile Works (FAW) Group Corp., one of China's three largest auto manufacturers.

The just-ended cross-strait conference on telematics cooperation and exchanges was the third in a series of activities prepared by the Ministry of Economic Affairs as part of a "bridging" program it initiated to boost cross-strait industrial and business cooperation and exchanges.
The program has already succeeded in pushing through cross-strait exchanges in the fields of traditional herbal medicine and solar energy.

The telematics event drew more than 80 Chinese professionals in the field from Beijing, Shanghai, Changchun, Fujien and Xiamen, including Dong Yang, executive vice president of the China Association of Automobile Manufacturers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to spend NT$60 million to improve gas water heater safety

TEXT.P: The government will spend up to NT$60 million (US$1.78 million) to help households around Taiwan to improve the safety of their gas water heaters and reduce the risk of carbon monoxide poisoning, Minister of the Interior Liao Liao-yi said Wednesday.

Liao told a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Social Welfare and Environmental Hygiene Committee that a recent survey shows that about 34,000 households in Taiwan are prone to carbon monoxide poisoning because their gas water heaters have been installed at locations where ventilation is poor.
The survey, conducted by the National Fire Agency under the Ministry of the Interior in March, collected information from the families of 960,000 junior middle school students.
The results showed that of the 34,000 households with a high risk of carbon monoxide poisoning, 20,000 said they would improve the situations themselves.

Liao said his ministry will grant a subsidy of NT$3,000 to each of the remaining 14,000 households to reduce gas poisoning risk by relocating their gas water heaters to safer locations or by improving the ventilation in their homes.
He acknowledged that he is not sure where the money will come from, but said he will try to coordinate with the Ministry of Economic Affairs to come up with funds for the plan.

According to the National Fire Agency, most carbon monoxide poisoning accidents caused by bathroom gas water heaters occur during the period from December to March when people normally do not open windows in the cold season.
Statistics compiled by the agency showed that the number of carbon monoxide poisoning accidents in Taiwan have steadily risen in recent years after falling in 2006.

There were 176 such cases nationwide in 2005, resulting in 31 deaths and 358 people injured; 38 cases in 2006, causing 20 deaths and 86 people injured; 41 cases in 2007, leading to 15 deaths and 90 people injured; and 68 cases in 2008, killing 13 people and injuring 155 others.
The statistics also showed that in January of this year alone, there were 16 carbon monoxide poisoning cases, causing 10 people to lose their lives and 40 others to suffer injuries.

DOC.HEADLINE: 18 pigs culled in Changhua County FMD scare: official

TEXT.P: Eighteen pigs on a farm in the central county of Changhua were culled late Monday after they were found to have developed symptoms of the highly contagious foot-and-mouth disease (FMD), a county official confirmed Wednesday.

Kuo Chou-tseh, head of the county's Bureau of Animal Health Inspection and Quarantine, said the 18 pigs were killed on the farm immediately after a veterinarian at the Changhua meat market discovered April 13 that 10 out of 50 pigs sent to the meat market by the farm appeared to have FMD symptoms.
A total of 947 pigs were being raised on the farm, Kuo added.

According to Kuo, seven other pig farms within a 1-km radius of the farm were disinfected later Monday in an effort to prevent the spread of the virus, and vaccinations were also given to about 5,000 pigs being raised in the neighborhood.

According to officials of the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA), there are about 12,000 hog farms in Taiwan, with 90 percent of their stock having received no FMD inoculation.

Monday's report was the fourth of its kind since February, following the first case reported in Yunlin County Feb. 4, a second reported in Changhua County Feb. 9 and a third in Chiayi County March 27, COA officials reported.

They urged the public not to panic over the development, describing the appearance of sporadic cases as normal in the process of gradual reduction of inoculation percentage on way to eradicating the disease.

Under guidelines set by the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE), Taiwan is entitled to apply for status as an FMD-free country with the body before its 2010 annual meeting slated for May of that year if no more cases are reported and no vaccinations are given to livestock for one year before applying for FMD- free status, according to the COA.
Once a country reports an FMD outbreak, it can take up to 40 years before it can eventually be listed as FMD-free, as has been the case in some European countries, COA officials noted.

The percentage of pigs in Taiwan to have received FMD vaccination has dropped from 50 percent last November to less than 10 percent on average at each farm, moving toward a zero injection rate so as to meet OIE requirements, COA officials went on.
After the first FMD case was reported in Taiwan March 20, 1997, Taiwan has been trying to stamp out the disease as quickly as possible, they added.
Since then, all pig farms and slaughterhouses around the country have continuously conducted disinfection work to keep the virus at bay.

Taiwan used to raise as many as 12 million pigs per year in the peak years, with 7 million exported to Japan annually, according to the COA officials. Taiwan now raises only about 6.4 million pigs a year, mainly for local consumption, the officials noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Defense minister denies son-in-law involved in arms sales

TEXT.P: Minister of National Defense Chen Chao-min denied on Wednesday a news report that implied that his son-in-law, Mo Hsu-teng, is involved in arms sales.

In a statement issued by the spokesman for the Ministry of National Defense (MND), Chen said the insinuations in the report carried in the latest issue of the weekly Next Magazine are "contrary to the facts."
Chen said the report has regrettably caused serious damage to his and his family members' reputations and that he reserves the right to take legal action against the magazine for defamation.

Chen's son-in-law also issued a written statement saying that he has absolutely not been involved in any arms sales related to the MND, nor has he used his relationship to the defense minister to seek any favors from the ministry.
Mo demanded that Next Magazine carry his statement in full, or he would consider seeking legal redress.

DOC.HEADLINE: Formosan black bear cub donated to Taipei Zoo

TEXT.P: A Formosan black bear cub was donated to the Taipei Zoo in a ceremony held Wednesday in southern Taiwan's Pingtung County.

Lee Teng-cheng, owner of the bear cub and a resident of the county's Changchi township, said donating the four-and-a-half-month old male cub felt like "giving away his daughter," so much so that he even prepared some of the cub's favorite fruit as a "dowry."

Jason Yeh, director of the Taipei Zoo, presided over the donation ceremony, with Hwang Mei-hsiu, an assistant professor at National Pingtung University of Science & Technology who has long dedicated herself to research on the bears, serving as "matchmaker."
As a gesture of appreciation for Lee's generosity, Yeh also announced that elementary school children from Changchi township will now be given free admission to the zoo.

Lee bought a pair of bears and various other wild animals more than 20 years ago in local shops because he did not have the heart to see them being killed for restaurant guests. He was later forced to get rid of most of them, especially after the enactment of the Wildlife Conservation Act in 1989, which prohibits private individuals from keeping or breeding protected species.
However, he could not bring himself to part with the bears, one of which gave birth to her seventh cub late last year.

Lee, who fought with the government to be allowed to keep the two previous surviving cubs, reached an agreement with Taipei Zoo two years ago that he would give away the latest cub because the zoo's own Formosan black bear could no longer breed.

Lee noted Wednesday that since the Formosan black bear is an endangered species, and "not my personal asset, " he was willing to give it away, although he has said previously that if the bears kept by government agencies or the academic sector are barren, competent people in the private sector should be allowed to breed the animals.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese tourist arrivals break 3,000 daily ceiling

TEXT.P: The number of arriving Chinese visitors broke the 3,000 mark for the first time Wednesday to reach 3,043, according to statistics released that day by the Tourism Bureau.

The tourists, among a total of 105 tour groups from major Chinese cities and provinces, arrived in Taiwan throughout the day, either via direct charter flights across the Taiwan Strait or through Hong Kong or Macau, Tourism Bureau officials said.

According to an agreement signed by the two sides of the Taiwan Strait last June, Taiwan allows entry of a maximum of 3,000 Chinese tourists per day, although due to the global economic downturn, the daily figure had never before hit the daily limit.
Tourism officials said the unrealized quotas from previous months can be used to accommodate the influx of Chinese tourists.
With cross-strait relations improving steadily, more Chinese tourists are expected to visit Taiwan in the future, the officials went on.

As Thailand has been plagued by anti-government protests in recent weeks, the officials said, many tourists have dropped their Thailand travel plans and have instead included Taiwan on their vacation itineraries.

Meanwhile, many Hong Kong citizens also took advantage of their Easter holidays to visit Taiwan, leading to a full load factor on nearly all Hong Kong-Taiwan flights and prompting carriers operating the route to offer additional flights in recent days to meet the surge in demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma hopes to see renewable energy legislation passed this year

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou urged the Executive Yuan Wednesday to integrate the seven different versions of a draft bill on renewable energy development and push for its passage in the current session of the legislature.
Ma made the call at the opening of the third national conference on energy policy, which is being held over two days at the Taipei International Convention Center.
Ma also stated that it is Taiwan's duty as part of the international community to save energy and cut carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions in an effort to help achieve sustainable global development.

He noted that the government has set a goal of reducing energy intensity -- calculated as units of energy consumption per unit of gross domestic product -- by 20 percent in 2015 from the 2005 level, and further by 50 percent in 2025.

The government will also push to cut carbon emissions in the period 2016-2020 to the 2008 level, is aiming for a reduction in 2025 to the 2000 level, and has set a goal of halving the volume in 2050 from the 2025 level, the president said.

He said that while these are ambitious goals, no action will be taken in Taiwan if the government does not set such targets. He also pointed out that an environmental protection component has been included in every project in his government's four-year NT$500 billion national economic stimulus package.

Also at the opening of the energy conference, Premier Liu Chao-shuan said the government is faced with the challenge of devising a comprehensive strategy for the research and development of green energy technologies and to put Taiwan in play in the expanding global market for green energy products.
Liu urged the participants at the conference to set aside their preconceived ideas and positions and assist the government in drafting a blueprint for the development of sustainable energy.
All governments around the world are facing the major task of finding a balance among developing energy, growing the economy and protecting the environment, he said.

Representatives of the industrial, governmental and academic sectors taking part in the energy conference were expected to discuss issues related to sustainable development and energy safety; energy management and efficiency improvement; energy prices and market opening; and energy technology and industrial development.

The conference was overshadowed by a German wind power company's threat to pull its investments out of Taiwan in an attempt to push the government to come up with concrete action in support of its policy to develop renewable energy.
The conference also drew demonstrations by anti-nuclear activists who gathered outside the venue to protest against the ongoing construction of the fourth nuclear power plant.

The national energy conference, launched in 1998, was slated to be held every three years, but since then there had been only one other meeting -- in 2005 -- as it has been plagued by nuclear energy disputes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Okinawa officials visit Hualien

TEXT.P: Three city and township chiefs from Japan's Okinawa Prefecture arrived Wednesday in eastern Taiwan's Hualien City for a two-day visit to promote bilateral exchanges.

The three Japanese officials from Ishigaki City, Yonaguni township and Taketomi township signed a pledge with Hualien City Mayor Tsai Chi-ta to jointly push for making one-day trips between the two sides possible, Hualien City officials said.

Due to the geographic proximity between the Hualien area and the Japanese localities, the two sides are planning to work out tour packages that could bring tourists and business people to the two countries and back within one day, the officials said.

Such an arrangement should be very appealing to both Taiwanese and Japanese people as well as travelers from other countries, they added, forecasting that more than 1 million foreign tourists would be attracted to eastern Taiwan's regions each year on the planned "one-day two-countries" tour packages.

Ishigaki City on Ishigaki Island is the southernmost Japanese city and the two townships all belong to Okinawa's Yaeyama Islands, which are only about 120 kilometers away from Taiwan's Hualien County.

These Japanese islands far from Tokyo have long maintained close economic and cultural links with Taiwan, and the two sides are expected to gradually form a regional trade bloc as a result of ever increasing two-way exchanges.

Chen Hsiao-ping, vice president of the Bureau of National Health Insurance under the Cabinet-level Department of Health, explained in detail the historical background of the national health insurance system, its special features, factors contributing to its success and the challenges it faces.
His address drew much attention as it came at a time when President Barack Obama's administration is actively promoting reform of the United States' health care system.
Chen used diagrams, graphs and solid figures to give an extensive and vivid analysis and to make comparisons between the health insurance systems in Taiwan and the U.S.

His presentation impressed many foreign public health officials and medical professionals at the WHCC conference, which is also being attended by health care industry representatives from across the United States and around the world with a view to exchanging opinions and experiences in medical service development.

A number of participants asked Chen questions during the Q&A session following his speech and expressed admiration over the wide coverage, efficiency and relatively low premiums that are the hallmarks of Taiwan's national health insurance system. Many of them also said it is worthy of emulation by the United States.

Muhammad Yunus, the 2006 Nobel Peace Prize winner who founded Grameen Bank to help poor people in Bangladesh build their own businesses, also spoke at the session, recounting his experience in developing social enterprises in Bangladesh that offer health insurance services for impoverished people.
The sixth WHCC conference opened Tuesday and will run until Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: More people in Taiwan seeking protection from domestic violence

TEXT.P: The 113 special phone line for the protection of women and children handled more than 284,600 phone calls last year, a considerably higher number than in 2007, the Ministry of the Interior said Wednesday.

Citing official statistics, officials at the ministry said that the special phone service to protect women and children from domestic violence and sexual assault received 284,641 phone calls in 2008, including 15,953 reporting domestic violence cases, a 56.2 percent increase over 2007.
There were also 187,950 phone calls last year from people seeking counseling on domestic violence and sexual assaults, representing an increase of 11.4 percent from 2007, the officials said.
The special phone line, set up by the ministry in January 2001, is managed by the Domestic Violence and Sexual Assault Prevention Committee under the Ministry of the Interior.

The phone line, manned around the clock by specially trained staff, provides service to callers seeking protection from domestic violence and sexual assaults and refers the cases to law enforcement agencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait trade pact could aid FTA talks with U.S.: rep

TEXT.P: If Taiwan signs an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, this would definitely contribute to future negotiations with the United States on a bilateral free trade agreement (FTA) , Taiwan's representative to Washington, D.C. said Wednesday.
Jason C. Yuan, who is currently on a home consultation tour in Taipei, made the remarks at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and National Defense Committee.

Fielding questions from legislators after reporting on the latest developments in Taiwan-U.S. relations and U.S. policy toward Taiwan under U.S. President Barack Obama, Yuan said the direction of the new U.S. administration's trade policy remains to be seen.
Amid the current global economic downturn, Yuan said, calls for protectionism are rife in the United States and its Congress is not keen on FTA talks with other countries at the moment.
Against this backdrop, American politicians friendly toward Taiwan have suggested that Taiwan foster a peaceful and harmonious atmosphere.
For instance, he said, if Taiwan can sign an ECFA with China, it would be very helpful in future FTA talks with the U.S.

As the Obama administration has publicly voiced support for the resumption of visits to Taiwan by U.S. Cabinet-level officials, the Taiwan representative office has stepped up efforts to invite senior U.S. officials to visit Taiwan in the future, Yuan said.

Yuan further said his office has also listed "signing of an extradition accord with the U.S. and pushing the Obama administration to grant visa-free treatment for prospective Taiwan tourists" as priority tasks on its work agenda.

On Taiwan's bid for joining the World Health Assembly (WHA) as an observer, Yuan said the U. S. adminsitration presented a report to Congress last week, in which it holds a positive stance on Taiwan's bid and clearly states that it would not like to see China interfer with the issue.
WHA is the decision-making arm of the U.N.-affiliated World Health Organization.

The weighted price index lost 17.49 points, or 0.29 percent, to close at 5,875.19 Wednesday.
