DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma invited to address U.S. seminar via teleconference
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 14 (CNA) 04/16/09 11:01:19 (By Jorge Liu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou has been invited to give a keynote speech by video conference from Taiwan at a seminar to be held in Washington, D.C. April 22 on the role of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) in Taipei-Beijing-Washington ties 30 years after its enactment.
Ma will be introduced by Richard Armitage, a former U.S. deputy secretary of state, according to the host, the Washington-based Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), Tuesday.

Noted China affairs experts such as Bonnie Glaser, Douglas Paal, Alan Romberg, Randy Schriver and Kerry Dumbaugh will take part in discussion panels at the seminar, which is titled "U.S. -Taiwan Relations in a New Era: Looking Forward 30 Years After the Taiwan Relations Act."
Since Washington switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1979, the TRA has served as a policy framework to define and guide Taiwan-U.S. relations.
Almost all major U.S. think tanks have sponsored seminars to mark the 30th anniversary of the U.S. law, particularly at a time of warming relations between Taiwan and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kenting corals spawning: diver

TEXT.P: Corals in the waters off the Kenting National Park in southern Taiwan are spawning, according to a diver and coral reef ecology observer who said he saw clumps of pink coral eggs drifting off Taiwan's southwestern coast.
Tsai Yung-chun, who made the discovery Monday, said he anticipated that the spawning will peak on April 18.

On his most recent dive, Tsai said, he also observed an increase in the population of cleaner shrimps in the protected marine area, which is a sign that the efforts to restore the marine ecology in Kenting are bearing fruit.

DOC.HEADLINE: Moderate recovery noted in container volume at Kaohsiung port

TEXT.P: The container handling volume at the port of Kaohsiung made some recovery in March, signifying that the global economy was slowly warming up, the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau indicated Wednesday.
Officials at the bureau quoted statistics as showing that Kaohsiung port handled 718,800 20-foot equivalent units (TEUs) in March, up from 551,000 TEUs in February and 619,100 TEUs in January.
They noted that the March figure, however, was still lower than the monthly average of 800,000 TEUs in recent years.
In the January-March period, Kaohsiung handled a total of 1.89 million TEUs, lower than the 2.46 million TEUs recorded in the same period of last year.

Kaohsiung's container-handling volume saw an year-on-year decline for the fifth consecutive month in February, mainly because of the severe global economic downturn and partly because of the Lunar New Year holiday.
The officials attributed the moderate increase in March to growing exports -- an apparent indicator that the world economy was recovering slowly.

In the past years, Kaohsiung port handled nearly 10 million TEUs per year, or an average of 800,000 TEUs per month, but the volume began to decline precipitously in the fourth quarter of 2008, with a year-on-year decrease of more than 10 percent recorded in October, more than 24 percent in November and December, and 28 percent in January.
The volume dropped to a seven-year low of 551,000 TEUs in February, before inching up again in March.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 16, or the 21st day of the third month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1828: Francisco Jose de Goya, Spanish artist whose paintings and etchings reflected the political and social turmoil of his time, dies at the age of 82.
1850: Madame Marie Tussaud, Swiss founder of the famous waxworks museum in London, dies at the age of 89.
1889: Sir Charles Spencer Chaplin, known as "Charlie," film actor and comedian much loved for his portrayal of a tramp in baggy pants and bowler hat, is born in Britain. His productions include "The Kid," "The Gold Rush," and "The Great Dictator."
1912: American pilot Harriet Quimby becomes the first woman to fly the English Channel.
1917: Vladimir Ilyich Lenin returns to Russia after three years of exile in Zurich.
1923: Japanese Crown Prince Hirohito arrives in Keelung for an inspection tour of Taiwan, which is under Japanese rule.
1925: In honor of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, who died in Peking on March 12, 1925 at the age of 59, the Kwangtung Provincial Government changes the name of Hsiangshan County, the place of birth of Dr. Sun, to Chungshan County.
1941: German troops enter Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, and the main synagogue is destroyed.
1948: The Organization for European Economic Co-operation (OEEC) is established in Paris by Western European nations in accordance with the Marshall Plan.
1960: The Taiwan Provincial Government begins the implementation of labor insurance regulations by establishing the Labor Insurance Bureau.
1972: Yasunari Kawabata, Japanese writer who won the 1968 Nobel Prize for literature, commits suicide at the age of 73. His novels, including "Thousand Cranes," often concern alienated, lonely individuals in search of beauty and purity.
1972: The Apollo 16 mission is launched from Cape Kennedy, Florida, to make the fifth manned moon landing.
1975: The communist Khmer Rouge seize Phnom Penh, capital of Cambodia.
1978: A tornado strikes the eastern state of Orissa in India, killing some 180 people.
1981: The Kaohsiung C.K.S. Cultural Center is inaugurated.
1982: Queen Elizabeth proclaims Canada's new constitution, severing the colonial links with Britain.
1985: The first test tube baby in the Republic of China is born at the Veterans General Hospital in Taipei.
1990: In London, Freed African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela publicly thanks the world for its support during his 26-year imprisonment by the South African government.
1998: Khmer Rouge leader Pol Pot is reported dead of a heart attack in his Cambodian jungle stronghold at the age of 73. During his four-year reign of terror some two million Cambodians died.
1999: Former opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang is blasted by other DPP members for his recent remarks on plebiscites and Taiwan independence.
1999: A field hospital donated by Taiwan opens at the Stenkovee refugee camp outside Skopje, Macedonia.
2000: Republic of China President-elect Chen Shui-bian says that "maintaining peace and stability and safeguarding the interests of Taiwan are the highest goals and moral obligations" for him as president.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Men in old times educated themselves for their own sakes. Men now educate themselves to impress others."

DOC.HEADLINE: Stray dogs rushed from Taichung to Kaohsiung for emergency treatment

TEXT.P: Members of the Animal Rescue Team Taiwan managed to catch six seriously ill stray dogs in the central city of Taichung and transport them to the organization's base in Kaohsiung City Wednesday for emergency treatment after a marathon chase of more than 18 hours.

The operation, which involved transporting the dogs over a long distance of 200 kilometers, was launched after the non-profit organization was informed that a pack of stray dogs sheltered by a vagrant living in an abandoned property in Taichung were suffering from severe skin disease, had lost almost all their hair and were bleeding from many parts of their bodies.
In preparation for the rescue operation, volunteers were dispatched one week in advance to inspect the location, and wooden planks and cardboard were used to block off all possible exits.

The operation, however, did not go as smoothly as anticipated, although the area was cordoned off, a blowpipe was being used to sedate the animals, and local residents and volunteers from northern and central Taiwan joined the effort.
The team eventually captured the animals after almost a whole day of work and delivered them immediately to the Hung-Li Animal Hospital in Kaohsiung for treatment.

According to veterinarian Feng Tzung-hung, all six dogs were infected with demodiscosis, scabies and chronic dermatitis and infested with fleas and ticks -- conditions that were attributed to the state of their living environment.
Two of the dogs were suffering from canine ehrlichiosis and coagulation disorders, and another two had many festering wounds on their bodies, Feng said.
He said that the animals will require up to two months of treatment before they could recover fully.
The rescue team, meanwhile, promised that it will help find people to adopt the dogs when they recover.
Since its establishment in 1995, the Animal Rescue Team Taiwan has saved thousands of abused and injured stray dogs and helped find homes overseas for more than 100 of them.
The organization, run by a retired math teacher Joseph Nee and his dog-loving family, rescues strays mainly in southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
President plans to attend El Salvador presidential inauguration

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou confirmed Thursday that President Ma Ying- jeou is planning to attend the inauguration ceremony of El Salvadore President- elect Mauricio Funes in June.

Ou made the remarks while reporting to the Legislative Yuan about his visit to El Salvador March 31-April 7 to cement bilateral relations with the Central American country and express gratitude to the outgoing government for its long- term support of Taiwan.
Ou said that during his meetings with Funes and El Salvadore's outgoing President Antonio Saca he informed them both of Ma's intention to attend the inauguration ceremony on June 1.
"Funes said that it would be an honor to have President Ma at the ceremony and that Ma will be accorded great hospitality," Ou related.

The foreign ministry is currently planning Ma's state visit to El Salvador and his delegation is likely to include a cultural performing group -- an unprecedented arrangement that will demonstrate Taiwan's soft power, Ou said.
However, the Presidential Office has not yet given a final word on the plan and the details are still being finalized, he added.

In response to ruling Kuomintang Legislator John Chiang's question on whether New York will be the first choice for the president's transit stops, Ou said the stopover arrangements in the United States will be in low keyed but will adhere to the principles of "dignity, safety, comfort, convenience."

Regarding bilateral relations between Taiwan and El Salvador, Ou said the ties remain strong and that Funes' recent statements indicated that he had adopted a more "flexible and open" stance on Taiwan relations. Since the end of last year, Funes has been emphasizing his intention to develop economic and trade relations with Beijing, which has been a change from the suggestions in his election campaign that he would switch diplomatic recognition from Taiwan to China, Ou noted.

"Funes stressed that his government will give top priority to the welfare of El Salvadore's people, and that its diplomacy will be based on national interests instead of ideology, " Ou said, adding that Funes also said he hoped to strengthen cooperation with Taiwan at all levels.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA lowers travel alert for certain areas of Thailand

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) lowered its travel alert for certain areas of Thailand Thursday, lifting its advisory for travelers to postpone trips to those locations, but still advised caution.

"Because the anti-government demonstrators in Thailand have ended their three- week long protests, the foreign ministry has lowered its travel alert from orange to yellow," the MOFA said in a press release.

A yellow alert is a reminder for travelers to exercise caution, while an orange travel alert advises travelers to postpone their trips, and a red alert warns travelers not to enter the area in question under any circumstances.
The foreign ministry on Tuesday issued an orange alert for Bangkok and its surrounding five districts -- Nonthaburi, Samut Prakan, Pathum Thani, Nakhon Pathom and Ayutthaya.

The warning also covered the northern and northeast parts of Thailand, including Chiangmai, Chiangrai, Phrae, Phitsanu Lok, Lam Pang, Lam Phun, and Nakhon Ratcha Sima, Nong Khai, Udon Thani and Ubon Ratcha Thani.
The MOFA said in the press release that it will keep updating its news and travel alerts on Thailand on the Web site of its Bureau of Consular Affairs at www.boca.gov.tw.

Travelers heading to Thailand are still advised to exercise caution, the foreign ministry said, adding that in case of emergency the Taiwan representative in Thailand can be contacted at 002-66-81-666-4006.

DOC.HEADLINE: Information and communication industry optimistic about Q2

TEXT.P: Taiwan's information and communication technology (ICT) companies have a more optimistic outlook on the economy for the second quarter of this year than they did in the previous quarter, but remain conservative about the outlook for the whole year, according to the results of an industry survey released Thursday.

In the survey, conducted by the Institute for Information Industry's Market Intelligence Center (MIC) among ICT manufacturers at the beginning of the second quarter, 42.3 percent of ICT respondents expressed confidence that the industry will resume growth gradually in the second quarter, compared with 6.3 percent who had said so in the first quarter.

The respondents said they were particularly optimistic about the outlook for the communication industry and the computer hardware and peripherals industry, with 80 percent of them saying they believe these sectors will maintain steady recovery or enjoy sharp growth in the second quarter, the survey showed.

MIC analyst Huang Yi-shuian attributed the overall optimistic sentiment to the effect of government policies that include bailing out failing enterprises, providing unemployment benefits and developing an economic stimulus package.

More than 25 percent of computer hardware and peripherals manufacturers who responded to the poll forecast that their business turnover will increase 41 percent to 50 percent year-on-year in the second quarter, while 44 percent of the manufacturers predicted a downturn or growth of less than 20 percent, the survey revealed.

In terms of Taiwan's economic prospects for the whole year, the survey indicated that 26.8 percent of respondents think the economy will rebound slowly this year, while 47.4 percent predicted it will contract slightly or even sharply. The figure translated into a decrease of 29.6 percent over the same period last year when 77 percent of the respondents in a similar poll said they expected the economy to contract.
Meanwhile, 18.6 percent of the respondents forecast that the global ICT industry will rebound gradually this year, while most of them predicted it will slump.
The most pessimistic sentiment was found among information software and services providers, with 70 percent of them predicting that the global ICT industry will remain weak.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan wants higher level of economic dialogue with Japan: Ma

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou urged Japan Thursday to upgrade the level of its economic meetings with Taiwan to further enhance bilateral relations.
Economic meetings between the two countries are currently being attended by officials at the bureau chief level, but should be upgraded to the ministerial or vice ministerial level, Ma said.
In the long term, he said, Taiwan hopes a free trade agreement or economic partnership agreement could be established between the two sides.
The president made the remarks while receiving representatives of the Japan Chamber of Commerce and Industry and the Fukuoka Chamber of Commerce and Industry.
Ma said that soon after his inauguration in May 2008, he repositioned Taiwan relations with Japan as a special partnership and this year has continued to work to strengthen bilateral ties.

Taiwan is expected to open an office in the Hakkaido capital of Sapporo later in the year and is preparing to set up a cultural center in Tokyo in a bid to promote cultural and tourism exchanges between the two sides, Ma said.

In addition, the Taiwan-Japan working holiday program scheduled to be launched June 1 will help to promote exchanges between young people of the two countries, and the charter flight services set to begin in October between Taipei's Sungshan airport and the Tokyo International Airport will be a milestone in aviation links between the two countries, Ma said.

He noted that Taiwan maintains very close trade relations with Japan, with the bilateral trade volume in 2008 amounting to US$64 billion. Japan was Taiwan's second-largest trading partner, and Taiwan was Japan's fifth-largest trading partner during the year, he added.
Also, the two countries concluded their 16th round of fishery talks in February, which further cemented the relations, Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Alishan cherry blossom festival ends

TEXT.P: The Alishan cherry blossom festival came to an end Wednesday after a month during which it attracted 304,485 visitors to view the wide range of flower species in the Alishan Forest Recreation Area in southern Taiwan's Chiayi County, officials said Thursday.

The single-day number of visitors peaked at 27,186 on March 22 during the festival, which ran from March 15-April 15, said officials of the Forestry Bureau under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture.

Although the festival has ended, a variety of flowers, including the Cerasus sieboldii cherry, Oshima cherry, Prunus lannesiana, camellias, azaleas and daisies, are still in full bloom in this late spring season, the officials said.

Alishan and Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei in the north of the country are two famous sites where visitors can witness the bursting forth of spring as the flowers bloom in splendor. However, Alishan is the only place in the country where such large plantations of Yoshino cherry trees, originally from Japan, can be found.
The oldest Yoshino cherry tree on Alishan was planted in 1903.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hong Kong gourmets to make food tour of Taiwan

TEXT.P: A group of 40 gourmets from Hong Kong is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan Friday for a special three-day, two-night food tour, during which they will try a variety of local flavors, the Tourism Bureau said.
The group, to be led by prominent Hong Kong chef Chow Chung, will make northern Taiwan the focus of their itinerary, bureau officials said.
During his stay in Taiwan, Chow, who formerly served at the Hyatt Regency Hong Kong hotel, will demonstrate Chinese cooking skills in a culinary workshop to be held at the Grand Hyatt Taipei hotel.
The Hong Kong visitors will get to taste authentic Taiwanese dishes during their tour, which costs HK$7,000 or NT$30,000 (US$890) per person.

Some of the dishes to be served to them will include seafood at the Bisha fishing port in Keelung, delicacies on Taipei City's Yongkang Street, as well as local snacks in Taipei's Ximending area and Keelung's Miaokou area, the officials said.
The gourmets will also go to Taipei's Binjiang market to purchase food and ingredients unique to Taiwan, and visit popular tourist spots, such as the Yangmingshan National Park and the Taipei Zoo.

DOC.HEADLINE: Elderly cyclists embark on 2,000-km journey

TEXT.P: Thirty elderly cyclists began a 2,000-km journey from Taiwan Thursday that will take them to Shanghai, Nanjing and Beijing.
The cyclists, with a combined age of more than 2,000, are all volunteers for Concern & Care Society, a Christian group that is dedicated to the care of the elderly.
Lee Chi-wei, leader of the group and executive director of the society, said before their departure from Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport that the ride was planned about a year and a half ago.
"All the members have undergone five sessions of physical training and physical examination to ensure that they would be able to endure the grueling 20-day, 2,000-km trip," Lee added.
The eldest member of the group, Kang Meng-lin, 84, said, "We completed an islandwide 931-km ride in 12 days in 2007. We are confident that we can successfully make this 2,000-km journey to Beijing."
The group departed from downtown Taipei at 5 a.m. Thursday, going along Guandu wharf and crossing the Danshui River to Pali, Taipei County, before proceeding to Tayuan township, Taoyuan County.
Five hours later, the cyclists, including three volunteers from Singapore, arrived at the airport in high spirits.
"The group will not focus on speed, but will hit the road with the dream of conquering the 2,000-km challenge," Lee said.
He noted that all the cyclists have served their country throughout their lives, even after their retirement.

The purpose of the ride is to send the message that "dreaming is not a prerogative of young people only, and getting old is not the end of life, " he said. "Those who break out of solitude can find hope in life."
The group is scheduled to return to Taipei May 5.
Concern & Care Society, which Lee helped to found in 2001, has recruited retirees as volunteers to visit elderly people living alone.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Loser dogs' snap back at social stereotypes

TEXT.P: CNA Staff Reporter

The growing popularity of the Taiwanese television seriesMy Queen,is attributed in no small part to the attraction it holds for tens of thousands of female viewers, some of whom identify closely with the main character, Shan Wu-shuang.

Shan is a 30-something successful single journalist who is stigmatized in the society as aloser, ormakeinuin Japanese. She is independent and competent, but is unpopular among her colleagues and even among some of her friends because she is highly competitive. Despite Shan's achievements, she is viewed as a loser because she is single -- particularly by her mother who tries everything she can to find a love match for her daughter.

The termmakeinu (loser dog) was coined by a famous Japanese female writer, Sakai Junko, in her 2003 bestsellerMakeinu no toboe" (The Howl of the Loser Dog). In the book, Sakai stated with some degree of pride that although many over-30 singles in Tokyo, like herself, were seen as losers, this was not necessarily how they saw themselves because they were satisfied with their lives and their achievements.
In Taiwan society, which is heavily influenced by Japanese culture, single women over the age of 30 often encounter the same types of pressures as females in this age group in Japan.

Eva Chang, a single 33-year-old media worker, told the CNA that it is difficult for her to ignore the expectations of her family and the society. However, she said firmly, she will not be rushed into marriage simply because she is ofmarriageable age.
I am single because I have not found the right person, but that is something that takes time and patience,Chang said.
She noted that in her experience, many Taiwanese men lack confidence and find women like her intimidating because they are well-educated, financially independent, smart, and intellectual.

This female demographic in Taiwan is one that been growing in recent years. Statistics from the Ministry of Interior show that 29.6 percent of Taiwanese women in the age group 30-39 were single in 2007, but by 2008 the figure had jumped to 32.3 percent.
One reason for the shift may be that single women are finding ways to defang the stigma against them in conservative East Asian societies.

For example, some women in Asia used themakeinulabel to forge a positive group identity, in much the same way that some close female friends in other societies affectionately call each other bitchor some African Americans greet each other asnigger, according to Lee Ming-tsung, an assistant professor at National Taiwan University's Department and Graduate Institute of Sociology.

It is a pity that the mass media in Asia continues to use makeinuin a derogatory context to describe women who are in fact independent and successful, while at the same time it depicts marriage as the only path to happiness, Lee said.
Marriage is a lifestyle that one chooses, he said.It is an important option but not the only one, and certainly not the only one that guarantees happiness.

While some people may be taking their social cues from the media in Asia, there are others who have been immersed in Western cultures and have therefore had a firsthand look at the status that is accorded to single women in more liberal societies.

A 36-year-old public relations specialist surnamed Wang who grew up in the United States noted that in that country single independent women over the age of 30 are not seen as picky or flawed in some way, but rather are regarded as mature and attractive.
Wang's personal views are more closely aligned with Western norms, as she thinks marriage is personal choice and sees no need to marry someone unless such a union would contribute to her happiness.
One cannot force marriage, Wang said.It is something good, but I will not allow myself to be unhappy simply because I am single."
Wang said her right to choose also includes setting the standard for what she wants in a husband.
As time passes, I might adjust my standards, but not necessarily lower them, she said.However, even by doing so, I would be making my own choice, and I would be comfortable with that."

How long it would take before such views become the mainstream in Taiwan is anyone's guess, but Lee thinks that the country should not continue to lag behind 21st century trends in this regard, as it reflects poorly on the society.
It is time to stop labeling women and stereotyping minorities, because this is not characteristic of a civil society, he said.
Diversity, openness, respect and tolerance are what constitute civilization, Lee said, adding that the mass media and schools should take the lead in reeducating the public along these lines.
On an individual level, people need to focus more on self awareness than on love and marriage, he suggested.
He thinks that a person must first discover and become comfortable with his or her self before he or she could form a meaningful intimate relationship with someone else.

It's much easier to see ourselves through the eyes of others and that is why we keep looking for someone who would be a 'mirror' for us, Lee said.However, only when one discovers one's self can one learn to be alone and not be lonely.
For Chang, being alone is nothing to balk at. One can be happy without being married, she said.It might be a rougher path to take, but certainly not an erroneous one.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign ministry vows to respect U.S. decision on security at AIT

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou said Thursday that his ministry will respect any decision by the United States to post Marine Corps (USMC) personnel at the new American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) compound that will be built in Taipei's Neihu District.
"We will respect the U.S. decision and will not oppose it, " Ou said at an interpellation session of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign Affairs and National Defense Committee.
"We will be looking forward to it because it would have positive connotations," he added.

Ou was responding to ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lin Yu-fang's question on a Taipei Times report that the the USMC held a meeting with U.S. State Department officials earlier this month in Washington to discuss proposals for protecting a number of new U.S. embassy buildings, including the new AIT office complex that will be completed in 2012.

If the plan goes through, the Marines would be the first U.S. military forces to be stationed in Taiwan since the U.S. switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1979, the report added.
AIT spokesman Thomas Hodges did not comment directly on the report, saying only that there have been no changes in the status of this matter since the AIT's last public discussion of it one year ago.

"The AIT's planned new office in Neihu will include housing for a security detachment. Such plans are in keeping with U.S. global security standards. These plans represent no change in U.S. policy toward Taiwan," Hodges said.

Lin suggested that if the U.S. decides to send armed Marines to take charge of AIT security, Taiwan should also resume its posting of military police to its representative office in Washington and its Twin Oaks Estate there.

Ou said that if the U.S. makes a request to post Marine Corps guards at the AIT new headquarters, the MOFA will of course make a similar request to send military police to Washington, based on the principles of reciprocity and equal status. However, this will require further discussion, he said.

Taiwan military police posted at the country's Washington representative office were replaced by private armed security guards in 2003 because foreign military police are not permitted to carry guns on U.S. soil.

Opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Tsai Huang-lang said if the U.S. goes through with the plan, the significance would be twofold -- an indirect acknowledgement of Taiwan's sovereignty and an upgrade of the importance of security across the Taiwan Strait.
KMT Legislator Chang Hsien-yao also expressed a similar view, saying that it would indirectly indicate that the AIT is being viewed as an embassy and an extension of U.S. territory.

Despite the absence of diplomatic relations, Taiwan and the U.S. maintain close substantive ties. The AIT functions as the de facto U.S. embassy in Taiwan and its head is also treated as the top U.S. representative to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former Control Yuan head arrives in Hainan for economic forum

TEXT.P: Former Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien arrived in Hainan, China at the head of a 34-member delegation Thursday to attend an economic conference there.
Chien will take part in the 2009 Boao Forum for Asia (BFA) April 17-19 in his capacity as chairman of a charity foundation and senior adviser to the Cross- Straits Common Market Foundation.

As the discussion of a financial memorandum of understanding (MOU) is high on agenda of the next round of cross-Taiwan strait talks later this month, Chien's delegation includes several financial experts such as Taiwan Stock Exchange Chairman Schive Chi, Cross-Strait Common Market Foundation Chairman Chan Huo- sheng and Taiwan Financial Holding Chairwoman Susan Chang.
China Premier Wen Jiabao and China's Taiwan Affairs Office Director Wang Yi will also attend the forum and are expected to meet with Chien's delegation.

The BFA is a non-government, non-profit international organization and its annual conferences gather leaders in government, business and academia in Asia and other continents to share their visions on the most pressing issues in the region and the world at large.
This year's theme is "Asia: Managing Beyond Crisis" and
participants are expected to debate and discuss the impact of the
crisis on Asia and how the region can weather these challenges as
effectively as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices on Taipei bourse surge

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices rose 2.07 percent Thursday, on optimism that Taiwan and China will move up their schedule for signing a long-anticipated financial supervision agreement in late April or early May.
Led by financial shares, the TAIEX advanced 121.98 points, or 2.07 percent, to close at 5,997.17 on turnover of NT$172.94 billion (US$5.12 billion), the highest turnover this year.
Following gains on Wall Street overnight, the local bourse opened at 5,814.17 and rose to 6,025.85 at one stage before moving down to 5,765.81.
A total of 7.80 billion shares changed hands.

All the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares surging the most at 5.5 percent. Textile stocks added 4.4 percent, cement stocks rose 2.4 percent, paper and pulp issues advanced 1.6 percent, machinery and electronics shares moved up 1.4 percent, construction shares gained 1.2 percent, plastics and chemicals issues rose 0.7 percent, and foodstuff shares moved up 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,559 to 666, with 110 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$7.73 billion.
Analysts believed that despite the possibility of selling pressure in the short term, the TAIEX could break the 6,000 threshold in the near future as the market is awash with funds.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, increasing NT$0.010 to close at NT$33.800.
A total of US$1.09 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.790 and fluctuated between NT$33.681 and NT$33.800.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutors help kids stay in school with crime offenders' funds

TEXT.P: Since the beginning of this year, the Prosecutors Office in southern Taiwan's Chiayi area has given scholarships to 150 local students with money raised from crime perpetrators, a source said Thursday.

Money for the scholarships -- which range from NT$2,000 (US$60) for each junior high school student and NT$1,000 for each elementary school student in every semester -- came from funds paid to the Chiayi Prosecutors Office by perpetrators of minor offenses in return for deferred prosecution.
The scholarships program began in 2007, benefiting 90 poor students that year, according to a worker with the Hsin Kang Foundation of Culture and Education (HKFCE) which cooperates in the program.
The scholarships were not issued in 2008 due to insufficient time to make arrangements, said the HKFCE official.
From 2006, the Chiayi Prosecutors Office began funding local charitable groups with the public funds to help them pay for social services for local residents, he added.
The aim is to help children from impoverished or low-income families stay in school to continue their studies and pave a good future for them, he said.

Chiayi Chief Prosecutor Hung Kuang-shuan presided over a ceremony at the Hsin Kang Junior High School Wednesday in which he handed out the scholarships to students of the school in need of monetary assistance. HKFCE Chairman Frank Chang also attended the activity.

Hung urged the disadvantaged students not to drop out of school because of their families' economic difficulties and encouraged them to keep studying as a means of finding new horizons in their lives and striving forward.
"We hope that our aid would help them ride over current difficulties and make a turnaround on the road of their lives, " he said.

The Chiayi Prosecutors Office has NT$10 million (US$298,000) worth of this kind of public funds under its disposal this year, Hung said in early January when the office sponsored an activity to help impoverished families celebrate the Lunar New Year.
Because of the widespread economic downturn, many low income families have seen their livelihoods greatly affected, said Hung.

DOC.HEADLINE: International ladies' calligraphy exhibition to take place in Taipei

TEXT.P: An international exhibition of the works of female Asian calligraphers is scheduled to open April 17 to promote the traditional Chinese artform, the National Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Management Office announced Thursday.

Featuring 250 works by female calligraphers from Taiwan, South Korea, Japan and Hong Kong, the exhibition will run through April 29 at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in Taipei, the office said in a press release.

Launched four years ago by the Taiwan International Calligraphy Association and South Korea's ladies' Chinese calligraphy association, the office said the exhibition is unlike any other because it promotes calligraphy and features exclusively the work of female calligraphers from Asia.

"Chinese calligraphy is not only part of China's cultural heritage but also represents Oriental art, as it has been passed on to countries deeply influenced by Chinese culture such as South Korea and Japan," the press statement said.
The exhibition will be open to the public every day from 9 a.m. to 6: 30 p.m. More information about the exhibition is available at http://www.cksmh.gov.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: Optimism growing among Taiwanese investors: survey

TEXT.P: Forty-three percent of investors in Taiwan expect the country's economic situation to improve in the second quarter of 2009, indicating that investors are emerging from a prevailing sentiment of pessimism, according to the results of a survey released Thursday by ING Investment Management Asia/Pacific.

The percentage represents an upswing of 29 percentage points from the previous survey conducted in December 2008, in which only 14 percent of Taiwanese investors predicted the situation would be better in the first quarter of 2009.

The increase is the highest seen among the 13 Asia-Pacific markets surveyed, which also include China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Korea, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, Japan, Australia and New Zealand.

The latest survey conducted in March 2009 found that the pan-Asia investor sentiment index -- excluding Japan, Australia and New Zealand -- stood at 85 for the first quarter of 2009, up from 73 for the previous quarter, driven mainly by strong confidence displayed by investors in China, India and Taiwan.
The increase moved the index from "pessimistic" back into the "neutral" category.
According to ING, the optimistic sentiment of Taiwanese investors is reflected in their expectations for the stock market and stock investment returns.

As many as 35 percent of Taiwanese investors surveyed in March expected the stock index to rise in the coming quarter (Q2 2009) , while only 9 percent of investors surveyed in December were positive about the outlook of the stock market for the coming quarter (Q1 2009).
Meanwhile, 40 percent of Taiwanese investors surveyed in March predicted returns will increase in the coming quarter, when only 13 percent of respondents in December held such a view.

The feeling of optimism is also encouraging Taiwanese investors to adopt a more aggressive approach toward investment, with the percentage of investors who prefer high-risk investments rising from 15 percent in the fourth quarter of 2008 to 31 percent in the first quarter of 2009, the survey results show.

Looking ahead to the coming quarter, 35 percent of investors in March said they will increase cash deposits, down from 51 percent in December, and 28 percent said they will adjust their investment portfolios.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mongolian educator visits local charity organization

TEXT.P: A prominent educator from Mongolia visited the Miaoli branch of the Taiwan Fund for Children and Families (TFCF) in northern Taiwan Thursday to exchange views with social welfare workers there.
Badrakh Jadambaa, president of the State Pedagogical University of Mongolia, received a warm greeting from TFCF Chairman Lin Porung.
Jadambaa is on a short-term academic tour of Taiwan at the invitation of National Chung Cheng University based in Chiayi County in southern Taiwan.

Expressing appreciation for the assistance extended by a TFCF center in the Mongolian capital of Ulan Bator to underprivileged children and impoverished families in Mongolia, he called for closer cooperation between his university and the TFCF's Ulan Bator center.

According to Jadambaa, the TFCF opened its unit in the Mongolian capital nearly four years ago, since which time it has helped more then 4,000 poor Mongolian children to attend school. It has also assisted many homeless people and poor families by offering accommodation and building water supply facilities for them, he added.

Jadambaa also expressed hope that Taiwanese welfare organizations, including the TFCF, will provide opportunities allowing students from his university to gain hands-on experience in social service work.

DOC.HEADLINE: Rice wine price expected to drop sharply

TEXT.P: The price of rice wine, a staple ingredient in local cuisine, is expected to drop sharply after a legislative committee passed the first reading of an amended tax law Thursday to reduce the duty levied on the product.

The Financial Committee reviewed the draft amendment to the Tobacco and Alcohol Law regarding duty on local and imported distilled liquor and decided that the tax will be adjusted depending on the alcohol content of the product, setting the tariff at NT$2.5 per degree of alcohol per liter.
The public is expected to be able to buy much cheaper rice wine as early as May once the amendment clears the legislature.

Finance Minister Lee Sush-der noted that a 0.6-liter bottle of rice wine sells for around NT$180 (including NT$111 in tax) at present, and said that after the tax cuts, the price per bottle will drop to between NT$60 and NT$65.

The committee also attached a resolution that the cost of a bottle of rice wine will not exceed NT$50. Even if this means that rice wine will be sold below cost price, the committee believes this is the best way to eradicate the common practice of buying much cheaper bootleg rice wine instead of the legal product.

Hsu An-hsiuan, president of the state-owned Taiwan Tobacco and Liquor Corp. said Thursday that he will continue to communicate with lawmakers, saying that he "could only accept a price range of between NT$58 and NT$60 per bottle."
Other distilled spirits such as whisky and brandy, which have a higher alcohol content, will not see much difference in their selling prices.
The ministry noted that before the implementation of the Tobacco and Alcohol Law, rice wine sales for 1994-1996 averaged 210 million bottles annually.
Since 2003, however, following Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization, rice wine has been levied with an NT$185-per-liter tax in line with WTO tax regulations on distilled spirits.
Since then, annual sales of locally produced rice wine have dropped to about 750,000 bottles, just 3.6 percent of the pre-WTO volume.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sport divers urged not to disturb coral spawning off Kenting

TEXT.P: Recreational divers should stay out of the water off the Kenting National Park in southern Taiwan in the coming days to avoid disrupting the annual coral spawning, the head of the Taiwanese Coral Reef Society (TCRS) said Thursday.

Coral spawning has become a famous attraction for divers in recent years, but TCRS President Cheng Ming-hsiu said domestic conditions have "not yet matured sufficiently" for local divers to experience such a spectacle.
According to Cheng, the coral on the reefs around Kenting has begun spawning, an annual spectacle that is expected to reach a peak this weekend.

As the Kenting National Park Administration has failed to draw up any regulations governing the observation of the coral spawning, Cheng said, recreational divers should not dive in the waters off Kenting to observe the annual spectacle.
For one thing, he said, the park administration has not even set a cap on the number of people allowed to dive in the area each day to admire the coral spawning.
Moreover, Cheng went on, the spawning is best observed at night, and night diving requires advanced training.
"Without proper training and equipment, divers are likely to sustain injuries or damage the coral and other marine resources, " Cheng explained.

Another problem lies in the fact that no local insurance companies are willing to sell insurance policies to local divers at the moment, with the exception of Cathay Life Insurance Co., which provides coverage for marine researchers with Academia Sinica, Taiwan's foremost academic institute.

According to Cheng, some local divers have joined dive trips arranged by local operators to experience the coral spawning in recent years, posing a threat to the coral reef ecosystems, as well as their own safety.

To discourage people from diving in the area during the spawning period, Cheng said his association will cooperate with Public Television Service to broadcast live footage of the coral spawning this Saturday at 8 p.m.
"Our underwater camera crew will present every aspect of the spawning of coral, as well as the reef's fish and invertebrates, to TV viewers," Cheng said.

He also urged the government to revise its civil service recruitment system to pave the way for employing marine biologists and ecologists in public service, thus better protecting the country's marine resources and ecosystems.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan committed to moving toward low-carbon society: premier

TEXT.P: Echoing a call from President Ma Ying-jeou for the speedy enactment of a draft statute for renewable energy development, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Thursday that the Cabinet has designated 2009 as "the year to start up the renewable energy act."
Liu made the pledge at the closing ceremony of a national energy conference -- the third of its kind in Taiwan -- aimed at charting the country's energy policy.

Noting that the renewable energy development statute pending legislative approval is aimed at building Taiwan into a low-carbon society with low carbon dioxide emissions, Liu said the executive branch will make every effort to push the Legislative Yuan to pass the bill this year.

The passage of the bill will provide a legal basis for establishing a mechanism for the procurement of renewable energy, figuring out viable market prices and removing hurdles to the development of renewable energy, Liu said, adding that only completion of this groundwork can turn Taiwan into an advanced country in terms of renewable energy development.
He also reaffirmed the government's commitment to accelerating the development of green energy industries through technological breakthroughs, increased investment and market opening.

"It is believed that guided by a low-carbon industrial policy, green energy industries, including the solar power industry, will inject new blood into the local economy, " the premier said confidently.
On the development of nuclear energy, Liu commented that the controversial form of energy is a "transitional option" in the process of Taiwan's metamorphosis into a low-carbon society.

"With three nuclear power plants in operation and another under construction, Taiwan cannot deny the fact that nuclear energy is one of its transitional options on its way toward a low-carbon society, " Liu said in response to protests by anti-nuclear power activists over the government's energy policy.

In the future, Liu went on, the government will focus its concern and energy on ensuring the safety of its nuclear power generators, improving radioactive waste treatment technology, enhancing operational transparency and reinforcing public supervision of nuclear power generation.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH keeping tabs on China SARS victim reports

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) is keeping close tabs on foreign wire service reports that a Chinese woman has died of suspected severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in Russia, a senior official said Thursday.

Shih Wen-yi, deputy director of the DOH's Centers for Disease Control, said the center has been seeking further information about the reports from the World Health Organization (WHO), as well as the Chinese and Russian authorities, through the platform of the International Health Regulations (IHR) but has not received any replies.

According to reports from Moscow, the 24-year-old Chinese woman died Wednesday while traveling on a train from the Far East Russian city of Blagoveshensk to Moscow. She was accompanied by her husband, mother and father, who all had slight temperatures, according to the reports.
Initial reports said the Chinese migrant was suspected of having died from SARS, a deadly respiratory disease that can be spread through the air.
Shih said his center has checked the IHR information networks since learning of the reports, but has not found any relevant information about the case. "We'll continue investigating," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for April 17, 2009

TEXT.P: 2. Event: President Ma Ying-jeou meeting with World Medical Association President Dr. Yoram Blachar. Date and Time: 03:15 p.m., Friday, April 17, 2009. Place: Presidential Office, No.122, Chongqing S. Road, Sec.1, Taipei City. Press Contact: Tel. 2311-3731.
