The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.800 and fluctuated between NT$33.725 and NT$33.850.

DOC.HEADLINE: Panda house at Taipei Zoo sees 1 millionth visitor

TEXT.P: The panda house at the Taipei Zoo received Friday its 1 millionth visitor since its opening less than three months ago to showcase two pandas given by China to Taiwan as part of warming ties between the two sides.
The visitor, who appeared soon after 11 a.m., was a four-year-old girl from Taipei County.

The lucky girl and the visitor before and after her were each offered a gift pack containing a pair of chopsticks, cup, hat and USB flash drive with panda patterns, a ticket for the film Trail of the Panda, and cards with the footprints of Tuan Tuan and Yuan Yuan -- the pair of pandas at the zoo.

The pandas were offered to Taiwan as a gift in 2005 after a visit to China by then-opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan. The rare animals were rejected by the previous pro-independence government, but were finally delivered to Taiwan on Dec. 24, 2008 after the current government, which hopes to build stronger economic ties with China, accepted them.
The animals have since been housed at the Taipei Zoo and were officially put on public display Jan. 26.

To cope with the influx of visitors, the zoo has set up numbered slip dispensers to control the maximum number of visitors at 14,000 per day. The method has also enable the zoo to keep track of how many visitors have been to the panda house.

DOC.HEADLINE: Profit-taking sends prices on Taipei bourse tumbling

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices fell sharply Friday on profit-taking, following a near seven-month closing high the previous day.
The weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropped 241.79 points, or 4.03 percent, to close at 5,755.38, the biggest single- day decline in three months.
The local bourse opened at 6,068.55 and fluctuated between 6,071.06 and 5,707.69 during the session.
A total of 10.44 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$223.65 billion (US$6.91 billion) , the highest turnover in a session this year.

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp shares falling the most at 6.9 percent. Construction issues shed 6.1 percent, foodstuff stocks as well as banking and financial shares fell 5.9 percent, textile issues dropped 4.9 percent, cement shares dropped 4.3 percent, plastics and chemical issues lost 3.8 percent, and machinery and electronics shares lost 3.4 percent,
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,906 to 433, with 60 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$10.44 billion.
Analysts said the fall in financial shares hurt investor confidence and dragged down prices in other sectors.
Cathay Financial Holding Co., Taiwan's biggest financial holding company, fell NT$2.30, or 6 percent, to close at NT$35.70.
Fubon Financial Holding Company, which lost NT$1.90 to close at NT$25.40, Mega Financial Holding Company, which lost NT$1.05 to end at NT$14.55, both fell by the maximum 7 percent.
The TAIEX has risen more than 1,500 points from the low of 4,242.61 points recorded on Jan. 20 and has tested the 6,000-point level several times.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT announces Taiwan's finalists for democracy video challenge

TEXT.P: The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) on Friday announced Taiwan's finalists for the worldwide contest "Democracy Video Challenge (DVC) aimed at enhancing the global dialogue on democracy.

AIT Director Stephen M. Young, who presented certificates to Taiwanese finalists at a news conference, said the AIT launched the contest in Taiwan in October 2008 to engage individuals from Taiwan in a global dialogue on democracy.

The challenge provided an opportunity for dialogue and exchange on the important subject of democracy, Young said.Democracy is a fundamental value shared by the people of the United States and the people of Taiwan.

Michael Ying-mao Kau, former deputy foreign minister and a senior fellow of the event partner Taiwan Foundation for Democracy (TFD) , said at the news conference that the holding of the competition is significant on three levels.
While the competition demonstrates the U.S.soft power in promoting democracy, it also serves as a platform for the young generation to think over the question of what democracy is, Kau said.
It also provides a chance for Taiwanese people to think about the nature of our own democracy and in which direction our democratic development should go,he added.

Announced by the AIT last fall, the DVC is a worldwide competition initiated by the U.S. Department of State which asks budding filmmakers, democracy advocates, and the general public to create three minute YouTube videos that complete the phrase, Democracy is...."

Selected from a total of eight entries by a panel of democracy advocates, film scholars and AIT representatives, the Taiwanese finalists areDBC Jmovie- Democracy,Goldfish, Ocean, Democracy, andDemocracy.

Lee Chia-hua and Chang Chia-yun, filmmakers ofDemocracyand freshmen in National Taiwan University of ArtsDepartment of Filmmaking, told the Central News Agency that to them, democracy is respecting and listening to others so that everyone can create a better world together.
Lee said that through making the video, she had a deeper understanding of the meaning of democracy, especially when she had to research for certain democracy movement events that happened in Taiwan.

Asked if the theme of the challenge is a bit too serious, Chang said democracy does not have to be a serious topic, but rather an interesting one because it all depends on the angle from which people interpret it.
A judging panel in the United States will choose the best three, who will then join a worldwide competition, according to Scott Robinson, director of the AIT's American Cultural Center.

Seven winning videos -- one each from Sub-Saharan Africa, East Asia and Pacific, Europe, the Near East and North Africa, South and Central Asia, and the Western Hemisphere, as well as one anonymous video -- will be chosen through public voting on YouTube, Robinson said.

They will be eligible for an all-expenses paid trip to the U.S. that includes screenings of their videos in New York, Hollywood and Washington, meetings with film directors, public officials and democracy advocates, and visits to film sets and television program sets, he added.

Friday's awards ceremony was co-hosted by the Taiwan partners of the DVC, including the TFD, the Council for Cultural Affairs, Chinese Taipei Film Archive, Taiwan Film and Culture Association, SPOT Taipei Film House and National Taiwan University of the Arts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Environmental agency to launch beach clean-up drive

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) will launch a nationwide beach clean-up campaign Saturday in which it will mobilize 20,000 volunteers to pick up trash on about 1,000 kilometers of coastline and riverbanks around the country.

Volunteers will be assembled from villages, boroughs, communities, schools and coastline administration units and private enterprises in the country's 25 cities and counties, including the outlying island counties of Penghu, Kinmen and Lienchiang, the EPA announced in a statement Friday.
The clean-up drive composed of a series of activities organized by local governments is slated to run until June 5.
The statement indicated the time and location for the sequence of activities will be made available on the EPA's Website.
As part of the drive, a large-scale beach cleanup will be staged this Sunday on the coast of the Yung An fishing port in the northern county of Taoyuan, according to the statement.
After the cleanups, the EPA will hold an awards ceremony on June 5 - World Environment Day - to honor three administrative municipalities with outstanding performance during the drive.

A subsidy of NT$500,000 will be given to each of the three municipalities which do a good job in organizing its local campaign. Another six municipalities with impressive performance will be given NT$300,000 each, the statement said.

As Taiwan's beautiful coastlines and beaches are its most precious resources, the EPA encouraged the public to take part in the campaign in order to ensure the resources are well maintained in terms of water quality and general cleanliness, the statement added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.K.-Taiwan education practice seminar to open in Taipei, Kaohsiung

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) announced Friday that it will invite experts from the United Kingdom to an upcoming seminar to discuss how to apply multimedia technology to education and vocational training.
The issue of how to apply information technology (IT) to talent training and vocational education has become one of the most important subjects in the 21st century, the BTCO said in a press release.

The statement said the U.K.-Taiwan Education Practice Seminar, to be held in Taipei and Kaohsiung on April 28 and 30, respectively, will serve as a platform for the U.K. to share its experience on integrating multimedia technology with education.
British experts will deliver speeches on the topic and share their views with Taiwanese educators on the future development of IT applications in schools, the BTCO said.

The BTCO encouraged people working in the education sector and related fields to participate. Individuals can sign up for the seminar by contacting the office at (02) 8758-2030 or by e-mailing angela.wu@fco.gov.uk.
More information about the seminar is available at http://ukintaiwan.fco.gov.uk/zh.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government urged to examine safety of drywall imported from China

TEXT.P: An opposition party leader urged the government Friday to immediately examine whether the 840 metric tons of drywall products Taiwan imported from China last year might have contained harmful chemicals.

Lin Jih-jia, secretary-general of the Taiwan Solidarity Union, called the government's attention to news reports from the United States that defective drywall products imported from China and used by American builders in more than 100,000 homes, including many in Florida, posed a health hazard to homeowners and apartment dwellers.
Citing customs statistics, Lin, a former legislator, said Taiwan imported 840 metric tons of drywall products from China at a cost of NT$42 million in 2008.

"If the drywall material is tainted, some 12,000 households in Taiwan could have been affected," he said, adding that the government should adopt emergency measures to find out whether the drywall products imported from China contained harmful substances.

According to recent reports from the United States, American builders imported millions of pounds of drywall products from China at the height of the housing boom following the devastation of Hurricane Katrina in August 2005.

The reports said that more than 300 homeowners complained that the putrid sulfur odor emissions -- a rotten-egg stench which grows worse with heat and humidity -- from the wallboard had corroded copper in electrical outlets and metal surfaces behind refrigerators.

The dwellers in these houses also complained that the odor caused them to experience respiratory irritation, and they said they were worried that the tainted drywall might cause long-term damage to their health, according to the reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: Financial regulator raises doubts over Singfor Life land purchase

TEXT.P: The Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) , Taiwan's financial regulator, has raised questions over the legality of Singfor Life Insurance Co.'s NT$2.818 billion (US$83.37 million) winning bid for a coveted piece of land in Taipei's upscale Xinyi District.

Singfor Life, whose bid was far above the NT$1.833 billion floor price, said immediately after winning the tender that it had purchased the land on behalf of a construction company operated by Chen Chung-ming, a Taiwanese businessman with investments in China.

Singfor Life reportedly made an NT$200 million commission by reselling the land to Chen's company soon after being named the winner of the tender for the 29-7 piece of the "D3" plot of land in the Xinyi District.

Late Thursday, the FSC indicated that at first glance, Singfor Life's bid was illegal because a company cannot act as a proxy for another legal entity in a tender and because it may have violated a ban against buying property imposed on it by the FSC last year.
The regulatory body noted, however, that it could not make a final determination until it had gathered complete details on the transaction.

FSC Chairman Sean Chen said Friday that if Singfor fails to give a convincing explanation on its latest move, it would be fined again. He said the FSC had reminded Singfor of the ban a day before Thursday's tender.

Singfor Life first drew the scrutiny of the FSC last July when it acquired two plots (29 and 29-1) in the Xinyi District's "D3" plot of land, considered the last plot in the upscale neighborhood available for the development of luxury apartments, from Citibank Taiwan for NT$3.389 billion.
The deal also included the rights to bid on other plots owned by Citibank.

Last December, the FSC fined Singfor Life NT$4.5 million and also barred it from acquiring property until it sold, within one year, the 29 and 29-1 plots. The regulator determined the insurer had spent more than an insurance company with negative net worth is allowed to spend on a real estate acquisition.
By law, it should not have been able to pay more than NT$100 million in any such transaction.

Singfor Life said it sold the 29 and 29-1 pieces to the construction firm Wednesday, a day before Thursday's bid, to comply with the FSC requirement, but the FSC insisted it had not lifted the restriction imposed on Singfor.

The life insurer also said its purchase Thursday of the 29-7 plot, the last of three pieces of the D3 plot, was necessary to avoid violating a contractual obligation it had with Citibank Taiwan based on the contract the two parties signed on the D3 plot last July.

Not convinced by Singfor Life's explanation, the FSC also said it will check whether there were other irregularities in the deal, such as whether Singfor Life colluded with the construction to resell it the properties at an artificially low price.

The price paid by Singfor Life for the 29-7 plot works out to about NT$1.53 million per ping (the measure of area used in Taiwan equal to about 3.3 square meters) of floor space that will be allowed to be built on the 919-ping plot.
The 1,552-ping D3 plot has an average floor space ratio of about 3.8, meaning a developer will be allowed to build about 6,700 pings of space.

The deal was attractive to Chen because of the exclusivity of the property and expectations that Taiwan's real estate market will rebound in the second half of this year because of warming relations between Taiwan and China, according to sources from Singfor Life.
The 29-7 plot of land fetched a high price because its development could be merged with that of adjacent properties said Lin Chin-sheng, a real estate appraiser.
He added that the insurance company has adequate liquidity to pay property taxes and other fees even if market conditions are not appropriate for developing the property.
Under Taipei City government regulations, the land could be used for residential buildings, which must occupy at least two-thirds of its area, Lin said.
However, using the land to construct an international hotel is also permitted, once the developer registers the project with the city government to ensure that it benefits the city, Lin added.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA vows to make center black-faced spoonbill research stronghold

TEXT.P: A research center under the Council of Agriculture (COA) vowed Friday to turn a conservation site for black-faced spoonbill in southern Taiwan into the top research facility on the endangered birds.
The COA's Endemic Species Research Institute made the pledge on the eve of taking over the black-faced spoonbill conservation center in Chiku, Tainan.

Hsueh Mei-li, an associate researcher at the Endemic Species Research Institute, noted that the center was set up in November 2005 by the Tainan County government after receiving funds from the Forestry Bureau.

The Tainan County government decided to relinquish its control of the center, Hsueh said, because it did not feel it had enough qualified scientists and management talent to operate the center in an optimal way.

She noted that according to statistics from the Construction & Planning Administration under the Minister of the Interior, Taiwan currently has two world-class wetlands -- Tainan County's Sichao wetland and the Chiku black-faced spoonbill conservation research center -- with the latter also the largest conservation site for black-faced spoonbills.

She said more than 1,500 black-faced spoonbills arrived in Taiwan last year to weather the winter, an indication that the conservation efforts have paid off given that the bird's worldwide population is only about 2,000.
She noted that the Endemic Species Research Institute already has low-, middle- and high-altitude research and experimental stations.
With the new addition of the Chiku center, the institute will be able to conduct more comprehensive research on Taiwan's ecological systems, Hsueh noted.
She also said that the institute is planning to sponsor the first international symposium at the Chiku research center in early November.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City to control traffic for Bike Day event

TEXT.P: The Taipei City government will impose traffic controls along certain vehicle lanes on Renai Road on May 3 when the annual Taiwan Bike Day event will be held simultaneously in nine cities and counties around the country, a city official said Friday.

The event, now in its third year, will kick off concurrently in the northern city and county of Taipei, the central county of Nantou, Chiayi City, Chiayi County, Kaohsiung City and Pingtung County in the south, as well as the southeastern county of Taitung and the outlying island county of Penghu, according to the official.

In Taipei City, the bicycle tour will begin at the plaza in front of the Presidential Office and then pass through Renai Road and Yixian Road before returning to the Presidential Office, the official indicated.

On the same day, the city government will also hold a parade of creatively- designed floats which will set off from the Presidential Office, tour along Hangzhou South Road, and then return to the start point.

To give cyclists and parade participants more room to maneuver during the day, two inner express lanes along Renai Road will be closed to all traffic, while only two outer slow traffic lanes along the road will remain open to motorists, the official indicated.
In addition, the municipal government, in collaboration with the Cycling Lifestyle Foundation, will organize a performance gala of BMX (or Bicycle Motocross) stunt shows and entertainment programs.

People interested in the event are encouraged to sign up at various outlets of Giant, Taiwan's largest bicycle manufacturer, with participants to be given an opportunity to win a commemorative bicycle worth NT$158,000 in a lucky draw, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local budding star to get chance to play with Agassi and Graf

TEXT.P: One young Taiwanese tennis player will be heading to the French Open in Paris to join 15 other youths from around the world to trade shots with two of the game's legendary players, Andre Agassi and his wife, Steffi Graf.

In a promotion being run by watchmaker and official French Open sponsor Longines, one budding star under 12 will be carefully selected from each of 16 countries to participate in the June 6 event, with the 16 players forming eight teams that will each take a shot at tennis' leading couple, winners of a combined 30 grand slam singles titles.

Longines Taiwan announced Friday that Taiwan would be one of the 16 countries participating in the event and that local tennis marketing firm Integration Sports, would run the local selection process.

"When a lot of my friends heard about the event, they asked me if we could get rid of the 12-year-old age bracket and make anybody eligible," joked Integration Sports CEO Jeff Hsu, on the interest the announcement drew.
"It's really a great opportunity because besides playing with Agassi and Graf, there will be a big dinner and other events."

The young boy and girl players will be chosen based on rigorous criteria, including national ranking, their past results, an interview, an Internet vote, and their performance in the ranking tournament for players 12 and under to take place in mid-May.

A group of 32 pre-selected boys and girls will be screened based on the first three criteria, with eight finalists to be chosen before an April 24 press conference, at which each will be introduced and watched closely to see how they hold up under questioning by the media.
"The winner will be representing Taiwan, so we want to make sure he or she can present themselves well," Hsu said.
The winner will be chosen on May 14.
Longines will donate US$10,000 to Agassi's two charities, the Andre Agassi Foundation and Children for Tomorrow, for each young team that beats him and Graf over a single set.
Taiwan's representative will be accompanied by an adult.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hualien Agricultural Research Station celebrates 70th anniversary

TEXT.P: The Hualien District Agricultural Research and Extension Station will celebrate its 70th anniversary Saturday by inviting the public to an open house to join in a series of activities.

Staff members at the research institute in eastern Taiwan said that in addition to seeing a photo exhibition and an exhibition of agricultural products, visitors will be treated to traditional music performances, rural dancing, tea- tasting and baked yams.

There will also be cooking classes and fun activities, including picture drawing and body painting, as well as a guided tour of the fields to allow visitors to familiarize themselves with landscape plants, indigenous vegetables, aromatic plants, water plants and plants which are conducive to good health.

The station was established in April 1939 while Taiwan was still Japan's colony. It was moved from its original site in Jian Township's Chingfeng Village to the current location in Jian Village in July 1942. Since the Japanese colonial era ended in 1945, the station has undergone four name changes to become what it is today.

The station has been undertaking research to improve various vegetables, including rice, sweet potatoes, tomatoes, scallions, and peanuts. In recent years, it has dedicated itself particularly to the development of health- promoting foods.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma aims to control drug abuse recidivism to within 30 percent

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that Taiwan's anti-drug efforts can be described as "successful" so long as the recidivism rate of incarcerated drug addicts within five years after being released from detention is controlled to within 30 percent.

Ma made the remarks during his visit to the Ming-Teh branch of southern Taiwan's Tainan Prison, accompanied by Justice Minister Wang Ching-feng. He was the first president of Taiwan to visit the only state-run drug addiction treatment center in the country.

Ma said he once set the ambitious goal of zero recidivism for incarcerated drug abusers when he served as minister of justice between 1993 and 1996, but admitted Friday that it was not a realistic goal.
Taiwan's efforts to crack down on drug crimes should focus on reducing the number of first-time drug offenders, which would automatically lead to a drop in the number of habitual offenders, Ma said.
The country's efforts can be considered successful if none of the offenders detained for obligatory drug treatment are recidivists, Ma noted.
During his visit, the president also acknowledged the achievements of the Ming-Teh center in lowering the relapse tendency of addicted inmates by taking advantage of the power of religion.

The Ming-Teh prison branch has been inviting Buddhist and Christian groups to help the inmates quit their addiction to drugs, by offering spiritual support and assisting the addicted in restoring their faith in life and in themselves.

In 2008, only 34 percent of drug addicts forced to undergo treatment in the Ming-Teh center were found to have again committed the crime of taking drugs, such as heroin and morphine, that are listed in the first-degree category, after they were released from detention, according to the prison.

Drug abuse has been on the rise in Taiwan, as more young people experiment with contraband drugs, such as ecstasy. Legislator Huang Chih-hsiung of the ruling Kuomindtang said April 7 that the number of people addicted to drugs has increased to over 230,000 people from the level of around 200,000 in 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exhibition of Lady's slipper orchids opens in Taipei

TEXT.P: An exhibition of Paphiopedilum orchids -- better known as Lady's slipper orchids -- opened at the National Museum of Natural Sciences in Taipei Friday and will run until April 26.

According to the Taiwan Paphiopedilum Society, the organizer of the event, the more than 200 pots of Lady's slipper orchids put on display at the exhibition include many that have won awards in competitions. They include the original species, the single-flower type, the multiflora type and the standard type.
The word Paphiopedilum was derived from the Greek word "Paphian," which refers to the Roman Goddess Venus, and "pedilon" which means slipper.

Kao Chi-ching, vice chairman of the Taiwan Paphiopedilum Society, said that Taiwan's orchid growers have cultivated about 3 million Lady's slipper orchids, most of which are locally developed species.
Kao said the Lady's slipper orchids are distinctive because their flowers are different from other orchids and that they appear in various shapes and colors.
He added that the award-winning orchids will remain on display until April 19, while the others, including many new hybrid Lady's slipper orchid species, will be on display until April 26.

The Lady's slipper orchids are also known in the United States as moccasin flowers. They are so named because of the flowers' slipper-shaped pouches. The pouch can trap insects in order to force them to climb up past the staminode, behind which they collect or deposit pollinia.

Lady's slipper orchids originated in the tropical and subtropical forests of Southeast Asia, including southern China, but over-collecting has caused the flowers to become rare and endangered in their original habitats.

The orchids bloom in a variety of colors ranging from white, maroon, yellow, red, pink, and green to nearly black. The color of the blooms may be solid, blended, striped or spotted. The flowers have a waxy texture, and can last six weeks or longer.

DOC.HEADLINE: New flight routes to be announced in 3rd round of cross-strait talks

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Friday that new flight routes will be announced in the third round of cross-strait talks.

MAC Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said that in addition to the present charter flights, the next round of talks between Taiwan and China will discuss the launch of regular passenger and cargo fights and additional flights and routes.

The 108 cross-strait flights permitted at present serve eight destinations in Taiwan and 21 destinations in China, Lai said as she introduced the agenda for the next round of talks set for Nanjing, China as a Chinese delegation arrived in Taiwan Friday for a preparatory meeting on the talks.

Lai noted that four major issues will be covered in the talks, including cross- strait cooperation in combating crimes and judicial assistance, the launch of regular cross-Taiwan Strait flights, cross-strait financial cooperation and Chinese investment in Taiwan.

Addressing progress in cross-strait tourism, she also said that when Taiwan first opened to Chinese tourists in July last year, the number of arrivals was initially low. But the number has increased dramatically since Chinese New Year this year, averaging between 2,000 and 3,000 arrivals daily.
In recent days, the number of Chinese tourists even hit 4,000, she said.
"To maintain the quality of tourism in Taiwan, we hope that the number could maintain an average of 3,000 daily," she added.
The first round of talks between Taiwan and China took place in Beijing in June, leading to the opening of Chinese tourists and weekend charter flights.
The second round of talks was held in Taipei in November, with both sides signing four agreements, including the expansion of air links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan makes breakthrough in new drug development

TEXT.P: Taiwan has developed a new drug for diabetes patients that will begin its first clinical trials on humans at a local medical center in 2010, marking the first drug ever to be developed on the island.

The National Health Research Institutes (NHRI) announced Friday that it has formed an alliance with six local pharmaceutical manufacturers to conduct investigational new drug trials on humans of its developed anti-diabetes drug, DPP-IV, at Taipei Veterans General Hospital (TVGH).

The alliance -- composed of Genovate Biotechnology, the Taipei-based China Chemical and Pharmaceutical Co., Nang Kuang Pharmaceutical, Yuan Shin Group, TTY Biopharm, and Taiwan Biotech -- recently obtained investment from the government's National Development Fund, according to the NHRI.

Chao Yu-sheng, director of the NHRI Division of Biotechnology and Pharmaceutical Research, estimated that the first- and second-stage clinical trials will require NT$200 million (US$5.9 million) , with the national fund to cover 85 percent of the cost and the alliance to take care of the rest.
TVGH will supervise the trials on humans, Chao noted.

Noting it will take 10-15 years and an investment of US$1 billion to get a new drug to the market, Chao added that the third stage of clinical trials for the DPP-IV inhibitor will be undertaken overseas.
At that point, the local pharmaceutical factories that have obtained the NHRI technology transfer might offer authorization to use the technology in exchange for further injections of capital.
Diabetes is considered to be the world's fourth top killer. In the global market, there are drugs developed by Merck and Novartis that have proven effective in treating Type 2 diabetes patients.
Chao, who led the DPP-IV inhibitor development, said he has discovered during animal tests that the chemical elements of the new drug are similar to that of the Merck drug, but the effect is better.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait theme tours to emerge as fashion in travel packages

TEXT.P: Tour packages that connect tourist attractions on both sides of the Taiwan Strait will emerge as a new travel fashion now that direct air and shipping links have been established, a senior official predicted Friday.

Speaking in an interview with Radio Taiwan International, Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chih-kuo said the opening of direct cross- strait transportation links has drawn the two sides closer, which has not only benefited Taiwanese businessmen with interests in China and passengers from both sides but will also help attract foreign visitors to Taiwan.
"I'm convinced that many new tour packages that connect Taiwanese and Chinese tourist attractions will be introduced in the travel market in the future," Mao said.

He forecast, for instance, that future tour packages may include visits to the National Palace Museum in suburban Taipei and the Palace Museum in Beijing to allow vacationers to compare ancient Chinese art collections kept at the two famous museums.
Likewise, tour packages featuring comparisons of special customs and cultures on the two sides may also be introduced in the market to attract research-savvy tourists, Mao said.
In his view, Mao said, bona fide tourism does not lie in deliberate creation of amusement parks or designation of scenic areas, but rather in the day-to-day ways of life and activities.

"In Europe, any street scene and human interaction can form an attraction that touches or moves the heart of visitors, " Mao said. "That's the highest goal of tourism development, but it takes a long time to foster and cultivate."
Noting that the government has listed tourism as one of six new emerging industries, Mao said priority will be given to the development of tourism- related facilities and infrastructure.
In the coming four years, he said, the government will attract at least 10 more international tourist hotel chains to operate in Taiwan.

Renovation of the Taoyuan International Airport, Taiwan's main gateway, is also in progress, Mao said, adding that when the first phase of the facelift of the First Terminal is completed at the end of 2011, the airport will resume its past glory.

Asked whether the third round of cross-strait talks scheduled for late April or early May will touch on the issue of upgrading the current direct cross-strait charter flights to regular scheduled flights, Mao refrained from making a direct response.
He instead said it's a "matter of course" that direct cross-strait air links move from charter services to scheduled flights.

"At the moment, one thing is certain -- that the number of diect cross-strait flights will increase. As to the scope or level of the increase, that depends on negotiations by the two sides," Mao added.

Top negotiators from both sides -- Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits President Chen Yunlin -- are scheduled to meet in Nanjing late this month or early May to discuss a range of issues, including cooperation in financial services and fight against crime and the expansion of direct flight services.

Preparatory talks for the planned Chiang-Chen meeting will be held in Taipei Saturday to flesh out texts of three agreements to be signed and a joint statement that will be issued at encounter in Nanjing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Suspected FMD cases in Changhua County false alarm: official

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) on Friday tentatively ruled out the possibility that pigs on a pig farm in the central county of Changhua were infected with foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) earlier in the week.

The COA's Bureau of Animal Health Inspection and Quarantine noted that initial tests on 18 pigs killed Monday in Hsiusui Village, Changhua County, showed that none were infected with the highly contagious disease.
But bureau officials said that to ensure the safety of the hog industry, they have adopted stringent quarantine measures after the pigs showed suspected symptoms of FMD.
Changhua County animal health officials were instructed to control human and vehicle movements to the farm, and adopt disinfection and visiting measures.
Pigs in farms within a 1-kilometer radius of the farm were given shots while the livestock farms within a 3-km radius of the farm will also be visited to ensure no abnormalities exist.
According to the regulations, if farm owners deliberately conceal infections, they will be fined between NT$10,000 and NT$50,000 and they will not be compensated for animals culled.
If the culled pigs are confirmed to have not been infected with FMD, then the farm owner will be compensated according to the law.
The COA said there are about 12,000 hog farms in Taiwan, with 90 percent of their stock having received no FMD inoculation.

But there have been three FMD reports since February. Following the first case reported in Yunlin County Feb. 4, a second was reported in Changhua County Feb. 9 and a third emerged in Chiayi County March 27, COA officials said.

They said there was no need for the public to panic over the development, describing the appearance of sporadic cases as normal when the percentage of animals receiving inoculations is gradually falling.
Fewer inoculations were given last year as part of a process to eradicate the disease and re-establish Taiwan as an FMD-free country.

Under guidelines set by the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) , Taiwan is entitled to apply to be treated as an FMD-free country with the body before its May 2010 annual meeting if no cases are reported and no vaccinations are given to livestock for one year before applying for FMD-free status, according to the COA.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait theme tours to emerge as fashion in travel packages

TEXT.P: Tour packages that connect tourist attractions on both sides of the Taiwan Strait will emerge as a new travel fashion now that direct air and shipping links have been established, a senior official predicted Friday.

Speaking in an interview with Radio Taiwan International, Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chih-kuo said the opening of direct cross- strait transportation links has drawn the two sides closer, which has not only benefited Taiwanese businessmen with interests in China and passengers from both sides but will also help attract foreign visitors to Taiwan.
"I'm convinced that many new tour packages that connect Taiwanese and Chinese tourist attractions will be introduced in the travel market in the future," Mao said.

He forecast, for instance, that future tour packages may include visits to the National Palace Museum in suburban Taipei and the Palace Museum in Beijing to allow vacationers to compare ancient Chinese art collections kept at the two famous museums.
Likewise, tour packages featuring comparisons of special customs and cultures on the two sides may also be introduced in the market to attract research-savvy tourists, Mao said.
In his view, Mao said, bona fide tourism does not lie in deliberate creation of amusement parks or designation of scenic areas, but rather in the day-to-day ways of life and activities.

"In Europe, any street scene and human interaction can form an attraction that touches or moves the heart of visitors, " Mao said. "That's the highest goal of tourism development, but it takes a long time to foster and cultivate."
Noting that the government has listed tourism as one of six new emerging industries, Mao said priority will be given to the development of tourism- related facilities and infrastructure.
In the coming four years, he said, the government will attract at least 10 more international tourist hotel chains to operate in Taiwan.

Renovation of the Taoyuan International Airport, Taiwan's main gateway, is also in progress, Mao said, adding that when the first phase of the facelift of the First Terminal is completed at the end of 2011, the airport will resume its past glory.

Asked whether the third round of cross-strait talks scheduled for late April or early May will touch on the issue of upgrading the current direct cross-strait charter flights to regular scheduled flights, Mao refrained from making a direct response.
He instead said it's a "matter of course" that direct cross-strait air links move from charter services to scheduled flights.

"At the moment, one thing is certain -- that the number of diect cross-strait flights will increase. As to the scope or level of the increase, that depends on negotiations by the two sides," Mao added.

Top negotiators from both sides -- Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits President Chen Yunlin -- are scheduled to meet in Nanjing late this month or early May to discuss a range of issues, including cooperation in financial services and fight against crime and the expansion of direct flight services.

Preparatory talks for the planned Chiang-Chen meeting will be held in Taipei Saturday to flesh out texts of three agreements to be signed and a joint statement that will be issued at encounter in Nanjing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Suspected FMD cases in Changhua County false alarm: official

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) on Friday tentatively ruled out the possibility that pigs on a pig farm in the central county of Changhua were infected with foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) earlier in the week.

The COA's Bureau of Animal Health Inspection and Quarantine noted that initial tests on 18 pigs killed Monday in Hsiusui Village, Changhua County, showed that none were infected with the highly contagious disease.
But bureau officials said that to ensure the safety of the hog industry, they have adopted stringent quarantine measures after the pigs showed suspected symptoms of FMD.
Changhua County animal health officials were instructed to control human and vehicle movements to the farm, and adopt disinfection and visiting measures.
Pigs in farms within a 1-kilometer radius of the farm were given shots while the livestock farms within a 3-km radius of the farm will also be visited to ensure no abnormalities exist.
According to the regulations, if farm owners deliberately conceal infections, they will be fined between NT$10,000 and NT$50,000 and they will not be compensated for animals culled.
If the culled pigs are confirmed to have not been infected with FMD, then the farm owner will be compensated according to the law.
The COA said there are about 12,000 hog farms in Taiwan, with 90 percent of their stock having received no FMD inoculation.

But there have been three FMD reports since February. Following the first case reported in Yunlin County Feb. 4, a second was reported in Changhua County Feb. 9 and a third emerged in Chiayi County March 27, COA officials said.

They said there was no need for the public to panic over the development, describing the appearance of sporadic cases as normal when the percentage of animals receiving inoculations is gradually falling.
Fewer inoculations were given last year as part of a process to eradicate the disease and re-establish Taiwan as an FMD-free country.

Under guidelines set by the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) , Taiwan is entitled to apply to be treated as an FMD-free country with the body before its May 2010 annual meeting if no cases are reported and no vaccinations are given to livestock for one year before applying for FMD-free status, according to the COA.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-diplomats from both sides of Taiwan Strait finally meet

TEXT.P: Two famous former diplomats in Taiwan and China finally met in Boao in the Chinese province of Hainan Friday on the opening day of the 2009 Boao Forum for Asia (BFA).

Fredrick Chien, a former Taiwanese foreign minister known for his eloquence and knowledge, met with Wang Yi, a retired Chinese career diplomat who is current director of China's Taiwan Affairs Office, for wide-ranging talks on the sidelines of the Boao Forum.

Chien, who is heading a delegation of Taiwanese academics and business leaders to attend the April 17-19 Boao Forum, lauded Wang, a former Chinese ambassador to Japan, for his diplomatic achievements.
Wang hosted a dinner in honor of Chien and his delegation. Both of them exchanged views on many matters of mutual interest, sources said after the dinner.
During the Boao Forum, Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao is also expected to meet with Chien.

The forum is a non-government, non-profit international organization and its annual conferences gather leaders in government, business and academia in Asia and other continents to share their visions on the most pressing issues in the region and the world at large.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 18, or the 23rd day of the third month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1480: Lucrezia Borgia, the illegitimate daughter of Pope Alexander VI, is born in Italy. She was married three times by the age of 18 to further her father's political ambitions.
1906: An earthquake devastates San Francisco, killing more than 1,000 people and making 300,000 others homeless.
1925: The first world women's exposition is opened in Chicago.
1927: The national government is established in Nanking by the Kuomintang.
1933: Fighting spreads in northern China as several strategic passes along the Great Wall fall to the Japanese.
1942: Planes from a U.S. aircraft carrier bomb Tokyo for the first time. They were commanded by Lt. Gen. James Doolittle.
1943: Isoroku Yamamoto, a Japanese naval officer, is killed when his plane is shot down by U.S. warplanes over the Solomon Islands. He planned Japan's naval strategies during World War II, including the attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941.
1946: The League of Nations is formally dissolved.
1948: By a two-thirds majority, the first National Assembly approves temporary provisions granting emergency powers to the president during the ongoing anti- Communist campaign.
1949: The Republic of Ireland is formally proclaimed in Dublin.
1954: Gamal Abdel Nasser becomes prime minister of Egypt.
1955: Albert Einstein, the German-born American theoretical physicist who won a Nobel Prize in 1921 for his explanation of the photoelectric effect, dies at the age of 76. His specific and general theories of relativity revolutionized modern thought on the nature of space and time and formed a theoretical basis for the exploitation of atomic energy.
1968: Army officers in western Africa's Sierra Leone take over the government, dissolve the Legislature and suspend the constitution.
1977: A boat capsizes near Suao Port in eastern Taiwan, killing 32 college students and teachers on board and injuring 16 others.
1980: The former Rhodesia becomes independent Zimbabwe under President Canaan Banana.
1982: Monaco's Prince Rainier III and his wife, Princess Grace Kelly, arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1988: The Republic of China Red Cross Society begins forwarding mail from Taiwan residents to mainland China.
1989: The Mainland Affairs Council under the Executive Yuan decides to permit Taiwan citizens to gather news and make films in mainland China.
1998: Official talks between South and North Korea end with the two sides failing to resolve a dispute over aid to the starving North and the reunion of separated families.
1999: A GIO-produced documentary featuring the relationship between the year of one's birth and the 12 animals in the 12-year cycle of the Chinese calendar wins a gold medal at the Houston International Film Festival.
2000: Tainan-based National Cheng Kung University signs an academic cooperation contract with Japan's Kanazawa Industrial University.
2000: President Lee Teng-hui confers the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on U.S. Senator Frank Murkowski (R-Alaska) for his contributions to promoting bilateral relations between the ROC and the United States.
2001: The Tainan District Court approves a prosecution request to hold Tainan City Mayor George Chang incommunicado over his alleged involvement in a governmental land-requisition scam.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man may be known in three ways which I am not able to show in my own person. As a moral man he is free from anxiety; as a man of understanding he is free from doubt; and as a man of courage he is free from fear."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
SEF, ARATS planning third round of cross-strait talks April 25

TEXT.P: A third round of talks between the top negotiators of Taiwan's Strait Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), has been scheduled to open April 25, an SEF official confirmed Saturday.

"The plan is to open the third round of talks April 25," said SEF Deputy Secretary-General Ma Shao-chang in the first direct SEF response to media speculation about the exact date of the talks scheduled to take place in Nanjing.

Ma made the remarks at a press briefing about the morning session of a preparatory meeting in Taipei between delegations led by ARATS Vice President Zheng Lizhong and his Taiwanese counterpart, SEF Vice Chairman Kao Koong-lian.
The meeting is aimed at hammering out details of procedural problems and technical issues for the upcoming Nanjing talks between SEF Chairman Chiang Pin- kung and ARATS President Chen Yunlin.

Noting that the session went smoothly and that both sides reached consensus on 90 percent of the procedural issues, Ma added that one or two details were left to be finalized in the next preparatory meeting, which will be held in Nanjing on the day the delegates arrive.

Asked about the hotly discussed issue of signing an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, Ma said the matter was not touched upon as it is not on the agenda of the third round of talks, although he added that Chiang and Chen might exchange views on the issue in Nanjing.

Taiwan has great interest in signing an ECFA with China, as the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou thinks such an economic pact would not only help normalize relations with China but would also prevent Taiwan's marginalization in the process of China's economic integration with other countries in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: Human rights covenants major progress for Taiwan: official
DOC.DATELINE: London, April 17 (CNA) 04/18/09 13:35:56 (By Jennifer Huang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The recent ratification of two human rights covenants by Taiwan is expected to help upgrade the country's international presence, Taiwan's representative to the United Kingdom said Friday.

According to Chang Siao-yue, despite Taiwan not being a member of the United Nations, the March 31 ratification of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights signifies Taiwan's intent to abide by the highest human rights standards, marking an important milestone in the country's progress in human rights protection.
The move by Taiwan has won high praise from the global human rights group Amnesty International.

"Taiwan's actions present a strong model for the region that economic growth and prosperity can go hand-in-hand with increasing respect for human rights, " said Sam Zarifi, Amnesty International's Asia-Pacific director, in a statement released April 9.

The covenants were introduced by the United Nations in 1966 and came into force in 1976. The Republic of China became a signatory to the covenants in 1967, when it was still a member of the United Nations.

With the human rights situation in Taiwan being not in compliance with the requirements set forth in the documents at that time, the ROC government did not proceed immediately with the ratification of the covenants and the procedure was suspended after the country lost its U.N. membership in 1971.

During the former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration, the Cabinet submitted the covenants to the legislature for endorsement, first in 2001 and again in 2002, 2005 and February 2008, but because of differences among the legislators, no decision was made on the issue.

A major bone of contention was a clause in the covenants promising self- determination of all peoples, which some feared could fuel a bid by pro- independence activists to promote a plebiscite on the issue of independence versus unification with China and thereby escalate tension across the Taiwan Strait.

The covenants failed to win the support of the then-opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party, which together held a majority in the legislature during the eight years the pro-independence DPP was in power.

With President Ma Ying-jeou's strong support for the ratification of the covenants following his inauguration last May, the legislature eventually ratified them and passed a law on the enforcement of the two covenants March 31.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China to make joint efforts to combat financial crisis

TEXT.P: A Chinese delegation visiting Taipei to talk with its Taiwanese counterparts on details of an upcoming third round of cross-Taiwan Strait talks pledged Saturday to make joint efforts to combat the financial crisis and boost cooperation in promoting the welfare of the people on both sides.

Zheng Lizhong, vice president of the quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) and his Taiwanese counterpart Kao Koong-lian, vice chairman and secretary-general of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) made the pledge at the opening of a preparatory session for the third round of talks between SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and ARATS President Chen Yunlin.

"While both sides of the Taiwan Strait are under the impact of the global financial crisis, we believe that on the basis of the fruitful results that have been achieved, we can overcome this universal difficulty by strengthening bilateral cooperation and boosting confidence," said Zheng.

Noting that cross-strait communications have been smooth and harmonious over the past year and that relations between Taiwan and China have now been put "on the track of peaceful development," Zheng said that both sides should follow policy of "easy issues and economic topics first, difficult issues and political topics later."
"Holding the preparatory session in Taipei for the first time is especially meaningful, as it symbolizes that negotiations between the SEF and ARATS are on an equal footing," Kao said.

In the face of the economic downturn, he went on, the SEF and ARATS should seize the historic opportunity, focus on the big picture and work together on improving relations and increasing mutual benefits.

Although details of the third round of talks had yet to be hammered out in Saturday's session, the upcoming Chiang-Chen meeting is expected to cover issues such as regularly scheduled cross-strait flights, financial cooperation, tackling cross-strait crime and opening Taiwan to investment from China.

While the meeting between Cheng and Kao was harmonious and pleasant, the atmosphere outside the conference room was extremely tense with tight security on high alert for fear that protests led by opposition Democratic Progressive Party politicians against the Chinese delegation that took place a day earlier at the airport might occur again.
Hundreds of policemen surrounded the hotel at which the meeting took place, using cameras to closely monitor any movement, but no demonstrations took place.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exhibition of Lady's slipper orchids opens in Taipei

TEXT.P: An exhibition of Paphiopedilum orchids -- better known as Lady's slipper orchids -- opened at the National Museum of Natural Sciences in Taipei Friday and will run until April 26.

According to the Taiwan Paphiopedilum Society, the organizer of the event, the more than 200 pots of Lady's slipper orchids put on display at the exhibition include many that have won awards in competitions. They include the original species, the single-flower type, the multiflora type and the standard type.
The word Paphiopedilum was derived from the Greek word "Paphian," which refers to the Roman Goddess Venus, and "pedilon" which means slipper.

Kao Chi-ching, vice chairman of the Taiwan Paphiopedilum Society, said that Taiwan's orchid growers have cultivated about 3 million Lady's slipper orchids, most of which are locally developed species.
Kao said the Lady's slipper orchids are distinctive because their flowers are different from other orchids and that they appear in various shapes and colors.
He added that the award-winning orchids will remain on display until April 19, while the others, including many new hybrid Lady's slipper orchid species, will be on display until April 26.

The Lady's slipper orchids are also known in the United States as moccasin flowers. They are so named because of the flowers' slipper-shaped pouches. The pouch can trap insects in order to force them to climb up past the staminode, behind which they collect or deposit pollinia.

Lady's slipper orchids originated in the tropical and subtropical forests of Southeast Asia, including southern China, but over-collecting has caused the flowers to become rare and endangered in their original habitats.

The orchids bloom in a variety of colors ranging from white, maroon, yellow, red, pink, and green to nearly black. The color of the blooms may be solid, blended, striped or spotted. The flowers have a waxy texture, and can last six weeks or longer.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan makes breakthrough in new drug development

TEXT.P: Taiwan has developed a new drug for diabetes patients that will begin its first clinical trials on humans at a local medical center in 2010, marking the first drug ever to be developed on the island.

The National Health Research Institutes (NHRI) announced Friday that it has formed an alliance with six local pharmaceutical manufacturers to conduct investigational new drug trials on humans of its developed anti-diabetes drug, DPP-IV, at Taipei Veterans General Hospital (TVGH).

The alliance -- composed of Genovate Biotechnology, the Taipei-based China Chemical and Pharmaceutical Co., Nang Kuang Pharmaceutical, Yuan Shin Group, TTY Biopharm, and Taiwan Biotech -- recently obtained investment from the government's National Development Fund, according to the NHRI.

Chao Yu-sheng, director of the NHRI Division of Biotechnology and Pharmaceutical Research, estimated that the first- and second-stage clinical trials will require NT$200 million (US$5.9 million) , with the national fund to cover 85 percent of the cost and the alliance to take care of the rest.
TVGH will supervise the trials on humans, Chao noted.

Noting it will take 10-15 years and an investment of US$1 billion to get a new drug to the market, Chao added that the third stage of clinical trials for the DPP-IV inhibitor will be undertaken overseas.
At that point, the local pharmaceutical factories that have obtained the NHRI technology transfer might offer authorization to use the technology in exchange for further injections of capital.
Diabetes is considered to be the world's fourth top killer. In the global market, there are drugs developed by Merck and Novartis that have proven effective in treating Type 2 diabetes patients.
Chao, who led the DPP-IV inhibitor development, said he has discovered during animal tests that the chemical elements of the new drug are similar to that of the Merck drug, but the effect is better.
