DOC.HEADLINE: Search for missing crewmen of sunken fishing boat continues

TEXT.P: Taiwanese and Japanese coast guard personnel are still looking for two crew members of a Taiwanese fishing vessel that sank near the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands early Friday, a fishery official said Saturday.

The 99-ton Hsing Tong Chuan No. 86, based out of Suao in the northeastern county of Yilan, sank some 20 nautical miles west of the Tiaoyutai Islands after it was allegedly hit by a Panama-registered tanker, the official from the Fisheries Administration under the Council of Agriculture said.
Eleven of the 13 crew manning the vessel were rescued by fishing boats operating nearby, but the ship's captain, Ho Hsi-chuan, and chief engineer Hsu Chung-wen, were still missing.

According to officials from the Maritime Patrol Directorate General under the Coast Guard Administration, a Japanese diver combed the interior of the sunken ship Friday evening but did not find the two missing men.
Coast guard personnel from Taiwan and Japan will continue search operations during the 72-hour "golden time" for rescue, the officials said.
The officials said the 160,000-ton Panamanian tanker TOSA is suspected of having hit the Taiwanese fishing boat.

A Hualien coast guard vessel stopped the TOSA, but the tanker refused to put into Hualien Harbor on Taiwan's eastern coast for investigation and continued its voyage to Singapore, escorted by the coast guard vessel.
Coast guard officials said they will seek permission through diplomatic or other channels to board the tanker to look for evidence that it was involved in a collision.

Two other foreign ships -- the Fratzis Star of the Marshall Islands and the Hong Kong-registered CHS World -- were also stopped, but were allowed to continue after radar data showed that they were many miles away from the collision site at the time.

Ministry of Foreign Affairs officials said Japan had dispatched five fast boats, two helicopters and three divers to assist in the search and rescue mission, while four Taiwanese coast guard ships and helicopters from the National Airborne Service Corps were also mobilized.
The rescued Hsing Tong Chuan crew members include one Taiwanese fisherman, two Chinese, six Indonesians and two Filipinos.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan offers loans to Salvadoran shrimp breeders
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, April 17 (CNA) 04/18/09 15:55:31 (By Huang Kwang-chun and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan announced Friday the launch of a program to issue small loans to fishermen in El Salvador to help them turn salt fields along the eastern coast of their country into shrimp farms.

Republic of China Ambassador to El Salvador Carlos S.C. Liao and Salvadoran Agriculture Ministry Mario Ernesto Salaverria hosted a ceremony at a fishery station in eastern El Salvador to mark the launch of the loans, which will total US$100,000.

In addition to the financial support, a Taiwanese technical mission in El Salvador will also teach local breeders how to cultivate shrimp and increase output, according to a statement by the ROC embassy in El Salvador.

It has been estimated that the loans will benefit 320 fishermen and help increase their local shrimp output to 66 tons per year. The annual production value is assessed at US$270,000, which will produce a net annual income of US$150,000 for the breeders, the statement said.
On Friday, Salaverria expressed gratitude for the financial support, saying that Taiwan has helped his country a great deal in terms of agricultural development.

Taiwanese technical missions have over the years not only helped local farmers grow vegetables and fruit but have also assisted them in establishing irrigation systems and promoting marketing, Liao said.

With the new Salvadoran government set to assume office June 1, Liao promised that Taiwan will continue to initiate plans in line with its agricultural policies to help El Salvador's sustainable development.

The Central American country is one of 23 that maintain diplomatic ties with Taiwan. In 2008, Taiwanese exports there reached US$89.71 million, while imports from El Salvador amounted to US$20.09 million.
President Ma Ying-jeou is planning to visit El Salvador in June to attend the inauguration of President-elect Mauricio Funes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bike touring in Taiwan emerges as red-hot niche travel deal

TEXT.P: Cycling around Taiwan has emerged as a popular travel package for visitors from China and other countries, tourism industry sources said Saturday.

On Friday, a 19-member Chinese tour group completed a seven-day, 1,200-km bike tour around Taiwan, with all the members describing the journey as an unforgettable and enthralling experience when they reached their final destination -- Danshui on the outskirts of Taipei City.
The group was the first from China to make the round-Taiwan bike trip since the Chinese government formally began allowing its people to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan last July.

Chen Miaolin, vice president of the China Tourism Association, told local reporters that he was very impressed by the spectacular sunset ocean scenery when he arrived at Eluanbi on Taiwan's southernmost coast on the third day of the tour.
"Standing looking out over the Bashi Channel, I was too excited to control myself from exalting `how beautiful is the treasure island of Taiwan,'" Chen recalled.
Most of the other members of the group were senior executives of a noted four- star tourist hotel chain in China.
According to Chen, they spent more than a year planning the NT$100,000 (US$2,994 )-per-person bike tour package in collaboration with Taiwanese travel agents.

Each member was provided with a high-end bicycle and other necessary accessories by Taiwan's famous bicycle company Giant Manufacturing Co. after their arrival aboard a direct cross-Taiwan Strait charter flight earlier this month. A team of technicians also escorted the group on its journey.
"All the group members were satisfied with the arrangements, praising the deal as `worth more than the price' and as an easy and healthy travel experience," Chen said.
When the group cycled past South Bay on the Kenting National Park coastline, many members jumped into the sea and swam for more than an hour, enjoying the magnificent beach scenery, Chen went on.

Yeh Zhou, a 50-year-old cycling fan, said the feelings he experienced cycling along Taiwan's coastline were even deeper than the movement he felt when he cycled from Hangzhou in southeastern China to the capital city of Beijing last year.
In his view, Yeh said, Taiwan's cycle trails are far better and far more beautiful than those in many other places around the world.
Tsai Ching, a local travel industry representative who accompanied the group, said at least 30 other Chinese tour groups are lining up for similar around-Taiwan bike trips later this year.
Moreover, he went on, quite a few cyclists from Japan, the United States and Europe are also coming to Taiwan to enjoy the thrill of cycling on Taiwan's beautiful roads.
Tsai also said that a group of bicycle dealers from Denmark are scheduled to come to Taiwan late this year for a cycling trip and to appraise the market potential of organizing package tours.

Giant President Ho You-jen said cycle tours of Taiwan have emerged as a popular travel package in the global tourist community, adding that many tourists also purchase Taiwan-made bicycles after concluding their tours. He added that cycle touring is expected to create NT$1 billion-worth of business opportunities per year for the local tourism industry.
Ho said his company will cooperate with local air carriers to bring cycling fans from around the world to Taiwan to experience the enjyoment of cycling here.

DOC.HEADLINE: Launch of regular cross-strait flights might help lower fares

TEXT.P: The daily charter flights between Taiwan and China inaugurated four months ago have attracted severe criticism, with detractors complaining about excessive pricing, but the opening of regular flights, expected later this year, is raising hopes of cheaper fares.

The issue is one of the major items on the agenda of the latest round of cross- Taiwan Strait negotiations taking place Saturday in Taipei, with the official signing of an agreement expected April 26 during talks in Nanjing between Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and his Chinese counterpart, Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits President Chen Yunlin.

According to Lee Long-wen, director-general of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) , upgrading the charter services to regularly scheduled services will mean an increase in supply, while the increased cargo capacity provided by regular passenger flights will also help lower operating costs, leaving room for carriers to reduce ticket prices.
Yeh Yung-ching, director of the CAA's Air Transport Division, said the rate of decrease will depend on how many flights are offered.

"Usually, ticket prices are in inverse proportion to the number of flights available, " Yeh said. "However, if there is only a limited increase in the number of flights, with demand still exceeding supply, it will not be easy for prices to be reduced."
Local carriers have proposed that the number of flights should at least be tripled to meet demand.

The daily charter services launched last Dec. 15 provide up to 108 flight per week at present -- 54 by Taiwanese carriers and another 54 by Chinese carriers -- and have recorded an average passenger load factor of nearly 90 percent.
Of the 21 Chinese destinations served by the flights, Shanghai remains the most popular, with 40 flights to and from Taiwan per week.
The next-most popular are flights serving Hangzhou, Beijing and Shenzhen, which have 12 to 14 flights per week, followed by Guangzhou, which has eight flights per week.

The other 16 destinations -- Chengdu, Chongqing, Dalian, Guilin, Wuhan, Fuzhou, Qingdao, Changsha, Haikou, Kunming, Xian, Shenyang, Tianjin and Zhengzhou, Xiamen and Nanjing -- see between one and three flights per week, although some have only one flight every several weeks.

The popularity of the charter services is due largely to their convenience and short travel time as compared to regular flight services for which transit is required through a third area such as Hong Kong or Macau.
For example, the charter flight between Taipei and Shanghai take less than 90 minutes, while it takes nearly six hours to travel via Hong Kong.
The shorter travel distance, however, has not resulted in lower fares.

According to a report released April 14 by the Consumers' Foundation, economic- class, round-trip charter flight tickets valid for 30 days between Taipei and Shanghai cost NT$13,776 (US$411) on average in April -- 40 percent more expensive than the flights via Hong Kong, which cost NT$9,844 on average.
Despite such high prices, there are hardly any empty seats on the charter flights.

Ticket agent Lin Ko-pen pointed out that most consumers, many of whom are business people operating in China, do not care about the price as long as they can get a seat, especially those with urgent travel needs.
"A customer came to me April 10 asking for a one-way ticket departing April 12 from Taipei to Shanghai. The ticket cost NT$14,000, but he bought it anyway," Lin said.

The recent influx of Chinese tourists to Taiwan is also helping to keep the cross-strait charter service extremely busy, with the number of daily arrivals rising to nearly 3,000 per day in the first half of April since tourism groups in various Chinese provinces launched a "10,000 people travel to Taiwan" campaign in February to promote Taiwan tours.

According to travel agent Chen Shih-chieh, almost 50 percent of the weekly quota of 108 flights are being used for popular destinations such as Shanghai, Hangzhou and Beijing, making flights very difficult to book for other destinations.
"Chengdu, where there are many Taiwanese businessmen, has only one flight per week, making reservations for travel tours no easy task," he said.
Airline companies in Taiwan have suggested that the number of charter flights should be expanded before the regular service is launched.
The regular services should at first target only popular destinations such as Shanghai, while charter flight services should continue for other destinations for which demand is lower, they proposed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Third round of cross-strait talks to open April 26 in Nanjing

TEXT.P: A third round of talks between the top negotiators of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , is set to open April 26 in Nanjing, high- level officials from either side of the Taiwan Strait announced Saturday.

Kao Koong-lian, vice chairman and secretary-general of the quasi-official SEF, and ARATS Vice President Zheng Lizhong, made the announcement in separate press conferences at the conclusion of a day-long joint preparatory session in Taipei.
"We have reached consensus on many issues, which I believe will lay a great foundation for the third round of talks," Kao said.

According to Kao, the SEF delegation is scheduled to arrive in Nanjing April 25 aboard a direct charter flight and there will be another preparatory meeting that same afternoon to finalize the details of the talks.

He said the third round of talks between SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and ARATS President Chen Yunlin will officially open April 26 with four major topics on the agenda -- regularly scheduled cross-strait flights to augment the existing charter services, financial cooperation, tackling cross-strait crime and providing legal assistance, and opening Taiwan to investment from China.

Chiang and Chen are expected to sign agreements on the first three issues that afternoon, while a decision by both sides on what to do about the issue of opening Taiwan to Chinese capital should be revealed after the meeting, Kao added.

Chiang will later meet with Wang Yi, director of the China State Council's Taiwan Affairs Office, and will visit Taiwanese businessmen based in Yangzhou, Suzhou, Kunshan and Shanghai before returning to Taiwan April 29, he said.

On the issue of launching regularly scheduled flights, the SEF vice chairman said the Chiang-Chen talks will discuss the launch of a new flight route that he said would be more convenient for travelers on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, but he did not elaborate.

As to the issue of cracking down on cross-strait crime and the provision of legal assistance, the agreement expected to be signed will include a clause concerning the repatriation of economic criminals, Kao went on, adding that this is a category that was missed out in the Kinmen Agreement signed in 1990 by the Red Cross Societies of Taiwan and China for extraditing criminals and suspects who flee across the strait to escape justice.

Asked whether the hotly discussed issue of Taiwan signing an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China will be touched upon in the third round of Chiang-Chen talks and be included formally on the agenda of a fourth round of talks scheduled for the end of the year, Kao did not answer directly, saying only that Taiwan and China should be able to start discussing the issue at some point in the future when the time is ripe but that at present, both sides can only make separate preparatory efforts.

Zheng said in an earlier press conference that signing a comprehensive trade pact with Taiwan will facilitate the establishment of a cross-strait economic cooperation mechanism beneficial to both economies.

"Both sides of the Taiwan Strait are adopting a proactive attitude on the issue and are trying to create (favorable) conditions for it step by step, " Zheng said, adding that "We should proceed to discuss the issue when conditions are ripe."

Taiwan has great interest in singing an ECFA with China, as the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou thinks such an economic pact would not only help normalize relations with China but would also prevent Taiwan's marginalization in the process of China's economic integration with other countries in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lou Gehrig's disease fighter publishes sixth book

TEXT.P: Chen Hung, a patient suffering from a neurological and muscle wasting disease, released Saturday the sixth in a series of his books that have been "written" by blinking his eyes.

Chen's wife, Liu Hsueh-hui, told a book launch party held in Taipei that like the previous five, the publication of this latest book, "An Easy Fish in Shallow Water, " involved no easy task, but he insisted on doing it because writing is one of his favorite.
"He is trying to encourage other patients suffering from the same disease as himself and those with other rare diseases," Liu said.

Also attending the party, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said the way Chen faces his life allows the public to see the infinite possibilities of life and to learn to adopt a positive and optimistic attitude toward life.

Chen, who began to have trouble walking in 1997, was diagnosed in 1999 to have amyotrophic lateral sclerosis or motor neuron disease (ALS/MND) , a condition that affect some 350,000 people around the world, and kills more than 100,000 each year.
Also known as Lou Gehring's disease, ALS/MND leads to symptoms such as muscle weakness and stiffness. The cause of the disease is unknown and there is no cure.
The disease did not defeat Chen, although now he can only communicate with the outside world by blinking his eyes.
Chen began to "write" books with the help of his wife, blinking his eyes to represent Chinese phonetic symbols, and published in 2002 his first book since suffering from the disease.
In 2007, he was certified by the Guinness World Records for "the record for most blinked words published" -- 190,185 -- between 1999 and 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nanjing talks to touch on principles of opening to Chinese capital

TEXT.P: A vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Council Affairs (MAC) said Saturday that the upcoming third round of talks between the top cross-Taiwan Strait negotiators on both sides will only address the general principles of allowing Chinese investment in Taiwan.

"The final statement, expected to be issued after the talks, will illustrate only the principles rather than specific categories to be opened to Chinese investment, " said Fu Tung-cheng in response to an inquiry from CNA after a one- day preparatory session for the third round of talks.

The talks between Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , will open April 26 in Nanjing and will discuss four issues -- regularly scheduled cross-strait flights, financial cooperation, tackling cross-strait crime and providing legal assistance, and opening Taiwan to investment from China.
According to Fu, both sides have agreed to include the issue of opening to Chinese investment on the agenda but will not make any resolution on it due to the complexity of the subject.

As opening Taiwan to investment from Chinese banks, securities and insurance institutions involves professional operations, it will be included in the discussions on cross-strait financial cooperation, Fu went on, adding that it will fall under the purview of the Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission.
The MAC, which coordinates Taiwan's policy toward China, oversees SEF operations.
Saturday's preparatory session in Taipei was attended by Kao Koong-lian, vice chairman and secretary-general of the SEF, and his Chinese counterpart, ARATS vice president Zheng Lizhong.

A dinner party was thrown in Zheng's honor later that evening in which he expressed gratitude for the SEF's hospitality and wished everyone good health, speaking in the Fukien dialect that is widely used in Taiwan.
He also sang a Puyuma aboriginal ballad titled "We All Belong to the Same Family" in Mandarin.
He was scheduled to leave along with his delegation the following day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tung blossoms spread snow-white warmth over Taiwan

TEXT.P: The 2009 Hakka Tung Blossom Festival kicked off in Miaoli County Saturday with a ceremony that was attended by Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, along with Council for Hakka Affairs Minister Huang Yu-cheng, Miaoli Magistrate Liu Cheng-hung and Wu Po-hsiung, honorary chairman of the World Hakka Federation and also chairman of the ruling Kuomintang.

The festival opened with the performance of a tung blossom dance at a village resort in the county, organized by the Cabinet-level Council for Hakka Affairs to celebrate the fall of what is popularly known as "April Snow" or "May snow" because of the way the fallen blossoms carpet the ground.

Liu noted that the tung blossom festival has become a significant annual event for the Hakka people and he invited the public to appreciate the clean-white beauty of the tung flowers at a slow pace and to taste the rich culture the Hakka people have created.

According to the council, 10 county and city governments, as well as 45 civic groups, have organized 100 activities around northern and central Taiwan to allow the public to experience local cultures and lifestyles while appreciating the beauty of the tung flowers.
The festival, now in its eighth year, is organized by the council to promote a culture industry centered on the Hakka, an ethnic group known for its diligence, frugality and hospitality.

Attracted by increasing trade opportunities in the unique culture industry, which covers the fields of tourism, ecological conservation, local cuisine and creative handicraft production, more and more local governments have become involved in organizing festival celebrations and this year, Yilan County, Keelung City, Taipei County, Taoyuan County, Hsinchu County, Miaoli County, Taichung County, Changhua County, Yunlin County and Nantou County have all prepared tung blossom appreciation activities to attract visitors.

Huang said the tung blossoms have also drawn the attention of foreign tourists over the years, adding that this year, the council has placed advertisements at airports in Tokyo and Beijing in the hope of attracting more visitors to Hakka villages in Taiwan.
In addition, it has also prepared free tour brochures providing information about the events in the 2009 Hakka Tung Blossom Festival that will run through May 17, he went on.
The information, including maps of the best places for tung blossom appreciation, is also available on the council's Web site at http://tung.hakka.gov.tw.

April and May are the months when the tung trees are in full bloom in central and northern Taiwan and the white flowers have become a symbol of the Hakka people. Every year, the flowering season is celebrated in Hakka villages with traditional music and song, coupled with the consumption of Hakka delicacies.

The Hakka originally lived in central China but gradually migrated south during different dynasties and settled in Jiangxi, Fujian and Guangdong provinces, as well as in Taiwan, after fleeing from war and famine, where they become known in Chinese as literally "guest people."

A 2008 survey by the council found that Taiwan's Hakka people, using a broad definition of the term, accounts for 25.6 percent of the country's total population. The first wave of migrants came from China to Taiwan in the 1690s, when China was under the rule of the Qing Dynasty.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese delegates meet with Chinese premier at Boao Forum

TEXT.P: The Taiwanese delegation attending the 2009 Boao Forum for Asia met with Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao Saturday on the sidelines of the event, which formally opened that day in the southern Chinese island province of Hainan.

In his brief welcoming remarks at the meeting, which was opened to reporters for just five minutes, Wen urged the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to "face the future, bury old grudges, cooperate with each other and move forward together "and called for them to seize the present opportunity to achieve peace in the strait.

Not every member of the Taiwanese delegation of academics and business leaders attended the meeting with Wen, but 10 of them, including the delegation head -- former Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien -- his wife Julie Chien, Cross- Strait Common Market Foundation Chairman Chan Hou-sheng and foundation director- in-chief Douglas Hung were present.

Chien has previously served as foreign minister and as Taiwan's representative to the United States and his meeting with Wen drew Taiwanese media attention. He is attending the forum in the capacity of the senior advisor of the non-profit Cross-Strait Common Market Foundation.

In response to Wen's call, Chien said he noticed that Wen proposed the ideas of seeking "peaceful development" between the two sides and boosting cross-strait cooperation in the fields of trade, the economy and investment, in a report he made March 5 to the annual session of the National People's Congress, China's parliament.
After Chien had finished making his remarks, the meeting was closed to reporters.

The April 17-19 forum is a non-government, non-profit international organization and its annual conferences gather leaders in government, business and academia in Asia and other continents to share their visions on the most pressing issues in the region and the world at large.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet-sponsored job fairs help more than 11,000 find jobs

TEXT.P: Two government-sponsored job fairs in northern and southern Taiwan Saturday helped more than 11,000 people landed jobs, Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) officials said that same day.

The job fairs were two in a series of four such events organized by the Cabinet- level council to help trim unemployed population as the country's jobless rate surged to a record 5.75 percent in February.
Initial statistics showed that the job fair in Taoyuan county in northern Taiwan attracted 41,078 visitors and 11,368 of them applied for various job vacancies provided by public and private sectors.
About 27 percent of those applicants, or 3,031 of the total, successfully found jobs, the CLA officials said.
Meanwhile, 1,042, or 20.46 percent of the 5,093 applicants, found internship at private enterprises or research positions at various local universities.
As to the job fair in Tainan in the south, 24.54 percent of the 18,873 applicants succeeded in landing positions, the officials said.

While attending the opening ceremony for the job fair in Taoyuan Saturday, President Ma Ying-jeou encouraged jobless people, including those who became out of work during the recent global economic downturn, not to lose self-confidence.
He also promised that his administration will do whatever it can to create jobs, saying that the economic stimulus package launched this year will help create 190,000 to 220,000 job openings.
Two similar job fairs were held in central and eastern Taiwan last weekend, with a slightly higher success rate of about 30 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan can do something for China: ex-official

TEXT.P: Taiwan can do something for China, particularly in charitable services for disadvantaged groups of people, Taiwan's top representative to the 2009 Boao Forum told Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao Saturday.

Fredrick Chien, a former president of the Control Yuan who also once served as Taiwan's minister of foreign affairs and representative to the United States, met with Wen on the sidelines of the annual international forum of government officials and business leaders in China's southern island province of Hainan.
Only the first few minutes of the Chien-Wen meeting was open for media coverage while the remaining part of their talks were held behind the closed door.
Chien told reporters after his longer-than-expected talks with Wen that he came up with several proposals in his capacity as a Taiwanese citizen, not as a representative of Taiwan's government.

According to Chien, he told Wen that Taiwan's Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation is planning to build a new community in Indonesia that will comprise a mixture of hospitals, factories, schools and housing units to accommodate 4,000 households in a slum.
In the Tzu Chi project, the Indonesian slum will also be developed into a tourist attraction.

Chien, who is attending the Boao Forum as the top adviser to the Taipei-based Cross-Strait Common Market Foundation, said he had received a positive reply from Tzu Chi that it is willing to mount a similar project in China.
In addition, Chien said some Taiwanese civic groups are help with restoration of the ancient Loulan Castle in China's Xinjiang Province.

Responding to Wen's remarks at the beginning of their talks that the two sides of the Taiwan Straits are connected at the roots and share the same blood, Chien said he noticed that Wen advocated the ideas of seeking cross-strait "peaceful development" and boosting bilateral engagements on an equal footing, in his March 5 report to the National People's Congress, China's parliament.

Based on Wen's such proposals, Chien told Wen that he looks forward to seeing China help Taiwan realize its goal of attracting 1 million Chinese tourists a year and purchase electric home appliances to help Taiwanese makers ride out the current global economic recession.

In an apparent effort to allay some Taiwan's pro-independence groups' apprehensions that he might represent President Ma Ying-jeou to broach the proposal of signing a cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) , Chien said he didn't mention throughout his talks with Wen anything about such topics or issues regarding Taiwan's desire to join the "ASEAN Plus 3" regional economic integration.
The Taiwanese delegation to the 2009 Boao Forum is composed of 30-plus academics, bankers and business executives.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan offers loans to Salvadoran shrimp breeders
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, April 17 (CNA) 04/18/09 15:55:31 (By Huang Kwang-chun and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan announced Friday the launch of a program to issue small loans to fishermen in El Salvador to help them turn salt fields along the eastern coast of their country into shrimp farms.

Republic of China Ambassador to El Salvador Carlos S.C. Liao and Salvadoran Agriculture Ministry Mario Ernesto Salaverria hosted a ceremony at a fishery station in eastern El Salvador to mark the launch of the loans, which will total US$100,000.

In addition to the financial support, a Taiwanese technical mission in El Salvador will also teach local breeders how to cultivate shrimp and increase output, according to a statement by the ROC embassy in El Salvador.

It has been estimated that the loans will benefit 320 fishermen and help increase their local shrimp output to 66 tons per year. The annual production value is assessed at US$270,000, which will produce a net annual income of US$150,000 for the breeders, the statement said.
On Friday, Salaverria expressed gratitude for the financial support, saying that Taiwan has helped his country a great deal in terms of agricultural development.

Taiwanese technical missions have over the years not only helped local farmers grow vegetables and fruit but have also assisted them in establishing irrigation systems and promoting marketing, Liao said.

With the new Salvadoran government set to assume office June 1, Liao promised that Taiwan will continue to initiate plans in line with its agricultural policies to help El Salvador's sustainable development.

The Central American country is one of 23 that maintain diplomatic ties with Taiwan. In 2008, Taiwanese exports there reached US$89.71 million, while imports from El Salvador amounted to US$20.09 million.
President Ma Ying-jeou is planning to visit El Salvador in June to attend the inauguration of President-elect Mauricio Funes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bike touring in Taiwan emerges as red-hot niche travel deal

TEXT.P: Cycling around Taiwan has emerged as a popular travel package for visitors from China and other countries, tourism industry sources said Saturday.

On Friday, a 19-member Chinese tour group completed a seven-day, 1,200-km bike tour around Taiwan, with all the members describing the journey as an unforgettable and enthralling experience when they reached their final destination -- Danshui on the outskirts of Taipei City.
The group was the first from China to make the round-Taiwan bike trip since the Chinese government formally began allowing its people to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan last July.

Chen Miaolin, vice president of the China Tourism Association, told local reporters that he was very impressed by the spectacular sunset ocean scenery when he arrived at Eluanbi on Taiwan's southernmost coast on the third day of the tour.
"Standing looking out over the Bashi Channel, I was too excited to control myself from exalting `how beautiful is the treasure island of Taiwan,'" Chen recalled.
Most of the other members of the group were senior executives of a noted four- star tourist hotel chain in China.
According to Chen, they spent more than a year planning the NT$100,000 (US$2,994 )-per-person bike tour package in collaboration with Taiwanese travel agents.

Each member was provided with a high-end bicycle and other necessary accessories by Taiwan's famous bicycle company Giant Manufacturing Co. after their arrival aboard a direct cross-Taiwan Strait charter flight earlier this month. A team of technicians also escorted the group on its journey.
"All the group members were satisfied with the arrangements, praising the deal as `worth more than the price' and as an easy and healthy travel experience," Chen said.
When the group cycled past South Bay on the Kenting National Park coastline, many members jumped into the sea and swam for more than an hour, enjoying the magnificent beach scenery, Chen went on.

Yeh Zhou, a 50-year-old cycling fan, said the feelings he experienced cycling along Taiwan's coastline were even deeper than the movement he felt when he cycled from Hangzhou in southeastern China to the capital city of Beijing last year.
In his view, Yeh said, Taiwan's cycle trails are far better and far more beautiful than those in many other places around the world.
Tsai Ching, a local travel industry representative who accompanied the group, said at least 30 other Chinese tour groups are lining up for similar around-Taiwan bike trips later this year.
Moreover, he went on, quite a few cyclists from Japan, the United States and Europe are also coming to Taiwan to enjoy the thrill of cycling on Taiwan's beautiful roads.
Tsai also said that a group of bicycle dealers from Denmark are scheduled to come to Taiwan late this year for a cycling trip and to appraise the market potential of organizing package tours.

Giant President Ho You-jen said cycle tours of Taiwan have emerged as a popular travel package in the global tourist community, adding that many tourists also purchase Taiwan-made bicycles after concluding their tours. He added that cycle touring is expected to create NT$1 billion-worth of business opportunities per year for the local tourism industry.
Ho said his company will cooperate with local air carriers to bring cycling fans from around the world to Taiwan to experience the enjyoment of cycling here.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nanjing talks to touch on principles of opening to Chinese capital

TEXT.P: A vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Council Affairs (MAC) said Saturday that the upcoming third round of talks between the top cross-Taiwan Strait negotiators on both sides will only address the general principles of allowing Chinese investment in Taiwan.

"The final statement, expected to be issued after the talks, will illustrate only the principles rather than specific categories to be opened to Chinese investment, " said Fu Tung-cheng in response to an inquiry from CNA after a one- day preparatory session for the third round of talks.

The talks between Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , will open April 26 in Nanjing and will discuss four issues -- regularly scheduled cross-strait flights, financial cooperation, tackling cross-strait crime and providing legal assistance, and opening Taiwan to investment from China.
According to Fu, both sides have agreed to include the issue of opening to Chinese investment on the agenda but will not make any resolution on it due to the complexity of the subject.

As opening Taiwan to investment from Chinese banks, securities and insurance institutions involves professional operations, it will be included in the discussions on cross-strait financial cooperation, Fu went on, adding that it will fall under the purview of the Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission.
The MAC, which coordinates Taiwan's policy toward China, oversees SEF operations.
Saturday's preparatory session in Taipei was attended by Kao Koong-lian, vice chairman and secretary-general of the SEF, and his Chinese counterpart, ARATS vice president Zheng Lizhong.

A dinner party was thrown in Zheng's honor later that evening in which he expressed gratitude for the SEF's hospitality and wished everyone good health, speaking in the Fukien dialect that is widely used in Taiwan.
He also sang a Puyuma aboriginal ballad titled "We All Belong to the Same Family" in Mandarin.
He was scheduled to leave along with his delegation the following day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tung blossoms spread snow-white warmth over Taiwan

TEXT.P: The 2009 Hakka Tung Blossom Festival kicked off in Miaoli County Saturday with a ceremony that was attended by Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, along with Council for Hakka Affairs Minister Huang Yu-cheng, Miaoli Magistrate Liu Cheng-hung and Wu Po-hsiung, honorary chairman of the World Hakka Federation and also chairman of the ruling Kuomintang.

The festival opened with the performance of a tung blossom dance at a village resort in the county, organized by the Cabinet-level Council for Hakka Affairs to celebrate the fall of what is popularly known as "April Snow" or "May snow" because of the way the fallen blossoms carpet the ground.

Liu noted that the tung blossom festival has become a significant annual event for the Hakka people and he invited the public to appreciate the clean-white beauty of the tung flowers at a slow pace and to taste the rich culture the Hakka people have created.

According to the council, 10 county and city governments, as well as 45 civic groups, have organized 100 activities around northern and central Taiwan to allow the public to experience local cultures and lifestyles while appreciating the beauty of the tung flowers.
The festival, now in its eighth year, is organized by the council to promote a culture industry centered on the Hakka, an ethnic group known for its diligence, frugality and hospitality.

Attracted by increasing trade opportunities in the unique culture industry, which covers the fields of tourism, ecological conservation, local cuisine and creative handicraft production, more and more local governments have become involved in organizing festival celebrations and this year, Yilan County, Keelung City, Taipei County, Taoyuan County, Hsinchu County, Miaoli County, Taichung County, Changhua County, Yunlin County and Nantou County have all prepared tung blossom appreciation activities to attract visitors.

Huang said the tung blossoms have also drawn the attention of foreign tourists over the years, adding that this year, the council has placed advertisements at airports in Tokyo and Beijing in the hope of attracting more visitors to Hakka villages in Taiwan.
In addition, it has also prepared free tour brochures providing information about the events in the 2009 Hakka Tung Blossom Festival that will run through May 17, he went on.
The information, including maps of the best places for tung blossom appreciation, is also available on the council's Web site at http://tung.hakka.gov.tw.

April and May are the months when the tung trees are in full bloom in central and northern Taiwan and the white flowers have become a symbol of the Hakka people. Every year, the flowering season is celebrated in Hakka villages with traditional music and song, coupled with the consumption of Hakka delicacies.

The Hakka originally lived in central China but gradually migrated south during different dynasties and settled in Jiangxi, Fujian and Guangdong provinces, as well as in Taiwan, after fleeing from war and famine, where they become known in Chinese as literally "guest people."

A 2008 survey by the council found that Taiwan's Hakka people, using a broad definition of the term, accounts for 25.6 percent of the country's total population. The first wave of migrants came from China to Taiwan in the 1690s, when China was under the rule of the Qing Dynasty.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese delegates meet with Chinese premier at Boao Forum

TEXT.P: The Taiwanese delegation attending the 2009 Boao Forum for Asia met with Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao Saturday on the sidelines of the event, which formally opened that day in the southern Chinese island province of Hainan.

In his brief welcoming remarks at the meeting, which was opened to reporters for just five minutes, Wen urged the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to "face the future, bury old grudges, cooperate with each other and move forward together "and called for them to seize the present opportunity to achieve peace in the strait.

Not every member of the Taiwanese delegation of academics and business leaders attended the meeting with Wen, but 10 of them, including the delegation head -- former Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien -- his wife Julie Chien, Cross- Strait Common Market Foundation Chairman Chan Hou-sheng and foundation director- in-chief Douglas Hung were present.

Chien has previously served as foreign minister and as Taiwan's representative to the United States and his meeting with Wen drew Taiwanese media attention. He is attending the forum in the capacity of the senior advisor of the non-profit Cross-Strait Common Market Foundation.

In response to Wen's call, Chien said he noticed that Wen proposed the ideas of seeking "peaceful development" between the two sides and boosting cross-strait cooperation in the fields of trade, the economy and investment, in a report he made March 5 to the annual session of the National People's Congress, China's parliament.
After Chien had finished making his remarks, the meeting was closed to reporters.

The April 17-19 forum is a non-government, non-profit international organization and its annual conferences gather leaders in government, business and academia in Asia and other continents to share their visions on the most pressing issues in the region and the world at large.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet-sponsored job fairs help more than 11,000 find jobs

TEXT.P: Two government-sponsored job fairs in northern and southern Taiwan Saturday helped more than 11,000 people landed jobs, Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) officials said that same day.

The job fairs were two in a series of four such events organized by the Cabinet- level council to help trim unemployed population as the country's jobless rate surged to a record 5.75 percent in February.
Initial statistics showed that the job fair in Taoyuan county in northern Taiwan attracted 41,078 visitors and 11,368 of them applied for various job vacancies provided by public and private sectors.
About 27 percent of those applicants, or 3,031 of the total, successfully found jobs, the CLA officials said.
Meanwhile, 1,042, or 20.46 percent of the 5,093 applicants, found internship at private enterprises or research positions at various local universities.
As to the job fair in Tainan in the south, 24.54 percent of the 18,873 applicants succeeded in landing positions, the officials said.

While attending the opening ceremony for the job fair in Taoyuan Saturday, President Ma Ying-jeou encouraged jobless people, including those who became out of work during the recent global economic downturn, not to lose self-confidence.
He also promised that his administration will do whatever it can to create jobs, saying that the economic stimulus package launched this year will help create 190,000 to 220,000 job openings.
Two similar job fairs were held in central and eastern Taiwan last weekend, with a slightly higher success rate of about 30 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan can do something for China: ex-official

TEXT.P: Taiwan can do something for China, particularly in charitable services for disadvantaged groups of people, Taiwan's top representative to the 2009 Boao Forum told Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao Saturday.

Fredrick Chien, a former president of the Control Yuan who also once served as Taiwan's minister of foreign affairs and representative to the United States, met with Wen on the sidelines of the annual international forum of government officials and business leaders in China's southern island province of Hainan.
Only the first few minutes of the Chien-Wen meeting was open for media coverage while the remaining part of their talks were held behind the closed door.
Chien told reporters after his longer-than-expected talks with Wen that he came up with several proposals in his capacity as a Taiwanese citizen, not as a representative of Taiwan's government.

According to Chien, he told Wen that Taiwan's Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation is planning to build a new community in Indonesia that will comprise a mixture of hospitals, factories, schools and housing units to accommodate 4,000 households in a slum.
In the Tzu Chi project, the Indonesian slum will also be developed into a tourist attraction.

Chien, who is attending the Boao Forum as the top adviser to the Taipei-based Cross-Strait Common Market Foundation, said he had received a positive reply from Tzu Chi that it is willing to mount a similar project in China.
In addition, Chien said some Taiwanese civic groups are help with restoration of the ancient Loulan Castle in China's Xinjiang Province.

Responding to Wen's remarks at the beginning of their talks that the two sides of the Taiwan Straits are connected at the roots and share the same blood, Chien said he noticed that Wen advocated the ideas of seeking cross-strait "peaceful development" and boosting bilateral engagements on an equal footing, in his March 5 report to the National People's Congress, China's parliament.

Based on Wen's such proposals, Chien told Wen that he looks forward to seeing China help Taiwan realize its goal of attracting 1 million Chinese tourists a year and purchase electric home appliances to help Taiwanese makers ride out the current global economic recession.

In an apparent effort to allay some Taiwan's pro-independence groups' apprehensions that he might represent President Ma Ying-jeou to broach the proposal of signing a cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) , Chien said he didn't mention throughout his talks with Wen anything about such topics or issues regarding Taiwan's desire to join the "ASEAN Plus 3" regional economic integration.
The Taiwanese delegation to the 2009 Boao Forum is composed of 30-plus academics, bankers and business executives.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 19, or the 24th day of the third month of the Year of Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1832: Jose Echegaray y Eizaguirre, Spanish dramatist, mathematician, statesman and Nobel laureate, is born.
1853: Russia claims to be the protectorate of Turkey in a prelude to the Crimean War.
1882: British naturalist Charles Darwin dies at the age of 73. He revolutionized the study of biology with his theory of evolution based on natural selection. His most famous works include "Origin of Species" and "The Descent of Man."
1906: French chemist and physicist Pierre Curie is run over and killed in Paris at the age of 47. He and his wife Marie shared the 1903 Nobel Prize for fundamental research into radioactivity.
1928: Japanese troops occupy Shantung Province in northern China.
1942: Chinese Expeditionary Forces led by Gen. Sun Li-jen capture Yenangyuang in northern Burma, rescuing more than 7,000 British and Burmese troops from Japanese encirclement.
1948: The first National Assembly elects Chiang Kai-shek as the Republic of China's first president under the new ROC Constitution, garnering 2,430 out of 2,704 votes.
1956: Prince Rainier of Monaco marries American screen actress Grace Kelly in Monte Carlo. Over 1,200 guests attend the televised Catholic wedding ceremony.
1959: The Dalai Lama, the Tibetan leader fleeing a Communist Chinese invasion of his country, finds sanctuary in India.
1960: South Korean President Syngman Rhee is toppled in a nationwide pro- democracy student uprising that was protesting election fraud.
1966: Australian troops leave Sydney to join American forces in Vietnam.
1974: The Blood Donation Association of the Republic of China is inaugurated.
1975: India's first satellite is launched by a Soviet rocket.
1977: ROC Education Minister Tsiang Yien-si resigns to take responsibility for an incident in which 32 college students and teachers were killed when their boat capsized near Suao Port in eastern Taiwan. Tsiang was succeeded by Li Yuan- zu.
1992: Dutch Minister of Foreign Trade Yvonne van Rooy visits Taipei to seek stronger bilateral relations.
1993: A total of 87 Branch Davidian cult members, including their leader David Koresh, are killed when federal agents storm their compound in Waco, Texas, after a 51-day standoff. Nine other members are freed.
1995: A huge truck bomb destroys the Alfred P. Murrah government building in Oklahoma City, killing 168 people and injuring more than 400 others.
1995: Malawi President Bakili Muluzi pays a state visit to Taipei.
1997: The S.S. Sheng Da, a mainland China container freighter, steams into Kaohsiung Port on its maiden voyage, becoming the first ship to sail directly to Taiwan from the mainland in 48 years, and completing a historic crossing of one of the world's great political divides.
1999: Tsai Shun-fa, 52, known as "Bean Curd Papa," is honored by Premier Vincent Siew for donating blood 495 times over 20 years.
1999: The Republic of China-Swaziland Conference on Economical and Technological Cooperation opens in Taipei.
2000: Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Taipei-based Chinese National Association of Industry & Commerce, says that if Beijing bullies Taiwanese doing business in mainland China, it will hurt both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
2000: President-elect Chen Shui-bian promises that his administration will help the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau transform itself into a "National Bureau of Investigation."
2001: Former ROC Premier Vincent Siew says that he will file an application with the government for a visit to mainland China to pitch for the formation of a "common market" across the Taiwan Strait.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be not concerned that men do not know you; be concerned that you have no ability."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
President kicks off freeway marathon

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou kicked off a marathon event in northeastern Taiwan's Yilan County Sunday by running five kilometers on a freeway connecting Taipei and Yilan.
Ma joined some 5,000 runners at the Yilan Sports Park to launch the marathon event, which featured 42-km, 21-km and 10-km competitions, as well as a 5-km fun run.
Accompanied by Yilan Magistrate Lu Kuo-hua, Ma, a noted runner, turned in a time of 27 minutes while enjoying the stunning views of the Yilan Plain.

Part of the 55-km Beiyi Freeway was closed for the marathon. The freeway, also known as the Chiang Wei-shui Freeway, is named to commemorate Chiang, a pioneer of Taiwan's democracy movement who was born in Yilan County. The freeway, which includes the 12.9-km Hsuehshan Tunnel -- the longest highway tunnel in East Asia and the fifth-longest in the world -- was opened in 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOUs to be signed after 3rd round of cross-strait talks

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China will sign memorandums of understanding (MOUs) on banking, securities and futures, and insurance shortly after a third round of cross- Taiwan Strait talks slated be held April 25-29 in Nanjing, a local banking official said Sunday.

The two sides reached the consensus at a preparatory meeting for the cross- strait talks presided over by Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Secretary- General Kao Koong-lian and Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) Vice President Zheng Lizhong in Taipei a day earlier, according to Chang Ming-daw, director-general of the Banking Bureau under the Financial Supervisory Commission.

Because of the complexity of each of the three items, especially the banking part, the two sides decided not to sign the MOUs at the next round of talks between SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and ARATS President Chen Yunlin set for April 26 in Nanjing before holding further negotiations on the issues, said Chang.

Four topics will be included in the Nanjing talks -- financial cooperation, augmenting the direct cross-strait charter flights with regular flights, combating crime and opening Taiwan to investment from China, with agreements on the first three issues expected to be signed during the talks.

The agreement on financial cooperation is likely to cover bilateral financial supervision cooperation, the establishment of a currency settlement mechanism, increasing access to each other's financial markets, and the establishment of a system to help Taiwanese businessmen in China to obtain loans, Chang said.

Once a banking MOU is inked, Taiwan's banking and financial industry is expected to post a 20 percent growth for five consecutive years thanks to the potential benefits from wealth management services, including an estimated NT$3,000 billion (US$88.72 billion) increase in loan demand, NT$80 billion in net interest revenue and NT$8 billion in service fees, according to a foreign bank with operations in Taiwan.

Local bankers also expressed hope that by signing a banking MOU with China, Taiwan's banking industry will be granted the same preferential treatment offered to their Hong Kong counterparts under the Closer Economic Partnership Arrangement (CEPA) between the special administrative region and China.

The preferential treatment can cover a wide range of areas, such as allowing Taiwan banks to set up branches or subsidiaries in China and provide Chinese yuan services, and relaxing restrictions on foreign insurance companies wishing to set up insurance companies in China, the bankers added.

According to Chinese regulations, foreign banks should set up representative offices for two years before upgrading them to branches or subsidiaries, while foreign insurance companies in China should have operated for over 30 years within any World Trade Organization state with a minimum year-end total asset value of US$500 million and should have established a representative office in China for two years.

Taiwan Federation of Industry Chairman Lee Cheng-chia said the establishment of a currency settlement mechanism should be prioritized during the third round of cross-strait talks and suggested that Taiwan and China authorize the Bank of Taiwan and the Bank of China to handle related business.

Although Taiwan last July authorized some 1,240 local bank outlets to begin exchanges between new Taiwan dollars and the Chinese yuan, with a daily transaction limit of 20,000 yuan per person per day, the supplies of yuan are insufficient and the cost of buying the Chinese currency is too high, as China's monetary authority has yet to promise to provide Taiwan with yuan on a regular basis, according to Lee.
Currently, Taiwan's banks buy Chinese yuan mainly from HSBC and Bank of America.
Therefore, Lee said, building a cross-strait currency clearance mechanism to normalize and systemize the clearance of Taiwanese and Chinese currencies is essential.

DOC.HEADLINE: Severely burned baby girl on verge of death, father arrested

TEXT.P: A 10-month-old baby girl who was dumped by her father into a pot of boiling water Saturday in southern Taiwan's Changhua County remained in critical condition as of Sunday morning in the intensive care unit of a local hospital.

The infant's mother, identified only by her family name of Lin, scooped her out of the pot and rushed to a nearby police station for help, whereupon officers immediately sent her to the Burn Center at the Changhua Christian Hospital.

The baby girl, who suffered second degree burns over 95 percent of her body, deteriorated overnight and had to be placed on a respirator as she could no longer breathe on her own, doctors said Sunday, adding that although she was being given fluids, the prognosis was not good.
Changhua Magistrate Cho Po-yuan paid a visit to the hospital where the baby is being treated and asked the public to pray for her.

The baby's father, a 47-year-old surnamed Huang with a history of drunkenness, threw her into the boiling water after having a fierce argument with Lin, who is alleged to have taunted him into carrying out the assault.
Police arrested Huang and handed him over to the Changhua Prosecutors Office on charges of attempted homicide following an initial investigation.

Huang and Lin, who have lived together for 12 years but are not married, have two daughters. The older one, a fifth grader, was placed with a foster family by county social welfare officials following the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: Laid-off dad spends quality time with preschool daughters

TEXT.P: A former employee of a high-tech company who was laid off late last year due to the global economic crunch, has taken the opportunity of his enforced leisure to spend rare quality time with his two young daughters on a tailor-made tricycle riding the roads from northern Taiwan to the south.

Riding and touring, the daughters, aged 4 and 5, learned that the rice seedlings in southern Taiwan are further on than those in the north and that small plastic windmills can help monitor the trike's speed, although they usually traveled at less than 10 kph, said Chiang Ching-piao, the girls' father.

Chiang, who calls himself "Peter Dad " and is from Taoyuan in northern Taiwan, was watching the television cartoon En Famille with his daughters last December when the youngsters expressed great yearning to travel on a donkey cart like the little girl in the cartoon adapted from a novel by 19th-Century French writer Hector Malot.
"Peter Dad" thought about buying an ox cart to fulfill his daughters' wishes but after long consideration and assessment, decided to get a tricycle instead.

He then spent NT$12,000 to have a tricycle tailor-made by a manufacturer in eastern Hualien County and determined to spend the break in his career with his daughters, who have not yet entered elementary school. The machine has two seats for the youngsters in the front and a driver's seat at the back.

They set off March 17 from Taoyuan on a month-long cycle journey, riding the country roads Monday through Friday, while Chiang's wife, a worker with an airline company in Taoyuan, joined them on the weekends.
Traveling at walking speed, the trio would stop for fun, food and rest whenever they wanted and the girls would learn about the roadside wildflowers and would see farmers working the land.
They also visited parks in different cities, where the girls would rate the slides, with one in the Chiayi Park descending from the roof of a public toilet down to a sandpit taking top honors.
It was not all plain sailing, of course, and the journey was occasionally disrupted by flat tires, worn brakes and loose nuts and bolts.

The worst situation was when they were riding on a downhill stretch of road in Chiayi County when the bike skidded and overturned, leaving the girls with bruised legs and elbows and a little bit scared, said their father.
The girls then asked him to install two plastic windmills they had bought at a night market on the front of the bike to help monitor its speed.
"The girls would ask me to slow down when the windmills spun wildly -- but they would demand that I pedal faster when the windmills were not spinning at all," he said ruefully.
Every evening after the girls went to bed Chiang would post about the day's adventures on his blog.
The blog helped them make friends, with some blog visitors even meeting them on the road and riding with them for a while.
The family reached Taiwan's southernmost town of Kenting April 15 and visited the shooting locations of Cape No. 7 -- the biggest grossing locally produced film in Taiwan's cinema history.
They were also entertained by another blog visitor with duck rice noodles accompanied with smoked fowl -- famous local delicacies in Pingtung County's Hengchun township.

They wrapped up their journey April 17 in Pingtung, where they headed for Kaohsiung County to take the high speed train home, leaving their now-battered tricycle to be transported home on an ordinary train.
Once they got home, Chiang had to visit a clinic to get his sore arms treated, but his five-year-old has already been asking him when he will take her for a "real bicycle ride" to eastern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS delegation returns to Beijing

TEXT.P: A Chinese delegation that arrived last Friday to hold the preparatory talks for a third round of cross- Taiwan Strait negotiations left Taiwan Sunday after completing its mission in Taipei.

Zheng Lizhong, vice president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), along with the rest of the delegation, was seen off at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport by Kao Wen-cheng, vice secretary-general of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , under a heavy police escort to fend off any of the pro-Taiwan independence protesters who marred the delegation's arrival. No incidents were reported.

The preparatory talks ended a day earlier with the two sides reaching agreement on four issues concerning allowing Chinese investment in Taiwan, financial cooperation, regularly scheduled cross-strait flights to augment the existing charter flights, and joint efforts in crime-fighting.
The four issues are expected to be settled during the third round of SEF-ARATS negotiations slated for April 26 in Nanjing. The SEF delegation will return to Taiwan April 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait MOU expected to benefit local futures industry

TEXT.P: Taiwan's futures industry is expected to be boosted when a proposed memorandum of understanding (MOU) on the futures business is signed by Taiwan and China, local futures companies said Sunday.

The signing of the agreement will help improve transparency in the industry, which is viewed widely as a promising sector but still in its fledgling stage in China, according to an executive of Polaris MF Global Futures Co.

Taiwan is expected to be able to contribute a great deal if it forges cooperative ties with China in this regard because local futures dealers specialize in brokerage services, marketing, risk control, exploiting information technology and delivering training programs, the executive said.
The key will be whether Taiwanese funds can be used to invest in China's futures markets, the executive added.

China has numerous financial institutions of various sizes, so once the agreement is inked, Taiwanese futures companies planning to venture into the Chinese market will face the challenge of dealing with the different-sized companies there, the executive noted.
Mutual recognition of professional qualifications obtained in Taiwan and China is also an important issue that should be addressed in the agreement, he added.

Meanwhile, a representative of Grand Cathay Futures Corp. said that to expand the scope of exchanges between the new Taiwan dollar and the Chinese yuan, which would facilitate investment in each other's markets, a currency clearing system should be first set up before both sides could engage in cooperation in that area.

According to statistics compiled by the Futures Industry Association (FIA), the Taiwan Futures Exchange (TAIFEX) was ranked as 17th in the world in terms of trade volume in 2008, ahead of the Singapore and Hong Kong markets.

Taiwan's futures market currently holds a total guarantee fund of NT$120 billion, while China's three futures markets -- located in the cities of Shanghai, Dalian and Zhengzhou -- hold a total guarantee fund of 250 billion yuan.

China's future markets are mainly for the trading of commodity futures, such as soybeans, wheat, cotton, plastics and metals, while financial futures play a larger role in Taiwan's future market. The markets on both sides can strongly complement each other if a cooperative agreement is clinched, according to market analysts.
Although an official cooperative mechanism has yet to be set up, futures companies on both sides have already been engaged in cross-strait exchanges, industry sources said.

For example, Polaris, which has five operating centers and more than 300 staff in Taiwan, is planning to send 50 employees to gain an understanding of Chinese laws and regulations and spur them to gain professional certification in China, while Grand Cathay Futures is looking forward to sharing its expertise with large Chinese futures companies that have 20-30 subsidiaries, the sources added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gym coach wins women's championship in freeway marathon

TEXT.P: A local gym coach won the championship in the women's category of the National Freeway No. 5 Marathon held in northeastern Taiwan's Yilan County Sunday.

Lee Hsiao-yu captured the women's title in the 42 km full marathon with a time of 3 hours, 18 minutes, 56.8 seconds. Describing the race as "full of variables, " she said she was glad to have won the women's title, even though her time was not a personal best.

Wu Yung-fa won the men's title in the full marathon held on the freeway connecting Taipei and Yilan in 2: 43: 09 and attributed his failure to break his own record to the strong headwind that was blowing throughout the race.
Chiang Chieh-wen took home the men's championship in the 21-km half marathon with a time of 1: 10: 58, while Chen Chih-hui bagged the women's title in 1:29:39.
Health Minister Yeh Chin-chuan and former Deputy Taipei Mayor Chin Pu-tsung also took part in the half marathon, both of whom finished.
President Ma Ying-jeou, an enthusiastic runner, kicked off the event, which also featured a 10-km competition and a 5-km fun run, finishing the 5-km run in 27 minutes.
Among some 5,000 runners who gathered at the start of the races at the Yilan Sports Park was a couple of newlyweds who ran the 5-km fun run in tux, wedding gown and sneakers.
One man, a 54-year-old bank employee from Taipei identified as Chen Hsi-chin, collapsed just 50 meters short of his 10-km run and died later in hospital.

DOC.HEADLINE: Majority of Taiwanese favor inking trade pact with China: MAC

TEXT.P: Some 70 percent of the respondents to a recent government survey are in favor of inking an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China to deal with two-way trade and investment issues, according to the poll results released Sunday.

The survey, carried out by a private consultancy for the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) also found that 23.5 percent of the respondents were not in favor, contending that such an agreement is unnecessary.
A total of 69.2 percent of those polled said they believe Taiwan and China will develop even closer trade and commerce ties in the future.

Around 60 percent of the respondents said that a Taiwan-China ECFA will help Taiwan clinch similar accords with other countries, while 60 percent said lower tariffs ensured by an ECFA will help Taiwanese products grab a bigger share of the Chinese market, according to the survey.

Concerning the sensitive Taiwan sovereignty issue, 53.6 percent said they believe the planned ECFA is designed to handle economic matters and will not affect Taiwan's independent sovereignty. Nevertheless, 37.7 percent said they were concerned about such a development.
As to the question of whether Chinese investment in Taiwan should be permitted, 79.9 percent agreed that limited opening is acceptable, while 17.2 percent strongly opposed the idea.
Around 90 percent of the respondents said they would not purchase fewer locally made products if more Chinese goods are allowed to enter the domestic market under the terms of an ECFA.
While close to 49 percent of the respondents said they believe that an ECFA will help increase jobs in Taiwan, 23.7 percent did not agree, according to the survey.
The opinion poll was conducted April 8-11, collecting 1,067 valid questionnaires from people aged between 20 and 69. It had a margin of error of 3 percentage points.

The MAC expressed hope that the results of the survey will help narrow the gap between the ruling party and the opposition, which is vehemently against such a pact with China, with the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union voicing fear that Taiwan's sovereign status would be compromised.
As for concern that an ECFA would deal a heavy blow to Taiwan's traditional businesses, MAC officials said the council will make a more precise assessment of the issue.
