DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 19, or the 24th day of the third month of the Year of Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1832: Jose Echegaray y Eizaguirre, Spanish dramatist, mathematician, statesman and Nobel laureate, is born.
1853: Russia claims to be the protectorate of Turkey in a prelude to the Crimean War.
1882: British naturalist Charles Darwin dies at the age of 73. He revolutionized the study of biology with his theory of evolution based on natural selection. His most famous works include "Origin of Species" and "The Descent of Man."
1906: French chemist and physicist Pierre Curie is run over and killed in Paris at the age of 47. He and his wife Marie shared the 1903 Nobel Prize for fundamental research into radioactivity.
1928: Japanese troops occupy Shantung Province in northern China.
1942: Chinese Expeditionary Forces led by Gen. Sun Li-jen capture Yenangyuang in northern Burma, rescuing more than 7,000 British and Burmese troops from Japanese encirclement.
1948: The first National Assembly elects Chiang Kai-shek as the Republic of China's first president under the new ROC Constitution, garnering 2,430 out of 2,704 votes.
1956: Prince Rainier of Monaco marries American screen actress Grace Kelly in Monte Carlo. Over 1,200 guests attend the televised Catholic wedding ceremony.
1959: The Dalai Lama, the Tibetan leader fleeing a Communist Chinese invasion of his country, finds sanctuary in India.
1960: South Korean President Syngman Rhee is toppled in a nationwide pro- democracy student uprising that was protesting election fraud.
1966: Australian troops leave Sydney to join American forces in Vietnam.
1974: The Blood Donation Association of the Republic of China is inaugurated.
1975: India's first satellite is launched by a Soviet rocket.
1977: ROC Education Minister Tsiang Yien-si resigns to take responsibility for an incident in which 32 college students and teachers were killed when their boat capsized near Suao Port in eastern Taiwan. Tsiang was succeeded by Li Yuan- zu.
1992: Dutch Minister of Foreign Trade Yvonne van Rooy visits Taipei to seek stronger bilateral relations.
1993: A total of 87 Branch Davidian cult members, including their leader David Koresh, are killed when federal agents storm their compound in Waco, Texas, after a 51-day standoff. Nine other members are freed.
1995: A huge truck bomb destroys the Alfred P. Murrah government building in Oklahoma City, killing 168 people and injuring more than 400 others.
1995: Malawi President Bakili Muluzi pays a state visit to Taipei.
1997: The S.S. Sheng Da, a mainland China container freighter, steams into Kaohsiung Port on its maiden voyage, becoming the first ship to sail directly to Taiwan from the mainland in 48 years, and completing a historic crossing of one of the world's great political divides.
1999: Tsai Shun-fa, 52, known as "Bean Curd Papa," is honored by Premier Vincent Siew for donating blood 495 times over 20 years.
1999: The Republic of China-Swaziland Conference on Economical and Technological Cooperation opens in Taipei.
2000: Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Taipei-based Chinese National Association of Industry & Commerce, says that if Beijing bullies Taiwanese doing business in mainland China, it will hurt both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
2000: President-elect Chen Shui-bian promises that his administration will help the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau transform itself into a "National Bureau of Investigation."
2001: Former ROC Premier Vincent Siew says that he will file an application with the government for a visit to mainland China to pitch for the formation of a "common market" across the Taiwan Strait.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be not concerned that men do not know you; be concerned that you have no ability."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan can do something for China: ex-official

TEXT.P: Taiwan can do something for China, particularly in charitable services for disadvantaged groups of people, Taiwan's top representative to the 2009 Boao Forum told Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao Saturday.

Fredrick Chien, a former president of the Control Yuan who also once served as Taiwan's minister of foreign affairs and representative to the United States, met with Wen on the sidelines of the annual international forum of government officials and business leaders in China's southern island province of Hainan.
Only the first few minutes of the Chien-Wen meeting was open for media coverage while the remaining part of their talks were held behind the closed door.
Chien told reporters after his longer-than-expected talks with Wen that he came up with several proposals in his capacity as a Taiwanese citizen, not as a representative of Taiwan's government.

According to Chien, he told Wen that Taiwan's Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation is planning to build a new community in Indonesia that will comprise a mixture of hospitals, factories, schools and housing units to accommodate 4,000 households in a slum.
In the Tzu Chi project, the Indonesian slum will also be developed into a tourist attraction.

Chien, who is attending the Boao Forum as the top adviser to the Taipei-based Cross-Strait Common Market Foundation, said he had received a positive reply from Tzu Chi that it is willing to mount a similar project in China.
In addition, Chien said some Taiwanese civic groups are help with restoration of the ancient Loulan Castle in China's Xinjiang Province.

Responding to Wen's remarks at the beginning of their talks that the two sides of the Taiwan Straits are connected at the roots and share the same blood, Chien said he noticed that Wen advocated the ideas of seeking cross-strait "peaceful development" and boosting bilateral engagements on an equal footing, in his March 5 report to the National People's Congress, China's parliament.

Based on Wen's such proposals, Chien told Wen that he looks forward to seeing China help Taiwan realize its goal of attracting 1 million Chinese tourists a year and purchase electric home appliances to help Taiwanese makers ride out the current global economic recession.

In an apparent effort to allay some Taiwan's pro-independence groups' apprehensions that he might represent President Ma Ying-jeou to broach the proposal of signing a cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) , Chien said he didn't mention throughout his talks with Wen anything about such topics or issues regarding Taiwan's desire to join the "ASEAN Plus 3" regional economic integration.
The Taiwanese delegation to the 2009 Boao Forum is composed of 30-plus academics, bankers and business executives.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
President kicks off freeway marathon

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou kicked off a marathon event in northeastern Taiwan's Yilan County Sunday by running five kilometers on a freeway connecting Taipei and Yilan.
Ma joined some 5,000 runners at the Yilan Sports Park to launch the marathon event, which featured 42-km, 21-km and 10-km competitions, as well as a 5-km fun run.
Accompanied by Yilan Magistrate Lu Kuo-hua, Ma, a noted runner, turned in a time of 27 minutes while enjoying the stunning views of the Yilan Plain.

Part of the 55-km Beiyi Freeway was closed for the marathon. The freeway, also known as the Chiang Wei-shui Freeway, is named to commemorate Chiang, a pioneer of Taiwan's democracy movement who was born in Yilan County. The freeway, which includes the 12.9-km Hsuehshan Tunnel -- the longest highway tunnel in East Asia and the fifth-longest in the world -- was opened in 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOUs to be signed after 3rd round of cross-strait talks

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China will sign memorandums of understanding (MOUs) on banking, securities and futures, and insurance shortly after a third round of cross- Taiwan Strait talks slated be held April 25-29 in Nanjing, a local banking official said Sunday.

The two sides reached the consensus at a preparatory meeting for the cross- strait talks presided over by Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Secretary- General Kao Koong-lian and Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) Vice President Zheng Lizhong in Taipei a day earlier, according to Chang Ming-daw, director-general of the Banking Bureau under the Financial Supervisory Commission.

Because of the complexity of each of the three items, especially the banking part, the two sides decided not to sign the MOUs at the next round of talks between SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and ARATS President Chen Yunlin set for April 26 in Nanjing before holding further negotiations on the issues, said Chang.

Four topics will be included in the Nanjing talks -- financial cooperation, augmenting the direct cross-strait charter flights with regular flights, combating crime and opening Taiwan to investment from China, with agreements on the first three issues expected to be signed during the talks.

The agreement on financial cooperation is likely to cover bilateral financial supervision cooperation, the establishment of a currency settlement mechanism, increasing access to each other's financial markets, and the establishment of a system to help Taiwanese businessmen in China to obtain loans, Chang said.

Once a banking MOU is inked, Taiwan's banking and financial industry is expected to post a 20 percent growth for five consecutive years thanks to the potential benefits from wealth management services, including an estimated NT$3,000 billion (US$88.72 billion) increase in loan demand, NT$80 billion in net interest revenue and NT$8 billion in service fees, according to a foreign bank with operations in Taiwan.

Local bankers also expressed hope that by signing a banking MOU with China, Taiwan's banking industry will be granted the same preferential treatment offered to their Hong Kong counterparts under the Closer Economic Partnership Arrangement (CEPA) between the special administrative region and China.

The preferential treatment can cover a wide range of areas, such as allowing Taiwan banks to set up branches or subsidiaries in China and provide Chinese yuan services, and relaxing restrictions on foreign insurance companies wishing to set up insurance companies in China, the bankers added.

According to Chinese regulations, foreign banks should set up representative offices for two years before upgrading them to branches or subsidiaries, while foreign insurance companies in China should have operated for over 30 years within any World Trade Organization state with a minimum year-end total asset value of US$500 million and should have established a representative office in China for two years.

Taiwan Federation of Industry Chairman Lee Cheng-chia said the establishment of a currency settlement mechanism should be prioritized during the third round of cross-strait talks and suggested that Taiwan and China authorize the Bank of Taiwan and the Bank of China to handle related business.

Although Taiwan last July authorized some 1,240 local bank outlets to begin exchanges between new Taiwan dollars and the Chinese yuan, with a daily transaction limit of 20,000 yuan per person per day, the supplies of yuan are insufficient and the cost of buying the Chinese currency is too high, as China's monetary authority has yet to promise to provide Taiwan with yuan on a regular basis, according to Lee.
Currently, Taiwan's banks buy Chinese yuan mainly from HSBC and Bank of America.
Therefore, Lee said, building a cross-strait currency clearance mechanism to normalize and systemize the clearance of Taiwanese and Chinese currencies is essential.

DOC.HEADLINE: Severely burned baby girl on verge of death, father arrested

TEXT.P: A 10-month-old baby girl who was dumped by her father into a pot of boiling water Saturday in southern Taiwan's Changhua County remained in critical condition as of Sunday morning in the intensive care unit of a local hospital.

The infant's mother, identified only by her family name of Lin, scooped her out of the pot and rushed to a nearby police station for help, whereupon officers immediately sent her to the Burn Center at the Changhua Christian Hospital.

The baby girl, who suffered second degree burns over 95 percent of her body, deteriorated overnight and had to be placed on a respirator as she could no longer breathe on her own, doctors said Sunday, adding that although she was being given fluids, the prognosis was not good.
Changhua Magistrate Cho Po-yuan paid a visit to the hospital where the baby is being treated and asked the public to pray for her.

The baby's father, a 47-year-old surnamed Huang with a history of drunkenness, threw her into the boiling water after having a fierce argument with Lin, who is alleged to have taunted him into carrying out the assault.
Police arrested Huang and handed him over to the Changhua Prosecutors Office on charges of attempted homicide following an initial investigation.

Huang and Lin, who have lived together for 12 years but are not married, have two daughters. The older one, a fifth grader, was placed with a foster family by county social welfare officials following the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: Laid-off dad spends quality time with preschool daughters

TEXT.P: A former employee of a high-tech company who was laid off late last year due to the global economic crunch, has taken the opportunity of his enforced leisure to spend rare quality time with his two young daughters on a tailor-made tricycle riding the roads from northern Taiwan to the south.

Riding and touring, the daughters, aged 4 and 5, learned that the rice seedlings in southern Taiwan are further on than those in the north and that small plastic windmills can help monitor the trike's speed, although they usually traveled at less than 10 kph, said Chiang Ching-piao, the girls' father.

Chiang, who calls himself "Peter Dad " and is from Taoyuan in northern Taiwan, was watching the television cartoon En Famille with his daughters last December when the youngsters expressed great yearning to travel on a donkey cart like the little girl in the cartoon adapted from a novel by 19th-Century French writer Hector Malot.
"Peter Dad" thought about buying an ox cart to fulfill his daughters' wishes but after long consideration and assessment, decided to get a tricycle instead.

He then spent NT$12,000 to have a tricycle tailor-made by a manufacturer in eastern Hualien County and determined to spend the break in his career with his daughters, who have not yet entered elementary school. The machine has two seats for the youngsters in the front and a driver's seat at the back.

They set off March 17 from Taoyuan on a month-long cycle journey, riding the country roads Monday through Friday, while Chiang's wife, a worker with an airline company in Taoyuan, joined them on the weekends.
Traveling at walking speed, the trio would stop for fun, food and rest whenever they wanted and the girls would learn about the roadside wildflowers and would see farmers working the land.
They also visited parks in different cities, where the girls would rate the slides, with one in the Chiayi Park descending from the roof of a public toilet down to a sandpit taking top honors.
It was not all plain sailing, of course, and the journey was occasionally disrupted by flat tires, worn brakes and loose nuts and bolts.

The worst situation was when they were riding on a downhill stretch of road in Chiayi County when the bike skidded and overturned, leaving the girls with bruised legs and elbows and a little bit scared, said their father.
The girls then asked him to install two plastic windmills they had bought at a night market on the front of the bike to help monitor its speed.
"The girls would ask me to slow down when the windmills spun wildly -- but they would demand that I pedal faster when the windmills were not spinning at all," he said ruefully.
Every evening after the girls went to bed Chiang would post about the day's adventures on his blog.
The blog helped them make friends, with some blog visitors even meeting them on the road and riding with them for a while.
The family reached Taiwan's southernmost town of Kenting April 15 and visited the shooting locations of Cape No. 7 -- the biggest grossing locally produced film in Taiwan's cinema history.
They were also entertained by another blog visitor with duck rice noodles accompanied with smoked fowl -- famous local delicacies in Pingtung County's Hengchun township.

They wrapped up their journey April 17 in Pingtung, where they headed for Kaohsiung County to take the high speed train home, leaving their now-battered tricycle to be transported home on an ordinary train.
Once they got home, Chiang had to visit a clinic to get his sore arms treated, but his five-year-old has already been asking him when he will take her for a "real bicycle ride" to eastern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS delegation returns to Beijing

TEXT.P: A Chinese delegation that arrived last Friday to hold the preparatory talks for a third round of cross- Taiwan Strait negotiations left Taiwan Sunday after completing its mission in Taipei.

Zheng Lizhong, vice president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), along with the rest of the delegation, was seen off at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport by Kao Wen-cheng, vice secretary-general of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , under a heavy police escort to fend off any of the pro-Taiwan independence protesters who marred the delegation's arrival. No incidents were reported.

The preparatory talks ended a day earlier with the two sides reaching agreement on four issues concerning allowing Chinese investment in Taiwan, financial cooperation, regularly scheduled cross-strait flights to augment the existing charter flights, and joint efforts in crime-fighting.
The four issues are expected to be settled during the third round of SEF-ARATS negotiations slated for April 26 in Nanjing. The SEF delegation will return to Taiwan April 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait MOU expected to benefit local futures industry

TEXT.P: Taiwan's futures industry is expected to be boosted when a proposed memorandum of understanding (MOU) on the futures business is signed by Taiwan and China, local futures companies said Sunday.

The signing of the agreement will help improve transparency in the industry, which is viewed widely as a promising sector but still in its fledgling stage in China, according to an executive of Polaris MF Global Futures Co.

Taiwan is expected to be able to contribute a great deal if it forges cooperative ties with China in this regard because local futures dealers specialize in brokerage services, marketing, risk control, exploiting information technology and delivering training programs, the executive said.
The key will be whether Taiwanese funds can be used to invest in China's futures markets, the executive added.

China has numerous financial institutions of various sizes, so once the agreement is inked, Taiwanese futures companies planning to venture into the Chinese market will face the challenge of dealing with the different-sized companies there, the executive noted.
Mutual recognition of professional qualifications obtained in Taiwan and China is also an important issue that should be addressed in the agreement, he added.

Meanwhile, a representative of Grand Cathay Futures Corp. said that to expand the scope of exchanges between the new Taiwan dollar and the Chinese yuan, which would facilitate investment in each other's markets, a currency clearing system should be first set up before both sides could engage in cooperation in that area.

According to statistics compiled by the Futures Industry Association (FIA), the Taiwan Futures Exchange (TAIFEX) was ranked as 17th in the world in terms of trade volume in 2008, ahead of the Singapore and Hong Kong markets.

Taiwan's futures market currently holds a total guarantee fund of NT$120 billion, while China's three futures markets -- located in the cities of Shanghai, Dalian and Zhengzhou -- hold a total guarantee fund of 250 billion yuan.

China's future markets are mainly for the trading of commodity futures, such as soybeans, wheat, cotton, plastics and metals, while financial futures play a larger role in Taiwan's future market. The markets on both sides can strongly complement each other if a cooperative agreement is clinched, according to market analysts.
Although an official cooperative mechanism has yet to be set up, futures companies on both sides have already been engaged in cross-strait exchanges, industry sources said.

For example, Polaris, which has five operating centers and more than 300 staff in Taiwan, is planning to send 50 employees to gain an understanding of Chinese laws and regulations and spur them to gain professional certification in China, while Grand Cathay Futures is looking forward to sharing its expertise with large Chinese futures companies that have 20-30 subsidiaries, the sources added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gym coach wins women's championship in freeway marathon

TEXT.P: A local gym coach won the championship in the women's category of the National Freeway No. 5 Marathon held in northeastern Taiwan's Yilan County Sunday.

Lee Hsiao-yu captured the women's title in the 42 km full marathon with a time of 3 hours, 18 minutes, 56.8 seconds. Describing the race as "full of variables, " she said she was glad to have won the women's title, even though her time was not a personal best.

Wu Yung-fa won the men's title in the full marathon held on the freeway connecting Taipei and Yilan in 2: 43: 09 and attributed his failure to break his own record to the strong headwind that was blowing throughout the race.
Chiang Chieh-wen took home the men's championship in the 21-km half marathon with a time of 1: 10: 58, while Chen Chih-hui bagged the women's title in 1:29:39.
Health Minister Yeh Chin-chuan and former Deputy Taipei Mayor Chin Pu-tsung also took part in the half marathon, both of whom finished.
President Ma Ying-jeou, an enthusiastic runner, kicked off the event, which also featured a 10-km competition and a 5-km fun run, finishing the 5-km run in 27 minutes.
Among some 5,000 runners who gathered at the start of the races at the Yilan Sports Park was a couple of newlyweds who ran the 5-km fun run in tux, wedding gown and sneakers.
One man, a 54-year-old bank employee from Taipei identified as Chen Hsi-chin, collapsed just 50 meters short of his 10-km run and died later in hospital.

DOC.HEADLINE: Majority of Taiwanese favor inking trade pact with China: MAC

TEXT.P: Some 70 percent of the respondents to a recent government survey are in favor of inking an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China to deal with two-way trade and investment issues, according to the poll results released Sunday.

The survey, carried out by a private consultancy for the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) also found that 23.5 percent of the respondents were not in favor, contending that such an agreement is unnecessary.
A total of 69.2 percent of those polled said they believe Taiwan and China will develop even closer trade and commerce ties in the future.

Around 60 percent of the respondents said that a Taiwan-China ECFA will help Taiwan clinch similar accords with other countries, while 60 percent said lower tariffs ensured by an ECFA will help Taiwanese products grab a bigger share of the Chinese market, according to the survey.

Concerning the sensitive Taiwan sovereignty issue, 53.6 percent said they believe the planned ECFA is designed to handle economic matters and will not affect Taiwan's independent sovereignty. Nevertheless, 37.7 percent said they were concerned about such a development.
As to the question of whether Chinese investment in Taiwan should be permitted, 79.9 percent agreed that limited opening is acceptable, while 17.2 percent strongly opposed the idea.
Around 90 percent of the respondents said they would not purchase fewer locally made products if more Chinese goods are allowed to enter the domestic market under the terms of an ECFA.
While close to 49 percent of the respondents said they believe that an ECFA will help increase jobs in Taiwan, 23.7 percent did not agree, according to the survey.
The opinion poll was conducted April 8-11, collecting 1,067 valid questionnaires from people aged between 20 and 69. It had a margin of error of 3 percentage points.

The MAC expressed hope that the results of the survey will help narrow the gap between the ruling party and the opposition, which is vehemently against such a pact with China, with the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union voicing fear that Taiwan's sovereign status would be compromised.
As for concern that an ECFA would deal a heavy blow to Taiwan's traditional businesses, MAC officials said the council will make a more precise assessment of the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 20, or the 25th day of the third month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1526: Baber, or Zahir ud-Din Mohammed, leads 2,000 Moguls to victory over 10,000 Muslims and 100 elephants under Ibrahim at the battle of Panipat. The conqueror of India later captured Delhi and Agra and founded the Mogul dynasty.
1657: Jews in New Amsterdam (now New York City) are granted equal rights and privileges as citizens.
1836: The U.S. Congress officially separates the western part of the Michigan Territory, creating a new zone known as the Wisconsin Territory.
1859: Holland concludes a treaty granting Portugal the right to govern the eastern part of Timor as well as Atauro Island and Oecussi.
1889: Adolf Hitler, house painter and subsequently German dictator who founded the National Socialist (Nazi) Party and was the architect of World War II, is born in Austria.
1908: Taiwan's West Coast Railway Trunk Line from Keelung to Kaohsiung, with a total length of 405 kilometers, is opened to traffic.
1916: The Taipei Yuanshan Zoo is inaugurated.
1933: President Franklin D. Roosevelt removes the United States from the gold standard.
1944: Britain's Royal Air Force drops a record 4,500 tons of bombs on Germany in a single raid.
1945: Soviet troops penetrate Berlin defenses.
1950: The Taiwan Garrison Command Headquarters is established, with Gen. Sun Li- jen serving at its first commander.
1957: Japan protests against nuclear testing by the Soviet Union.
1968: Pierre Elliot Trudeau of the Liberal Party becomes the 15th prime minister of Canada.
1970: President Richard M. Nixon announces the withdrawal of 150,000 U.S. military personnel from South Vietnam.
1974: The Republic of China announces the termination of Taiwan-Japan flights by China Airlines and Japan Airlines after Japan and mainland China sign an air pact in Beijing.
1978: Soviet warplanes force an off-course South Korean airliner down in the Soviet Union near the Arctic Circle, killing two passengers aboard and injuring 13 others.
1984: Britain announces that its administration of Hong Kong will cease in 1997 when the colony is returned to mainland China.
1986: A reservoir bursts and floods a Sri Lankan town, killing 100 people and making some 20,000 families homeless.
1990: Soviet troops storm Lithuania's state printing works after Mikhail Gorbachev cuts off 85 percent of gas supplies to the rebellious republic.
1996: World leaders meeting in Moscow agree to cooperate on increasing nuclear safety.
1999: Taiwan's Council of Agriculture rejects a call from South Korea for a resumption of reciprocal trade in fruit between the two countries.
1999: Defense Minister Tang Fei denies a U.S. media report that the Republic of China plans to develop medium range missiles.
2000: Central News Agency President Bill Wang says that CNA will shortly add a commercial information databank to its Internet services.
2000: National Yang Ming University President Tseng Chih-lang announces that he has decided to accept President-elect Chen Shui-bian's offer of the post of education minister in the new administration.
2001: Japanese Foreign Minister Yohei Kono announces that Japan will issue a visa to former ROC President Lee Teng-hui to seek medical treatment for his heart condition.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who does not anticipate deceit nor imagine untrustworthiness, but who can readily detect their presence, must be a very superior man."

DOC.HEADLINE: Buddhist charity offers tips on how to cope with financial crisis

TEXT.P: A local Buddhist charity, the Tzu Chi Foundation, has been offering some tips on how people can cope on an everyday basis with the effects of the financial crisis that has gripped the world.
As part of its 43rd founding anniversary celebrations, the foundation launched an exhibition Sunday in Taipei to give details on how people can save money by living simply.
First, the foundation recommended that people use less of everything, starting with plastic bags and disposable tableware.
It suggested that shoppers carry their own bags rather than buying plastic bags and that consumers take along their own cups to buy drinks rather than using disposable cups.
Living simply also means refraining from buying luxury items, such as cosmetics and designer products, the charity said.
The foundation called on people to use cheap endurable handbags instead of expensive designer brands, and to buy functional mobile phones rather than fancy ones.

Noting that Taiwan sells more than 7 million mobile phones a year domestically, the foundation suggested the public learn to use their cell phones properly and not to discard them if they are still usable.
"When you do have to replace them, remember to turn them in to a recycling station," the foundation said, adding that less them 20 percent of used mobile phones in Taiwan are recycled.

Citing statistics compiled by a foreign environmental group, the foundation said if each mobile phone user worldwide hands over one phone for recycling, this can save 2,400,000 tons of raw materials and cut carbon dioxide emissions by a volume equivalent to that produced by 4 million cars.

The volume of raw materials saved will be more significant if mobile phone appliances such batteries, battery chargers, wireless earphones, and packing materials are also recycled, said the foundation.

Living more simply would not compromise the quality of life, as it does not cost much to live happily, and people would not be deprived of their pleasure if that pleasure is derived from activities such as gardening, hiking, sports, reading, voluntary service, and arts appreciation, said the foundation.
In order to convince the general public that they can live simply and save money, the exhibition also includes several practical examples.
The exhibition was staged at the foundation's seven offices in downtown Taipei. More information can be found at the charity's Web site at www.tzuchi.org.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Legislative speaker calls for connecting flight accord with China

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Monday that it is critically important for Taiwan to sign an accord with China on connecting flight rights, which would be beneficial to Taiwanese air carriers.
"The Legislative Yuan will ask Taiwan negotiators in the upcoming cross-strait talks to seek that goal," Wang said.

Connecting flight rights, also known as the Fifth Freedom of the Air, allow air carriers to fly passengers from one's own country to a second country, and from that country to a third country, with tickets available on any or all sectors.
On concerns that such an agreement might involve "nation-to-nation" political barriers, Wang suggested that the two sides shelve sovereignty disputes and focus on substantive issues.

Negotiators from Taiwan and China are expected to discuss four main topics in Nanjing April 26 in their third round of cross-Taiwan Strait talks. The topics on the agenda are financial cooperation, augmenting the direct cross-strait charter flights with regular flights, combating crime, and opening Taiwan to investment from China. Agreements on the first three issues are expected to be signed during the talks.

Meanwhile, Deputy Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Sheng-chung expressed hope at the Legislative Yuan that the issue of patent rights infringement will be included in the fourth round of cross-strait talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: Reporters receive hypoxia tolerance training at WuFeng Lab

TEXT.P: A group of reporters traveled Monday to Jade Mountain, Taiwan's highest peak, after receiving hypoxia tolerance training in a lab at the WuFeng Institute of Technology in southern Chiayi County.

The five journalists and cameramen from a local daily newspaper and two cable TV stations continued their training to adapt to a high-altitude environment in preparation for their upcoming coverage of an attempt to summit Everest by four Taiwanese climbers in May.
They received the hypoxia tolerance training at WuFeng Institute's Hypoxia Environment Lab, simulating an oxygen level similar to that found at a height of 6,000 meters above sea level.
They stayed in a 9.9 sq. ft. hypoxia ward all night to familiarize themselves with dealing with a lack of oxygen, according to Prof. Su Chung-hui, a project manager at the laboratory.

Noting that most people usually cannot tolerate the hypoxia room for more than an hour, Su said all five signed consent forms before entering the room, while lab staff closely monitored them around the clock.
The five then traveled Monday to Jade Mountain, Taiwan's highest peak, to continue their training to adapt to a high-altitude environment.

They are scheduled to depart from Taiwan April 30 for Nepal and to reach Everest base camp May 9 to cover the Everest expedition by four Taiwanese climbers -- Wu Yu-lung, Huang Chih-hao, Hsieh Ying-su and Chiang Hsiu-chen -- around mid-May.
The four climbers received hypoxia tolerance training at the lab in March.
The expedition, the first by a Taiwan alpine team since 1996, is being sponsored by Atunas, a sports gear supplier that also operates an outdoor resort, the Atunas Holiday Country, in Chiayi County.
Of the four climbers, Chiang is the only woman. She reached the summit of Everest from the north 14 years ago.
The latest expedition plans to make its summit attempt on the south face of the mountain, the conventional route.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, increasing NT$0.014 to close at NT$33.830.
A total of US$798 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$33.955 before dropping to the day's low of NT$33.754.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma hails TRA as cornerstone of cross-strait peace

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou hailed the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) Monday as the cornerstone of cross-Taiwan Strait peace and the mutually beneficial ties that are developing among Taiwan, China and the United States.

Ma made the remarks during a meeting at the Presidential Office with members of the Washington-based Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) , including CSIS President and CEO and former U.S. Deputy Secretary of Defense John Hamre as well as other academics familiar with Asian and China affairs.

"The TRA is the key to preserving peace in the strait and has served as a pillar, supporting mutually beneficial relations between Taiwan and mainland China over the past 30 years, " the president said.

Since assuming office in May 2008, Ma said, he has actively sought to improve Taiwan's links with China and the United States, which had soured during the 2000-2008 period under the former Democratic Progressive Party administration.
With improved China ties, there have also been initial signs of progress in Taiwan's relations with the United States and Japan as well as in other diplomatic relations, he said.

Ma has been invited to give a keynote speech by teleconference from Taiwan at a seminar to be organized by the CSIS in Washington, D.C. April 22 to examine the role of the TRA in Taipei-Beijing- Washington ties 30 years after its enactment.
It will be Ma's first exchange with U.S. academics in such a forum since he took office.
Ma will be introduced by Richard Armitage, a former U.S. deputy secretary of state, according to the host.
Almost all major U.S. think tanks have sponsored seminars to mark the 30th anniversary of the U.S. law, particularly at a time of warming relations between Taiwan and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices rise on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed slightly higher Monday, bolstered by electronics and financial stocks.
The weighted index, the market's key barometer, advanced 26.28 points, or 0.45 percent, to close at 5,781.66.
Rebounding from their large decline of 241.79 points in the previous session, the local bourse opened at 5,764.48 and once dropped to 5,648.10 before hitting the day's high of 5,797.63.
A total of 6.01 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$121.46 billion (US$3.59 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics stocks moving up the most at 1.1 percent. Plastics and chemicals issues added 1.0 percent, banking and financial stocks rose 0.7 percent, and foodstuff shares advanced 0.2 percent.

The four other major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp shares dropping the most at 4.8 percent. Construction shares dropped 3.9 percent, textile issues shed 1.8 percent, and cement shares lost 0.5 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,480 to 734, with 102 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$3.42 billion.

An analyst attributed the out performance of electronics and financial shares to a government plan to invest NT$50 billion in five years in a national energy development program and to expectation that China and Taiwan will sign an agreement on financial services soon.
The analyst said that the market will have the opportunity to maintain the momentum to stand above 5,560 and even test a new high, if foreign investors continue on the buying side.

DOC.HEADLINE: Percentage of Taiwan-originated Internet spam declines

TEXT.P: The percentage of junk e-mails originating from Taiwan fell to 10 percent of the global total in 2008, while China remained the Asia-Pacific region's biggest proliferator, Internet security company Symantec Corp. said Monday.
Junk e-mails from Taiwan constituted 19 percent of global spam in 2007, but fell to 10 percent of the 119.6 billion junk e-mails sent in 2008, according to the Cupertino, California-based company.

The declining number sent Taiwan's ranking in the Asia-Pacific region as a proliferator of spam tumbling to fifth from second in 2007. China remained the No. 1 source of Internet mayhem in 2008 in the area, Symantec said.
According to the producer of Norton anti-virus software, 90 percent of global junk e-mail was sent from bots and botnets -- one of the most sophisticated and popular types of cybercrime today.

They allow hackers to take control of many computers at a time, and turn them into "zombie" computers, which operate as part of a powerful "botnet" to spread viruses, generate spam, and commit other types of online crime and fraud.
Of the junk e-mail, 24 percent was Internet-related junk, 19 percent was commerce-related spam, and about 16 percent was junk e-mail related to personal finances.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmaker proposes ban on children-targeted life insurance

TEXT.P: With the economic recession causing an increasing unemployment rate, the ethical risks created by selling life insurance policies targeting minors has inspired a call for a ban on the sale of life insurance policies for children aged under 14.

Legislator Kao Jyh-peng of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party proposed an amendment to the Insurance Law last week at the Legislative Yuan to make the ban possible and his proposal has received sufficient endorsement by lawmakers for it to be put on the legislative agenda.

Under the existing law, life insurance policies for children aged 14 or under, or those who are diagnosed as suffering from a mental disorder, pay out funeral benefits to a maximum of NT$2 million (US$59,000).

Although there is no provision of death benefits to the beneficiary of the policy in the event of the death of the insured child, the funeral payout can still be an attractive enough incentive for parents to murder their children, according to Chen Charng-ven, a well-known local attorney and president of the Republic of China Red Cross Society who recently published his opinions in a local newspaper.
In response to the call, Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) Chairman Sean Chen said he supports the proposed ban and that the commission has moved to review the law.

According to data provided by police authorities and insurance businesses, the latest attempted murder for the purpose of claiming insurance benefits was reported in Taoyuan County last year when a 43-year-old truck driver tried to drown his 11-year-old daughter in a river so that he could claim the NT$2 million funeral benefit.
The attempt failed and the father, who had credit card debts in excess of NT$600,000, was arrested, convicted of attempted murder and given a 12-year prison term.

Prior to 1997, the law had prohibited insurers from marketing life policies for children aged under 14, but the legislature amended the law to allow parents to insure their children with no ceiling on the death benefits.

In 2001, the legislature revised the law again according to a proposal by Hsieh Chi-ta, at the time a legislator of the opposition New Party, to set a ceiling of NT$1 million for funeral compensation, which was later raised again to NT$2 million following demands of insurance businesses.

Commenting on the issue, Chiang Chao-kuo, a law professor at National Taipei University, suggested that parents should be allowed to purchase medical or annuity insurance policies for their children that "are only payable as long as the insured is still alive."

According to statistics of the Life Insurance Association, as of the end of 2008, the total population of children aged under 14 stood at just over 3.9 million, more than 2.5 million of whom had private insurance -- mostly medical insurance -- packages.

DOC.HEADLINE: Law being amended to weed out sex offenders from schools

TEXT.P: Two Legislative Yuan committees adopted an amendment Monday, paving the way for legislation to weed out teachers in Taiwan's schools who are found to have molested their students.

The lawmakers serving on the Judiciary and Organic Laws and Statutes Committee and the Education and Culture Committee held a joint meeting and adopted the amendment to the Statute Governing the Appointment of Educators.

The amendment would require teachers accused of sexual assaults against their students be suspended from their posts. If the school's Gender Equity Education Committee has established that the allegations are true, they will be laid off immediately and will never be allowed to work for any schools again.

The KMT legislators who introduced the amendment said the amendment is necessary because under the existing law, teachers who are suspended pending investigation into their alleged sexual assaults can still receive half of their salaries, and after the period of suspension is over, they can return to their teaching posts, placing students in peril.

Many of the teachers in Taiwan's schools who molested their students are repeat offenders, Feng Chiao-lan, director-general of the Humanistic Education Foundation, pointed out at a public hearing held at the legislature before the legislators began to screen the amendment.
Feng deplored that school principals usually play down the incidents and allow teachers to continue to serve in their teaching posts.

From 2006 to 2008, a total of 288 sexual assault cases occurred in Taiwan's schools at all levels, according to statistics compiled by the Domestic Violence and Sexual Assault Prevention Committee under the Ministry of the Interior.
The statistics also show that nearly all the victims were students, with 68 percent of the them being underage.

The amendment was introduced by legislators of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), including Huang Chao-shun and Chao Li-yun. It will be submitted to the legislature to undergo a floor debate and the second and third readings before becoming law.

Meanwhile, senior education officials said the Ministry of Education will establish a sex offenders registry, which will allow the personnel offices of all schools to find out easily whether an applicant for a teaching job is a sex offender.

The officials said that the database will include the ID numbers of all the teachers fired because of their sexual offenses against students, and that even if they have changed their names, they can still be identified easily.

DOC.HEADLINE: DHL Taiwan operational center expected to help lure investors

TEXT.P: The soon-to-be-inaugurated DHL operational center in Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport is being regarded as a powerful magnet to help attract investors to invest in a project to build an "aviation city" surrounding the airport near Taipei.

The new DHL operational center, located in the Farglory Free Trade Zone, will be inaugurated April 24. It will help raise shipment management efficiency of the international express and logistic service provider in Taiwan by three times, according to a DHL Taiwan executive.
The higher efficiency in handling cargo shipment is expected to attract companies to set up their operational base in the planned aviation city.
The construction of the new facility worth NT$210 million (US$6.16 million) began in August 2007.
An aviation city, also known as an aerotropolis, is a new type of mini-city comprising aviation-intensive businesses and related enterprises extending up to 25 kilometers outward from major airports.

The aviation city project to be built around the Taiwan Taoyuan airport is part of the major national construction development plans initiated by the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou, which is hoping to attract NT$1 trillion of foreign investment.
The project is expected to be completed by the year 2020.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOF agrees to open sniffer dog training center to public

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) agreed Monday to open its sniffer dog training center in central Taiwan to children on field trips.

Chien Liang-chi, the head of the MOF's Directorate General of Customs, made the pledge at a legislative committee meeting after ruling Kuomintang lawmaker Chen Shu-huey suggested opening the center to children so that they will learn that animals can carry out public duties.
She also suggested that sniffer dog figurines or dolls be produced to publicize the anti-drug campaign.
Chien noted that between June 2008 and March 2009, sniffer dogs detected 20 shipments of drugs worth NT$1 billion (US$28.59 million).
The 12-hectare sniffer dog training center is located in Houli Village, Taichung County, and currently accommodates 32 dogs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Controversial star to retain role in Taipei Deaflympics: official

TEXT.P: Hong Kong action movie star Jackie Chan will stay on as an International Goodwill Ambassador for Deaflympics Taipei 2009 despite controversial comments he recently made about Taiwan's democracy, a Taipei City government official said Monday.

Emile Chih-jen Sheng, director of the city's Research, Development and Evaluation Commission and CEO of the 2009 Taipei Deaflympics Organizing Committee, said he did not agree with Chan's view, but that Chan's role as International Goodwill Ambassador for the Games will not be affected.
"Politics should be separated from sports, and Jackie Chan will not be replaced for the time being," Sheng said.
"If we really removed Chan from the role just because of some comments he made, it would in turn damage Taiwan's democratic image in the international area," he argued.

Sheng refused to answer whether Chan would be invited to take part in the games in Taipei, but he said the city government will let Chan know through the Organizing Committee that it felt Chan's comments were imprudent.
Speaking at the Boao Forum for Asia summit meeting on China's Hainan Island last Saturday, Chan opined that "Chinese need to be controlled" and that "freedom in Taiwan and Hong Kong is chaotic."
His comments drew a backlash from people in Taiwan and his native Hong Kong.
It is not the first time that Chan has trampled on Taiwan's democracy, he said.

DPP lawmaker Gao Jyh-peng said that if the city continued to use Chan as a spokesman for the 2009 Deaflympics, the DPP caucus would not rule out submitting a proposal to have the Executive Yuan cut off its funding for the event.
"Chan does not deserve the honor because he did not respect universally recognized democratic values," Gao said.
A group of DPP Taipei City councilors also handed a protest letter to the city government asking that Chan be replaced.
Later Monday, Minister without Portfolio Ovid J. L. Tseng said the Executive Yuan will not meddle in the controversy even though it is providing financial support to the city for the Deaflympics.
"Freedom of speech is respected in Taiwan's society, and I believe that Taipei City will carefully assess the issue, " he said.
The 21st Summer Deaflympics Taipei 2009 will be held Sept. 5-15.

DOC.HEADLINE: Irish couple adopts an orphan in central Taiwan

TEXT.P: A couple from Ireland on Monday finally met the boy they have waited for more than a year to adopt at an orphanage in Yunlin County in couth-central Taiwan.

Sean Thomas O'Neill and his wife Eileen Josephine O'Neill, accompanied by two children they adopted in China, arrived at the Hsin Yi orphanage in Siluo Township near noon and appeared excited to see the two-year-old boy, nicknamed Hsiao Cheng (little Cheng).
Through an interpreter, the couple said, "we like him very much!"
They said that although they have two children already, they'll still give the boy their very best when they bring Hsiao Cheng back to their homeland.
Wu Wen-hui, the head of the orphanage, recalled that Hsiao Cheng was sent to the orphanage five days after his birth at a local hospital.
His blood father was never identified, and his blood mother left soon after giving birth without leaving any forwarding address, Wu said.
The young boy has never known parents until meeting the O'Neills, Wu said, and he hoped that Hsiao Cheng would grow up happily in his new home.

DOC.HEADLINE: Budget for Taichung metro plan increased to over NT$50 billion

TEXT.P: The central government approved a revised budget Monday for the planned Taichung Mass Rapid Transit system in central Taiwan, increasing funding for the project to NT$51.39 billion (US$1.52 billion) from the previous NT$28.79 billion.

The Council for Economic Planning and Development gave the green light Monday to the 16.71-kilometer public transit project, which will link Taichung City's Beitun district to Taichung County's Wuri based on an amended plan.

The project was originally approved in 2004 with a budget of NT$28.79 billion but was not launched because the city never received the final go-ahead to begin the system's construction, according to Taichung City Transportation Bureau Director Wen Tai-hsin.

Five years later, Wen said, the cost has risen considerably even though the system's length remains the same because of the addition of three stations -- bringing the total to 18 -- a revision to the system's anti-vibration features, and building material inflation.
Construction of the project will begin in October this year, and its completion is slated for 2015, Wen said. It will be central Taiwan's first metro line.

DOC.HEADLINE: China keen on cross-strait financial cooperation: ex-official

TEXT.P: Former Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien said Monday that China is highly interested in cross-Taiwan Strait financial cooperation if the interaction between financial professionals from the two sides at the recently concluded Boao Forum for Asia (BFA) is any indication.
Chien gave his impressions of the annual forum in China's southern island province of Hainan after returning to Taiwan through Hong Kong Monday.
Chien, who also served as Taiwan's minister of foreign affairs and representative to the United States, attended the economic forum, which concluded April 19, in a private capacity.

He observed, however, that the closeness of cross-strait exchanges was reflected at one of the forum's financial seminars, which lasted 30 minutes longer than planned because of the enthusiastic exchange of views between individuals from the two sides.

Chien, who met with Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao and Wang Yi, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council, during the forum, also said that he was able to see many of his old friends from his days as a diplomat.

The BFA is a nongovernmental, nonprofit international organization and its annual conferences gather leaders in government, business and academia in Asia and other continents to share their visions on the most pressing issues in the region and the world at large.

DOC.HEADLINE: Referendums on nuclear waste dumping sites at least six months away

TEXT.P: The state-owned Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) indicated Monday that it will take at least six months before referendums can be held to determine if two Taiwanese townships will become low-level radioactive waste dumping sites.

Taipower officials said that the Ministry of Economic Affairs and Taipower have received a total of 138 letters raising various questions since March 16, when the ministry proposed in a bulletin that Daren Township in Taitung County in southeastern Taiwan and Wang-an Township in Penghu County off the west coast of Taiwan be designated as the radioactive waste storage sites.

According to regulations governing the selection of a nuclear waste dumping ground, the government must allow one month's time after the bulletin is released for the public to express their views on the issue and ask related questions.
Government authorities must gather all the views and answer all the questions before the voters in the two counties where the potential sites are located can determine the issue through referendum.
Taipower officials estimated that it will be at least six months before the two referendums take place.
Taipower has maintained a dumping site at the southeastern tip of Lanyu, also known as Orchid Island, off southeastern Taiwan for the low-level waste from its three nuclear power plants.

The dump was completed in 1982 without the knowledge and consent of the residents of Lanyu. Subsequent legislation requires that local residents in a particular county be consulted first and given the right to vote on whether they would agree to the construction of a dumping site in their area.

DOC.HEADLINE: High-risk family databank to be expanded: minister

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) will expand its high-risk family databank to prevent the occurrence of domestic violence-related cases, Interior Minister Liao Liou-yi said Monday.

Liao made the remarks at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting at which lawmakers from across the political spectrum expressed concern about the country's social relief network in the wake of several heart-wrenching abuse cases, including the dumping of a 10-month-old baby girl by her father into a pot of boiling water last Saturday.

Stressing that his heart ached upon learning of the baby girl's tragedy, Liao said his ministry immediately directed its office in central Taiwan's Changhua County to keep tabs on the case and offer all necessary assistance.
The baby girl was still in critical condition as of Monday evening.
At the moment, Liao said, the ministry keeps data on and tracks families with young children where the parents are alcoholic or addicted to drugs and are known to fight frequently.
In the future, Liao said more high-risk families, including those without young children, will be entered into the ministry's databank.
Lawmakers also suggested that the ministry reinforce contacts with borough chiefs to get first-hand information about domestic violence cases.
Liao pledged that his agency will devote more funding and manpower to improve its grassroots community information network to help stem domestic violence or child abuse cases.

DOC.HEADLINE: Suspected tornado damages eight houses in southern Taiwan

TEXT.P: A suspected tornado damaged eight homes in Tainan County in southern Taiwan Monday, but no casualties were reported.
Officials from the Tainan County government and the Beihe Township administration who inspected the damaged houses said they will help the owners apply for emergency relief.
Chung Shin-chuan, who witnessed the occurrence, said that at about 1:30 p.m., a suspected twister lasting about nine seconds swept across a neighborhood of Beihe Township, damaging a row of homes.
He said that one of the homes -- a wooden house -- was severely damaged, while seven others suffered varying degrees of damage.

Wu Guo-yu, 75, whose wooden house was hit hardest among the affected homes, said she was outside getting some fresh air shortly after taking a nap when a weird gust of wind with strange noises destroyed the roof and main beams supporting her house.
She has been brought to live in her son's home while the local government helps her repair her home.

DOC.HEADLINE: First Chinese group arrives in Taichung by sea through Kinmen

TEXT.P: A 259-member tour group on Monday became the first Chinese group to arrive in Taichung on a passenger vessel from China through Kinmen since travel to Taiwan was liberalized last year.

The large group, comprised mainly of tourists from Zhejiang province, first took a ferry from Xiamen, Fujian province, to Kinmen. After touring the outlying island, they then took a 10-hour overnight boat ride on the Kinmen Express, reaching Taichung Monday morning to begin a six-day tour of Taiwan proper.
It was the first time a Chinese group boarded a ship from Kinmen to Taichung. Previous groups have sailed directly to Kinmen before flying on to Taiwan.
King Hung Marine Co. has applied to sail the Taichung-Kinmen route 18 times from April to early July, with each run expecting to carry between 200 and 300 people.

Meanwhile, a ship carrying 923 Chinese tourists left by boat from Kaohsiung to Magong in the island county of Penghu, after concluding their tour of Taiwan. From there, they will return to Xiamen Tuesday via another direct shipping link.
Compared with the Zhejiang group, in which a number of passengers got seasick, the Fujian group said the four-and-a-half-hour ride to Magong was smooth and comfortable.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to spend NT$600 million on improving English proficiency

TEXT.P: The government will invest NT$600 million (US$17.66 million) over the next three years to enhance English proficiency among the local population, an official from the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) said Monday.

According to the official, the government's top economic planning agency, the Council for Economic Planning and Development, has approved the RDEC-proposed plan to upgrade the English ability of Taiwan's residents.
The program will include the establishment of several English villages and the replacement of bilingual (Chinese-English) signboards at various government agencies.

From 2010 through 2012, the official said, the government will set aside a budget of NT$200 million per year for the program, which will also include cultivating manpower, upgrading major local cities' international competitiveness, building an English-friendly environment and strengthening services to foreign expatriates.

The official also said the number of planned "English Villages" -- a real English-speaking community that immerses its students in all-English environment to provide an alternative for those who cannot afford private tutoring or overseas study programs -- will be more than one or two as reported by the local media.

"Schools around the country that have unused or vacated classrooms are wlecome to apply to establish an 'English Village, '" the official said, adding that private groups can also apply for the construction of an "English Village" in line with the existing statute encouraging private investors to invest in public infrastructure construction.
It is hoped that the "English Village" project will be able to enroll 3,000 people, or 1,000 per year, who eventually obtain certificates proving they are proficient in English.

The government will also conduct annual surveys among foreign expatriates living in Taiwan to get their opinions on the country's English environment and hope to improve the average level of satisfaction by 1 percent a year to 68 percent in 2012.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, increasing NT$0.014 to close at NT$33.830.
A total of US$798 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$33.955 before dropping to the day's low of NT$33.754.
