In 2001, the legislature revised the law again according to a proposal by Hsieh Chi-ta, at the time a legislator of the opposition New Party, to set a ceiling of NT$1 million for funeral compensation, which was later raised again to NT$2 million following demands of insurance businesses.

Commenting on the issue, Chiang Chao-kuo, a law professor at National Taipei University, suggested that parents should be allowed to purchase medical or annuity insurance policies for their children that "are only payable as long as the insured is still alive."

According to statistics of the Life Insurance Association, as of the end of 2008, the total population of children aged under 14 stood at just over 3.9 million, more than 2.5 million of whom had private insurance -- mostly medical insurance -- packages.

DOC.HEADLINE: Law being amended to weed out sex offenders from schools

TEXT.P: Two Legislative Yuan committees adopted an amendment Monday, paving the way for legislation to weed out teachers in Taiwan's schools who are found to have molested their students.

The lawmakers serving on the Judiciary and Organic Laws and Statutes Committee and the Education and Culture Committee held a joint meeting and adopted the amendment to the Statute Governing the Appointment of Educators.

The amendment would require teachers accused of sexual assaults against their students be suspended from their posts. If the school's Gender Equity Education Committee has established that the allegations are true, they will be laid off immediately and will never be allowed to work for any schools again.

The KMT legislators who introduced the amendment said the amendment is necessary because under the existing law, teachers who are suspended pending investigation into their alleged sexual assaults can still receive half of their salaries, and after the period of suspension is over, they can return to their teaching posts, placing students in peril.

Many of the teachers in Taiwan's schools who molested their students are repeat offenders, Feng Chiao-lan, director-general of the Humanistic Education Foundation, pointed out at a public hearing held at the legislature before the legislators began to screen the amendment.
Feng deplored that school principals usually play down the incidents and allow teachers to continue to serve in their teaching posts.

From 2006 to 2008, a total of 288 sexual assault cases occurred in Taiwan's schools at all levels, according to statistics compiled by the Domestic Violence and Sexual Assault Prevention Committee under the Ministry of the Interior.
The statistics also show that nearly all the victims were students, with 68 percent of the them being underage.

The amendment was introduced by legislators of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), including Huang Chao-shun and Chao Li-yun. It will be submitted to the legislature to undergo a floor debate and the second and third readings before becoming law.

Meanwhile, senior education officials said the Ministry of Education will establish a sex offenders registry, which will allow the personnel offices of all schools to find out easily whether an applicant for a teaching job is a sex offender.

The officials said that the database will include the ID numbers of all the teachers fired because of their sexual offenses against students, and that even if they have changed their names, they can still be identified easily.

DOC.HEADLINE: DHL Taiwan operational center expected to help lure investors

TEXT.P: The soon-to-be-inaugurated DHL operational center in Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport is being regarded as a powerful magnet to help attract investors to invest in a project to build an "aviation city" surrounding the airport near Taipei.

The new DHL operational center, located in the Farglory Free Trade Zone, will be inaugurated April 24. It will help raise shipment management efficiency of the international express and logistic service provider in Taiwan by three times, according to a DHL Taiwan executive.
The higher efficiency in handling cargo shipment is expected to attract companies to set up their operational base in the planned aviation city.
The construction of the new facility worth NT$210 million (US$6.16 million) began in August 2007.
An aviation city, also known as an aerotropolis, is a new type of mini-city comprising aviation-intensive businesses and related enterprises extending up to 25 kilometers outward from major airports.

The aviation city project to be built around the Taiwan Taoyuan airport is part of the major national construction development plans initiated by the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou, which is hoping to attract NT$1 trillion of foreign investment.
The project is expected to be completed by the year 2020.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOF agrees to open sniffer dog training center to public

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) agreed Monday to open its sniffer dog training center in central Taiwan to children on field trips.

Chien Liang-chi, the head of the MOF's Directorate General of Customs, made the pledge at a legislative committee meeting after ruling Kuomintang lawmaker Chen Shu-huey suggested opening the center to children so that they will learn that animals can carry out public duties.
She also suggested that sniffer dog figurines or dolls be produced to publicize the anti-drug campaign.
Chien noted that between June 2008 and March 2009, sniffer dogs detected 20 shipments of drugs worth NT$1 billion (US$28.59 million).
The 12-hectare sniffer dog training center is located in Houli Village, Taichung County, and currently accommodates 32 dogs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Controversial star to retain role in Taipei Deaflympics: official

TEXT.P: Hong Kong action movie star Jackie Chan will stay on as an International Goodwill Ambassador for Deaflympics Taipei 2009 despite controversial comments he recently made about Taiwan's democracy, a Taipei City government official said Monday.

Emile Chih-jen Sheng, director of the city's Research, Development and Evaluation Commission and CEO of the 2009 Taipei Deaflympics Organizing Committee, said he did not agree with Chan's view, but that Chan's role as International Goodwill Ambassador for the Games will not be affected.
"Politics should be separated from sports, and Jackie Chan will not be replaced for the time being," Sheng said.
"If we really removed Chan from the role just because of some comments he made, it would in turn damage Taiwan's democratic image in the international area," he argued.

Sheng refused to answer whether Chan would be invited to take part in the games in Taipei, but he said the city government will let Chan know through the Organizing Committee that it felt Chan's comments were imprudent.
Speaking at the Boao Forum for Asia summit meeting on China's Hainan Island last Saturday, Chan opined that "Chinese need to be controlled" and that "freedom in Taiwan and Hong Kong is chaotic."
His comments drew a backlash from people in Taiwan and his native Hong Kong.
It is not the first time that Chan has trampled on Taiwan's democracy, he said.

DPP lawmaker Gao Jyh-peng said that if the city continued to use Chan as a spokesman for the 2009 Deaflympics, the DPP caucus would not rule out submitting a proposal to have the Executive Yuan cut off its funding for the event.
"Chan does not deserve the honor because he did not respect universally recognized democratic values," Gao said.
A group of DPP Taipei City councilors also handed a protest letter to the city government asking that Chan be replaced.
Later Monday, Minister without Portfolio Ovid J. L. Tseng said the Executive Yuan will not meddle in the controversy even though it is providing financial support to the city for the Deaflympics.
"Freedom of speech is respected in Taiwan's society, and I believe that Taipei City will carefully assess the issue, " he said.
The 21st Summer Deaflympics Taipei 2009 will be held Sept. 5-15.

DOC.HEADLINE: Irish couple adopts an orphan in central Taiwan

TEXT.P: A couple from Ireland on Monday finally met the boy they have waited for more than a year to adopt at an orphanage in Yunlin County in couth-central Taiwan.

Sean Thomas O'Neill and his wife Eileen Josephine O'Neill, accompanied by two children they adopted in China, arrived at the Hsin Yi orphanage in Siluo Township near noon and appeared excited to see the two-year-old boy, nicknamed Hsiao Cheng (little Cheng).
Through an interpreter, the couple said, "we like him very much!"
They said that although they have two children already, they'll still give the boy their very best when they bring Hsiao Cheng back to their homeland.
Wu Wen-hui, the head of the orphanage, recalled that Hsiao Cheng was sent to the orphanage five days after his birth at a local hospital.
His blood father was never identified, and his blood mother left soon after giving birth without leaving any forwarding address, Wu said.
The young boy has never known parents until meeting the O'Neills, Wu said, and he hoped that Hsiao Cheng would grow up happily in his new home.

DOC.HEADLINE: Budget for Taichung metro plan increased to over NT$50 billion

TEXT.P: The central government approved a revised budget Monday for the planned Taichung Mass Rapid Transit system in central Taiwan, increasing funding for the project to NT$51.39 billion (US$1.52 billion) from the previous NT$28.79 billion.

The Council for Economic Planning and Development gave the green light Monday to the 16.71-kilometer public transit project, which will link Taichung City's Beitun district to Taichung County's Wuri based on an amended plan.

The project was originally approved in 2004 with a budget of NT$28.79 billion but was not launched because the city never received the final go-ahead to begin the system's construction, according to Taichung City Transportation Bureau Director Wen Tai-hsin.

Five years later, Wen said, the cost has risen considerably even though the system's length remains the same because of the addition of three stations -- bringing the total to 18 -- a revision to the system's anti-vibration features, and building material inflation.
Construction of the project will begin in October this year, and its completion is slated for 2015, Wen said. It will be central Taiwan's first metro line.

DOC.HEADLINE: China keen on cross-strait financial cooperation: ex-official

TEXT.P: Former Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien said Monday that China is highly interested in cross-Taiwan Strait financial cooperation if the interaction between financial professionals from the two sides at the recently concluded Boao Forum for Asia (BFA) is any indication.
Chien gave his impressions of the annual forum in China's southern island province of Hainan after returning to Taiwan through Hong Kong Monday.
Chien, who also served as Taiwan's minister of foreign affairs and representative to the United States, attended the economic forum, which concluded April 19, in a private capacity.

He observed, however, that the closeness of cross-strait exchanges was reflected at one of the forum's financial seminars, which lasted 30 minutes longer than planned because of the enthusiastic exchange of views between individuals from the two sides.

Chien, who met with Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao and Wang Yi, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council, during the forum, also said that he was able to see many of his old friends from his days as a diplomat.

The BFA is a nongovernmental, nonprofit international organization and its annual conferences gather leaders in government, business and academia in Asia and other continents to share their visions on the most pressing issues in the region and the world at large.

DOC.HEADLINE: Referendums on nuclear waste dumping sites at least six months away

TEXT.P: The state-owned Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) indicated Monday that it will take at least six months before referendums can be held to determine if two Taiwanese townships will become low-level radioactive waste dumping sites.

Taipower officials said that the Ministry of Economic Affairs and Taipower have received a total of 138 letters raising various questions since March 16, when the ministry proposed in a bulletin that Daren Township in Taitung County in southeastern Taiwan and Wang-an Township in Penghu County off the west coast of Taiwan be designated as the radioactive waste storage sites.

According to regulations governing the selection of a nuclear waste dumping ground, the government must allow one month's time after the bulletin is released for the public to express their views on the issue and ask related questions.
Government authorities must gather all the views and answer all the questions before the voters in the two counties where the potential sites are located can determine the issue through referendum.
Taipower officials estimated that it will be at least six months before the two referendums take place.
Taipower has maintained a dumping site at the southeastern tip of Lanyu, also known as Orchid Island, off southeastern Taiwan for the low-level waste from its three nuclear power plants.

The dump was completed in 1982 without the knowledge and consent of the residents of Lanyu. Subsequent legislation requires that local residents in a particular county be consulted first and given the right to vote on whether they would agree to the construction of a dumping site in their area.

DOC.HEADLINE: High-risk family databank to be expanded: minister

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) will expand its high-risk family databank to prevent the occurrence of domestic violence-related cases, Interior Minister Liao Liou-yi said Monday.

Liao made the remarks at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting at which lawmakers from across the political spectrum expressed concern about the country's social relief network in the wake of several heart-wrenching abuse cases, including the dumping of a 10-month-old baby girl by her father into a pot of boiling water last Saturday.

Stressing that his heart ached upon learning of the baby girl's tragedy, Liao said his ministry immediately directed its office in central Taiwan's Changhua County to keep tabs on the case and offer all necessary assistance.
The baby girl was still in critical condition as of Monday evening.
At the moment, Liao said, the ministry keeps data on and tracks families with young children where the parents are alcoholic or addicted to drugs and are known to fight frequently.
In the future, Liao said more high-risk families, including those without young children, will be entered into the ministry's databank.
Lawmakers also suggested that the ministry reinforce contacts with borough chiefs to get first-hand information about domestic violence cases.
Liao pledged that his agency will devote more funding and manpower to improve its grassroots community information network to help stem domestic violence or child abuse cases.

DOC.HEADLINE: Suspected tornado damages eight houses in southern Taiwan

TEXT.P: A suspected tornado damaged eight homes in Tainan County in southern Taiwan Monday, but no casualties were reported.
Officials from the Tainan County government and the Beihe Township administration who inspected the damaged houses said they will help the owners apply for emergency relief.
Chung Shin-chuan, who witnessed the occurrence, said that at about 1:30 p.m., a suspected twister lasting about nine seconds swept across a neighborhood of Beihe Township, damaging a row of homes.
He said that one of the homes -- a wooden house -- was severely damaged, while seven others suffered varying degrees of damage.

Wu Guo-yu, 75, whose wooden house was hit hardest among the affected homes, said she was outside getting some fresh air shortly after taking a nap when a weird gust of wind with strange noises destroyed the roof and main beams supporting her house.
She has been brought to live in her son's home while the local government helps her repair her home.

DOC.HEADLINE: First Chinese group arrives in Taichung by sea through Kinmen

TEXT.P: A 259-member tour group on Monday became the first Chinese group to arrive in Taichung on a passenger vessel from China through Kinmen since travel to Taiwan was liberalized last year.

The large group, comprised mainly of tourists from Zhejiang province, first took a ferry from Xiamen, Fujian province, to Kinmen. After touring the outlying island, they then took a 10-hour overnight boat ride on the Kinmen Express, reaching Taichung Monday morning to begin a six-day tour of Taiwan proper.
It was the first time a Chinese group boarded a ship from Kinmen to Taichung. Previous groups have sailed directly to Kinmen before flying on to Taiwan.
King Hung Marine Co. has applied to sail the Taichung-Kinmen route 18 times from April to early July, with each run expecting to carry between 200 and 300 people.

Meanwhile, a ship carrying 923 Chinese tourists left by boat from Kaohsiung to Magong in the island county of Penghu, after concluding their tour of Taiwan. From there, they will return to Xiamen Tuesday via another direct shipping link.
Compared with the Zhejiang group, in which a number of passengers got seasick, the Fujian group said the four-and-a-half-hour ride to Magong was smooth and comfortable.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to spend NT$600 million on improving English proficiency

TEXT.P: The government will invest NT$600 million (US$17.66 million) over the next three years to enhance English proficiency among the local population, an official from the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) said Monday.

According to the official, the government's top economic planning agency, the Council for Economic Planning and Development, has approved the RDEC-proposed plan to upgrade the English ability of Taiwan's residents.
The program will include the establishment of several English villages and the replacement of bilingual (Chinese-English) signboards at various government agencies.

From 2010 through 2012, the official said, the government will set aside a budget of NT$200 million per year for the program, which will also include cultivating manpower, upgrading major local cities' international competitiveness, building an English-friendly environment and strengthening services to foreign expatriates.

The official also said the number of planned "English Villages" -- a real English-speaking community that immerses its students in all-English environment to provide an alternative for those who cannot afford private tutoring or overseas study programs -- will be more than one or two as reported by the local media.

"Schools around the country that have unused or vacated classrooms are wlecome to apply to establish an 'English Village, '" the official said, adding that private groups can also apply for the construction of an "English Village" in line with the existing statute encouraging private investors to invest in public infrastructure construction.
It is hoped that the "English Village" project will be able to enroll 3,000 people, or 1,000 per year, who eventually obtain certificates proving they are proficient in English.

The government will also conduct annual surveys among foreign expatriates living in Taiwan to get their opinions on the country's English environment and hope to improve the average level of satisfaction by 1 percent a year to 68 percent in 2012.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open sharply lower

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened sharply lower Tuesday, moving down 115.72 points at 5,665.94 on a turnover of NT$3.33 billion (US$98.43 million).
The weighted price index gained 26.28 points, or 0.45 percent, to close at 5,781.66 Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 21, or the 26th day of the third month of the Year of Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1634: Jan van Riebeeck, Dutch naval surgeon and founder of Cape Town, South Africa, is born.
1898: The United States declares war on Spain.
1910: Mark Twain, pen name of Samuel Langhorne Clemens, American author and humorist, dies at the age of 74. He drew on his childhood along the Mississippi River to create masterpieces of humor and sarcasm, including "Tom Sawyer" and "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn."
1926: Elizabeth II, Queen of England since 1952, is born.
1930: Fire breaks out at the Ohio state penitentiary, killing 355 people.
1935: An earthquake hits central and northern Taiwan, killing some 3,000 people.
1937: Steamships formally begin plying a regular weekly route between Shanghai and San Francisco.
1946: British economist John Maynard Keynes dies at the age of 63. He proposed that high unemployment, being a result of insufficient consumer spending, can be relieved by government-sponsored programs.
1948: Republic of China troops evacuate Yenan.
1949: The Chinese communists resume an all-out offensive and cross the Yangtze River.
1954: The United States flies a French battalion to Indochina to defend Dien Bien Phu, which is overrun by Vietnamese forces three weeks later.
1957: Taiwan voters go to the polls for the third time to elect county magistrates, city mayors and provincial assemblymen.
1958: The Taiwan Provincial Assembly building in Wufeng, Taichung County, is inaugurated.
1960: Brazil moves its capital from Rio de Janeiro to Brazilia, the brain-child of President Juselino Kubitschek.
1966: The ROC and Dahomey resume diplomatic relations.
1971: Haitian dictator Francois Duvalier, known as "Papa Doc," dies at the age of 64. Elected president in 1957, he declared himself president for life in 1964 and ruled in an authoritarian manner until his death. He was succeeded by his son Jean-Claude, who fled the country in 1986 after widespread civil unrest.
1975: South Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu resigns after denouncing the United States as untrustworthy.
1987: Terrorists detonate a bomb near the main bus station in Colombo, Sri Lanka, killing and injuring more than 400 people.
1989: More than 10,000 workers and students clamoring for democracy and human rights march from campuses to converge on Tiananmen Square in Beijing in defiance of official warnings against anti-government protests.
1997: An advance contingent of communist Chinese troops enter Hong Kong in preparation for the July 1 handover of the British crown colony to communist China.
1998: Seoul drops efforts to receive Japanese compensation for women held as sex slaves during World War II and says it will pay the surviving women.
1999: A survey conducted by the Switzerland-based Business Environment Risk Intelligence ranks Taiwan as the least risky area for investment in the world.
1999: Renowned local writer Su Hsueh-lin, winner of the Chungshan Literature Prize and the National Literature Prize, dies at the age of 104.
2000: Taiwanese "Go" player Wang Li-cheng wins the title of "Go Sage," the highest title and honor for any Go professional in Japan.
2000: Tsai Ying-wen, an advisor to the National Security Council and a professor at National Chengchi University, is confirmed chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council.
2001: A pro-unification organization urges Taiwan's three main opposition parties to monitor the Democratic Progressive Party-led government to prevent Taiwan from "marching toward independence."
Confucius lesson of the day: "A good horse is considered so not because of its mere brute strength but because of its moral qualities."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was traded at NT$33.922 at 9:45 a.m. Tuesday on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.092 from Monday's close.

DOC.HEADLINE: Baby girl dumped into pot of boiling water dies

TEXT.P: The baby girl the nation has been praying for after she was dumped by her father in a pot of boiling water Saturday died Tuesday morning.
Changhua Christian Hospital doctors said the baby died of multiple organ failure, and the doctors took her off a life-support system at 10:05 a.m.
The 10-month-old girl, who was thrown into the boiling water by her father during a quarrel with the girl's mother, suffered second- and third-degree burns over 84 percent of her body.
The girl had been in critical condition since being rushed to the hospital by her mother after the incident.
The father is being held in custody by prosecutors and could face homicide charges.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
MOFA to release first white paper on foreign aid policy in May

TEXT.P: A long-awaited "white paper" on foreign aid, which will outline the country's new thinking on "professional and effective" overseas assistance, will be released next month, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

Now that the statistics of our foreign aid programs have been compiled according to the standards of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) , the white paper is scheduled to be released in early May, said Weber Shih, director-general of the MOFA's Department of Economic and Trade Affairs.

The main goal for issuing a foreign aid white paper is to bring Taiwan's overseas aid program in line with international trends, " Shih said of the initiative, which will be the first white paper Taiwan has ever issued on the subject.

The ministry first broached the idea of a white paper last September and had initially planned to release the study late last year, but efforts to bring the project's methodology in line with international standards resulted in delays.

According to Shih, the paper will use theParis Declaration on Aid Effectivenessand the United NationsMillennium Development Goals as references and stress "transparency and professionalism" as the future direction of Taiwan's overseas assistance.

The goal ofprogressive partnerships and sustainable developmentwill be clearly indicated in the white paper, " Shih said, adding that Taiwan will help its diplomatic allies achieve long-term development through the transfer of its expertise in various fields.

Besides bilateral aid programs, Taiwan will also provide aid through multilateral channels by strengthening its cooperation with international organizations such as the World Trade Organization's Aid for Trade program, Shih said.

A special exhibition will be held later in May to demonstrate Taiwan's foreign aid achievements over the years and help the public better understand the functions of the country's International Cooperation and Development Fund, he added.
Taiwan's foreign aid program has been criticized in the past by the international community for its use as a tool to solicit the recognition of countries in a diplomatic tug-of-war with China.

After President Ma Ying-jeou took office last May, the government has considered overhauling its foreign aid program based on a "diplomatic truce" in which Taiwan and China tacitly agree not to vie for each other's allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mini-knife maker achieves unexpected success

TEXT.P: The small knives made by Yang Ming-shan, a member of the Taroko tribe in Hualien County, have recently gained popularity with tourists to the area, but he admits that he never would have had the idea if it had not been for his son.
"Because my son kept asking for toys, I tried to make him an miniature aboriginal machete," the 40-year-old Yang recalls.

Yang had been a motorcycle repair technician since he graduated from junior high school and set up a motorcycle repair shop in Wenlan Village in the eastern county's Sioulin Township in 1992. His wife operates a betel nut shop at a tourist service center in nearby Dongmen village.
"One day, my son saw a knife I took along with me and asked for one as a kind of toy. I had no choice but to make a miniature version for him, " Yang remembers.

The episode fueled his interest in making traditional aboriginal knives. He began crafting a series of small knives, ranging from 5.5 centimeters to 12 centimeters in length, that are based on real Taroko tribal machetes of 58 cm in length.
Yang attributed his success in producing the knives to the "skills I obtained working as a motorcycle repair technician and indigenous people's talent for handicrafts."

Yang's creation has become popular among tourists visiting Hualien after knife sheaths he made with juniper wood, which can be used as key rings and mobile phone and bag pendant straps, were put on sale at his wife's store.

Knives play an important role in many aspects of aboriginal life, being widely used for hunting, farming, working and preparing food and were once used as a betrothal gift given to the bride's family by the groom's family.

With the growing popularity of the knives, producing them has become Yang's main job while repairing motorcycles has been relegated to a sideline occupation. His wife and his brother-in-law are sometimes called on to lend a hand to meet increasing demand.

The popularity of the knives has not been without a significant downside, however, as a number of low-priced copies of his products made in China have swarmed into the local market hoping to piggyback on Yang's success.
The knife marker hopes to use innovation and new products to stay ahead of the competition created by the cheap knock-offs from China.

Yang said that the Taroko tribe is the only one of Taiwan's 14 indigenous tribes to make knives, and he vowed to stick with the industry and develop more products to protect and promote his tribe's unique culture.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma donates NT$100,000 to Taitung hospital

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou donated NT$100,000 (US$3,000) Monday to St. Mary's Hospital in Taitung City after learning of its financial difficulties.

The hospital, long dedicated to providing health care to underprivileged people in southeastern Taiwan, hopes to raise NT$31.42 million by November and transform itself into a nonprofit health care provider, which would allow it to survive.

The hospital, set up by foreign missionaries 48 years ago, is facing closure because of heavy operating deficits in recent years, and becoming a nonprofit entity would enable it to cushion losses with private donations and other public funding contributions.
Earlier the same day, Taitung County Magistrate Kuang Li-chen also donated NT$50,000 to St. Mary's Hospital and called for greater public attention and assistance to the establishment.
The hospital recently launched a campaign to reach its fund-raising target in which it is soliciting NT$10,000 donations from 3,000 donors to help it survive, but it remains a long way from its goal.
St. Mary's hospital was the sole winner of the nationwide "Group Medical Contribution Award" last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Growth in jobless rate slowing down: CLA

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) assured the public Tuesday that the unemployment rate for March would post only a slight increase from the previous month as the country's worsening jobless situation has shown signs of moderation.

CLA Minister Wang Ju-hsuan noted that since the global financial storm hit last September, Taiwan's unemployment rate has been rising by 0.3 percentage points per month on average, reaching 5.75 percent in February.
However, the recent influx of rush orders for Taiwan's industrial sector has helped moderate the situation, Wang said.
She predicted that the official unemployment rate for March -- set to be released Wednesday -- "won't exceed 6 percent, though it will be slightly higher than in February."
She said the improvement in the unemployment situation is also reflected in the declining number of first-time applicants for unemployment benefits.
From December to February, an average over 30,000 people per month applied for the benefits for the first time after becoming unemployed, but the number dropped to 28,000 in March, Wang said.
During the first 20 days of April, there were just 14,000 such applications, she added.
Wang warned, however, that the unemployment rate could rise again in August and September, when many of this year's graduates are expected to enter the job market.
The CLA also announced Tuesday the introduction of a program aimed at providing psychological support for the country's unemployed.

One main element of the program is free psychological counseling offered by a team of more than 70 experts and therapists. Appointments for the service can be made through any government-run employment service station or by the workers themselves by calling (02) 2557-6841.
In addition, a regular radio program on labor law and psychological issues will be launched April 28 in cooperation with the Taiwan-based Broadcasting Corporation of China.
Meanwhile, various resources will be made available to the public on the CLA's Web site and employment service stations around the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former NBA star to serve as Deaflympics ambassador

TEXT.P: Former NBA star Scottie Pippen will serve as a goodwill ambassador for the 21st Summer Deaflympics Taipei 2009, the chief executive director of the Deaflympics Organizing Committee said Tuesday.

Emile Sheng said that Pippen will arrive in Taiwan April 24 and will share his basketball experiences with Taiwan's high school champion Song-Shan Senior High School and Taiwan's Deaflympic basketball team the following day.
He will also shoot a TV commercial to promote the Games.
On April 26, Pippen will appear at a Super Basketball League (SBL) game in Sinjhuang Gymnasium and will show off some of his skills to the crowd, before leaving the following day.
Pippen teamed with Michael Jordan to help the Chicago Bulls win six NBA championships in the 1990s.

Sheng said the committee is still trying to invite two other international sports stars of Pippen's stature to Taiwan to also serve as goodwill ambassadors, but the final details have yet to be worked out.
Hong Kong action star Jackie Chan and former actress Lin Ching-hsia are also serving as ambassadors for the Deaflympics, which are scheduled for Sept. 5-15.

DOC.HEADLINE: Giant, China Airlines join forces to boost bike tourism

TEXT.P: Taiwan's largest bicycle manufacturer, Giant Inc., and the country's largest air carrier, China Airlines (CAL), signed an agreement Monday to jointly promote bicycle tourism in Taiwan.

Under the agreement signed by Giant Chairman King Liu and CAL Chairman Wei Hsing-hsiung, the two companies will pool their resources to promote Taiwan globally as a cycling mecca. They will seek to lure more visitors from abroad by selling bike tours as a way to experience the island's beauty and local people's hospitality.
Wei said that CAL, in collaboration with a Taiwan travel agency, launched a cycling tour of Okinawa in Japan in February which drew an enthusiastic response from tourists.
In the future, more cycling travel packages will be offered at CAL and Giant's domestic and overseas operating centers and outlets, he added.
Liu said the agreement is also aimed at arranging local and foreign bike tours for Taiwan residents and boosting public interest in that type of eco-friendly tourism.

According to the Giant chairman, Taiwan is well-suited to the development of bicycle tourism, given that its bicycle production standards are among the highest in the world and that Giant has vast experience in providing bicycle rental and maintenance services.
Liu said that the strategic alliance between the CAL and Giant is expected to benefit their respective customers and boost Taiwan's tourism industry.
He also disclosed that Giant has applied to the Ministry of Transportation and Communication for permission to open a travel agency in June to offer bike tour packages in Taiwan and elsewhere.
The travel agency is likely to create a business worth hundreds of millions of New Taiwan dollars, Liu forecast.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economics ministry launches energy saving campaign

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) launched an energy-saving campaign Tuesday, on the eve of Earth Day, calling on the public to turn off electric appliances when they are not in use and thus save an estimated 3.5 billion units of energy per year.

Huang Jung-chiou, vice minister of the MOEA, said at a news conference, held under the theme "Love the Earth, it's our business to switch off," that turning off electric appliances is the easiest way to start saving energy and that it requires everyone's participation to save the Earth.
"A simple action such as switching off electric appliances can help people to shape a completely different attitude in life," Huang said.
"Each little effort can add up to make a major difference to the Earth," he added.

According to the MOEA's Bureau of Energy and the Cabinet-level Directorate- General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, switching off the six most commonly used home and office appliances -- copy machines, printers, office water dispensers, drinking fountains, home electric thermos and computers -- can save 3.5 billion units of energy per year. This is equivalent to the amount of energy used annually by 950,000 households and can reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 2.26 million tons per year, he said.
Most startlingly, Huang added, the statistics show that 85.2 percent of the country's 6 million office water dispensers are usually left on around the clock, seven days a week.
If these machines are switched off after office hours, this could easily save 1.34 billion energy units annually and reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 854,000 tons per year, he said.
As part of the "switch off campaign," the public should use electric timers with an automatic on-off switches to conserve energy, the MOEA suggested.

In response to the government's call, representatives from 28 companies and industrial groups joined Tuesday's news conference, pledging to take the lead in switching off electric appliances after office hours and to help raise awareness among their customers of the importance of saving energy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices rise on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed 1.72 percent higher Tuesday, bolstered by tourism and property shares on hopes of an increase in Chinese tourist arrivals and that closer ties between Taiwan and China would give a boost to the industries.
The weighted index, the market's key barometer, advanced 99.75 points, to close at 5,881.41.
Shrugging off an early weakness that followed a 289-point loss for the Dow Jones Industrial Average, the local bourse opened at 5,665.94 and fluctuated between 5,881.41 and 5,663.56.
A total of 5.74 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$122.43 billion (US$3.62 billion).

All the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction stocks moving up the most at 5.7 percent. Paper and pulp issues gained 5 percent, foodstuff shares added 3.2 percent, cement stocks surged 2.5 percent, plastics and chemicals issues rose 2.0 percent, machinery and electronics stocks as well as textile issues advanced 1.6 percent, and banking and financial stocks rose 1.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,630 to 529, with 124 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$6.17 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, increasing NT$0.030 to close at NT$33.860.
A total of US$753 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.960 and fluctuated between NT$33.750 and NT$34.000.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2 Panamanian tanker crewmen barred from leaving Taiwan

TEXT.P: Two crew members of the Panama-registered tanker TOSA have been barred from leaving Taiwan for the time being to assist prosecutors in the investigation into the sinking of a Taiwanese fishing boat last Friday, prosecutors said Tuesday.
The TOSA was suspected of having hit the 99-ton Hsing Tong Chuan No.86 fishing vessel that sank near the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands early last Friday.
Eleven of the 13 crew members of the sunken ship, based in Suao in the northeastern county of Yilan, were rescued, but the ship's captain Ho Si-chuan and chief engineer Hsu Tsung-wen remain missing.
The 160,000-ton TOSA was escorted to Hualien Harbor by a Taiwanese coast guard vessel on the eastern Taiwan coast Saturday pending investigation into the matter.

Huang Yi-chun, a Hualien chief prosecutor, said that both navigation and track maps as well as the results of detective police work show that the Panamanian tanker was passing the disaster site when the fishing boat was sinking.

During the interrogations, Huang said, neither the tanker's first mate, second mate nor its night-watch sailor admitted that the tanker had hit the fishing boat. But they did not deny that the tanker was passing the site as the boat was sinking, the prosecutor added.
Huang said if the two Taiwanese crewmen aboard the sunken ship have indeed died, certain tanker crew members may be indicted on charges of involuntary manslaughter.
Against this backdrop, Huang said, the tanker's second mate and night-duty sailor have been barred from leaving Taiwan pending further investigations into the cause of the fishing vessel's sinking.
According to Huang, the tanker's owner is willing to pay damages if there is sufficient evidence to prove that the tanker was liable in the fishing boat's sinking.
The Hsing Tong Chuan crew members who were rescued include one Taiwanese fisherman, two Chinese, six Indonesians and two Filipinos.

DOC.HEADLINE: Baby girl thrown into pot of boiling water dies (Update)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/09 19:17:29 (By Lilian Wu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A 10-month old girl who suffered severe burns after her father threw her in a pot of boiling water in a case that shocked Taiwan, died Tuesday morning.
Her father, who was arrested following the incident on Saturday, could face the death penalty, a prosecutor said later.

Despite intensive efforts by doctors to try to save the girl, who suffered second and third-degree burns over 84 percent of her body, she died of multiple organ failure, according to doctors at Changhua Christian Hospital in central Taiwan's Changhua City.
With consent of her mother, who did not want her daughter to continue to suffer the immense pain, the girl was pronounced dead after doctors took her off a life-support system at 10:05 a.m.
The baby had been in critical condition since being rushed to the hospital by her mother after her father, surnamed Huang, did the unimaginable act during an argument with her mother.

The infant's mother, identified only by her family name of Lin, immediately scooped the baby out of the pot in the noodle shop they owned and rushed to a nearby police station for help, whereupon officers immediately sent the baby to the hospital's burn center.

The father, 47, is being held on a homicide charge, and would face either the death penalty, life imprisonment or a jail term of over 15 years, Chang Hui- chung, a prosecutor at the Changhua Prosecutors Office.
"The punishment will be 50 percent more severe because the victim is a small child," said Chang.

The case has ignited anger from people across the country who questioned how someone could harm a child in such a way. Many people prayed for the girl, with some religious people maintaining a vigil at the hospital. Nurses were in tears as they changed the baby's bandages, seeing the pain she was going through.

The incident has also raised concerns about the increase in violence against children in Taiwan since the economic downturn began to be widely felt last year on the island, which is suffering from record unemployment and a sharp decline in GDP and exports.

The nonprofit Taiwan Fund for Children and Families (TFCF) said earlier this month that as the economy has worsened, it has observed a growing rate of domestic violence against children, triggered primarily by a lack of parenting skills, unemployment, and poverty.

As of March, 46 cases of domestic violence involving 73 children, including eight who died, have been reported this year in the local media. The TFCF urged parents who are on edge to seek professional help or take some time away from their children.

In the wake of the incident, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) on Monday announced it will expand its databank of high-risk families and increase funding and manpower to prevent domestic violence from occurring.

Interior Minister Liao Liou-yi said more families considered at risk will be entered into an MOI databank and be tracked. These are families with young children where the parents are alcoholic or addicted to drugs or are known to fight frequently.
It is reported that the parents of the little girl had a fierce argument after the woman blasted Huang for being lazy.
The baby's father has a history of drunkenness and neighbors said the couple, who are not married but have lived together for 12 years, often argued.
The couple have another older daughter besides the baby girl. That daughter, a fifth grader, was placed with a foster family by county social welfare officials following the incident.

The baby's mother, on Tuesday, thanked all walks of life for their care, encouragement and support over the past four days, but some people believe she also has responsibility because she allegedly taunted the father into carrying out the act.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taitung public prosecutor detained on charges of bribery

TEXT.P: Prosecutors at the Taitung District Court's Public Prosecutors' Office in southeastern Taiwan arrested one of their own early Tuesday on charges of bribery.

Deputy Minister of Justice Huang Shih-ming confirmed that prosecutor Lin Sheng- lin was taken into custody for questioning after an internal investigation found that he had accepted bribes in at least two cases.

Members of the anti-corruption division at the Taitung Public Prosecutors' Office and agents from the Investigation Bureau, armed with a search warrant from the court, raided Lin's residence and arrested him.

In August last year, Lin was reassigned from the Shihlin Public Prosecutors' Office in Taipei to the Taitung Public Prosecutors' Office because he had left too many criminal cases unhandled, according to the Taitung prosecutors' office.

Ethics officers in the Taitung prosecutors' office placed Lin under surveillance after noting that he continued to allow the accumulation of many cases, and that he had dismissed quite a few cases that he obviously should have prosecuted.
Further investigation led to the admission by suspects in two criminal cases that Lin had offered not to indict them if they would pay him bribes.
The Taitung prosecutors' office was investigating whether Lin was involved in bribery in other criminal cases that he failed to prosecute.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bird tracking shows migration routes: researcher

TEXT.P: Two of three gray-faced buzzards that were released last year in southern Taiwan in a satellite tracking project of the birds' migration journey have been recorded as having arrived in China, a project researcher said Monday.

One of the birds, named Cape No. 1, which was implanted with satellite tracers and released Oct. 12 last year in Kenting township, was discovered the next day to have traveled to the Philippines, where it remained for some time before moving to the coast of China's Guangdong Province, according to Lin Wun-hong, secretary-general of the Raptor Research Group of Taiwan.

Another released buzzard named Cape No. 2 spent more than five months of the winter in the Philippines and returned to central Taiwan March 21 after flying through Pingtung, Kaohsiung, Tainan, and Chiayi counties in southern Taiwan. The bird was later recorded as having arrived Zhejiang Province in eastern China March 25, Lin said.
Lin said the research team had lost contact with the third of the birds, named Cape No. 3, probably because the bird either died or the satellite tracker was dislodged.

The satellite tracking project is being conducted by the Forestry Bureau in collaboration with Taiwan's top academic institution Academia Sinica and the non-government Raptor Research Group of Taiwan in attempt to establish the migration patterns of the buzzards, Lin said, adding that the research team also released another two -- Cape No. 4 and Cape No. 5 -- in late March in the central county of Changhua.
After moving north, the two birds left Taiwan mid-April and are presently in China's southeastern province of Anhui, having used a migration route similar to that of Cape No. 2.

Every October, numerous gray-faced buzzards migrate through the Hengchun peninsula in the southern county of Pingtung before continuing their migration to destinations of which the researchers were previously unaware, although a Forestry Bureau official said the migration areas of the species are limited to eastern and southern Asia.
In summer, the species breeds in eastern Asia, including northeastern China, the Korean peninsula, southeastern areas of Russia and Japan.
In autumn, the birds migrate south to southern China, the Indochina area of Southeast Asia, the Philippines, Indonesia and New Guinea to spend the winter.
A few of them also winter on Japan's Ishigaki Island, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Possible end to test exemption for foreign medical school graduates

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Department of Health (DOH) is considering rescinding regulations exempting graduates of overseas medical schools who want to practice in Taiwan from tough educational background certification tests.

Under the current regulations, graduates from the United States, Canada, South Africa, Australia, New Zealand, the European Union, Singapore, Japan and Hong Kong are allowed to bypass the tests and directly enter the second stage of qualification examinations.

If the DOH's plan goes through, graduates from the nine countries and areas will have to take the tests, which are the first of three sets of tests that also include the national physician license examination and practical physician license examination.
Only then can they be allowed to practice in Taiwan.

The move was sparked by recent public debate over the controversial regulation. Critics said the regulation provided a shortcut for Taiwanese graduates of overseas medical schools which adopt a shorter and looser curriculum than that of Taiwan.

Over past years after Poland joined the EU, more and more Taiwanese students have gone to that eastern European country to study medicine because the schools of medicine there adopt a four-year, or six-year curriculum system, shorter than the system followed in Taiwanese medical schools.

Students in Taiwan's medical schools must complete a seven-year course of study, which includes a two-year internship, before qualifying for the national physician license examination. The physician candidates cannot move any further toward the position of resident at hospital without passing the test.

However, some criticized the DOH's acceptance rate of the educational background certification tests as so low -- between 3 percent and 5 percent - that it would be hard for overseas medical students to pass.
"It may take over 50 years to pass the tests, " a mother whose daughter is studying medicine in Poland was seen saying on TV.
Her daughter is among over 200 Taiwanese students who are studying medicine in Poland. If the law is revised, these students will be affected.
The issue has triggered discussions in Taiwan's Legislative Yuan over the past few days, with relevant authorities asked to brief lawmakers on their concerning policies and opinions.

During the legislative briefings, DOH Minister Yeh Ching-chuan stressed that revising the law to demand graduates of overseas medical colleges pass the three qualification challenges before they are allowed to practice in Taiwan is the best way to ensure a high standard of medical care in the country.
Meanwhile, the Ministry of Education indicated it will follow the DOH's decision on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Seaweed polysaccharides can prevent enterovirus 71 infection: study

TEXT.P: Coming on the heels of a warning to the public about a potential outbreak of enterovirus 71 (EV71) that mainly affects young children, the results of a study released Tuesday show that eating seaweed might help prevent infection.

The study conducted by Wu Chang-jer, an associate professor at the Department of Food Science at National Taiwan Ocean University, found that the polysaccharides in seaweed can protect against EV71 infection, with the best result seen in those containing chlorella, a species of green freshwater algae.
The second-best result was seen in polysaccharides from brown algae, followed by those from red algae and marine green algae, Wu said.
"While eating the plants directly can be a way to obtain seaweed polysaccharides, extracts can produce even better results as they contain a higher concentration of the polysaccharides," Wu said.
Laboratory experiments have found that an extract amount as little as 10 micrograms is sufficient to produce the protective effect, he said.
The researchers found that the polysaccharides absorb the virus, inhibiting it from invading the cells, according to Wu.
"This means that after the polysaccharides are consumed, they provide protection in the oral cavity or the intestinal system that can capture the virus," he explained.

Enteroviruses are the most common cause of aseptic meningitis and can be deadly, especially in young children. EV71 -- the deadliest type of enterovirus -- is one of the major causative agents of hand-foot-and-mouth syndrome and is sometimes associated with severe central nervous system diseases.
Taiwan experienced a serious outbreak of EV71 in 1998, with 405 severe infections recorded, 78 of which were fatal.

So far this year, 13 enterovirus cases have been reported in which severe complications have developed, one of which has resulted in death. The majority of the cases were linked to EV71, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health.

According to CDC Deputy Director-General Shih Wen-yih, drowsiness, muscle spasms, rapid breathing or heartbeat, as well as increased intracranial pressure with continued vomiting are the four major signs of severe enterovirus infection, and any children displaying any of these symptoms should be taken immediately to hospital.

The results of a survey conducted recently by the CDC among 1,100 child caregivers indicate that the public's awareness of enterovirus may still be insufficient, with 30 percent of respondents saying they would take a sick child to a clinic rather than a hospital even if they displayed symptoms of severe enterovirus infection, Shih said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan has 3rd-highest density of solar water heaters

TEXT.P: Taiwan has the world's third-highest density in terms of the number of household solar-powered water heaters in relation to the size of its territory, the Bureau of Energy under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Tuesday.

According to data provided by the Executive Yuan, 433,000 households in Taiwan have taken advantage of government subsidies to install solar-powered water heaters, giving the country the world's third-largest installation rate per kilometer of its territory, behind only Israel and Cyprus.
To date, 1.78 million square meters of solar energy panels are being used by the 433,000 households, according to the data.

The bureau estimated that this is reducing Taiwan's carbon dioxide emissions by about 350,000 tons per year -- equivalent to some 5.3 million 20-kilo cylinders of liquefied petroleum gas for household use.
Bureau officials attributed the solar power uptake to the subsidies offered by central and local governments.
Although the central government finances 20 percent of the installation fee, they said, some city and counties also provide additional monetary incentives to encourage residents to use solar power.
Since the beginning of this year, they went on, the bureau has increased its subsides to NT$2,250 (US$67) per square meter, up from the previous NT$1,500 per square meter.
The officials added that 80 percent of Taiwan's solar-powered water heaters are installed in central and southern parts of the country due to the sunny weather in those regions.
They forecast that by 2012, 570,000 Taiwanese families will have a solar water heater, with the total amount of solar energy panels increasing to 2.29 million square meters.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipower plans to purchase more coal from China

TEXT.P: The state-run Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) is considering purchasing more coal from China amid the thawing relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, company spokeswoman Tu Yueh-yuan said Tuesday.
Tu said that as a government-operated business, Taipower was heavily restricted in the amount of coal it could buy from China in the past, when cross-strait relations were tense.

The ratio at that time could not account for more than 20 percent of all the fuel it purchased from overseas, Tu said, noting that the ceiling was raised to 30 percent after the Ma Ying-jeou government took office last May as part of the administration's efforts to broaden relations with China.

Most of Taipower's coal comes from Indonesia, accounting for around 60 percent of the total, and if Taiwan buys more from China, it will result in major transport cost savings, a Taipower executive told CNA.
According to a Taipower assessment, Chinese coal is also high quality, so a decision to increase purchases would make sound economic sense, especially at this time of economic recession.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taoyuan magistrate to represent KMT in cross-strait forum

TEXT.P: The chairman of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) announced Tuesday that he has named the magistrate of Taoyuan County, who is also a KMT vice chairman, as the party's chief delegate to the first cross-Taiwan Strait civic forum, to be held May 15-22 in the city of Xiamen in China's Fujian Province.

Wu Poh-hsiung made the announcement at a regular meeting of the KMT. He said he chose Eric Lilun Chu to represent the KMT at the forum because in addition to promoting cross-strait exchanges, Chu, as Taoyuan magistrate, is in a good position to introduce the county's aerotropolis project to the other participants and try to attract Chinese investment to the massive plan.

The project to be built around the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport is one of the country's major development projects and is expected to attract NT$1 trillion (US$29.6 billion) in foreign investment. It is scheduled for completion by the end of 2020.

The cross-strait forum is a platform for exchanges between the private sectors of the two sides and is in addition to an annual forum between the KMT and the Communist Party of China. It is sponsored by the Taiwan Affairs Office of China's State Council and the Fujian provincial government.

The forum, along with various related activities, will take place in four Fujian cities -- Xiamen, Fuzhou, Quanzhou and Putian. Participants from all walks of life will discuss exchanges between the two sides in various areas, including economy and trade, tourism, culture, education, folk arts, women and youth.

DOC.HEADLINE: Seeking connecting flight rights from China difficult: air official

TEXT.P: It will be difficult to seek connecting flight rights from China owing to political considerations and the unequal benefits it would yield to Taiwan and China, an aviation chief said Tuesday.

Lee Lung-wen, director-general of the Civil Aeronautics Administration, said the issue of connection flight freedom, which is also called the fifth freedom of the air and refers to the right of carriers to take passengers from their own country to a second country and from that country to a third country, should be reserved for future talks with China.

He made the remarks against the background that Taiwan is set to wrap up an aviation agreement with China in talks scheduled for April 26 to enhance the existing cross-strait charter flights with regular flights.
However, Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng urged the government a day earlier to also seek connecting flight rights from China.

However, Lee said the issue is politically charged, as the third country served by the connecting flight would be entitled to use the same route, which would be inconsistent with the understanding between Taipei and Beijing that the cross- strait flight routes are not intended to be used by other countries.

Furthermore, Lee went on, Taiwan would gain greater benefit from such an arrangement than would China, as Taiwanese carriers are eager to fly to many European cities via China, while Chinese carriers would be able fly to only a few cities in Southeast Asia, Australia and New Zealand via Taiwan, none of which attract heavy passenger loads.
Therefore, China is reluctant to negotiate with Taiwan on the fifth freedom for the time being, Lee concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for April 22, 2009

TEXT.P: 2. Event: President Ma Ying-jeou to take part via teleconference in a seminar organized by U.S. think tank CSIS in Washington, D.C., on the Taiwan Relations Act. Date and Time: 8.20 p.m., Wednesday, April 22, 2009 Place: Presidential Office, No. 122, Chongqing South Road, Taipei City. Host and/or main speakers: President Ma Ying-jeou. Organizers: Presidential Office. Press Contact: (02) 2311-3731.
Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma donates NT$100,000 to Taitung hospital

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou donated NT$100,000 (US$3,000) Monday to St. Mary's Hospital in Taitung City after learning of its financial difficulties.
