Emile Sheng said that Pippen will arrive in Taiwan April 24 and will share his basketball experiences with Taiwan's high school champion Song-Shan Senior High School and Taiwan's Deaflympic basketball team the following day.
He will also shoot a TV commercial to promote the Games.
On April 26, Pippen will appear at a Super Basketball League (SBL) game in Sinjhuang Gymnasium and will show off some of his skills to the crowd, before leaving the following day.
Pippen teamed with Michael Jordan to help the Chicago Bulls win six NBA championships in the 1990s.

Sheng said the committee is still trying to invite two other international sports stars of Pippen's stature to Taiwan to also serve as goodwill ambassadors, but the final details have yet to be worked out.
Hong Kong action star Jackie Chan and former actress Lin Ching-hsia are also serving as ambassadors for the Deaflympics, which are scheduled for Sept. 5-15.

DOC.HEADLINE: Giant, China Airlines join forces to boost bike tourism

TEXT.P: Taiwan's largest bicycle manufacturer, Giant Inc., and the country's largest air carrier, China Airlines (CAL), signed an agreement Monday to jointly promote bicycle tourism in Taiwan.

Under the agreement signed by Giant Chairman King Liu and CAL Chairman Wei Hsing-hsiung, the two companies will pool their resources to promote Taiwan globally as a cycling mecca. They will seek to lure more visitors from abroad by selling bike tours as a way to experience the island's beauty and local people's hospitality.
Wei said that CAL, in collaboration with a Taiwan travel agency, launched a cycling tour of Okinawa in Japan in February which drew an enthusiastic response from tourists.
In the future, more cycling travel packages will be offered at CAL and Giant's domestic and overseas operating centers and outlets, he added.
Liu said the agreement is also aimed at arranging local and foreign bike tours for Taiwan residents and boosting public interest in that type of eco-friendly tourism.

According to the Giant chairman, Taiwan is well-suited to the development of bicycle tourism, given that its bicycle production standards are among the highest in the world and that Giant has vast experience in providing bicycle rental and maintenance services.
Liu said that the strategic alliance between the CAL and Giant is expected to benefit their respective customers and boost Taiwan's tourism industry.
He also disclosed that Giant has applied to the Ministry of Transportation and Communication for permission to open a travel agency in June to offer bike tour packages in Taiwan and elsewhere.
The travel agency is likely to create a business worth hundreds of millions of New Taiwan dollars, Liu forecast.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economics ministry launches energy saving campaign

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) launched an energy-saving campaign Tuesday, on the eve of Earth Day, calling on the public to turn off electric appliances when they are not in use and thus save an estimated 3.5 billion units of energy per year.

Huang Jung-chiou, vice minister of the MOEA, said at a news conference, held under the theme "Love the Earth, it's our business to switch off," that turning off electric appliances is the easiest way to start saving energy and that it requires everyone's participation to save the Earth.
"A simple action such as switching off electric appliances can help people to shape a completely different attitude in life," Huang said.
"Each little effort can add up to make a major difference to the Earth," he added.

According to the MOEA's Bureau of Energy and the Cabinet-level Directorate- General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, switching off the six most commonly used home and office appliances -- copy machines, printers, office water dispensers, drinking fountains, home electric thermos and computers -- can save 3.5 billion units of energy per year. This is equivalent to the amount of energy used annually by 950,000 households and can reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 2.26 million tons per year, he said.
Most startlingly, Huang added, the statistics show that 85.2 percent of the country's 6 million office water dispensers are usually left on around the clock, seven days a week.
If these machines are switched off after office hours, this could easily save 1.34 billion energy units annually and reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 854,000 tons per year, he said.
As part of the "switch off campaign," the public should use electric timers with an automatic on-off switches to conserve energy, the MOEA suggested.

In response to the government's call, representatives from 28 companies and industrial groups joined Tuesday's news conference, pledging to take the lead in switching off electric appliances after office hours and to help raise awareness among their customers of the importance of saving energy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices rise on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed 1.72 percent higher Tuesday, bolstered by tourism and property shares on hopes of an increase in Chinese tourist arrivals and that closer ties between Taiwan and China would give a boost to the industries.
The weighted index, the market's key barometer, advanced 99.75 points, to close at 5,881.41.
Shrugging off an early weakness that followed a 289-point loss for the Dow Jones Industrial Average, the local bourse opened at 5,665.94 and fluctuated between 5,881.41 and 5,663.56.
A total of 5.74 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$122.43 billion (US$3.62 billion).

All the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction stocks moving up the most at 5.7 percent. Paper and pulp issues gained 5 percent, foodstuff shares added 3.2 percent, cement stocks surged 2.5 percent, plastics and chemicals issues rose 2.0 percent, machinery and electronics stocks as well as textile issues advanced 1.6 percent, and banking and financial stocks rose 1.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,630 to 529, with 124 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$6.17 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, increasing NT$0.030 to close at NT$33.860.
A total of US$753 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.960 and fluctuated between NT$33.750 and NT$34.000.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2 Panamanian tanker crewmen barred from leaving Taiwan

TEXT.P: Two crew members of the Panama-registered tanker TOSA have been barred from leaving Taiwan for the time being to assist prosecutors in the investigation into the sinking of a Taiwanese fishing boat last Friday, prosecutors said Tuesday.
The TOSA was suspected of having hit the 99-ton Hsing Tong Chuan No.86 fishing vessel that sank near the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands early last Friday.
Eleven of the 13 crew members of the sunken ship, based in Suao in the northeastern county of Yilan, were rescued, but the ship's captain Ho Si-chuan and chief engineer Hsu Tsung-wen remain missing.
The 160,000-ton TOSA was escorted to Hualien Harbor by a Taiwanese coast guard vessel on the eastern Taiwan coast Saturday pending investigation into the matter.

Huang Yi-chun, a Hualien chief prosecutor, said that both navigation and track maps as well as the results of detective police work show that the Panamanian tanker was passing the disaster site when the fishing boat was sinking.

During the interrogations, Huang said, neither the tanker's first mate, second mate nor its night-watch sailor admitted that the tanker had hit the fishing boat. But they did not deny that the tanker was passing the site as the boat was sinking, the prosecutor added.
Huang said if the two Taiwanese crewmen aboard the sunken ship have indeed died, certain tanker crew members may be indicted on charges of involuntary manslaughter.
Against this backdrop, Huang said, the tanker's second mate and night-duty sailor have been barred from leaving Taiwan pending further investigations into the cause of the fishing vessel's sinking.
According to Huang, the tanker's owner is willing to pay damages if there is sufficient evidence to prove that the tanker was liable in the fishing boat's sinking.
The Hsing Tong Chuan crew members who were rescued include one Taiwanese fisherman, two Chinese, six Indonesians and two Filipinos.

DOC.HEADLINE: Baby girl thrown into pot of boiling water dies (Update)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/09 19:17:29 (By Lilian Wu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A 10-month old girl who suffered severe burns after her father threw her in a pot of boiling water in a case that shocked Taiwan, died Tuesday morning.
Her father, who was arrested following the incident on Saturday, could face the death penalty, a prosecutor said later.

Despite intensive efforts by doctors to try to save the girl, who suffered second and third-degree burns over 84 percent of her body, she died of multiple organ failure, according to doctors at Changhua Christian Hospital in central Taiwan's Changhua City.
With consent of her mother, who did not want her daughter to continue to suffer the immense pain, the girl was pronounced dead after doctors took her off a life-support system at 10:05 a.m.
The baby had been in critical condition since being rushed to the hospital by her mother after her father, surnamed Huang, did the unimaginable act during an argument with her mother.

The infant's mother, identified only by her family name of Lin, immediately scooped the baby out of the pot in the noodle shop they owned and rushed to a nearby police station for help, whereupon officers immediately sent the baby to the hospital's burn center.

The father, 47, is being held on a homicide charge, and would face either the death penalty, life imprisonment or a jail term of over 15 years, Chang Hui- chung, a prosecutor at the Changhua Prosecutors Office.
"The punishment will be 50 percent more severe because the victim is a small child," said Chang.

The case has ignited anger from people across the country who questioned how someone could harm a child in such a way. Many people prayed for the girl, with some religious people maintaining a vigil at the hospital. Nurses were in tears as they changed the baby's bandages, seeing the pain she was going through.

The incident has also raised concerns about the increase in violence against children in Taiwan since the economic downturn began to be widely felt last year on the island, which is suffering from record unemployment and a sharp decline in GDP and exports.

The nonprofit Taiwan Fund for Children and Families (TFCF) said earlier this month that as the economy has worsened, it has observed a growing rate of domestic violence against children, triggered primarily by a lack of parenting skills, unemployment, and poverty.

As of March, 46 cases of domestic violence involving 73 children, including eight who died, have been reported this year in the local media. The TFCF urged parents who are on edge to seek professional help or take some time away from their children.

In the wake of the incident, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) on Monday announced it will expand its databank of high-risk families and increase funding and manpower to prevent domestic violence from occurring.

Interior Minister Liao Liou-yi said more families considered at risk will be entered into an MOI databank and be tracked. These are families with young children where the parents are alcoholic or addicted to drugs or are known to fight frequently.
It is reported that the parents of the little girl had a fierce argument after the woman blasted Huang for being lazy.
The baby's father has a history of drunkenness and neighbors said the couple, who are not married but have lived together for 12 years, often argued.
The couple have another older daughter besides the baby girl. That daughter, a fifth grader, was placed with a foster family by county social welfare officials following the incident.

The baby's mother, on Tuesday, thanked all walks of life for their care, encouragement and support over the past four days, but some people believe she also has responsibility because she allegedly taunted the father into carrying out the act.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taitung public prosecutor detained on charges of bribery

TEXT.P: Prosecutors at the Taitung District Court's Public Prosecutors' Office in southeastern Taiwan arrested one of their own early Tuesday on charges of bribery.

Deputy Minister of Justice Huang Shih-ming confirmed that prosecutor Lin Sheng- lin was taken into custody for questioning after an internal investigation found that he had accepted bribes in at least two cases.

Members of the anti-corruption division at the Taitung Public Prosecutors' Office and agents from the Investigation Bureau, armed with a search warrant from the court, raided Lin's residence and arrested him.

In August last year, Lin was reassigned from the Shihlin Public Prosecutors' Office in Taipei to the Taitung Public Prosecutors' Office because he had left too many criminal cases unhandled, according to the Taitung prosecutors' office.

Ethics officers in the Taitung prosecutors' office placed Lin under surveillance after noting that he continued to allow the accumulation of many cases, and that he had dismissed quite a few cases that he obviously should have prosecuted.
Further investigation led to the admission by suspects in two criminal cases that Lin had offered not to indict them if they would pay him bribes.
The Taitung prosecutors' office was investigating whether Lin was involved in bribery in other criminal cases that he failed to prosecute.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bird tracking shows migration routes: researcher

TEXT.P: Two of three gray-faced buzzards that were released last year in southern Taiwan in a satellite tracking project of the birds' migration journey have been recorded as having arrived in China, a project researcher said Monday.

One of the birds, named Cape No. 1, which was implanted with satellite tracers and released Oct. 12 last year in Kenting township, was discovered the next day to have traveled to the Philippines, where it remained for some time before moving to the coast of China's Guangdong Province, according to Lin Wun-hong, secretary-general of the Raptor Research Group of Taiwan.

Another released buzzard named Cape No. 2 spent more than five months of the winter in the Philippines and returned to central Taiwan March 21 after flying through Pingtung, Kaohsiung, Tainan, and Chiayi counties in southern Taiwan. The bird was later recorded as having arrived Zhejiang Province in eastern China March 25, Lin said.
Lin said the research team had lost contact with the third of the birds, named Cape No. 3, probably because the bird either died or the satellite tracker was dislodged.

The satellite tracking project is being conducted by the Forestry Bureau in collaboration with Taiwan's top academic institution Academia Sinica and the non-government Raptor Research Group of Taiwan in attempt to establish the migration patterns of the buzzards, Lin said, adding that the research team also released another two -- Cape No. 4 and Cape No. 5 -- in late March in the central county of Changhua.
After moving north, the two birds left Taiwan mid-April and are presently in China's southeastern province of Anhui, having used a migration route similar to that of Cape No. 2.

Every October, numerous gray-faced buzzards migrate through the Hengchun peninsula in the southern county of Pingtung before continuing their migration to destinations of which the researchers were previously unaware, although a Forestry Bureau official said the migration areas of the species are limited to eastern and southern Asia.
In summer, the species breeds in eastern Asia, including northeastern China, the Korean peninsula, southeastern areas of Russia and Japan.
In autumn, the birds migrate south to southern China, the Indochina area of Southeast Asia, the Philippines, Indonesia and New Guinea to spend the winter.
A few of them also winter on Japan's Ishigaki Island, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Possible end to test exemption for foreign medical school graduates

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Department of Health (DOH) is considering rescinding regulations exempting graduates of overseas medical schools who want to practice in Taiwan from tough educational background certification tests.

Under the current regulations, graduates from the United States, Canada, South Africa, Australia, New Zealand, the European Union, Singapore, Japan and Hong Kong are allowed to bypass the tests and directly enter the second stage of qualification examinations.

If the DOH's plan goes through, graduates from the nine countries and areas will have to take the tests, which are the first of three sets of tests that also include the national physician license examination and practical physician license examination.
Only then can they be allowed to practice in Taiwan.

The move was sparked by recent public debate over the controversial regulation. Critics said the regulation provided a shortcut for Taiwanese graduates of overseas medical schools which adopt a shorter and looser curriculum than that of Taiwan.

Over past years after Poland joined the EU, more and more Taiwanese students have gone to that eastern European country to study medicine because the schools of medicine there adopt a four-year, or six-year curriculum system, shorter than the system followed in Taiwanese medical schools.

Students in Taiwan's medical schools must complete a seven-year course of study, which includes a two-year internship, before qualifying for the national physician license examination. The physician candidates cannot move any further toward the position of resident at hospital without passing the test.

However, some criticized the DOH's acceptance rate of the educational background certification tests as so low -- between 3 percent and 5 percent - that it would be hard for overseas medical students to pass.
"It may take over 50 years to pass the tests, " a mother whose daughter is studying medicine in Poland was seen saying on TV.
Her daughter is among over 200 Taiwanese students who are studying medicine in Poland. If the law is revised, these students will be affected.
The issue has triggered discussions in Taiwan's Legislative Yuan over the past few days, with relevant authorities asked to brief lawmakers on their concerning policies and opinions.

During the legislative briefings, DOH Minister Yeh Ching-chuan stressed that revising the law to demand graduates of overseas medical colleges pass the three qualification challenges before they are allowed to practice in Taiwan is the best way to ensure a high standard of medical care in the country.
Meanwhile, the Ministry of Education indicated it will follow the DOH's decision on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Seaweed polysaccharides can prevent enterovirus 71 infection: study

TEXT.P: Coming on the heels of a warning to the public about a potential outbreak of enterovirus 71 (EV71) that mainly affects young children, the results of a study released Tuesday show that eating seaweed might help prevent infection.

The study conducted by Wu Chang-jer, an associate professor at the Department of Food Science at National Taiwan Ocean University, found that the polysaccharides in seaweed can protect against EV71 infection, with the best result seen in those containing chlorella, a species of green freshwater algae.
The second-best result was seen in polysaccharides from brown algae, followed by those from red algae and marine green algae, Wu said.
"While eating the plants directly can be a way to obtain seaweed polysaccharides, extracts can produce even better results as they contain a higher concentration of the polysaccharides," Wu said.
Laboratory experiments have found that an extract amount as little as 10 micrograms is sufficient to produce the protective effect, he said.
The researchers found that the polysaccharides absorb the virus, inhibiting it from invading the cells, according to Wu.
"This means that after the polysaccharides are consumed, they provide protection in the oral cavity or the intestinal system that can capture the virus," he explained.

Enteroviruses are the most common cause of aseptic meningitis and can be deadly, especially in young children. EV71 -- the deadliest type of enterovirus -- is one of the major causative agents of hand-foot-and-mouth syndrome and is sometimes associated with severe central nervous system diseases.
Taiwan experienced a serious outbreak of EV71 in 1998, with 405 severe infections recorded, 78 of which were fatal.

So far this year, 13 enterovirus cases have been reported in which severe complications have developed, one of which has resulted in death. The majority of the cases were linked to EV71, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health.

According to CDC Deputy Director-General Shih Wen-yih, drowsiness, muscle spasms, rapid breathing or heartbeat, as well as increased intracranial pressure with continued vomiting are the four major signs of severe enterovirus infection, and any children displaying any of these symptoms should be taken immediately to hospital.

The results of a survey conducted recently by the CDC among 1,100 child caregivers indicate that the public's awareness of enterovirus may still be insufficient, with 30 percent of respondents saying they would take a sick child to a clinic rather than a hospital even if they displayed symptoms of severe enterovirus infection, Shih said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan has 3rd-highest density of solar water heaters

TEXT.P: Taiwan has the world's third-highest density in terms of the number of household solar-powered water heaters in relation to the size of its territory, the Bureau of Energy under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Tuesday.

According to data provided by the Executive Yuan, 433,000 households in Taiwan have taken advantage of government subsidies to install solar-powered water heaters, giving the country the world's third-largest installation rate per kilometer of its territory, behind only Israel and Cyprus.
To date, 1.78 million square meters of solar energy panels are being used by the 433,000 households, according to the data.

The bureau estimated that this is reducing Taiwan's carbon dioxide emissions by about 350,000 tons per year -- equivalent to some 5.3 million 20-kilo cylinders of liquefied petroleum gas for household use.
Bureau officials attributed the solar power uptake to the subsidies offered by central and local governments.
Although the central government finances 20 percent of the installation fee, they said, some city and counties also provide additional monetary incentives to encourage residents to use solar power.
Since the beginning of this year, they went on, the bureau has increased its subsides to NT$2,250 (US$67) per square meter, up from the previous NT$1,500 per square meter.
The officials added that 80 percent of Taiwan's solar-powered water heaters are installed in central and southern parts of the country due to the sunny weather in those regions.
They forecast that by 2012, 570,000 Taiwanese families will have a solar water heater, with the total amount of solar energy panels increasing to 2.29 million square meters.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipower plans to purchase more coal from China

TEXT.P: The state-run Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) is considering purchasing more coal from China amid the thawing relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, company spokeswoman Tu Yueh-yuan said Tuesday.
Tu said that as a government-operated business, Taipower was heavily restricted in the amount of coal it could buy from China in the past, when cross-strait relations were tense.

The ratio at that time could not account for more than 20 percent of all the fuel it purchased from overseas, Tu said, noting that the ceiling was raised to 30 percent after the Ma Ying-jeou government took office last May as part of the administration's efforts to broaden relations with China.

Most of Taipower's coal comes from Indonesia, accounting for around 60 percent of the total, and if Taiwan buys more from China, it will result in major transport cost savings, a Taipower executive told CNA.
According to a Taipower assessment, Chinese coal is also high quality, so a decision to increase purchases would make sound economic sense, especially at this time of economic recession.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taoyuan magistrate to represent KMT in cross-strait forum

TEXT.P: The chairman of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) announced Tuesday that he has named the magistrate of Taoyuan County, who is also a KMT vice chairman, as the party's chief delegate to the first cross-Taiwan Strait civic forum, to be held May 15-22 in the city of Xiamen in China's Fujian Province.

Wu Poh-hsiung made the announcement at a regular meeting of the KMT. He said he chose Eric Lilun Chu to represent the KMT at the forum because in addition to promoting cross-strait exchanges, Chu, as Taoyuan magistrate, is in a good position to introduce the county's aerotropolis project to the other participants and try to attract Chinese investment to the massive plan.

The project to be built around the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport is one of the country's major development projects and is expected to attract NT$1 trillion (US$29.6 billion) in foreign investment. It is scheduled for completion by the end of 2020.

The cross-strait forum is a platform for exchanges between the private sectors of the two sides and is in addition to an annual forum between the KMT and the Communist Party of China. It is sponsored by the Taiwan Affairs Office of China's State Council and the Fujian provincial government.

The forum, along with various related activities, will take place in four Fujian cities -- Xiamen, Fuzhou, Quanzhou and Putian. Participants from all walks of life will discuss exchanges between the two sides in various areas, including economy and trade, tourism, culture, education, folk arts, women and youth.

DOC.HEADLINE: Seeking connecting flight rights from China difficult: air official

TEXT.P: It will be difficult to seek connecting flight rights from China owing to political considerations and the unequal benefits it would yield to Taiwan and China, an aviation chief said Tuesday.

Lee Lung-wen, director-general of the Civil Aeronautics Administration, said the issue of connection flight freedom, which is also called the fifth freedom of the air and refers to the right of carriers to take passengers from their own country to a second country and from that country to a third country, should be reserved for future talks with China.

He made the remarks against the background that Taiwan is set to wrap up an aviation agreement with China in talks scheduled for April 26 to enhance the existing cross-strait charter flights with regular flights.
However, Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng urged the government a day earlier to also seek connecting flight rights from China.

However, Lee said the issue is politically charged, as the third country served by the connecting flight would be entitled to use the same route, which would be inconsistent with the understanding between Taipei and Beijing that the cross- strait flight routes are not intended to be used by other countries.

Furthermore, Lee went on, Taiwan would gain greater benefit from such an arrangement than would China, as Taiwanese carriers are eager to fly to many European cities via China, while Chinese carriers would be able fly to only a few cities in Southeast Asia, Australia and New Zealand via Taiwan, none of which attract heavy passenger loads.
Therefore, China is reluctant to negotiate with Taiwan on the fifth freedom for the time being, Lee concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 22, or the 27th day of the third month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1500: On his way to India with 13 ships, Portuguese navigator Pedro Alvarez Cabral discovers Brazil and claims it for Portugal.
1724: Immanuel Kant, German idealist philosopher and one of history's greatest thinkers, is born. He argued that reason is the means by which the phenomena of experience is translated into understanding. His classic works include "Critique of Pure Reason" and "Critique of Practical Reason."
1870: Vladimir Ilich Lenin, Russian leader of the Bolshevik Revolution and first leader of Communist Russia, is born.
1904: Robert Oppenheimer, American nuclear scientist who developed the atom bomb, is born.
1915: The Germans use poison gas for the first time on British troops on the Western Front during World War I.
1944: Allied forces land on Dutch New Guinea.
1947: Wei Tao-ming becomes governor of the newly established Taiwan Provincial Government.
1951: The first contingent of officers from the U.S. Military Assistance Advisory Group (MAAG) in Taiwan, arrives in Taipei. Maj. Gen. William C. Chase, the first MAAG chief, would arrive in Taipei later.
1956: Beijing appoints the Dalai Lama as chairman of a committee to prepare Tibet for regional autonomy within Communist China.
1961: The construction of the Taipei Chunghua Bazaar is completed with Gov. Chow Chih-jou of Taiwan Provincial Government presiding over the inauguration ceremony.
1969: American surgeons conduct the first human eye transplant.
1973: President Hammer de Roburt of the Republic of Nauru and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1974: A Pan American Airlines passenger plane crashes in Bali, Indonesia, killing 107 people.
1975: The first batch of Vietnamese refugees arrive on the western coast of the United States, as South Vietnam falls to the communists.
1980: S.S. Don Juan, a vehicle ferry, collides with a car float and sinks near Mindoro Island in the Philippines, killing some 1,000 people.
1984: Medical researchers working in the United States and France identify a type of human cancer virus that may be the causative agent in the killer disease Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS).
1991: The second extraordinary session of the First National Assembly passes, at its sixth plenary meeting, the Additional Articles of the Constitution of the Republic of China and approves the abolishment of the Temporary Provisions Effective During the Period of Communist Rebellion.
1992: Gasoline that leaked from a nearby refinery explodes in the sewer system of Guadalajara, Mexico, killing more than 200 people and injuring over 600 others.
1993: The Legislative Yuan ratifies a 1989 ROC-U.S. copyright agreement and passes amendments to the ROC's copyright law that go into effect April 26.
1993: Tongan Prime Minister Baron Vaea and Madame Vaea visit the Republic of China.
1994: Former U.S. President Richard M. Nixon dies of a stroke at the age of 81. He visited mainland China in 1972 and established detente with the USSR. When Congress recommended three articles of impeachment for Nixon's involvement in the Watergate scandal, he resigned from office Aug. 9, 1974.
1999: Visiting President Kirsan Nikolayevich Ilyumzhinov of the Kalmykia Republic meets with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and expresses interest in creating sisterhood ties between the Russian state and Taipei.
2000: The newly founded People First Party calls for a halt in revamping the ROC Constitution by the National Assembly, branding the draft amendments unconstitutional.
2000: The ROC Foreign Ministry formally approves the appointment of Chen Kuo- huang, director of the Foreign Ministry's Western Asian Affairs Department, as ambassador to Palau.
2001: Nobel laureate Yang Chen-ning is honored as the outstanding alumnus of the century in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, by his alma mater National Tsinghua University.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When the rulers encourage education and good manner, the people are easily amenable to government."

DOC.HEADLINE: NCU calls on students to sign up for summer astronomy camp

TEXT.P: Taiwan's National Central University (NCU) urged university and graduate students Wednesday to sign up for its summer astronomy camp, aimed at increasing interest in the field in the International Year of Astronomy (IYA) 2009.

The summer camp, called Asia-Pacific Youth Astronomy Camp, is part of the university's efforts to promote astronomy in Taiwan and to provide a platform for graduate and undergraduate students in the country to interact with other enthusiasts in the Asia-Pacific region, according to NCU.

Chou Yi, a professor in the university's Graduate Institute of Astronomy, said in a press release that IYA 2009 not only marks the 400th anniversary of the first observation of space through a telescope by Galileo Galilei, but also the 200th anniversary of the birth of evolutionist Charles Darwin.
"'Evolution' will be the theme of the summer camp, which will introduce the formation and development of planets, the solar system, galaxies and the universe,Chou said.
While we are trying to increase research capabilities in local universities, it is also our obligation to pass on knowledge to a younger generation,he added.
According to Chou, similar summer astronomy camps have been held in the past by NCU, National Taiwan University and National Tsing Hua University, but they were much smaller in scale.

Funded by the Cabinet-level National Science Council and sponsored by the Astronomical Society of the Republic of China (Taiwan) and the local chapter of the IYA activity planning panel, the Asia-Pacific Youth Astronomy Camp will have 120 openings for graduates and undergraduates in the Asia Pacific region, according to NCU.
Participants are preferred to have taken general physics, astronomy, or introduction to astrophysics courses and have good command of English, it added.
Scheduled to be held in Sitou in central Taiwan July 6-10, the event will invite noted astronomers from home and abroad to lecture on the latest astronomical developments.

Among them will be Dina Prialnik, a planetary scientist and the author ofAn Introduction to the Theory of Stellar Structure and Evolution, and radio astronomer Makoto Inoue, winner of the 2005 International Astronautics Award.
The summer camp is free of charge and those who are interested in joining can sign up before April 30 at http://apyac2009.astro.ncu.edu.tw/.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese identify Japan as favorite foreign country: survey

TEXT.P: Japan is the foreign country enjoying the highest popularity among Taiwanese, most of whom are fascinated by the country's culture and natural environment, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday by Japan's Interchange Association.
The survey found that when asked to name their favorite foreign country, 38 percent of respondents mentioned Japan.
Coming a distant second was the United States, named by 5 percent of respondents, followed by Switzerland, named by 3 percent.
The results showed that although only 2 percent of respondents picked China as their favorite foreign country, 34 percent said China was the country that Taiwan should grow closest to.
Another 31 percent thought Taiwan should move more closely toward Japan, and 20 percent supported moving closer to the United States.

Sixty-nine percent of respondents said they have a feeling of closeness for Japan, and 90 percent described Japan as a charming country that people would want to travel to, with many attracted to Japan's natural landscape, hot springs, festive culture and cuisine.

Seventy-nine percent of respondents thought Japan is an economically powerful country, while 44 percent said it is trustworthy. The sense of trust, according to 65 percent of respondents, derives from the cultural connection between Taiwan and Japan.
On current Taiwan-Japan relations, 64 percent of respondents described them as average, while 29 percent said they are good. Only 7 percent said relations are poor.
Looking ahead, 55 percent of respondents believed relations between the two sides will continue to improve, while 7 percent thought they will worsen.
The survey was conducted between Nov. 17 and Dec. 12, 2008 among 1,040 people by the Nielsen Company for the Interchange Association. It had a margin of error of 3.1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Seeking connecting flight rights from China difficult: air official

TEXT.P: It will be difficult to seek connecting flight rights from China owing to political considerations and the unequal benefits it would yield to Taiwan and China, an aviation chief said Tuesday.

Lee Lung-wen, director-general of the Civil Aeronautics Administration, said the issue of connection flight freedom, which is also called the fifth freedom of the air and refers to the right of carriers to take passengers from their own country to a second country and from that country to a third country, should be reserved for future talks with China.

He made the remarks against the background that Taiwan is set to wrap up an aviation agreement with China in talks scheduled for April 26 to enhance the existing cross-strait charter flights with regular flights.
However, Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng urged the government a day earlier to also seek connecting flight rights from China.

However, Lee said the issue is politically charged, as the third country served by the connecting flight would be entitled to use the same route, which would be inconsistent with the understanding between Taipei and Beijing that the cross- strait flight routes are not intended to be used by other countries.

Furthermore, Lee went on, Taiwan would gain greater benefit from such an arrangement than would China, as Taiwanese carriers are eager to fly to many European cities via China, while Chinese carriers would be able fly to only a few cities in Southeast Asia, Australia and New Zealand via Taiwan, none of which attract heavy passenger loads.
Therefore, China is reluctant to negotiate with Taiwan on the fifth freedom for the time being, Lee concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taoyuan magistrate to represent KMT in cross-strait forum

TEXT.P: The chairman of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) announced Tuesday that he has named the magistrate of Taoyuan County, who is also a KMT vice chairman, as the party's chief delegate to the first cross-Taiwan Strait civic forum, to be held May 15-22 in the city of Xiamen in China's Fujian Province.

Wu Poh-hsiung made the announcement at a regular meeting of the KMT. He said he chose Eric Lilun Chu to represent the KMT at the forum because in addition to promoting cross-strait exchanges, Chu, as Taoyuan magistrate, is in a good position to introduce the county's aerotropolis project to the other participants and try to attract Chinese investment to the massive plan.

The project to be built around the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport is one of the country's major development projects and is expected to attract NT$1 trillion (US$29.6 billion) in foreign investment. It is scheduled for completion by the end of 2020.

The cross-strait forum is a platform for exchanges between the private sectors of the two sides and is in addition to an annual forum between the KMT and the Communist Party of China. It is sponsored by the Taiwan Affairs Office of China's State Council and the Fujian provincial government.

The forum, along with various related activities, will take place in four Fujian cities -- Xiamen, Fuzhou, Quanzhou and Putian. Participants from all walks of life will discuss exchanges between the two sides in various areas, including economy and trade, tourism, culture, education, folk arts, women and youth.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung grandmother a model environmentalist

TEXT.P: An elderly woman in central Taiwan, who together with her husband set up a charitable recycling operation nearly 10 years ago, has finally gained recognition for the green life she leads and for helping others do the same.

Sixty-eight year-old Chang Su-mei from Daya Township in Taichung County was cited Wednesday by neighbors of her community on World Earth Day as an environmental protection role model, in recognition of her continued dedication to protecting the earth and recycling.

For the better part of the past 10 years, Chang has devoted herself to a recycling center built on land owned by her husband's family after an earthquake in September 1999 devastated much of central Taiwan.

Chang said she and her husband donated the land after being inspired by the rebuilding efforts of the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation in the aftermath of the temblor, which left nearly 2,400 people dead and some 11,000 injured islandwide.

Following in the footsteps of Tzu Chi -- which has long operated major recycling centers in Taiwan -- Chang has managed the recycling center since it was established. The center sorts, recovers and sells recyclable materials, and turns over the proceeds to charity.
It has gradually made a name for itself in the community, as many Daya residents now send Chang their reusable cans and containers, knowing any benefits will go to the needy.

Of all the garbage that Chang has handled, plastic bags are the biggest headache, she says. She urged consumers to use as few plastic bags as possible since plastic is not biodegradable, and creates a great burden on the earth and the environment.

Chang's recycling center also processes kitchen leftovers, which she layers with bran to produce organic compost. The compost is then used as a fertilizer on the land adjacent to the recycling center.

She said her adult children harvest safe, organic vegetables from her garden every week and take them home to consume. The children then donate the money that would have otherwise been spent on groceries to public welfare organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Group donates NT$1 million to Taipei Deaflympics

TEXT.P: The Kon Wen Educational Organization donated NT$1 million (US$30,000) Tuesday to the 2009 Taipei Deaflympics Organizing Committee to encourage local athletes participating in the event and boost the morale of people hard hit by the economic slump.
Taipei City Mayor Hau Lung-bin thanked Tsai Hsueh-ni, president of the organization, for her generosity.

According to Hau, Tsai was deeply moved by an advertisement for the Deaflympics and contacted the Taipei City government, expressing her desire to recognize the athletes' dedication and provide them encouragement ahead of the Games, to be held Sept. 5-15.

Tsai said she hoped the donation would draw society's attention to these hearing-impaired athletes who are willing to challenge themselves and the world despite their disability, and offer encouragement to those who have suffered from the economic downturn.
As part of Tuesday's donation presentation, Tsai's organization also made a donation to the city's Education Department directed at underprivileged school children.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese urged to equip hot drinking water dispenser with timer

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Bureau of Energy urged local households Wednesday to install timers on their hot water dispensers and hot water bottles to save electricity, one of a number of suggestions the agency made to conserve energy on World Earth Day.

By using a timer on water heating devices, local households could still have access to hot drinking water at any time while saving the country nearly 1.6 billion kilowatt-hours per year, or about 0.8 percent of Taiwan's total electricity consumption, bureau officials said.

The estimate was based on the results of a survey conducted by the nonprofit Industrial Technology Research Institute, which found that 85.2 percent of Taiwan's households keep their hot water dispensers running 24 hours a day and 81 percent keep their electrical thermal bottles running around the clock.
The bureau suggested that households equip these devices with automatic timers to regulate the amount of time they are turned on.

It estimated that if timers were used across the country, some 1.3 billion kwh would be saved on the operation of hot water dispensers and nearly 290 million kwh would be saved on the use of hot water bottles.
State-run utility Taiwan Power Company generated and bought a total of 200 billion kwh of electricity in 2008.

The Bureau of Energy also urged private offices to turn off their lights and switch off electrical equipment when not in use, or alternatively install timers on energy-consuming equipment, to further conserve energy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's share prices marginally higher

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices edged higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, gaining 4.7 points, or 0.07 percent, to close at 5,886.11.
Buoyed by Wall Street's rise overnight, the local bourse opened higher at 5,887.48 and rose to a high of 5,925.92 early in the session before falling back to as low as 5,856.13,
A total of 6.27 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$135.47 billion (US$4 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 3.8 percent. Cement stocks advanced 3.1 percent, textile stocks and construction issues both increased 1.2 percent, paper and pulp issues rose 0.4 percent, and machinery and electronics shares were up 0.3 percent.
Two other major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares moving down 1 percent and plastics and chemicals shares falling 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,467 to 717, with 136 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$152 million.

Although the market has challenged the 6,000-point threshold in recent days, analysts believed that many investors remain in a profit-taking mood, making it unlikely that the index will rise above the 6,000-point barrier in the coming days.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar remains unchanged on Taipei Forex

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar remained unchanged against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday to close at NT$33.860.
A total of US$666 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at NT$33.960 and fluctuated between NT$33.800 and NT$34.000.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's jobless rate hit 5.81 percent in March

TEXT.P: The jobless rate rose to a record high of 5.81 percent in March, according to a report released Wednesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
The figure represented a 0.06 percentage point increase from the 5.75 percent reported in February.
The number of people unemployed in March rose to 630,000, which was also a record high since the first unemployment survey was conducted in 1978, DGBAS officials said.
The average jobless rate in the first three months was 5.62 percent, up 1.75 percentage points year-on-year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japanese man begins round-Taiwan walk

TEXT.P: A 26-year-old Japanese man began a three-month walk around Taiwan Wednesday in southern Taiwan's Tainan City, in a bid to raise environmental awareness.
Yuji Miyata attended World Earth Day activities sponsored by the Tainan city government that day before embarking on his walk.
He arrived in Tainan a day earlier, having completed walks over the course of a little over a year in Hong Kong, Beijing, South Korea and Okinawa.

Miyata, who has a master's degree from a university in South Korea, said he became concerned about environmental protection issues at the age of 6 after watching a television report on ozone holes caused by pollutants in the atmosphere.

He said he was greatly inspired by Paul Colemen -- earthwalker, tree planter, environmentalist -- in late 2007 and has become a vegetarian as well as starting on a global journey to deliver his message on the environment.
He said he has walked 4,400 km through three nations over the past 14 months. Without much money in his pocket, he said, he is often provided with shelter and given food and water by strangers.
"It's a wonderful feeling camping in the wild for the night after having nothing but water for two or three days," Miyata said.
A determined Miyata said even his parents' worry cannot change his decision to walk around the globe.
"I'll keep walking around the globe until the Earth takes a turn for the better environmentally," he vowed.
After the Taiwan walk, he went on, he will proceed to other Asian countries before heading for the Middle East and Europe.
He said he got to know Chang Huang-chen, director of Tainan city's Environmental Protection Bureau, via a U.S. World Earth Day Web site, prompting him to organize the Taiwan leg of his walk.
For his part, Chang said, he will write letters to the local governments of all the country's cities and counties asking them to provide hospitality to Miyata and to cheer him along on his quest.

Since 1990, Coleman, a British citizen, has walked 47,500 km through 39 nations, planting trees and encouraging people to preserve the natural environment, delivering the environmental message to all aspects of society, from the jungles of the Amazon to the highlands of Zimbabwe, and even into war zones.

In 2000, Coleman began a campaign to plant 100,000,000 trees, one for every man, woman and child killed in the last century of war. Thanks to the support of people around the world, he says, at least 11,350,000 trees have been planted so far.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutor charged with bribe-taking released on bail

TEXT.P: The Taitung District Court in southeastern Taiwan allowed a public prosecutor charged with taking bribes to be released on bail of NT$500,000 (US$14,760) early Wednesday.

Lin Sheng-lin, a prosecutor at the district court's public prosecutors' office, was taken into custody a day earlier for questioning after an investigation by the anti-corruption division of the office and agents from the Investigation Bureau found that he had accepted bribes in at least two cases.
The court ruled that there is no need to detain Lin, even though he could face at least five years in prison if convicted.
The court also set bail at NT$200,000 for Wu Dong-sheng, a broker who prosecutors said assisted Lin in taking bribes.
The court also ruled that both Lin and Wu are not allowed to leave the country.
According to the Taitung Public Prosecutors' Office, Lin was reassigned from the Shihlin Public Prosecutors' Office in Taipei to work in Taitung because he left too many criminal cases unhandled.

Ethics officers at the Taitung prosecutors' office placed Lin under surveillance after noting that he continued to allow the accumulation of many cases, and that he had dismissed quite a few cases that he should have prosecuted.
Further investigation led to the admission by suspects in two criminal cases that Lin had offered not to indict them in return for bribes.
The Taitung prosecutors' office is investigating whether Lin was also involved in bribery in other criminal cases that he failed to prosecute.

DOC.HEADLINE: Housing brokerage firm tapping military for fresh talent

TEXT.P: A local housing brokerage firm will hold a job fair in collaboration with the Ministry of National Defense to scout for sales talent within the military, a corporate source said Wednesday.
Yung Ching Rehouse said it will recruit and train some 300 young men, who will soon be discharged from the military, to work as salesmen in its branch offices islandwide.

The new recruits will be paid a monthly wage of NT$40,000 (US$1,183) for the first nine months -- one of the best offers to rookies from a local business at a time when the global economic crunch is still showing no signs of easing, Yung Ching Rehouse said.
Yung Ching currently employs 6,100 people.

Meanwhile, other leading real estate brokerage companies, including H&B Housing and CTHouse Group, are planning to hire this year, despite the global economic slump. H&B Housing said it plans to recruit 1,500 new salespeople this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Internet use increases among local children: survey

TEXT.P: The Internet has become an important form of entertainment for Taiwanese children in addition to watching television, as children's access to the Internet continues to increase, according to the results of a survey released Wednesday.
The survey, targeting children between the ages of 7 and 14 and their parents, was conducted by the Child Welfare League Foundation (CWLF) in cooperation with the Cartoon Network TV channel.
It was found that more than 90 percent of the respondent children have frequent access to the Internet, an increase of more than 31 percent compared with the results of a similar survey done in 2007.

Thirty-seven of the child respondents said they go online every day, making the Internet the third-most popular source of entertainment after television and computers, which are used every day by 90 percent and 45 percent of the young respondents, respectively.

Among the respondents in the 13-14 age group, approximately 50 percent said they use the Internet every day mainly to play online games, download music, receive or send e-mail, or use instant messaging services.
In addition, 42 percent of the respondents in the 13-14 age group said they own a mobile phone, compared with just 5 percent among the 7-8 age group.
The results also indicate that more than 50 percent of the parent respondents watch television with their children every day.
Approximately 60 percent said they allow their children to watch their favorite TV programs, while nearly 40 percent said they allow them to use the Internet freely.

CWLF Executive Director Alicia Wang warned however that the high level of freedom enjoyed by the respondents in Internet use and choice of TV program could indicate that parents are simply too busy to pay attention to what their children are doing -- according to the survey results, 80 percent of the children polled complained that their parents spend too little time with them, and 82 percent said they should be taken out more.
The survey also found a wide gap between parents and children in terms of expectations of their schoolwork performance.

While most of the children said they already work very hard, 95 percent of the parents said their children should work harder and 75 percent expressed concern that their children are not competitive enough in terms of their academic performance.

Although nearly 20 percent of the adult respondents said they have reduced their children's pocket money because of the economic downturn, more than 85 percent still send their children to cram schools and will maintain or increase their investment in their children's education.
The results also show that more than 70 percent of the children surveyed enjoy attending school.
Among those who said they do not like school, 64 percent complained about the large amount of homework and examinations, 35 percent about boring lessons and 16 percent about being tired.

Around 20 percent of the respondents said they had been feeling unhappy lately, either because they had been scolded by their parents, had experienced heavy pressure from schoolwork or were not getting along well with their classmates.
Meanwhile, approximately half of the children polled said they experience peer pressure and feel unhappy if their parents do not buy them the things that their friends have.

The survey was conducted via street interviews between Feb. 24 and March 23 among 1,001 children and 1,001 parents in the Taipei, Taichung and Kaohsiung areas. It had a margin of error of 3.16 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chiayi magistrate leads beach-cleanup campaign

TEXT.P: Chiayi Magistrate Chen Ming-wen led a brigade of around 500 people in a cleanup of a section of the southern county's beaches Wednesday to mark World Earth Day.

Chen and a number of other people, including Chiayi-based Legislator Chang Hua- kuan and volunteers from the Dalin branch of the Buddhist Tzu Chi General Hospital, cleaned the beaches along the wetlands in the county's Dongshi township and formed a human chain to shift around 60 tons of garbage to a pickup location for disposal or recycling.
The garbage included almost everything from driftwood and discarded oyster- farming equipment to EPS foam containers, PE bottles and aluminum beer cans.

Other people who pitched in to clean up the beaches included members of a Chiayi-based air force jet fighter group, officials from the Chiayi section of the Coast Guard Administration, Chiayi-based Taiwan Sugar Corp. employees, officials from the Chiayi county government and conscripts serving their alternative national service in the southern county.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait container volume soars at Kaohsiung port

TEXT.P: The volume of cross-Taiwan Strait containers handled by the port of Kaohsiung has increased by 4.6 times since the launch of direct shipping links between Taiwan and China last December, according to statistics released Wednesday by the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau.
The statistics showed that while there were just 38 cross-strait voyages that included a stop at Kaohsiung in December 2008, the number more than tripled to 118 in March.
The volume of cross-strait containers handled by the port, which stood at 16,000 twenty-foot equivalent units (TEUs) in December, soared to 74,000 TEUs in March, the statistics indicated.
Harbor Master Tsai Ting-yi noted that the direct cross-strait shipping links inaugurated on Dec. 15 has helped businesses cut transportation costs by 15 percent to 30 percent.
Ships previously had to take long detours through waters near Japan or Hong Kong because direct routes were banned.
Taiwan's exports to China are mainly machinery and capital-intensive goods, while imports from China are mostly raw commodities and textiles, Tsai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government officials, local chiefs mark World Earth Day

TEXT.P: Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) Minister Stephen Shen presided over a ceremony Wednesday in which groups and individuals from around the country were awarded for their efforts to protect the environment.

Speaking at the World Earth Day ceremony at National Taiwan University Hospital, Shen urged the public to change their lifestyles by using green energy and consuming green products to save the earth for future generations.
One river protection team from southern Taiwan's Tainan County was among the groups highly recognized at the award ceremony for their efforts.

The team helped clean up the county's Er Jen Stream -- once Taiwan's most polluted river -- and now patrols the river regularly to monitor whether there is waste water being discharged from factories along the riverbanks.
World Earth Day was marked worldwide in various other ways that day, with Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin traveling to work by bicycle.
Accompanied by more than 10 city government officials, Hau used a bike he rented from the city's U-bike service center after getting off the metro from his home in Shihlin district.
He encouraged the public to use more public transport as a way to help the campaign to make the globe greener and cleaner.

Meanwhile, Penghu Magistrate Wang Chien-fa also led a group of county officials and environmental protection activists on a bike ride to work in the offshore county, in a gesture to remind the public of the seriousness of global warming. He urged Penghu residents to walk more or use car-pooling.

Shops in downtown Makung City, Penghu's capital, turned off their lights for one hour later in the day in response to the government's energy-saving campaign, while in central Taiwan's Nantou County, public agencies and schools also switched off their lights for one hour at noon in line with the government's drive to make Taiwan into a low-carbon society.

During a keynote speech given at Tatung University in Taipei later that day, former EPA Minister Winston Dang said Taiwanese products might be banned by other highly environmentally conscious countries if it fails to slash its emissions of greenhouse gases.
Taiwan's population accounts for only 0.3 percent of the world's total but produces nearly 1 percent of the globe's carbon dioxide, Chen pointed out.
Taiwan's citizens must realize that they are entitled to demand that the government pay full heed to Taiwan's natural environment every day instead of just during a "one-day" activity, he said.
The former EPA chief, however, hailed Taiwan's outstanding performance in recycling.
Around 50,000 Taiwanese people recycle every day -- some 30,000 scavengers and about 20,000 private individuals -- creating an annual production value of more than NT$100 billion (US$3 billion).
As many as 4.5 billion PET bottles can be recycled in Taiwan per year, which helps save the energy equivalent to a month's worth of electricity for 40,000 households.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA regrets Taiwan's barring from digital library inauguration

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) expressed regret Wednesday over a Taiwanese representative being prevented from entering the venue of a ceremony to mark the inauguration of the World Digital Library (WDL) , an international cooperation project that involves Taiwan's participation.

MOFA spokesman Henry Chen expressed the regret in response to media inquiries over the absence of Karl Min Ku, director-general of the National Central Library of Taiwan, at the event that took place a day earlier at United Nations Education, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) headquarters in Paris.
Chen said the ministry will instruct its representative office in France to lodge a protest at UNESCO and to seek fair treatment for Taiwan in non-political international activities.

Chen said the ministry found out that Ku was blocked from entering UNESCO headquarters because of his Republic of China passport, which he said was probably because Taiwan is not a member of the United Nations.

He said the official MOFA view is that the UNESCO move of not allowing an ROC passport-holder to enter its building was "not only unreasonable but also unfair, " as well as violating international practice, because the passport is recognized by most nations around the world as a valid travel document.
He further said the ministry deeply regrets that Taiwanese citizens are discriminated against even in non-political international activities.

The MOFA will continue to make Taiwan's stance known to the U.N. through the various channels at its disposal, seeking respect for the people of Taiwan and protection of their rights to participate in international activities, Chen added.

Taiwan's national library is one of 32 libraries in 19 countries that are participating in the WDL project, which was formed based on the idea of a joint establishment for the sharing of resources that was first put forward by U.S. Librarian of Congress James H. Billington in 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: Issue of extradition must be in upcoming cross-strait talks: DPP

TEXT.P: The issue of extradition of major economic criminals must be included on the agenda of the third round of negotiations between Taiwan and China, and if it is not, talks between the two sides about cooperating in combating crime will be "meaningless, " a spokesman for the opposition Democratic Progressive Party said Wednesday.

There are 85 Taiwanese fugitives who are wanted in connection with major economic crimes currently living in China, including former Tuntex Group Chairman Chen You-hao, who was listed in 2003 as one of Taiwan's 10 most wanted criminals after he fled the country leaving behind over NT$60 billion in unpaid bank debts.
The DPP has for long wanted the criminals' repatriation back to Taiwan to face prosecution or stand trial.

On Wednesday, Cheng Wen-tsang, director of the DPP Department of Culture and Information, reiterated the party's stance on the issue, saying if China is sincere about forming a joint frontline to combat crime with Taiwan, it should repatriate major Taiwanese fugitives as soon as possible.
Cheng made the remarks as he released the results of a telephone survey conducted by the DPP from April 20-21 on a planned joint cross-strait crime fighting agreement.
In the survey, 88.4 percent of the respondents said the issue of extradition of major economic criminals should be included in a proposed cross-strait agreement on crime control.

The agreement on crime fighting is expected to be signed by Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Taiwan's semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, and his Chinese counterpart Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, when they meet on April 25-26 in Nanjing, China.
Only 4.4 percent of the respondents in the poll, who were drawn from people over age 19, expressed opposition to the extradition idea.

The Mainland Affairs Council and Straits Exchange Foundation have not clearly stated whether the issue of extradition of major criminals will be included in the upcoming talks or any crime fighting agreement that will be signed.
The poll also gauged the level of public satisfaction with the performance of President Ma Ying-jeou, who will have served as president for one year on May 20.
In terms of President Ma's performance, 34.7 percent of the survey's respondents gave him a positive rating, while 57.1 percent gave him a thumbs down.
A total of 1,062 valid samples were collected in the poll, which had a margin of error of plus or minus 3.06 percent.

Since the institutionalized talks between Taiwan and China resumed last June, the issue of joint crime-fighting efforts has been high on the Taiwan government's agenda, as mainland China is known to be the main haven for criminals fleeing Taiwan.

However, the two sides have not yet formalized any such arrangement. What exists at the moment is a non-governmental agreement that was signed in the Taiwan-controlled island of Kinmen in 1992 by the Red Cross societies of the two sides to facilitate repatriation of stowaways and some relatively lesser-known criminals across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: Spain holds tourism fair to attract Taiwanese visitors

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Spanish Chamber of Commerce (CCE) held a tourism fair Wednesday, inviting 200 local travel agents to explore the diversity of Spain's tourism with the aim of increasing the number of visitors from Taiwan.

CCE Director-General Jose Luis Lamas said at a news conference that the fair was designed not only to promote Spain as a tourist destination for Taiwanese people but also to increase their awareness and knowledge of the country.

Ignacio Ducasse, director of the Spanish Tourism Office in Tokyo -- which covers Spain's tourism business in Japan, Taiwan and South Korea -- said that while 90 percent of Spain's tourists come from Europe, the country wants to increase the presence of people from more distant countries.
"We believe that in Taiwan we have strong potential for attracting visitors to Spain. For that reason, Taiwan is a very important market for us," Ducasse told CNA.

He noted that compared with other Asian countries, Taiwan has one of the highest numbers of travelers to Spain, with an average of 30,000 per year, a number that has been growing steadily over the past decade.
While Taiwanese people are familiar with Spain for its art, sports, fashion and food, Ducasse said, Spain has much more to offer as it is a very diverse and rich country.
Maria Luisa Fernandez, deputy director of new markets for Spain's Institute of Tourism, said at the news conference that Spain is unique because it is a "green, sunny and modern tourist destination."
The country also has a rich cultural legacy with some 40 historic sites and 13 cities declared as UNESCO world heritage sites, she added.
The tourism fair provided local travel agents with the latest tourist information and will help them organize various kinds of tourist itineraries for their Taiwanese customers, Fernandez added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2-year-old girl dies after being severely beaten by father

TEXT.P: A 2-year-old girl has died after being severely beaten by her father with a broom, according to prosecutors in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County, who have detained the father.
The case is the second in less than a week involving deaths of children from domestic violence.

The 2-year-old girl's father beat her on Tuesday for playing with water in the bathroom while he was trying to take a nap during a break from work, and then tied her to a bed before going back to work, according to police.

The girl's mother who was taking a nap at the time told police she did not think much of the beating and continued sleeping. When she awoke, she untied the girl, but after doing house chores, noticed the child had fallen unconscious. She rushed the girl to a hospital, but doctors could not save her. The child died Tuesday evening. Doctors discovered that the girl's arms, legs and buttocks were covered with bruises.

The father, 40, was in tears when he saw his unconscious daughter at the hospital. He expressed regret and said he really loved his daughter, but that she was naughty and he was just trying to discipline her. He is being held on a charge of assault causing death.
Chung Chu-sheng, a prosecutor of the Kaohsiung District Prosecutor's Office, said the crime is severe and that the lightest punishment the father could face is seven years imprisonment.

The case was widely reported in Taiwan's media Wednesday, with some TV stations showing a broom which had broken into several pieces. Local media reports said the father's beating caused the broom to break.
The girl's exact cause of death remains under investigation.

The incident is the second this month involving child abuse leading to death. On Saturday, a father in central Taiwan's Changhua City threw his 10-month-old daughter into a pot of boiling water, causing her to die from severe burns.

The two cases have ignited public concerns about the rising incidences of child abuse in Taiwan, with child welfare groups urging parents not to take out their anger on children and the Ministry of the Interior pledging to devote more funding and resources to identifying at-risk families to prevent further violence against children.

DOC.HEADLINE: January-February wages fell steeply, government data shows

TEXT.P: The monthly nominal salary for office workers in Taiwan during the January- February period averaged NT$55,131 (US$1,630), marking a record drop of 12.13 percent year on year, a government agency said Wednesday.

It was the largest ever decrease since 1980 when the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) started compiling such data, said Hung Chien-chung, a DGBAS official.
Per capita actual income also fell 12.18 percent during the same period compared to a year ago, which was also a record plunge since 1980, Huang said.
He attributed the decrease mainly to a noticeable shrinkage in year-end bonuses last year as a result of the global financial crisis which broke in September 2008.
At the same time, a survey found that 53 percent of Taiwan's white-collar workers are now required to work longer every day, while 28 percent of blue- collar workers have shorter work hours.

According to the results of the survey released Wednesday, around 60 percent of the respondents said their wealth has contracted and their economic burdens have increased. Only 5 percent said they felt no financial pressure, compared to the 52 percent who said they were under heavy financial strain.
Some 64 percent said they are not satisfied with their current living standards, compared to six months ago, the poll showed.
In terms of outlook, 16 percent said that they did not think their living standards would recover in three years, and 7 percent felt that it never would.
The poll, commissioned by Business Today Magazine, was conducted April 2-7, and collected 1,640 valid questionnaires from office workers aged 25-44. It had a margin of error of 2.5 percentage points.

Meanwhile, in another survey conducted by Yes123, an online head hunting network, 70 percent of the respondents said they were concerned about losing their jobs and that they only had enough money to get though 6.6 months.

Nearly 50 percent of jobless workers said they spent two hours every day playing video games to kill time, while 40 percent admitted to watching pornographic movies at least once every five days, the Yes123 survey showed. Close to 10 percent said they take anti-depressants to try to relax.

Some 20 percent of the unemployed workers who responded to the poll said that they would have no chance of finding a new job if they remain out of work for more than two years, while 30 percent said they will seek assistance from fortune tellers, and 36 percent plan to visit to temples to ask for divine intervention. Another 10 percent said they will seek help from doctors or professional counselors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Civic groups call for law revisions to prevent child abuse

TEXT.P: Two major social welfare groups urged the government Wednesday to push for a law revision that would require grassroots community leaders to report child abuse cases to the relevant government agencies and thus better protect children's well-being.
The Child Welfare League Foundation (CWLF) and the Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation (TWRF) made the appeal after two heart-wrenching cases of child abuse were reported in the past few days.

On Tuesday, a 2-year-old girl in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County was beaten to death by her father, and a day earlier, a 10-month-old baby girl died in a hospital in central Taiwan's Changhua County after she was dumped into a pot of boiling water over the weekend.

CWLF Chief Executive Wang Yu-min said neither of the two families were included in the Ministry of the Interior's at-risk families databank, which indicates that there are holes in Taiwan's current community security networks.

Wang said grassroots community leaders, such as borough and neighborhood chiefs, better known locally as lichang and linchang in Chinese, have not been included on the list of personnel who are obligated to report child abuse cases to the relevant public agencies.

Under the current Children's Welfare Law, medical professionals, social workers, education personnel, caregivers, police, judicial personnel and other professionals who deal with child and juvenile welfare services are mandated to report cases of child abuse to the relevant city and county government departments.
"Regretfully, this stipulation is not comprehensive and effective enough to expose child abuse cases in time," Wang said.
Noting that the foundation has recorded a total of 141 cases of child abuse since 2005, Wang said the gravity of those cases and the death rate have escalated.

The two latest cases also signaled a decline in the family's function of protecting the safety of children, Wang said. An analysis of major cases of child abuse indicated that 67 percent of them were related to martial problems in the home that had spilled over to the children, she added.
The situation becomes even worse if the parents are alcoholics or drug addicts, Wang said.
TRWF head Liao Ying-chih shared Wang's views, saying that the grassroots community information system should be reinforced to better protect young children from maltreatment.
If necessary, Liao said, residential apartment building managers or guards may also be mandated to report cases of child abuse.

As many of the parents who are most likely to maltreat or abuse their children tend to be drug addicts or alcoholics, the Ministry of the Interior and the Department of Health should collaborate more closely to prevent child abuse, Liao suggested.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma urges U.S. to sell Taiwan more arms

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou called on the United States Wednesday to sell more arms to Taiwan, saying that such a request is justified and the arms sales will help Taiwan to maintain a military balance against China.

"The delicate balance of the status quo is being shaken by the gross military imbalances across the (Taiwan) Strait. Therefore, I urge the United States to not hesitate to provide Taiwan with the necessary defensive arms as stipulated in the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) , " Ma said via teleconferencing from Taiwan in a forum on the TRA.

Ma's comment in the forum, titled "U.S.-Taiwan Relations in a New Era: Looking Forward 30 Years After the Taiwan Relations Act, " was his first major public statement to U.S. political and academic sectors since he took office last May.
He promised that Taiwan will not "free-ride" on the U.S. for its own security, as it has taken several steps to show its intention to build its military strength.

Those steps, he explained, included publishing a quadrennial defense review last month, making plans to create an all volunteer force to enhance the professionalism of the military and increasing the defense budget to at least three percent of the country's GDP.
During a Q&A session, Ma urged the U.S. to approve Taiwan's requests to acquire submarines and high performance jet fighters such as the F-16 C/D because they are for defensive purposes.
"In view of the sharp changes in the military balance across the Taiwan Strait, I think it is fully justified for the U.S. to seriously consider selling them (to Taiwan),"the president said.
Given the warming cross-strait ties, he said, Washington should not be worried that such arms sales would jeopardize its relations with China.

"Even China understands very well that at the moment we want to improve relations with the mainland. But we also, as a government, have to maintain a military balance across the Taiwan Strait, " he said.
The U.S. has long been Taiwan's major weapons supplier, despite the fact that this has been an irritant in U.S.-China relations.

In the latest arms deal between Taiwan and the U.S., the administration of former President George W. Bush approved in October 2008 the sale of a weapons package that includes 30 Apache attack helicopters, 330 advanced capability Patriot missiles, 32 Harpoon sub-launched missiles, 182 Javelin guided missiles, and four E-2T system upgrades.

Asked about confidence building measures with China, Ma said it is a rather "difficult and sensitive" issue at the moment, and that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should focus only on economic issues because they are more urgent and more closely related to the livelihood of the people on both sides.
As to bilateral relations between Taiwan and the U.S., Ma said in the future the focus will be less on politics and more on pragmatism.

Taiwan will work closely with the U.S. on issues such as opening Taiwan's market to U.S. agricultural products, promoting e-commerce, exploring ways to reform Taiwan's investment environment and improving the protection of intellectual property rights, he explained.

On top of that, Taiwan would also like to conclude an extradition agreement with the U.S., to participate in America's visa-waiver program and to sign a free trade agreement with the U.S., the president said.

The forum, hosted by the Washington-based Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) , also included panelists such as noted China affairs experts Bonnie Glaser, Douglas Paal, Alan Romberg, Randy Schriver and Kerry Dumbaugh.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exhibition marking 100th anniversary of lyricist's birth opens

TEXT.P: A special exhibition featuring out-of-print albums, manuscripts and other objects related to Lee Lin-chiu, a famous Taiwanese lyricist, opened Wednesday to mark the centenary anniversary of his birth.
