Addressing the opening ceremony, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Lee's lyrics gave expression to the heartfelt aspirations and thoughts of the Taiwanese people of his time and enriched Taiwan's cultural legacies.
Many pop singers, young and old, attended the opening ceremony of the exhibition at the preparatory office of the Taiwan New Culture Movement Memorial Hall in Taipei to pay tribute to Lee.
Shih Wen-pin, a pop singer of mainland Chinese origin who rose to fame by writing and singing romantic Taiwanese songs, said he likes Lee's emotional and nostalgic lyrics.
The exhibit followed the release of a CD last weekend by the Taipei's Department of Cultural Affairs featuring digitally remastered original recordings of popular Taiwanese songs from the 1930s.
Nine of the 23 tracks on the CD were written by Lee, who was born in 1909 in Taipei while Taiwan was under Japanese colonial rule.
The songs, including Spring Breeze, Fixing Broken Fishing Nets and Four Seasons, were written before Japan launched its "Kominka Movement" (Japanization Movement) in Taiwan in the early 1940s.

Lee, along with many other Taiwanese musicians, such as composer Teng Yu-hsien and lyricists Chen Chun-yu and Chen Ta-ju, created songs that reflected the daily lives of ordinary Taiwanese people in that era.

"One major motivation behind the creation of those songs was the concern that Taiwanese culture and the originality of Taiwanese music would disappear, as most people were listening to popular Japanese songs during that period, " said Chuang Yung-ming, a noted Taiwanese cultural history expert.
According to Chuang, the attempt to develop "Taiwan's own popular music" was successful, as many people today consider the 1930s the first golden age of Taiwanese popular music.
However, only about 200 of the 500-plus songs created during that period have survived.

Speaking at an April 18 news conference to introduce the new CD, Lee Yong-ping, director of the Taipei City Department of Cultural Affairs, said it was a tough task to find the original recordings and to digitize the music for release on CD.
For one thing, she recalled, many record collectors were reluctant to loan the more than half-a-century-old records that still had good sound quality.
It was also no easy task to get the copyright issues straightened out as most of the musicians have passed away, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japanese man begins round-Taiwan walk

TEXT.P: A 26-year-old Japanese man began a three-month walk around Taiwan Wednesday in southern Taiwan's Tainan City, in a bid to raise environmental awareness.
Yuji Miyata attended World Earth Day activities sponsored by the Tainan city government that day before embarking on his walk.
He arrived in Tainan a day earlier, having completed walks over the course of a little over a year in Hong Kong, Beijing, South Korea and Okinawa.

Miyata, who has a master's degree from a university in South Korea, said he became concerned about environmental protection issues at the age of 6 after watching a television report on ozone holes caused by pollutants in the atmosphere.

He said he was greatly inspired by Paul Colemen -- earthwalker, tree planter, environmentalist -- in late 2007 and has become a vegetarian as well as starting on a global journey to deliver his message on the environment.
He said he has walked 4,400 km through three nations over the past 14 months. Without much money in his pocket, he said, he is often provided with shelter and given food and water by strangers.
"It's a wonderful feeling camping in the wild for the night after having nothing but water for two or three days," Miyata said.
A determined Miyata said even his parents' worry cannot change his decision to walk around the globe.
"I'll keep walking around the globe until the Earth takes a turn for the better environmentally," he vowed.
After the Taiwan walk, he went on, he will proceed to other Asian countries before heading for the Middle East and Europe.
He said he got to know Chang Huang-chen, director of Tainan city's Environmental Protection Bureau, via a U.S. World Earth Day Web site, prompting him to organize the Taiwan leg of his walk.
For his part, Chang said, he will write letters to the local governments of all the country's cities and counties asking them to provide hospitality to Miyata and to cheer him along on his quest.

Since 1990, Coleman, a British citizen, has walked 47,500 km through 39 nations, planting trees and encouraging people to preserve the natural environment, delivering the environmental message to all aspects of society, from the jungles of the Amazon to the highlands of Zimbabwe, and even into war zones.

In 2000, Coleman began a campaign to plant 100,000,000 trees, one for every man, woman and child killed in the last century of war. Thanks to the support of people around the world, he says, at least 11,350,000 trees have been planted so far.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutor charged with bribe-taking released on bail

TEXT.P: The Taitung District Court in southeastern Taiwan allowed a public prosecutor charged with taking bribes to be released on bail of NT$500,000 (US$14,760) early Wednesday.

Lin Sheng-lin, a prosecutor at the district court's public prosecutors' office, was taken into custody a day earlier for questioning after an investigation by the anti-corruption division of the office and agents from the Investigation Bureau found that he had accepted bribes in at least two cases.
The court ruled that there is no need to detain Lin, even though he could face at least five years in prison if convicted.
The court also set bail at NT$200,000 for Wu Dong-sheng, a broker who prosecutors said assisted Lin in taking bribes.
The court also ruled that both Lin and Wu are not allowed to leave the country.
According to the Taitung Public Prosecutors' Office, Lin was reassigned from the Shihlin Public Prosecutors' Office in Taipei to work in Taitung because he left too many criminal cases unhandled.

Ethics officers at the Taitung prosecutors' office placed Lin under surveillance after noting that he continued to allow the accumulation of many cases, and that he had dismissed quite a few cases that he should have prosecuted.
Further investigation led to the admission by suspects in two criminal cases that Lin had offered not to indict them in return for bribes.
The Taitung prosecutors' office is investigating whether Lin was also involved in bribery in other criminal cases that he failed to prosecute.

DOC.HEADLINE: Housing brokerage firm tapping military for fresh talent

TEXT.P: A local housing brokerage firm will hold a job fair in collaboration with the Ministry of National Defense to scout for sales talent within the military, a corporate source said Wednesday.
Yung Ching Rehouse said it will recruit and train some 300 young men, who will soon be discharged from the military, to work as salesmen in its branch offices islandwide.

The new recruits will be paid a monthly wage of NT$40,000 (US$1,183) for the first nine months -- one of the best offers to rookies from a local business at a time when the global economic crunch is still showing no signs of easing, Yung Ching Rehouse said.
Yung Ching currently employs 6,100 people.

Meanwhile, other leading real estate brokerage companies, including H&B Housing and CTHouse Group, are planning to hire this year, despite the global economic slump. H&B Housing said it plans to recruit 1,500 new salespeople this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Internet use increases among local children: survey

TEXT.P: The Internet has become an important form of entertainment for Taiwanese children in addition to watching television, as children's access to the Internet continues to increase, according to the results of a survey released Wednesday.
The survey, targeting children between the ages of 7 and 14 and their parents, was conducted by the Child Welfare League Foundation (CWLF) in cooperation with the Cartoon Network TV channel.
It was found that more than 90 percent of the respondent children have frequent access to the Internet, an increase of more than 31 percent compared with the results of a similar survey done in 2007.

Thirty-seven of the child respondents said they go online every day, making the Internet the third-most popular source of entertainment after television and computers, which are used every day by 90 percent and 45 percent of the young respondents, respectively.

Among the respondents in the 13-14 age group, approximately 50 percent said they use the Internet every day mainly to play online games, download music, receive or send e-mail, or use instant messaging services.
In addition, 42 percent of the respondents in the 13-14 age group said they own a mobile phone, compared with just 5 percent among the 7-8 age group.
The results also indicate that more than 50 percent of the parent respondents watch television with their children every day.
Approximately 60 percent said they allow their children to watch their favorite TV programs, while nearly 40 percent said they allow them to use the Internet freely.

CWLF Executive Director Alicia Wang warned however that the high level of freedom enjoyed by the respondents in Internet use and choice of TV program could indicate that parents are simply too busy to pay attention to what their children are doing -- according to the survey results, 80 percent of the children polled complained that their parents spend too little time with them, and 82 percent said they should be taken out more.
The survey also found a wide gap between parents and children in terms of expectations of their schoolwork performance.

While most of the children said they already work very hard, 95 percent of the parents said their children should work harder and 75 percent expressed concern that their children are not competitive enough in terms of their academic performance.

Although nearly 20 percent of the adult respondents said they have reduced their children's pocket money because of the economic downturn, more than 85 percent still send their children to cram schools and will maintain or increase their investment in their children's education.
The results also show that more than 70 percent of the children surveyed enjoy attending school.
Among those who said they do not like school, 64 percent complained about the large amount of homework and examinations, 35 percent about boring lessons and 16 percent about being tired.

Around 20 percent of the respondents said they had been feeling unhappy lately, either because they had been scolded by their parents, had experienced heavy pressure from schoolwork or were not getting along well with their classmates.
Meanwhile, approximately half of the children polled said they experience peer pressure and feel unhappy if their parents do not buy them the things that their friends have.

The survey was conducted via street interviews between Feb. 24 and March 23 among 1,001 children and 1,001 parents in the Taipei, Taichung and Kaohsiung areas. It had a margin of error of 3.16 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chiayi magistrate leads beach-cleanup campaign

TEXT.P: Chiayi Magistrate Chen Ming-wen led a brigade of around 500 people in a cleanup of a section of the southern county's beaches Wednesday to mark World Earth Day.

Chen and a number of other people, including Chiayi-based Legislator Chang Hua- kuan and volunteers from the Dalin branch of the Buddhist Tzu Chi General Hospital, cleaned the beaches along the wetlands in the county's Dongshi township and formed a human chain to shift around 60 tons of garbage to a pickup location for disposal or recycling.
The garbage included almost everything from driftwood and discarded oyster- farming equipment to EPS foam containers, PE bottles and aluminum beer cans.

Other people who pitched in to clean up the beaches included members of a Chiayi-based air force jet fighter group, officials from the Chiayi section of the Coast Guard Administration, Chiayi-based Taiwan Sugar Corp. employees, officials from the Chiayi county government and conscripts serving their alternative national service in the southern county.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait container volume soars at Kaohsiung port

TEXT.P: The volume of cross-Taiwan Strait containers handled by the port of Kaohsiung has increased by 4.6 times since the launch of direct shipping links between Taiwan and China last December, according to statistics released Wednesday by the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau.
The statistics showed that while there were just 38 cross-strait voyages that included a stop at Kaohsiung in December 2008, the number more than tripled to 118 in March.
The volume of cross-strait containers handled by the port, which stood at 16,000 twenty-foot equivalent units (TEUs) in December, soared to 74,000 TEUs in March, the statistics indicated.
Harbor Master Tsai Ting-yi noted that the direct cross-strait shipping links inaugurated on Dec. 15 has helped businesses cut transportation costs by 15 percent to 30 percent.
Ships previously had to take long detours through waters near Japan or Hong Kong because direct routes were banned.
Taiwan's exports to China are mainly machinery and capital-intensive goods, while imports from China are mostly raw commodities and textiles, Tsai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government officials, local chiefs mark World Earth Day

TEXT.P: Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) Minister Stephen Shen presided over a ceremony Wednesday in which groups and individuals from around the country were awarded for their efforts to protect the environment.

Speaking at the World Earth Day ceremony at National Taiwan University Hospital, Shen urged the public to change their lifestyles by using green energy and consuming green products to save the earth for future generations.
One river protection team from southern Taiwan's Tainan County was among the groups highly recognized at the award ceremony for their efforts.

The team helped clean up the county's Er Jen Stream -- once Taiwan's most polluted river -- and now patrols the river regularly to monitor whether there is waste water being discharged from factories along the riverbanks.
World Earth Day was marked worldwide in various other ways that day, with Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin traveling to work by bicycle.
Accompanied by more than 10 city government officials, Hau used a bike he rented from the city's U-bike service center after getting off the metro from his home in Shihlin district.
He encouraged the public to use more public transport as a way to help the campaign to make the globe greener and cleaner.

Meanwhile, Penghu Magistrate Wang Chien-fa also led a group of county officials and environmental protection activists on a bike ride to work in the offshore county, in a gesture to remind the public of the seriousness of global warming. He urged Penghu residents to walk more or use car-pooling.

Shops in downtown Makung City, Penghu's capital, turned off their lights for one hour later in the day in response to the government's energy-saving campaign, while in central Taiwan's Nantou County, public agencies and schools also switched off their lights for one hour at noon in line with the government's drive to make Taiwan into a low-carbon society.

During a keynote speech given at Tatung University in Taipei later that day, former EPA Minister Winston Dang said Taiwanese products might be banned by other highly environmentally conscious countries if it fails to slash its emissions of greenhouse gases.
Taiwan's population accounts for only 0.3 percent of the world's total but produces nearly 1 percent of the globe's carbon dioxide, Chen pointed out.
Taiwan's citizens must realize that they are entitled to demand that the government pay full heed to Taiwan's natural environment every day instead of just during a "one-day" activity, he said.
The former EPA chief, however, hailed Taiwan's outstanding performance in recycling.
Around 50,000 Taiwanese people recycle every day -- some 30,000 scavengers and about 20,000 private individuals -- creating an annual production value of more than NT$100 billion (US$3 billion).
As many as 4.5 billion PET bottles can be recycled in Taiwan per year, which helps save the energy equivalent to a month's worth of electricity for 40,000 households.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA regrets Taiwan's barring from digital library inauguration

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) expressed regret Wednesday over a Taiwanese representative being prevented from entering the venue of a ceremony to mark the inauguration of the World Digital Library (WDL) , an international cooperation project that involves Taiwan's participation.

MOFA spokesman Henry Chen expressed the regret in response to media inquiries over the absence of Karl Min Ku, director-general of the National Central Library of Taiwan, at the event that took place a day earlier at United Nations Education, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) headquarters in Paris.
Chen said the ministry will instruct its representative office in France to lodge a protest at UNESCO and to seek fair treatment for Taiwan in non-political international activities.

Chen said the ministry found out that Ku was blocked from entering UNESCO headquarters because of his Republic of China passport, which he said was probably because Taiwan is not a member of the United Nations.

He said the official MOFA view is that the UNESCO move of not allowing an ROC passport-holder to enter its building was "not only unreasonable but also unfair, " as well as violating international practice, because the passport is recognized by most nations around the world as a valid travel document.
He further said the ministry deeply regrets that Taiwanese citizens are discriminated against even in non-political international activities.

The MOFA will continue to make Taiwan's stance known to the U.N. through the various channels at its disposal, seeking respect for the people of Taiwan and protection of their rights to participate in international activities, Chen added.

Taiwan's national library is one of 32 libraries in 19 countries that are participating in the WDL project, which was formed based on the idea of a joint establishment for the sharing of resources that was first put forward by U.S. Librarian of Congress James H. Billington in 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: Issue of extradition must be in upcoming cross-strait talks: DPP

TEXT.P: The issue of extradition of major economic criminals must be included on the agenda of the third round of negotiations between Taiwan and China, and if it is not, talks between the two sides about cooperating in combating crime will be "meaningless, " a spokesman for the opposition Democratic Progressive Party said Wednesday.

There are 85 Taiwanese fugitives who are wanted in connection with major economic crimes currently living in China, including former Tuntex Group Chairman Chen You-hao, who was listed in 2003 as one of Taiwan's 10 most wanted criminals after he fled the country leaving behind over NT$60 billion in unpaid bank debts.
The DPP has for long wanted the criminals' repatriation back to Taiwan to face prosecution or stand trial.

On Wednesday, Cheng Wen-tsang, director of the DPP Department of Culture and Information, reiterated the party's stance on the issue, saying if China is sincere about forming a joint frontline to combat crime with Taiwan, it should repatriate major Taiwanese fugitives as soon as possible.
Cheng made the remarks as he released the results of a telephone survey conducted by the DPP from April 20-21 on a planned joint cross-strait crime fighting agreement.
In the survey, 88.4 percent of the respondents said the issue of extradition of major economic criminals should be included in a proposed cross-strait agreement on crime control.

The agreement on crime fighting is expected to be signed by Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Taiwan's semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, and his Chinese counterpart Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, when they meet on April 25-26 in Nanjing, China.
Only 4.4 percent of the respondents in the poll, who were drawn from people over age 19, expressed opposition to the extradition idea.

The Mainland Affairs Council and Straits Exchange Foundation have not clearly stated whether the issue of extradition of major criminals will be included in the upcoming talks or any crime fighting agreement that will be signed.
The poll also gauged the level of public satisfaction with the performance of President Ma Ying-jeou, who will have served as president for one year on May 20.
In terms of President Ma's performance, 34.7 percent of the survey's respondents gave him a positive rating, while 57.1 percent gave him a thumbs down.
A total of 1,062 valid samples were collected in the poll, which had a margin of error of plus or minus 3.06 percent.

Since the institutionalized talks between Taiwan and China resumed last June, the issue of joint crime-fighting efforts has been high on the Taiwan government's agenda, as mainland China is known to be the main haven for criminals fleeing Taiwan.

However, the two sides have not yet formalized any such arrangement. What exists at the moment is a non-governmental agreement that was signed in the Taiwan-controlled island of Kinmen in 1992 by the Red Cross societies of the two sides to facilitate repatriation of stowaways and some relatively lesser-known criminals across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: Spain holds tourism fair to attract Taiwanese visitors

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Spanish Chamber of Commerce (CCE) held a tourism fair Wednesday, inviting 200 local travel agents to explore the diversity of Spain's tourism with the aim of increasing the number of visitors from Taiwan.

CCE Director-General Jose Luis Lamas said at a news conference that the fair was designed not only to promote Spain as a tourist destination for Taiwanese people but also to increase their awareness and knowledge of the country.

Ignacio Ducasse, director of the Spanish Tourism Office in Tokyo -- which covers Spain's tourism business in Japan, Taiwan and South Korea -- said that while 90 percent of Spain's tourists come from Europe, the country wants to increase the presence of people from more distant countries.
"We believe that in Taiwan we have strong potential for attracting visitors to Spain. For that reason, Taiwan is a very important market for us," Ducasse told CNA.

He noted that compared with other Asian countries, Taiwan has one of the highest numbers of travelers to Spain, with an average of 30,000 per year, a number that has been growing steadily over the past decade.
While Taiwanese people are familiar with Spain for its art, sports, fashion and food, Ducasse said, Spain has much more to offer as it is a very diverse and rich country.
Maria Luisa Fernandez, deputy director of new markets for Spain's Institute of Tourism, said at the news conference that Spain is unique because it is a "green, sunny and modern tourist destination."
The country also has a rich cultural legacy with some 40 historic sites and 13 cities declared as UNESCO world heritage sites, she added.
The tourism fair provided local travel agents with the latest tourist information and will help them organize various kinds of tourist itineraries for their Taiwanese customers, Fernandez added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2-year-old girl dies after being severely beaten by father

TEXT.P: A 2-year-old girl has died after being severely beaten by her father with a broom, according to prosecutors in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County, who have detained the father.
The case is the second in less than a week involving deaths of children from domestic violence.

The 2-year-old girl's father beat her on Tuesday for playing with water in the bathroom while he was trying to take a nap during a break from work, and then tied her to a bed before going back to work, according to police.

The girl's mother who was taking a nap at the time told police she did not think much of the beating and continued sleeping. When she awoke, she untied the girl, but after doing house chores, noticed the child had fallen unconscious. She rushed the girl to a hospital, but doctors could not save her. The child died Tuesday evening. Doctors discovered that the girl's arms, legs and buttocks were covered with bruises.

The father, 40, was in tears when he saw his unconscious daughter at the hospital. He expressed regret and said he really loved his daughter, but that she was naughty and he was just trying to discipline her. He is being held on a charge of assault causing death.
Chung Chu-sheng, a prosecutor of the Kaohsiung District Prosecutor's Office, said the crime is severe and that the lightest punishment the father could face is seven years imprisonment.

The case was widely reported in Taiwan's media Wednesday, with some TV stations showing a broom which had broken into several pieces. Local media reports said the father's beating caused the broom to break.
The girl's exact cause of death remains under investigation.

The incident is the second this month involving child abuse leading to death. On Saturday, a father in central Taiwan's Changhua City threw his 10-month-old daughter into a pot of boiling water, causing her to die from severe burns.

The two cases have ignited public concerns about the rising incidences of child abuse in Taiwan, with child welfare groups urging parents not to take out their anger on children and the Ministry of the Interior pledging to devote more funding and resources to identifying at-risk families to prevent further violence against children.

DOC.HEADLINE: January-February wages fell steeply, government data shows

TEXT.P: The monthly nominal salary for office workers in Taiwan during the January- February period averaged NT$55,131 (US$1,630), marking a record drop of 12.13 percent year on year, a government agency said Wednesday.

It was the largest ever decrease since 1980 when the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) started compiling such data, said Hung Chien-chung, a DGBAS official.
Per capita actual income also fell 12.18 percent during the same period compared to a year ago, which was also a record plunge since 1980, Huang said.
He attributed the decrease mainly to a noticeable shrinkage in year-end bonuses last year as a result of the global financial crisis which broke in September 2008.
At the same time, a survey found that 53 percent of Taiwan's white-collar workers are now required to work longer every day, while 28 percent of blue- collar workers have shorter work hours.

According to the results of the survey released Wednesday, around 60 percent of the respondents said their wealth has contracted and their economic burdens have increased. Only 5 percent said they felt no financial pressure, compared to the 52 percent who said they were under heavy financial strain.
Some 64 percent said they are not satisfied with their current living standards, compared to six months ago, the poll showed.
In terms of outlook, 16 percent said that they did not think their living standards would recover in three years, and 7 percent felt that it never would.
The poll, commissioned by Business Today Magazine, was conducted April 2-7, and collected 1,640 valid questionnaires from office workers aged 25-44. It had a margin of error of 2.5 percentage points.

Meanwhile, in another survey conducted by Yes123, an online head hunting network, 70 percent of the respondents said they were concerned about losing their jobs and that they only had enough money to get though 6.6 months.

Nearly 50 percent of jobless workers said they spent two hours every day playing video games to kill time, while 40 percent admitted to watching pornographic movies at least once every five days, the Yes123 survey showed. Close to 10 percent said they take anti-depressants to try to relax.

Some 20 percent of the unemployed workers who responded to the poll said that they would have no chance of finding a new job if they remain out of work for more than two years, while 30 percent said they will seek assistance from fortune tellers, and 36 percent plan to visit to temples to ask for divine intervention. Another 10 percent said they will seek help from doctors or professional counselors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Civic groups call for law revisions to prevent child abuse

TEXT.P: Two major social welfare groups urged the government Wednesday to push for a law revision that would require grassroots community leaders to report child abuse cases to the relevant government agencies and thus better protect children's well-being.
The Child Welfare League Foundation (CWLF) and the Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation (TWRF) made the appeal after two heart-wrenching cases of child abuse were reported in the past few days.

On Tuesday, a 2-year-old girl in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County was beaten to death by her father, and a day earlier, a 10-month-old baby girl died in a hospital in central Taiwan's Changhua County after she was dumped into a pot of boiling water over the weekend.

CWLF Chief Executive Wang Yu-min said neither of the two families were included in the Ministry of the Interior's at-risk families databank, which indicates that there are holes in Taiwan's current community security networks.

Wang said grassroots community leaders, such as borough and neighborhood chiefs, better known locally as lichang and linchang in Chinese, have not been included on the list of personnel who are obligated to report child abuse cases to the relevant public agencies.

Under the current Children's Welfare Law, medical professionals, social workers, education personnel, caregivers, police, judicial personnel and other professionals who deal with child and juvenile welfare services are mandated to report cases of child abuse to the relevant city and county government departments.
"Regretfully, this stipulation is not comprehensive and effective enough to expose child abuse cases in time," Wang said.
Noting that the foundation has recorded a total of 141 cases of child abuse since 2005, Wang said the gravity of those cases and the death rate have escalated.

The two latest cases also signaled a decline in the family's function of protecting the safety of children, Wang said. An analysis of major cases of child abuse indicated that 67 percent of them were related to martial problems in the home that had spilled over to the children, she added.
The situation becomes even worse if the parents are alcoholics or drug addicts, Wang said.
TRWF head Liao Ying-chih shared Wang's views, saying that the grassroots community information system should be reinforced to better protect young children from maltreatment.
If necessary, Liao said, residential apartment building managers or guards may also be mandated to report cases of child abuse.

As many of the parents who are most likely to maltreat or abuse their children tend to be drug addicts or alcoholics, the Ministry of the Interior and the Department of Health should collaborate more closely to prevent child abuse, Liao suggested.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exhibition marking 100th anniversary of lyricist's birth opens

TEXT.P: A special exhibition featuring out-of-print albums, manuscripts and other objects related to Lee Lin-chiu, a famous Taiwanese lyricist, opened Wednesday to mark the centenary anniversary of his birth.

Addressing the opening ceremony, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Lee's lyrics gave expression to the heartfelt aspirations and thoughts of the Taiwanese people of his time and enriched Taiwan's cultural legacies.
Many pop singers, young and old, attended the opening ceremony of the exhibition at the preparatory office of the Taiwan New Culture Movement Memorial Hall in Taipei to pay tribute to Lee.
Shih Wen-pin, a pop singer of mainland Chinese origin who rose to fame by writing and singing romantic Taiwanese songs, said he likes Lee's emotional and nostalgic lyrics.
The exhibit followed the release of a CD last weekend by the Taipei's Department of Cultural Affairs featuring digitally remastered original recordings of popular Taiwanese songs from the 1930s.
Nine of the 23 tracks on the CD were written by Lee, who was born in 1909 in Taipei while Taiwan was under Japanese colonial rule.
The songs, including Spring Breeze, Fixing Broken Fishing Nets and Four Seasons, were written before Japan launched its "Kominka Movement" (Japanization Movement) in Taiwan in the early 1940s.

Lee, along with many other Taiwanese musicians, such as composer Teng Yu-hsien and lyricists Chen Chun-yu and Chen Ta-ju, created songs that reflected the daily lives of ordinary Taiwanese people in that era.

"One major motivation behind the creation of those songs was the concern that Taiwanese culture and the originality of Taiwanese music would disappear, as most people were listening to popular Japanese songs during that period, " said Chuang Yung-ming, a noted Taiwanese cultural history expert.
According to Chuang, the attempt to develop "Taiwan's own popular music" was successful, as many people today consider the 1930s the first golden age of Taiwanese popular music.
However, only about 200 of the 500-plus songs created during that period have survived.

Speaking at an April 18 news conference to introduce the new CD, Lee Yong-ping, director of the Taipei City Department of Cultural Affairs, said it was a tough task to find the original recordings and to digitize the music for release on CD.
For one thing, she recalled, many record collectors were reluctant to loan the more than half-a-century-old records that still had good sound quality.
It was also no easy task to get the copyright issues straightened out as most of the musicians have passed away, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Growth in jobless rate slowing down: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Although Taiwan's jobless rate rose to a record high of 5.81 percent in March, the growth in joblessness is slowing down, a spokesman for the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Wednesday.

Had the government not taken measures to create job openings, the jobless rate in March would probably have surged past 6.21 percent, said Huang Chien-chung, deputy director of the DGBAS fourth bureau.

The March jobless rate of 5.81 percent represented a 0.06 percentage point increase from the 5.75 percent recorded in February, and a 1.95 percentage point growth compared to same month in 2008, according to the DGBAS statistics.
The data indicated a rise in the unemployment rate for 11 consecutive months, Huang said.

Even when seasonal changes were taken into consideration, Huang said, the unemployment rate in March remained as high as 5.72 percent, which represented a 0.09 percentage point increase from the previous month and a rise for the 12th month in a row.
Huang said both unadjusted and seasonally adjusted jobless rates for March were the highest since 1978.

However, although unemployment is still rising, the growth rate is slowing, Huang said, citing as an indicator the growth rate for March job losses -- 4.55 percent -- due to business contraction or closure, which he said was the lowest in the past seven months.
Other signs include an increase of 89,000 in the number of government employees from last October to nearly 1.05 million in March, he added.
According to the DGBAS report, the unemployment figure rose to 630,000 in March, which was a record high since the first unemployment survey was conducted in 1978.
The number of jobless people has increased by nearly 213,000 over the past seven months, Huang noted.
Also in March, a record 344,000 people lost their jobs because of business contraction or closure, he added.
The average jobless rate in the first three months of the year was 5.62 percent, up 1.75 percentage points year-on-year.

DOC.HEADLINE: January-February wages fell steeply, government data shows

TEXT.P: The monthly nominal salary for office workers in Taiwan during the January- February period averaged NT$55,131 (US$1,630), marking a record drop of 12.13 percent year on year, a government agency said Wednesday.

It was the largest ever decrease since 1980 when the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) started compiling such data, said Hung Chien-chung, a DGBAS official.
Per capita actual income also fell 12.18 percent during the same period compared to a year ago, which was also a record plunge since 1980, Huang said.
He attributed the decrease mainly to a noticeable shrinkage in year-end bonuses last year as a result of the global financial crisis which broke in September 2008.
At the same time, a survey found that 53 percent of Taiwan's white-collar workers are now required to work longer every day, while 28 percent of blue- collar workers have shorter work hours.

According to the results of the survey released Wednesday, around 60 percent of the respondents said their wealth has contracted and their economic burdens have increased. Only 5 percent said they felt no financial pressure, compared to the 52 percent who said they were under heavy financial strain.
Some 64 percent said they are not satisfied with their current living standards, compared to six months ago, the poll showed.
In terms of outlook, 16 percent said that they did not think their living standards would recover in three years, and 7 percent felt that it never would.
The poll, commissioned by Business Today Magazine, was conducted April 2-7, and collected 1,640 valid questionnaires from office workers aged 25-44. It had a margin of error of 2.5 percentage points.

Meanwhile, in another survey conducted by Yes123, an online head hunting network, 70 percent of the respondents said they were concerned about losing their jobs and that they only had enough money to get though 6.6 months.

Nearly 50 percent of jobless workers said they spent two hours every day playing video games to kill time, while 40 percent admitted to watching pornographic movies at least once every five days, the Yes123 survey showed. Close to 10 percent said they take anti-depressants to try to relax.

Some 20 percent of the unemployed workers who responded to the poll said that they would have no chance of finding a new job if they remain out of work for more than two years, while 30 percent said they will seek assistance from fortune tellers, and 36 percent plan to visit to temples to ask for divine intervention. Another 10 percent said they will seek help from doctors or professional counselors.

The situation becomes even worse if the parents are alcoholics or drug addicts, Wang said.

If necessary, Liao said, residential apartment building managers or guards may also be mandated to report cases of child abuse.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 23, or the 28th day of the third month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1616: William Shakespeare, English playwright and poet whose body of works is considered by most as the greatest in English literature, dies at New Place at the age of 52.
1616: Miguel de Cervantes, Spanish writer best known for his classic satirical novel "Don Quixote," dies at the age of 69.
1873: The Dutch war against the Sultan of Achin begins in northwest Sumatra, Indonesia.
1895: Russia, Germany and France protest the ceding of Chinese territory to Japan.
1897: Lester Pearson, Canadian prime minister from 1963-1968, is born. He won the 1957 Nobel Peace Prize for his part in settling the Suez crisis.
1919: Peking Teachers High School for Girls is formally established.
1928: Shirley Temple Black, American child star who went on to become the U.S. ambassador to Ghana, is born. As Shirley Temple, she was an immensely popular child actress of the 1930s, starring in films such as "Wee Willie Winkie" and "Bright Eyes."
1935: Joseph Stalin officially opens the Moscow underground rail system.
1945: U.S. and Soviet forces meet at Torgau in eastern Germany.
1946: Hsia Kai-chun, noted writer of modern Chinese literature, dies in Shanghai at the age of 63.
1949: Government forces of the Republic of China evacuate Nanking.
1962: In the biggest-ever "ban the bomb" demonstration, some 150,000 people rally in London's Hyde Park.
1965: The Soviet Union launches its first communications satellite.
1965: President Charles de Gaulle of France emphasizes his opposition to the United States' Asian policies by withdrawing French units from naval maneuvers of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization.
1969: A Los Angeles jury decides that Sirhan B. Sirhan should be sent to the gas chamber for the murder of Sen. Robert Kennedy in June 1968.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford declares the Vietnam War is over as panic grips Saigon after the South Vietnamese regime's Cabinet resigns.
1985: The Industrial Technology Research Institute successfully develops an amorphous-silicon solar battery of high commercial value.
1986: National Taiwan University Hospital separates a pair of 14-day-old Siamese twins, saving the life of one of the girls. The twins set a record for being the youngest to be separated.
1990: Li Peng, premier of mainland China, arrives in Moscow for a visit, becoming the most senior Beijing leader to tour the Soviet Union in 26 years.
1991: Tens of thousands of striking Soviet workers fill the streets in Minsk on the eve of the Communist Party plenum.
1997: After 26 days of occupation by rebels, Peru's government launches a sudden attack on the Japanese ambassador's residence in Lima, freeing 71 hostages. Three soldiers, one hostage and all 14 guerrillas die in the attack.
1999: State-run Taiwan Sugar Corp. inaugurates a phalaenopsis plant in Costa Rica, with scores of ranking Costa Rican government officials attending the ceremony.
2000: Former U.S. Assistant Secretary for East Asia and Pacific Affairs Winston Lord visits People First Party Chairman James Soong to exchange opinions on the Taiwan Strait situation.
2000: President-elect Chen Shui-bian and Vice President-elect Annette Lu kick off an island-wide tour to express thanks to their supporters in the March 18 presidential election.
2001: Computer chip giant Intel signs a memorandum of cooperation with the Industrial Development Bureau and the Technology Department under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man is one who sets himself seriously to order his conversation aright."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Decorated painter transcends gaps in East-West artistic traditions

TEXT.P: "East is East and West is West, and never the twain shall meet." Rudyard Kipling's famous line best described the world Liu Kuo-Sung found himself in when he enrolled in the fine arts department of National Taiwan Normal University (NTNU) in Taipei in 1951.
The university's fine arts department was considered the best in Taiwan at the time, with many well-known painters counted among its faculty.

The department, however, could not transcend the divide seen in the art world at the time. A clear schism existed between professors teaching Oriental, or Chinese, painting styles and those emphasizing Western painting techniques.
Teachers of each school would stick to the norms, techniques and traditions of their own camps and would not venture out of the own worlds, much less borrow ideas or skills from the opposing school.

It was this fractured environment that inspired Liu to narrow the art world's boundaries by transcending them and to modernize traditional Chinese ink painting with revolutionary materials over a 60-year career that culminated with his winning the National Award for Arts in 2008.

His use of unprecedented techniques, such as manipulating natural fibers embedded in grainy paper or exposing paper to ink-colored water, were the product of his willingness to experiment following his university years.

Curious about how to erase the gap between East and West, Liu and four other like-minded painters formed a group in 1956 after graduating called the Salon de May to bring Chinese painting into the 20th century.

In an interview with the Central News Agency in 2009, Liu recalled his dissatisfaction at the time with traditional Chinese painting, also known as ink and wash painting because it uses the same ink and brushes as those used in Chinese calligraphy.

He said Chinese painting came a long way before the Yuan dynasty (1206-1368) as painters had moved from "realism, " reproducing nature in their works, to "expressionism, " in which they expressed their perception of the world in their paintings.

But development stalled after the Yuan dynasty because Chinese painting from that time was taught mainly through imitation, with students patterning their works on those of their teachers or other well-known painters.
"New techniques were not encouraged if not repressed, and the creativity of the students waned during this process of meticulous imitation." Liu said.

As a result, he said, Chinese painting was trapped in a rigid mold, evident by the minimal difference between modern and centuries-old works in terms of their subjects or the techniques used to create them.

Liu's criticism echoes the views of some early 20th century Chinese thinkers, such as Kang Youwei (1858-1927) and Chen Duxiu (1879-1942), who believed Chinese painting was doomed to be replaced by western art because it no longer reflected the modern world and did not resonate on an emotional level with modern people.
Liu believed Chinese painters' overemphasis on traditional technique, especially the use of the tip of fine brushes, had contributed to the lack of innovation in the art form.

"'If you cannot use the tip of the brush as dexterously as a calligrapher, you can never be a good painter.' That is what the traditional painters would tell their students, and that is what I opposed the most." Liu said.

Hsiao Chun-rei, a professor of fine arts history at National Cheng Kung University in Tainan, said Liu's advocacy of modernizing Chinese painting was not surprising, considering it came at a time when there was a vacuum in the field in Taiwan.

"In the 1950s, Taiwan had been weaned away from the influence of Japan, which left Taiwan after the end of World War II. It was also separated politically from China at the end of the Chinese civil war and thereby was sheltered from the influence of China," Hsiao said.
This provided the young Liu and his fellow artists in the Salon De May an opportunity to allow their imaginations to run wild and create their own innovative style.
To break new ground in Chinese ink painting, Liu began to explore new techniques. He first replaced the delicate brushes and brush pens with a big brush used by artillery troops to clean cannons.
The big brush gave Liu's landscape paintings simple yet dynamic slashes that contrasted sharply with the fine, delicate strokes seen in traditional works.

Another of his innovations, and one that has become his trademark, was to paint on coarse paper embedded with randomly scatter natural fibers and then rip the fiber from the paper to create irregular white lines uncovered by ink.
By manipulating these lines of various width, Liu created unusual and beautiful shapes that cannot be produced by a painting brush.
Yuan Chin-ta, a professor at National Taiwan Normal University, describes Liu's innovation as "a stroke of genius, " as there had never been any white lines in Chinese painting.
"Liu produced it by removing ink rather than using white paint and created a new form of expression. It was unprecedented, " Yuan said.
Liu also explored what he called the "water print method, " in which he would let colored ink be absorbed in water and then lay the paper on the water to absorb the ink.
To create an even more exotic pattern using the technique, Liu would stack sheets of the water-soaked paper, leaving tiny air pockets between them.
He would then apply ink along the edges of the paper where bubbles would form, leaving the ink to migrate with the bubbles to create unexpected lines, shapes and grains.

By employing these techniques skillfully, Liu created many strange abstract paintings which look like mountains, streams, rocks and clouds but are quite different from those seen in traditional Chinese paintings.
Poet Yu Kuang-chung described Liu's paintings as "floating between the real and unreal, " as depicting things that look like something without clearly defining what it is.

In another deviation from tradition, Liu incorporates the modern world in his art. Inspired by the launch of Apollo 8 in 1969, Liu unveiled a series of paintings that year representing the Earth and the moon.

His painting "Which is Earth" not only earned him the top prize at the Mainstream '69 exhibition in the United States and praise as "the most sensitive modern painter, " it also "took Chinese landscape painting from the Earth to the universe, " says National Cheng Kung University's Hsiao.
Liu's contributions to the arts were formally recognized in 2008 when he won the National Award for Arts, the highest honor conferred to artists in Taiwan.
In honoring Liu, the award organizer hailed him as "a traditionalist with a revolutionary spirit."

Liu took the honor in stride, saying he believed modernizing Chinese painting was the only chance for this type of art to survive, and that he made every effort to push this innovative style to its limit and enhance the glory of Chinese painting.
But he refuses to say if he succeeded.
"Did I realize my goal? That will be up to the people following me to determine."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA looking to revise rules pertaining to international NGOs

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that it is reviewing a set of regulations, in collaboration with other governmental agencies, with the aim of creating a more friendly environment for international non-governmental organizations (INGOs) to set up chapters in Taiwan.

"We are looking at relaxing the current regulations to make it easier for INGOs to set up offices in Taiwan, " said David C.K. Wu, deputy head of the MOFA's NGO Affairs Committee, at a regular press briefing.

"If INGOs can set up their offices here, it will help significantly to boost the connections and cooperation between local NGOs and their international counterparts, which is also vital to Taiwan's globalization," he added.

The issues of resident and work permits and taxation are the most crucial for INGOs planning to set up headquarters, secretariats or local chapters in Taiwan, Wu said. The two sets of regulations governing these matters were introduced more than two decades ago and are now outdated, he added.
Some INGOs have even complained that Taiwan's regulations are "unfriendly," Wu said.

According to Wu, his committee held an inter-governmental agency meeting March 24 to review the regulations and suggested that the Ministry of Interior work with the relevant agencies to relax the rules.

Representatives from several INGOs also attended the meeting, including the Asia Foundation, the Democratic Pacific Union, the International Commission on Irrigation and the Drainage and International Association for Volunteer Effort Taiwan, Wu said.
Among them, the San Francisco-based Asia Foundation showed the greatest interest in setting up a branch in Taiwan, he added.

Noting that Singapore and Bangkok are the two most favored locations for INGOs seeking to gain a footing in Asia, Wu said the MOFA has also asked its representatives offices in those countries to study the regulations there for reference.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA opens 'taiwanlook' boutique to promote local culture

TEXT.P: Taiwan's largest trade promotion agency opened its first Taiwan-themed boutique and souvenir shop at the Taipei World Trade Center (TWTC) Thursday with the aim of advertising Taiwan's culture among the millions of foreign exhibitors and buyers that come to the country every year.

Walter M.S. Yeh, executive vice president of the semi-governmental Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA), said at the formal opening of the shop that the TWTC, one of the landmarks in Taipei, each year attracts three to four million visitors who come to Taiwan for various types of conventions.

Seeking to maximize the advantages of this influx of visitors, the TAITRA started planning last year to open a Taiwan-themed souvenir shop at the TWTC to promote Taiwan's culture and its innovative industries, he added.
"We hope that visitors from home and abroad will be able to sample the richness and creativity of Taiwan's diverse culture at the souvenir shop and boutique," Yeh said.
"We also hope that visitors who see the souvenirs from different parts of Taiwan will decide to stay longer to further explore the city and the country," he added.
According to Yeh, the shop, called "taiwanlook, " will not only sell cultural and creative souvenirs, but will also occasionally launch limited edition products on different convention themes.

In addition to souvenirs, the work of local artists and museum pieces will be showcased at the shop, Yeh said, adding that the first exhibit was co-hosted by National Taiwan Museum and the National Culture and Arts Foundation.
TAITRA was founded in 1970 to help promote foreign trade and is sponsored by the government, industry associations and several commercial organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shopping voucher program helps slow consumption decline: MOEA

TEXT.P: The decline in private consumption showed signs of slowdown in the first quarter, thanks partly to the shopping voucher program introduced by the government in January to stimulate consumption, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Thursday.

This positive development is evident in the performance of the country's retail trade and the food and beverage services where the revenue contraction has slowed despite the economic downturn, said Huang Chi-shih, chief of the MOEA's Department of Statistics.

The latest MOEA statistics show that these sectors' revenue amounted to NT$877.6 billion (US$25.9 billion) in the first quarter, up marginally by 0.28 percent from the previous quarter but down by 4.46 percent from the same period last year.
Nevertheless, the year-on-year decline was obviously smaller compared with the year-on-year contraction of 6.47 percent recorded in the fourth quarter of 2008, the statistics indicate.

In the first quarter of 2009, the revenue of general merchandise retailers -- including department stores, supermarkets, chain convenience stores and hypermarkets -- totaled NT$213.7 billion, a slight increase of 0.88 percent from the previous quarter.

According to Huang, from Jan 18. when the shopping vouchers were issued to the public until the end of March, the wholesale trade, retail trade and food and beverage service sectors received vouchers amounting to NT$66.7 billion.
Of this amount, NT$30.4 billion, or 46 percent, went to general merchandise retailers, Huang said.
The vouchers are being given out until April 30 as part of an economic stimulus package to boost consumer spending and economic growth in light of the current economic downturn.

All Taiwanese citizens -- with the exception of those living abroad without identity cards, household registration or residency rights -- and their foreign spouses are eligible to each receive NT$3,600 in vouchers, which must be exchanged for goods or services by Sept. 30, 2009.

Data from the Ministry of Finance show that as of April 20, more than NT$65.53 billion, or 78.26 percent, of the total of NT$83.73 billion vouchers issued had been used by consumers and cashed by the businesses that received them.
The largest amount of vouchers cashed on a single day -- NT$8.16 billion -- was recorded Feb. 3, the second working day after the Chinese New Year holiday, according to Bank of Taiwan.
The daily amount that was being cashed stood at between NT$2 billion and NT$3 billion on the other working days during the week after the new year holiday, the bank said.
However, the daily amount has decreased significantly to between NT$200 million and NT$500 million in recent days, probably because most consumers have already spent their vouchers, the bank said.

While the shopping voucher program might have helped slow down the decline in private consumption, its effect in terms of encouraging consumers to spend more than the NT$3,600 in vouchers remains doubtful.

Most department stores and hypermarkets complained that although their sales soared during the two weeks leading up to the Chinese New Year holiday, revenue has since dropped as the vouchers are gradually being used up by consumers.

During the holiday period, shopping voucher payments accounted for 20 percent to 30 percent of the total revenue received by department stores, and contributed to 40 percent to 50 percent of the revenue of hypermarkets and supermarkets, according to statistics from the businesses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Japan work to launch natural disaster relief platform

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that Taiwan and Japan will be in charge of launching an international disaster relief and rescue platform to coordinate humanitarian aid efforts by non-governmental organizations (NGOs) in the Southeast Asian region.

"The initiative aims at increasing connections and exchanges between Taiwan's NGOs with their counterparts in the region to better facilitate and coordinate their humanitarian aid efforts," said David C.K. Wu, deputy head of the MOFAs NGO Affairs Committee, at a regular press briefing.

According to Wu, under the leadership of Taiwan and Japan, a memorandum was signed by nine NGOs from Taiwan, six from Japan and one each from the U.S. and Indonesia at the 5th Southeast Asian NGO Forum that took place in Japan last week.
the agreement provides a platform for the signatory NGOs to launch a mechanism in four years to coordinate humanitarian aid in the event of any natural disasters in the region, he added.

As to other NGO-related programs, Wu said his committee will work with the Taiwan Nurses Association to dispatch nursing personnel to Afghanistan June 1 to run a three-month training program for Afghan nurses.
This initiative is being carried out in recognition of the work of Afghan human rights activist Sima Samar, who won the third Asia Democracy and Human Rights Award (ADHRA) last November, he said.

The award was created in 2006 by the government-funded Taiwan Foundation for Democracy to honor individuals or groups dedicated to democratic development, the advancement of human rights and the building of democracy.

Samar, who is a doctor and the chair of the Afghanistan Independent Human Rights Commission, in 1989 established the Shuhada Organization, which operates 12 clinics and 4 hospitals in Afghanistan and Pakistan, all dedicated to the provision of health care to Afghan women and girls.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan develops world's first Android notebook

TEXT.P: The Institute for Information Industry (III) recently developed the world's first Android-based notebook, which is expected to help create enormous business opportunities for Taiwan's information and communication technology (ICT) industry, according to an industry report released Thursday.

Android is a software platform and operating system developed by Google and later the Open Handset Alliance, which enables developers to create compelling mobile applications. It is built on the open source Linux Kernel.

The successful development of the Android notebook is an important milestone for the notebook market, and the products are likely to take a slice of the market, according to the report released by the III's Market Intelligence & Consulting Institute (MIC).
This year, the output of Taiwan-made notebooks is expected to increase to 23 million units, the MIC forecast.

Following the development of Android-based handsets, the government-backed III also successfully developed several key software technologies based on Android, including a whiteboard equipped with a handwriting recognition program for real-time communications. The whiteboard has a touch screen that allows users to send handwritten messages during long distance teleconferencing.
In addition, the company has developed a mobility-assisted device equipped with handwriting input and map marking functions that enable users to compile a travelog at any time during a trip.

In view of the great business potential in the applications of the Android operating system, the III will help domestic ICT manufacturers to grab the opportunities to produce more new Android-based products in order to better meet consumer demand, the report concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: Repatriated Chinese tourists return, this time with travel documents

TEXT.P: The 38 Chinese visitors who were repatriated upon arrival in Taiwan last week because they lacked entry permits, are returning to Taiwan Thursday after having their travel documents prepared this time around, according to a travel agency source.

The group from China's northeastern city of Shenyang, comprising of 37 tourists and one tour guide, are traveling to Taiwan from the Chinese southeastern port city of Xiamen via ship, with a transit flight from Taiwan's outlying island of Kinmen, said Lin Chin-jung, chairman of Taiwan's Travel Quality Assurance Association.
They are expected to arrive in Taipei's Songshan Airport later in the day.
The tourists, mostly retirees from Liaoning Province, where Shenyang is located, had stayed in Xiamen City since April 18 after they were repatriated, Lin said.
"They were innocent visitors as they didn't know that the travel agency in charge of their Taiwan tour had not applied for entry permits for them in advance," Lin added.

After being repatriated, the group stayed in Xiamen, waiting for their travel documents to be arranged by Beijing's quasi-official Cross Strait Tourism Exchange Association and Taipei-based Taiwan Strait Tourism Association, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Airport worker investigated for money smuggling

TEXT.P: Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport police have launched a probe into allegations that a female security officer was providing cover for a traveler who was smuggling gold and foreign currency to the tune of NT$2 billion (US$59.17 million) out of Taiwan over a three-year period.
Airport police authorities said they are investigating a security officer surnamed Wu and a traveler identified as Pu.
The case broke last week when airport police officers caught Pu as he was attempting to fly out of Taiwan with more than 10 kilograms of gold bars in his luggage.
In a long-term tracking operation, airport police discovered that Pu had been traveling to Hong Kong three or four times a week for the past three years.
They found that all of Pu's flights to Hong Kong coincided with Wu's shifts at the airport near Taipei and the police suspect that Wu and others may have been in cahoots with Pu for a long time.
On every trip to Hong Kong, Pu carried gold and foreign currency worth more than NT$30 million, which he sometimes declared and sometimes did not, the police suspect.

According to the video footage from the airport's X-ray machines, even when Pu declared the gold or foreign currency he was carrying, Wu did not comprehensively check the declared items. And it was obvious that Pu was not declaring all the valuables and money he was carrying, the police said.

Based on the amount that Pu declared on two consecutive one-day trips to Hong Kong late last year, it is estimated that he was actually carrying 74 million Japanese yen, 860,000 Singapore dollars, 27,000 Swiss francs, 18,000 euros and US$800, airport police said.

The police estimated that Pu smuggled out at least NT$30 million worth of gold and foreign currency on each trip, which they said means he probably took more than NT$2 billion in money and gold out of Taiwan illegally over a period of three years.

Taiwan law stipulates that travelers are not allowed to take more than US$10,000 worth of foreign currency or gold out of the country and are required to declare any amounts in excess of this figure to airport customs authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, falling NT$0.040 to close at NT$33.820.
A total of US$522 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.860 and fluctuated between NT$33.781 and NT$33.887.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet approves renewable energy promotion plan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/09 17:49:37 (MOEA), the government will invest NT$25 billion (US$739.64 million) (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Cabinet approved a project Thursday to further develop the country's renewable energy industries and to attract private investment in the sector.
Under the project proposed by the Ministry of Economic Affairs over he next five years in the development of renewable energy and will subsidize the general installation of energy saving devices.
It will also provide NT$20 billion for research and development of green energy technologies, which is expected in turn to draw NT$200 billion in private investment in the industry.

The project will target industries that focus on solar energy, light emitting diode (LED) lighting, wind power, biomass fuel, hydrogen power, fuel cells, electric vehicles, energy information and communication technology.
Premier Liu Chao-shiuan told reporters after a Cabinet meeting that building Taiwan into a low-carbon society is one of the administration's priority policies.
He referred again to his pledge earlier in the month at a national energy conference that the government will spare no effort to advance its goal of building a "low carbon-emission homeland."
The premier said he was confident that the MOEA project will help to stimulate Taiwan's renewable energy industry and create more job opportunities in that sector.

Liu added his voice to President Ma Ying-jeou's call for the legislature to quickly pass a renewable energy bill that has been stalled for a long time, saying that the MOEA should push for the legislation's passage as it will provide a legal basis for the development of the energy sector.

Under a NT$500 billion four-year economic stimulus plan proposed by the Cabinet last November, the government will spend 10 percent of the total to promote green energy industries and to fund engineering work on renewable energy, Liu said.

Meanwhile, the MOEA should set up a task force to examine the difficulties that green energy industries are facing and help them clear technical bottlenecks and deal with investment and operating problems, the premier suggested.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's share prices marginally lower

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices edged lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, losing 10.87 points, or 0.18 percent, to close at 5,875.24, snapping three days of gains.
The local bourse opened at 5,900.45 and dropped to a low of 5,789.27 early in the session before rebounding to 5,903.47.
A total of 6.05 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$130.24 billion (US$3.85 billion).
The TAIEX has risen sharply from a low of 4,242.61 points recorded on Jan. 20, making it the second strongest market in the world, behind only the Shanghai stock market.
Two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up at 0.4 percent, and plastics and chemicals stocks advancing 0.3 percent.

Six other major stock categories lost ground, with construction stocks moving down the most at 2.2 percent. Banking and financial shares shed 1.9 percent, foodstuff shares fell 1.8 percent, cement issues dropped 0.5 percent, paper and pulp stocks lost 0.4 percent, and textile shares dropped 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,252 to 916, with 141 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$274 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Defense ministry 'determined' to get to bottom of bribery scandal

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Defense investigators probing a scandal involving senior military officers allegedly buying their way to the posts of generals, will forsake holidays to get to the bottom of the case, Deputy Minister of National Defense Chang Liang-jen said Thursday.

"It would be a round-the-clock, all-year-round task to proceed with the investigations into the bribery scandal involving a group of generals who were promoted en masse when former President Chen Shui-bian was in office," Chang said at the Legislative Yuan.
"The Ministry of National Defense is resolved not to leave any stone unturned to crack the scandal, " Chang said in response to an inquiry by Legislator Lee Chia-chin from the ruling Kuomintang.
According to the local media reports this week, prosecutors will first focus on around 30 generals promoted by Chen, who left office last May after serving two terms from 2000 to 2008.
Defense Minister Chen Chao-min told lawmakers recently that he hopes the Defense Ministry will come up with investigative reports in three months.

On Thursday, Legislator Lee criticized the military over a recent spate of scandals, deriding that "the ROC (Republic of China) Armed Forces could put themselves to rout from within, without China's military invasion."
Chang responded to Lee by saying that it would be unfair to vilify the ROC Armed Forces as undisciplined or lacking combative capability simply because of a few scandals.
Marine Corps Commander Lt. Gen. Hsu Shang-wen was questioned by prosecutors the day before on suspicion of taking bribes from private suppliers.
According to newspaper reports published Tuesday, prosecutors said they will also investigate several hundred lieutenants and major generals promoted under Chen's presidency.
The investigation follows the recent indictment of a retired lieutenant general on charges of bribery, blackmail and leaking secrets. He allegedly tried to bribe his superiors for a promotion.
In a separate case, three colonels have been indicted on corruption charges.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2009 Urban Nomad film festival opens in Taipei

TEXT.P: The 2009 Urban Nomad Film Fest officially opened Thursday at the Taipei Artist Village (TAV) and Nanhai Gallery, according to the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT).

"The AIT is pleased to co-sponsor the 2009 Urban Nomad Film Fest and has invited Brent Hoff, noted American editor-in-chief and curator of an innovative San Francisco-based DVD magazine called Wholphin, to attend the festival and discuss his career and projects," the AIT said in a press release.
Wholphin magazine collects rare and unseen short films, with each issue riding a fine line between delivering solid entertainment and responsible information.

Hosted by the AIT and the TAV, the Urban Nomad Film Fest will run through May 9 in Taipei and Hsinchu, featuring submissions of short films from Taiwan and abroad that discuss this year's theme of "Sex, Drugs and Human Rights."

Launched in 2002, Urban Nomad Film Fest is the only underground independent film festival that supports independent filmmaking in Taiwan. It encourages local independent filmmakers to develop contacts with other filmmakers in the region.
Since 2007, when the festival began touring outside Taiwan, it has appeared in Hong Kong, Miami and Basel, Switzerland.
Details on the screenings and seminars at this year's festival are available at the Web site http://urbannomadfilmfest.blogspot.com/.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shopping vouchers help boost theme parks business: tourism bureau

TEXT.P: Business at Taiwan's theme parks and resorts grew significantly in the first quarter of this year compared to Q1 last year, the Tourism Bureau said Thursday, attributing the growth to the government's shopping voucher program and other promotion efforts.

The latest statistics provided by 24 amusement parks and resorts in Taiwan showed that the number of visitors in the first quarter grew by 26.21 percent compared to the same period last year, the bureau said.

Some 2.23 million people visited these venues in Q1 this year, generating revenues of NT$1.34 billion (US$39.66 million) , which represented an increase of 12.19 percent over the same period last year, the data showed.

The Formosan Aboriginal Culture Village in Nantou County, LeoFoo Village Theme Park in Hsinchu County, Janfusun Fancy World in Yunlin County, Window on China Theme Park in Taoyuan County and Hualien Farglory Ocean Park are the five most popular amusement parks in Taiwan, the bureau said.
"The government's shopping voucher program and related promotion programs during the winter vacation contributed to the growth in first quarter of 2009," the bureau stated in a press release.

Some 91 percent of eligible Taiwan citizens had picked up their NT$3,600 worth of vouchers as of Jan. 18 to pay for goods and services. The vouchers are the business end of an NT$85.7 billion program that is part of a government economic stimulus package.

The Tourism Bureau said that the publication of a magazine and the establishment of a Web site to provide comprehensive information about theme parks and resorts in Taiwan helped fuel the public's interest in these places, with some amusement parks seeing growth of 40 percent both in the number of visitors and in revenue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't will recruit over 1,400 social workers by 2015

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) announced Wednesday that it will recruit 1,427 social workers from 2010-2015 to set up a more comprehensive social service network for the country.

The announcement came amid sharp criticism from society for Taiwan's lack of a sufficient social service mechanism and professional social workers to help troubled families, after two girls were abused to death by their fathers in the past week.

The two girls died on two consecutive days, shocking the entire country. One was a 10-month-old baby who suffered severe burns after her father threw her into a pot of boiling water during an argument with her mother. She died Tuesday morning. The other was a 2-year-old who died Tuesday evening after her father beat her severely with a broom for playing with water while he was trying to take a nap.

Since the first death occurred, the MOI has pledged to devote more funding and resources to identifying more high-risk families, including those with parents who abuse drugs or alcohol or frequently fight.
To help prevent recurrence of such tragedies, the MOI said in a statement that it will hire another 1,427 social workers to serve communities throughout Taiwan during the six-year period.
Before that aim is achieved, the MOI said it will continue helping local governments fill the gap by adding new members to their current lineup of social workers.
To date, 320 child protection social workers and 190 anti-domestic violence and sexual assault workers have been stationed in localities across the country in the past year.

The ministry also uses a portion of earnings from the state lotteries to help promote programs directed at helping women, the elderly, the physically and mentally challenged, as well as 29,000 children in high-risk families.
Since the beginning of this year, 193 social workers have been dispatched to local governments across the country with the lotteries' earnings, and 265 for the whole of 2008, it said.
But this is widely believed to be insufficient given Taiwan's population of 23 million people.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan wins big in iF concept award 2009

TEXT.P: Have you ever had the experience of seeing your mobile phone flying out of its holder when you turn your car around? If you do, a "sticker phone" may be your solution.

The design by Liu Hsiang-ling, a student from National Taiwan University of Science and Technology (NTUST) , is one of the winners of the iF concept award 2009 announced recently by the Hanover-based International Forum Design GmbH (iF).

The mobile phone made of polysiloxane and installed with solar panels on the back was born exactly out of Liu's own driving experience. The device, which can be stuck to a window, will stay put when you drive, and even better, it can be recharged by absorbing sunlight.
"I drive everyday to school, and I have always had the idea of having my mobile phone stick to the window glass, just like a doll," Liu said.
The iF concept award, which has been held for the second year since 2008, is an international competition for new talent that is open to students in the fields of design and architecture.
A total of 3,221 concepts and ideas were submitted by students from 39 countries this year.

Nine of the concepts and ideas contributed by Taiwanese students are included in the list of the "Best 100" announced last month by iF, making the country one of the biggest winners of the annual event.

Of these nine designs, three are by students from NTUST. The university has been rated second by the "iF University Ranking" that is based on the performance of contestants in the iF concept award over a period of three years.
The other two NTUST winners, besides the "sticker phone", are "eat clean" tableware by Yeh Ming-hong and Lai Chung-ping, as well as "rocking chair" by Kuo Tsu-jung.

The "eat clean" design is intended as a solution for people who feel uncomfortable about using cutlery which has been in contact with the table top. The design, which combines the special shape and weight principle of a seesaw, enables the parts of the cutlery in contact with the mouth to always stay away from the table top whichever way the cutlery is placed.
The "rocking chair, " meanwhile, enables users to adjust their sitting positions to increase fun and comfort.
Another of this year's winner is "braille scanner" by Wang Fu-hua from Tainan National University of the Arts.
The design, a mobile phone intended for the visually impaired which can convert braille into audible speech, is listed among the first 28 of the "Best 100" that shared 30,000 euros in prize money.

Others Taiwanese designs on the "Best 100" list also include the "so sweet" clinical thermometer jointly contributed by Hsu Chun-chia from National Chiao Tung University in Hsinchu City, Liu Rong-cheng and Chang Chia-wei from Ming-Chi University of Technology (MCUT) in Taipei County, and Chen You-ren from National Taipei University of Technology.
The design turns clinical thermometers into lollipops, whose sweet coating melts on contact with saliva, giving users a pleasant experience while having their temperature taken.

The "rabbit hanger" by Yeh Hsin-hua from Shu-Te University in Kaohsiung County is not only a unique clothes hanger but also a useful tool for putting on clothes and shoes. On one end of the hanger is a hole for doing up a zipper and on the other, a shoe puller.

The "freedle" by Mao Chia-lin, Huang Cheng-jia and Li Pei-sin from National Kaohsiung Normal University is a needle equipped with an eye made of soft flexible nylon, allowing the thread to be threaded more easily. Also, the needle's fluorescent material makes it easier to find if it gets dropped on the floor or somewhere dark.

The "plug for visually" by Lin Chia-hsiang from Taichung-based Chaoyang University of Technology involves the creation of tracks leading into the plug socket to allow the visually impaired to insert the plug into the socket more easily.
