DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan researchers extract brain-boosting nutrient from squid skin

TEXT.P: A local research team has successfully extracted a brain-boosting nutrient from cheap squid skin that can improve memory and enhance learning ability, a fisheries official said Thursday.

Researchers at the Fisheries Research Institute under the Council of Agriculture have been able to extract PL-DHA (phospholipid docosahexaenoic acid), a memory enhancing substance, from the skin of squid, the official explained.

According to the official, PL-DHA is better than TG-DHA, another form of docosahexaenoic acid that is commonly found in deep-sea fish oil, in inhibiting degradation of the intellect because it can cross the blood brain barrier and be absorbed directly into the brain.

The researchers have also discovered that the PL-DHA squid extract is effective in reviving neural cells and enhancing the content of three oxidation-resistant enzymes -- GSH, CAT and SOD -- as well as moderating free radical-induced oxidative damage to neural cells, thus slowing down the accumulation of plaque and tangles in brain cells.
Quoting medical reports, the official said Alzheimer's and other senile dementia diseases are associated with the accumulation of plaque and tangles in brain.
At present, the official went on, more than 24 million people suffer from senile dementia, with the rate of new cases growing at 4.6 million every year.
"This means that one person in the world falls victim to Alzheimer's every six minutes, " the official said.

Taiwan boasts abundant squid catches, with annual output reaching between 150,000 tons and 200,000 tons, the official continued, adding that by-products from squid processing accounts for 35 percent of the total catch, with squid skins making up about 15 percent of the by-products.
As squid skins are tough and unpalatable, they are usually processed into powder that is used as an additive to animal and livestock feed.
Following the discovery of PL-DHA in squid skins, the official said, the Fisheries Research Institute will step up the development of squid skin-based health products to enhance its market value.

DOC.HEADLINE: President set to visit Central America twice this summer

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou will visit Central America twice between late May and July to attend presidential inaugurations in two of Taiwan's allies in the region, political sources said Thursday.

According to the president's travel plan, he will depart for a week-long Central America visit in late May that will take him to El Salvador to attend the inauguration of President-elect Mauricio Funes and to several of Taiwan's other allies in the region.
In July, the sources said, Ma is scheduled to visit Panama for three to four days, mainly to attend the inauguration of that country's next president.

Ma made his first overseas tour as Taiwan's head of state last August when he visited the Dominican Republic and Paraguay. For that trip, Ma used a regularly scheduled commercial flight to the United States, from where he flew to Central America via chartered plane.

For the forthcoming two visits, the sources said, the president will fly on chartered flights on the entire journeys, with no decision yet made on which carrier will be contracted to provide the flights.
On customary transit stops in the United States, the sources went on, safety, convenience and comfort will remain the top guiding principles in all relevant arrangements.
Central and South America and the Caribbean are Taiwan's diplomatic stronghold, with many of its 23 diplomatic allies located there.
Meanwhile, the sources went on, Ma is also likely to attend a summit meeting between the leaders of Taiwan and its South Pacific allies to be held in August or September in the Solomon Islands.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 24, or the 29th day of the third month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1731: Daniel Defoe, British journalist, novelist and economist, dies at the age of 71. His works include "Robinson Crusoe" and "Moll Flanders."
1800: The U.S. Congress votes to set up a congressional library.
1898: Spain declares war on the United States after receiving a U.S. ultimatum to pull out of Cuba.
1919: Chan Tien-yu, a railway pioneer in China, dies in Hankou at the age of 59.
1941: Hsieh Chin-yuan, a Chinese hero in the War of Resistance Against Japan, is assassinated at the age of 37. The ROC Army regimental commander led his "800 Brave Fighters" in a heroic battle against invading Japanese troops at a warehouse in Shanghai. Shanghai was captured by the Japanese on Nov. 11, 1937, after three months of fierce fighting.
1946: The ROC government postpones the convention of the National Assembly set for May 6, 1946.
1948: Lin Hsien-tang is appointed head of the Historical Research Commission of Taiwan Province.
1955: The Bandung Conference ends with five Asian states condemning colonialism by both the West and the Soviet Union.
1963: "Liang Shan-po and Chu Ying-tai," a movie directed by Lee Han-hsiang, premieres in Taipei and receives a warm welcome from a large audience.
1965: The Indonesian government formally takes control of all foreign companies in the country.
1967: Soviet cosmonaut Vladimir Komarov plunges to Earth and dies when parachute straps on his Soyuz craft get tangled.
1970: Vice Premier Chiang Ching-kuo arrives in New York for a visit and survives an assassination attempt in front of his hotel by a pro-Taiwan independence radical.
1970: Mainland China launches its first satellite, the Dong Fang Hong, into orbit.
1970: The Food and Fertilizer Technology Center of the Asian and Pacific Council is inaugurated in Taipei.
1974: A 16-member Orient Trade Mission of the U.S. Pacific Northwest International Trade Council, led by William Martin, president of the council, arrives in Taipei for a three-day business trip.
1975: Thousands of Vietnamese refugees are flown to Guam as communists move rapidly in their takeover of South Vietnam.
1976: The 1976 convention of 4-H Clubs opens in Taipei with more than 300 delegates taking part.
1981: A train encounters a landslide while on its way to Mt. Ali in Chiayi County, killing 10 passengers and injuring 19 others.
1986: Wallis Simpson, Duchess of Windsor, for whom a British king gave up his throne amid great controversy, dies in Paris at the age of 89.
1986: ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Chu Fu-sung and Paraguayan Foreign Minister Carlos Augusto Saldivar sign an extradition treaty in Taipei on behalf of their respective governments.
1990: West and East Germany agree to set July 2 as the date for economic union, a prelude to full political unification.
1996: Russian President Boris Yeltsin meets with his mainland Chinese counterpart, Jiang Zemin, at the start of a visit to Beijing.
1997: The head of states of Russia, mainland China, Kazakhstan, Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan sign a pact on troop reduction along the former Sino-Soviet border.
2000: The ROC National Assembly begins to fade into history after it downgrades itself to a virtual ceremonial organization without much power by passing a series of constitutional amendments during a third reading.
2001: Competition at the Second Asian Physics Olympiad kicks off in Taipei with 81 senior high school students from 12 countries participating.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man sometimes also meets with distress; but a fool, when in distress, becomes reckless."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan's export sector revitalizing: MOEA

TEXT.P: The decline in Taiwan's export orders has not worsened further since hitting bottom in January, indicating that the export sector is gradually revitalizing, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Friday.

The latest MOEA statistics show that export orders amounted to US$23.94 billion in March, representing an increase of 18.99 percent from the previous month and a decrease of 24.29 percent from the same month of last year.

The year-on-year decline marks a slight increase compared with February, when the year-on-year decline was 22.27 percent, but was noticeably narrower compared with January, when a year-on-year plunge of 41.67 percent was recorded, according to the statistics.

Huang Chi-shih, chief of the MOEA's Department of Statistics, said the development might be a sign of the revitalization of the export sector and is thanks mainly to the restoration of demand from China -- one of Taiwan's major export markets.

In March, orders from China accounted for 25.7 percent of the total orders received, putting China back into position as Taiwan's top export market for the first time since October 2008, when the position was replaced by the United States, Huang noted.

According to Lin Chu-chia, an economics professor at National Chengchi University, China's latest economic stimulus measures to encourage home appliance purchases by rural consumers have played an important role in reinvigorating Taiwan's export sector.

Lin said that during a recent visit to China when he met with Taiwanese businessmen based in Shenzhen, Shanghai and Beijing, most of them shared the view that the economic situation has been showing slight improvement.
Meanwhile, the MOEA-compiled index for industrial production outlook stood at 51.26 in March, the first time since June 2008 it has exceeded 50, which signals a revival in demand, Huang said.
An index of over 50 is considered an indication that production will increase in the coming month.

According to Huang, many manufacturers of computer and electronic parts and components are expecting their restored production capacity utilization to continue into June and July, thanks to a recent influx of rush orders and short- term orders.

DOC.HEADLINE: New routes for regular cross-strait flights will be worked out: MAC

TEXT.P: New routes for regularly scheduled flights across the Taiwan Strait will be discussed during the upcoming round of cross-strait talks scheduled for April 26, Lai Shin-yuan, the head of the Cabinet-level Mainland Council Affairs (MAC) said Friday.

"Both northern and southern routes must be finalized during the talks between Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), slated to open in Nanjing Sunday," Lai said.
The MAC coordinates Taiwan's policy toward China and oversees SEF operations.

Speaking during a radio interview, Lai said that as far as Taiwan is concerned, the greater the number of regularly scheduled cross-strait flights set up the better, but added that it will be difficult to increase the number of cross- strait flights further on the existing flight routes.

Noting that the Taiwanese negotiators hope that during the upcoming talks they will achieve a target of increasing the number of flights from the existing 180 weekly flights to 375, Lai said an eventual 500 flights per week is their minimum demand.
"The SEF negotiators will try their utmost to push back the boundaries," she continued.

The third round of Chiang-Chen talks will discuss four issues -- regularly scheduled cross-strait flights, financial cooperation, tackling cross-strait crime and providing legal assistance, and opening Taiwan to investment from China.

On Taiwan's opening to Chinese capital and investment, Lai said the Ministry of Economic Affairs will adopt a "positive list, " although the opening will be gradual and categories involving national security will not be included on the list.
"The list, as well as opening procedures, will be made known after the talks, followed by fact-finding trips to Taiwan by Chinese investors," she announced.

Relevant regulations should be worked out by the third quarter of this year, Lai added, although she pointed out that it is still not known exactly when Chinese capital will be allowed to enter Taiwan, as this "will depend on how Beijing's policy unfolds. "

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier demands strengthened social welfare network

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan directed relevant government agencies Thursday to form a task force to map out a project to strengthen the social welfare network in light of a recent increase in the number of deaths caused by child abuse, according to a press release issued by the Government Information Office later that day.

Liu was quoted as saying at a Cabinet meeting that although the establishment of a social security network by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) has attained initial positive results from the Chinese New Year holiday until now, there are still some blind spots in the network, given the increased number of child abuse cases reported in recent days.

The premier demanded that social workers should single out violent families and set up a database on such families. He also said health education, covering methods to relieve stress, deal with drug and alcohol abuse problems, and maintain mental health, should be included in the network.
Touching on social education, Liu said teachers and social workers should keep in close contact with community leaders and security guards and conduct frequent family visits.

In addition, providing guidance for newlywed couples and new parents, as well as strengthening reporting systems for child abuse cases and campus bullying, should be included among the high priority tasks, Liu noted.

Liu cited statistics showing that over the past five years, 56 children have died from abuse, 66 percent of whom died at the hands of their parents, 17 percent of whom were killed by a cohabiting partner of one of the child's parents, and 9 percent of whom lost their lives at the hands of babysitters.

Meanwhile, 101 children died when their parents committed suicide and killed their children at the same time during the five-year period, according to Liu, who said the biggest threat to children's lives normally comes from those closest to them.
He further said the government should make every effort to encourage people to pay attention to or report child abuse cases.

MOI Deputy Minister Lin Chung-sun said Thursday after the Cabinet meeting that "the act of child abuse or domestic violence is not merely a domestic affair but actually a crime, " while calling on the public to call the 24-hour hotlines 113 and 1957 when they discover cases of child abuse.

Lin said that the MOI, in an effort to help those in need, has stepped up promotion of the 113 hotline for the protection of women and children and the 1957 national welfare hotline, as well as the reporting systems used by local governments around the country.

According to MOI official Chien Hui-chuan, the number of calls made to the 113 hotline reporting child abuse has been on the rise over the past few years. She said 13,703 children and juveniles have been rescued, provided with emergency relief or taken into care after government intervention.

DOC.HEADLINE: One dies in crane accident in Taipei's upscale Xinyi district

TEXT.P: The hook of a large crane fell from the air onto a nearby tour bus at a construction site in Taipei's upscale Xinyi shopping district Friday, killing one passenger and injuring four to five others, police said.
The injured passengers have been rushed to Taipei Medical University Hospital and the Zhongxiao branch of the Taipei Municipal Hospital for emergency treatment.
The city's fire brigade has been mobilized to conduct rescue operations, police said.
There was no initial word on what precipitated the accident.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sales of recycled furniture, cycles soar last year

TEXT.P: Recycled furniture and bicycles have become a hit recently, with more than 25,000 such items sold for nearly NT$18 million (US$53,400) last year, according to statistics released Friday by the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA).

A total of 18 cities and counties around the country have established recycling systems to collect discarded furniture and bicycles, repair and refurbish them and put them on sale, according to EPA official Lin Mao-yuan.
EPA statistics show that sales of the two types of recycled goods have risen in recent years, from just 1,100 sold in 2003, rising to 20,000 in 2007, with an additional 5,000 items sold last year.
The total revenue from the sales showed a year-on-year increase last year of NT$2.8 million, according to the statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: Solve the easier problems first, says president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that he wants the Taiwanese negotiators at the upcoming round of cross-Taiwan Strait talks to seek solutions to issues related to the people's livelihoods before tackling more difficult questions.
"Try to solve the easier ones first, in the same way that elementary school students solve math questions, " Ma exhorted the delegation to the talks slated to open in Nanjing Sunday.

Ma made the remarks during a brief meeting at the Presidential Office with members of the delegation under the leadership of Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the quasi-official intermediary Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), before its departure for China slated for the following day.

The upcoming talks between Chiang and his Chinese counterpart, Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin, are expected to focus on four issues -- regularly scheduled cross-strait flights, financial cooperation, tackling cross-strait crime and providing legal assistance, and opening Taiwan to investment from China.

"We should first seek to settle these issues and should not rush our pace, " Ma said, adding that once technical issues pertaining to the livelihoods and wellbeing of the people on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are solved, a new, more trusting atmosphere will be created across the strait.
"Increasing mutual trust between the two sides is the greatest harvest that this administration has achieved over the past year, " Ma added.
This newly achieved mutual trust exists not only in cross-strait relations but has also been demonstrated in relations with Japan and the United States, Ma went on.

He expressed his appreciation to both the SEF and ARATS for their agreement to jointly tackle crime-fighting issues, saying that the pragmatism displayed by the two groups on technical affairs is worthy of praise.
He also praised Chiang for his strenuous efforts to build mutual trust across the strait.

In related news, Financial Supervisory Commission Chairman Sean Chen said a day earlier that talks on the signing of a loose, wide-ranging agreement on banking, securities, futures and insurance will be high on the agenda of the upcoming talks.
Chen said such an agreement is expected to be forged by the negotiators from the two sides, but will not take the form of a memorandum of understanding (MOU) as had been widely speculated.
"A cross-strait financial MOU will be struck later, after an agreement has been signed first upon which an MOU can be based," Chen noted.

Meanwhile, on the topic of the government's plans to allow Chinese investment in Taiwan, Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming said the two sides have agreed to include the issue on the agenda but will not make any resolution on it due to the complexity of the subject.
Yiin said the Ministry of Economic Affairs will adopt a "positive list" to the liberalization of Chinese investment, but will implement it in a gradual, step- by-step manner.

"There will still be caps on each category of the industries opened to Chinese capital initially, and further opening will be adopted only once the initial plan is found to be proceeding satisfactorily," he said.

Fu Dong-cheng, a vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Council Affairs (MAC) which coordinates Taiwan's China policy and oversees SEF operations, said there has been consensus reached by the administration that the cap on Chinese investment in Taiwanese companies will be 30 percent of their total investment capital.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan expecting US$100 million in flat panel orders in near future

TEXT.P: Buyers from China, the United States and Japan are scheduled to visit Taiwan in the coming two months to purchase an estimated US$100 million in flat panels, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Friday.

A Chinese delegation comprised of 11 Chinese home appliance vendors, including Haier Co., Hisense Group and TCL Corp., will visit Taiwan in May to make flat panel buys, said TAITRA Deputy Secretary-General Walter Yeh.
The group will have one-on-one meetings with leading thin film transistor liquid crystal display (TFT-LCD) manufacturers such as Chi Mei Optoelectronics, AU Optronics and Chunghwa Picture Tubes.

Another group of 50 home electronics vendors, including U.S.-based Hewlett- Packard and Japan-based Toshiba, will arrive in June to procure flat panels and related components during the annual Display Taiwan 2009 fair slated for June 10-12 in Taipei, Yeh said.
According to TAITRA, 156 manufacturers have registered for participation in the exhibition, with the number of booths totaling 432.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's share prices finish the week higher

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices edged higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, advancing 5.53 points, or 0.09 percent, to close at 5,880.77.

Buoyed by Wall Street's rise overnight and hopes that the third round of talks between Taiwan and China this weekend will help the economy, the local bourse opened higher at 5,913.13 and rose to a high of 5,987.23 early in the session before falling back to as low as 5,824.42.
A total of 6.52 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$144.46 billion (US$3.91 billion).

Taiwan's stock market added 125.39 points, or 2.18 percent, this week and has risen sharply from a low of 4,242.61 points recorded on January 20. It is the world's second best-performing market this year, trailing only the Shanghai market.

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp stocks moving up the most at 4.0 percent. Construction shares advanced 1.9 percent, banking and financial issues gained 1.1 percent, and textile shares rose 0.6 percent.

Four other major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 1.9 percent. Foodstuff shares fell 0.6 percent, and machinery and electronics shares and plastics and chemicals stocks dropped 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,154 to 968, with 170 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$1.64 billion.

One institutional investor told the Central News Agency that the weekend's talks between Taiwan and China have already been factored into share prices, and without further positive news to buoy the market next week, the Taiex could fall to 5,600 on profit taking.
If, however, turnover falls to below NT$100 billion per session but the market stays firm, and margin trading does not noticeably increase, it could mark the start of a new rally, the analyst said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two Chinese tourists die in crane accident in Taipei

TEXT.P: A section of a crane's boom fell 37 stories onto a moving tour bus carrying a group of Chinese tourists in Taipei Friday, leaving two passengers dead, another in critical condition, and two others injured, according to the city's fire department.

One passenger, 46-year-old Li Fuqing, was cut in half and killed immediately when the boom smashed through the back of the bus as it was heading toward Taipei 101 in Taipei's upscale Xinyi shopping district.

Another tourist, 57-year-old Wang Bingkun, died after being taken to the Zhongxiao branch of Taipei Municipal Hospital. Zhang Shiguang, 63, suffered out- of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) before arriving at Taipei Medical University and is in critical condition.
The bus was carrying a total of 27 people at the time, including 25 Chinese tourists, and a Taiwanese tour guide and driver.
Police cordoned off the area where the accident occurred, and Taipei prosecutors are on the scene to investigate.
A preliminary investigation found that a small crane was operating a mid-sized boom on the 37th floor of the construction site when the boom broke off and fell to the street below.
Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin immediately ordered the construction company to halt work at the site.
The tourists were on their way to Taipei 101 for a visit when the accident occurred, according to the Taipei travel agency that is hosting the tour group.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, falling NT$0.109 to close at NT$33.711.
A total of US$798 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$33.820 before dropping to the day's low of NT$33.678.

DOC.HEADLINE: President instructs SEF to talk about ECFA with China: negotiator

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou instructed the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) to discuss with China the signing of a cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) in upcoming talks, SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung said Friday.

Chiang, who will be leading the SEF delegation to the third round of cross- strait talks slated to open in Nanjing, China Sunday, made the remarks at news conference held after meeting with President Ma, before the delegation's departure for China Saturday.

The upcoming talks between Chiang and his Chinese counterpart, Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin, are expected to focus on expanding cross-strait flight services, paving the way for financial cooperation, tackling cross-strait crime and providing legal assistance, as well as opening Taiwan to investment from China.

The talks are a continuation of a significant warming of relations between the two former rivals since Taiwan in 2008 elected new President Ma Ying-jeou, whose administration has made it a priority to ease tensions and improve relations with China.

Although the controversial ECFA - which Ma's administration has said is similar to a free trade agreement with no political strings attached - is not on the agenda of the talks, it is an issue that the president feels strongly about.

Ma has argued that if Taiwan does not sign such an agreement with China, it risks being marginalized and losing its competitiveness as China and neighboring countries are about to sign FTAs and as Beijing continues to block Taiwan's efforts to reach FTA agreements with other countries.
Critics, however, warned that the agreement jeopardize Taiwan's sovereignty, make Taiwan too economically dependent and linked to China, and lead to an influx of Chinese capital and goods.

Also Friday, the President said that currently there are still some problems that are unhelpful to the already improved cross-strait air links, including ticket fares for direct charter flights being too high and the number of flights being insufficient to meet the demand, according to Chiang.
"The President also wants me to relay his greetings to the people on the Chinese mainland," Chiang added.

A number of trailblazing principles have been reached in the last two rounds of SEF-ARATS talks, held last year, and the preparatory meeting on the third round of talks, said Chiang. These include consensus that both sides should be pragmatic on cross-strait relations and build relations in a gradual, step-by- step manner.

SEF and ARATS have also agreed that China and Taiwan will first engage in talks on economic issues and temporarily shelve political issues, beginning with the easier problems, rather than the challenging ones, Chiang said.
The two intermediary bodies agreed during previous talks that SEF and ARATS will meet regularly twice a year, with each side playing host to one meeting alternately.

On Chiang's entourage will be SEF Vice Chairman and Secretary-General Kao Koong-lian and Fu Dong-chen, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, which coordinates Taiwan's policy toward China and oversees SEF operations.
Other officials on the 22-member delegation will also include Deputy Justice Minister Huang Shih-ming and Financial Supervisory Commission Deputy Chairwoman Lee Chi-chu.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dependence on National Health Insurance increasing

TEXT.P: Individuals enrolled in Taiwan's compulsory National Health Insurance system averaged 15 outpatient visits in 2008, a record high since the program was launched in 1995, according to statistics released Friday by the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI).
The bureau said the public's use of National Health Insurance resources has increased over the years due to the rapid graying of the country's population.

Of all types of outpatient visits, those made to treat kidney disease have recorded the fastest growth, having risen 13.9 percent over the past 10 years, said BHNI Vice President Lee Cheng-hua during a bureau meeting.
Sharp growth in outpatient visits for breast cancer (10.09 percent) and hypertension and diabetes (6 percent) was also seen, Lee said.
He predicted that the demand for outpatient visits for chronic diseases will further increase as Taiwan's population continues to age.

Teng Hsi-hua, a spokesman for a civic group monitoring the National Health Insurance program, suspected, however, that the increase in the number of outpatient visits reflected an abuse of medical resources.

For example, Teng said, patients who want to get a checkup are usually required to make a total of three outpatient visits -- one to schedule the examination, one to undergo the checkup, and a third one to get the results of tests performed.

To avoid wasting medical resources, Teng suggested that hospitals should only require patients showing abnormalities in their tests to return for further diagnosis while notifying those with normal results by telephone, e-mail or postcard.

DOC.HEADLINE: TMC project will not fall through: economics minister

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Yiin Chii-ming said Friday that the government is determined to revamp the country's struggling dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chip industry, despite rumors that the head of a proposed takeover company has decided to quit.

Yiin told reporters he has not heard from John Hsuan, appointed convener of the government-proposed DRAM company Taiwan Memory Co. (TMC) , about his alleged attempt to quit his job, but that he will meet with Hsuan first thing Saturday to cheer him up.

Yiin said despite negative rumors and remarks, he is confident that Hsuan will go ahead with his mission of heading a team to establish TMC in collaboration with Japanese chipmaker Elpida Memory Inc. so that the government can consolidate selected technology providers and domestic memory chip makers and revamp the industry.
"The TMC project will not fall through and the government is resolved to carry it on," Yiin said.

He said Hsuan, honorary vice chairman of United Microelectronics Corp. who is authorized by the administration to oversee TMC's launch, has laid a sound foundation for TMC so far, marking a good beginning for the ambitious DRAM revitalization plan.
Yiin called for the Taiwanese public to give Hsuan more encouragement than criticism and allow him more room to maneuver.
Elpida Memory Inc. of Japan agreed on April 1 to join the soon-to-be-established TMC as a major strategic cooperation partner.
Welcoming Elpida's commitment, Hsuan said back then that progress made in negotiations on the content and terms of cooperation had been smooth.
At that time, Yiin also said that Elpida's involvement does not preclude the participation of another global DRAM giant, United States-based Micron Co., as a key partner.

Micron Co., however, announced on April 9 that it will not cooperate with TMC, but looks forward to more support from Taiwan's government. Micron Co., a leading DRAM technology provider, which has long been a key technology provider for Nanya and Inotera, both of which are affiliates of Taiwan's giant Formosa Plastics Group., said it has decided instead to further reinforce its long-term cooperation with Nanya Technology and Inotera Memories in research and development of advanced DRAM technology.

When Yiin projected the new company's role on March 5, he suggested it would develop its own core technologies to boost the local DRAM sector's competitiveness and said it would also set up a research and development center, develop a capacity-consolidation platform and centralize sales functions.
The TMC-Elpida tie-up has been seen as a positive step forward in consolidating the local DRAM chip industry, which has long taken a back seat technologically to South Korea's DRAM sector.

According to Taiwan-based DRAMeXchange Technology Inc., Asia's biggest spot market for memory chips, local makers held a 23.2 percent share of the global market in terms of revenue in the fourth quarter of 2008.
South Korea led the industry worldwide as Samsung Electronics Co. controlled 24.5 percent and Hynix Semiconductor Inc. 20.4 percent of the global market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier reiterates need to push through 'green' bills

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan reaffirmed the government's determination Friday to push three draft "green bills, " seen as crucial to developing Taiwan's renewable energy industry, through the Legislative Yuan by the end of the year.
Liu repeated the pledge during his visit to Motech Industrial Inc., Taiwan's largest solar cell manufacturer, in Tainan County, southern Taiwan.

He also stressed that the Cabinet will make every effort to get the legislature to pass a long-stalled renewable energy bill -- one of the three green bills -- in its current session to secure the future development of alternative energy development in Taiwan.
The other two measures the government hopes to pass by the end of the year include energy tax and greenhouse gas reduction bills.

The passage of the renewable energy bill, the administration's top priority, will provide a legal basis for establishing a mechanism encouraging the procurement and production of renewable energy, establishing viable market prices, and removing hurdles to alternative energy development.
Lin and others in the government have repeatedly urged the legislature recently to pass the legislation.

The Cabinet has made solar energy the cornerstone of its green energy plan approved Thursday and will develop the solar industry by encouraging technology breakthroughs, forging a better environment for solar energy, making crucial investments, and promoting exports and domestic demand, Liu said.
During Liu's visit, Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-jhih urged him and the Executive Yuan to make more farmland available to the photovoltaic industry on which they can build facilities.
Liu responded cautiously, saying the problem is complicated and that the government needs more time to figure out how to deal with it. He promised, however, that the issue would be dealt with.
The government is "dead serious this time" he said.

At Motech, Liu and the company's chairman, Simon Tsuo, exchanged views on the solar cell industry's fundamentals, current bottlenecks in the industry, and government incentives for the emerging sector.

Tsuo suggested the government establish a national certification mechanism for solar generation systems and help integrate domestic photovoltaic operators to make inroads into the international market, reflecting his concern that the industry was dangerously concentrated on solar cell production.

At a cross-Taiwan Strait forum on solar technology in Taipei last month, Tsuo said Taiwanese solar firms were running a risk by focusing primarily on cell and wafer manufacturing with a limited presence in both the upstream raw material market and the downstream application market.
Liu responded that the government will provide assistance to the sector, including establishing a green industry service team to help tackle problems challenging local solar companies.
According to Motech, the company was the eighth largest manufacturer of solar cells in the world in 2008, with an output of 272 MW of crystalline silicon solar cells.

DOC.HEADLINE: DHL opens new operational center in Taoyuan airport

TEXT.P: International express courier service DHL inaugurated its new operational center in Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport during a ceremony Friday.

Addressing the inauguration ceremony, Vice Premier Chiu Cheng- hsiung said that the center's opening is expected to facilitate trans-national cooperation in express delivery services from Taiwan to all over the world and benefit Taiwan's export sector.

Citing as an example, Chiu said many German people love luxury sedans made in Sweden, while many Swedish people like Germany's BMW automobiles, and only through transactions between the two countries, could their people obtain what they want at a low cost.

Likewise, Chiu said that Taiwan, as an export-oriented country because of its small domestic market, relies on cooperation with international companies, like DHL, to efficiently deliver goods to other countries around the globe.
For this reason, the vice premier added that he hopes DHL can further expand its investment in Taiwan.

Meanwhile, Jerry Hsu, president of DHL Greater China, said that DHL has great confidence in Taiwan's market and therefore decided to invest an additional NT$210 million (US$6.2 million) for the construction of the new Taiwan logistics center aimed at providing Taiwanese enterprises with complete solutions for goods transportation to the global market via the DHL network.

DHL handled some 3.3 million pieces of cargo in Taiwan last year. The new center is expected to handle three times the previous capacity, according to Stephen Fenwick, senior vice president of operations for DHL Express Asia Pacific.

The new center covers 13,515 square meters, about four times the floor space of its old one. With the center's opening, DHL will be able to handle 11,000 pieces per hour, three times the previous capacity of 3,600 pieces per hour, Fenwick added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan academic awarded for achievement in liver study

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica member Chen Ding-shinn has won the International Recognition Award by the European Association for the Study of the Liver (EASL) , becoming the first Taiwanese to receive the award, Taiwan's top-notch research institute said Friday.

The award ceremony took place Friday at EASL headquarters in Copenhagen, Denmark as part of the 44th EASL annual meeting April 22-26, which drew around 7,400 clinicians and scientists, the institute said in a statement.
Chen left Taiwan a few days ago for Copenhagen to receive the award in person, according to the statement.
Chen, a former dean of National Taiwan University's College of Medicine, has long been devoted to combating hepatitis B and the devastation it has caused around the world.

The research conducted by Chen and his team has contributed to understanding the natural history of the hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, the early detection and treatment of hepatocellular carcinoma, and the prevention of HBV infection.
Chen's achievements also extend to hepatitis C virus, having developed a new and effective treatment for chronic hepatitis C.
The combination therapy of interferon and ribavirin recommended by Chen has become a standard treatment worldwide, according to Academia Sinica, the highest academic institute in Taiwan.
Chen is also a distinguished chair professor in the Department of Internal Medicine of the National Taiwan University College of Medicine (NTUCM) where he specializes in hepatology.
Chen was elected an academician of Academia Sinica in 1992, a fellow of the Third World Academy of Sciences in 2001 and foreign associate of the U.S. National Academy of Sciences in 2005.
He was president of the International Association for the Study of the Liver (2004-2006) and in 2007 he earned the Presidential Science Prize of Taiwan.
EASL, founded in 1966, is a leading European association in the field of liver research. It currently has 28 members.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's Global Mobile signs cooperative pact with Clearwire

TEXT.P: Taiwan WiMAX licensee Global Mobile Corp. announced Friday it has signed a cooperative agreement with U.S.-based Clearwire Corp. to strengthen the WiMAX network it is preparing to install in the Hsinchu area in northern Taiwan.

Global Mobile Chairwoman Rosemary W. Ho said after signing the pact with Clearwire Chairman Barry West that her company looks forward to attracting more than 1 million customers to its WiMAX service over the next five years.

Ho believes that the partnership with Clearwire, a leading provider of wireless broadband services for homes and businesses, will help Global Mobile maximize the potential of its network, which will be tested in the Hsinchu area in September and begin operating commercially next year.

"We expect to catch up with the global technological trends through exchanges of experience and cooperation with Clearwire, " Ho said, adding that the cooperation pact will cover international roaming services, technological development and digital content.

According to company sources, Global Mobile looks forward to learning from Clearwire's experience in providing fast, easy and reliable wireless broadband services, particularly its expertise in interconnecting WiMAX base stations and other technology testing and applications.
Ho said Clearwire may assess the possibility of acquiring a stake in Global Mobile, an investment that would require the approval of relevant authorities.
While Global Mobile does not have any plan to increase its capital this year, the issue will be revisited next year, Ho indicated.
Global Mobile was one of six local telecommunications companies that won licenses in July 2007 to operate WiMAX services in Taiwan.
Some of the licensees have secured partnerships with foreign companies to help build their networks and successfully launch commercial WiMAX operations.
Founded in 2003, Clearwire has provided WiMAX services in major U.S. cities, including Baltimore and Portland, with more than 460,000 customers, topping the world in terms of clientele.

DOC.HEADLINE: Way cleared for relatives of crane accident victims to visit Taiwan

TEXT.P: Family members of Chinese nationals killed in a deadly crane accident in a bustling commercial district in Taipei City Friday will be able to come to Taiwan starting Saturday, a Tourism Bureau official said.

In coordination with the National Immigration Agency, the bureau is assisting the Chinese family members in getting visas to Taiwan, said Chen Mei-hsiu, the head of the bureau's Hotel, Travel and Training Division.
Meanwhile, the Immigration Agency announced that it has opened a special counter to manage the visits of the family members of the victims, who were from Guangdong province in southern China.
The accident occurred just before 2 p.m. Friday when a section of a crane's lattice boom fell 37 stories onto a moving tour bus carrying 25 Chinese tourists in the upscale Xinyi shopping district.
As of 10 p.m., two passengers had died, another remains in critical condition, and three others were injured.

One passenger, 46-year-old Li Fuqing, was cut in half and killed immediately when the boom smashed through the back of the bus as it was heading toward Taipei 101, the second highest skyscraper in the world.

Another tourist, 57-year-old Wang Bingkun, died after being taken to the Zhongxiao branch of Taipei Municipal Hospital. Zhang Shiguang, 63, suffered out- of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) before arriving at Taipei Medical University and remains in critical condition.
The bus was carrying a total of 27 people at the time, including 25 Chinese tourists, and a Taiwanese tour guide and driver.

According to police data, each of the Chinese tourists was covered by travel safety insurance provided by Taipei-based Fubon Insurance Co. The beneficiaries of the two dead passengers will receive a maximum of NT$3 million (US$89,000) in compensation for the accident.
Those injured are also entitled to compensation of up to NT$3 million if they were disabled in the accident and can also claim NT$200,000 each to cover medical expenses.
The family members of each victim will also receive NT$100,000 to cover travel costs and follow-up expenses, according to police sources.
A preliminary investigation found that a small crane was operating a mid-sized boom on the 37th floor of a planned MRT transit hub when the boom broke off and fell to the street below.

The building is a build-operate-transfer (BOT) project planned by the city government and contracted to Uni-President Development Corp., a subsidiary of the Uni-President Group, one of Taiwan's biggest conglomerates.
Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin ordered the construction company to halt work at the site soon after the accident occurred.

Investigators said that the crane was hauling a weight of 3.1 tons at the time of the accident, within its 3.2-ton capacity. They suggested that weather conditions might have played a role in the boom's collapse but had yet to pinpoint its cause.

According to municipal authorities, the city's Department of Labor has launched a probe into whether human error or professional negligence on the part of the crane company had anything to do with the tragedy.
The tourists were on their way to Taipei 101 for a visit when the accident occurred, according to the Taipei travel agency that is hosting the tour group.

DOC.HEADLINE: Catholic hospital may have to return millions in donations

TEXT.P: A Catholic hospital in eastern Taiwan's Taitung might have to return nearly NT$100 million in donations it has collected because of possible violations of the law, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said Friday.
An official from the MOI's Department of Social Affairs said that according to the Medical Treatment Act, medical institutions are not allowed to solicit donations.
"If the donation account is designated as a hospital, then the money will have to be returned," the official said.

If the hospital is soliciting the money as a nonprofit organization, it will have to apply to the ministry to gain permission to ask for donations and alert donors of the name change. If donors do not agree with the name change, the money also will have to be returned.

The official made the remarks after St. Mary's Hospital in Taitung City launched a campaign to collect "NT$10,000 donations from 3,000 donors" and raise the more than NT$31 million it needs to transform itself into a nonprofit organization by November.

The hospital said it would have to shut down if it failed to reach the target, but it collected NT$98 million in just 10 days from donors that included President Ma Ying-jeou and Taitung County Magistrate Kuang Li-cheng.

St. Mary's Hospital, built by the Catholic Church Hualien diocese half a century ago, was the first hospital in Taitung with a 30-bed professional maternity ward. In the past, half of the county's children were born in the hospital.
But the establishment of Mackay Hospital, Taitung Christian Hospital and Taitung Hospital under the Department of Health has put pressure on St. Mary's operations.

The hospital closed its well-known maternity department in 2002, and was mulling whether to shut down permanently. But then it was transformed into the first hospice hospital in Taitung in 2004 with public support.

Under the Medical Treatment Act, which classifies hospitals as private, nonprofit or government institutions, St. Mary's Hospital has to be transformed into a nonprofit organization by November as requested by the Taitung County Health Department.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH tracking sources of malachite-green contaminated fish

TEXT.P: Seven of 25 samples of aquatic products examined in March were found to contain small amounts of a banned fungicide residue, the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) said Friday.
The samples of tilapia, grouper and threadfin fish that were contaminated with malachite green had residue amounts of around 0.002 ppm -- the maximum level acceptable in the European Union.

Taiwan's food safety law bans the presence of residues of malachite green in aquatic products sold locally. The toxic chemical, used to treat external fungal and parasitic infections on fish and shellfish, has been found to harm the livers of animals in laboratory tests.

Hsu Ching-hsin, a DOH food safety official, said the contaminated aquatic samples were collected from seven places, including a supermarket operated by a farmers' association in eastern Taiwan's Taitung County, a marine food restaurant in Kaohsiung County, a fish market in Chiayi City, a Carrefour shop in Taipei City's Wanhua District, a department store in Taichung County, a seafood restaurant in Taichung City and a coastal fish market in Keelung City.

Even though the contaminated fish might have been consumed, Hsu said, the DOH will track all related suppliers, who could be slapped with fines ranging between NT$60,000 and NT$300,000 if they are found to have illegally used the fungicide in disinfection.
Hsu said local public health and fishery administration officials will be required to cooperate with the DOH in tracking down suppliers of contaminated fishery products.

Meanwhile, officials from the Fisheries Administration said the banned substance might come from groundwater used in fish farming or from residues of contamination incidents reported in 2004 and 2005.
Officials said, however, that it's premature to speculate on the cause of the contamination before relevant aquaculture farms are identified.

As to whether the incident could affect Taiwan's fish exports, the officials said among the three contaminated fish species, only grouper is on the export list, with Hong Kong as a major market. Hong Kong does not have any regulations governing malachite green residues.

DOC.HEADLINE: Contractors form response task force to tackle crane accident
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 24 (CNA) 04/25/09 00:17:56 (By Sofia Wu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Major contractors on a construction project in Taipei's upscale Xinyi shopping district formed an emergency task force late Friday after a crane accident at the construction site killed two Chinese tourists and injured three others earlier that day.

Meanwhile, eight workers at the construction site, including the crane operator and a steel structure company executive, were questioned by prosecutors at the police department's Xinyi precinct over the tragic accident.
Those found to be liable in the case may be detained, prosecution authorities said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 25, or the first day of the fourth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1744: Anders Celsius, Swedish astronomer who devised the Celsius thermometer in 1742, dies at the age of 43.
1859: Under the direction of Ferdinand de Lesseps, the construction of the Suez Canal begins. It was opened 10 years later on Nov. 16, 1869.
1874: Gulielmo Marconi, Italian engineer and inventor who shared the 1909 Nobel Prize in physics, is born. He became the first person to transmit long-wave radio signals across the Atlantic Ocean, doing so in 1901.
1895: Lai Ho, a noted Chinese writer of anti-Japanese literature, is born in Changhua.
1898: The U.S. Congress passes a joint resolution declaring war on Spain over events in Cuba.
1912: The Chung Kuo Ke Ming Tung Meng Hui is reorganized as the Kuomintang.
1925: Field Marshal Paul von Hindenburg becomes the second president of Germany's postwar Weimar Republic.
1927: After the national government in Nanking announces a purification movement that will entail the expulsion of Chinese communists, the communists meet in Wuhan and decide to set up a Soviet-style regime.
1930: Construction of the Chianan irrigation canal is completed.
1941: The United States and the United Kingdom sign in Washington separate but parallel agreements with China for stabilizing China's national currency. The United States provides US$50 million and the United Kingdom provides five million pounds.
1942: An accident at a coal mine in Benxi, located within Japanese-occupied China, kills 1,549 workers in the world's worst mining disaster.
1945: Delegates of 45 nations, including the Republic of China, meet in San Francisco, Calif., to organize the United Nations.
1946: The foreign ministers of the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France meet in Paris to discuss the signing of a peace treaty with Germany.
1956: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the establishment of diplomatic relations with Haiti.
1962: The United States successfully launches its Saturn rocket, the largest in the world at the time.
1965: President Lyndon B. Johnson sends U.S. troops to the Dominican Republic to maintain order after rebel followers of Juan Bosch try to seize power.
1971: T.V. Soong, former president of the Executive Yuan, dies in San Francisco at the age of 77.
1971: Some 200,000 anti-Vietnam War protesters march on Washington, D.C.
1973: The Chinese National Baseball Team leaves Taipei for Manila to take part in the 10th Asian Cup Tournament.
1974: Portugal's dictator Marcelo Caetano is overthrown in a bloodless military coup. He surrenders to Gen. Antonio de Spinola, who becomes president the following month.
1982: The last Israeli soldier leaves Sinai, ending 15 years of Israeli occupation of the peninsula.
1989: Japanese Prime Minister Noburu Takeshita announces plans to resign over the "Recruit Affair," the country's biggest political scandal in decades.
1994: Tsutomu Hata becomes Japan's 51st prime minister.
1995 Ginger Rogers, American dancer and actress, dies at the age of 83. She is particularly noted for her partnership with Fred Astaire in several motion pictures, including "Swing Time," "Flying Down to Rio" and "Roberta."
2000: President Lee Teng-hui bestows a medal on Steve Forbes, president and CEO of U.S.-based Forbes Magazine, in recognition of his long-term contribution to the promotion of exchanges and coorperation between the Republic of China and the United States.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian says that the ROC government will take steps to develop the island into a "competitive country with a knowledge-based economy" within five years.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The ancient Emperor Shun was perhaps the one man who successfully carried out the principle of no-government. For what need is there really for what is called government? A ruler needs only to be earnest in his personal conduct, and to behave in a manner worthy of his position."
