DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan chief negotiator arrives in Nanjing for talks with China
DOC.DATELINE: Nanjing, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/09 13:19:53 (By Chiang Chin-yeh and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's chief negotiator with China, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, arrived in Nanjing Saturday morning on a mission to seal three agreements and one joint statement with China.

The highlight of Chiang's visit will be a meeting with his Chinese counterpart, Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin, slated for Sunday in the Chinese city.
The two sides are expected to sign agreements on the launch of regular cross- strait passenger flights, cross-strait cooperation to fight crime, mutual judicial assistance, and financial cooperation.
A joint statement on a proposal to open Taiwan to Chinese investment will also be released at that time.
Representatives of the SEF and ARATS are set to hold a preparatory meeting later Saturday to finalize the texts of the agreements and the joint statement.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan, who was at Taiwan Taoyuan Airport to see off Chiang and his delegation, promised that the SEF's negotiations with ARATS will be conducted in accordance with the principles of equality and dignity, and will prioritize the interests of Taiwan and its people.

According to Lai, a survey conducted recently by the MAC found that more than 60 percent of respondents think the Chiang-Chen meeting will be helpful to the normalization of cross-strait trade and economic ties.
"With the support of the public, I believe the upcoming Chiang-Chen meeting will produce very fruitful results and help create a mutually beneficial win-win situation across the strait, " she said.
During his talks with Chen, Chiang is also likely to officially raise a proposal for Taiwan and China to sign an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).
The SEF and ARATS are intermediary bodies set up by Taiwan and China, respectively, to handle cross-strait affairs in the absence of official ties.

The upcoming Chiang-Chen meeting will be the third of its kind since the resumption of cross-strait dialogue less than one year ago following a nine-year hiatus. It signifies continued warming of relations between the two former rivals since the inauguration of President Ma Ying-jeou, whose administration has made it a priority to ease tensions and improve relations with China.

In their first meeting held in June 2008 in Beijing, Chiang and Chen signed agreements on the launch of weekend cross-strait passenger charter flights and the admission of larger numbers of Chinese tourists to Taiwan.

Their second meeting took place in November in Taipei, during which they signed agreements on expanding the weekend passenger charter services to become daily services, opening cargo charter services, direct cross-strait shipping and postal services, and improving food safety.
During this latest China trip, Chiang will also visit Taiwanese businesses in Yangzhou, Suzhou and Shanghai before returning to Taiwan April 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former NBA star coaches local Deaflympics basketball team

TEXT.P: Former NBA star Scottie Pippen, who is a goodwill ambassador for the 21st Summer Deaflympics Taipei 2009, served as a one-day coach Saturday for Taiwans Deaflympics basketball team and shared his experience with Taiwan's high school basketball champions Song Shan Senior High School.

Greeting several hundred fans with a warm smile, Pippen said he was pleased to visit Taiwan for the second time in a year. The former USA Olympic Dream Team player demonstrated his two-time Olympic gold-medalist skills in a session with Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin and Taiwan's Deaflypics team and he instructed them on shooting techniques.

Noting that team work is the key to victory, Pippen said that to him basketball is very special and that he admired the hearing impaired players for the great courage they showed in taking up the game.
"Basketball teaches you a lot about sharing and giving. When you play between these lines. it's a team game," the former NBA superstar said.
Hau said that he is also a big fan of Pippen who, teamed with Michael Jordan, helped the Chicago Bulls win six NBA championships in the 1990s.
"We hope that Pippen's high profile will help promote the 2009 Deaflympics in Taipei and spread his game spirit to all players," the mayor said.
Pippen, who arrived in Taiwan Friday, observed some games between the Deaflympic team, Song Shan Senior High school and a charity basketball team of EeLin Modeling Agency.
He will shoot a TV commercial to promote the Deaflympics scheduled for Sept. 5-15 and will appear at a Super Basketball League game in Sinjhuang Gymnasium before departing the country on April 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: Severely injured tourist still in critical condition: doctor

TEXT.P: A Chinese tourist, who was injured Friday when a crane boom fell onto a moving bus in which he traveling, remained in critical condition Saturday, according to a surgeon at the hospital where he is being treated.

Tzao Neil-wen, chief of the cardiac surgery department at Taipei Medical University, said that the tourist, Zhang Shiguang, 63, suffered severe damage to his head, including leakage of his brain fluid.

Zhang also sustained multiple bone fractures all over his body and is suffering from neurogenic and hemorrhagic shock, Tzao said. The patient is in a state of deep unconsciousness, which measured 3 on a 15-point coma scale, he added.
Zhang is now receiving extracorporeal membrane oxygenation and hemodialysis and has been transfused with more than 30,000 cc of blood, the doctor said.

Zhang and 24 other visitors from Guandong, China were traveling on a tour bus in the upscale Xinyi shopping district in Taipei Friday around 2 p.m. when a lattice boom from a crane fell 31 stories from a building under construction and smashed the back part of the bus. Two of the passengers were killed and several others injured.
Two of the moderately injured tourists are showing signs of improvement, according to the staff at the Zhongxiao branch of the Taipei Municipal Hospital where they are being treated.

Wang Peiling, 53, and Yeh Zhitang, 29, who both sustained bone fractures and contusions, were transferred to the general ward for further observation Saturday morning as their condition had became stable, the hospital staff said.
However, the doctors cannot yet say when the two patients will be discharged, the hospital said.

Meanwhile, the Taipei District Prosecutors Office and police released six crane operators in the wee hours of Saturday on bail of between NT$100,000 (US$2,965) and NT$500,000 each after eight hours of interrogation over the accident.
Two representatives of two construction companies that are involved in the building project were also questioned, but were later freed without bail.
Chief Prosecutor Lai Cheng-sheng said that there will be no further probe into criminal liability until the municipal authorities complete their investigation report.
When the boom fell Friday, it smashed through the back of the bus, immediately killing one passenger, 46-year-old Li Fuqing, who was cut in half.
Another tourist, 57-year-old Wang Bingkun, died after being taken to the Zhongxiao branch of Taipei Municipal Hospital.
The bus was carrying a total of 27 people -- 25 Chinese tourists, and a Taiwanese tour guide and driver. It was heading toward Taipei 101, the tallest occupied skyscraper in the world.
A preliminary investigation found that a small crane was operating a mid-sized boom on the 31st floor of a planned MRT transit hub when the boom broke off and fell to the street below.

Investigators said that the crane was hauling a weight of 3.1 tons at the time of the accident, within its 3.2-ton capacity. They suggested that weather conditions might have played a role in the boom's collapse, but had yet to pinpoint the cause.
The city's Department of Labor has launched a probe into whether human error or professional negligence on the part of the crane company had anything to do with the tragedy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Group urges intellectual property rights protection in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Taiwan chapter of the Washington-based Business Software Alliance (BSA) -- a non-profit organization that promotes intellectual property rights (IPR) -- called on the government, enterprises and the public to work together against software piracy and to create a safe and legal digital world.

Sung Hong-ti, co-chair of BSA Taiwan, made the call at an event hosted by the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Intellectual Property Office to celebrate World Intellectual Property Day (World IP Day) on April 26.

Established by the World Intellectual Property Organization in 2001, World IP Day aims at raising awareness of the role of IPR in daily life and celebrating the contribution made by innovators and artists to the development of societies across the globe.
"Public awareness of the need to protect intellectual property rights has been getting better and better over the years. However, there is still a lot of room for improvement," Sung told CNA.

Taiwan's efforts to combat commercial piracy and to strengthen IPR have achieved concrete results, as the country's IPR infringement rate fell from 43 percent in 2006 to 40 percent in 2008, the third lowest in Asia after Japan's 23 percent and Singapore's 37 percent, according to Sung.
In addition, the Office of the U.S. Trade Representatives on Jan. 16 removed Taiwan from the Special 301 Watch list, in recognition of the country's progress on IPR protection, Sung noted.
However, IPR infringements remain serious in small and medium sized enterprise (SMEs) in Taiwan where licensed software is not provided for all users, Sung noted.
"The concept of 'the user pays' is important and we hope that the government, enterprises and the general public can all work together to support licensed software," Sung said.
According to Sung, BSA Taiwan has launched a "333 campaign" aimed at combining the efforts of the government, companies and the public to reduce Taiwan's piracy rate by 3 percent in three years.

Many studies have shown that economic growth is linked to the reduction of software piracy, Sung said, adding that if Taiwan can reduce software piracy to 31 percent by 2012, it would add an estimated US$414 million to the country's GDP.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan pledges to normalize economic ties with China

TEXT.P: The issues to be addressed in the upcoming round of high-level meetings between Taiwan and China will help pave the way for the normalization of trade and economic relations and improve order in the civic exchanges between the two sides, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said Saturday.

Lai made the comment during an interview with a radio station based in the central city of Taichung, in reference to a meeting scheduled for Sunday in Nanjing between Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin- kung and Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits President Chen Yunlin.

During the meeting, Chiang and Chen are expected to sign three agreements on the launch of regular cross-Taiwan Strait passenger flights, financial cooperation, and mutual judicial assistance and cross-strait cooperation to fight crime. Meanwhile, any consensus reached on opening Taiwan to Chinese investment will be covered in a joint statement.

According to Lai, opening up to investment from China will be an important step in normalizing trade and economic ties across the strait, because the one-way movement of investment from Taiwan to China over the past 20 years has tilted the balance of cross-strait capital flows.
On the possible negative impact on Taiwan's industrial sector, Lai said the government will make sure the liberalization process is gradual and will set limits on the scope of the opening.

In the initial stage, the opening will target fields that would diffuse national benefits as a result of Chinese investments and in which Chinese investors are interested, she said. She named as examples industries such as light-emitting diode (LED) lighting, wind energy, photovoltaics and logistic services.

Chinese investment will still be prohibited in fields where Taiwan enjoys a crucial technological edge and where there are national security concerns, such as flat panel display and semiconductor manufacturing, she said.

Regarding the launch of regular passenger flights, Lai noted that there is an urgent need for such services now, as the current daily charter services do not have the capacity to meet the high market demand.
Lai, however, said the upcoming air services agreement will not cover the complex issue of allowing air carriers on the cross-strait route to operate connecting flights to a third country.
Meanwhile, an agreement on mutual judicial assistance and cooperation to fight crime will allow for the repatriation of Taiwanese fugitives in China to face justice, she said.

Of the 85 major Taiwanese economic criminals who fled to China over the past 10 years, only one has been returned to Taiwan, which makes it obvious that China is a haven for Taiwanese fugitives, she said.

As to Taiwan's proposal to sign an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, Lai said Chiang will seek to discuss the issue with Chen during their upcoming talks, in the hope that it could be placed on the agenda of their fourth meeting.
According to Lai, the proposed agreement will address the issues of free trade and reducing cross-strait tariffs, which are essential to the normalization of economic ties between the two sides.
President Ma Ying-jeou has expressed strong support for the establishment of the ECFA, stressing that it is similar to a free trade agreement (FTA) with no political strings attached.

Ma has argued that if Taiwan does not sign such an agreement with China, it risks being marginalized and losing its competitiveness, as China and neighboring countries are about to sign FTAs and as Beijing continues to block Taiwan's efforts to reach FTA agreements with other countries.
Critics, however, warned that the agreement could jeopardize Taiwan's sovereignty, make Taiwan too economically dependent on China, and lead to an influx of Chinese capital and goods.

DOC.HEADLINE: Travel agency manager in Taiwan to assist in aftermath of accident

TEXT.P: The general manager of the Chinese travel agency that organized an ill-fated tour of Taiwan arrived in the country from Guangdong, China Saturday to help the surviving members of the tour group deal with the aftermath of a fatal accident.

Hu Wenqiang of the Guangzhou-based Lijing Travel Service will offer assistance to the surviving Chinese tourists who were on a bus that was smashed by a falling crane boom Friday in the upscale Xinyi shopping district of Taipei, according to the Travel Agent Association of Taiwan (TAAT).
Two of the 25 Chinese tourists from Guangdong were killed in the accident and several others injured.

The tour group arrived in Taiwan via Hong Kong April 20 on a six-day sightseeing trip. On the day before their scheduled return home, a section of a crane's boom fell 31 stories onto their tour bus as it was traveling past a construction site toward Taipei 101, the tallest occupied skyscraper in the world.

On Saturday afternoon, 15 members of the tour group left Taiwan as scheduled. Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo was at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport to see them off and to offer his condolences to them.
The TAAT said that the families of the two people who died in the accident were scheduled to arrive in Taiwan at 10:10 p.m. Saturday on Air Macau NX632.

DOC.HEADLINE: Palace Museum taking steps to control overcrowding

TEXT.P: The National Palace Museum (NPM) in suburban Taipei will take steps to better manage crowds, as the recent influx of Chinese tourists has seriously affected the quality of its service to visitors, a senior curator said Saturday.

The museum, home to the cream of ancient Chinese art, is usually a must-see tourist attraction for visitors from China. This has resulted in frequent overcrowding in its major display rooms or galleries since the number of Chinese visitors began to increase substantially in March, NPM Deputy Director Feng Ming-chu said.

In the past, Feng said, the daily number of visitors to the museum would exceed 8,000, or even 10,000 only on holidays. "But nowadays, the number tends to surpass the 8,000 mark every day," she added.

Noting that the number of Chinese visitors is expected to increase further following the launch of regularly scheduled flights across the Taiwan Strait in the near future, Feng said the museum is studying measures to control overcrowding.

According to Feng, the museum is contacting local travel agencies and tour guides to seek their cooperation on crowd management through a reservation system that may be introduced on an experimental basis, Feng said.
Better crowd management can result in improved service quality and thus allow visitors to appreciate the museum's art treasures in an orderly and quiet atmosphere, she added.
At present, the display area for the museum's Jadeite Cabbage with Insects -- the piece most beloved among Chinese visitors -- is always chaotic and noisy because of overcrowding, Feng said.
Acknowledging that the museum has been receiving an increasing number of complaints, Feng said it is giving top priority to improving crowd control in the area.

Among others measures, she said, the museum will advise tour guides to introduce to Chinese visitors special aspects of the Jadeite Cabbage in the museum's front hall where there are light boxes that feature the item. Visitors will therefore be able to better appreciate the piece in a quieter ambience when they actually see it, Feng added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pact will give financial sector access to Chinese market: FSC

TEXT.P: The upcoming financial cooperation agreement between Taiwan and China will pave the way for Taiwan's financial sector to gain access to the Chinese market, Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) Chairman Sean Chen said Saturday.

The agreement is one of three accords expected to be signed Sunday in Nanjing during the third meeting between the two top cross-strait negotiators from both sides -- Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation, and Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits.

The FSC's Chen explained that the agreement will provide a framework for future negotiations between the two sides on the establishment of three separate memorandums of understanding on cooperation on financial supervision and regulation in the banking, securities and futures, and insurance industries.
After the signing of the MOUs, the two sides will officially enter talks on market access, he said.
"To Taiwan's financial sector, this would be like obtaining an admission ticket to the Chinese market," he said.

Norman Yin, a professor of financial studies at National Chengchi University, said the MOUs will serve as a platform from which Taiwan's financial sector could make inroads to the Chinese market, which he said is very important to the sector's development.
According to Yin, Taiwan's financial market has in recent years showed signs of saturation as a result of excess banking capacity, which gives urgency to the exploration of new markets.
He said the vast market in China holds very good opportunities for Taiwan and will help enhance the competitiveness of the financial sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: Travel agency penalized for poor service to Chinese tourists

TEXT.P: Taiwan's tourism authorities have ordered a Taipei-based travel agency to suspend operations for three months with effect from May 1, after it failed to book ground transportation for Chinese tour groups in Taiwan as promised, a Tourism Bureau official said Saturday.
"It is mean to stand up travelers, " said Chen Mei-hsiu, the head of the bureau's Hotel, Travel and Training Division.
Chen was referring to the Sun Hua Travel Service which she said left four groups of Chinese tourists stranded either at the airport or in hotels after they arrived in Taiwan Thursday.
A similar situation arose again the following day with four other tour groups from China that were to be hosted by Sun Hua, she said.

Therefore, the Tourism Bureau has suspended the operations of Sun Hua Travel Service for three months and has asked that it present a concrete plan within that time to improve its services, Chen said.
If there is no improvement by then, the bureau will revoke the agency's business license, she added.

However, the bureau is allowing Sun Hua to fulfill its obligations to other previously booked tours groups until May 1, but has warned the agency to deal with its clients based on the principles of honesty and sincerity.
If it does not follow the rules, the bureau will revoke its business license, Chen said, suggesting the travel agency cancel the upcoming tours if it cannot secure buses to transport the visitors.

The eight groups of Chinese tourists that Sun Hua was supposed to host began their scheduled tour of the island Saturday after the Taipei-based Travel Quality Assurance Association stepped in with an emergency tour bus arrangement.

Meanwhile, other tour groups from China that were contracted to Sun Hua were expected to arrive in Taiwan Saturday and Sunday as scheduled, as Sun Hua gave the assurance that it had made all the necessary ground transportation arrangements.

At this time of year when many students usually take graduation trips and local people go on religious pilgrimages, the shortage of tour buses in Taiwan has been exacerbated by a steep increase in the number of sightseers from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of Chinese sightseers to Taipei 101 increases seven-fold

TEXT.P: The number of Chinese tourists visiting Taipei 101, the world's tallest occupied skyscraper, has risen sharply with the influx of sightseers from China, a Taipei 101 official said Saturday.

Taipei 101 Acting Chairman and President Harace Lin said that in mid-April alone, Chinese tourists made 17,000 visits per week to the landmark building in Taipei, about seven times more than in the past.

According to statistics released by the Tourism Bureau, Chinese travelers made 87,002 visits to Taiwan in March, up 362.5 percent from the same month last year. Of that number, 45,739 were for sightseeing purposes, which represented a whopping 1,526.56 percent increase from the same period last year, the figures showed.

The Tourism Bureau said that since Taiwan's opening to larger numbers of Chinese tourists and the launch of direct cross-strait charter flights in July 2008, there has been double digit growth in total number of visitors and sightseers from China.
Lin said that prior to July 2008, the number of Chinese visitors to Taipei 101 was several thousand per month, but the number began to climb in October 2008.
Last week, Chinese travelers made 17,000 visits to Taipei 101, averaging 2,500 per day, compared with fewer than 2,500 per week previously, he said.
Lin also said that seven out of 10 Chinese visitors usually want to go to the Observatory on the 89th floor to get an aerial view of the metropolis.
In view of the sharp increase in the number of Chinese visitors to Taipei 101, Lin said, he is making some changes to maximize the business opportunities.
This includes offering brand name items preferred by Chinese tourists and changing the location of certain counters to areas frequented by Chinese tourist groups.
For example, the cosmetic section will be adjusted, and priority will be given to those counters that carry brands favored by both Chinese and Taiwanese visitors, he said.
In addition, as it has been observed that Chinese tourists like to buy watches, a watch section opened in the tower in early April, Lin said.
He noted that while China has a luxury item tax of between 20 and 30 percent, there is no such tax in Taiwan and visitors are also entitled to a five percent duty free concession on certain items.
This means that Chinese tourists can obtain luxury goods in Taiwan at 25 percent less than in China, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet minister resigns over skipping work to go on dates

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan approved Minister Without Portfolio Chu Yun-peng's resignation Saturday after a local magazine stated that Chu skipped work twice earlier this month to go on dates.
"The premier agreed earlier today to accept my resignation, " Chu said a news conference Saturday evening in the company of Government Information Office Minister Su Jun-pin.
Chu said he tendered his resignation during a meeting with the premier Friday afternoon.
"I appreciate the premier's acceptance of my resignation, " he added.

Chu's announcement came a day after the Control Yuan, the country's supreme watchdog body that supervises government operations and public functionaries' behavior, promised at the request of an opposition Democratic Progressive Party politician to investigate whether Chu has violated the Civil Service Act by skipping work to go dates.
The Chinese-language weekly Next Magazine on Wednesday carried a story and photos of Chu and his girlfriend going out on April 7 and April 10 during office hours.
Chu, an economist-turned-official who is known to be one of President Ma Ying- jeou's most trusted economics advisers, apologized later that day for going out on dates during office hours.

At the time, Chu, citing personal privacy, declined to comment on whether his marriage ended in divorce late last year and whether he was having an affair with the woman in the magazine photos. He instead said he had spoken with Premier Liu by phone about the report.

Chu was the third Cabinet member to resign since President Ma Ying-jeou took office last May. The other two members were Lin Fang-yu, who resigned from the post of Department of Health, and Gordon Chen, who stepped down from the post of Financial Supervisory Commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: Family members of victims in crane accident arrive in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Family members of the Chinese tourists who were killed or wounded by a falling crane boom arrived in Taipei Saturday, while three officials in charge of travel affairs in China's Guangdong Province where the tourists came from were scheduled to arrive Sunday.

Hu Wenqiang of the Chinese travel agency that organized the ill-fated tour arrived here earlier in the day to handle the aftermath of the accident that occurred the previous day in the upscale Xinyi shopping district in Taipei City.

Two Chinese tourists were killed and several others injured when a section of a crane's lattice boom fell from the top of a 31-story building under construction onto a passing tour bus that was carrying 25 visitors from Guangdong on the second to last day of their six-day tour of Taiwan.

On Saturday, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said the contractors must take full responsibility for the accident, as a report by the city's Labor Standards Inspection Office indicated that it was caused by human negligence.
The office in charge of the investigation into the accident stated that the major causes were flawed operations and undercapacity of a smaller crane that was lifting the lattice boom when it fell.

Office Director Chang Chi-yu said the operators of the crane failed to take into consideration crucial factors such as weather conditions and the crane's capacity. A small crane with a 3.2-ton capacity was used to lift a boom that weighed over 4 tons, he said.
The office's inspectors also discovered many safety flaws at the construction site close to the scene of the accident, Chang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait talks set to deliver new breakthrough (roundup)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/09 23:22:04 (By Sofia Wu and Y.F.Low)

TEXT.P: Top negotiators from Taiwan and China will meet in the central Chinese city of Nanjing Sunday to seal three pacts and issue a joint statement, which are expected to deliver new breakthroughs in relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Prior to his departure for Nanjing Saturday morning, Taiwan's chief delegate, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, said the agreements will increase economic and financial cooperation amid President Ma Ying-jeou's efforts to enhance Taiwan's competitiveness in the global market and will ensure the peaceful development of cross-strait relations.

Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan also said Saturday in an interview that the financial cooperation agreement to be signed Sunday and a joint statement on opening Taiwan to Chinese investment to be issued simultaneously will pave the way for normalization of trade and economic relations and improve order in the civic exchanges between the two sides.

According to Lai, opening up to investment from China will be an important step in normalizing trade and economic ties across the strait, because the one-way movement of investment from Taiwan to China over the past 20 years has tilted the balance of cross-strait capital flows.
Taiwanese companies are believed to have invested more than US$100 billion in China and business leaders often compalin they are hurt by restrictions on finance and trade.
Lai said any investment agreement with China will bar Chinese access to sectors deemed critical to Taiwan's national security and economic well-being.

The agreement on mutual judicial assistance and cooperation in fighting crime will mark yet another step forward in cross-strait engagements and in Taiwan's quest to bring to justice many of its notorious fugitives in China, SEF Vice Chairman Kao Koong-lian said in Nanjing Saturday after wrapping up a preparatory session for Sunday's meeting.

Furthermore, Kao added, the agreement on the launch of regular cross-strait flights will facilitate cross-strait tourism development and boost mutual understanding and trust through increased civilian exchanges.

Referring to the significance of the four documents to be signed by Chiang and his Chinese counterpart, Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , Kao stressed that cross-strait relations will enter a new stage following the Chiang-Chen talks Sunday.
More than 260 reporters from Taiwan, China, Hong Kong and many other countries have registered to cover Sunday's event, which will be held at a hillside resort on the outskirts of Nanjing.
During his talks with Chen, Chiang is also likely to officially raise a proposal for Taiwan and China to sign an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).
President Ma has expressed strong support for the establishment of the ECFA, stressing that it is similar to a free trade agreement (FTA) with no political strings attached.

He has argued that if Taiwan does not sign such an agreement with China, it risks being marginalized and losing its competitiveness, as China and neighboring countries are about to sign FTAs and as Beijing continues to block Taiwan's efforts to reach FTA agreements with other countries.
The SEF and ARATS are intermediary bodies set up by Taiwan and China, respectively, to handle cross-strait affairs in the absence of official ties.
The Chiang-Chen meeting Sunday will be the third of its kind since the resumption of regular cross-strait dialogue less than one year ago after a nine- year hiatus.

The meeting signifies continued warming of relations between the two former rivals since the inauguration of Ma, whose administration has made it a priority to ease tensions and improve relations with China.
In their earlier rounds of talks, the two sides agreed to begin daily charter flights and direct sea and postal service and to increase the number of Chinese tourists visiting Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Travel agency penalized for poor service to Chinese tourists

TEXT.P: Taiwan's tourism authorities have ordered a Taipei-based travel agency to suspend operations for three months with effect from May 1, after it failed to book ground transportation for Chinese tour groups in Taiwan as promised, a Tourism Bureau official said Saturday.
"It is mean to stand up travelers, " said Chen Mei-hsiu, the head of the bureau's Hotel, Travel and Training Division.
Chen was referring to the Sun Hua Travel Service which she said left four groups of Chinese tourists stranded either at the airport or in hotels after they arrived in Taiwan Thursday.
A similar situation arose again the following day with four other tour groups from China that were to be hosted by Sun Hua, she said.

Therefore, the Tourism Bureau has suspended the operations of Sun Hua Travel Service for three months and has asked that it present a concrete plan within that time to improve its services, Chen said.
If there is no improvement by then, the bureau will revoke the agency's business license, she added.

However, the bureau is allowing Sun Hua to fulfill its obligations to other previously booked tours groups until May 1, but has warned the agency to deal with its clients based on the principles of honesty and sincerity.
If it does not follow the rules, the bureau will revoke its business license, Chen said, suggesting the travel agency cancel the upcoming tours if it cannot secure buses to transport the visitors.

The eight groups of Chinese tourists that Sun Hua was supposed to host began their scheduled tour of the island Saturday after the Taipei-based Travel Quality Assurance Association stepped in with an emergency tour bus arrangement.

Meanwhile, other tour groups from China that were contracted to Sun Hua were expected to arrive in Taiwan Saturday and Sunday as scheduled, as Sun Hua gave the assurance that it had made all the necessary ground transportation arrangements.

At this time of year when many students usually take graduation trips and local people go on religious pilgrimages, the shortage of tour buses in Taiwan has been exacerbated by a steep increase in the number of sightseers from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of Chinese sightseers to Taipei 101 increases seven-fold

TEXT.P: The number of Chinese tourists visiting Taipei 101, the world's tallest occupied skyscraper, has risen sharply with the influx of sightseers from China, a Taipei 101 official said Saturday.

Taipei 101 Acting Chairman and President Harace Lin said that in mid-April alone, Chinese tourists made 17,000 visits per week to the landmark building in Taipei, about seven times more than in the past.

According to statistics released by the Tourism Bureau, Chinese travelers made 87,002 visits to Taiwan in March, up 362.5 percent from the same month last year. Of that number, 45,739 were for sightseeing purposes, which represented a whopping 1,526.56 percent increase from the same period last year, the figures showed.

The Tourism Bureau said that since Taiwan's opening to larger numbers of Chinese tourists and the launch of direct cross-strait charter flights in July 2008, there has been double digit growth in total number of visitors and sightseers from China.
Lin said that prior to July 2008, the number of Chinese visitors to Taipei 101 was several thousand per month, but the number began to climb in October 2008.
Last week, Chinese travelers made 17,000 visits to Taipei 101, averaging 2,500 per day, compared with fewer than 2,500 per week previously, he said.
Lin also said that seven out of 10 Chinese visitors usually want to go to the Observatory on the 89th floor to get an aerial view of the metropolis.
In view of the sharp increase in the number of Chinese visitors to Taipei 101, Lin said, he is making some changes to maximize the business opportunities.
This includes offering brand name items preferred by Chinese tourists and changing the location of certain counters to areas frequented by Chinese tourist groups.
For example, the cosmetic section will be adjusted, and priority will be given to those counters that carry brands favored by both Chinese and Taiwanese visitors, he said.
In addition, as it has been observed that Chinese tourists like to buy watches, a watch section opened in the tower in early April, Lin said.
He noted that while China has a luxury item tax of between 20 and 30 percent, there is no such tax in Taiwan and visitors are also entitled to a five percent duty free concession on certain items.
This means that Chinese tourists can obtain luxury goods in Taiwan at 25 percent less than in China, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet minister resigns over skipping work to go on dates

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan approved Minister Without Portfolio Chu Yun-peng's resignation Saturday after a local magazine stated that Chu skipped work twice earlier this month to go on dates.
"The premier agreed earlier today to accept my resignation, " Chu said a news conference Saturday evening in the company of Government Information Office Minister Su Jun-pin.
Chu said he tendered his resignation during a meeting with the premier Friday afternoon.
"I appreciate the premier's acceptance of my resignation, " he added.

Chu's announcement came a day after the Control Yuan, the country's supreme watchdog body that supervises government operations and public functionaries' behavior, promised at the request of an opposition Democratic Progressive Party politician to investigate whether Chu has violated the Civil Service Act by skipping work to go dates.
The Chinese-language weekly Next Magazine on Wednesday carried a story and photos of Chu and his girlfriend going out on April 7 and April 10 during office hours.
Chu, an economist-turned-official who is known to be one of President Ma Ying- jeou's most trusted economics advisers, apologized later that day for going out on dates during office hours.

At the time, Chu, citing personal privacy, declined to comment on whether his marriage ended in divorce late last year and whether he was having an affair with the woman in the magazine photos. He instead said he had spoken with Premier Liu by phone about the report.

Chu was the third Cabinet member to resign since President Ma Ying-jeou took office last May. The other two members were Lin Fang-yu, who resigned from the post of Department of Health, and Gordon Chen, who stepped down from the post of Financial Supervisory Commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: Family members of victims in crane accident arrive in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Family members of the Chinese tourists who were killed or wounded by a falling crane boom arrived in Taipei Saturday, while three officials in charge of travel affairs in China's Guangdong Province where the tourists came from were scheduled to arrive Sunday.

Hu Wenqiang of the Chinese travel agency that organized the ill-fated tour arrived here earlier in the day to handle the aftermath of the accident that occurred the previous day in the upscale Xinyi shopping district in Taipei City.

Two Chinese tourists were killed and several others injured when a section of a crane's lattice boom fell from the top of a 31-story building under construction onto a passing tour bus that was carrying 25 visitors from Guangdong on the second to last day of their six-day tour of Taiwan.

On Saturday, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said the contractors must take full responsibility for the accident, as a report by the city's Labor Standards Inspection Office indicated that it was caused by human negligence.
The office in charge of the investigation into the accident stated that the major causes were flawed operations and undercapacity of a smaller crane that was lifting the lattice boom when it fell.

Office Director Chang Chi-yu said the operators of the crane failed to take into consideration crucial factors such as weather conditions and the crane's capacity. A small crane with a 3.2-ton capacity was used to lift a boom that weighed over 4 tons, he said.
The office's inspectors also discovered many safety flaws at the construction site close to the scene of the accident, Chang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait talks set to deliver new breakthrough (roundup)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/09 23:22:04 (By Sofia Wu and Y.F.Low)

TEXT.P: Top negotiators from Taiwan and China will meet in the central Chinese city of Nanjing Sunday to seal three pacts and issue a joint statement, which are expected to deliver new breakthroughs in relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Prior to his departure for Nanjing Saturday morning, Taiwan's chief delegate, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, said the agreements will increase economic and financial cooperation amid President Ma Ying-jeou's efforts to enhance Taiwan's competitiveness in the global market and will ensure the peaceful development of cross-strait relations.

Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan also said Saturday in an interview that the financial cooperation agreement to be signed Sunday and a joint statement on opening Taiwan to Chinese investment to be issued simultaneously will pave the way for normalization of trade and economic relations and improve order in the civic exchanges between the two sides.

According to Lai, opening up to investment from China will be an important step in normalizing trade and economic ties across the strait, because the one-way movement of investment from Taiwan to China over the past 20 years has tilted the balance of cross-strait capital flows.
Taiwanese companies are believed to have invested more than US$100 billion in China and business leaders often compalin they are hurt by restrictions on finance and trade.
Lai said any investment agreement with China will bar Chinese access to sectors deemed critical to Taiwan's national security and economic well-being.

The agreement on mutual judicial assistance and cooperation in fighting crime will mark yet another step forward in cross-strait engagements and in Taiwan's quest to bring to justice many of its notorious fugitives in China, SEF Vice Chairman Kao Koong-lian said in Nanjing Saturday after wrapping up a preparatory session for Sunday's meeting.

Furthermore, Kao added, the agreement on the launch of regular cross-strait flights will facilitate cross-strait tourism development and boost mutual understanding and trust through increased civilian exchanges.

Referring to the significance of the four documents to be signed by Chiang and his Chinese counterpart, Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , Kao stressed that cross-strait relations will enter a new stage following the Chiang-Chen talks Sunday.
More than 260 reporters from Taiwan, China, Hong Kong and many other countries have registered to cover Sunday's event, which will be held at a hillside resort on the outskirts of Nanjing.
During his talks with Chen, Chiang is also likely to officially raise a proposal for Taiwan and China to sign an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).
President Ma has expressed strong support for the establishment of the ECFA, stressing that it is similar to a free trade agreement (FTA) with no political strings attached.

He has argued that if Taiwan does not sign such an agreement with China, it risks being marginalized and losing its competitiveness, as China and neighboring countries are about to sign FTAs and as Beijing continues to block Taiwan's efforts to reach FTA agreements with other countries.
The SEF and ARATS are intermediary bodies set up by Taiwan and China, respectively, to handle cross-strait affairs in the absence of official ties.
The Chiang-Chen meeting Sunday will be the third of its kind since the resumption of regular cross-strait dialogue less than one year ago after a nine- year hiatus.

The meeting signifies continued warming of relations between the two former rivals since the inauguration of Ma, whose administration has made it a priority to ease tensions and improve relations with China.
In their earlier rounds of talks, the two sides agreed to begin daily charter flights and direct sea and postal service and to increase the number of Chinese tourists visiting Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for April 26, 2009

TEXT.P: Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 26, or the 2nd day of the fourth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1452: Leonardo da Vinci, Italian painter, engineer, scientist and one of the most versatile artists of the Renaissance, is born. As a painter, he is best known for "The Last Supper" and "Mona Lisa."
1885: Britain occupies Port Hamilton, Korea.
1925: Paul von Hinderburg, German general and politician, is elected president of the Weimar Republic. He appointed Adolf Hitler as chancellor in 1933.
1946: Chinese communist troops take over Harbin and Tsitsihar as Soviet forces evacuate.
1954: The United Nations meets at Geneva and insists on free elections in Korea.
1960: The construction of the East-West Cross-Island Highway in Taiwan is completed.
1966: Mt. Kelud erupts in Java, Indonesia, killing some 1,000 people.
1971: A White House commission recommends that Communist China be brought into the United Nations, with the Republic of China on Taiwan retaining its membership.
1972: The eleven-member Chinese track and field team returns from Manila after winning 11 gold, 2 silver and 4 bronze medals in the three-day Philippine National Open Track and Field Championships.
1975: The Embassy of the Republic of China in Saigon suspends operations.
1975: Shortly before the fall of Saigon, former South Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu and his wife arrive in Taipei for a temporary stay before going into exile in the United States.
1976: The Fourth Asian Writers Conference of International P.E.N. opens with some 90 leading writers in Asia, Europe and America attending.
1976: The government of the Republic of China and the government of the Republic of South Africa announce the elevation of their consulates general to embassy status.
1976: Brig. Gen. Dan A. Brooksher of the U.S. Air Force arrives to replace Brig. Gen. David O. Williams Jr. as chief of staff of the U.S. Taiwan Defense Command.
1983: Explosions occur in buildings occupied by the Central Daily News and the United Daily News in Taipei.
1984: U.S. President Ronald Reagan and his wife Nancy leave for a trip to mainland China.
1986: A nuclear reactor at the Chernobyl plant in the Ukraine explodes, spreading a radioactive cloud across Europe and causing grave pollution. It was the world's worst nuclear accident.
1989: Mainland students march to central Beijing to protest government statements condemning their campaign for democracy.
1994: A China Airlines A300-600 Airbus crashes at Nagoya airport in Japan, killing 264 aboard. There were only seven survivors.
1996: Communist China, Russia and three former Soviet republics sign a treaty aimed at reducing tensions along their common borders.
1997: Peng Zhen, a senior leader of Communist China, dies in Beijing at the age of 95.
1999: NATO planes destroy the Zezeljev railway bridge in Novi Sad during the Kosovo war.
2000: Rodolfo T. Reyes, the new defacto Philippine representative to the Republic of China in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
2000: ROC President-elect Chen Shui-bian pays a visit to former Premier Hau Pei- tsun for talks on a wide range of issues.
2001: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs congratulates Junichiro Koizumi on his election as Japanese prime minister.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be conscientious and sincere in what you say; be earnest and serious in what you do: in that way, although you might be in barbarous countries, you will get along well with men."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
China proposes cross-strait economic cooperation mechanism

TEXT.P: China's top negotiator with Taiwan proposed Sunday that both sides work to establish an economic cooperation mechanism as the basis for the normalization of cross-strait economic ties and enhanced competitiveness.

Speaking at the opening of a new round of cross-strait talks, Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , said that in order to meet economic challenges at home and abroad, the two sides should seek to build a cooperation mechanism or framework that would reflect their respective economic characteristics and at the same time allow both sides to develop economically.

Echoing Chinese President Hu Jintao's recent comment during a tour of Shandong Province that "those who who can weather the current economic difficulties will see great development in the future," Chen urged that the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait cooperate to ride out the global financial crisis.

Chen said that the mainland will push Chinese businesses to make investments in Taiwan and buy more Taiwan-made products. As a result, Chinese companies will make lots of shopping sprees in Taiwan, Taiwan businesses will be enticed to explore the Chinese market, and more Chinese tourists will be encouraged to travel to Taiwan, all of which will help "balance the development of the markets," he said.

He was most likely alluding to remarks made Saturday by Lai Shin-yuan, chairwoman of Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council, that Taiwanese companies are believed to have invested more than US$100 billion in China and the one-way movement of investment from Taiwan to China over the past 20 years has tilted the balance of cross-strait capital flows.

Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , is leading the Taiwan delegation to the one-day SEF-ARATS meeting -- the third in less than a year -- in the central Chinese city of Nanjing.

Chiang noted that the two sides have signed six agreements since last June on weekend charter flights, tourism, direct shipping, air transport, postal services, and food safety. Sunday's talks will mainly focus on reviews of the progress made in these six areas, he added.

Negotiators from the two sides will hold their final discussions before sealing three pacts on regular scheduled flights, mutual judicial assistance and cooperation in fighting crime, and financial cooperation. They will also issue a joint statement on Chinese investment in Taiwan.
The three agreements, along with the joint statement, are expected to deliver new breakthroughs in relations across the Taiwan Strait.

During his talks with Chen, Chiang will also officially raise a proposal for Taiwan and China to sign an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) . He said he was authorized by the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou to put forth the proposal during the current round of talks.

President Ma has argued that if Taiwan does not sign such an agreement with China, it risks being marginalized and losing its competitiveness, as China and neighboring countries are about to sign FTAs and as Beijing continues to block Taiwan's efforts to reach FTA agreements with other countries.
The two sides will also exchange views on the agenda for the fourth round of SEF-ARATS talks, Chiang added.

Negotiators of the two intermediary bodies, founded in 1990 and 1991 respectively to handle cross-strait affairs in the absence of official ties, are expected to hold separate news conferences soon after the Nanjing talks.
The two organizations agreed to meet twice a year on the mainland and Taiwan alternately after negotiations resumed last June following a nine-year hiatus.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sailing junk on quest for record sinks off Suao, all crew safe

TEXT.P: A Hong Kong-registered Chinese sailing junk, Princess Taiping, sank off the northeastern Taiwan fishing port of Suao early Sunday morning after it was struck by an unknown foreign freighter, the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) reported.
The Princess Taiping is a rebuilt Ming Dynasty sailing junk that set sail from the northeastern Taiwan harbor of Keelung last June on an ambitious, engineless cross-Pacific voyage.
When it sank, it was only a few hours, or roughly 42 nautical miles, from completing the 10-month round trip challenge, as it was scheduled to pull into Keelung's Bisha Fishing Port later in the day.

All 11 crew members aboard the sailing junk -- Taiwanese Captain Liu Ning-sheng, six Americans, two Japanese, one Taiwanese and one mainland Chinese -- were rescued in a Taiwan joint rescue operation after they sent out an S-O-S call around 3: 40 a.m. Sunday. Shortly after the distress call was sent, the vessel sank at a location about 30 nautical miles off Suao.

The crew members were rescued by two helicopters dispatched by the National Rescue Center, and 10 of them were taken to two military hospitals in Taipei City for treatment at around 8 a.m. Liu, who sustained slight head injuries, was taken to Veterans General Hospital in Suao.
Two of the crew members had serious injuries to the head and neck, respectively, while the others were receiving treatment for hypothermia, according to CGA officials.
Some of the crew said that during the chaos after the junk was hit at around 2: 40 a.m., they spotted the name of the freighter as Champion Express.

A check of the maritime charts by the Suao-based CGA found that a vessel named Champion Express was indeed in the area at that time. Radar records showed that the freighter, which was heading north before it rammed into the Princess Taiping, made an abrupt turn in a westerly direction after the sailing junk broke in two. The ship then turned northward and fled, the records showed.
The Princess Taiping put out from Keelung's Bisha Fishing Port on June 26, 2008 and had made port calls in Japan, the west coast of the United States, Hawaii and Saipan over the past 10 months.

It departed from Naha, Okinawa Saturday for Taiwan and was scheduled to return to Bisha later Sunday to complete a cross-Pacific voyage that would have set a record as the first by a rebuilt Ming Dynasty sailing junk without mechanical power.
Liu, 62, a local yacht skipper, became the first Taiwanese to accomplish a round-the-world voyage by yacht in 2001, completing the feat in 877 days.

DOC.HEADLINE: Stainless steel producers expect market recovery

TEXT.P: Leading stainless producers in Taiwan on Sunday reported substantially improved sales in April, kindling hopes that the market has at least touched the bottom, if not yet started to rebound.

Yieh United Steel Corp. in Kaohsiung County -- the largest integrated stainless steel mill in Southeast Asia with an annual capacity of 1 million metric tons -- indicated that thanks to rising international nickel prices, its stainless steel supply in April is expected to reach 70,000 metric tons.
The estimated volume for April is a significant increase from the historical monthly lows of 40,000 tons in January and February and around 60,000 tons in March, the mill said.

Tang Eng Iron Works Co. in Kaohsiung, a specialized producer of stainless steel with an annual capacity is 260,000 metric tons, also reported that its capacity utilization rate has increased from 20 percent in February to 80 percent in April, with total production in April estimated to triple to 24,000 metric tons from the monthly average of the first quarter.

Both Yieh United and Tang Eng hiked their stainless steel prices in mid-April, prompting a wave of price increases by downstream producers, including Yeun Chyang Industrial Co., Froch Enterprise Co., Chien Shing Stainless Steel Co., Yeou Yih Steel Co., Sinkang Industries Co., Ta Chen Stainless Pipe Co., and Rodex Fasteners Corp.
Most producers said they believe that as long as nickel prices remain above US$10,000 per metric ton in May and June, their monthly revenues in the second quarter will continue to recover.
Stainless-steel producers use about two-thirds of global nickel supplies, as the alloy contains up to 9 percent nickel, which accounts for about half of total stainless-steel production costs.

Nickel traded at an average price of US$9,686 per ton in January on the London Metal Exchange and rose 15 percent to slightly above US$10,000 per ton in February and mid-March before dipping below US$10,000 per ton again in late March.
The prices soared again in April and broke US$12,000 per ton a week ago, setting a new high for this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan heightens preventive measures against swine flu

TEXT.P: Taiwan's public health authorities on Sunday heightened preventive measures against the threat of swine influenza, in light of outbreaks of human infections with swine flu in Mexico and the United States.
The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the Cabinet-level Department of Health announced that it has raised its travel advisory for Mexico to a "regional pandemic" alert against swine flu.
CDC officials said Taiwan travelers should take strong precautionary measures against swine flu before and after visits to Mexico.
They said Taiwan visitors to California and Texas in the U.S. should also be on high alert against the disease.

The CDC said it is keeping in close contact with the World Health Organization (WHO) to obtain updates on the spread and control of swine flu. This information is being obtained under the International Health Regulations (IHR) framework, to which Taiwan gained entry in early April.
CDC officials said they will advise Taiwan citizens against making any unnecessary trips to Mexico and the two U.S. states if the situation in the affected areas worsens.
According to the WHO, the Swine Influenza A/H1N1 viruses characterized in this outbreak had not been previously detected in pigs or humans.

The world health regulatory body on Saturday declared the swine flu outbreak in Mexico and the United States a "public health emergency of international concern" and urged countries to be on the alert.

Based on the advice of a WHO emergency committee, Director- general Margaret Chan recommended that all countries intensify surveillance for unusual outbreaks of influenza-like illness and severe pneumonia, a WHO statement said.

Through its accession to the IHR -- a framework under the WHO devised to control the spread of infectious diseases around the globe -- Taiwan is now able for the first time to directly contact WHO authorities and get first-hand information about avian flu prevention and control, food security, and the spread and control of other epidemic diseases.

Because of China's opposition, Taiwan had previously been excluded from the IHR, even though a "universal application" phrase was introduced in the regulations in 2005 with the firm support of the United States and Taiwan's diplomatic allies, and the encouragement of the EU and Japan.
In the past, Taiwan was only able to obtain information on outbreaks of communicable diseases or emergencies in the region, including in China and Hong Kong, on a secondhand basis.

Under the IHR framework, the WHO will dispatch specialists to Taiwan or invite Taiwan representatives to meetings called by the WHO in the event of any public health emergencies in Taiwan of international concern.
Taiwan is also allowed to recommend candidates to be included in the IHR group of specialists.
The IHR was adopted in May 2005 by the WHA and took effect in June 2007. It requires all member states to report and address any public health emergencies of international concern.

DOC.HEADLINE: National Palace Museum will launch 'night feast' activity

TEXT.P: The National Palace Museum (NPM) in suburban Taipei will launch a new "night feast" program, utilizing its cultural resources to promote creative industry in line with a government policy.

Chu Hui-liang, deputy director of the NPM's education promotion department, said Saturday that the program will be introduced on a trial basis over the next six months and will target corporate clients and government agencies, offering them the opportunity to rent the entire venue at NT$220,000 (US$6,510) per night for an all-inclusive "night feast."
Each session, once a month, will accommodate groups of up to 100 guests who will be given a one-hour guided tour of the museum's masterpieces, with in-depth commentary by art experts, she said.
After viewing the exhibits, the guests will be offered a wide variety of refined tea deserts at the museum's tea house on its top floor.

The evening will climax with a magnificent "night feast" at which three different types of meals will be served, she said. These will feature health foods, Chinese herbal medicine and seafood. After the feast, a one-hour concert of traditional nanguan music and dance will bring the night to a close, Chu added.
On Saturday night, the museum staged a trial session, inviting the media and members of the business community to get the first taste of the event.
According to Chu, the Government Information Office and the MiTAC Group has each booked a session.

The "night feast" program is the second activity of that kind to be launched by the National Palace Museum since last November when it came up with a "Saturday Night at NPM" to lure young adults, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan signs three pacts with China to strengthen cooperation

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China signed three pacts and one joint statement here Sunday through their top negotiators, with the aim of strengthening cooperation between the two former civil war rivals.

During the third round of negotiation between the two sides, Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , and Chen Yunlin, president of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, inked the documents on behalf of Taiwan and China, respectively.
Notable among the three pacts was one aimed at increasing the current 108 direct passenger charter flights per week between the two sides to 270.
Some of these flights would be regular scheduled flights that would take off and land at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport and Kaohsiung airport.
China agreed to open six more destinations for such flights, in addition to the current 21 cities.
The number of cargo flights, which now stands at 30 per month, will be increased to 112.

In order to accommodate the increased number of flights, the two sides agreed to set up a new southern route through the flight information region between Taipei and Guangzhou, and a new northern route through the flight information region between Taipei and Shanghai.

Taiwan had proposed that the number of flights be increased to 300 per week because the load factor of the charter flights had increased from 70.3 percent when they were launched on Dec. 15, 2008 to 90.6 percent early this month.

In the second pact, both sides agreed to work together to maintain financial stability. They agreed to cooperate on the supervision of financial and monetary management and to begin negotiations on access to their respective markets by banks, stock brokers and futures companies on each side.

Analysts believe this agreement will pave the way for a memorandum of understanding on financial regulatory cooperation between Taiwan and China, which will in turn lead to the opening of their markets to each other's financial institutions.

The third pact concerned cooperation in fighting crime, with both sides agreeing to help each other in serving judicial documents, and probing and collecting evidence, and to confirm each other's civil judgments and arbitration awards.

Most significantly, the two sides agreed to repatriate criminals and suspected criminals. This aspect of the pact was hailed as a milestone because China has long been considered a haven for Taiwan criminals, mainly because of the absence of a repatriation agreement.
In the joint statement on investment, Taiwan said it would sincerely welcome Chinese investment, and promised to formulate regulations to facilitate this process.
On its part, China agreed to support private investment in Taiwan, and encouraged eligible Chinese enterprises to make fact-finding tours of Taiwan to explore investment opportunities there.
The negotiations began Sunday morning and continued into the afternoon.
During the meeting, the two sides reviewed the execution of six previous pacts between them, and explored the possibility of entering into a trade agreement.
According to SEF Deputy Secretary-General Ma Shaochang, who participated in Sunday's meeting, both sides agreed to begin negotiations on the proposed trade agreement at a yet unspecified time.
Taiwan's opposition parties, notably the Democratic Progressive Party, have opposed this idea out of concerns that it will compromise the country's sovereignty.
Sunday's meeting also decided the next round negotiations should take place the second half of this year in Taiwan.
Taiwan's President Ma Ying-jeou hailed the results of the meeting between Chiang and Chen, during on a visit to Taiwan's southern county of Pingdong Sunday afternoon.

He said although Beijing did not agree to the full number of cross-strait flights proposed by Taipei, and the number of flights between some destinations would be inadequate,"these issues will be addressed in future negotiations."

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese supermarket chains to send procurement mission to Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Nanjing, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/09 20:51:40 (By Kuo Mei-lan and Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: Supermarket chains in China will dispatch a joint procurement mission to Taiwan next month to buy Taiwan-made food products, the head of an amity organization of the supermarket chains disclosed Sunday.

Gu Guojian, secretary-general of the organization, told the Central News Agency that the organization has asked the City Shop supermarket chain in Shanghai to help its members with the procurement plan.
Gu said the organization's members are located in Beijing and in other major cities in different provinces, including Henan, Sichuan, Hubei, Shandong and Liaoning.

Cui Yixiong, general manager of City Shop, said he was getting price quotations from Taiwanese suppliers about various food items the Chinese supermarkets plan to buy, and that the joint procurement plan is expected to be completed within one month.
Cui said that City Shop will send a procurement mission of its own to Taiwan every two months, starting from June, to meet Shanghai's demand for Taiwan-made food products.

Gu and Cui made the disclosure after Chen Yunlin, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits --a semi-official body in Beijing that manages relations with Taiwan -- told participants in the third meeting between him and the head of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation in Nanjing that China will expand its procurement from Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Implementation of pact more crucial than signing: academics

TEXT.P: Putting words into action is more important than signing agreements, said two local academics Sunday, commenting on a pact signed earlier in the day between Taiwan and China on mutual judicial assistance and cooperation in fighting crime.
Prof. Lo Chih-cheng, director of the Department of Political Science of Soochow University in Taipei City, said the signing of the judicial cooperation and crime fighting pact was just a formality.
"What is more important is how the two sides will actually cooperate in this area," Lo said. "No pact is useful unless there is solid action."
Lo suggested that China begin by repatriating major Taiwanese fugitives there and helping Taiwan to return illegal Chinese immigrants who have been detained in Taiwan.

Yang Yung-nien, a professor at National Cheng Kung University in Tainan City, southern Taiwan, said that in his view the pact only deals with principles and does not detail any concrete plans on how to solve cross-strait criminal cases.

Yang said currently, there are huge gaps in the judicial and crime investigation systems between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. Noting that judicial personnel in Taiwan and China have widely differing powers, he said that implementing the agreement will expose even greater differences.
"These gaps could only be narrowed if there are more exchanges between the two sides in actual crime fighting," he added.

He suggested that in order to achieve long-term benefits, first-line law enforcement authorities from Taiwan and China should first build a direct communication channel to facilitate action against crime.

The agreement was one of three signed in the Chinese city of Nanjing earlier in the day between Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and his counterpart Chen Yunlin, president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign ministry releases position paper on Taiwan's WHA bid

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has completed a multi-language position paper to seek global support for Taiwan's bid to gain observer status in the World Health Assembly (WHA) -- the highest decision-making body of the World Health Organization (WHO).
The MOFA is presenting its position paper on the issue in Chinese, English, Spanish and French to explain to the international community the importance of Taiwan joining the WHA.

With the 62nd WHA scheduled for May 18-27 in Geneva, Taiwan is preparing to make its 13th consecutive bid since 1997 for participation in the body. Its previous attempts have been blocked due to obstruction from China.

In the position paper, the MOFA said that Taiwan was pleased to be included in the International Health Regulations (IHR) in January, but added that this is not enough because the IHR mechanism is limited to the monitoring and control of infectious diseases.

Only by taking part in WHO-led exchanges and activities can Taiwan fully engage with other member states to provide or obtain the latest technology and information relating to other human health issues such as food safety, tobacco hazard control and fake medication eradication, the MOFA said.

For instance, it added, Taiwan may not be able to share with WHO member states an anti-H5N1 virus bird flue vaccination that it has been developing since 2005, even if it begins commercial production, because Taiwan is not yet a WHO member.

If Taiwan can become an observer in the WHA and further participate in WHO policy coordination meetings, the country will be able to offer the anti-H5N1 vaccinations to combate avian flu and can make a greater contribution to the international community, the ministry stated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan inks three pacts with China to strengthen cooperation (update)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China signed three pacts and one joint statement here Sunday through their top negotiators, with the aim of strengthening cooperation between the two former civil war rivals.

During the third round of negotiation between the two sides, Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , and Chen Yunlin, president of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, inked the documents on behalf of Taiwan and China, respectively.
Notable among the three pacts was one aimed at increasing the current 108 direct passenger charter flights per week between the two sides to 270.
Some of these flights would be regular scheduled flights that would take off and land at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport and Kaohsiung airport.
China agreed to open six more destinations for such flights, in addition to the current 21 cities.
The number of cargo flights, which now stands at 30 per month, will be increased to 112.

In order to accommodate the increased number of flights, the two sides agreed to set up a new southern route through the flight information region between Taipei and Guangzhou, and a new northern route through the flight information region between Taipei and Shanghai.

Taiwan had proposed that the number of flights be increased to 300 per week because the load factor of the charter flights had increased from 70.3 percent when they were launched on Dec. 15, 2008 to 90.6 percent early this month.

In the second pact, both sides agreed to work together to maintain financial stability. They agreed to cooperate on the supervision of financial and monetary management and to begin negotiations on access to their respective markets by banks, stock brokers and futures companies on each side.

Analysts believe this agreement will pave the way for a memorandum of understanding on financial regulatory cooperation between Taiwan and China, which will in turn lead to the opening of their markets to each other's financial institutions.

The third pact concerned cooperation in fighting crime, with both sides agreeing to help each other in serving judicial documents, and probing and collecting evidence, and to confirm each other's civil judgments and arbitration awards.

Most significantly, the two sides agreed to repatriate criminals and suspected criminals. This aspect of the pact was hailed as a milestone because China has long been considered a haven for Taiwan criminals, mainly because of the absence of a repatriation agreement.
In the joint statement on investment, Taiwan said it would sincerely welcome Chinese investment, and promised to formulate regulations to facilitate this process.
On its part, China agreed to support private investment in Taiwan, and encouraged eligible Chinese enterprises to make fact-finding tours of Taiwan to explore investment opportunities there.
The negotiations began Sunday morning and continued into the afternoon.
During the meeting, the two sides reviewed the execution of six previous pacts between them, and explored the possibility of entering into a trade agreement.
Taiwan's top negotiator Chiang Pin-kung said after the meeting that his Chinese counterpart Chen Yunlin didn't rule out the possibility for talks on the proposed trade agreement.
However Chiang quoted Chen as saying that bilateral economical exchanges should begin from easy things such as those issues raised in previous bilateral negotiations but had not yet been addressed.

Taipei authorities are eager to talk with China on such a pact out of concerns that it might be excluded from a regional economic bloc to be formed between China and Association of Southeast Asian Nations.
Taiwan's opposition parties, notably the Democratic Progressive Party, have opposed this idea, claiming that it will compromise the country's sovereignty.
Sunday's meeting also decided the next round negotiations should take place the second half of this year in Taiwan.
Taiwan's President Ma Ying-jeou hailed the results of the meeting between Chiang and Chen, during on a visit to Taiwan's southern county of Pingdong Sunday afternoon.

He said although Beijing did not agree to the full number of cross-strait flights proposed by Taipei, and the number of flights between some destinations would be inadequate,"these issues will be addressed in future negotiations."
