DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 27, or the third day of the fourth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1521: Portuguese navigator Ferdinand Magellan is killed by the inhabitants on the island of Mactan in the Philippines.
1791: American painter and inventor Samuel F.B. Morse is born. A portraitist whose subjects included Lafayette, he refined and patented the telegraph and developed the telegraphic code that bears his name.
1822: Ulysses S. Grant, the 18th president of the United States, is born. After his victorious Vicksburg campaign, he was made commander in chief of the Union Army and accepted the surrender of Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee at Appomattox in 1865, thus ending the Civil War.
1882: Ralph Waldo Emerson, the American essayist, philosopher, and a central figure of American transcendentalism, dies at the age of 78. His poems, orations and essays are regarded as landmarks in the development of American thought and literary expression.
1887: The world's first surgical removal of an appendix, an operation known as an appendectomy, is performed by American surgeon Dr. Thomas Morton in Philadelphia.
1911: An uprising in Canton, China, is foiled when revolutionaries led by Huang Shing are defeated by the local garrison. The battle in Canton is the 10th uprising directed by Dr. Sun Yat-sen after he launched a revolutionary movement against the Ching court in the late 19th century.
1937: The new Golden Gate suspension bridge linking the city of San Francisco with Marin County reaches completion after four years.
1945: The Allies reject peace offers by German S.S. chief Heinrich Himmler, insisting on unconditional German surrender.
1949: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek arrives in Shanghai and reiterates his determination to suppress the communist rebellion.
1950: The British government officially recognizes the state of Israel.
1956: Rocco Marciano, known as "Rocky," the American boxer who won the world heavyweight championship in 1952 and defended it six times, retires as undefeated world heavyweight boxing champion.
1959: Liu Shao-chi is elected "state chairman" of Communist China.
1960: The ROC establishes diplomatic relations with the Republic of Togo.
1960: Syngman Rhee resigns as president of South Korea, ending his 12-year rule.
1962: Hsieh Chin wins the "best director" award in the first film festival to be held in mainland China.
1972: After a journey to the moon, U.S. Apollo 16 spacecraft carrying three astronauts makes a safe landing in the Pacific Ocean.
1972: Kwame Nkrumah, the Ghanaian president who was deposed in 1966 by a military coup while he was in mainland China, dies in Bucharest, Hungary.
1973: Jordanian Ambassador to the ROC Mutasim Bileisi returns to Amman after a two-year tour of duty in Taipei.
1974: The Academia Sinica Advisory Council votes on a list of candidates for academicians.
1974: The Taiwan Railway Administration and General Electric of the United States sign a contract for the electrification of Taiwan's western trunk line railway. GE will provide 74 locomotives and heavy trucks for the project.
1978: President Mohammed Daoud is killed in a bloody coup and replaced by Afghanistan's first communist ruler, Nur Mohammed Taraki, who proclaims the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan.
1992: The International Monetary Fund and World Bank approve the membership of Russia and 12 other former Soviet republics.
1993: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the ROC Straits Exchange Foundation, and Wang Daohan, chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, meet in Singapore in what is the first official contact between Taipei and Beijing since 1949.
1997: The world's longest road-rail suspension bridge, linking Hong Kong to its new offshore airport, is formally opened.
1998: Nguyen Van Linh, former general secretary of the Vietnam Communist Party, dies.
1999: Verka Modanu, the Republic of Macedonia's first resident envoy to the Republic of China, arrives in Taipei to assume her post.
2000: President-elect Chen Shui-bian says that only mutual trust can bring real peace to the people of both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
2001: The first-ever civic group to promote private exchanges between Taiwan- controlled offshore island of Kinmen and mainland China' Xiamen is formally established following the implementation of the "mini three links" with mainland China at the beginning of the year.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When you meet the proper person to speak to and do not speak out, you lose your opportunity; but when you meet one who is not a proper person to speak to and you speak to him, you waste your words. A man of intelligence never loses his opportunity, neither does he waste his words."

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese tourist injured in crane accident dies

TEXT.P: A Chinese tourist, who was hit by a falling crane boom as his group's tour bus was driving in a bustling Taipei commercial district last week, died Monday at Taipei Medical University Hospital, according to hospital sources.
The 63-year-old Zhang Shiguang had been on extracorporeal membrane oxygenation and hemodialysis machines since being rushed to the hospital after the accident occurred Friday.
Taipei Medical University Hospital plans to hold a press conference later Monday to discuss Zhang's death.

Zhang and 24 other visitors from Guangdong, China were traveling on a tour bus in the upscale Xinyi shopping district in Taipei Friday around 2 p.m. when a lattice boom from a crane fell 31 stories from a building under construction and smashed through the back quarter of the roof of the bus.
One of the passengers was killed on the spot and another died on the way to the hospital, and several others were injured.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China expected to ink financial supervisory MOU in 60 days

TEXT.P: Taiwan hopes to sign a memorandum of understanding (MOU) on financial supervisory cooperation with China in 60 days, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Fu Dong-cheng said in Nanjing Sunday.

"An MOU can further facilitate the implementation of the content of the agreement on financial cooperation that Taiwan and China signed today, " Fu said after Taiwan and China signed three pacts and one joint statement in the central Chinese city Sunday.

In the deal on financial cooperation, Taiwan and China agreed to cooperate on financial institution supervision and currency management, set up a cross- strait currency clearance and settlement mechanism, permit commercial banks to exchange currency and work together on developing technologies to spot counterfeit notes, and allow financial institutions to establish branches in each other's market.

"It is hoped that the MOU and the cross-strait financial cooperaton pact will take effect simultaneously, " said Fu, who was one of 22 Taiwan officials taking part in the third round of cross-strait talks.

Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , and Chen Yunlin, president of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, signed the documents on behalf of Taiwan and China, respectively.
Fu said local banks are allowed to exchange, supply, and recirculate the Chinese currency but are not allowed to have banking links with Chinese counterparts.

But with increased bilateral trade between Taiwan and China spurring a growing flow of money across the Taiwan Strait, Fu hoped a comprehensive currency clearance and settlement mechanism would be negotiated.
He said the plan at present is to designate one or two banks from either side as currency and settlement banks.

Meanwhile, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs John Deng said Monday he welcomed the joint statement on investment made at the talks in Nanjing, saying that increased Chinese investment in Taiwan will help facilitate Taiwan's liberalization policy toward China.
"Once the policy is put into practice, representatives from Chinese business sectors will visit Taiwan to understand the local investment climate," Deng said.
The administration can exchange views with the Chinese business leaders at that time and gather their opinions as a reference in adjusting Taiwan's investment policies, he added.
China agreed to support private investment in Taiwan, and encouraged eligible Chinese enterprises to make fact-finding tours of Taiwan to explore investment opportunities there.

DOC.HEADLINE: Youth encouraged to take in-depth journey in learning about Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level National Youth Commission (NYC) , in collaboration with local nonprofit organizations, launched a program Monday to encourage people aged 15-30 to take an educational journey around Taiwan and explore their roots.

"Given that many young people in Taiwan do not have in-depth knowledge about the country, we hope this program will provide them a whole new way of exploring Taiwan," said NYC minister Wang Yu-ting at a news conference to promote the "Youth Travel Spots in Taiwan -- Grand Tour" program.
The program also aims at boosting the competitiveness of people in the age group because they can learn as much from society as in the classroom, Wang said.
"The youngsters should begin their grand tour of life by learning about their homeland before heading to other parts of the world," she said.

The Grand Tour program, which lists 29 destinations in Taiwan that one must visit before the age of 30, covers activities exposing travelers to local eco- systems, indigenous cultures, humanitarian care and artistic events.

Lahuy Icyeh, a member of the Atayal tribe who just finished his post-graduate studies, said at the news conference that in his trip to Smangus Village in Hsinchu County, he not only immersed himself in the beauty of nature but also learned about the spirit of sharing in indigenous cultures.
"Learning about multiple cultures is a mandatory course that everyone must take," he said.

Chang Hsin-wen, who joined an aboriginal hunter school and took a 20-kilometer journey in Yilan County's Hapen forest, said that the journey taught her about respecting all living creatures and the concept of sustainability.

According to the NYC, the first group of participants in the program will receive a10 percent discount. They can also submit their travel journals and pictures to http: //youthtravel.tw/grandtour by Aug. 31 as part of a competition.
Underprivileged and low-income people in the 15-30 age bracket can receive as much as NT$30,000 (US$889) in subsidies by participating in programs that work with local charities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Father who dumped girl into hot water indicted on homicide charges

TEXT.P: The man who threw his 10-month-old baby girl into boiling water April 18 was indicted Monday on murder charges, with Changhua prosecutors recommending he be sentenced to life imprisonment.

If convicted, the 47-year-old man surnamed Huang could spend the rest of his life in jail and have his political rights severed for his action, which shook up Taiwanese society for its sheer cruelty and raised concerns over increasing violence against children.

The girl, who suffered second and third-degree burns over 84 percent of her body, was pronounced dead after doctors, with the consent of her mother, took her off a life-support system at 10: 05 a.m.. last Tuesday, according to Changhua Christian Hospital in central Taiwan's Changhua City.

Huang has been detained by the Changhua District Prosecutors Office since April 18, when the incident occurred. During a fierce argument between the couple, prompted when the girl's mother criticized Huang for being lazy, the mother dared Huang to throw the girl into a pot of boiling water, and he complied.

The infant's mother, identified only by her family name of Lin, immediately got the baby out of the pot in the noodle shop they owned and rushed the girl to a nearby police station for help. The police immediately transferred the baby to the hospital's burn center.

The couple, who were not married but had lived together for 12 years, also have an older daughter, who is in the fifth grade. County social welfare officials placed the fifth grader with a foster family following the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: Flights between Taipei, Shanghai city airports to be discussed

TEXT.P: The opening of direct charter flights between Taipei's Songshan Airport and Shanghai's Hongqiao Airport will be discussed in the next round of cross-Taiwan Strait aviation negotiations, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said Monday.

Potential travelers were disappointed that Songshan Airport was only allocated 21 direct cross-strait flights a week in an agreement reached at the latest round of negotiations between Taiwan and China in Nanjing Sunday, even though the number of direct flights was increased from 108 to 270 per week.

Songshan Airport, in the northeastern part of Taipei, served as the country's international airport until 1979. It has exclusively handled domestic flights since then but was opened to direct charter flights from China last year when air links between the two countries were liberalized.

Located a short drive away from most of Taipei's commercial centers, compared to the 50-minute drive between the city and Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, the airport is favored by business travelers for its convenience.

Explaining the small number of flights to and from China allocated to the airport, CAA officials said they wanted to reserve the airport's capacity for potential flights from other city airports in Asia, such as Shanghai's Hongqiao Airport, Tokyo's Haneda International Airport and Seoul's Kimpo Internatinal Airport.
Songshan Airport was also not included in the agreement among airports allowed to handle regularly scheduled flights.

CAA officials said Songshan Airport is only allowed to operate direct cross- strait charter flights because regular scheduled flights can transport cargo, but Songshan Airport's facilities are not capable of handling cargo at present.

Aside from increasing flight numbers, the avaiation agreement -- one of the three agreements and one joint statement concluded by Taiwan and China to further strengthen bilateral cooperation -- established regularly scheduled flights and opened six more Chinese destinations, bringing the total to 27.
The number of cargo flights, which now stands at 30 per month, will be increased to 112.

Taiwan had proposed that the number of flights be increased to 300 per week because the load factor of the charter flights had increased from 70.3 percent when they were launched on Dec. 15, 2008 to 90.6 percent early this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese fugitives in China may be repatriated under new pact

TEXT.P: A new pact signed between Taiwan and China Sunday on mutual judicial assistance paves the way for the extradition of at least 84 Taiwanese fugitives hiding in China, according to information provided by the Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of Justice.

Under the agreement -- one of three signed in the Chinese city of Nanjing between Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and his counterpart Chen Yunlin, president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits -- the two sides will assist each other on judicial matters and cooperate in fighting crime.
The two sides will establish a platform to exchange crime-related information and help with the repatriation of wanted criminals.
According to the Investigation Bureau, many of Taiwan's most wanted fugitives have fled to China. Its files show that at least 84 convicted criminals may be hiding there.
The most prominent among these criminals include:
--Former Legislative Yuan Speaker Liu Sung-pan, who was sentenced to four years in prison and fined NT$30 million in September 2004 for breach of trust.

He was found guilty of using his status as the former chairman of Taichung Business Bank in 1998 to broker an illegal NT$1.5 billion (US$44.22 million) loan to the Kuangsan Group in exchange for an NT$150 million bribe.
--Tycoon Tseng Cheng-jen, who fled to China in June 2004 a week after he was sentenced to 11 years in prison in the same illegal loan case that implicated Liu.

--Chen Yu-hao, former head of the Tuntex Group, wanted for questioning on charges that he stole NT$800 million from a group subsidiary in 1995 to invest in his own name in China. He and his wife fled Taiwan in 2002 and are believed to be living in China.
--Former Kaohsiung Mayor Wang Yu-yun, indicted in June 2000 for an illegal NT$8 billion bank loan involving Chung Shing Bank.
He was prohibited from leaving the country in 2002 but managed to flee to China. He is believed to be hiding in Hangzhou, Zhejiang province. In April 2007, he was sentenced to seven years in prison.
--Former Legislator Wang Chih-hsiung, son of Wang Yu-yun, who is also wanted in a bad loan case that resulted in NT$9.7 billion in nonperforming loans at Chung Shing Bank.

--Former Kaohsiung City Council Speaker Chu An-hsiung, who fled to China after being sentenced to seven years in prison for embezzling NT$21.7 billion from a metal company and for vote buying in September 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese firms to be allowed to register businesses in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Chinese companies will soon be allowed to apply to register businesses in Taiwan, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs John Deng said Monday.

Speaking at the Legislative Yuan Economics Committee, Deng said that a bill governing Chinese businesses establishing affiliates or branches in Taiwan has been drafted by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and submitted to the Executive Yuan for approval.

"Several rounds of inter-division meetings have been convened on the matter and the regulations are expected to be formally publicized by the administration for implementation as soon as final procedures are completed," Deng told lawmakers.
Deng was responding to a question raised by ruling Kuomintang Legislator Ting Shou-chung concerning Taiwan's plans to open the country to Chinese capital and investment.
Ting criticized the government for planning to allow Chinese citizens to invest but not having come up with regulations to govern Chinese people establishing businesses in Taiwan.
"How can Chinese capital enter Taiwan if Chinese citizens are not even allowed to establish a company here in the first place? " Ting questioned.

Ting said China Eastern Airlines had planned to lease a Cathay Life building to be used as its Taiwan headquarters, but the plan was aborted because the two companies could not find any domestic legal basis to use in finalizing the transaction.
Ting said the failed deal cost Taiwan 40 to 50 jobs and attributed it to the negligence of relevant administrative agencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Majority support tourism development: government

TEXT.P: A great majority of the public support plans by the government to develop Taiwan's tourism and make the country one of the key destinations for tourism in Asia, a government agency said Monday.

In a recent survey conducted by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) , 78 percent of the respondents said they support the administration's plans to make tourism development one of the top goals with regard to Taiwan's overall development, the DGBAS said.

Seventy-two percent of the respondents said they support the government's plans to investment NT$30 billion (US$890 million) over the next four years to develop Taiwan into a key Asian tourism destination.

The poll, conducted April 21-22, found that 81 percent of the respondents agreed that an online national tourism services network should be set up by the government and that the administration should help local governments to plan tourism routes and provide tourism information, DGBAS officials said.
Meanwhile, 78 percent of the respondents said tourist attractions around the country should be redesignated and overhauled, they noted.
The poll of 969 adults selected randomly nationwide had a margin of error of 3.15 percentage points, DGBAS said.

DOC.HEADLINE: No human infections of swine flu in Taiwan: health minister

TEXT.P: Health Minister Yeh Ching-chuan urged the public Monday to remain calm despite outbreaks of human infections of swine flu in Mexico and the United States, saying that so far, no-one in Taiwan is known to be infected and that the Department of Health (DOH) is watching developments closely.

The DOH also declared the viruses characterized in the swine flu outbreak as new subtypes of the H1N1 virus, a level-one legal infectious disease that requires immediate reporting by hospitals when they encounter such cases, according to Yeh.

His remarks were quoted by Government Information Office Minister Su Jun-bin after attending an inter-government agency meeting hosted by Vice Premier Chiu Cheng-hsiung on coordinating information and preventive measures against the threat of swine flu.
"So far there have been no human infections in Taiwan. People should not panic about the outbreak but should stay alert," Yeh said.

He added that under the framework of the International Health Regulations, to which Taiwan gained entry in early April, the DOH is maintaining close contact with the World Health Organization (WHO) to obtain updates on the spread and control of swine flu.
The DOH will take countermeasures in accordance with the WHO after as soon as it updates the latest situation, expected the following day, Yeh said.
A day earlier, the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the DOH raised a travel advisory for Mexico to a "regional pandemic" alert against swine flu.
CDC officials said Taiwanese travelers should take strong precautionary measures against swine flu before and after visits to Mexico.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) also issued a yellow travel alert for Mexico that same day, the third-highest travel advisory that warns travelers to exercise caution.

"The Foreign Ministry is collecting relevant information and watching closely the development of the swine flu outbreaks in Mexico. Necessary measures will be taken after the WHO meeting scheduled for tomorrow," MOFA spokesman Henry Chen told CNA.

As to concerns about eating pork, Lee Chao-chuan, head of the Tainan City Animal Health Inspection Institute, said there is no safety concern, as long as the pork is properly cooked at over 70 degrees Celsius.

Given that there have been no swine flu cases reported in Taiwan, Lee said the first and most important step is to contain the disease abroad. All pig farms should boost quarantine measures, including disinfection and personnel controls, he added.

The outbraeks of swine flu in Mexico have spread to other parts of the world, raising concerns that it could turn into a global pandemic. The U.S. has declared a "public health emergency" with 20 confirmed cases, while Mexico has more than 100 deaths and 1,600 illnesses attributed to the virus.
Canada and New Zealand have also reported human infections while suspected cases have been identified in Israel, Spain and the United Kingdom.
The WHO has declared the flu a "public health emergency of international concern."

DOC.HEADLINE: History museum to launch exhibition on Taiwan's coffee culture

TEXT.P: The National Museum of History said in a newsletter released Monday that it is scheduled to launch an exhibition in May on Taiwan's coffee culture, which took root during the 1896-1945 Japanese colonial period.

"The aim of this exhibition is to reconstruct this unique aspect of Taiwan's cultural space and to present the influences and underlying meanings of coffee houses in the early years of Japanese rule," the newsletter said.

Although the coffee house is mainly considered to be a product of Western culture, the formation of Taiwan's coffee culture is closely connected to Japan. In the early years of Japanese rule, coffee houses in Taiwan were mostly run by Japanese people and were mostly located in an area of Taipei known at the time as the Sakaemachi, around what is known today as Heng Yang Road, according to the National Museum of History.

Later, when local students would return to Taiwan after studying overseas, bringing with them their greater understanding of Western culture, Taiwanese people began to run coffee houses on their own, including names that became famous, such as Werther, Tianma Teahouse and Bolero, it added.

"Despite being called coffee houses, they were in fact more like restaurants and cabarets -- places catering to Western forms of recreation," the museum said, adding that it will also introduce the coffee growing area of Gukeng township in Central Taiwan's Yunlin County.
The exhibition, titled "Early Taiwanese Coffee Culture," will run May 27- June 14 from 10 a.m-6 p.m. every day except Monday.
Other museum draws to open in May will include an exhibition on the transition of Buddhist statuary featuring gold and bronze statuettes and an exhibition of ancient Chinese jade, the museum added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Swine flu could cause severe epidemic: expert

TEXT.P: Should the swine influenza outbreak in Mexico spread around the world, it could cause much more significant harm to human society than avian flu ever could, a Taiwanese stock disease expert warned Monday.

In response to media inquiries over recent outbreaks of swine flu in the United States and Mexico, Lai Shiow-suey, a former veterinary medicine professor at National Taiwan University, expressed concern about the recombination of different strains of flu virus in pigs.
Describing a pig's body as a big factory, Lai stated that if three different virus strains recombine with each other in pigs, they will transform into a new, more virulent strain.

Lai said that since pigs share similar physical functions and heredity with humans, they can easily pass on the new strain of flu virus to humans, from which the virus can be further spread through human-to-human transmission.

"It is dreadful; it seems the worst senario has happened, " he said, referring to the recent swine flu outbreaks in Mexico where over 100 people are believed to have died and more than 1,600 have been sickened by the virus, a recombinant of the H1N1 flu strain.

Lai recalled an earlier outbreak of H1N1 swine flu reported in the U.S. state of New Jersey in 1976 that infected 230 new military recruits, killing one of them. That outbreak prompted the U.S. government to administer vaccinations, but the outbreak still lasted for more than two months, he said.
The latest outbreak in Mexico will likely cause greater harm than the one in 1976 because "the strain of virus is much more vicious, " Lai said.
He warned people who have recently returned from the United States and Mexico to stay away from pig farms, and that people in the hog-raising industry should be on their guard against an outbreak.

Taiwan's public health authorities heightened preventive measures against the threat of swine flu Sunday, with the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) raising its travel advisory for Mexico to the level of a"regional pandemic" alert against the flu.
Symptoms of the disease include fever, aches, coughing, sore throat, respiratory congestion and in some cases vomiting and diarrhea.

According to foreign wire services, the virus is usually contracted through direct contact with pigs, but Joseph Domenech, chief of animal health services at the U.N. Food and Agriculture Agency in Rome, said all indications so far are that the virus is being spread through human-to-human transmission.
There is no vaccine that protects specifically against swine flu and it is unclear how much protection the current human flu vaccines can offer.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, increasing NT$0.019 to close at NT$33.730.
A total of US$741 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.711 and fluctuated between NT$33.631 and NT$33.749.

DOC.HEADLINE: 36 percent of Taiwan jobless interested in entrepreneurship: poll

TEXT.P: Thirty-six percent of Taiwan's unemployed want to start up their own businesses as a way out of their financial problems, according to the results of a recent survey released Monday by a government-run online employment service network.
With an unprecedentedly high unemployment rate of 5.81 percent, over 630,000 people in Taiwan became jobless in March.

According to the ejob.gov.tw Web site run by the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) , of those unemployed who are interested in entrepreneurship, 17.47 percent said they want to start a business of their own because they want to be their own boss.

In addition to being unemployed or facing a bad employment situation, other reasons that were cited by the potential entrepreneurs include attempting to realize his or her dreams (16.3 percent), the belief that running his or her own business would make more money (10.13 percent) , desire to live the life they want (8.66 percent) and putting his or her ability into full play (7.34 percent), the poll found.

Of the potential entrepreneurs, 5.73 percent said they are positive they want to start a business this year, 14.68 percent said they have strong desire to start a business and have started planning, while 73.27 percent said they are interested in entrepreneurship as a way out but are still just mulling the idea, according to the poll.
A total of 74.45 percent of the potential entrepreneurs said they would prefer to start a business of their own rather than buy a franchise.

Of the potential entrepreneurs, 46.69 percent said they would be prepared to spend less than NT$100,000 (US$2,967) to start their businesses, while 79.28 percent said their startup funds would be controlled within NT$500,000, the survey found.
Ejob.gov.tw conducted the survey between Feb. 13 and April 27 and obtained 681 valid responses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's share prices drop sharply

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices plunged 2.98 percent Monday, as the talks between Taiwan and China the previous day had been factored into the market.
The weighted index, the market's key barometer, lost 175.72 points to close at 5,705.05.
The local bourse opened at 5,931.87 and dropped to a low of 5,672.25 early in the session before rebounding to the day's high 5,946.97.
A total of 6.31 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$136.8 billion (US$4.06 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares dropping the most at 5.3 percent. Paper and pulp stocks lost 4.5 percent, construction shares dropped 4.4 percent, foodstuff shares fell 3.2 percent, machinery and electronics shares shed 2.6 percent, cement issues slid 2.3 percent, plastics and chemicals stocks lost 2.0 percent, and textile issues dropped 1.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,850 to 419, with 64 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$5.34 billion.

Biotech stocks clearly outperformed the overall market on hopes of an increasing demand for flu drugs in the wake of the outbreak of swine flu in Mexico, the United States and elsewhere, analysts said.

Tourism shares and financial and banking stocks slid sharply after President Ma Ying-jeou instructed the Ministry of Transport and Communications to take action to control the number of Chinese tourists visiting Taiwan, and as there was no additional positive news from the third round cross-Taiwan Strait talks to bolster those sectors, according to the analysts.
There is little chance of the market rising further, and it is likely to hit 5,500-point level if it falls below 5,646 Tuesday, the analysts added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung prosecutors help poor students with public funds

TEXT.P: The Taichung District Prosecutors Office donated NT$7.5 million (US$221,890) of public funds Monday to the Taichung City government to provide meals for impoverished students during the summer vacation period.

Taichung Mayor Jason Hu thanked the prosecutors for their generosity and strong support for his proposal that the office use the funds -- recovered from petty offenders in return for deferred prosecution -- to help the cash-strapped city government launch the program.
According to Hu, the city government plans to use the money to issue lunch vouchers to students from the city's impoverished families during the coming summer vacation.
It will be the second program of its kind carried out by the city following initial success with a similar program implemented over the last winter vacation, Hu noted.

Prosecutor Chang Dou-hui said that under the instruction of the Ministry of Justice, the Taichung District Prosecutors Office has made cash donations of the public funds to some 40 welfare groups in the Taichung area and he voiced hope that more enterprises and groups will collaborate with the city government in efforts to aid students in need.

The city's education department estimated that there are about 7,000 needy elementary and junior high students in the city, and said it plans to distribute about 408,000 lunch vouchers during the summer vacation.

In a similar move, the Chiayi District Prosecutors Office in southern Taiwan had as of April 16 granted scholarships to 150 local students from the area from the beginning of the year using money collected in the same way.
The scholarships ranged from NT$2,000 (US$60) for each junior high school student to NT$1,000 for each elementary school student per semester.

The Chiayi Prosecutors Office has NT$10 million (US$298,000) at its disposal this year raised from deferred prosecution payments, a spokesman for the office said in early January when the office sponsored an activity to help impoverished families celebrate the Lunar New Year.
The Chiayi Prosecutors Office has been funding local charitable groups to help them pay for social services for local residents since 2006, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutor detained for second time on suspicion of bribery

TEXT.P: A public prosecutor in Taitung, southeastern Taiwan, who was released on bail five days ago pending further investigation into his alleged acceptance of bribes, was detained again Tuesday.

The Taitung Public Prosecutors' Office took Lin Sheng-lin into custody Sunday night for questioning on the strength of new evidence implicating him in a second bribery case and sought permission from the Taitung District Court again to keep him in custody.

The court granted the permission Monday after reviewing the arguments submitted by the prosecutors' office that Lin tried to contact witnesses and defendants in the bribery cases, through his father, in an apparent attempt to collude with them.

On April 22, Lin was released on bail of NT$500,000 (US$14,760) after being taken into custody a day earlier to answer charges that he had accepted bribes from suspects who should have been indicted in criminal cases that he handled. At the time, the court ruled that there was no need to keep Lin in detention, even though he could face at least five years in prison if convicted.

On that day, the court also set bail at NT$200,000 for Wu Dong-sheng, a broker whom prosecutors said assisted Lin in obtaining bribes. The court ruled that both Lin and Wu are not allowed to leave the country.

According to the Taitung Public Prosecutors' Office, Lin was reassigned from the Shihlin Public Prosecutors' Office in Taipei to work in Taitung in August last year because he left too many criminal cases unhandled.

Ethics officers at the Taitung prosecutors' office placed Lin under surveillance after noting that he continued to allow the accumulation of many cases, and that he had dismissed quite a few cases that he should have prosecuted.
Further investigation led to the admission by several suspects in at least two criminal cases that Lin had offered not to indict them in return for bribes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan elevates travel alert for Mexico City over swine flu scare

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) raised the level of its travel alert for Mexico City to orange Monday, urging prospective travelers to defer their plans for the time being in light of an outbreak of human infections of swine flu there.
The ministry had originally issued a yellow travel alert for Mexico, the lowest level advisory that warns travelers to exercise caution.

However, the MOFA decided to raise the alert for Mexico's capital to orange, the second-highest level, in view of the latest reports that the swine flu outbreak is most serious in Mexico City and has spread to other parts of the world, MOFA officials said.
Moreover, they added, World Health Organizations (WHO) officials have warned that there is a potential for the new swine flu virus to become a global pandemic.
On the ministry's three-color travel advisory scale, an orange alert suggests that would-be travelers should suspend their travel plans over safety or health concerns.
According to MOFA statistics, an average of 3,000 to 4,000 Taiwanese citizens apply for visas to Mexico annually, most of whom intend to travel to Mexico City for business or sightseeing purposes.

In support of the ongoing global campaign to contain the spread of the new H1N1 swine flu virus and out of local health concerns, residents of Taiwan are advised to refrain from traveling to Mexico City for the time being, the officials warned.
Meanwhile, they said the MOFA will maintain its yellow alert for other areas and cities of Mexico, and urged would-be travelers to exercise a high degree of caution.

As of late Sunday, the number of suspected swine flu cases in Mexico had climbed to 1,614, including as many as 103 deaths, according to Mexican Health Secretary Jose Angel Cordova. The United States has confirmed at least 11 cases of swine flu, and Canada six cases.

The Mexican City government has ordered suspension of all public activities and closure of all libraries, museums, theaters and other public places. It has also closed schools of all levels until May 6.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hijacked Taiwanese fishing boat still near Gulf of Aden: owner

TEXT.P: The GPS signal from a hijacked Taiwan fishing vessel indicates that it is still anchored in waters near the Gulf of Aden off the coast of Somalia, the boat's owner said Monday.
Hsieh Lung-feng also said that he has yet to receive any demands for ransom, and that he thinks the ship and its crew members are safe.

The 700-ton long-line fishing ship "Win Far 161" was hijacked near an island in the Seychelles in the Indian Ocean April 6. Among its 30 crew members, the ship's skipper and first engineer are Taiwanese nationals, while five others are Chinese, 17 are Filipinos and six are Indonesian.

"Efforts to obtain the release (of the boat and crew) are still in progress," Hsieh said, adding that he hopes to establish the identity of the pirates and find ways to open a negotiation channel with them.

DOC.HEADLINE: Epidemic prevention drive activated over swine flu scare (roundup)

TEXT.P: Taiwan stepped up its epidemic prevention efforts Monday amid reports of a further spread of human infections of swine flu globally.

An outbreak of human infections of swine flu was first reported in Mexico March 18 and the number of related deaths has exceeded 100 so far. Several confirmed cases were also reported in the southwestern part of the United States and Canada. Suspected cases were reported in Brazil, Spain and the Philippines.
World Health Organization (WHO) officials have warned that there is a potential for the new H1N1 swine virus to become a global pandemic.

No cases of the disease have been reported in Taiwan, but the government is on heightened alert, with the Executive Yuan calling a supraministerial meeting Monday morning to coordinate preventive measures in hopes of averting any possible outbreak of human infections of the new swine flu strain.

Addressing the meeting, Vice Premiser Chiu Cheng-hsiung directed the Ministry of the Interior and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications to tighten fever screening at airports and harbors to ward off entry of the virus from abroad.

The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health (DOH) later listed human infections of swine flu as a level-one notifiable disease in line with the WHO's definition of the new swine flu strain.
From now on, DOH Minister Yeh Ching-chuan said, medical institutions are obligated to report suspected swine flu cases to facilitate tracking and prevention of an epidemic.
Meanwhile, Premier Liu Chao-hsiuan will make an inspection tour of Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport to see for himself epidemic preventive measures there.

In the meantime, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs raised th level of its travel alert for Mexico City to the second-highest orange level Monday, urging prospective travelers to defer their travel plans for the time being in light of the wine flu outbreak there.
Economics officials prdicted that the new swine flu outbreak could delay a global economic recovery and add uncertainty if the outbreak became serious in the United States.
As Taipei will sponsor the 2009 Deaflympics in September, city councilors have urged the city government to take precautionary measures to cope with the situation.
Nevertheless, DOH Minister Yeh said local people need not overreact to the swine flu scare because no suspected cases of swine flu or human infections of the virus have ever been reported in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 27, or the third day of the fourth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1521: Portuguese navigator Ferdinand Magellan is killed by the inhabitants on the island of Mactan in the Philippines.
1791: American painter and inventor Samuel F.B. Morse is born. A portraitist whose subjects included Lafayette, he refined and patented the telegraph and developed the telegraphic code that bears his name.
1822: Ulysses S. Grant, the 18th president of the United States, is born. After his victorious Vicksburg campaign, he was made commander in chief of the Union Army and accepted the surrender of Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee at Appomattox in 1865, thus ending the Civil War.
1882: Ralph Waldo Emerson, the American essayist, philosopher, and a central figure of American transcendentalism, dies at the age of 78. His poems, orations and essays are regarded as landmarks in the development of American thought and literary expression.
1887: The world's first surgical removal of an appendix, an operation known as an appendectomy, is performed by American surgeon Dr. Thomas Morton in Philadelphia.
1911: An uprising in Canton, China, is foiled when revolutionaries led by Huang Shing are defeated by the local garrison. The battle in Canton is the 10th uprising directed by Dr. Sun Yat-sen after he launched a revolutionary movement against the Ching court in the late 19th century.
1937: The new Golden Gate suspension bridge linking the city of San Francisco with Marin County reaches completion after four years.
1945: The Allies reject peace offers by German S.S. chief Heinrich Himmler, insisting on unconditional German surrender.
1949: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek arrives in Shanghai and reiterates his determination to suppress the communist rebellion.
1950: The British government officially recognizes the state of Israel.
1956: Rocco Marciano, known as "Rocky," the American boxer who won the world heavyweight championship in 1952 and defended it six times, retires as undefeated world heavyweight boxing champion.
1959: Liu Shao-chi is elected "state chairman" of Communist China.
1960: The ROC establishes diplomatic relations with the Republic of Togo.
1960: Syngman Rhee resigns as president of South Korea, ending his 12-year rule.
1962: Hsieh Chin wins the "best director" award in the first film festival to be held in mainland China.
1972: After a journey to the moon, U.S. Apollo 16 spacecraft carrying three astronauts makes a safe landing in the Pacific Ocean.
1972: Kwame Nkrumah, the Ghanaian president who was deposed in 1966 by a military coup while he was in mainland China, dies in Bucharest, Hungary.
1973: Jordanian Ambassador to the ROC Mutasim Bileisi returns to Amman after a two-year tour of duty in Taipei.
1974: The Academia Sinica Advisory Council votes on a list of candidates for academicians.
1974: The Taiwan Railway Administration and General Electric of the United States sign a contract for the electrification of Taiwan's western trunk line railway. GE will provide 74 locomotives and heavy trucks for the project.
1978: President Mohammed Daoud is killed in a bloody coup and replaced by Afghanistan's first communist ruler, Nur Mohammed Taraki, who proclaims the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan.
1992: The International Monetary Fund and World Bank approve the membership of Russia and 12 other former Soviet republics.
1993: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the ROC Straits Exchange Foundation, and Wang Daohan, chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, meet in Singapore in what is the first official contact between Taipei and Beijing since 1949.
1997: The world's longest road-rail suspension bridge, linking Hong Kong to its new offshore airport, is formally opened.
1998: Nguyen Van Linh, former general secretary of the Vietnam Communist Party, dies.
1999: Verka Modanu, the Republic of Macedonia's first resident envoy to the Republic of China, arrives in Taipei to assume her post.
2000: President-elect Chen Shui-bian says that only mutual trust can bring real peace to the people of both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
2001: The first-ever civic group to promote private exchanges between Taiwan- controlled offshore island of Kinmen and mainland China' Xiamen is formally established following the implementation of the "mini three links" with mainland China at the beginning of the year.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When you meet the proper person to speak to and do not speak out, you lose your opportunity; but when you meet one who is not a proper person to speak to and you speak to him, you waste your words. A man of intelligence never loses his opportunity, neither does he waste his words."

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese tourist injured in crane accident dies

TEXT.P: A Chinese tourist, who was hit by a falling crane boom as his group's tour bus was driving in a bustling Taipei commercial district last week, died Monday at Taipei Medical University Hospital, according to hospital sources.
The 63-year-old Zhang Shiguang had been on extracorporeal membrane oxygenation and hemodialysis machines since being rushed to the hospital after the accident occurred Friday.
Taipei Medical University Hospital plans to hold a press conference later Monday to discuss Zhang's death.

Zhang and 24 other visitors from Guangdong, China were traveling on a tour bus in the upscale Xinyi shopping district in Taipei Friday around 2 p.m. when a lattice boom from a crane fell 31 stories from a building under construction and smashed through the back quarter of the roof of the bus.
One of the passengers was killed on the spot and another died on the way to the hospital, and several others were injured.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China expected to ink financial supervisory MOU in 60 days

TEXT.P: Taiwan hopes to sign a memorandum of understanding (MOU) on financial supervisory cooperation with China in 60 days, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Fu Dong-cheng said in Nanjing Sunday.

"An MOU can further facilitate the implementation of the content of the agreement on financial cooperation that Taiwan and China signed today, " Fu said after Taiwan and China signed three pacts and one joint statement in the central Chinese city Sunday.

In the deal on financial cooperation, Taiwan and China agreed to cooperate on financial institution supervision and currency management, set up a cross- strait currency clearance and settlement mechanism, permit commercial banks to exchange currency and work together on developing technologies to spot counterfeit notes, and allow financial institutions to establish branches in each other's market.

"It is hoped that the MOU and the cross-strait financial cooperaton pact will take effect simultaneously, " said Fu, who was one of 22 Taiwan officials taking part in the third round of cross-strait talks.

Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , and Chen Yunlin, president of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, signed the documents on behalf of Taiwan and China, respectively.
Fu said local banks are allowed to exchange, supply, and recirculate the Chinese currency but are not allowed to have banking links with Chinese counterparts.

But with increased bilateral trade between Taiwan and China spurring a growing flow of money across the Taiwan Strait, Fu hoped a comprehensive currency clearance and settlement mechanism would be negotiated.
He said the plan at present is to designate one or two banks from either side as currency and settlement banks.

Meanwhile, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs John Deng said Monday he welcomed the joint statement on investment made at the talks in Nanjing, saying that increased Chinese investment in Taiwan will help facilitate Taiwan's liberalization policy toward China.
"Once the policy is put into practice, representatives from Chinese business sectors will visit Taiwan to understand the local investment climate," Deng said.
The administration can exchange views with the Chinese business leaders at that time and gather their opinions as a reference in adjusting Taiwan's investment policies, he added.
China agreed to support private investment in Taiwan, and encouraged eligible Chinese enterprises to make fact-finding tours of Taiwan to explore investment opportunities there.

DOC.HEADLINE: Youth encouraged to take in-depth journey in learning about Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level National Youth Commission (NYC) , in collaboration with local nonprofit organizations, launched a program Monday to encourage people aged 15-30 to take an educational journey around Taiwan and explore their roots.

"Given that many young people in Taiwan do not have in-depth knowledge about the country, we hope this program will provide them a whole new way of exploring Taiwan," said NYC minister Wang Yu-ting at a news conference to promote the "Youth Travel Spots in Taiwan -- Grand Tour" program.
The program also aims at boosting the competitiveness of people in the age group because they can learn as much from society as in the classroom, Wang said.
"The youngsters should begin their grand tour of life by learning about their homeland before heading to other parts of the world," she said.

The Grand Tour program, which lists 29 destinations in Taiwan that one must visit before the age of 30, covers activities exposing travelers to local eco- systems, indigenous cultures, humanitarian care and artistic events.

Lahuy Icyeh, a member of the Atayal tribe who just finished his post-graduate studies, said at the news conference that in his trip to Smangus Village in Hsinchu County, he not only immersed himself in the beauty of nature but also learned about the spirit of sharing in indigenous cultures.
"Learning about multiple cultures is a mandatory course that everyone must take," he said.

Chang Hsin-wen, who joined an aboriginal hunter school and took a 20-kilometer journey in Yilan County's Hapen forest, said that the journey taught her about respecting all living creatures and the concept of sustainability.

According to the NYC, the first group of participants in the program will receive a10 percent discount. They can also submit their travel journals and pictures to http: //youthtravel.tw/grandtour by Aug. 31 as part of a competition.
Underprivileged and low-income people in the 15-30 age bracket can receive as much as NT$30,000 (US$889) in subsidies by participating in programs that work with local charities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Father who dumped girl into hot water indicted on homicide charges

TEXT.P: The man who threw his 10-month-old baby girl into boiling water April 18 was indicted Monday on murder charges, with Changhua prosecutors recommending he be sentenced to life imprisonment.

If convicted, the 47-year-old man surnamed Huang could spend the rest of his life in jail and have his political rights severed for his action, which shook up Taiwanese society for its sheer cruelty and raised concerns over increasing violence against children.

The girl, who suffered second and third-degree burns over 84 percent of her body, was pronounced dead after doctors, with the consent of her mother, took her off a life-support system at 10: 05 a.m.. last Tuesday, according to Changhua Christian Hospital in central Taiwan's Changhua City.

Huang has been detained by the Changhua District Prosecutors Office since April 18, when the incident occurred. During a fierce argument between the couple, prompted when the girl's mother criticized Huang for being lazy, the mother dared Huang to throw the girl into a pot of boiling water, and he complied.

The infant's mother, identified only by her family name of Lin, immediately got the baby out of the pot in the noodle shop they owned and rushed the girl to a nearby police station for help. The police immediately transferred the baby to the hospital's burn center.

The couple, who were not married but had lived together for 12 years, also have an older daughter, who is in the fifth grade. County social welfare officials placed the fifth grader with a foster family following the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: Flights between Taipei, Shanghai city airports to be discussed

TEXT.P: The opening of direct charter flights between Taipei's Songshan Airport and Shanghai's Hongqiao Airport will be discussed in the next round of cross-Taiwan Strait aviation negotiations, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said Monday.

Potential travelers were disappointed that Songshan Airport was only allocated 21 direct cross-strait flights a week in an agreement reached at the latest round of negotiations between Taiwan and China in Nanjing Sunday, even though the number of direct flights was increased from 108 to 270 per week.

Songshan Airport, in the northeastern part of Taipei, served as the country's international airport until 1979. It has exclusively handled domestic flights since then but was opened to direct charter flights from China last year when air links between the two countries were liberalized.

Located a short drive away from most of Taipei's commercial centers, compared to the 50-minute drive between the city and Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, the airport is favored by business travelers for its convenience.

Explaining the small number of flights to and from China allocated to the airport, CAA officials said they wanted to reserve the airport's capacity for potential flights from other city airports in Asia, such as Shanghai's Hongqiao Airport, Tokyo's Haneda International Airport and Seoul's Kimpo Internatinal Airport.
Songshan Airport was also not included in the agreement among airports allowed to handle regularly scheduled flights.

CAA officials said Songshan Airport is only allowed to operate direct cross- strait charter flights because regular scheduled flights can transport cargo, but Songshan Airport's facilities are not capable of handling cargo at present.

Aside from increasing flight numbers, the avaiation agreement -- one of the three agreements and one joint statement concluded by Taiwan and China to further strengthen bilateral cooperation -- established regularly scheduled flights and opened six more Chinese destinations, bringing the total to 27.
The number of cargo flights, which now stands at 30 per month, will be increased to 112.

Taiwan had proposed that the number of flights be increased to 300 per week because the load factor of the charter flights had increased from 70.3 percent when they were launched on Dec. 15, 2008 to 90.6 percent early this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese fugitives in China may be repatriated under new pact

TEXT.P: A new pact signed between Taiwan and China Sunday on mutual judicial assistance paves the way for the extradition of at least 84 Taiwanese fugitives hiding in China, according to information provided by the Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of Justice.

Under the agreement -- one of three signed in the Chinese city of Nanjing between Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and his counterpart Chen Yunlin, president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits -- the two sides will assist each other on judicial matters and cooperate in fighting crime.
The two sides will establish a platform to exchange crime-related information and help with the repatriation of wanted criminals.
According to the Investigation Bureau, many of Taiwan's most wanted fugitives have fled to China. Its files show that at least 84 convicted criminals may be hiding there.
The most prominent among these criminals include:
--Former Legislative Yuan Speaker Liu Sung-pan, who was sentenced to four years in prison and fined NT$30 million in September 2004 for breach of trust.

He was found guilty of using his status as the former chairman of Taichung Business Bank in 1998 to broker an illegal NT$1.5 billion (US$44.22 million) loan to the Kuangsan Group in exchange for an NT$150 million bribe.
--Tycoon Tseng Cheng-jen, who fled to China in June 2004 a week after he was sentenced to 11 years in prison in the same illegal loan case that implicated Liu.

--Chen Yu-hao, former head of the Tuntex Group, wanted for questioning on charges that he stole NT$800 million from a group subsidiary in 1995 to invest in his own name in China. He and his wife fled Taiwan in 2002 and are believed to be living in China.
--Former Kaohsiung Mayor Wang Yu-yun, indicted in June 2000 for an illegal NT$8 billion bank loan involving Chung Shing Bank.
He was prohibited from leaving the country in 2002 but managed to flee to China. He is believed to be hiding in Hangzhou, Zhejiang province. In April 2007, he was sentenced to seven years in prison.
--Former Legislator Wang Chih-hsiung, son of Wang Yu-yun, who is also wanted in a bad loan case that resulted in NT$9.7 billion in nonperforming loans at Chung Shing Bank.

--Former Kaohsiung City Council Speaker Chu An-hsiung, who fled to China after being sentenced to seven years in prison for embezzling NT$21.7 billion from a metal company and for vote buying in September 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese firms to be allowed to register businesses in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Chinese companies will soon be allowed to apply to register businesses in Taiwan, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs John Deng said Monday.

Speaking at the Legislative Yuan Economics Committee, Deng said that a bill governing Chinese businesses establishing affiliates or branches in Taiwan has been drafted by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and submitted to the Executive Yuan for approval.

"Several rounds of inter-division meetings have been convened on the matter and the regulations are expected to be formally publicized by the administration for implementation as soon as final procedures are completed," Deng told lawmakers.
Deng was responding to a question raised by ruling Kuomintang Legislator Ting Shou-chung concerning Taiwan's plans to open the country to Chinese capital and investment.
Ting criticized the government for planning to allow Chinese citizens to invest but not having come up with regulations to govern Chinese people establishing businesses in Taiwan.
"How can Chinese capital enter Taiwan if Chinese citizens are not even allowed to establish a company here in the first place? " Ting questioned.

Ting said China Eastern Airlines had planned to lease a Cathay Life building to be used as its Taiwan headquarters, but the plan was aborted because the two companies could not find any domestic legal basis to use in finalizing the transaction.
Ting said the failed deal cost Taiwan 40 to 50 jobs and attributed it to the negligence of relevant administrative agencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Majority support tourism development: government

TEXT.P: A great majority of the public support plans by the government to develop Taiwan's tourism and make the country one of the key destinations for tourism in Asia, a government agency said Monday.

In a recent survey conducted by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) , 78 percent of the respondents said they support the administration's plans to make tourism development one of the top goals with regard to Taiwan's overall development, the DGBAS said.

Seventy-two percent of the respondents said they support the government's plans to investment NT$30 billion (US$890 million) over the next four years to develop Taiwan into a key Asian tourism destination.

The poll, conducted April 21-22, found that 81 percent of the respondents agreed that an online national tourism services network should be set up by the government and that the administration should help local governments to plan tourism routes and provide tourism information, DGBAS officials said.
Meanwhile, 78 percent of the respondents said tourist attractions around the country should be redesignated and overhauled, they noted.
The poll of 969 adults selected randomly nationwide had a margin of error of 3.15 percentage points, DGBAS said.

DOC.HEADLINE: No human infections of swine flu in Taiwan: health minister

TEXT.P: Health Minister Yeh Ching-chuan urged the public Monday to remain calm despite outbreaks of human infections of swine flu in Mexico and the United States, saying that so far, no-one in Taiwan is known to be infected and that the Department of Health (DOH) is watching developments closely.

The DOH also declared the viruses characterized in the swine flu outbreak as new subtypes of the H1N1 virus, a level-one legal infectious disease that requires immediate reporting by hospitals when they encounter such cases, according to Yeh.

His remarks were quoted by Government Information Office Minister Su Jun-bin after attending an inter-government agency meeting hosted by Vice Premier Chiu Cheng-hsiung on coordinating information and preventive measures against the threat of swine flu.
"So far there have been no human infections in Taiwan. People should not panic about the outbreak but should stay alert," Yeh said.

He added that under the framework of the International Health Regulations, to which Taiwan gained entry in early April, the DOH is maintaining close contact with the World Health Organization (WHO) to obtain updates on the spread and control of swine flu.
The DOH will take countermeasures in accordance with the WHO after as soon as it updates the latest situation, expected the following day, Yeh said.
A day earlier, the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the DOH raised a travel advisory for Mexico to a "regional pandemic" alert against swine flu.
CDC officials said Taiwanese travelers should take strong precautionary measures against swine flu before and after visits to Mexico.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) also issued a yellow travel alert for Mexico that same day, the third-highest travel advisory that warns travelers to exercise caution.

"The Foreign Ministry is collecting relevant information and watching closely the development of the swine flu outbreaks in Mexico. Necessary measures will be taken after the WHO meeting scheduled for tomorrow," MOFA spokesman Henry Chen told CNA.

As to concerns about eating pork, Lee Chao-chuan, head of the Tainan City Animal Health Inspection Institute, said there is no safety concern, as long as the pork is properly cooked at over 70 degrees Celsius.

Given that there have been no swine flu cases reported in Taiwan, Lee said the first and most important step is to contain the disease abroad. All pig farms should boost quarantine measures, including disinfection and personnel controls, he added.

The outbraeks of swine flu in Mexico have spread to other parts of the world, raising concerns that it could turn into a global pandemic. The U.S. has declared a "public health emergency" with 20 confirmed cases, while Mexico has more than 100 deaths and 1,600 illnesses attributed to the virus.
Canada and New Zealand have also reported human infections while suspected cases have been identified in Israel, Spain and the United Kingdom.
The WHO has declared the flu a "public health emergency of international concern."

DOC.HEADLINE: History museum to launch exhibition on Taiwan's coffee culture

TEXT.P: The National Museum of History said in a newsletter released Monday that it is scheduled to launch an exhibition in May on Taiwan's coffee culture, which took root during the 1896-1945 Japanese colonial period.

"The aim of this exhibition is to reconstruct this unique aspect of Taiwan's cultural space and to present the influences and underlying meanings of coffee houses in the early years of Japanese rule," the newsletter said.

Although the coffee house is mainly considered to be a product of Western culture, the formation of Taiwan's coffee culture is closely connected to Japan. In the early years of Japanese rule, coffee houses in Taiwan were mostly run by Japanese people and were mostly located in an area of Taipei known at the time as the Sakaemachi, around what is known today as Heng Yang Road, according to the National Museum of History.

Later, when local students would return to Taiwan after studying overseas, bringing with them their greater understanding of Western culture, Taiwanese people began to run coffee houses on their own, including names that became famous, such as Werther, Tianma Teahouse and Bolero, it added.

"Despite being called coffee houses, they were in fact more like restaurants and cabarets -- places catering to Western forms of recreation," the museum said, adding that it will also introduce the coffee growing area of Gukeng township in Central Taiwan's Yunlin County.
The exhibition, titled "Early Taiwanese Coffee Culture," will run May 27- June 14 from 10 a.m-6 p.m. every day except Monday.
Other museum draws to open in May will include an exhibition on the transition of Buddhist statuary featuring gold and bronze statuettes and an exhibition of ancient Chinese jade, the museum added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Swine flu could cause severe epidemic: expert

TEXT.P: Should the swine influenza outbreak in Mexico spread around the world, it could cause much more significant harm to human society than avian flu ever could, a Taiwanese stock disease expert warned Monday.

In response to media inquiries over recent outbreaks of swine flu in the United States and Mexico, Lai Shiow-suey, a former veterinary medicine professor at National Taiwan University, expressed concern about the recombination of different strains of flu virus in pigs.
Describing a pig's body as a big factory, Lai stated that if three different virus strains recombine with each other in pigs, they will transform into a new, more virulent strain.

Lai said that since pigs share similar physical functions and heredity with humans, they can easily pass on the new strain of flu virus to humans, from which the virus can be further spread through human-to-human transmission.

"It is dreadful; it seems the worst senario has happened, " he said, referring to the recent swine flu outbreaks in Mexico where over 100 people are believed to have died and more than 1,600 have been sickened by the virus, a recombinant of the H1N1 flu strain.

Lai recalled an earlier outbreak of H1N1 swine flu reported in the U.S. state of New Jersey in 1976 that infected 230 new military recruits, killing one of them. That outbreak prompted the U.S. government to administer vaccinations, but the outbreak still lasted for more than two months, he said.
The latest outbreak in Mexico will likely cause greater harm than the one in 1976 because "the strain of virus is much more vicious, " Lai said.
He warned people who have recently returned from the United States and Mexico to stay away from pig farms, and that people in the hog-raising industry should be on their guard against an outbreak.

Taiwan's public health authorities heightened preventive measures against the threat of swine flu Sunday, with the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) raising its travel advisory for Mexico to the level of a"regional pandemic" alert against the flu.
Symptoms of the disease include fever, aches, coughing, sore throat, respiratory congestion and in some cases vomiting and diarrhea.

According to foreign wire services, the virus is usually contracted through direct contact with pigs, but Joseph Domenech, chief of animal health services at the U.N. Food and Agriculture Agency in Rome, said all indications so far are that the virus is being spread through human-to-human transmission.
There is no vaccine that protects specifically against swine flu and it is unclear how much protection the current human flu vaccines can offer.
