A total of US$741 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.711 and fluctuated between NT$33.631 and NT$33.749.

DOC.HEADLINE: 36 percent of Taiwan jobless interested in entrepreneurship: poll

TEXT.P: Thirty-six percent of Taiwan's unemployed want to start up their own businesses as a way out of their financial problems, according to the results of a recent survey released Monday by a government-run online employment service network.
With an unprecedentedly high unemployment rate of 5.81 percent, over 630,000 people in Taiwan became jobless in March.

According to the ejob.gov.tw Web site run by the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) , of those unemployed who are interested in entrepreneurship, 17.47 percent said they want to start a business of their own because they want to be their own boss.

In addition to being unemployed or facing a bad employment situation, other reasons that were cited by the potential entrepreneurs include attempting to realize his or her dreams (16.3 percent), the belief that running his or her own business would make more money (10.13 percent) , desire to live the life they want (8.66 percent) and putting his or her ability into full play (7.34 percent), the poll found.

Of the potential entrepreneurs, 5.73 percent said they are positive they want to start a business this year, 14.68 percent said they have strong desire to start a business and have started planning, while 73.27 percent said they are interested in entrepreneurship as a way out but are still just mulling the idea, according to the poll.
A total of 74.45 percent of the potential entrepreneurs said they would prefer to start a business of their own rather than buy a franchise.

Of the potential entrepreneurs, 46.69 percent said they would be prepared to spend less than NT$100,000 (US$2,967) to start their businesses, while 79.28 percent said their startup funds would be controlled within NT$500,000, the survey found.
Ejob.gov.tw conducted the survey between Feb. 13 and April 27 and obtained 681 valid responses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's share prices drop sharply

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices plunged 2.98 percent Monday, as the talks between Taiwan and China the previous day had been factored into the market.
The weighted index, the market's key barometer, lost 175.72 points to close at 5,705.05.
The local bourse opened at 5,931.87 and dropped to a low of 5,672.25 early in the session before rebounding to the day's high 5,946.97.
A total of 6.31 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$136.8 billion (US$4.06 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares dropping the most at 5.3 percent. Paper and pulp stocks lost 4.5 percent, construction shares dropped 4.4 percent, foodstuff shares fell 3.2 percent, machinery and electronics shares shed 2.6 percent, cement issues slid 2.3 percent, plastics and chemicals stocks lost 2.0 percent, and textile issues dropped 1.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,850 to 419, with 64 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$5.34 billion.

Biotech stocks clearly outperformed the overall market on hopes of an increasing demand for flu drugs in the wake of the outbreak of swine flu in Mexico, the United States and elsewhere, analysts said.

Tourism shares and financial and banking stocks slid sharply after President Ma Ying-jeou instructed the Ministry of Transport and Communications to take action to control the number of Chinese tourists visiting Taiwan, and as there was no additional positive news from the third round cross-Taiwan Strait talks to bolster those sectors, according to the analysts.
There is little chance of the market rising further, and it is likely to hit 5,500-point level if it falls below 5,646 Tuesday, the analysts added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung prosecutors help poor students with public funds

TEXT.P: The Taichung District Prosecutors Office donated NT$7.5 million (US$221,890) of public funds Monday to the Taichung City government to provide meals for impoverished students during the summer vacation period.

Taichung Mayor Jason Hu thanked the prosecutors for their generosity and strong support for his proposal that the office use the funds -- recovered from petty offenders in return for deferred prosecution -- to help the cash-strapped city government launch the program.
According to Hu, the city government plans to use the money to issue lunch vouchers to students from the city's impoverished families during the coming summer vacation.
It will be the second program of its kind carried out by the city following initial success with a similar program implemented over the last winter vacation, Hu noted.

Prosecutor Chang Dou-hui said that under the instruction of the Ministry of Justice, the Taichung District Prosecutors Office has made cash donations of the public funds to some 40 welfare groups in the Taichung area and he voiced hope that more enterprises and groups will collaborate with the city government in efforts to aid students in need.

The city's education department estimated that there are about 7,000 needy elementary and junior high students in the city, and said it plans to distribute about 408,000 lunch vouchers during the summer vacation.

In a similar move, the Chiayi District Prosecutors Office in southern Taiwan had as of April 16 granted scholarships to 150 local students from the area from the beginning of the year using money collected in the same way.
The scholarships ranged from NT$2,000 (US$60) for each junior high school student to NT$1,000 for each elementary school student per semester.

The Chiayi Prosecutors Office has NT$10 million (US$298,000) at its disposal this year raised from deferred prosecution payments, a spokesman for the office said in early January when the office sponsored an activity to help impoverished families celebrate the Lunar New Year.
The Chiayi Prosecutors Office has been funding local charitable groups to help them pay for social services for local residents since 2006, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutor detained for second time on suspicion of bribery

TEXT.P: A public prosecutor in Taitung, southeastern Taiwan, who was released on bail five days ago pending further investigation into his alleged acceptance of bribes, was detained again Tuesday.

The Taitung Public Prosecutors' Office took Lin Sheng-lin into custody Sunday night for questioning on the strength of new evidence implicating him in a second bribery case and sought permission from the Taitung District Court again to keep him in custody.

The court granted the permission Monday after reviewing the arguments submitted by the prosecutors' office that Lin tried to contact witnesses and defendants in the bribery cases, through his father, in an apparent attempt to collude with them.

On April 22, Lin was released on bail of NT$500,000 (US$14,760) after being taken into custody a day earlier to answer charges that he had accepted bribes from suspects who should have been indicted in criminal cases that he handled. At the time, the court ruled that there was no need to keep Lin in detention, even though he could face at least five years in prison if convicted.

On that day, the court also set bail at NT$200,000 for Wu Dong-sheng, a broker whom prosecutors said assisted Lin in obtaining bribes. The court ruled that both Lin and Wu are not allowed to leave the country.

According to the Taitung Public Prosecutors' Office, Lin was reassigned from the Shihlin Public Prosecutors' Office in Taipei to work in Taitung in August last year because he left too many criminal cases unhandled.

Ethics officers at the Taitung prosecutors' office placed Lin under surveillance after noting that he continued to allow the accumulation of many cases, and that he had dismissed quite a few cases that he should have prosecuted.
Further investigation led to the admission by several suspects in at least two criminal cases that Lin had offered not to indict them in return for bribes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan elevates travel alert for Mexico City over swine flu scare

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) raised the level of its travel alert for Mexico City to orange Monday, urging prospective travelers to defer their plans for the time being in light of an outbreak of human infections of swine flu there.
The ministry had originally issued a yellow travel alert for Mexico, the lowest level advisory that warns travelers to exercise caution.

However, the MOFA decided to raise the alert for Mexico's capital to orange, the second-highest level, in view of the latest reports that the swine flu outbreak is most serious in Mexico City and has spread to other parts of the world, MOFA officials said.
Moreover, they added, World Health Organizations (WHO) officials have warned that there is a potential for the new swine flu virus to become a global pandemic.
On the ministry's three-color travel advisory scale, an orange alert suggests that would-be travelers should suspend their travel plans over safety or health concerns.
According to MOFA statistics, an average of 3,000 to 4,000 Taiwanese citizens apply for visas to Mexico annually, most of whom intend to travel to Mexico City for business or sightseeing purposes.

In support of the ongoing global campaign to contain the spread of the new H1N1 swine flu virus and out of local health concerns, residents of Taiwan are advised to refrain from traveling to Mexico City for the time being, the officials warned.
Meanwhile, they said the MOFA will maintain its yellow alert for other areas and cities of Mexico, and urged would-be travelers to exercise a high degree of caution.

As of late Sunday, the number of suspected swine flu cases in Mexico had climbed to 1,614, including as many as 103 deaths, according to Mexican Health Secretary Jose Angel Cordova. The United States has confirmed at least 11 cases of swine flu, and Canada six cases.

The Mexican City government has ordered suspension of all public activities and closure of all libraries, museums, theaters and other public places. It has also closed schools of all levels until May 6.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hijacked Taiwanese fishing boat still near Gulf of Aden: owner

TEXT.P: The GPS signal from a hijacked Taiwan fishing vessel indicates that it is still anchored in waters near the Gulf of Aden off the coast of Somalia, the boat's owner said Monday.
Hsieh Lung-feng also said that he has yet to receive any demands for ransom, and that he thinks the ship and its crew members are safe.

The 700-ton long-line fishing ship "Win Far 161" was hijacked near an island in the Seychelles in the Indian Ocean April 6. Among its 30 crew members, the ship's skipper and first engineer are Taiwanese nationals, while five others are Chinese, 17 are Filipinos and six are Indonesian.

"Efforts to obtain the release (of the boat and crew) are still in progress," Hsieh said, adding that he hopes to establish the identity of the pirates and find ways to open a negotiation channel with them.

DOC.HEADLINE: Epidemic prevention drive activated over swine flu scare (roundup)

TEXT.P: Taiwan stepped up its epidemic prevention efforts Monday amid reports of a further spread of human infections of swine flu globally.

An outbreak of human infections of swine flu was first reported in Mexico March 18 and the number of related deaths has exceeded 100 so far. Several confirmed cases were also reported in the southwestern part of the United States and Canada. Suspected cases were reported in Brazil, Spain and the Philippines.
World Health Organization (WHO) officials have warned that there is a potential for the new H1N1 swine virus to become a global pandemic.

No cases of the disease have been reported in Taiwan, but the government is on heightened alert, with the Executive Yuan calling a supraministerial meeting Monday morning to coordinate preventive measures in hopes of averting any possible outbreak of human infections of the new swine flu strain.

Addressing the meeting, Vice Premiser Chiu Cheng-hsiung directed the Ministry of the Interior and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications to tighten fever screening at airports and harbors to ward off entry of the virus from abroad.

The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health (DOH) later listed human infections of swine flu as a level-one notifiable disease in line with the WHO's definition of the new swine flu strain.
From now on, DOH Minister Yeh Ching-chuan said, medical institutions are obligated to report suspected swine flu cases to facilitate tracking and prevention of an epidemic.
Meanwhile, Premier Liu Chao-hsiuan will make an inspection tour of Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport to see for himself epidemic preventive measures there.

In the meantime, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs raised th level of its travel alert for Mexico City to the second-highest orange level Monday, urging prospective travelers to defer their travel plans for the time being in light of the wine flu outbreak there.
Economics officials prdicted that the new swine flu outbreak could delay a global economic recovery and add uncertainty if the outbreak became serious in the United States.
As Taipei will sponsor the 2009 Deaflympics in September, city councilors have urged the city government to take precautionary measures to cope with the situation.
Nevertheless, DOH Minister Yeh said local people need not overreact to the swine flu scare because no suspected cases of swine flu or human infections of the virus have ever been reported in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, May 28, or the fourth day of the fourth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1738: French physician and revolutionary Joseph Ignace Guillotin is born. He developed the execution device which was so heavily used during the "reign of terror" in the French revolution that it would later bear his name.
1754: George Washington, then in the service of the British Crown, destroys a French regiment under Jumonville near Uniontown, Penn., in the first battle of the French-Indian Wars.
1759: English statesman William Pitt the Younger is born. He became prime minister at the age of 24, the youngest-ever British prime minister.
1912: Patrick White, the Australian novelist who won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1973, is born.
1934: Cecilie, Emilie, Marie, Annette and Yvonne Dionne are born to Olivia Dionne in Callender, Canada. They are the world's first surviving quintuplets.
1932: Dutch engineers complete the world's biggest dam, a major victory in their 900-year battle to push back the sea. The new dam, or dike, is 29 km long and turns the Zuider Zee into a vast freshwater lake, called the Ijsselmeer.
1933: Chinese Gen. Feng Yu-hsiang revolts at Kalgan Pass, near Changkiakow, capital of China's Chahar Province.
1956: Republic of China Foreign Minister George K.C. Yeh informs Philippine Ambassador Narciso Ramos that the ROC has full sovereignty over the Nansha, or Spratly Islands.
1959: The United States launches its Jupiter rocket into space with two monkeys aboard. The monkeys return to earth safely, opening the way for manned space flight.
1966: Construction of Taiwan's Northern Cross-Island Highway is completed. An inauguration ceremony is held at Tahsi, Taoyuan County.
1966: The Cultural Revolution begins in mainland China after the central committee of the Chinese Communist Party sets up a "central cultural revolution group" to lead the movement.
1967: Francis Chichester, a 65-year-old British yachtsman, receives a hero's welcome when he arrives in Plymouth 119 days after setting out on a solo round- the-world trip.
1972: The Duke of Windsor, the British king who abdicated to marry American divorcee Wallis Simpson, dies in Paris at the age of 77.
1974: The Pacific-Asian Congress of Municipalities opens its third conference in Taipei.
1978: Chiang Ching-kuo, who was sworn in as the 6th president of the ROC on May 20, tells Reader's Digest that "our interests and those of America cannot be divided. If we stick together, both will benefit. If we go our separate ways, both will suffer. In any case, the Republic of China will persist."
1981: The ROC Executive Yuan approves Premier Sun Yun-suan's appointment of Konsin Shah as ambassador to the Republic of Uruguay and Loh I-cheng as ambassador to the Republic of Guatemala.
1982: Pope John Paul II arrives in Britain for the first papal visit to Britain since 1531.
1985: President Luis Alberto Monge Alvarez of the Republic of Costa Rica arrives in Taipei for a visit.
1986: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs protests an Argentine gunboat attack on an unarmed ROC trawler in the seas off the Falkland Islands that left one dead, one missing, and six injured.
1987: Mathias Rust, a West German teenager, flies his Cessna light plane from Helsinki to Moscow and lands in Red Square, evading the entire Soviet air defense system. Both the Soviet defense minister and the air defense commander were sacked as a result of the prank.
1989: The Ching Kuo, the first ROC-developed and manufactured indigenous defense fighter, successfully completes its first test flight.
1995: A strong earthquake rocks the Russian Far East oil-producing town of Neftegorsk on Sakhalin Island, killing more than 1,980 people.
1996: The ROC exchanges economic and trade representative offices with the Republic of Belarus. Belarus is the second (Russia being the first) member of the Commonwealth of Independent States to establish such a level of relations with the ROC.
1998: Pakistan conducts five nuclear test blasts and declares a state of emergency, triggering economic sanctions by Japan and the United States.
2000: Taiwan's Tseng Hsin-feng wins Japan's three-day Kosaido Ladies' Golf Tournament in the Tokyo suburb of Ichihara.
2001: The New Taiwan dollar plunges three percent, or 1.0005 against the U.S. dollar to close at 34.5 on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange market.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Men of totally different principles can never act together."
