DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Over 160,000 people have yet to collect shopping vouchers: MOI

TEXT.P: A total of 160,841 people have yet to pick up their government-issued consumption vouchers as of Sunday, a few days before the April 30 deadline, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said Tuesday.
The MOI indicated that as of Sunday, 23,103,405 out of 23,264,246 eligible people, a 99.31 collection rate, had collected vouchers worth a total of more than NT$83.17 billion.

The ministry urged eligible people who have not collected their vouchers to do so at designated post offices, adding that those who fail to pick them up by the deadline will lose their rights to pick up the NT$3,600 in vouchers.
The MOI also advised those who do not know where their designated post office is to check related information on its voucher Web site at 3600.moi.gov.tw or to call 0800-88-3600 for information.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA issues red travel alert for Mexico on swine flu

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has issued a red travel alert for Mexico, warning local travelers not to visit the country because of the spread of the swine flu virus from Mexico to the rest of the world.

"The Foreign Ministry has decided to issue a red travel advisory for Mexico. The decision is based on only one concern -- the travel safety and health of our citizens, MOFA spokesman Henry Chen said Tuesday at a regular press briefing.
The ministry also issued a yellow travel alert for the United States and Canada, Chen added.

A red alert -- the most serious travel advisory alert -- warns travelers not to enter the area in question under any circumstances. It is followed by an orange travel alert, which advises travelers to postpone their trips, and a yellow alert, which serves as a reminder for travelers to exercise caution.
So far, no Taiwanese expatriates or businessmen in Mexico have been reported ill, and the ministry's representative office there will continue to collect relevant information, Chen said.

Meanwhile, three or four unidentified Taiwanese high school exchange students in Nova Scotia -- Canada's second smallest province located on its southeastern coast -- remained under isolation, Chen said.
The MOFA's representative office in Ottawa is trying to get more details on the situation, Chen said.

A Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) report quoted Joe Seagram, headmaster of Nova Scotia's King's-Edgehill School as saying that as of Monday there were four confirmed human swine flu cases at the school while 27 others with flu-like symptoms remained in isolation.
The outbreaks of swine flu in Mexico have spread to other parts of the world, raising concerns that it could turn into a global pandemic.
The U.S., with 47 confirmed cases, has declared apublic health emergency," while in Mexico, 149 deaths have been linked to the flu while another 2,000 people have been hospitalized.
The World Health Organization (WHO) said Canada has six confirmed human infections while Spain has one and Scotland has two.
The world health regulatory body raised its global pandemic flu alert from level 3 to level 4 Tuesday, indicating that there has been sustained human-to-human transmission of the flu.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China one step closer to normalized ties: chief negotiator
DOC.DATELINE: Yangzhou, China, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/09 13:57:46 (By Chiang Chin-yeh and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The two sides of the Taiwan Strait have moved a step closer to normalizing their trade and economic relations after reaching understandings on financial cooperation and opening Taiwan to Chinese investment, Taipei's chief negotiator with Beijing said Monday.

The achievement, together with agreements reached previously on the launch of cross-strait air, shipping and mail services, has contributed to an intial realization of "three links" -- direct transportation, trade and postal links -- between the two sides, said Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

Chiang made the remarks during a visit to Yangzhou, the second leg of his current China visit that first took him to Nanjing, where he met with his Chinese counterpart, Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin.
The two signed three agreements covering the launch of regular cross-strait passenger flights, financial cooperation, and cross-strait cooperation to fight crime.
A joint statement on a proposal to open Taiwan to Chinese investment was also released on the occasion.
Chiang pointed out that including these three agreements, the two sides have reached a total of nine agreements in 10 months.

Among the four understandings reached Sunday, the joint statement on liberalizing Taiwan-bound Chinese investment will facilitate a two-way flow of investment, reversing the current one-way movement of investment from Taiwan to China, Chiang said.

Issues to be addressed by the two sides in the future, such as investment protection, dual taxation avoidance and intellectual property right protection, are expected to help further promote direct cross-strait business links, he said.
The latest Chiang-Chen meeting was the third of its kind since the resumption of cross-strait dialogue less than one year ago following a nine-year hiatus.

It signifies the continued warming of relations between the two former rivals since the inauguration of President Ma Ying-jeou, whose administration has made it a priority to ease tensions and improve relations with China.

In their first meeting held in June 2008 in Beijing, Chiang and Chen signed agreements on the launch of weekend cross-strait passenger charter flights and the admission of larger numbers of Chinese tourists to Taiwan.

Their second meeting took place in November in Taipei, during which they signed agreements on extending charter flights from weekends to every day of the week, opening direct cross-strait shipping, postal, and air cargo charter services, and improving food safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pork prices in Taiwan not affected by swine flu outbreak

TEXT.P: Domestic pork prices have not been affected by outbreaks of the A/H1N1 swine flu in Mexico, the United States, and Canada, said a senior Council of Agriculture (COA) official said Tuesday.

Hsu Tien-lai, the head of the COA's Animal Industry Division, noted that the wholesale price for pork stood at NT$5,999 (US$176) per 100 kilograms on Monday, the same as usual, but he said he would continue to monitor the market.

Hsu said the outbreak has not affected the pork market because the new H1N1 strain has not attacked pigs. In a statement issued Monday, the World Organization for Animal Health stressed, "the virus has not been isolated in animals to date " and said that calling the disease "swine influenza" was not justified, Hsu noted.
Although the new virus contains genetic fragments of swine flu, it is regarded as a recombinant virus formed in the human body, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President touts Taoyuan Aerotropolis as key to Taiwan's future

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that building the Taoyuan Aerotropolis is an important key to Taiwan's future development and an essential element in Taiwan's efforts to become more closely connected with the international community.

"Taiwan is exceptionally blessed in terms of its location. I would even advise aliens to take hold of Taiwan if they come to Earth, " said Ma at the opening ceremony of the 2009 International Conference on Aerotropolis, hosted by Taoyuan County and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).
"It would be such a waste if we do not make good use of this advantage and develop it well.

Because Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport is at the center of every major Asian air route, it has more potential than other Asian airports to become a regional hub, Ma said, stressing that the aerotropolis development program will be vital to Taiwan's future development.
Taoyuan County magistrate Eric Liluan Chu agreed with the president that the project would be of fundamental importance to Taiwan's long-term development.
Chu acknowledged that the Taoyuan airport's passenger traffic and freight volume declined in 2008, but he stressed that the international gateway's future was still bright.

Chu cited Civil Aeronautics Administration forecasts that the airport's passenger traffic will increase from 21.9 million people in 2008 to 47.5 million people in 2035, and cargo volume will rise from 1.49 million tons in 2008 to 4.03 million tons in 2035.
Chu said Taoyuan County must seize the potential for growth and work hard in cooperation with the central government to convert the airport area into an aerotropolis.

The Taoyuan Aerotropolis project -- set to be completed in 2020 -- would involve the expansion of existing airport terminals and the establishment of an aerospace industrial park and special zones for cargo, passenger and logistics services.
It is expected to attract NT$1.2 trillion (US$35.5 billion) in investment, while generating NT$600 billion in revenues and creating more than 80,000 jobs.

The goal of the two-day conference is to give experts affiliated with the industrial sector, governments and academia the chance to share their experience and views and use the knowledge gained to ensure that the aerotropolis plan best meets Taiwan's development needs.

Some 40 experts from home and abroad are attending the conference, including Tom Leppert, mayor of Dallas, U.S., Shigemitsu Tsumura, mayor of Miyazaki, Japan, Cedric Foo, a member of the Singaporean parliament, Peter Trautmann, representative for international projects of Munich Airport, and Brian Joiner, Australia aviation strategy manager of Melbourne Airport.

DOC.HEADLINE: World Vision Taiwan promotes 20th 30-Hour Famine

TEXT.P: World Vision Taiwan, the local chapter of the international Christian relief organization, promoted its 20th 30-Hour Famine program for 2009 on Tuesday, calling on the public to join the event to help raise funds to combat the global food crisis.

"Through the 30-hour famine program, people will be able to experience firsthand the needs of starving people, World Vision Taiwan said in a press release. "With more people participating in the event, more children affected by famines will be saved."

More than 20,000 people from home and abroad are expected to attend this year's Famine Hero Rally scheduled for Aug. 15-16 at the National Taiwan Sport University stadium in Linkou, an event World Vision Taiwan hopes will raise NT$170 million (US$5 million).
The group urged the public to sign up for the "lively and rewarding" event starting May 1 at www.30hf.org.tw. The registration fee for adults is NT$1,000 and NT$500 for students.

Separate from the event to be held in Linkou, groups and individuals are also welcome to register for the DIY Famine challenge, in which participants can fast for 12 to 30 hours on their own through educational, emotional and fun activities, the organization said.
World Vision provides a planning guide, video clips and related information to assist the planning of a DIY famine.

Since the program was introduced three years ago, over 900 famine groups have been organized, with more than 80,000 famine heroes receiving a certificate. Some 177 groups and 28,772 individuals are already registered for this year's program.

The 30-Hour Famine program is one of World Vision Taiwan's three principal fund- raising activities, the other two being a child sponsorship program that helps poor children in Taiwan and abroad and a program that assists local and overseas development projects.
The Taiwan chapter of World Vision was established 43 years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan sets up command center to counter swine flu

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) set up a central command center Tuesday to prevent a possible swine flu outbreak in Taiwan as the virus continues to spread around the world.

The DOH took the step after the World Health Organization (WHO) raised its influenza pandemic alert to phase 4 from phase 3 earlier in the day, indicating that there is sustained human-to-human transmission of the virus.

Established at a meeting of cross-government agencies, the center will focus on strengthening surveillance for swine flu at boundary control points and raising travel warnings for the United States and Mexico and other areas affected by the virus, Minister Yeh Ching-chuan said.

Although no cases of the influenza have been reported in Taiwan, Yeh said the virus would eventually find its way into the country and that Taiwan had to be well prepared for the worst possible scenario.

The government has also mapped out a national flu pandemic strategy in response to the threat, which includes establishing a channel to co-ordinate the replenishment of medication and vaccine stockpiles among various government agencies, he indicated.
The flu virus that has struck Mexico is a new strain of the H1N1, which appears to be easily passed from person to person, and is a mixture of the swine, human and avian flu viruses.

The World Organization for Animal Health said in a statement that the virus should not be called swine flu because it has yet to be isolated in pigs, and Yeh reiterated that people would not get infected with the flu by eating pork.
The virus is being transmitted, he said, by people coming in physical contact with people who have the flu.

Yeh assured local residents that Taiwan has a sufficient supply of surgical masks and vaccine to deal with the flu. The DOH has 50 million to 60 million masks in stock and local manufacturers have the capability of producing 200,000 doses of the flu vaccine a month, he said.
Health care and ambulance workers and custom officials would be given top priority for receipt of the vaccine, Yeh noted.
Taiwan also has enough stockpiled Tamiflu, the best available medicine against the H1N1 flu, to treat up to 2.3 million people-- one-tenth of Taiwan's total population, Yeh added.
The country also has three manufacturers capable of producing Tamiflu if necessary, he said.

The government will also earmark a special budget, use TV channels and set up commander centers in all cities and counties around the country to promote information and measures on flu prevention, Yeh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, increasing NT$0.065 to close at NT$33.795.
A total of US$825 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.880 and fluctuated between NT$33.730 and NT$33.887.

DOC.HEADLINE: Swine flu fears send Taiwan's share prices lower

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed 1.89 percent lower Tuesday amid worries that the swine flu outbreak could spread and hinder the economic recovery.
The weighted index, the market's key barometer, lost 108.32 points to close at 5,596.73. A total of 5.99 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$126.94 billion (US$3.76 billion).
The local bourse opened higher at 5,744.77 and fluctuated between 5,773.53 and 5,596.73.

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks losing the most at 5.1 percent. Foodstuff shares fell 4.8 percent, construction issues dropped 4.2 percent, paper and pulp stocks shed 3.7 percent, textile issues dropped 3.0 percent, plastics and chemicals stocks lost 2.1 percent, banking and financial shares slid 1.5 percent, and machinery and electronics shares shed 1.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,687 to 505, with 76 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$5.55 billion.

Transportation and travel-related issues were hardest hit by fears of a wider swine flu outbreak, falling more than 5 percent amid concerns passengers could refrain from flying for fear of catching the virus.
The only beneficiaries were hygiene and medical-related companies on expectations that demands for their products may surge to deal with any outbreak of the disease.

Shares in Kang Na Hsiung Enterprise and Universal Inc., manufacturers of non- woven fabrics, Medtecs, a major disposable medical supplies producer, and household cleaning products producer Mao Bao Inc. rose by the maximum 7 percent.
As market worries over a flu pandemic continue, the market is likely to drop below the 5,500-point level, analysts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Travelers advised to take masks to Mexico: TAITRA

TEXT.P: Taiwanese people planning to visit Mexico are suggested to equip themselves with surgical masks before entering that country, which is in the grip of a swine flu panic, because there is a shortage of supply there, according to a statement released Tuesday by the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA).

Citing Mario Tsai, the head of the TAITRA-affiliated Taiwan Trade Center in Mexico City, the statement said center staff had unsuccessfully tried to purchase masks at several local grocery stores since April 25.

Tsai stated that only around 40 percent of passengers on public transport in Mexico City were observed wearing masks that day, while fewer than 50 percent of pedestrians and people in shopping malls were bothering to wear masks to ward off the flu virus.
However, he went on, the Mexican government has begun releasing gauze masks to people at metro stations.

Tsai advised visitors to the capital, Mexico City, to refrain from using public transport and suggested that Taiwanese visitors stay in hotels graded with at least four stars and he also suggested avoiding hotels in the old city district of Col Centro.

According to the latest report by the World Health Organization (WHO) April 27 on swine flu outbreaks, as of that same day Mexico had reported 26 confirmed human cases of infection with swine influenza A(H1N1), including seven deaths, while the United States government had reported 40 laboratory confirmed human cases, with no deaths.
Canada had reported six cases, with no deaths, while Spain had reported one case, with no deaths, the WHO said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pact offers no 'escape' for Taiwan's fugitives in China: MAC

TEXT.P: An agreement signed between Taiwan and China over the weekend to cooperate in fighting crime means China must not reject Taiwan's demands that it extradite major economic criminals wanted by the government, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Tuesday.

The MAC made the remarks in a statement released Monday evening to refute media speculation that an article in the crime-combating and judicial assistance pact inked by the two sides Sunday might provide an "escape" for some major Taiwanese economic fugitives who take shelter in China.

Some local newspaper reports voiced their suspicion of the pact, pointing to the article which stipulates that "either side receiving the plea from the other side may decide on its own whether to repatriate wanted fugitives if vital interest or exceptional circumstances are involved."

According to the MAC, the two sides worked out the mutually acceptable wording based on the main spirit of most international judicial assistance accords, which usually exclude political, military and religious criminals from mandatory repatriation.

Due to the sensitive relations between Taiwan and China, it is essential to distinguish political, military or religious criminals from two-way crime- fighting efforts, in which economic criminals are included, particularly those who commit crimes relating to embezzlement, breach of trust, fraud and money laundering, the MAC said.

More than 50 major economic criminals from Taiwan, including those convicted or indicted, have fled to China over the past few years, according to information provided by the Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of Justice.

They include former Legislative Yuan Speaker Liu Sung-pan, former Kaohsiung Mayor Wang Yu-yun and his son Wang Chih-hsiung, an ex- legislator, and former Kaohsiung City Council Speaker Chu An-hsiung, as well as Chen Yu-hao, former head of the Tuntex Group, and Tseng Cheng-jen, former owner of the Sogo Department Store in Taichung City.

But government officials said in recent days that China will no longer be a safe haven for Taiwanese fugitives, as the Investigation Bureau and the National Police Agency have referred a list of most-wanted Taiwanese criminals to Chinese authorities.

The Ministry of Justice said it will soon hold work meetings with Chinese public security, prosecution and law authorities to discuss the establishment of a cooperation framework and related details on joint efforts in crime fighting.

In the future, Taiwanese inmates serving jail terms in China can apply to complete their sentence in Taiwan and vice versa based on humanitarian considerations and mutual benefits in compliance with the Taiwan-China judicial assistance accord.
This accord is one of three pacts signed by Taiwan and China in the Chinese city of Nanjing on April 26.
The two other pacts concerned financial cooperation and increasing regularly scheduled flights between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to post marginal economic growth in 2009: think tank

TEXT.P: Taiwan is likely to post marginal economic growth of 0.11 percent in 2009 as the country's export momentum is battered by overall plunging demand, the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER), a local think tank, forecast Tuesday.
Despite expanded demand in some Asian markets, overall demand continues to dwindle because of the global financial crisis, according to a monthly report published by the think tank.

Under these circumstances, Taiwan's exports are projected to shrink by 9.19 percent in 2009, while imports are likely to contract by 13.87 percent, the TIER said, predicting a trade surplus of US$25.05 billion for the year.
The sharp fall in international commodity prices will ease inflation significantly, with Taiwan's inflation rate projected at 0.17 percent for 2009, the report said.

Although government investment will increase by 26.96 percent thanks to the administration's efforts to promote public construction projects, fixed investment by the private sector is expected to drop by 11.53 percent as businesses delay or cut back on their capital expenditure, the report went on.

In terms of private consumption, the TIER predicted that there will be a slight growth of 0.62 percent, as the forced unpaid leave policy and workforce reduction by local businesses are taking a heavy toll on the public's purchasing power.

Further observation is required to judge the effect of the government's shopping voucher program and the recent influx of Chinese tourists on boosting private consumption, according to the TIER report.

Meanwhile, a survey conducted by the TIER in March on the business climate for the manufacturing sector shows that 42.8 percent of manufacturers think conditions will improve over the next six months, up from 36.6 percent recorded in a February survey.
A total of 18.6 percent of the respondents predicted that conditions worsen over the next six months, down from 24 percent in the previous month.
Meanwhile, 38.6 percent said they think conditions will remain the same, down from 39.4 percent in February.

According to the TIER, despite weak demand from the European and U.S. markets, shipments by Taiwan's electronics and machinery sectors are likely to pick up in the next six months thanks to rush orders from emerging markets.
The composite business climate indicator for the manufacturing sector stood at 105.59 in March, up 11.86 points compared with the previous month, the TIER report shows.
The composite business climate indicator for the service sector registered 103.26, up 9.78 points from February.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to launch on-board flu checks on flights from America

TEXT.P: Every flight from America that arrives in Taiwan from April 29 onward will be subject to a strict on-board screening procedure in an effort to prevent the entry of a new strain of swine influenza, the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) announced in a statement Tuesday.
The first flight to undergo the procedure will be EVA Airways flight BR017 from San Francisco, which is scheduled to land at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport at 5: 10 a.m. that day, the CDC said.

The statement said the CDC decided to take the unusual step under the instruction of Premier Liu Chao-shiuan and following a resolution of the Executive Yuan's command center for prevention of A/H1N1 swine flu outbreaks that have been reported in Mexico, the United States, Canada and several other countries.
CDC Deputy Director-General Shih Wen-yi said it is impossible to predict when the procedure will be lifted.
In addition to Taiwan, Japan has already taken the same measure for flights from Mexico, said Shih.

He continued that when an affected flight arrives at the airport, all passengers will be asked to stay in their seats until quarantine officials board the plane and give them a hygiene lecture and information on the new type of flu.
The officials will also screen every passenger and anyone with flu-like symptoms, including coughing and sore throat, will be kept on the plane for further checks, Shih said.
Those passengers allowed to leave the aircraft will still have to pass a temperature reader once inside the airport.

If the officials cannot eliminate the possibility of swine flu infection, those who are suspected of being infected will be taken directly to a hospital for further checks, Shih went on, adding that those who do not show signs of infection at the airport but who develop symptoms after entering the country will be requested to report to the CDC, he added.
According to border surveillance statistics, around 50 flights from the U.S. and Canada had landed over the past three days, bringing more than 15,000 travelers into the country.
Shih said five of the travelers were found to have a fever upon arrival, but all were declared uninfected with swine flu.
Meanwhile, the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau also activated an emergency checking mechanism Tuesday at the country's largest seaport.
The outbreaks in Mexico and the U.S. have prompted the World Health Organization to raise its alert level to phase 4 on a scale of six, indicating a significantly increased risk of pandemic.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese agricultural exports to China show marked growth

TEXT.P: The value of Taiwan's agricultural exports to China increased from US$66.4 million in 2002 to US$436.58 million in 2008, marking a 5.6-fold growth, a Council of Agriculture (COA) official said Tuesday.

Encouraged by this performance, described by the COA as "remarkable, " the COA has marked China as a target market for more Taiwanese agricultural products, said Chang Shu-hsien, who is in charge of international affairs at the COA.
As a result, Chang went on, the council has since last year been strengthening measures to promote Taiwan-grown fruit and vegetables to buyers in China.

This year, she went on, the COA plans to cooperate with traders in major cities in northern, central and southern regions of China in organizing promotional activities such as Taiwanese fruit festivals to attract Chinese consumers.

The council will also invite Chinese wholesalers to visit Taiwan and meet with local businessmen for talks on issues including opening a stable distribution channel between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Chang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan marks anniversary of Sino-Japan Peace Treaty

TEXT.P: The Republic of China marked the 57th anniversary of the Sino-Japanese Peace Treaty by unveiling a set of five statues Tuesday at Taipei Guest House, where the treaty was signed in 1952.
President Ma Ying-jeou presided over the unveiling of the statues which depict ROC Envoy George Yeh and his Japanese counterpart Isao Kawada inking the treaty while three other diplomats look on.
At Tuesday's ceremony, Ma stressed that the reenactment of the 1952 signing should serve as a reminder to the public that Taiwan belongs to the Republic of China.

Ma, who holds a doctorate in International Law from Harvard University, said the Sino-Japanese treaty was a followup to the Treaty of San Francisco concluded between Japan and the allied nations in 1951.

The ROC was not invited to sign the San Francisco treaty because it was engaged in a civil war with the People's Republic of China and there was disagreement among the allied nations over which side was the legitimate government of China.

"The Sino-Japanese Peace Treaty stated only that Japan renounced all rights to territories it had occupied by force, but did not specify that Taiwan should be ceded to any particular state, " Ma said, adding that "this was in line with the terms of the Treaty of San Francisco."

Since the territories occupied by Japan at the time were many, the signatories to the San Francisco treaty preferred that the territorial issues be resolved through separate agreements between the individual states and Japan, Ma said.
"This gave rise to many bilateral treaties between Japan and other countries on territorial rights," Ma said, citing as an example the treaty between Japan and Russia.
"The Sino-Japanese Treaty was concluded against a similar backdrop, and reading between the lines, one can easily see that the aim was to hand over Taiwan to the Republic of China." Ma said.
The treaty not only brought peace to Taiwan and Japan, but also ushered in a period of friendly relations between the two states, he added.
"The treaty is vital not only to Taiwan, but also to the whole region, " and the statues are a reminder of its value, the president stated.
"These statues will remind people who visit this house of how much we owe to those who drafted the treaty," he said.
Ma's comments took direct aim the argument by many pro-independence activists that Taiwan has not belonged to any state since Japan gave it up at the end of World War II.
These activists reject China's claim to the island and promote their Taiwan independence cause based on the argument that Japan did not hand over Taiwan to any other state.
The issue is often a contentious one in Taiwan, especially at election time when some politicians campaign on a platform of permanent separation between Taiwan and China.

Ma was obviously trying to tread a fine line between Beijing's view and that of the proponents of independence by saying that Taiwan belongs to the "Republic of China, " rather than "China, " which usually refers to the People's Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for April 29, 2009

TEXT.P: 2. Event: Strait Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung briefs

Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan on his Chinese mission. Date and Time:3 p.m.,Wednesday, April 29, 2009. Place: 15 flr., No. 2-2, Section 1, Jinan Road, Taipei City. Host and/or main speakers: Chiang Pin-kung and Lai Shin-yuan. Organizers: Mainland Affairs Council. Press Contact: 2397-5598.
Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Daily number of Chinese tourists to be fixed below 5,000: premier

TEXT.P: The number of Chinese tourists visiting Taiwan should be limited to 5,000 per day to ensure the quality of their trips, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Tuesday.

Noting that Chinese made up 1 million of the 3.7 million foreign visitors to Taiwan last year, the premier said, however, his administration had not anticipated that the number would grow to the current 5,000 to 6,000 Chinese tourists per day.
"This influx results in a lower quality of service -- a problem that must be addressed urgently by the government." Liu said at a media gathering.
"We should not admit more tourists than we can accommodate and we need to improve our local tourism infrastructure," the premier said.

"The exact daily cap for the number of Chinese tourists should be determined jointly by the Ministry of the Interior and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, but I expect it to be below 5,000." Liu said.

In order to encourage Chinese tourists to make more comprehensive tours of the island, the premier said, his administration is mulling a revision of the pertinent regulations to allow groups of two or three people to visit rather, than the current minimum of five.

Liu made the statements two days after President Ma Ying-jeou asked the administration to impose a proper cap on the daily number of Chinese tourists, after he learned that there were not enough tour buses to meet demand.

When Taiwan's opening to Chinese tourists took effect on July 4, 2008, the government imposed a cap of 3,000 visitors per day, but the number has spiked in the lead up to China's May Day holiday, and local officials have raised the ceiling by transferring unused quotas from previous days.

DOC.HEADLINE: Epidemic prevention drive activated over swine flu scare (roundup)

TEXT.P: Taiwan stepped up its epidemic prevention efforts Monday amid reports of a further spread of human infections of swine flu globally.

An outbreak of human infections of swine flu was first reported in Mexico March 18 and the number of related deaths has exceeded 100 so far. Several confirmed cases were also reported in the southwestern part of the United States and Canada. Suspected cases were reported in Brazil, Spain and the Philippines.
World Health Organization (WHO) officials have warned that there is a potential for the new H1N1 swine virus to become a global pandemic.

No cases of the disease have been reported in Taiwan, but the government is on heightened alert, with the Executive Yuan calling a supraministerial meeting Monday morning to coordinate preventive measures in hopes of averting any possible outbreak of human infections of the new swine flu strain.

Addressing the meeting, Vice Premiser Chiu Cheng-hsiung directed the Ministry of the Interior and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications to tighten fever screening at airports and harbors to ward off entry of the virus from abroad.

The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health (DOH) later listed human infections of swine flu as a level-one notifiable disease in line with the WHO's definition of the new swine flu strain.
From now on, DOH Minister Yeh Ching-chuan said, medical institutions are obligated to report suspected swine flu cases to facilitate tracking and prevention of an epidemic.
Meanwhile, Premier Liu Chao-hsiuan will make an inspection tour of Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport to see for himself epidemic preventive measures there.

In the meantime, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs raised th level of its travel alert for Mexico City to the second-highest orange level Monday, urging prospective travelers to defer their travel plans for the time being in light of the wine flu outbreak there.
Economics officials prdicted that the new swine flu outbreak could delay a global economic recovery and add uncertainty if the outbreak became serious in the United States.
As Taipei will sponsor the 2009 Deaflympics in September, city councilors have urged the city government to take precautionary measures to cope with the situation.
Nevertheless, DOH Minister Yeh said local people need not overreact to the swine flu scare because no suspected cases of swine flu or human infections of the virus have ever been reported in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutor detained for second time on suspicion of bribery

TEXT.P: A public prosecutor in Taitung, southeastern Taiwan, who was released on bail five days ago pending further investigation into his alleged acceptance of bribes, was detained again Tuesday.

The Taitung Public Prosecutors' Office took Lin Sheng-lin into custody Sunday night for questioning on the strength of new evidence implicating him in a second bribery case and sought permission from the Taitung District Court again to keep him in custody.

The court granted the permission Monday after reviewing the arguments submitted by the prosecutors' office that Lin tried to contact witnesses and defendants in the bribery cases, through his father, in an apparent attempt to collude with them.

On April 22, Lin was released on bail of NT$500,000 (US$14,760) after being taken into custody a day earlier to answer charges that he had accepted bribes from suspects who should have been indicted in criminal cases that he handled. At the time, the court ruled that there was no need to keep Lin in detention, even though he could face at least five years in prison if convicted.

On that day, the court also set bail at NT$200,000 for Wu Dong-sheng, a broker whom prosecutors said assisted Lin in obtaining bribes. The court ruled that both Lin and Wu are not allowed to leave the country.

According to the Taitung Public Prosecutors' Office, Lin was reassigned from the Shihlin Public Prosecutors' Office in Taipei to work in Taitung in August last year because he left too many criminal cases unhandled.

Ethics officers at the Taitung prosecutors' office placed Lin under surveillance after noting that he continued to allow the accumulation of many cases, and that he had dismissed quite a few cases that he should have prosecuted.
Further investigation led to the admission by several suspects in at least two criminal cases that Lin had offered not to indict them in return for bribes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan elevates travel alert for Mexico City over swine flu scare

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) raised the level of its travel alert for Mexico City to orange Monday, urging prospective travelers to defer their plans for the time being in light of an outbreak of human infections of swine flu there.
The ministry had originally issued a yellow travel alert for Mexico, the lowest level advisory that warns travelers to exercise caution.

However, the MOFA decided to raise the alert for Mexico's capital to orange, the second-highest level, in view of the latest reports that the swine flu outbreak is most serious in Mexico City and has spread to other parts of the world, MOFA officials said.
Moreover, they added, World Health Organizations (WHO) officials have warned that there is a potential for the new swine flu virus to become a global pandemic.
On the ministry's three-color travel advisory scale, an orange alert suggests that would-be travelers should suspend their travel plans over safety or health concerns.
According to MOFA statistics, an average of 3,000 to 4,000 Taiwanese citizens apply for visas to Mexico annually, most of whom intend to travel to Mexico City for business or sightseeing purposes.

In support of the ongoing global campaign to contain the spread of the new H1N1 swine flu virus and out of local health concerns, residents of Taiwan are advised to refrain from traveling to Mexico City for the time being, the officials warned.
Meanwhile, they said the MOFA will maintain its yellow alert for other areas and cities of Mexico, and urged would-be travelers to exercise a high degree of caution.

As of late Sunday, the number of suspected swine flu cases in Mexico had climbed to 1,614, including as many as 103 deaths, according to Mexican Health Secretary Jose Angel Cordova. The United States has confirmed at least 11 cases of swine flu, and Canada six cases.

The Mexican City government has ordered suspension of all public activities and closure of all libraries, museums, theaters and other public places. It has also closed schools of all levels until May 6.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Over 160,000 people have yet to collect shopping vouchers: MOI

TEXT.P: A total of 160,841 people have yet to pick up their government-issued consumption vouchers as of Sunday, a few days before the April 30 deadline, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said Tuesday.
The MOI indicated that as of Sunday, 23,103,405 out of 23,264,246 eligible people, a 99.31 collection rate, had collected vouchers worth a total of more than NT$83.17 billion.

The ministry urged eligible people who have not collected their vouchers to do so at designated post offices, adding that those who fail to pick them up by the deadline will lose their rights to pick up the NT$3,600 in vouchers.
The MOI also advised those who do not know where their designated post office is to check related information on its voucher Web site at 3600.moi.gov.tw or to call 0800-88-3600 for information.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA issues red travel alert for Mexico on swine flu

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has issued a red travel alert for Mexico, warning local travelers not to visit the country because of the spread of the swine flu virus from Mexico to the rest of the world.

"The Foreign Ministry has decided to issue a red travel advisory for Mexico. The decision is based on only one concern -- the travel safety and health of our citizens, MOFA spokesman Henry Chen said Tuesday at a regular press briefing.
The ministry also issued a yellow travel alert for the United States and Canada, Chen added.

A red alert -- the most serious travel advisory alert -- warns travelers not to enter the area in question under any circumstances. It is followed by an orange travel alert, which advises travelers to postpone their trips, and a yellow alert, which serves as a reminder for travelers to exercise caution.
So far, no Taiwanese expatriates or businessmen in Mexico have been reported ill, and the ministry's representative office there will continue to collect relevant information, Chen said.

Meanwhile, three or four unidentified Taiwanese high school exchange students in Nova Scotia -- Canada's second smallest province located on its southeastern coast -- remained under isolation, Chen said.
The MOFA's representative office in Ottawa is trying to get more details on the situation, Chen said.

A Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) report quoted Joe Seagram, headmaster of Nova Scotia's King's-Edgehill School as saying that as of Monday there were four confirmed human swine flu cases at the school while 27 others with flu-like symptoms remained in isolation.
The outbreaks of swine flu in Mexico have spread to other parts of the world, raising concerns that it could turn into a global pandemic.
The U.S., with 47 confirmed cases, has declared apublic health emergency," while in Mexico, 149 deaths have been linked to the flu while another 2,000 people have been hospitalized.
The World Health Organization (WHO) said Canada has six confirmed human infections while Spain has one and Scotland has two.
The world health regulatory body raised its global pandemic flu alert from level 3 to level 4 Tuesday, indicating that there has been sustained human-to-human transmission of the flu.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China one step closer to normalized ties: chief negotiator
DOC.DATELINE: Yangzhou, China, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/09 13:57:46 (By Chiang Chin-yeh and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The two sides of the Taiwan Strait have moved a step closer to normalizing their trade and economic relations after reaching understandings on financial cooperation and opening Taiwan to Chinese investment, Taipei's chief negotiator with Beijing said Monday.

The achievement, together with agreements reached previously on the launch of cross-strait air, shipping and mail services, has contributed to an intial realization of "three links" -- direct transportation, trade and postal links -- between the two sides, said Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

Chiang made the remarks during a visit to Yangzhou, the second leg of his current China visit that first took him to Nanjing, where he met with his Chinese counterpart, Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin.
The two signed three agreements covering the launch of regular cross-strait passenger flights, financial cooperation, and cross-strait cooperation to fight crime.
A joint statement on a proposal to open Taiwan to Chinese investment was also released on the occasion.
Chiang pointed out that including these three agreements, the two sides have reached a total of nine agreements in 10 months.

Among the four understandings reached Sunday, the joint statement on liberalizing Taiwan-bound Chinese investment will facilitate a two-way flow of investment, reversing the current one-way movement of investment from Taiwan to China, Chiang said.

Issues to be addressed by the two sides in the future, such as investment protection, dual taxation avoidance and intellectual property right protection, are expected to help further promote direct cross-strait business links, he said.
The latest Chiang-Chen meeting was the third of its kind since the resumption of cross-strait dialogue less than one year ago following a nine-year hiatus.

It signifies the continued warming of relations between the two former rivals since the inauguration of President Ma Ying-jeou, whose administration has made it a priority to ease tensions and improve relations with China.

In their first meeting held in June 2008 in Beijing, Chiang and Chen signed agreements on the launch of weekend cross-strait passenger charter flights and the admission of larger numbers of Chinese tourists to Taiwan.

Their second meeting took place in November in Taipei, during which they signed agreements on extending charter flights from weekends to every day of the week, opening direct cross-strait shipping, postal, and air cargo charter services, and improving food safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pork prices in Taiwan not affected by swine flu outbreak

TEXT.P: Domestic pork prices have not been affected by outbreaks of the A/H1N1 swine flu in Mexico, the United States, and Canada, said a senior Council of Agriculture (COA) official said Tuesday.

Hsu Tien-lai, the head of the COA's Animal Industry Division, noted that the wholesale price for pork stood at NT$5,999 (US$176) per 100 kilograms on Monday, the same as usual, but he said he would continue to monitor the market.

Hsu said the outbreak has not affected the pork market because the new H1N1 strain has not attacked pigs. In a statement issued Monday, the World Organization for Animal Health stressed, "the virus has not been isolated in animals to date " and said that calling the disease "swine influenza" was not justified, Hsu noted.
Although the new virus contains genetic fragments of swine flu, it is regarded as a recombinant virus formed in the human body, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President touts Taoyuan Aerotropolis as key to Taiwan's future

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that building the Taoyuan Aerotropolis is an important key to Taiwan's future development and an essential element in Taiwan's efforts to become more closely connected with the international community.

"Taiwan is exceptionally blessed in terms of its location. I would even advise aliens to take hold of Taiwan if they come to Earth, " said Ma at the opening ceremony of the 2009 International Conference on Aerotropolis, hosted by Taoyuan County and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).
"It would be such a waste if we do not make good use of this advantage and develop it well.

Because Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport is at the center of every major Asian air route, it has more potential than other Asian airports to become a regional hub, Ma said, stressing that the aerotropolis development program will be vital to Taiwan's future development.
Taoyuan County magistrate Eric Liluan Chu agreed with the president that the project would be of fundamental importance to Taiwan's long-term development.
Chu acknowledged that the Taoyuan airport's passenger traffic and freight volume declined in 2008, but he stressed that the international gateway's future was still bright.

Chu cited Civil Aeronautics Administration forecasts that the airport's passenger traffic will increase from 21.9 million people in 2008 to 47.5 million people in 2035, and cargo volume will rise from 1.49 million tons in 2008 to 4.03 million tons in 2035.
Chu said Taoyuan County must seize the potential for growth and work hard in cooperation with the central government to convert the airport area into an aerotropolis.

The Taoyuan Aerotropolis project -- set to be completed in 2020 -- would involve the expansion of existing airport terminals and the establishment of an aerospace industrial park and special zones for cargo, passenger and logistics services.
It is expected to attract NT$1.2 trillion (US$35.5 billion) in investment, while generating NT$600 billion in revenues and creating more than 80,000 jobs.

The goal of the two-day conference is to give experts affiliated with the industrial sector, governments and academia the chance to share their experience and views and use the knowledge gained to ensure that the aerotropolis plan best meets Taiwan's development needs.

Some 40 experts from home and abroad are attending the conference, including Tom Leppert, mayor of Dallas, U.S., Shigemitsu Tsumura, mayor of Miyazaki, Japan, Cedric Foo, a member of the Singaporean parliament, Peter Trautmann, representative for international projects of Munich Airport, and Brian Joiner, Australia aviation strategy manager of Melbourne Airport.

DOC.HEADLINE: World Vision Taiwan promotes 20th 30-Hour Famine

TEXT.P: World Vision Taiwan, the local chapter of the international Christian relief organization, promoted its 20th 30-Hour Famine program for 2009 on Tuesday, calling on the public to join the event to help raise funds to combat the global food crisis.

"Through the 30-hour famine program, people will be able to experience firsthand the needs of starving people, World Vision Taiwan said in a press release. "With more people participating in the event, more children affected by famines will be saved."

More than 20,000 people from home and abroad are expected to attend this year's Famine Hero Rally scheduled for Aug. 15-16 at the National Taiwan Sport University stadium in Linkou, an event World Vision Taiwan hopes will raise NT$170 million (US$5 million).
The group urged the public to sign up for the "lively and rewarding" event starting May 1 at www.30hf.org.tw. The registration fee for adults is NT$1,000 and NT$500 for students.

Separate from the event to be held in Linkou, groups and individuals are also welcome to register for the DIY Famine challenge, in which participants can fast for 12 to 30 hours on their own through educational, emotional and fun activities, the organization said.
World Vision provides a planning guide, video clips and related information to assist the planning of a DIY famine.

Since the program was introduced three years ago, over 900 famine groups have been organized, with more than 80,000 famine heroes receiving a certificate. Some 177 groups and 28,772 individuals are already registered for this year's program.

The 30-Hour Famine program is one of World Vision Taiwan's three principal fund- raising activities, the other two being a child sponsorship program that helps poor children in Taiwan and abroad and a program that assists local and overseas development projects.
The Taiwan chapter of World Vision was established 43 years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan sets up command center to counter swine flu

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) set up a central command center Tuesday to prevent a possible swine flu outbreak in Taiwan as the virus continues to spread around the world.

The DOH took the step after the World Health Organization (WHO) raised its influenza pandemic alert to phase 4 from phase 3 earlier in the day, indicating that there is sustained human-to-human transmission of the virus.

Established at a meeting of cross-government agencies, the center will focus on strengthening surveillance for swine flu at boundary control points and raising travel warnings for the United States and Mexico and other areas affected by the virus, Minister Yeh Ching-chuan said.

Although no cases of the influenza have been reported in Taiwan, Yeh said the virus would eventually find its way into the country and that Taiwan had to be well prepared for the worst possible scenario.

The government has also mapped out a national flu pandemic strategy in response to the threat, which includes establishing a channel to co-ordinate the replenishment of medication and vaccine stockpiles among various government agencies, he indicated.
The flu virus that has struck Mexico is a new strain of the H1N1, which appears to be easily passed from person to person, and is a mixture of the swine, human and avian flu viruses.

The World Organization for Animal Health said in a statement that the virus should not be called swine flu because it has yet to be isolated in pigs, and Yeh reiterated that people would not get infected with the flu by eating pork.
The virus is being transmitted, he said, by people coming in physical contact with people who have the flu.

Yeh assured local residents that Taiwan has a sufficient supply of surgical masks and vaccine to deal with the flu. The DOH has 50 million to 60 million masks in stock and local manufacturers have the capability of producing 200,000 doses of the flu vaccine a month, he said.
Health care and ambulance workers and custom officials would be given top priority for receipt of the vaccine, Yeh noted.
Taiwan also has enough stockpiled Tamiflu, the best available medicine against the H1N1 flu, to treat up to 2.3 million people-- one-tenth of Taiwan's total population, Yeh added.
The country also has three manufacturers capable of producing Tamiflu if necessary, he said.

The government will also earmark a special budget, use TV channels and set up commander centers in all cities and counties around the country to promote information and measures on flu prevention, Yeh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, increasing NT$0.065 to close at NT$33.795.
A total of US$825 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.880 and fluctuated between NT$33.730 and NT$33.887.

DOC.HEADLINE: Swine flu fears send Taiwan's share prices lower

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed 1.89 percent lower Tuesday amid worries that the swine flu outbreak could spread and hinder the economic recovery.
The weighted index, the market's key barometer, lost 108.32 points to close at 5,596.73. A total of 5.99 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$126.94 billion (US$3.76 billion).
The local bourse opened higher at 5,744.77 and fluctuated between 5,773.53 and 5,596.73.

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks losing the most at 5.1 percent. Foodstuff shares fell 4.8 percent, construction issues dropped 4.2 percent, paper and pulp stocks shed 3.7 percent, textile issues dropped 3.0 percent, plastics and chemicals stocks lost 2.1 percent, banking and financial shares slid 1.5 percent, and machinery and electronics shares shed 1.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,687 to 505, with 76 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$5.55 billion.

Transportation and travel-related issues were hardest hit by fears of a wider swine flu outbreak, falling more than 5 percent amid concerns passengers could refrain from flying for fear of catching the virus.
The only beneficiaries were hygiene and medical-related companies on expectations that demands for their products may surge to deal with any outbreak of the disease.

Shares in Kang Na Hsiung Enterprise and Universal Inc., manufacturers of non- woven fabrics, Medtecs, a major disposable medical supplies producer, and household cleaning products producer Mao Bao Inc. rose by the maximum 7 percent.
As market worries over a flu pandemic continue, the market is likely to drop below the 5,500-point level, analysts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Travelers advised to take masks to Mexico: TAITRA

TEXT.P: Taiwanese people planning to visit Mexico are suggested to equip themselves with surgical masks before entering that country, which is in the grip of a swine flu panic, because there is a shortage of supply there, according to a statement released Tuesday by the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA).

Citing Mario Tsai, the head of the TAITRA-affiliated Taiwan Trade Center in Mexico City, the statement said center staff had unsuccessfully tried to purchase masks at several local grocery stores since April 25.

Tsai stated that only around 40 percent of passengers on public transport in Mexico City were observed wearing masks that day, while fewer than 50 percent of pedestrians and people in shopping malls were bothering to wear masks to ward off the flu virus.
However, he went on, the Mexican government has begun releasing gauze masks to people at metro stations.

Tsai advised visitors to the capital, Mexico City, to refrain from using public transport and suggested that Taiwanese visitors stay in hotels graded with at least four stars and he also suggested avoiding hotels in the old city district of Col Centro.

According to the latest report by the World Health Organization (WHO) April 27 on swine flu outbreaks, as of that same day Mexico had reported 26 confirmed human cases of infection with swine influenza A(H1N1), including seven deaths, while the United States government had reported 40 laboratory confirmed human cases, with no deaths.
Canada had reported six cases, with no deaths, while Spain had reported one case, with no deaths, the WHO said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pact offers no 'escape' for Taiwan's fugitives in China: MAC

TEXT.P: An agreement signed between Taiwan and China over the weekend to cooperate in fighting crime means China must not reject Taiwan's demands that it extradite major economic criminals wanted by the government, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Tuesday.

The MAC made the remarks in a statement released Monday evening to refute media speculation that an article in the crime-combating and judicial assistance pact inked by the two sides Sunday might provide an "escape" for some major Taiwanese economic fugitives who take shelter in China.

Some local newspaper reports voiced their suspicion of the pact, pointing to the article which stipulates that "either side receiving the plea from the other side may decide on its own whether to repatriate wanted fugitives if vital interest or exceptional circumstances are involved."

According to the MAC, the two sides worked out the mutually acceptable wording based on the main spirit of most international judicial assistance accords, which usually exclude political, military and religious criminals from mandatory repatriation.

Due to the sensitive relations between Taiwan and China, it is essential to distinguish political, military or religious criminals from two-way crime- fighting efforts, in which economic criminals are included, particularly those who commit crimes relating to embezzlement, breach of trust, fraud and money laundering, the MAC said.

More than 50 major economic criminals from Taiwan, including those convicted or indicted, have fled to China over the past few years, according to information provided by the Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of Justice.

They include former Legislative Yuan Speaker Liu Sung-pan, former Kaohsiung Mayor Wang Yu-yun and his son Wang Chih-hsiung, an ex- legislator, and former Kaohsiung City Council Speaker Chu An-hsiung, as well as Chen Yu-hao, former head of the Tuntex Group, and Tseng Cheng-jen, former owner of the Sogo Department Store in Taichung City.

But government officials said in recent days that China will no longer be a safe haven for Taiwanese fugitives, as the Investigation Bureau and the National Police Agency have referred a list of most-wanted Taiwanese criminals to Chinese authorities.

The Ministry of Justice said it will soon hold work meetings with Chinese public security, prosecution and law authorities to discuss the establishment of a cooperation framework and related details on joint efforts in crime fighting.

In the future, Taiwanese inmates serving jail terms in China can apply to complete their sentence in Taiwan and vice versa based on humanitarian considerations and mutual benefits in compliance with the Taiwan-China judicial assistance accord.
This accord is one of three pacts signed by Taiwan and China in the Chinese city of Nanjing on April 26.
The two other pacts concerned financial cooperation and increasing regularly scheduled flights between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to post marginal economic growth in 2009: think tank

TEXT.P: Taiwan is likely to post marginal economic growth of 0.11 percent in 2009 as the country's export momentum is battered by overall plunging demand, the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER), a local think tank, forecast Tuesday.
Despite expanded demand in some Asian markets, overall demand continues to dwindle because of the global financial crisis, according to a monthly report published by the think tank.

Under these circumstances, Taiwan's exports are projected to shrink by 9.19 percent in 2009, while imports are likely to contract by 13.87 percent, the TIER said, predicting a trade surplus of US$25.05 billion for the year.
The sharp fall in international commodity prices will ease inflation significantly, with Taiwan's inflation rate projected at 0.17 percent for 2009, the report said.

Although government investment will increase by 26.96 percent thanks to the administration's efforts to promote public construction projects, fixed investment by the private sector is expected to drop by 11.53 percent as businesses delay or cut back on their capital expenditure, the report went on.

In terms of private consumption, the TIER predicted that there will be a slight growth of 0.62 percent, as the forced unpaid leave policy and workforce reduction by local businesses are taking a heavy toll on the public's purchasing power.

Further observation is required to judge the effect of the government's shopping voucher program and the recent influx of Chinese tourists on boosting private consumption, according to the TIER report.

Meanwhile, a survey conducted by the TIER in March on the business climate for the manufacturing sector shows that 42.8 percent of manufacturers think conditions will improve over the next six months, up from 36.6 percent recorded in a February survey.
A total of 18.6 percent of the respondents predicted that conditions worsen over the next six months, down from 24 percent in the previous month.
Meanwhile, 38.6 percent said they think conditions will remain the same, down from 39.4 percent in February.

According to the TIER, despite weak demand from the European and U.S. markets, shipments by Taiwan's electronics and machinery sectors are likely to pick up in the next six months thanks to rush orders from emerging markets.
The composite business climate indicator for the manufacturing sector stood at 105.59 in March, up 11.86 points compared with the previous month, the TIER report shows.
The composite business climate indicator for the service sector registered 103.26, up 9.78 points from February.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to launch on-board flu checks on flights from America

TEXT.P: Every flight from America that arrives in Taiwan from April 29 onward will be subject to a strict on-board screening procedure in an effort to prevent the entry of a new strain of swine influenza, the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) announced in a statement Tuesday.
The first flight to undergo the procedure will be EVA Airways flight BR017 from San Francisco, which is scheduled to land at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport at 5: 10 a.m. that day, the CDC said.

The statement said the CDC decided to take the unusual step under the instruction of Premier Liu Chao-shiuan and following a resolution of the Executive Yuan's command center for prevention of A/H1N1 swine flu outbreaks that have been reported in Mexico, the United States, Canada and several other countries.
CDC Deputy Director-General Shih Wen-yi said it is impossible to predict when the procedure will be lifted.
In addition to Taiwan, Japan has already taken the same measure for flights from Mexico, said Shih.

He continued that when an affected flight arrives at the airport, all passengers will be asked to stay in their seats until quarantine officials board the plane and give them a hygiene lecture and information on the new type of flu.
The officials will also screen every passenger and anyone with flu-like symptoms, including coughing and sore throat, will be kept on the plane for further checks, Shih said.
Those passengers allowed to leave the aircraft will still have to pass a temperature reader once inside the airport.

If the officials cannot eliminate the possibility of swine flu infection, those who are suspected of being infected will be taken directly to a hospital for further checks, Shih went on, adding that those who do not show signs of infection at the airport but who develop symptoms after entering the country will be requested to report to the CDC, he added.
According to border surveillance statistics, around 50 flights from the U.S. and Canada had landed over the past three days, bringing more than 15,000 travelers into the country.
Shih said five of the travelers were found to have a fever upon arrival, but all were declared uninfected with swine flu.
Meanwhile, the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau also activated an emergency checking mechanism Tuesday at the country's largest seaport.
The outbreaks in Mexico and the U.S. have prompted the World Health Organization to raise its alert level to phase 4 on a scale of six, indicating a significantly increased risk of pandemic.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese agricultural exports to China show marked growth

TEXT.P: The value of Taiwan's agricultural exports to China increased from US$66.4 million in 2002 to US$436.58 million in 2008, marking a 5.6-fold growth, a Council of Agriculture (COA) official said Tuesday.

Encouraged by this performance, described by the COA as "remarkable, " the COA has marked China as a target market for more Taiwanese agricultural products, said Chang Shu-hsien, who is in charge of international affairs at the COA.
As a result, Chang went on, the council has since last year been strengthening measures to promote Taiwan-grown fruit and vegetables to buyers in China.

This year, she went on, the COA plans to cooperate with traders in major cities in northern, central and southern regions of China in organizing promotional activities such as Taiwanese fruit festivals to attract Chinese consumers.

The council will also invite Chinese wholesalers to visit Taiwan and meet with local businessmen for talks on issues including opening a stable distribution channel between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Chang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan marks anniversary of Sino-Japan Peace Treaty

TEXT.P: The Republic of China marked the 57th anniversary of the Sino-Japanese Peace Treaty by unveiling a set of five statues Tuesday at Taipei Guest House, where the treaty was signed in 1952.
President Ma Ying-jeou presided over the unveiling of the statues which depict ROC Envoy George Yeh and his Japanese counterpart Isao Kawada inking the treaty while three other diplomats look on.
At Tuesday's ceremony, Ma stressed that the reenactment of the 1952 signing should serve as a reminder to the public that Taiwan belongs to the Republic of China.

Ma, who holds a doctorate in International Law from Harvard University, said the Sino-Japanese treaty was a followup to the Treaty of San Francisco concluded between Japan and the allied nations in 1951.

The ROC was not invited to sign the San Francisco treaty because it was engaged in a civil war with the People's Republic of China and there was disagreement among the allied nations over which side was the legitimate government of China.

"The Sino-Japanese Peace Treaty stated only that Japan renounced all rights to territories it had occupied by force, but did not specify that Taiwan should be ceded to any particular state, " Ma said, adding that "this was in line with the terms of the Treaty of San Francisco."

Since the territories occupied by Japan at the time were many, the signatories to the San Francisco treaty preferred that the territorial issues be resolved through separate agreements between the individual states and Japan, Ma said.
"This gave rise to many bilateral treaties between Japan and other countries on territorial rights," Ma said, citing as an example the treaty between Japan and Russia.
"The Sino-Japanese Treaty was concluded against a similar backdrop, and reading between the lines, one can easily see that the aim was to hand over Taiwan to the Republic of China." Ma said.
The treaty not only brought peace to Taiwan and Japan, but also ushered in a period of friendly relations between the two states, he added.
"The treaty is vital not only to Taiwan, but also to the whole region, " and the statues are a reminder of its value, the president stated.
"These statues will remind people who visit this house of how much we owe to those who drafted the treaty," he said.
Ma's comments took direct aim the argument by many pro-independence activists that Taiwan has not belonged to any state since Japan gave it up at the end of World War II.
These activists reject China's claim to the island and promote their Taiwan independence cause based on the argument that Japan did not hand over Taiwan to any other state.
The issue is often a contentious one in Taiwan, especially at election time when some politicians campaign on a platform of permanent separation between Taiwan and China.

Ma was obviously trying to tread a fine line between Beijing's view and that of the proponents of independence by saying that Taiwan belongs to the "Republic of China, " rather than "China, " which usually refers to the People's Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for April 29, 2009

TEXT.P: 2. Event: Strait Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung briefs

Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan on his Chinese mission. Date and Time:3 p.m.,Wednesday, April 29, 2009. Place: 15 flr., No. 2-2, Section 1, Jinan Road, Taipei City. DOC.HEADLINE: Daily number of Chinese tourists to be fixed below 5,000: premier

TEXT.P: The number of Chinese tourists visiting Taiwan should be limited to 5,000 per day to ensure the quality of their trips, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Tuesday.

Noting that Chinese made up 1 million of the 3.7 million foreign visitors to Taiwan last year, the premier said, however, his administration had not anticipated that the number would grow to the current 5,000 to 6,000 Chinese tourists per day.
"This influx results in a lower quality of service -- a problem that must be addressed urgently by the government." Liu said at a media gathering.
"We should not admit more tourists than we can accommodate and we need to improve our local tourism infrastructure," the premier said.

"The exact daily cap for the number of Chinese tourists should be determined jointly by the Ministry of the Interior and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, but I expect it to be below 5,000." Liu said.

In order to encourage Chinese tourists to make more comprehensive tours of the island, the premier said, his administration is mulling a revision of the pertinent regulations to allow groups of two or three people to visit rather, than the current minimum of five.

Liu made the statements two days after President Ma Ying-jeou asked the administration to impose a proper cap on the daily number of Chinese tourists, after he learned that there were not enough tour buses to meet demand.

When Taiwan's opening to Chinese tourists took effect on July 4, 2008, the government imposed a cap of 3,000 visitors per day, but the number has spiked in the lead up to China's May Day holiday, and local officials have raised the ceiling by transferring unused quotas from previous days.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Wednesday, moving up 30.81 points at 5,627.54 on a turnover of NT$3.77 billion (US$111.55 million).
The weighted price index lost 108.32 points, or 1.89 percent, to close at 5,596.73 Tuesday.
