"The treaty is vital not only to Taiwan, but also to the whole region, " and the statues are a reminder of its value, the president stated.
"These statues will remind people who visit this house of how much we owe to those who drafted the treaty," he said.
Ma's comments took direct aim the argument by many pro-independence activists that Taiwan has not belonged to any state since Japan gave it up at the end of World War II.
These activists reject China's claim to the island and promote their Taiwan independence cause based on the argument that Japan did not hand over Taiwan to any other state.
The issue is often a contentious one in Taiwan, especially at election time when some politicians campaign on a platform of permanent separation between Taiwan and China.

Ma was obviously trying to tread a fine line between Beijing's view and that of the proponents of independence by saying that Taiwan belongs to the "Republic of China, " rather than "China, " which usually refers to the People's Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Daily number of Chinese tourists to be fixed below 5,000: premier

TEXT.P: The number of Chinese tourists visiting Taiwan should be limited to 5,000 per day to ensure the quality of their trips, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Tuesday.

Noting that Chinese made up 1 million of the 3.7 million foreign visitors to Taiwan last year, the premier said, however, his administration had not anticipated that the number would grow to the current 5,000 to 6,000 Chinese tourists per day.
"This influx results in a lower quality of service -- a problem that must be addressed urgently by the government." Liu said at a media gathering.
"We should not admit more tourists than we can accommodate and we need to improve our local tourism infrastructure," the premier said.

"The exact daily cap for the number of Chinese tourists should be determined jointly by the Ministry of the Interior and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, but I expect it to be below 5,000." Liu said.

In order to encourage Chinese tourists to make more comprehensive tours of the island, the premier said, his administration is mulling a revision of the pertinent regulations to allow groups of two or three people to visit rather, than the current minimum of five.

Liu made the statements two days after President Ma Ying-jeou asked the administration to impose a proper cap on the daily number of Chinese tourists, after he learned that there were not enough tour buses to meet demand.

When Taiwan's opening to Chinese tourists took effect on July 4, 2008, the government imposed a cap of 3,000 visitors per day, but the number has spiked in the lead up to China's May Day holiday, and local officials have raised the ceiling by transferring unused quotas from previous days.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 29, or the fifth day of the fourth month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1429: French military leader and heroine Joan of Arc enters Orleans, France, and defeats English forces. She was later tried for heresy and witchcraft and was burned at the stake in Rouen.
1661: Cheng Cheng-kung, also known as Koxinga, a national hero and one of the Ming loyalists and resistance fighters against foreign invasion, claims Taiwan from the Dutch and chooses Anping (present-day Tainan) as his capital, in the hope of returning to mainland China one day to restore the Ming dynasty.
1667: John Arbuthnot, Scottish physician and writer, is born. He was noted for his satirical anti-Whig pamphlets published in 1712 as "Law Is a Bottomless Pit" and later retitled "The History of John Bull."
1769: Arthur Wellesley, Duke of Wellington, English soldier and later the prime minister known as the Iron Duke, is born. He defeated Napoleon at Waterloo.
1818: Alexander II, the czar of Russia who emancipated the serfs in 1861, is born. He was assassinated in 1881 after severe repression of political opposition.
1863: William Randolph Hearst, American newspaper and magazine publisher, is born. Beginning with the San Francisco Examiner in 1887, he built the world's largest publishing empire, comprised of 28 major newspapers.
1901: Hirohito, the Japanese emperor who advocated the country's unconditional surrender that ended World War II, is born. He renounced his divine status in 1946.
1903: After Russia refuses to leave Manchuria when the troops of other foreign powers withdraw from Chinese territory, and prior to the outbreak of the Russo- Japanese War, Chinese students studying in Japan meet in Tokyo and set up a "Resist Russia" volunteer corps.
1937: American chemist Wallace Hume Carothers commits suicide just two months after he patented nylon.
1942: Japanese troops capture the Burmese town of Lashio, cutting off the Burma Road between China and India.
1945: U.S. forces in Germany liberate 32,000 victims of the Nazi death camp at Dachau, just northwest of Munich.
1946: Former Japanese leaders are indicted in Tokyo as war criminals.
1948: Li Tsung-jen is elected vice president of the Republic of China in the republic's fourth ballot.
1957: The first nuclear reactor goes into operation in the United States.
1969: Hsu Peh-yuen, governor of the Central Bank of China, is released from office and succeeded by Yu Kuo-hwa, the incumbent minister of finance.
1975: The last U.S. troops are evacuated from Saigon as thousands of foreigners and South Vietnamese are ferried out by helicopter from the roof of the American embassy.
1976: Edward Y. Kuan, ROC vice minister of foreign affairs, is named by the Executive Yuan as first ambassador to South Africa.
1976: The Sino-U.S. Seminar on Food Science and Nutrition opens in Taipei with 24 food scientists attending.
1980: Alfred Hitchcock, the British-born film director and the silver screen's master of suspense, dies in Los Angeles at the age of 80.
1985: The space shuttle Challenger is launched, and Dr. Wang Kan-chuen becomes the first Chinese American astronaut in space.
1992: Bolivian Vice President Luis Ossio Sanjines officiates at the inauguration of the Bolivian Commercial and Financial Representative Office in Taipei.
1993: Representatives of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, sign three agreements and a joint accord at a historic meeting in Singapore; the agreements and accord went into effect on May 29.
1996: On the third anniversary of the Koo-Wang cross-strait talks, SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu appeals to mainland China not to postpone the second round of talks so that both sides can resume their pursuit of reunification.
1998: North Korea publishes an open letter by its leader Kim Jong-Il calling for unification with South Korea.
2000: Premier-designate Tang Fei checks out of Taipei Veterans General Hospital after fully recovering from surgery removing a benign thymoma on April 16.
2001: The Ministry of National Defense says that in accordance with relevant government laws, military generals on active service will not be allowed to travel to mainland China either for meetings or visits.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A workman who wants to perfect his work first sharpens his tools. When you are living in a country, you should serve those nobles and ministers in that country who are men of moral worth, and you should cultivate the friendship of the gentlemen of that country who are men of moral worth."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan invited to take part in World Health Assembly

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou announced Wednesday that Taiwan has been invited to take part in the upcoming World Health Assembly (WHA), a major step forward in Taiwan's campaign for meaningful participation in international organizations.

According to Department of Health Minister Yeh Ching-chuan, Taiwan received a letter from the World Health Organization (WHO) Tuesday night inviting it to participate as an observer in the annual meeting of the WHO's decision-making arm scheduled for May 18-27 in Geneva.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was traded at NT$33.676 at 11 a.m. Wednesday on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.119 from Tuesday's close.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan launches on-board flu checks on flights from North America

TEXT.P: Taiwan began to make on-board checks of passengers on flights arriving from the United States Wednesday in a bid to keep the swine flu virus at bay.

Quarantine officials from the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) boarded eight flights from Canada and the United States after they arrived at their gates at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport early Wednesday morning and asked passengers if they had flu-like symptoms, such as coughing or a sore throat.
Since none of the fewer-than-3,000 passengers gave positive answers, they were all allowed to leave the aircraft.
Two of the passengers, however, were found to have high temperatures when they passed a temperature sensor as they headed to the immigration counter.
The quarantine officials later let the two go after excluding the possibility that they were infected with swine flu.

The CDC announced Tuesday that every flight from the U.S. arriving in Taiwan beginning Wednesday would be subject to a strict on-board screening procedure, as health officials try to prevent the entry of the A/H1N1 virus that is suspected of being responsible for over 150 deaths in Mexico.

The CDC decided to take the unusual step at the instruction of Premier Liu Chao- shiuan and following a resolution of the Executive Yuan's command center to prevent A/H1N1 swine flu outbreaks that have been reported around the world.
The Department of Health (DOH) set up a central command center Tuesday to take preventive measures against the virus and cope with any local outbreaks.

Established at a meeting of cross-government agencies, the center will focus on strengthening surveillance for swine flu at boundary control points and raising travel warnings for the United States and Mexico and other areas affected by the virus, Health Minister Yeh Ching-chuan said.

The World Health Organization (WHO) on Monday raised its influenza pandemic alert from phase 3 to phase 4 -- just two levels short of a full-blown pandemic -- to indicate that there is sustained human-to-human transmission of the virus.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Former Marine Corps commander attempts suicide, life not threatened

TEXT.P: Former Marine Corps Commander Lt. Gen. Hsu Shang-wen, who had been disciplined for corruption allegations, attempted suicide at his residence in southern Taiwan Wednesday, a military source said.
Hsu, who stabbed himself twice at his home early Wednesday morning, was rushed to the Armed Forces Hospital in Zuoying, Kaohsiung County, for emergency treatment.
His wounds were not life-threatening, doctors at the military hospital said.

Hsu had been under investigation for allegedly taking bribes and receiving special treatment from private companies. He was given two demerits by the Ministry of National Defense Tuesday and was re-assigned, pending further investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan expects to join other WHO mechanisms besides IHR

TEXT.P: Taiwan expects to take part in more World Health Organization (WHO) information- sharing groups after it becomes an observer in the World Health Assembly (WHA) , the WHO's decision-making arm, a Taiwan health official said Wednesday.

Among the groups it expects to take part in include the International Health Regulations (IHR) , and five other information mechanisms, including the WHO's Food Safety Network (INFOSAN), said Yang Che-ming, director-general of Bureau of International Cooperation under the Department of Health.

It will also participate in the Global Outbreak Alert Response Network (GOARN), the Stop TB Partnership, the Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC) , and the International Collaboration and Prevention Combating Counterfeit Drugs (IMPACT), Yang said.
Taiwan was included in the IHR framework in early April -- which some attributed to improved ties with China.

Through its accession to the IHR -- a framework under the WHO devised to control the spread of infectious diseases around the globe -- Taiwan was able to directly contact WHO authorities for the first time and get first-hand information about avian flu prevention and control, food security, and the spread and control of other epidemic diseases.
As to Taiwan's participation in the other mechanisms, Yang said it was still too early to speculate how deeply Taiwan will be involved in activities in these groups.
There are currently six WHA observers, including the Holy See and the International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement, and Yang said the degree and content of their participation as observers vary.
"How Taiwan should take part in the WHA as an observer and to what degree will require further discussion," Yang noted.

Because of China's opposition, Taiwan had previously been excluded from the IHR, even though a "universal application" phrase was introduced in the regulations in 2005 with the firm support of the United States and Taiwan's diplomatic allies, and the encouragement of the EU and Japan.
In the past, Taiwan was only able to obtain information on outbreaks of communicable diseases or emergencies in the region, including in China and Hong Kong, on a secondhand basis.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan invited to attend World Health Assembly (update)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou announced Wednesday that Taiwan has been invited to take part as an observer in the upcoming World Health Assembly (WHA) , a major step forward in Taiwan's campaign for meaning participation in international organizations.

Taiwan's possible presence at the annual meeting of the decision-making arm of the World Health Organization (WHO) will mark the first time that the country has been allowed to participate in a meeting or activity of United Nations specialized agencies since losing its U.N. membership to China in 1971.
This is also the first time Taiwan will be allowed to take part in the WHA after 12 failed attempts at WHA participation since 1997.

Ma attributed the achievement to the goodwill displayed by Beijing toward Taiwan after the inauguration last May of his administration, which has been working to improve cross-Taiwan Strait ties and has adopted a moderate approach to promote foreign relations.

Ma also praised the strong support of prominent members of the international community, including the United States, Japan, the European Union, Southeast Asia, Australia and New Zealand, as helping with the campaign.
Efforts made by various groups in Taiwan regardless of political affiliation also made important contributions to the cause, Ma said.

"Participation in the activities of the WHO is not merely a political issue. More importantly, it is a human rights issue, and the health and medical rights of Taiwan's 23 million people should not get overlooked, " the president said during a high-level meeting attended by administration officials.

According to Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yeh Ching-chuan, Taiwan received a letter from the WHO Tuesday night inviting it to attend as an observer in the WHA's annual meeting scheduled for May 18-27 in Geneva.
The letter, addressed to Yeh and signed by WHO Director-General Margaret Chan, extends the invitation to "the Department of Health, Chinese Taipei."
"I would appreciate if you could confirm the attendance of the Department of Health, Chinese Taipei, and the names of the attendees at your earliest convenience," the letter read.

Analysts said the use of the name "Chinese Taipei" by the WHO could signify a policy change by the world body, which had previously stuck to the name "Taiwan, China" or "Taiwan, province of China" in its official documents to reflect the United Nations' "one China" policy.

Yeh explained that obtaining observer status in the WHA will enable Taiwan to maintain direct contact with the WHO to exchange information on disease control and prevention, better protecting the health and safety of the people in Taiwan.
Yeh said the DOH will assemble a 15-member delegation comprised of 12 health officials and three public health experts to attend the event, and that the team is expected to arrive in Geneva May 17.
Journalists from Taiwan are also expected to be allowed to cover this year's WHA for the first time in five years, he said.
Taiwanese journalists used to be able to cover the annual event, but authorization was withdrawn in 2004 under pressure from China, on grounds that Taiwan is not a member of the United Nations.

Taiwan has not been represented in the United Nations since 1971, when the Republic of China's seat was given to the People's Republic of China, and it has tried unsuccessfully -- thanks to Beijing's objections -- to have the United Nations consider the issue of its representation since 1993.

Unlike in 2007, when Taiwan made a high-profile push for full membership under the name "Taiwan, " the country promoted a bid in 2008 to "participate meaningfully in the activities of the U.N. specialized agencies, " in line with Ma's "modus vivendi" diplomatic strategy that favors a moderate and pragmatic approach.
Ma first disclosed in March that representatives of Taiwan and China would meet overseas in April to discuss issues concerning Taiwan's participation in the WHA.
As to the membership name preferred by the government in joining international organizations, Ma said the country's official name of "the Republic of China" remains the government's top choice.
Coming in second would be "Taiwan, " followed by "Chinese Taipei" -- the name used by Taiwan when competing in the Olympic Games and many other sports events, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local pharmaceutical companies prepare to develop swine flu vaccine

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been in contact with the United States, seeking samples of the H1N1 swine flu virus strain so that local pharmaceutical companies can start developing a human vaccine against the virus that emerged in Mexico last week, Health Minister Yeh Chin-chuan said Wednesday.
Yeh said at the Legislative Yuan that the Department of Health (DOH) has also instructed the non-profit National Health Research Institute (NHRI) to prepare for developing the vaccine.

He said the NHRI is capable of producing vaccine in emergency situations and that an expanded vaccine plant run by Adimmune Corp., also known as Kuo Kwang Biotechnology, is expected to be inaugurated by June.

The Adimmune vaccine plant, which will be the largest of its kind in Asia with a maximum annual capacity of 30 million doses of vaccine, will allow production of human vaccine against swine flu to be significantly ramped up, Yeh noted.
Noting that the World Health Organization (WHO) is working on a global H1NI vaccine production plan, Yeh said the country will take part in the global action in line with WHO instructions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local company can produce 24M doses of flu vaccine in six months

TEXT.P: Local biopharmaceutical firm Adimmune Corp. officials said Wednesday that the company will cancel all existing orders and shift exclusively to the production of a human vaccine against H1N1 swine flu if asked to do so by the government.
A spokesman said that once Adimmune receives samples of the H1N1 swine flu virus strain, it will be capable of churning out up to 24 million doses of swine flu vaccine in three to six months.

The expansion of an Adimmune influenza vaccine plant is scheduled to be completed in June and will be capable of producing 30 million doses of flu vaccine a year -- a capacity far exceeding the approximately 3 million doses per year that Taiwan has actually needed in terms of flu vaccine in the past prior to the threat of a swine flu outbreak, said Lin Teh-kun, head of the business department of Adimmune Corp.
Adimmune, the only private human vaccine manufacturing company in Taiwan, has been mainly producing vaccines against influenza, Japanese encephalitis, tetanus and tuberculosis.

A current Good Manufacturing Practices (CGMP) biopharmaceutical manufacturing facility endorsed by the Cabinet-level Department of Health, Adimmune is poised to become the largest human vaccine producing company in Asia when its expanded facilities come online in June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nearly US$16 million worth of Taiwan's shopping vouchers unclaimed

TEXT.P: It's free money that many people would love to snap up, but in Taiwan, more than 147,000 people have not picked up their share of shopping vouchers issued by the government to stimulate domestic spending, it was announced Wednesday.

As of Wednesday, with only one day to go before the deadline for collection, vouchers worth more than NT$530 million (US$15.74 million) have yet to be collected, according to statistics released by Chunghwa Post Co.

Chen Tzu-teh, vice president of the state-run postal company, said the number of uncollected vouchers is still lower than expected, pointing out that 99.36 percent of the vouchers issued have been collected.
He urged their rightful recipients to come forward to collect them at designated post offices before business closes Thursday.

The vouchers were given out earlier this year as part of an economic stimulus package to boost consumer spending and economic growth in light of the current economic downturn, which has hit export-dependent Taiwan hard.

All Taiwanese citizens -- with the exception of those living abroad without identity cards, household registration or residency rights -- and their foreign spouses are eligible to each receive NT$3,600 in vouchers.
The vouchers must be exchanged for goods or services by Sept. 30, 2009.

Data from the Ministry of Finance show that as of April 20, more than NT$65.53 billion, or 78.26 percent, of the total of NT$83.73 billion vouchers issued had been used by consumers and cashed by the businesses that received them.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's share prices marginally higher

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices edged higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, gaining 17.33 points, or 0.3 percent, to close at 5,614.06.
Rebounding after two sessions of decline, the local bourse opened at 5,627.54 and fluctuated between 5,649.24 and 5,571.93.
A total of 5.28 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$112.49 billion (US$3.34 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 3.1 percent. Banking and financial shares and plastics and chemicals shares advanced 1.2 percent each, construction stocks rose 0.8 percent, and paper and pulp issues surged 0.1 percent.

Three other major stock categories lost ground, with textile shares moving down the most at 1.2 percent. Cement stocks dropped 0.3 percent, and machinery and electronics shares shed 0.2 percent. Gainers outnumbered losers 1,330 to 784, with 140 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyer of shares worth NT$10.03 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, falling NT$0.137 to close at NT$33.658.
A total of US$959 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.795 and fluctuated between NT$33.645 and NT$33.800.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China to negotiate on LED, flat panel product specs

TEXT.P: Taiwan will negotiate with China to establish unified standards for digital television, light-emitting diode (LED) , and flat panel display products in a fourth round of talks between the two sides, a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) official said Tuesday.

Cooperation on unified product standards and certification systems will be put on the agenda of the fourth round of talks between Taiwan and China, expected to take place in the second half of the year, according to Chen Jay-san, director of the MOEA's Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection (BSMI).

Negotiations will cover establishing joint product standards and testing, inspection and certification systems, developing certification and metrology techniques, and supervising and managing markets, Chen said.

Part of the effort to create uniform standards, especially for more advanced technologies, across the Taiwan Strait is to help Taiwan become more competitive in the rapidly expanding market, Chen said.

Chen made the remarks at a forum on the development of flat panel standards attended by several flat panel manufacturers and the Taiwan Accreditation Foundation, the Taiwan Digital TV Alliance and the Industrial Technology Research Institute's Center for Measurement Standards.

During the forum, AU Optronics and Chi Mei Optoelectronics, Taiwan's two largest LCD manufacturers, indicated that standards and measurement standardization could be established for flat panel industries in Taiwan and China, which would help reduce production costs and better ensure product quality.

A series of standards for the industry developed by the International Organization for Standards (ISO) , the International Electrotechnical Committee (IEC), and the Semiconductor Equipment and Materials International (SEMI) already exist, according to Chen.

The most important question for the two sides across the Taiwan Strait is how to integrate Taiwan's edge in research and manufacturing technology and China's vast market to create more clout in developing standards for international use, Chen noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEMG has sold US$700 million-worth of products in Taiwan: FSC head

TEXT.P: Some 16,000 people in Taiwan have purchased structured notes and investment funds from the U.S.-based Private Equity Management Group (PEMG) , which is mired in a fraud scandal, the Finance Supervisory Commission (FSC) chairman said Wednesday.

Sean Chen revealed the figures at a Legislative Yuan Finance Committee meeting in response to questions about the PEMG case, including that of whether the investors will be able to recover their money.

Some legislators expressed doubt as to whether the FSC can freeze PEMG assets in Taiwan, to which Chen responded that the FSC has asked the banks that introduced PEMG products into Taiwan to draw up plans by May 1 to protect the affected investors.

He stated that the commission is still trying to find out how PEMG sold investment policies and said that if the financial products still have any value, there is hope that the investors will be able to claim their money back.

Chen noted that the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission has already taken action to freeze PEMG's assets and that in Taiwan, the FSC has asked the relevant banks to organize a task force to investigate PEMG's local financial condition and to take legal action against the group if necessary.

The FSC has also reached a consensus with the U.S. authorities to take joint action to trace all PEMG's business operations and has come up with a resolution that the involved banks should inform their clients of the details and future developments of the case, Chen said.

According to a foreign wire report, the U.S. authorities last week accused PEMG and its founder and former chief executive Danny Pang of bilking investors by falsely portraying returns as coming from investments in timeshare real estate and seniors' life insurance policies, when in fact Pang was operating a Ponzi scheme whereby investors were paid using funds raised from newer investors.

Pang, a Taiwan-born American, was arrested Tuesday by the FBI on charges that he withdrew about US$360,000 from a company account through several dozen small transactions so that he would not have to report the money to federal regulators.

As most of Pang's investors are from Taiwan, the case has been described locally as "Taiwan's Bernard Madoff storm, " referring to the former American businessman and former non-executive chairman of the NASDAQ stock exchange who was convicted of operating a Ponzi scheme that has been called the world's largest investor fraud ever committed by a single individual.

DOC.HEADLINE: No hidden agenda with China on WHA discussions: MOFA

TEXT.P: Deputy Foreign Minister Andrew Hsia said Wednesday that there is no hidden agenda or conditions in discussions between Taiwan and China on Taipei's participation as an observer in the upcoming World Health Assembly (WHA) in May.
"I can say with conviction that there is no secret arrangement or hidden agenda regarding Taiwan's participation in the WHA," Hsia said in a meeting with the local press.

However, he declined to divulge details of the cross-Taiwan Strait discussions on the issue, saying only that "health officials of both sides of the strait have exchanged pragmatic views on related issues."

Describing the fact that Taiwan received an invitation April 28 from the World Health Organization (WHO) Secretariat to take part in this year's WHA meeting as an observer as "a good result and something that we want, " Hsia said it also shows that China is demonstrating goodwill on the matter.

The deputy foreign minister said he expects to continue receiving annual invitations from the WHO Secretariat for Taiwan to attend the meeting "almost as a matter of course" and expressed belief that there will be no interruption in Taiwan's participation, as the country will enjoy the same rights and obligations as other WHA observers.
The annual meeting of WHA -- the decision-making arm of the WHO -- is scheduled for May 18-27 in Geneva.

Taiwan's presence will mark the first time the country has been allowed to participate in a meeting or activity of United Nations specialized agencies since losing its U.N. membership to China in 1971 and will also be the first time the country has been allowed to take part in the WHA after 12 failed attempts at WHA participation since 1997.

Attributing the positive result mainly to the thawing in cross-Taiwan Strait relations since President Ma Ying-jeou took office last May, Hsia said, however, that it should not be viewed as the only reason for the achievement, as strong support from major countries around the world and the Foreign Ministry's hard work have also played significant roles.

"Many countries have also told us that they do not wish to see China as the only reason for Taiwan being able to participate in the WHA," he went on, but rather to see other international factors taken into consideration by the WHO's decision-making body when dealing with the matter.
Hsia said the supporting countries were all informed of the result immediately after Taiwan received the letter from WHO Director-General Margaret Chan Tuesday.
Asked about Taiwan's next step, Hsia said Taiwan will participate in all meetings of the WHA and try its best to make contributions.
"It has not been an easy path for us to come to this point and we have to prove that we are a worthy participant," he said.

As to how the result could affect Taiwan's attempt to participate in the United Nations in September, Hsia said the Foreign Ministry is still studying the issue and has yet to draw up a plan on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japan pleased to see Taiwan's acceptance into WHA meeting

TEXT.P: Japan is pleased to see that Taiwan has been invited to participate as an observer in this years World Health Assembly (WHA) in May, as Tokyo has long been a supporter of Taiwan's involvement, Naohiro Tsutsumi, director-general of the Interchange Association Taipei Office said Wednesday.
Japan welcomes and is pleased to see such a result. We also expect to cooperate with Taiwan on public health issues in World Health Organizations (WHOs) technical activities, Tsutsumi told the CNA.
The Interchange Association serves as the de facto Japanese embassy in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between Taiwan and Japan.

President Ma Ying-jeou announced Wednesday that Taiwan has been invited to take part in the upcoming WHA, which is a major step forward in Taiwans campaign for meaningful participation in international organizations.

According to Department of Health Minister Yeh Ching-chuan, Taiwan received a letter from the WHO Tuesday night inviting it to attend as an observer the WHAs annual meeting scheduled for May 18-27 in Geneva.
It will be the first time Taiwan will be allowed to take part in the WHA after 12 failed attempts at WHA participation since 1997.

Taiwans presence at the annual meeting of the decision-making arm of the WHO will mark the first time that the country has been allowed to participate in a meeting or activity of a United Nations specialized agency since losing its U.N. membership to China in 1971.

Asked what contributed to the result, Tsutsumi said that among many reasons, improvement of relations between Taiwan and China and cross-Taiwan Strait communications, as well as international support were crucial to the development.
However, the most important reason is Taiwans steady and persistent efforts over the past 12 years to fight for inclusion in WHO meetings and activities, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to open financial markets to China QDII investors

TEXT.P: Taiwan will open its stock and futures markets to qualified direct institutional investors (QDIIs) from China beginning later this year, in a bid to attract more foreign investment and prop up the local financial market, Vice Premier Chiu Cheng-hsiung said Wednesday.
The move is expected to lead to an influx of US$1.12 billion from QDIIs into Taiwan's stock market in the first year, according to estimates from industry observers.

It will be a much-needed cash injection into the local bourse, which has dropped more than 3,500 points from 9,287 points July 31, 2007, - one of the worst falls of stock markets worldwide during this period.

As to the scope in which Chinese investors may invest in Taiwan, that is expected to be announced in one to two months, Chiu said at a forum on financial memorandums of understanding (MOUs) across the Taiwan Strait, as well as financial reform.

Meanwhile, Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) Chairman Sean Chen said at a legislative session that the commission, in collaboration with Taiwan's central bank, will map out relevant rules to pave the way for Chinese QDIIs to invest in Taiwan's financial market, such as the investment amount, and the rights to operate and serve as members of the board of directors and supervisors.

After Taiwan and China sign MOUs for cooperation in the supervision of banking, securities, and insurance, scheduled in the second quarter this year, China is also expected to lift the cap on QDII investment in Taiwan from 3 percent to 10 percent of Chinese QDII funds in the financial market, which is estimated to be at NT$30 billion.
If QDII funds are used to buy shares of Taiwan's financial institutions, a cap on the investment amount will be imposed by Taiwan, Chen added.

Allowing the institutional investors into Taiwan's stock, futures and financial markets will be the latest in a recent string of market-opening measures adopted by Taiwan and mainland China after relations between the two sides began improving last year.

Since Taiwan's new government took office last May, it has lifted the cap on China-bound investment by Taiwanese companies from 40 percent to 60 percent of the company's total assets, and has been working to relax other economic and financial regulations in an attempt to strengthen Taiwan's competitiveness, Chiu said.

Other areas of relaxation include allowing companies listed in the Hong Kong stock market to list in Taiwan. In one example of the effects of such a move, Want Want China, the Hong Kong-listed unit of Taiwan's food giant Want Want Group, began to have its Taiwan depositary receipts (TDRs) traded on Taiwan's stock market Tuesday, according to Chiu.

After Want Want started its debut trading, many more Taiwanese businesses are expected to come back to list in Taiwan to give local financial markets a shot in the arm, according to Former Minister Without Portfolio Chu Yun-peng, who resigned a few days ago for going on dates during office hours. He was also speaking at the forum.

DOC.HEADLINE: Flu outbreak may delay 2009 World Games in Kaohsiung: official

TEXT.P: The 2009 World Games, scheduled to take place July 16-26 in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, may have to be suspended or delayed if the current outbreak of swine flu in North America develops into a pandemic, the CEO of the event's organizing committee said Wednesday.

Hsu Chao-juan, director-general of the World Games organizing committee under the Kaohsiung city government, said that her committee is preparing for the worst, and that if the flu situation escalates, the committee will consider suspending or postponing the world games.
Hsu disclosed that committee members will meet with officials from the International World Games Association May 5 to discuss contingency plans in the event of a global flu pandemic.

According to wire service reports from North America, the current flu outbreak, caused by a new version of the A/H1N1 virus strain, has caused 2,498 infections and 159 deaths in Mexico. The United States has reported 68 cases, including 45 in New York State, while Canada has reported 13 cases.
Kaohsiung, the second largest city in Taiwan, has been looking forward to playing host to at least 4,500 athletes from 82 countries during the 2009 World Games.
The city government has estimated that the World Games will attract at least 100,000 tourists to Kaohsiung to watch the various sports events and go sightseeing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government urged to safeguard Taiwan's dignity at WHA

TEXT.P: Civic groups in Taiwan asked the government Wednesday to clarify whether a 2005 memorandum of understanding (MOU) between China and the World Health Organization (WHO), which allows China to determine what information from the WHO should reach Taiwan, is still in effect.

Although Taiwan has been invited to attend the upcoming World Health Assembly (WHA) as an observer, this does not necessarily invalidate the MOU, said Lin Shih-chia, chief executive of the Foundation of Medical Professionals Alliance in Taiwan -- a front-runner in Taiwan's campaign for participation in the WHO.

It is possible that Taiwan is being admitted to the WHA as an observer under the China-WHO MOU framework, which would mean a degradation of Taiwan's status to that of a non-governmental organization like the Red Cross, Lin said.

He noted that among the current WHA observers, the Holy See is categorized as a state, while the Red Cross is regarded as an NGO, and Palestine is listed as a political entity under a special resolution.

Earlier in the day, Department of Health Minister Yeh Ching-chuan said that while Taiwan has been invited to join the 2009 WHA as an observer for the first time ever, it is so far not known how Taiwan's status will be classified.

According to Yeh, Taiwan's dignity was harmed by the secret China-WHO MOU that was concluded in 2005. Since then, Taiwan's public health experts have not been able to participate in international health meetings without permission from the WHO, and even then they have been listed as participants from "Taiwan Province, China," which falsely implies that Taiwan is part of China, he said.
The WHA invitation, addressed to Yeh and signed by WHO Director-General Margaret Chan, was extended to "the Department of Health, Chinese Taipei."
"I would appreciate if you could confirm the attendance of the Department of Health, Chinese Taipei, and the names of the attendees at your earliest convenience," the letter read.
Yeh said that the use of the name "Chinese Taipei" in the WHA would not imply that Taiwan is part of China.

Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs Andrew Hsia welcomed the invitation for Taiwan to participate in the WHA under the name "Chinese Taipei, " saying that this is in line with the "expectations of the Taiwan people."
It is the designation that Taiwan uses in major international organizations, including the International Olympic Committee and the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, he noted.

Responding to Lin's concerns, Centers for Disease Control Director General Steve H. S. Kuo said the WHO removed the secret MOU barrier when it brought Taiwan into the International Health Regulations (IHR) framework in January. This gave Taiwan access to the WHO international information network on quarantine, food safety and tobacco hazards, he said.
Kuo, however, said he is not aware that the China-WHO MOU has been invalidated. "The next challenge for Taiwan is to resolve this issue," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: World Games, Deaflympics may be deferred if H1N1 outbreak worsens

TEXT.P: Two major sports events scheduled to be held in Taiwan this summer may be deferred if the current global H1N1 new swine flu outbreaks reach a peak during that period, the country's top sports administrator said Wednesday.
"We won't rule out the possibility of postponing the 2009 World

Games slated for July 16-26 in Kaohsiung and the 21st Summer Deaflympics to be held in Taipei Sept.5-15 if the new swine flu outbreaks peak during the scheduled times, " said Sports Affairs Council (SAC) Minister Tai Hsia-ling.

Tai made the remarks after the World Health Organization (WHO) raised its influenza pandemic alert Monday from phase 3 to phase 4 -- just two levels short of a full-blown pandemic -- to indicate that there is sustained human-to-human transmission of the new flu virus.
Acknowledging that Taiwan has put a lot into securing the rights to host the two major world sports extravaganzas, Tai said the government is unlikely to postpone them lightly.

"Nevertheless, in the face of the new swine flu outbreaks in Mexico and several other countries, we must be prepared for the worst, " Tai said. "If the situation gets worse, we'll seek a professional assessment, and postponement of the two sports events will be the last resort."
Tai said that she was so worried by WHO health experts' forecast Monday that the H1N1 outbreak could hit a peak in September, she couldn't sleep.
Stressing that public health should always be given top priority, Tai said the SAC will deal with any epidemic situation in the most serious manner.

According to Tai, the World Games organizing committee has staged several anti- terrorism drills in light of the attacks on the Sri Lankan cricket players in Pakistan earlier this year and knowing that many Middle Eastern countries may take part in the World Games.

The organizing committee has also staged anti-epidemic exercises, with a focus on dengue fever prevention because outbreaks of the mosquito-borne disease have been reported in the southern port city of Kaohsiung in recent years, Tai said.
"Given the new epidemic situation, the organizing committee will include H1N1 swine flu prevention in future anti-epidemic drills, " Tai added.

Moreover, Tai said, the sports council will keep close tabs on local sports teams that plan to go abroad for competitions or exchanges, particularly those bound for the swine flu-affected areas, and will provide them with information on prevention of the disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health authorities warn against hoarding of face masks

TEXT.P: Health authorities warned business owners Wednesday not to hoard protective face masks in anticipation of higher prices amid a swine flu outbreak, saying that they could face lengthy prison terms and harsh fines.

Shih Wen-yi, spokesman for the Center for Disease Control and Prevention under the Cabinet-level Department of Health, gave the warning as the flu outbreak in Mexico has prompted fears that the disease might develop into a global pandemic.

Shih pointed out that according to Article 61 of the Communicable Disease Control Act, amended in July 2007, those who try to profiteer by stockpiling materials needed to fight against an ongoing epidemic or by hiking the prices of such materials are liable to a sentence of one to seven years in prison, plus a fine of NT$5 million (US$148,286).
Shih also urged the public not to rush to buy up face masks because Taiwan has an abundant supply of the product.

DOC.HEADLINE: Swine flu outbreak to be factored into president's overseas visits

TEXT.P: The outbreak of swine flu is being taken onto consideration as part of the planning for overseas visits by President Ma Ying-jeou, an official from the National Security Bureau (NSB) said Wednesday.

Acting NSB Director Tsai Teh-sheng made the remarks at a legislative committee meeting when asked about Ma's planned trips, amid reports that countries around the world have heightened alerts against swine flu as the number of confirmed cases continues to rise.

Political sources said last week that President Ma Ying-jeou planned to visit Central America twice between late May and July to attend presidential inaugurations in two countries with which Taiwan has diplomatic relations.

According to the travel plan, the president will depart Taiwan in late May for a week-long Central America visit that will take him to El Salvador to attend the inauguration of President-elect Mauricio Funes and to several of Taiwan's other allies in the region.
In July, the sources said, Ma is scheduled to visit Panama for three to four days, mainly to attend the inauguration of that country's next president.
Tsai said that since the first swine flu cases were reported, the NSB has stepped up collection of information on the new strain of the flu.

If infections are reported in countries that the president plans to visit, then the bureau will suggest that he seriously reconsider his trips, Tsai said, adding that it is "still too early to make a decision."

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier confident of riding out swine flu impact (roundup)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/09 23:56:23 (By Sofia Wu, Deborah Kuo and Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Wednesday that Taiwan, given its experience in fighting the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) outbreak in 2003, will be able to ride out any possible impact of a swine flu epidemic.
Liu made the remarks as Taiwan earlier in the day launched on-board checks of passengers on flights arriving from North America as part of its efforts to keep the new H1N1 swine flu virus at bay.

Noting that the government has fleshed out standards of operations for swine flu outbreaks, Liu said the post of the country's top epidemic prevention official will be upgraded if the World Health Organization (WHO) further raises its influenza pandemic alert.

The world health regulatory body raised its flu pandemic alert Monday from phase 3 to phase 4 -- just two levels short of a full-blown pandemic -- to indicate that there is sustained human-to-human transmission of the virus.

Meanwhile, opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Tsai Huang-liang urged the party's headquarters to consider deferring an anti- government protest scheduled for May 17 amid the current swine flu concerns.

"At a time when countries around the world are gearing up to fight the flu outbreaks, the ruling party will definitely misrepresent our motives if we assemble a large number of people to voice outrage over controversial government policies and measures, " Tsai said.
In response to the legislator's suggestion, DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said she will direct the party's staff members to review the situation and will make a final decision later.

Earlier in the day, Department of Health Minister Yeh Ching-chuan said Taiwan has been in contact with the United States, seeking samples of the H1N1 swine flu virus strain so that local pharmaceutical companies can start developing a human vaccine against the virus that emerged in Mexico last week.
Yeh said at the Legislative Yuan that the Department of Health (DOH) has also instructed the non-profit National Health Research Institute (NHRI) to prepare for developing the vaccine.

He said the NHRI is capable of producing vaccine in emergency situations and that an expanded vaccine plant run by Adimmune Corp., also known as Kuo Kwang Biotechnology, is expected to be inaugurated by June.

The Adimmune vaccine plant, which will be the largest of its kind in Asia with a maximum annual capacity of 30 million doses of vaccine, will allow production of human vaccine against swine flu to be significantly ramped up, Yeh noted.

In the meantime, Sports Affairs Council Minister Tai Hsia-ling said two major sports events scheduled to be held in Taiwan this summer may be deferred if the current global H1N1 new swine flu outbreaks reach a peak during that period.
"We won't rule out the possibility of postponing the 2009 World
Games slated for July 16-26 in Kaohsiung and the 21st Summer Deaflympics to be held in Taipei Sept.5-15 if the new swine flu outbreaks peak during the scheduled times, " said Tai.

Meanwhile, health authorities warned business owners Wednesday not to hoard protective face masks in anticipation of higher prices amid a swine flu outbreak, saying that they could face lengthy prison terms and harsh fines.

Shih Wen-yi, spokesman for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention under the Cabinet-level Department of Health, gave the warning as the flu outbreak in Mexico has prompted fears that the disease might develop into a global pandemic.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local pharmaceutical companies prepare to develop swine flu vaccine

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been in contact with the United States, seeking samples of the H1N1 swine flu virus strain so that local pharmaceutical companies can start developing a human vaccine against the virus that emerged in Mexico last week, Health Minister Yeh Chin-chuan said Wednesday.
Yeh said at the Legislative Yuan that the Department of Health (DOH) has also instructed the non-profit National Health Research Institute (NHRI) to prepare for developing the vaccine.

He said the NHRI is capable of producing vaccine in emergency situations and that an expanded vaccine plant run by Adimmune Corp., also known as Kuo Kwang Biotechnology, is expected to be inaugurated by June.

The Adimmune vaccine plant, which will be the largest of its kind in Asia with a maximum annual capacity of 30 million doses of vaccine, will allow production of human vaccine against swine flu to be significantly ramped up, Yeh noted.
Noting that the World Health Organization (WHO) is working on a global H1NI vaccine production plan, Yeh said the country will take part in the global action in line with WHO instructions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local company can produce 24M doses of flu vaccine in six months

TEXT.P: Local biopharmaceutical firm Adimmune Corp. officials said Wednesday that the company will cancel all existing orders and shift exclusively to the production of a human vaccine against H1N1 swine flu if asked to do so by the government.
A spokesman said that once Adimmune receives samples of the H1N1 swine flu virus strain, it will be capable of churning out up to 24 million doses of swine flu vaccine in three to six months.

The expansion of an Adimmune influenza vaccine plant is scheduled to be completed in June and will be capable of producing 30 million doses of flu vaccine a year -- a capacity far exceeding the approximately 3 million doses per year that Taiwan has actually needed in terms of flu vaccine in the past prior to the threat of a swine flu outbreak, said Lin Teh-kun, head of the business department of Adimmune Corp.
Adimmune, the only private human vaccine manufacturing company in Taiwan, has been mainly producing vaccines against influenza, Japanese encephalitis, tetanus and tuberculosis.

A current Good Manufacturing Practices (CGMP) biopharmaceutical manufacturing facility endorsed by the Cabinet-level Department of Health, Adimmune is poised to become the largest human vaccine producing company in Asia when its expanded facilities come online in June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nearly US$16 million worth of Taiwan's shopping vouchers unclaimed

TEXT.P: It's free money that many people would love to snap up, but in Taiwan, more than 147,000 people have not picked up their share of shopping vouchers issued by the government to stimulate domestic spending, it was announced Wednesday.

As of Wednesday, with only one day to go before the deadline for collection, vouchers worth more than NT$530 million (US$15.74 million) have yet to be collected, according to statistics released by Chunghwa Post Co.

Chen Tzu-teh, vice president of the state-run postal company, said the number of uncollected vouchers is still lower than expected, pointing out that 99.36 percent of the vouchers issued have been collected.
He urged their rightful recipients to come forward to collect them at designated post offices before business closes Thursday.

The vouchers were given out earlier this year as part of an economic stimulus package to boost consumer spending and economic growth in light of the current economic downturn, which has hit export-dependent Taiwan hard.

All Taiwanese citizens -- with the exception of those living abroad without identity cards, household registration or residency rights -- and their foreign spouses are eligible to each receive NT$3,600 in vouchers.
The vouchers must be exchanged for goods or services by Sept. 30, 2009.

Data from the Ministry of Finance show that as of April 20, more than NT$65.53 billion, or 78.26 percent, of the total of NT$83.73 billion vouchers issued had been used by consumers and cashed by the businesses that received them.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's share prices marginally higher

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices edged higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, gaining 17.33 points, or 0.3 percent, to close at 5,614.06.
Rebounding after two sessions of decline, the local bourse opened at 5,627.54 and fluctuated between 5,649.24 and 5,571.93.
A total of 5.28 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$112.49 billion (US$3.34 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 3.1 percent. Banking and financial shares and plastics and chemicals shares advanced 1.2 percent each, construction stocks rose 0.8 percent, and paper and pulp issues surged 0.1 percent.

Three other major stock categories lost ground, with textile shares moving down the most at 1.2 percent. Cement stocks dropped 0.3 percent, and machinery and electronics shares shed 0.2 percent. Gainers outnumbered losers 1,330 to 784, with 140 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyer of shares worth NT$10.03 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, falling NT$0.137 to close at NT$33.658.
A total of US$959 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.795 and fluctuated between NT$33.645 and NT$33.800.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China to negotiate on LED, flat panel product specs

TEXT.P: Taiwan will negotiate with China to establish unified standards for digital television, light-emitting diode (LED) , and flat panel display products in a fourth round of talks between the two sides, a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) official said Tuesday.

Cooperation on unified product standards and certification systems will be put on the agenda of the fourth round of talks between Taiwan and China, expected to take place in the second half of the year, according to Chen Jay-san, director of the MOEA's Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection (BSMI).

Negotiations will cover establishing joint product standards and testing, inspection and certification systems, developing certification and metrology techniques, and supervising and managing markets, Chen said.

Part of the effort to create uniform standards, especially for more advanced technologies, across the Taiwan Strait is to help Taiwan become more competitive in the rapidly expanding market, Chen said.

Chen made the remarks at a forum on the development of flat panel standards attended by several flat panel manufacturers and the Taiwan Accreditation Foundation, the Taiwan Digital TV Alliance and the Industrial Technology Research Institute's Center for Measurement Standards.

During the forum, AU Optronics and Chi Mei Optoelectronics, Taiwan's two largest LCD manufacturers, indicated that standards and measurement standardization could be established for flat panel industries in Taiwan and China, which would help reduce production costs and better ensure product quality.

A series of standards for the industry developed by the International Organization for Standards (ISO) , the International Electrotechnical Committee (IEC), and the Semiconductor Equipment and Materials International (SEMI) already exist, according to Chen.

The most important question for the two sides across the Taiwan Strait is how to integrate Taiwan's edge in research and manufacturing technology and China's vast market to create more clout in developing standards for international use, Chen noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEMG has sold US$700 million-worth of products in Taiwan: FSC head

TEXT.P: Some 16,000 people in Taiwan have purchased structured notes and investment funds from the U.S.-based Private Equity Management Group (PEMG) , which is mired in a fraud scandal, the Finance Supervisory Commission (FSC) chairman said Wednesday.

Sean Chen revealed the figures at a Legislative Yuan Finance Committee meeting in response to questions about the PEMG case, including that of whether the investors will be able to recover their money.

Some legislators expressed doubt as to whether the FSC can freeze PEMG assets in Taiwan, to which Chen responded that the FSC has asked the banks that introduced PEMG products into Taiwan to draw up plans by May 1 to protect the affected investors.

He stated that the commission is still trying to find out how PEMG sold investment policies and said that if the financial products still have any value, there is hope that the investors will be able to claim their money back.

Chen noted that the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission has already taken action to freeze PEMG's assets and that in Taiwan, the FSC has asked the relevant banks to organize a task force to investigate PEMG's local financial condition and to take legal action against the group if necessary.

The FSC has also reached a consensus with the U.S. authorities to take joint action to trace all PEMG's business operations and has come up with a resolution that the involved banks should inform their clients of the details and future developments of the case, Chen said.

According to a foreign wire report, the U.S. authorities last week accused PEMG and its founder and former chief executive Danny Pang of bilking investors by falsely portraying returns as coming from investments in timeshare real estate and seniors' life insurance policies, when in fact Pang was operating a Ponzi scheme whereby investors were paid using funds raised from newer investors.

Pang, a Taiwan-born American, was arrested Tuesday by the FBI on charges that he withdrew about US$360,000 from a company account through several dozen small transactions so that he would not have to report the money to federal regulators.

As most of Pang's investors are from Taiwan, the case has been described locally as "Taiwan's Bernard Madoff storm, " referring to the former American businessman and former non-executive chairman of the NASDAQ stock exchange who was convicted of operating a Ponzi scheme that has been called the world's largest investor fraud ever committed by a single individual.

DOC.HEADLINE: No hidden agenda with China on WHA discussions: MOFA

TEXT.P: Deputy Foreign Minister Andrew Hsia said Wednesday that there is no hidden agenda or conditions in discussions between Taiwan and China on Taipei's participation as an observer in the upcoming World Health Assembly (WHA) in May.
"I can say with conviction that there is no secret arrangement or hidden agenda regarding Taiwan's participation in the WHA," Hsia said in a meeting with the local press.

However, he declined to divulge details of the cross-Taiwan Strait discussions on the issue, saying only that "health officials of both sides of the strait have exchanged pragmatic views on related issues."

Describing the fact that Taiwan received an invitation April 28 from the World Health Organization (WHO) Secretariat to take part in this year's WHA meeting as an observer as "a good result and something that we want, " Hsia said it also shows that China is demonstrating goodwill on the matter.

The deputy foreign minister said he expects to continue receiving annual invitations from the WHO Secretariat for Taiwan to attend the meeting "almost as a matter of course" and expressed belief that there will be no interruption in Taiwan's participation, as the country will enjoy the same rights and obligations as other WHA observers.
The annual meeting of WHA -- the decision-making arm of the WHO -- is scheduled for May 18-27 in Geneva.

Taiwan's presence will mark the first time the country has been allowed to participate in a meeting or activity of United Nations specialized agencies since losing its U.N. membership to China in 1971 and will also be the first time the country has been allowed to take part in the WHA after 12 failed attempts at WHA participation since 1997.

Attributing the positive result mainly to the thawing in cross-Taiwan Strait relations since President Ma Ying-jeou took office last May, Hsia said, however, that it should not be viewed as the only reason for the achievement, as strong support from major countries around the world and the Foreign Ministry's hard work have also played significant roles.

"Many countries have also told us that they do not wish to see China as the only reason for Taiwan being able to participate in the WHA," he went on, but rather to see other international factors taken into consideration by the WHO's decision-making body when dealing with the matter.
Hsia said the supporting countries were all informed of the result immediately after Taiwan received the letter from WHO Director-General Margaret Chan Tuesday.
Asked about Taiwan's next step, Hsia said Taiwan will participate in all meetings of the WHA and try its best to make contributions.
"It has not been an easy path for us to come to this point and we have to prove that we are a worthy participant," he said.

As to how the result could affect Taiwan's attempt to participate in the United Nations in September, Hsia said the Foreign Ministry is still studying the issue and has yet to draw up a plan on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japan pleased to see Taiwan's acceptance into WHA meeting

TEXT.P: Japan is pleased to see that Taiwan has been invited to participate as an observer in this years World Health Assembly (WHA) in May, as Tokyo has long been a supporter of Taiwan's involvement, Naohiro Tsutsumi, director-general of the Interchange Association Taipei Office said Wednesday.
Japan welcomes and is pleased to see such a result. We also expect to cooperate with Taiwan on public health issues in World Health Organizations (WHOs) technical activities, Tsutsumi told the CNA.
The Interchange Association serves as the de facto Japanese embassy in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between Taiwan and Japan.

President Ma Ying-jeou announced Wednesday that Taiwan has been invited to take part in the upcoming WHA, which is a major step forward in Taiwans campaign for meaningful participation in international organizations.

According to Department of Health Minister Yeh Ching-chuan, Taiwan received a letter from the WHO Tuesday night inviting it to attend as an observer the WHAs annual meeting scheduled for May 18-27 in Geneva.
It will be the first time Taiwan will be allowed to take part in the WHA after 12 failed attempts at WHA participation since 1997.

Taiwans presence at the annual meeting of the decision-making arm of the WHO will mark the first time that the country has been allowed to participate in a meeting or activity of a United Nations specialized agency since losing its U.N. membership to China in 1971.

Asked what contributed to the result, Tsutsumi said that among many reasons, improvement of relations between Taiwan and China and cross-Taiwan Strait communications, as well as international support were crucial to the development.
However, the most important reason is Taiwans steady and persistent efforts over the past 12 years to fight for inclusion in WHO meetings and activities, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to open financial markets to China QDII investors

TEXT.P: Taiwan will open its stock and futures markets to qualified direct institutional investors (QDIIs) from China beginning later this year, in a bid to attract more foreign investment and prop up the local financial market, Vice Premier Chiu Cheng-hsiung said Wednesday.
The move is expected to lead to an influx of US$1.12 billion from QDIIs into Taiwan's stock market in the first year, according to estimates from industry observers.

It will be a much-needed cash injection into the local bourse, which has dropped more than 3,500 points from 9,287 points July 31, 2007, - one of the worst falls of stock markets worldwide during this period.

As to the scope in which Chinese investors may invest in Taiwan, that is expected to be announced in one to two months, Chiu said at a forum on financial memorandums of understanding (MOUs) across the Taiwan Strait, as well as financial reform.

Meanwhile, Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) Chairman Sean Chen said at a legislative session that the commission, in collaboration with Taiwan's central bank, will map out relevant rules to pave the way for Chinese QDIIs to invest in Taiwan's financial market, such as the investment amount, and the rights to operate and serve as members of the board of directors and supervisors.

After Taiwan and China sign MOUs for cooperation in the supervision of banking, securities, and insurance, scheduled in the second quarter this year, China is also expected to lift the cap on QDII investment in Taiwan from 3 percent to 10 percent of Chinese QDII funds in the financial market, which is estimated to be at NT$30 billion.
If QDII funds are used to buy shares of Taiwan's financial institutions, a cap on the investment amount will be imposed by Taiwan, Chen added.

Allowing the institutional investors into Taiwan's stock, futures and financial markets will be the latest in a recent string of market-opening measures adopted by Taiwan and mainland China after relations between the two sides began improving last year.

Since Taiwan's new government took office last May, it has lifted the cap on China-bound investment by Taiwanese companies from 40 percent to 60 percent of the company's total assets, and has been working to relax other economic and financial regulations in an attempt to strengthen Taiwan's competitiveness, Chiu said.

Other areas of relaxation include allowing companies listed in the Hong Kong stock market to list in Taiwan. In one example of the effects of such a move, Want Want China, the Hong Kong-listed unit of Taiwan's food giant Want Want Group, began to have its Taiwan depositary receipts (TDRs) traded on Taiwan's stock market Tuesday, according to Chiu.

After Want Want started its debut trading, many more Taiwanese businesses are expected to come back to list in Taiwan to give local financial markets a shot in the arm, according to Former Minister Without Portfolio Chu Yun-peng, who resigned a few days ago for going on dates during office hours. He was also speaking at the forum.

DOC.HEADLINE: Flu outbreak may delay 2009 World Games in Kaohsiung: official

TEXT.P: The 2009 World Games, scheduled to take place July 16-26 in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, may have to be suspended or delayed if the current outbreak of swine flu in North America develops into a pandemic, the CEO of the event's organizing committee said Wednesday.

Hsu Chao-juan, director-general of the World Games organizing committee under the Kaohsiung city government, said that her committee is preparing for the worst, and that if the flu situation escalates, the committee will consider suspending or postponing the world games.
Hsu disclosed that committee members will meet with officials from the International World Games Association May 5 to discuss contingency plans in the event of a global flu pandemic.

According to wire service reports from North America, the current flu outbreak, caused by a new version of the A/H1N1 virus strain, has caused 2,498 infections and 159 deaths in Mexico. The United States has reported 68 cases, including 45 in New York State, while Canada has reported 13 cases.

The city government has estimated that the World Games will attract at least 100,000 tourists to Kaohsiung to watch the various sports events and go sightseeing.

Moreover, Tai said, the sports council will keep close tabs on local sports teams that plan to go abroad for competitions or exchanges, particularly those bound for the swine flu-affected areas, and will provide them with information on prevention of the disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health authorities warn against hoarding of face masks

TEXT.P: Health authorities warned business owners Wednesday not to hoard protective face masks in anticipation of higher prices amid a swine flu outbreak, saying that they could face lengthy prison terms and harsh fines.

Shih Wen-yi, spokesman for the Center for Disease Control and Prevention under the Cabinet-level Department of Health, gave the warning as the flu outbreak in Mexico has prompted fears that the disease might develop into a global pandemic.

Shih pointed out that according to Article 61 of the Communicable Disease Control Act, amended in July 2007, those who try to profiteer by stockpiling materials needed to fight against an ongoing epidemic or by hiking the prices of such materials are liable to a sentence of one to seven years in prison, plus a fine of NT$5 million (US$148,286).
Shih also urged the public not to rush to buy up face masks because Taiwan has an abundant supply of the product.

DOC.HEADLINE: Swine flu outbreak to be factored into president's overseas visits

TEXT.P: The outbreak of swine flu is being taken onto consideration as part of the planning for overseas visits by President Ma Ying-jeou, an official from the National Security Bureau (NSB) said Wednesday.

Acting NSB Director Tsai Teh-sheng made the remarks at a legislative committee meeting when asked about Ma's planned trips, amid reports that countries around the world have heightened alerts against swine flu as the number of confirmed cases continues to rise.

Political sources said last week that President Ma Ying-jeou planned to visit Central America twice between late May and July to attend presidential inaugurations in two countries with which Taiwan has diplomatic relations.

According to the travel plan, the president will depart Taiwan in late May for a week-long Central America visit that will take him to El Salvador to attend the inauguration of President-elect Mauricio Funes and to several of Taiwan's other allies in the region.
In July, the sources said, Ma is scheduled to visit Panama for three to four days, mainly to attend the inauguration of that country's next president.
Tsai said that since the first swine flu cases were reported, the NSB has stepped up collection of information on the new strain of the flu.

If infections are reported in countries that the president plans to visit, then the bureau will suggest that he seriously reconsider his trips, Tsai said, adding that it is "still too early to make a decision."

DOC.HEADLINE: WHA invitation raises Taiwan's international profile (roundup)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will attend this year's World Health Assembly as an observer under the name Chinese Taipei, marking a giant step forward in its quest for greater international participation.
It will mark the first time since its 1971 withdrawal from the United Nations wthat Taiwan has participated in a U.N. specialized agency's event.

President Ma Ying-jeou announced Wednesday that Taiwan has been invited to take part as an observer in the upcoming World Health Assembly (WHA), a major step forward in Taiwan's campaign for meaning participation in international organizations.

Taiwan's possible presence at the annual meeting of the decision-making arm of the World Health Organization (WHO) will mark the first time that the country has been allowed to participate in a meeting or activity of United Nations specialized agencies since losing its U.N. membership to China in 1971.
This is also the first time Taiwan will be allowed to take part in the WHA after 12 failed attempts at WHA participation since 1997.

Ma attributed the achievement to the goodwill displayed by Beijing toward Taiwan after the inauguration last May of his administration, which has been working to improve cross-Taiwan Strait ties and has adopted a moderate approach to promote foreign relations.

Ma also praised the strong support of prominent members of the international community, including the United States, Japan, the European Union, Southeast Asia, Australia and New Zealand, as helping with the campaign.
Efforts made by various groups in Taiwan regardless of political affiliation also made important contributions to the cause, Ma said.

"Participation in the activities of the WHO is not merely a political issue. More importantly, it is a human rights issue, and the health and medical rights of Taiwan's 23 million people should not get overlooked, " the president said during a high-level meeting attended by administration officials.

According to Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yeh Ching-chuan, Taiwan received a letter from the WHO Tuesday night inviting it to attend as an observer in the WHA's annual meeting scheduled for May 18-27 in Geneva.
The letter, addressed to Yeh and signed by WHO Director-General Margaret Chan, extends the invitation to "the Department of Health, Chinese Taipei."
"I would appreciate if you could confirm the attendance of the Department of Health, Chinese Taipei, and the names of the attendees at your earliest convenience," the letter read.

Analysts said the use of the name "Chinese Taipei" by the WHO could signify a policy change by the world body, which had previously stuck to the name "Taiwan, China" or "Taiwan, province of China" in its official documents to reflect the United Nations' "one China" policy.

Yeh explained that obtaining observer status in the WHA will enable Taiwan to maintain direct contact with the WHO to exchange information on disease control and prevention, better protecting the health and safety of the people in Taiwan.
Yeh said the DOH will assemble a 15-member delegation comprised of 12 health officials and three public health experts to attend the event, and that the team is expected to arrive in Geneva May 17.
Journalists from Taiwan are also expected to be allowed to cover this year's WHA for the first time in five years, he said.
Taiwanese journalists used to be able to cover the annual event, but authorization was withdrawn in 2004 under pressure from China, on grounds that Taiwan is not a member of the United Nations.

Taiwan has not been represented in the United Nations since 1971, when the Republic of China's seat was given to the People's Republic of China, and it has tried unsuccessfully -- thanks to Beijing's objections -- to have the United Nations consider the issue of its representation since 1993.

Unlike in 2007, when Taiwan made a high-profile push for full membership under the name "Taiwan, " the country promoted a bid in 2008 to "participate meaningfully in the activities of the U.N. specialized agencies, " in line with Ma's "modus vivendi" diplomatic strategy that favors a moderate and pragmatic approach.
Ma first disclosed in March that representatives of Taiwan and China would meet overseas in April to discuss issues concerning Taiwan's participation in the WHA.
As to the membership name preferred by the government in joining international organizations, Ma said the country's official name of "the Republic of China" remains the government's top choice.
Coming in second would be "Taiwan, " followed by "Chinese Taipei" -- the name used by Taiwan when competing in the Olympic Games and many other sports events, he said.
