DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 30, or the sixth day of the fourth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1770: David Thompson, the Canadian explorer who followed the Columbia River to its mouth in 1881 and mapped much of western Canada, is born in England.
1777: Karl Friedrich Gauss, the German mathematician and astronomer known for his contributions to algebra, differential geometry, probability theory and number theory, is born in Germany.
1789: George Washington is inaugurated as the first president of the United States in a ceremony at Federal Hall in New York.
1803: The United States buys Louisiana Territory and New Orleans from the French.
1893: Joachim von Ribbentrop, the German politician who was Adolf Hitler's foreign minister, is born.
1900: The republic of Hawaii cedes itself to the United States.
1909: Juliana, queen of the Netherlands from 1948, is born. She abdicated this day in 1980 in favor of her daughter Beatrix.
1919: The Paris Peace Conference allows Japan to take over Germany's prewar rights in China's Shantung Province, whereupon China leaves the conference.
1945: Adolf Hitler, the German dictator known as "Der Fuhrer" who reduced his country and much of Europe to ashes, commits suicide with his mistress Eva Braun after bidding farewell to the few aides remaining with him in his Berlin bunker hideaway.
1946: The national government of the Republic of China issues an order moving the national capital back to Nanking from Chungking.
1948: A total of 21 American nations sign the "Charter of Bogota," setting up the Organization of American States (OAS).
1957: Egypt reopens the Suez Canal to traffic.
1967: Muhammad Ali, who first won the world heavyweight boxing crown as Cassius Clay in 1964, is stripped of his title for refusing to be drafted into the U.S. armed forces.
1968: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek approves a set of "Guidelines for the Lives of Citizens" drafted by the National Committee of Chinese Cultural Renaissance Movement.
1973: U.S. President Richard Nixon accepts responsibility for the bugging that took place at the Watergate apartment complex in 1972.
1974: Adm. Maurice F. Weisner, commander in chief of the U.S. Pacific Fleet, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1975: The Vietnam War ends with South Vietnam's surrender to the communists after North Vietnamese tanks capture the Presidential Office in Saigon.
1977: Public and private buses begin joint operations in Taipei City.
1989: Finance Minister Shirley Kuo leads an ROC delegation to the 22nd annual Asian Development Bank meeting in Beijing.
1990: Elected ROC officials of all levels are permitted to make private visits to mainland China during recesses. Veterans who were stranded on the mainland after the nationalist government moved to Taiwan in 1949 are allowed to apply for resettlement in Taiwan.
1991: Cyclone hits Bangladesh, killing more than 125,000 people.
1991: ROC President Lee Teng-hui declares the termination of the Period of National Mobilization for Suppression of the Communist Rebellion, effective May 1. He abolishes the Temporary Provisions and promulgates the Additional Articles of the Constitution, also effective May 1.
1997: Trains collide at Rongchiawan Station in Yuehyang City, in mainland China's Hunan Province, killing 58 people and injuring hundreds of others.
1998: Secessionist rebels sign a permanent ceasefire with the Papua New Guinea government to end a nine-year rebellion on the South Pacific Island of Bougainville.
2000: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou inaugurates Taiwan's first tap water museum.
2001: The Second Asian Physics Olympiad concludes in Taipei after more than 10 days of competition with Seven gold medals, five silvers and 11 bronzes, as well as 16 honorary citations awarded to the winners.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If a man takes no thought for the morrow, he will be sorry before the day is out."

DOC.HEADLINE: Government urged to safeguard Taiwan's dignity at WHA

TEXT.P: Civic groups in Taiwan asked the government Wednesday to clarify whether a 2005 memorandum of understanding (MOU) between China and the World Health Organization (WHO), which allows China to determine what information from the WHO should reach Taiwan, is still in effect.

Although Taiwan has been invited to attend the upcoming World Health Assembly (WHA) as an observer, this does not necessarily invalidate the MOU, said Lin Shih-chia, chief executive of the Foundation of Medical Professionals Alliance in Taiwan -- a front-runner in Taiwan's campaign for participation in the WHO.

It is possible that Taiwan is being admitted to the WHA as an observer under the China-WHO MOU framework, which would mean a degradation of Taiwan's status to that of a non-governmental organization like the Red Cross, Lin said.

He noted that among the current WHA observers, the Holy See is categorized as a state, while the Red Cross is regarded as an NGO, and Palestine is listed as a political entity under a special resolution.

Earlier in the day, Department of Health Minister Yeh Ching-chuan said that while Taiwan has been invited to join the 2009 WHA as an observer for the first time ever, it is so far not known how Taiwan's status will be classified.

According to Yeh, Taiwan's dignity was harmed by the secret China-WHO MOU that was concluded in 2005. Since then, Taiwan's public health experts have not been able to participate in international health meetings without permission from the WHO, and even then they have been listed as participants from "Taiwan Province, China," which falsely implies that Taiwan is part of China, he said.
The WHA invitation, addressed to Yeh and signed by WHO Director-General Margaret Chan, was extended to "the Department of Health, Chinese Taipei."
"I would appreciate if you could confirm the attendance of the Department of Health, Chinese Taipei, and the names of the attendees at your earliest convenience," the letter read.
Yeh said that the use of the name "Chinese Taipei" in the WHA would not imply that Taiwan is part of China.

Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs Andrew Hsia welcomed the invitation for Taiwan to participate in the WHA under the name "Chinese Taipei, " saying that this is in line with the "expectations of the Taiwan people."
It is the designation that Taiwan uses in major international organizations, including the International Olympic Committee and the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, he noted.

Responding to Lin's concerns, Centers for Disease Control Director General Steve H. S. Kuo said the WHO removed the secret MOU barrier when it brought Taiwan into the International Health Regulations (IHR) framework in January. This gave Taiwan access to the WHO international information network on quarantine, food safety and tobacco hazards, he said.
Kuo, however, said he is not aware that the China-WHO MOU has been invalidated. "The next challenge for Taiwan is to resolve this issue," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: World Games, Deaflympics may be deferred if H1N1 outbreak worsens

TEXT.P: Two major sports events scheduled to be held in Taiwan this summer may be deferred if the current global H1N1 new swine flu outbreaks reach a peak during that period, the country's top sports administrator said Wednesday.
"We won't rule out the possibility of postponing the 2009 World

Games slated for July 16-26 in Kaohsiung and the 21st Summer Deaflympics to be held in Taipei Sept.5-15 if the new swine flu outbreaks peak during the scheduled times, " said Sports Affairs Council (SAC) Minister Tai Hsia-ling.

Tai made the remarks after the World Health Organization (WHO) raised its influenza pandemic alert Monday from phase 3 to phase 4 -- just two levels short of a full-blown pandemic -- to indicate that there is sustained human-to-human transmission of the new flu virus.
Acknowledging that Taiwan has put a lot into securing the rights to host the two major world sports extravaganzas, Tai said the government is unlikely to postpone them lightly.

"Nevertheless, in the face of the new swine flu outbreaks in Mexico and several other countries, we must be prepared for the worst, " Tai said. "If the situation gets worse, we'll seek a professional assessment, and postponement of the two sports events will be the last resort."
Tai said that she was so worried by WHO health experts' forecast Monday that the H1N1 outbreak could hit a peak in September, she couldn't sleep.
Stressing that public health should always be given top priority, Tai said the SAC will deal with any epidemic situation in the most serious manner.

According to Tai, the World Games organizing committee has staged several anti- terrorism drills in light of the attacks on the Sri Lankan cricket players in Pakistan earlier this year and knowing that many Middle Eastern countries may take part in the World Games.

The organizing committee has also staged anti-epidemic exercises, with a focus on dengue fever prevention because outbreaks of the mosquito-borne disease have been reported in the southern port city of Kaohsiung in recent years, Tai said.
"Given the new epidemic situation, the organizing committee will include H1N1 swine flu prevention in future anti-epidemic drills, " Tai added.

Moreover, Tai said, the sports council will keep close tabs on local sports teams that plan to go abroad for competitions or exchanges, particularly those bound for the swine flu-affected areas, and will provide them with information on prevention of the disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
MOFA reevaluating president's plans to visit Central America

TEXT.P: Deputy Foreign Minister Andrew Hsia said Thursday that in light of the swine flu outbreaks around the world, his ministry is reevaluating President Ma Ying- jeou's plans to visit Taiwan's Central American allies in June.

"We are evaluating the situation right now, making comprehensive assessments that are focused on the president's safety the outbreaks of swine flu," Hsia said before reporting to the Legislative Yuan's Foreign Affairs and National Defense Committee.
"We will make a decision in time for the president to make the final call," he added.

Ma is planning to visit Taiwan's Central American allies May 27-June 4 to attend the inauguration of El Salvador's President-elect Mauricio Funes on June 1 and is scheduled to also visit two other allies, Guatemala and Honduras.
However, the outbreak of the new H1N1 swine flu and its spread across the world has given rise to concerns about the president's safety on his planned trips.

Asked under what conditions the Foreign Ministry would consider postponing Ma's state visits, Hsia said it will depend on the number of new human infections in the countries that Ma is planning to visit and whether there is containment of the outbreaks.
"If unfortunately the outbreaks continue to spread, we will of course seriously consider postponing the visit," the deputy foreign minister said.

Ruling Kuomintang legislator Lin Yu-fang suggested during the interpellation session that while Ma's plans remain in place at the moment, the Foreign Ministry should inform the three countries that there is a possibility the president might cancel his trips.
Hsia said that Lin's suggestion is a good one and that his ministry will work on it.

While there have been no human infections of swine flu in Taiwan to date, the country is taking no chances and has instituted a number of precautions, including on-board checks of passengers on flights arriving from the United States.

In the face of the rapid escalation of the swine flu situation, the World Health Organization (WHO) early Thursday morning Taipei time raised its pandemic alert to Phase five -- the second-highest level -- which signals that a pandemic is imminent.

The WHO said that as of April 29, nine countries had officially reported 148 cases of swine influenza A/H1N1 infection, including 91 laboratory confirmed human cases and one death in the U.S. and 26 confirmed human cases of infection with seven deaths in Mexico.
Austria, Canada, Germany, Israel, New Zealand, Spain and the United Kingdom have all reported laboratory confirmed cases with no deaths.

DOC.HEADLINE: Regulations on Chinese investment to be released late May

TEXT.P: The regulations governing Chinese investment in Taiwan and the list of permitted fields of investment are expected to be released in late May, paving the way for Taiwan's official opening to investment from China, Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming said Thursday.
Yiin said the government will adopt a gradual approach in opening up to Chinese investment, with initially strict restrictions and an incremental expansion of the permitted fields.
In the initial stage, 63 industries in the manufacturing sector will be opened up, which will account for 30 percent of the total 212 businesses, Yiin said.
In the services sector, 24 industries will be opened up, accounting for 21 percent of the total 113, he said.
As to the infrastructure sector, 11 of the total of 812 categories will be liberalized, including airports, harbors, tourism and recreation, the minister said.
According to Yiin, the regulations will include a provision that bans any monopoly investment.

Opening Taiwan to Chinese investment was one of the understandings reached Sunday in Nanjing between the chief negotiators representing the respective sides -- Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits President Chen Yunlin.
The measure is expected to reverse the current one-way movement of investment from Taiwan to China and help normalize cross-Taiwan Strait trade and economic ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Rural St. Lucia residents get tap water with Taiwan's help
DOC.DATELINE: Washington-Castries, April 28 (CNA) 04/30/09 15:38:34 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: With the help of Taiwan, residents of the rural area of La Bourne, Saint Lucia recently got tap water for the first time ever, Taiwan's Ambassador to St. Lucia Tom Chou said Tuesday.

The tap water system was inaugurated last Saturday during a ceremony presided over by St. Lucia Prime Minister Stephenson King and attended by Chou, some 300 local residents and reporters, Chou told CNA in a telephone interview.
During the ceremony, King thanked Taiwan for its contribution to St. Lucia's economic and social development, and particularly its work in helping to build the country's infrastructure.
The results prove that his country's decision to resume diplomatic relations with Taiwan in 2007 was correct, the prime minister was reported as saying.
The La Bourne Water project was a joint undertaking by the governments of Saint Lucia and Taiwan.

A 70-year-old woman was quoted as saying that some 1,000 La Bourne residents had never used tap water before in their lives. Following old practices, they had been collecting rain water or carrying it from ponds filled with frogs and fish, she said.

"With the water supply being so precious, we had to make every drop count," the woman told Taiwanese embassy workers. She added that a lack of water is a hardship beyond the imagination of city people.

During the ceremony, Lennard Montoute, minister of St. Lucia's Sports and Public Services, emphasized the importance his country attached to the project, and expressed appreciation for the Taiwanese government's support.

Montoute said the project was completed in one year at a cost of nearly US$400,000, with the St. Lucia Social Development Fund contributing US$300,000 and the Taiwanese government giving about US$97,000.
Except for some technicians, all the workers on the project were from La Bourne, he said, adding that the project created a great number of jobs during its construction.

"This is an important moment in La Bourne, as local residents can enjoy the use of water in their homes from the convenience of their own faucets, " said Montoute. More importantly, more investments now are now expected to flow into the area to help boost local tourism and the economy, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Bear mother' urges action to save long-neglected black bears

TEXT.P: She is often called "Taiwan's Jane Goodall, " but she prefers the more modest "bear mother," a rough translation of the respectful nickname "ali duma" given to her by the Bunun tribe.

For more than a decade, Hwang Mei-hsiu, an assistant professor at National Pingtung University of Science and Technology, has devoted herself to studying and helping Taiwan better understand one of its national symbols -- the Formosan black bear.

Despite her efforts, this symbol, although voted Taiwan's most representative wildlife in a 2001 poll, could one day disappear from its native land if poaching, habitat encroachment, and government and public indifference continue.
It is an outcome Hwang is determined to prevent.
"We should do something quickly and urgently to turn around the bear's grim prospects. Otherwise, its fate will be sealed," said Hwang in a recent interview with the Central News Agency.

There are no clear figures on how many Formosan black bears remain in the wild because they live in remote mountainous areas that are hard to reach. They are also intelligent and elusive animals, which make them difficult to track.
But there is no doubt that their numbers are dwindling, Hwang said, citing Forestry Bureau surveys and discussions with aboriginal hunters, who report fewer sightings.

Historical records show that the bears roamed in low-altitude areas during the Japanese colonial occupation of Taiwan (1895-1945), but aboriginal hunters tell Hwang that the bears, listed as an endangered species by the enactment of the nation's Wildlife Protection Act in 1989, have now disappeared from traditional hunting grounds, possibly having fled to higher altitudes.

Hwang puts the estimate on the number of black bears remaining in Taiwan at between 200 and 700, way below the count of at least 2,000 that conservationists generally consider as a healthy number for large mammals.
"The number of the Formosan black bears has fallen mainly because of over- exploitation and habitat encroachment, " Hwang said.

Poaching remains serious, as evidenced by the continued use of wire snares and jaw traps to catch the bears, said Hwang, who tracked and tagged bears in their habitat in Dafen, at an elevation of 1,350 meters, in Yushan National Park from 1998-2000, and now returns there frequently.

Eight out of the 15 bears she and her team of volunteers found at Yushan National Park in the late 1990s were either pawless or toeless, as the bears had bitten off their extremities or lost them after being ensnared for too long.
She is also concerned that the bear's elusiveness may be their undoing.
The public, she worries, is more interested in more visible endangered animals, such as the Formosan landlocked salmon, green turtle, or the bird fairy pitta.

"The average person has no chance of encountering Formosan black bears because the animals live in remote mountainous areas and are rare and shy, " Hwang says. "But just because you haven't seen one doesn't mean it does not exist."
The government needs to get more involved if the Formosan black bear is to have a future, Hwang said, criticizing the efforts of past and present administrations as "slow and limited."

"The government has not really addressed the issue squarely, so it has never come up with a systematic and long-term plan. It has shown a lack of commitment to resolve the complicated questions involved in conservation efforts," Hwang said candidly.

One sign of the government's limited commitment is the NT$18 million (US$540,540) it has spent to conserve the species over the past five years. However, this largely went to raising the animals in captivity, and was lower than what is provided to protect more visible endangered species.

Unlike funding for other endangered animals, funding for the work of Hwang's team -the only group researching the Formosan black bears in the wild - is frequently interrupted because of bureaucratic vagaries.
The law also needs to support a long-term recovery plan and matching funds to maintain a sustainable bear population, she added.

Hwang made a name for herself with her study of the bears at Dafen in the late 1990s. Respected by Bunun tribesman because she was seen as "a woman who always lives in the mountains and takes care of the Formosan black bear."

Her study provided long-awaited baseline information on bears in the wild, including their seasonal movements, the range of their activities, and the food they consume, especially the acorn, the fruit of the ring-cupped oak.
Although many people mistake bears as carnivorous, they are actually mainly herbivores, Hwang noted.
Her Dafen research in late 1990s for her Ph.D. studies in the University of Minnesota made Hwang realize how important a steady flow of resources is to tracking the animal.
"It takes a lot of time, money and people to do the job," Hwang said when asked why she has not caught a bear since her return from the United States in 2003, despite monthly trips to Dafen.

To ensure that conservation efforts continue and become more effective, Hwang is preparing a 10-year NT$200 million proposal to submit to authorities to finance her team's long-term bear tracking activities and expand public education campaigns.
Tracking the bears requires funding, training and much effort, as Hwang learned during her research in the mountains in the late 1990s.

She and her team had to carry heavy backpacks and walk three days from the trailhead to Dafen. Although the distance is only 40 kilometers, they had to navigate very steep hills, cross old suspension bridges, and even heck their way through thick forest growth with machetes.
Laborious preparation work goes into setting up the team's harmless traps. Team members have to endure long and frequently fruitless periods waiting for the animals and then release them.

Though the working conditions of the Dafen station, which Hwang's team set up, has improved now with solar panel-powered electricity, Hwang or her students still need to hike to Dafen every month to monitor the installed infrared camera and check the traps to collect the hairs of the bears.
The hairs are then used for DNA analysis to develop estimates of the bears' population.

Over the years, Hwang has also devoted much of her time to educating the public about the importance of protecting the animals. She has given more than 100 speeches around the island since 2003 when she returned from the United States, where she earned her Ph.D.

One of the central themes of her speeches is to dispel ancient Chinese beliefs that could be harmful to the bears. According to the Chinese medicine Bible -- Ben Cao Kang Mud -- every part of the bear, whether it is the gall bladder, fat, meat, or blood, is useful as medicine. Bear paws also have long been regarded as a culinary delicacy.

Yang Chieh-chung, deputy director of the Council of Agriculture's Endemic Species Research Institute (ESRI), which has worked closely with Hwang on research on Formosan black bear in captivity, agreed with Hwang on the challenges Taiwan faces in protecting the animals.

"Aside from limited funding, finding researchers is also not easy because of the hardship involved. Long-term observation also means that they can't obtain tangible results as quickly as they want," Yang said.

Among the findings on bear by the researchers is that the animal snap wild silver grass stalks or any other available materials to make a comfortable resting place for itself, - a unique trait compared to other bear species. Formosan black bears also do not hibernate.
Hwang, Yang and others hope to continue to learn more about the bears to raise public awareness about them and ultimately save them from extinction.
What concerns them however, is whether humans can play a supportive, rather than destructive role, in the bears' survival.

"If the Formosan black bear continues to be ignored, it could end up facing the same fate as the clouded leopard and the river otter, " said Hwang, referring to two other animals thought to be extinct in the wild. ******** captions: 1.A female Formosan black bear is breastfeeding her two cubs at a research station of the Council of Agriculture's Endemic Species Research Institute in central Taiwan's Taichung County. Although a mother bear neither eats nor drinks for around two months after giving birth, it can use its stored energy to feed the cubs. 2.Formosan black bears are good at tree climbing. When encountering the bears in the wild, humans should not try to outclimb them, and should avoid making sudden movements out of panic, which can provoke an attack. Just slowly walk away backwards. 3.A Formosan black bear enjoys berries. Although many people mistakenly think bears are purely carnivorous, they are mainly herbivores. 4. DOC.HEADLINE: Premier calls for larger reserves of flu vaccines in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan on Thursday urged biopharmaceutical manufacturing companies in Taiwan, which are capable of producing human vaccines, to begin developing a vaccine against swine flu as soon as possible.

Liu advised the companies to quickly acquire samples of the A/H1N1 swine flu virus strain from the United States so they can produce a swine flu vaccine locally, to help Taiwan acquire enough reserves to keep at bay the virus that emerged in Mexico last week.
"The government will purchase these newly-developed swine flu vaccines at reasonable prices, " Liu said while presiding over an emergency meeting at the A/H1N1 Flu Central Command Center.
The command center was set up by the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) Tuesday in a bid to prevent a possible swine flu outbreak in Taiwan, as the virus continues to spread around the world.
Liu stressed that the country has enough reserves of medical supplies to fight a potential swine flu pandemic, but he warned individuals against attempting to hoard supplies.
"The administration will not be lenient toward those who hoard or seize the opportunity to make a fortune," he noted.
Meanwhile, Department of Health Minister Yeh Ching-chuan said that one-eighth of the swine flu is not detectable.
He said that during the eight-day period of contagion of swine flu, the virus is not detectable in one of the eight days, meaning that one-eighth of the virus cannot be monitored.
Since only seven-eighths of the virus can be detected, Yeh called for full cooperation from the public to ensure adequate monitoring of any possible swine flu epidemic in Taiwan.

Yeh, convened the emergency meeting of the A/H1N1 Flu Central Command Center after the World Health Organization (WHO) raised its influenza pandemic alert for swine flu to phase 5, from phase 4, earlier in the day, indicating that there is sustained human-to-human transmission of the virus.
As of Thursday, 148 cases of swine flu infection have been reported in nine countries in the world, according to Yeh.
Nine suspected cases were reported in Taiwan over the past two days, with five of them having been ruled out as swine flu and four others still being checked.
The virus so far is known to only spread from human to human, not animal to human. Victims suffer flu-like symptoms, including fever and coughing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei wins 'Judges' Prize' at int'l flower fair in South Korea

TEXT.P: Taiwan-grown butterfly and Oncidium orchids presented by the Taipei City government took first place in the Judges' Prize at an international flower exhibition being held in South Korea, a city government said Thursday.

Taipei City is one of 121 exhibitors from 21 countries in Asia, Europe and the Americas, which competed for the prize in the Korea Floritopia 2009, according to Chen Hsiung-wen, head of the city government's Department of Economic Development.

The city saw the exhibition, which opened on April 23 in South Chungcheong Province, as a warm-up to its 2010 Taipei International Gardening and Horticulture Exposition, which will be held in Taipei next year, Chen said.

In the Korea fair, the 36-square-meter Taipei booth, which focuses on promoting Taipei's upcoming horticulture expo, is displaying a wide array of unique flower species from Taiwan, including the butterfly orchid, Oncidium orchid, flamingo flower, peace lily, and Pleomele.
These are all high-priced species in South Korea and have been under the media spotlight since they made their presence at the fair, Chen added.

The 2010 Taipei exhibition and the ongoing Korean fair are two of the biggest flower shows in the world. Both are International Association of Horticultural Producers (AIPH) -certified expositions, Chen noted.

Taipei will also participate in the 10th Floralies Flower Show slated to take place in Nantes, France from May 8-19, and the Hamamatsu International Mosaiculture 2009 in Hamamatsu City, Japan from Sept 19- Nov.23, according to Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bitou-Longdong geopark to be inaugurated May 2

TEXT.P: As soft and warm breezes herald the approach of summer, the first geographic park in Taiwan's northeast coast and Yilan area will be officially opened Saturday to public tours, a tourism official said Thursday.

Chen Mei-kang, head of the Northeast and Yilan Coast National Scenic Area Administration under the Tourism Bureau, said the opening of the "Bitou-Longdong Geopark" on May 2 is aimed at bolstering local development and promoting eco- friendly tourism to inject new life into local communities.

Chen said the geology of Taiwan's northeast region, particularly the curious and intriguing rock formations created by sea erosion over thousands of years, is amazing and impressive not only to tourists but also to international researchers.

Nanya is the northern gateway to the Northeast Coast National Scenic Area. The views from there encompass rising mountain peaks, large expanses of ocean, unique land and rock formations, serene fishing villages and quiet towns.
From Nanya, tourists can travel to Bitou and Longdong where the Bitou-Longdong Geopark, with its unique ecology and geology, will be opened to the public.

Scores of geologists from Taiwan and 11 East Asian countries will jointly preside over Saturday's opening of a "Geography Pavilion" within the park in Taipei County. The more than 40 foreign experts are in Taiwan to attend the 2009 East Asia Geopark Conference being held in Taipei.

Apart from the Bitou-Longdong Geopark, Chen said, a second geopark between Longdong and San Diego Cape and a third between Dali and the Turtle Island off Taiwan's northeastern coast, are also under protection by the Tourism Bureau.
A new tour route featuring nearby coastal and mountain areas will be unveiled May 2 on the same occasion to attract more tourists to the region, Chen added.

Meanwhile, the Tourism Bureau said it is planning to apply by 2010 to list the Yehliu Geopark, in northern Taipei County's Wanli Village, as part of UNESCO's Global Geoparks Network, and thus step up Taiwan's exchanges with the international community.

Yehliu is a 1.7-kilometer-long cape that juts into the sea, and where wave erosion, weathering, and the action of the earth's crust have combined to create sea-eroded trenches, candlestick rocks, mushroom rocks, bean curd rocks, beehive rocks, potholes, dissolved basins, and all sorts of other unusual rock formations.
Queen's Head Rock, Fairy Shoe, and Candlestick Rock are among those most spectacular and famous formations in Yehliu.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.K. language school CES opens its first overseas branch in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Britains private English-learning school Center of English Studies (CES) on Thursday opened its first branch outside England and Ireland in Taipei, aiming to help Taiwanese students improve their English skills so they can get into schools abroad.

The branch was opened in collaboration with the local education consultant United Kingdom Education Advisory Service (UKEAS) , which has been working with the CES in sending Taiwanese students to study at CES schools in England and Ireland.

The Taipei CES School will offer specialized training for students who plan to take the U.K. English proficiency tests for foreign students - IELTS. Scoring high on the test is necessary if students want to study in the U.K. The School will also provide learning and consultancy services on British education to Taiwanese students.

Justin Quinn, managing director of CES, said at an opening ceremony that he believed the Taipei CES School will provide the same high level of standards and commitment to quality in English language learning, as it has done in England and Ireland over the past 30 years.

The new school has been fitted out with highest quality facilities to provide an excellent learning environment. We employ excellent and well qualified teachers with many years experience of teaching IELTS, " Quinn said. "We are sure the new Taipei school will uphold these standards and set a new level for quality IELTS."

David Campbell, director of the Taipei-based British Trade & Cultural Office, said at the same occasion that the opening of the first private British- Irish based language school in Taiwan showed the confidence that CES and UKEAS have in Taiwan's market potential.

"We believe that the longstanding cooperation between CES and UKEAS and this new joint venture specialist school will enjoy great success here and be of huge benefits to English language learners in Taiwan,Campbell said.
The joint venture of CES and UKEAS also serves as a good example for great partnership between Taiwan and the U.K., Campbell added.
There are currently 15,000 Taiwanese students studying in the U.K., Campbell said.

The School will help more and more Taiwanese students fulfill their dreams of studying abroad, Campbell said, adding that he hoped more students will go to the U.K. for short courses, as starting March 3 Taiwanese citizens can enjoy visa-free entry to the U.K. for maximum stays of up to six months.
Established in 1976, CES is one of the leading English language schools in Europe. It is accredited by the British Council in England.
The UKEAS, established in 1993, offers free services to Taiwanese students on studying in the U.K.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices post biggest single-day gains on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices surged 6.74 percent Thursday, marking the biggest single- day rise this year and the eighth biggest ever, on optimism that the new government will soon announce measures to boost investment and relax controls on economic links with China, market analysts noted.

The TAIEX advanced 378.51 points to close at 5,992.57, following the invitation to Taiwan to attend this year's World Health Assembly as an observer, a sign of Taiwan's rapidly warming ties with China.

Buoyed by media reports that Taiwan will open its stock and futures markets to qualified direct institutional investors (QDIIs) from China beginning next week at the earliest, the local bourse opened sharply higher at 5,964.03 and rose to 5,995.12 at one stage before moving down to 5,932.03.
A total of 5.62 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$136.88 billion (US$ 4.12 billion).

All the eight major stock categories gained more than 6.7 percent, with cement stocks and paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 6.9 percent. Banking and financial shares and construction stocks surged 6.8 percent. Textile stocks, machinery and electronics shares, foodstuff issues, and plastics and chemicals issues all rose 6.7 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 2,090 to 277, with 24 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$32.99 billion.

Analysts believe that as the TAIEX Index futures rose by the maximum allowable 7 percent to 6,015 Thursday on bullish sentiments, the TAIEX could break the 6,000-point threshold to reach 6,071 in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHA participation will not harm Taiwan's sovereign status: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday that Taiwan's success in obtaining the right to attend this year's World Health Assembly (WHA) has not been achieved at the expense of the country's sovereign status.
Instead, the achievement has been the result of a pragmatic and flexible approach adopted by his administration to promote Taiwan's international presence, Ma stressed.

As an observer at the annual meeting of the World Health Organization's (WHO) decision-making body, Taiwan will enjoy the same rights and will have the same obligations as other WHA observers, he said.
WHA observers are different from full members only in that they do not have voting rights.
"We will be participating under these conditions, and the name used will be 'Chinese Taipei, ' which involves nothing that would downgrade our sovereign status," Ma said at a news conference.

He pointed out that Taiwan is known simply as "Chinese Taipei" in the World Trade Organization, although the country's membership name is "the Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu."
Taiwan also used the name "Chinese Taipei" to join the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum (APEC) in 1991, Ma noted.

After 12 failed attempts since 1997 to participate in the WHA, Taiwan received a letter from the WHO Tuesday inviting it to take part as an observer in the next WHA that is scheduled to open May 18 in Geneva.

The invitation opens the way for Taiwan to participate for the first time in any meeting or activity of the United Nations specialized agencies since the country lost its U.N. membership to China in 1971.

The former ruling pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), however, has expressed fears Taiwan is being invited to attend the WHA as an non- governmental organization or an associate of China, rather than a sovereign state.

Ma explained that over the past year since his inauguration, his administration has been promoting a "modus vivendi" diplomatic strategy that favors a moderate and pragmatic approach, with the goal of ending the cutthroat struggle between Taiwan and China in the international arena.

Such a strategy has resulted in improved cross-Taiwan Strait relations and enhanced mutual trust and understanding, which in turn has prompted Beijing to take a pragmatic and amicable view of Taiwan's bid to participate in the WHA, Ma said.
"This shows that harmonious and amiable cross-strait relations complement rather than conflict with Taiwan's goal of international participation," he said.

Expressing disapproval of the aggressive strategy adopted by the former DPP administration to highlight the status of Taiwan as an independent country, the president stressed that the purpose of Taiwan's participation in the WHA is to better protect the health of the people in Taiwan, which "should not involve any unnecessary confrontation to highlight some specific ideology."

At a time when the world is facing a possible swine flu outbreak, Taiwan's WHA participation will help the government establish closer contact with the WHO and improve its preparations for emergencies, he said.

Asked about the government's strategy to push for Taiwan's participation in the United Nations this year, Ma said his administration will continue to follow a pragmatic and flexible approach in promoting Taiwan's participation in international organizations and will not set any "impractical objectives."

Taiwan has not been represented in the United Nations since 1971, when the Republic of China's seat was given to the People's Republic of China. Since 1993, Taiwan has been trying to have the United Nations consider the issue of its representation, but these efforts have proved futile due largely to China's objections.

In a departure from the then DPP administration's high-profile push in 2007 for U.N. membership under the name "Taiwan, " Ma's government adopted a "modus vivendi" diplomatic strategy in 2008, which included seeking "meaningful participation" in the activities of the U.N.'s specialized agencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down sharply on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, falling NT$0.425 to close at NT$33.233, the weakest in two weeks.
A total of US$3.84 billion changed hands during the day's trading, the highest volume in a session this year.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$33.658 before dropping to the day's low of NT$33.057.

Market analysts attributed the big drop and high volume mainly to the influx of foreign funds for local investments and exporters' demand for local currency for cash needs at home at the end of the month.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two Chinese tourists injured by falling rocks in Hualien

TEXT.P: Two female Chinese tourists were injured by falling rocks Thursday while touring the Taroko National Park in eastern Taiwan's Hualien County, according to medical sources.
The women, identified as Shih Jinhong, 56, and Shu Yuying, 57, were rushed to the Buddhist Tzu Chi General Hospital in Hualien City for emergency treatment.
According to a hospital spokesman, both women sustained serious injuries to their heads and were undergoing surgery as of press time.
Shih was in a coma when she arrived at the hospital, the spokesman said, adding that she was struck on the head by falling rocks, which fractured her skull and caused intracranial bleeding.
Chu also sustained skull fractures and had a 20-cm laceration on the left side of her face, the spokesman said.

Travel sources said the women were members of a tour group from China's southeastern coastal city of Fuzhou. The group arrived in Taiwan earlier this week, traveling from Fuzhou to the Taiwan-held island of Kinmen via what is commonly known as the "mini three links."

Members of the group were walking along the Jiucyudong Trail, also known as the Tunnel of Nine Turns, one of the most popular sightseeing spots in the Taroko National Park, when they were struck by rocks that fell down the steep side of the mountain.

The injuries were the second travel accident involving Chinese tourists reported in less than a week. Last Friday, a crane that fell from a construction site at Taipei's upscale Xinyi shopping district left three Chinese tourists dead and three others injured.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA expresses thanks for responses to Taiwan's WHA admission

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that it is grateful to the countries that have responded positively to Taiwan's acceptance into this year's World Health Assembly (WHA) in May.
"We welcome the responses by those countries that have said they will be pleased to see Taiwan attend this year's WHA as an observer, and we thank them," said MOFA spokesman Henry Chen.

Noting that the United States, the United Kingdom, Japan and Singapore have all responded positively to the WHA arrangement for Taiwan, Chen said the foreign ministry's representative offices in those countries will also thank the individual governments.
Taiwan received an invitation from the World Health Organization (WHO) Tuesday night to take part as an observer in the upcoming WHA scheduled for May 18-27 in Geneva.
It will be the first time Taiwan will be allowed to participate in the WHA after 12 failed attempts since 1997 to be seated in the WHO's highest decision-making body.

It will also mark the first time that the country has been allowed to take part in a meeting or activity of a United Nations specialized agency since 1971 when the country lost its U.N. membership to the China.

Singapore's foreign ministry issued a statement April 29, saying that the city state welcomes the agreement for Taiwan to participate in this year's WHA meeting as an observer under the name of Chinese Taipei.

"This is a positive development which demonstrates the determination of both sides (of the Taiwan Strait) to set aside differences in order to cooperate in mutually beneficial areas. This is in the interest of the global community," it said.

British Foreign Office Minister Bill Rammell also expressed similar views on his ministry's Web site April 29, saying that the U.K. welcomes the news and hopes that both sides of the Taiwan Strait will continue to engage in direct dialogue to resolve differences and strengthen cross-strait stability.

"It is important that Taiwan can meaningfully participate in the global health safety net. The fact that the rapid spread of diseases is again high in the news emphasizes the importance of this decision," Rammell said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Job seekers favor Taiwan's telecoms firm in wake of economic crunch

TEXT.P: Taiwan's partially state-owned Chunghwa Telecom company has emerged as the favorite place to find a job by the island's fresh job seekers, as the global economic downturn is making job security their top demand.

Cheers monthly magazine in its latest poll found that Chunghwa Telecom has for the first time become the most coveted company by fresh graduates of university or postgraduate schools in Taiwan among 100 top choices for employment.

Under the impact of the global economic crisis, the rankings of high-tech and financial services companies -- which used to be top choices -- have all slid in the 100 most coveted enterprises rankings, according to Cheers.
Chunghwa Telecom has edged out Taiwan's top electronics maker Hon Hai Precision Instrument, which was Taiwan new job seekers' top choice in 2008.
This year, their top five choices were Chunghwa Telecom, the food company Uni- President Group, Eslite Bookstore, China Steel Corp., and Hon Hai, in that order, according to Cheers.
Of this year's top 20 choices, only four were high-tech companies.

Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC) , once the most coveted enterprise in Taiwan by young job seekers, fell in ranking beyond the top 10 this year, while AU Optronics, which used to rank high on the "top 100" list, fell beyond 30.
The Cheers poll found that over 40 percent of the fresh job seekers favor seeking a career as a civil servant or at a state-run enterprise.

Over half of these people said they want to work at a government agency or state-run enterprise because wages and benefits there are seen as better and more secure than at private companies, according to Cheers.

Meanwhile, graduates of National Taiwan University (NTU) were considered by private enterprises as the best choice in terms of overall job performance, according to a survey conducted jointly by 104 Job Bank, Taiwan's largest online employment service provider, and the Global Views (GV) Survey Research Center.

Graduates of National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) , meanwhile, were named as top hiring choices for local businesses, in terms of performances as new workers, professional quality and alumni influence, according to the 104-GV poll.

The poll also found that 60.6 percent of the companies surveyed said they will recruit fresh graduates as employees this year, but 51.7 percent of them said their recruiting standards will be tougher.

The candidates' ability to withstand stress is considered by the businesses as a quality or criterion they value most in hiring fresh graduates, with 53.5 percent of the businesses identifying it as such.

Some 47.5 percent of the businesses mentioned professional knowledge and skills as a desired quality in job applicants, 46.3 percent mentioned self-motivation, 45.7 percent said a sense of responsibility, and 40.1 percent said flexible learning ability.

A total of 851 valid samples were collected in the 104-GV poll conducted from March 23-31. The survey was given to the human resources personnel of Taiwan- based companies which are 104 Job Bank's members. The poll has a margin of error of plus or minus 3.36 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung MRT deficit expected to be reduced

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Mass Rapid Transit System is expected to cut its operating losses this year by NT$900 million (US$27.08 million), a city official said Thursday.

Chou Teh-li, acting director of the city's Kaohsiung City Rapid Transit Department, forecast that the system is likely to slash spending in 2009 thanks to a retrenchment plan that the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) implemented in 2008 after the launch of its Red Line in March that same year.

The MRT system consists of the Red Line, which is 28.3-km long, has 23 stations and runs from Kaohsiung's Siaogang district to Chiaotou in neighboring Kaohsiung County, and the Orange Line, which began running in August 2008 and is 14.4-km long with 15 stations running from Sizihwan in western Kaohsiung to Daliao township in Kaohsiung County.
Chou expressed concern that the KRTC might encounter difficulties if operational losses continue to expand.

The Kaohsiung city government, meanwhile, has been mulling the possibility of adopting possible countermeasures in the hope of tackling the looming crisis to secure the system's continued operations in the largest city in southern Taiwan, he added.
KRTC General Manager Yen Pang-chieh said the company needs some NT$4.5 billion to maintain its operations each year and is trying hard to run peripheral businesses to help offset the system's losses.
According to the KRTC, the MRT registered a loss of NT$2.2 billion for 2008.
Experts have estimated that the MRT needs to attract at least 400,000 passengers per day to break even and contended that it might take six to eight years for that to happen.

Speaking at a seminar on the issue sponsored by a Kaohsiung city councilor later that same day, Lee Liang-chien, secretary-general of I-Shou University in Kaohsiung County, ascribed the system's red ink to its low passenger load -- averaging just 110,000 passengers per day over the past year, well short of the original daily target of 200,000 passengers.
Lee called for stimulus measures from the city government to increase the passenger load.
In addition, Lee continued, mounting expenditure in interest on loans and high spending for phasing out equipment also put dents into the system's operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Three nabbed for producing semi-finished amphetamine

TEXT.P: Three people were nabbed in two separate police actions reported Thursday for producing semi-finished material that would have been processed into illegal amphetamine, law enforcement sources said that day.

Agents with the Bureau of Investigation's Central Taiwan operations raided a house in Taichung County's Taiping City, catching two men red-handed and seizing 7.8 kg of ephedrine -- a precursor chemical used in the production of amphetamine.
According to an initial investigation, the men had bought some 500,000 flu pills that they refined to obtain the ephedrine.

If the ephedrine had been sold to downstream underground drug makers, it would have fetched some NT$2 million (US$60,000), said Lee Hua-chun, a secretary at the Bureau of Investigation's Central Taiwan office.

Lee said that because the acquisition of raw materials for the production of amphetamine -- mostly from China -- has become increasingly difficult, Taiwanese drug rings have begun to use flu medicine to process into ephedrine as a substitute.
Also that day, police in the northern city of Keelung announced that they had nabbed a man surnamed Chin in Taipei City for ephedrine processing the previous day.

The Keelung police said they busted an amphetamine processing plant in Keelung operated by a woman surnamed Huang in March and from that case, discovered that Chin had been Huang's supplier. They raided Chin's Taipei home Wednesday, where they seized 2.1 kg of ephedrine and equipment for producing the chemical.

DOC.HEADLINE: 190 Taiwanese citizens still serving prison terms in Korea: MOFA

TEXT.P: There are still 190 Taiwanese citizens serving prison terms in South Korea after participating in fraud rings in that country, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday.

MOFA officials said that since September 2006, a total of 321 people from Taiwan have been arrested by South Korean police for allegedly opening dummy bank accounts, receiving suspicious funds from banks or using fake credit cards for purchases made in that country.
To date, 190 of them are still doing time in Korean jails, the officials said.

Last month, a Korean university student killed herself after she was conned out of her tuition by a fraud ring -- a case that aroused international attention and prompted the Korean police to crack down on cross-border fraud ring operations, as well as seeking tougher penalties for people convicted of such crimes, the officials went on.

The MOFA has issued a series of press releases since the beginning of 2007 urging the Taiwanese public to remain alert and guard against the possibility of being "unwittingly" set up as the front for an illegal company, group or individual based in South Korea, the officials said.
They reminded the public once again Thursday not to seek employment with fly- by-night companies or individuals seeking frontmen for unlawful activities in South Korea.
They pointed out that the perpetrators' greed has not only caused big trouble for themselves and their families, but has also left Taiwan's international image severely tarnished.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taroko Gorge falling rock reporting mechanism in pipeline

TEXT.P: The Tourism Bureau plans to collaborate with the Taroko National Park Administration in setting up a mechanism to report rockfalls in Taroko Gorge to better protect the safety of tourists, a bureau official said Thursday.
The official issued the statement after two Chinese tourists were injured by falling rocks earlier in the day while touring the Taroko National Park in eastern Taiwan's Hualien County.

The women, identified as Shih Jinhong, 56, and Chu Yuying, 57, were rushed to the Buddhist Tzu Chi General Hospital in Hualien City for emergency treatment and surgery for fractured skulls, intracranial bleeding and lacerations.
A later report from the Tourism Bureau, however, said that one of the two had sustained less serious injuries than had been previously reported.

According to the Tourism Bureau official, both were members of a tour group from Putien in China's southeastern coastal province of Fujian. The 12-member group, led by a tour guide, arrived in Taiwan April 25 and was originally scheduled to leave Taiwan this weekend.

Travel sources said members of the group were walking along the Jiucyudong Trail, also known as the Tunnel of Nine Turns, one of the most popular sightseeing spots in the park, when they were struck by falling rocks from the mountain above.

The injuries were the second accidents involving Chinese tourists reported in less than a week. On April 24, a crane fell onto a moving tour bus from a construction site in Taipei's upscale Xinyi shopping district, killing three Chinese tourists and injuring three others.

DOC.HEADLINE: Huge funds to be invested in health care industry upgrading

TEXT.P: The government will invest NT$86.4 billion (US$2.59 billion) over the next four years to upgrade the health care industry, Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yeh Ching-chuan said Thursday.
Yeh made the announcement at a news conference held after a weekly Executive Yuan meeting in which the four-year investment project was approved.

According to Yeh, the investment project is aimed at raising the the health care industry's production value by an estimated NT$346.4 billion by 2012 and creating an additional 310,000 jobs during the four-year period.

Noting that health care services are one of six emerging industries that the government is promoting, Yeh said the government move is not aimed at boosting the gross domestic product but rather at enhancing the people's well-being and benefiting society.

The new investment project will cover three categories -- medical care and long- term care in the service category; health care, intelligent medicine, medical service globalization and public health and safety in the category of value- added industries; and biotechnology development in the manufacturing category, Yeh explained.

The most noteworthy feature of the package lies in the development of intelligent medicine, Yeh said, adding that Taiwan, given its competitive edge in the information technology industry, stands a good chance of success in this field.

Under the new investment project, the government plans to spend NT$1.4 billion on digitizing medical examination reports, anamnesis and medical imaging within five years, establishing an image exchange and sharing center in two years and issuing second-generation smart health insurance cards.

Relevant databanks from those system can also be further used in remote medical monitoring and wireless medical telemetry services, Yeh went on, adding that the project is also expected to boost the annual production value of the RFID technology-related industry from NT$20.73 billion in 2009 to NT$129.3 billion in 2012.

On the long-term care system, Yeh continued, the launch of such a system will account for nearly half of the new investment budget. He added that Premier Liu Chao-shiuan has also instructed that the originally scheduled 10-year development period be shortened.

In addition, the Council for Economic Planning and Development will work out a comprehensive plan for the gradual launch of a long-term care insurance system, beginning probably in specified regions or for specific age groups.

On the globalization of medical services, Yeh said his department will pool its resources with other relevant government agencies in promoting medical tourism to attract foreign patients seeking bone marrow transplants, joint replacements, health checkups, tooth implants and other medical treatment.
"The government is planning to invest NT$1.7 billion in this regard, with the goal of seeing medical tourists accounting for 10 percent of the total tourist arrivals," he added.

On health care, Yeh said, the government will inspire market demand by subsidizing preventive health care services and encouraging private investment in the field, with the goal of seeing the market value of health care services and health food industry reaching NT$189.5 billion by 2012 and revenues of health checkups amounting to NT$11.4 billion.
Meanwhile, Yeh said, the government will also induce the private sector to join investment in development and production of flu vaccines, serum-vaccines and selected pharmaceuticals.
